summary: Lloyds Banking Group's profit was wiped out by a £2.4 billion charge for bad loans due to the coronavirus pandemic. The bank now expects to set aside £4.5-5.5 billion this year to cover economic fallout, citing a spike in unemployment to 12.5% and a contraction in the economy of 17.2%. The charge was £1 billion above analyst forecasts, leading to a statutory pretax loss of £676 million for the second quarter. Lloyds' shares fell 9.3% in London, with the bank's chief executive warning that the outlook is "very disappointing".

site_title: Samsung expects smartphone demand to drive second-half earnings
summary: Samsung Electronics expects a global recovery in smartphone demand to drive profits in the second half of the year, fueled by a coronavirus-propelled shift to online working. The company posted a 23% jump in operating profit in the April-June quarter, driven by strong DRAM memory chip sales and cuts in marketing costs. Samsung expects server demand for chips to remain solid and a boost in smartphone demand, despite ongoing risks from the pandemic and trade disputes. The company plans to unveil new flagship smartphones and expand mid-tier sales.

images.alt_text: Samsung plans to unveil new flagship smartphones, including the Galaxy Note and a foldable phone in H2.

site_title: Singapore bank lending continues to slide in June
summary: Singapore bank lending declined for the fourth consecutive month in June, falling 0.7% to S$680.36 billion, with business loans and consumer loans both experiencing declines. On a year-on-year basis, total loans fell 1% for the first time since 2016. The transport, storage and communication segment saw the biggest plunge, while industries like manufacturing and building and construction saw upticks in loans. Consumer loans, particularly share financing and car loans, also declined, while credit cards and unsecured personal loans ticked up.

site_title: RTS Link to boost Singapore-Johor investments
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Malaysian counterpart Muhyiddin Yassin have marked the resumption of the Johor Bahru-Singapore Rapid Transit System (RTS) Link project, a cross-border train service expected to ease congestion on the Causeway and boost business links between the two cities. The project, which began in 2010, is now set to be operational by end-2026. Business leaders and economists welcome the agreement, citing increased mobility for the workforce, which will lead to increased investments and economic growth. The RTS Link is expected to benefit both countries, with reduced travel times and increased economic opportunities.

site_title: Chinese VCs sanguine on Asean despite Covid-19 and geopolitical headwinds
summary: Chinese venture capitalists remain optimistic about investing in Southeast Asia despite the COVID-19 pandemic and global economic headwinds. Long-term interest in the region remains robust, driven by accelerated digital adoption and the potential for synergies between Chinese and Southeast Asian businesses. Despite a slowdown in VC deal value, firms such as Qiming Venture Partners and 01vc continue to hunt for deals in Southeast Asia, citing the region's growing consumer internet market and potential for innovation.

site_title: Exxon prepares spending, job cuts in last ditch move to save dividend
summary: ExxonMobil is preparing deep spending and job cuts to preserve its 8% shareholder dividend, amid a projected $2.63 billion second-quarter loss due to sharply lower oil prices and weaker production. The company, the largest US oil company, has already slashed its budget by 30% and borrowed $18 billion to bolster cash. Analysts warn that Exxon may need to cut its dividend or face financial jeopardy, with rival Chevron successfully covering its payout through operations.

site_title: Switzerland posts its first Defence Attaché to Singapore
summary: Switzerland has posted its first Defence Attaché to Singapore, Colonel Hans Eberhart, as part of its growing strategic importance in Southeast Asia. This move aims to enhance dialogue on military doctrine and cyber defence, and to better understand security and technological developments in the region. The attaché will focus on two main areas: enhancing dialogue on military doctrine and cyber defence, and using Singapore as an information hub for understanding security and technological developments in Asia.

site_title: Trump suggests delay in presidential election over coronavirus fears
summary: US President Donald Trump suggested delaying the 2020 presidential election due to coronavirus fears and concerns over "fraudulent" mail-in voting. In a tweet, Trump stated that the election would be the "most INACCURATE & FRAUDULENT Election in history." The proposal comes as Trump lags in the polls.

site_title: Germany's economic slump previews Europe's challenge
summary: Germany's economy shrank 10.1% in the second quarter, the largest decline in at least half a century, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. This slump is expected to worsen across Europe, with Spain, France, and Italy likely to report deeper contractions. The European Union has implemented a 130 billion euro stimulus package, but the recovery is uncertain due to job losses and concerns about a COVID-19 resurgence. Bloomberg economist Jamie Rush estimates the recovery will be limited to 3-6% compared to pre-crisis norms, with weak external demand and social distancing rules a major factor.

site_title: Husband and wife team up for job sharing
summary: A husband and wife team, Barbara and Nikolas Gonzenbach, are sharing a job as Deputy Head of Mission at the Embassy of Switzerland in Singapore. This unique arrangement is inspired by the Swiss foreign ministry's progressive policy on job sharing by couples. The couple has a well-defined division of work, with Barbara focusing on finance, communications, security, and culture, and Nikolas covering business relations, science, diplomacy, and legal affairs. They enjoy the benefits of job sharing, including more family time, professional satisfaction, and flexibility. Their arrangement has been well-received by their colleagues and Ambassador Filliez, and they highly recommend it to others.

site_title: Swiss central bank's only overseas branch office is in Singapore
summary: The Swiss National Bank's (SNB) first and only overseas branch office is located in Singapore, established in 2013 to manage its foreign currency reserves in the Asia-Pacific region. The branch, with nine staff, oversees the SNB's $1.2 trillion currency reserves, including $1.1 billion in Asian-Pacific bonds and stocks. The SNB uses Singapore's location to implement monetary policy in the foreign exchange market during Asian trading hours and to gather market intelligence. The branch is also involved in digital transformation and digital currencies, with Singapore serving as a regional hub.

site_title: Sushi that gives you bang for your buck
summary: Sushi Kenji, a no-frills restaurant in Singapore, offers dependable and affordable sushi in a cozy atmosphere. Chef Kenji Nakagawa, a skilled acclimatised sushi chef, serves a variety of dishes, including sashimi, omakase, and sushi, with a focus on good pricing and authenticity. The restaurant's modest surroundings belie its quality offerings, which include medium-fat chutoro, hotate, and amaebi sashimi, and a platter of sushi with crunchy tsubugai and prawn. With a rating of 6.5, Sushi Kenji is a good option for those seeking a mid-quality but acceptable meal at an affordable price.

images.alt_text: Platter of sashimi - medium fat chutoro, hotate (scallop), amaebi (shrimp), kombu-marinated tai (sea bream) and shima aji (horse mackerel).
Kenji Nakagawa: chef, dishwasher, cashier and tea-maker all rolled into one.
A little bowl of cold, shimmery, slippery Japanese mushrooms with scant threads of dried chilli for decoration and a fitting kick of spice.
A little bowl of rice topped with a generous serving of clean, fresh-tasting uni and a mega load of salmon roe.
A surprising mongoika or cuttlefish sushi which is a firmer, crunchier version of regular sumi ika.

site_title: US civil unrest reinforces sense of chaos and insecurity
summary: US civil unrest has heightened feelings of chaos and insecurity, with many blaming the White House for the issues. This sentiment is reminiscent of the 1950s and 1960s civil rights protests, where activists like John Lewis faced violence and racism. Lewis, a prominent civil rights leader, passed away recently, with an honour guard placing his coffin in the Capitol Rotunda. The timing of his death has reignited concerns about the state of the US, echoing the tumultuous era of his lifetime.

site_title: SIA takes further action to cut costs, including early retirement scheme
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has implemented cost-cutting measures, including a 10% salary reduction for staff below manager level and a 35% cut to CEO Goh Choon Phong's salary. The airline will also offer a Covid-19 special early retirement scheme (SERS) for eligible staff. The measures come as the airline posts a record quarterly loss, with analysts predicting further cost-saving measures. Not all staff unions are on board, with the Air Line Pilots Association, Singapore (Alpa-S) expressing dissatisfaction with the SERS and pay cuts.

images.alt_text: Newly appointed Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung says reviving Singapore's aviation sector is the Government's top priority.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hi-P International's net profit for H1 FY2020 fell 3.3% to S$24.2 million due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, with revenue decreasing 5.1% to S$543.8 million. The company's gross profit fell 10.1% to S$68.4 million, and gross profit margin contracted to 12.6%. Uni-Asia Group, a cargo ship and real estate investor, expects a net loss for H1 due to Covid-19's impact on its business.

site_title: Sias doesn't endorse any Hyflux rescue deal; urges Utico to address concerns
summary: Sias, the Securities Investors Association of Singapore, will not endorse the proposed S$485 million cash-and-stock rescue package for Hyflux by Utico, a Middle Eastern utility firm. The rescue deal aims to save Hyflux from judicial management and provide the highest possible recovery for Hyflux's perpetual and preference share (PnP) holders. However, Sias has not been satisfied with Utico's response to its concerns, including the removal of an upfront payment option for small PnP holders. Sias urges Utico to address these concerns before the restructuring proposal can proceed.

site_title: Is US interest in 5G really about 5G?
summary: The US interest in 5G is being questioned, with some arguing that the country is more concerned with sending a signal rather than owning a piece of the telecom infrastructure market. Despite 5G's potential to turbocharge consumer broadband and vertical markets, the US' focus on 5G is dwarfed by the combined revenue of its big five Internet behemoths, which could reach nearly $2.5 trillion by 2026. The US' attack on 5G is seen as an attempt to send a warning to the world that it is still relevant, rather than a genuine concern about the technology's impact on the digital economy.

site_title: Shell posts massive loss of US$18.1b due to virus-hit oil market
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported a massive net loss of US$18.1 billion for the second quarter due to asset writedowns caused by the coronavirus-hit oil market. The company attributed the loss to a US$16.8 billion charge, citing revised medium- and long-term price and refining margin outlook assumptions. Shell's production dropped 6% to 3.4 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, and the company forecasts further declines in the third quarter. CEO Ben van Beurden indicated that job cuts are possible, citing the need to "resize" the workforce.

site_title: Covid-19 slashes US GDP by 33% in second quarter, outlook shaky
summary: The US economy contracted at its steepest pace since the Great Depression in the second quarter, with a 32.9% annualized decline in GDP. The Covid-19 pandemic led to a collapse in consumer and business spending, threatening a nascent recovery. The decline is the deepest since the Commerce Department started keeping records in 1947. A resurgence in new coronavirus cases raises concerns about the economic outlook.

site_title: Gold prices have soared to all-time highs despite a demand paradox
summary: Gold prices have reached all-time highs of nearly $2,000 despite a decline in Asian consumption and an increase in investment and speculative demand in the West, particularly in the US and Europe. Consumption in China and India, the world's largest gold consumers, has slumped by 48% and 55% respectively. In contrast, investment in gold exchange-traded funds has soared, with holdings exceeding those of the International Monetary Fund and several central banks. This shift has raised price volatility and is expected to continue, with some traders predicting a potential setback or further price increases.

site_title: John Lewis looks to homes and gardens to revive profits
summary: The John Lewis Partnership plans to diversify beyond retail to survive the high street turmoil, aiming to expand into financial services, gardening, housing, and rental options. The company hopes to revive profits over the next three to five years. As part of the plan, it will become a 60% online retailer, grow its financial services arm, and explore partnerships in horticulture and affordable housing. The move aims to make the Partnership sustainable in the long-term, as retail profit margins are under pressure.

site_title: Clash of China tech titans
summary: Chinese tech giants are increasing investments in South-east Asia, driven by global trade tensions and the region's rapidly digitalizing population. The companies are competing in sectors such as streaming, fintech, and e-commerce. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the tech wars are intensifying, with major players vying for market share. The competition is expected to continue, with a focus on engaging with consumers and establishing a strong presence in the region.

site_title: Gold steadies after 9-day rally as Fed flags risk from virus
summary: Gold prices paused after a 9-day rally to a record, as investors weighed the Federal Reserve's comments on the economic recovery amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Fed left interest rates near zero and vowed to use all tools to drive the recovery, but sounded a dour tone, noting more fallout from the outbreak still lies ahead. Gold has surged 30% to a record this year, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a surge to $2,300 an ounce, and spot gold trading at $1,964.79 an ounce.

site_title: Bilateral cooperation in multiple ways
summary: Switzerland and Singapore have maintained strong bilateral ties despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with cooperation in multilateral forums and various initiatives. The two countries have successfully collaborated on global issues, including vaccine multilateralism through the "Friends of Covax Facility." They have also strengthened economic ties, with Switzerland being Singapore's most important trading partner in Southeast Asia. Additionally, Singapore has elected a Swiss national, Daren Tang, as the new director general of the World Intellectual Property Organization. The Swiss Embassy in Singapore continues to operate, providing assistance to Swiss nationals and promoting bilateral cooperation.

site_title: ESR-Reit's buyout offer for Sabana Reit unit holders 'too low', draws criticism
summary: ESR-Reit has proposed a buyout offer for Sabana Reit unit holders, valuing each unit at S$0.377, a 26% discount to Sabana Reit's book value. Activist fund Quarz Capital Management has criticized the offer as too low, citing a history of no mergers in the Singapore-listed Reit market acquiring targets at such a steep discount. Quarz has raised its stake in Sabana Reit to 5% and urged unit holders to do their research before making a decision. The proposed merger will be put to a vote at an extraordinary general meeting in October, with a majority of unit holders required to approve the scheme.

site_title: Grim business outlook extends to year-end: surveys
summary: Singapore businesses face a bumpy and uneven outlook for the next half-year, with sentiment slightly improving from three months ago despite the end of the circuit breaker. Official quarterly surveys show that domestic firms remain cautious and pessimistic about their business prospects, with a net weighted balance of 7% expecting business conditions to worsen. The services sector remains very negative, with a net weighted balance of -31%, while tourism-reliant industries such as accommodation and retail expect double-digit negative net balances. Manufacturers are more optimistic, but still expect business conditions to worsen, with a 6% net weighted balance forecasting a decline in factory output.

site_title: Covid weighs on two of Hong Kong's biggest retail landlords
summary: Hong Kong's two largest retail landlords, Wharf Real Estate Investment and Hang Lung Properties, reported significant losses due to the COVID-19 pandemic and anti-government protests. Wharf's six-month loss reached HK$4.45 billion, while Hang Lung's loss was HK$2.54 billion. The pandemic has exacerbated the economic downturn, with the city's economy sinking into a deep recession. Landlords face pressure to reduce rents, while the government has urged caution, citing landlords' own difficulties in covering expenses.

site_title: Swiss investments in Singapore up S$22b
summary: Switzerland's investments in Singapore have reached a record S$60.7 billion at the end of 2018, a 57% jump from the previous year, according to Singapore's statistics department. This growth is attributed to the strong business ties between Switzerland and Singapore, with Swiss companies operating in various sectors such as finance, insurance, and production. SwissCham, the Swiss chamber of commerce in Singapore, attributes the growth to Singapore's position as a hub for Southeast Asia and the Asia Pacific. The chamber also notes that Singapore's plans to upgrade its economy and workforce are attractive to Swiss companies, and it expects Singapore to remain an attractive location for Swiss businesses despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Mastercard profit drops as pandemic hits consumer spending
summary: Mastercard reported a 30% slump in quarterly profit due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with net income falling to $1.4 billion from $2 billion in the same quarter last year. The decline in consumer spending led to a decrease in spending volumes for the payment processor.

site_title: Oil down nearly 4% as virus surge weighs on demand outlook
summary: Oil prices dropped by nearly 4% on Thursday as the surge in coronavirus infections worldwide threatened to jeopardize fuel demand recovery. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell to $39.75 a barrel, while Brent crude fell to $42.41 a barrel. The decline is attributed to the devastating impact of the coronavirus on the US economy, which contracted at its steepest pace since the Great Depression in the second quarter. Opec+ is set to raise output in August, adding 1.5 million barrels per day to global supply, further testing market sentiment.

site_title: Pandemic skin and hair solutions
summary: Covid-19 has led to increased hair loss and mask-induced acne, with experts attributing it to stress and poor scalp care. Trichologist Peggy Goh recommends seeing a professional for a scalp analysis and trying treatments like the DRx Medispa's Purifying Therapy and Shiseido Professional's Sublimic Adenovital haircare range. For maskne, skincare expert Su-Mae Chia's BSKIN products, such as the Anti-Acne 3C Spot Treatment, can help reduce inflammation and prevent blemishes, with results seen within 14 days.

(Left) BSKIN Anti-Acne 3C Spot Treatment. (Right) BSKIN Intense PAF Concentrate.

site_title: Travel company TUI to shut 166 stores in UK and Ireland
summary: Travel company TUI will shut 166 stores in the UK and Ireland due to the coronavirus pandemic, with 350 stores remaining in its retail network. The move affects 900 staff, with 70% relocated to homeworking sales and services roles. TUI aims to retain other employees in remaining high street stores.

site_title: Air Line Pilots Association disagrees with SIA's cost-cutting measures
summary: Singapore Airlines' (SIA) cost-cutting measures have been met with opposition from the Air Line Pilots Association (Alpa-S), which will take the matter to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM). SIA has implemented measures such as a Covid-19 special early-retirement scheme for ground staff and pilots, and pay cuts for captains, first officers, and second officers. Alpa-S disagrees with the measures, citing the lack of consultation and inadequate information on how excess manpower will be managed. The union has arranged an audience with MOM to discuss the issue.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Airlines has implemented a 10% pay cut for all rank-and-file staff, in addition to bigger pay cuts for bosses, and early retirement for pilots and ground staff as part of cost-cutting measures.

images.alt_text: SIA has implemented more measures to slash costs, including bigger pay cuts for the bosses, a 10 per cent salary reduction for other employees, and early retirement for pilots and ground staff.

site_title: National Broadband Network is a part of Singapore's success story
summary: Singapore's National Broadband Network (NBN) has played a crucial role in the country's success story, supporting its transformation into an intelligent nation and a global city. Established in 2008, the NBN has provided nationwide broadband access at speeds exceeding 1 Gbps, enabling new economic opportunities and enhancing the vibrancy of the telecommunications sector. With over 98% household broadband adoption, the NBN has fostered a competitive broadband market, where retail-service providers compete on commercial terms. As Singapore continues on its path towards a digital economy, the NBN will remain a critical infrastructure, requiring further investment and maintenance to maintain its resilience and competitiveness.

site_title: Chinese oil giant CNPC eyes BP's US$1.5b stake in Oman gas field
summary: Chinese state-owned oil giant CNPC is in talks to acquire a 10% stake in Oman's Khazzan natural gas field from BP for approximately $1.5 billion. The minority stake is part of BP's efforts to sell a 10% stake in the project. This deal comes as China increases its presence in the Middle East under the Belt and Road initiative, with CNPC already operating in five Middle Eastern countries. No final decisions have been made, and other companies have expressed interest in the asset.

site_title: Renault gets 'wake-up call' with record 7 billion euro H1 loss
summary: Renault reported a record net loss of 7.29 billion euros (S$11.8 billion) in the first half of the year due to the Covid-19 crisis and issues with its alliance partner Nissan. The French carmaker's losses are attributed to factory shutdowns and reduced customer demand. This significant financial setback serves as a wake-up call for Renault, highlighting the challenges faced by the global automotive industry during the pandemic. The company will need to address these issues to recover and regain its footing in the market.

site_title: Diamond giant De Beers likely to cut jobs after Covid-19 hit
summary: Diamond mining giant De Beers is likely to cut jobs after the COVID-19 pandemic hit jewellery demand. The company reported plunging earnings in the first half of 2020, with underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) at just $2 million. CEO Bruce Cleaver said official consultations with workers will begin on August 11 and the process will last for three months, potentially leading to job losses. De Beers employs 20,000 people and its business transformation plan aims to boost margins by modernizing diamond sales.

site_title: Hi-P posts 3.3% dip in H1 earnings to S$24.2m
summary: Hi-P's net profit for H1 FY2020 fell 3.3% to S$24.2 million, despite a 5.1% drop in revenue to S$543.8 million due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Other income rose 61.4% and losses from associates narrowed. Gross profit fell 10.1% and gross profit margin contracted to 12.6%. The company expects higher revenue and similar profit for H2 FY2020 and FY2020 compared to H1 FY2020.

site_title: Xi calls for deeper reform to escape 'grave' economic conditions
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping called for deeper economic reforms to escape "grave" conditions, urging a push on domestic demand and foreign investment to stimulate growth. He emphasized the need for a "dual circulation" growth model, balancing domestic and foreign trade. The Politburo meeting, ahead of high-level meetings in August and October, focused on targeted policies, lower financing costs, and balanced growth to avoid asset bubbles. Xi expressed confidence in China's ability to overcome challenges and achieve a "great rejuvenation." The moves aim to stabilize the economy and set the stage for the next five-year plan.

site_title: DuPont takes US$2.5b charge, posts bigger quarterly loss
summary: DuPont reported a bigger second-quarter loss of US$2.48 billion, largely due to a non-cash impairment charge of US$2.5 billion for its automotive business. The company, however, expects a "decent" year for the auto sector in 2021 with orders picking up in mid-July. DuPont's adjusted earnings for the current quarter were marginally above analysts' estimate, driven by cost cuts and higher organic sales in its nutrition and electronics units. The company's CEO, Ed Breen, noted a gradual recovery in demand, but with a measured and uneven pace.

site_title: CNMC, Heeton guide for H1 net losses; ISOTeam for FY2020 loss
summary: CNMC Goldmine and Heeton Holdings guided for H1 FY2020 net losses due to Covid-19's impact on gold output. CNMC attributed its loss to reduced gold processing activities in Malaysia from March to May. ISOTeam also reported a FY2020 loss. The companies cited the pandemic's restrictions as the primary cause of their financial struggles.

site_title: Procter & Gamble sales surge at blistering rate
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) reported a 6% surge in organic sales in the quarter ended June 30, driven by higher at-home consumption of laundry detergent and dish soap. The company's fabric and home care unit saw a record 14% revenue lift, while family care units, including Charmin, Bounty, and Puffs, experienced double-digit growth. P&G expects organic revenue growth of 2-4% in fiscal 2021, slower than last year's 6%, but still optimistic about core earnings per share growth of 3-7%.

site_title: Quarz to Sabana Reit manager: Will you sell your personal property at a 25% discount to book?
summary: Activist fund Quarz Capital Management is questioning the proposed merger between Sabana Reit and ESR-Reit, citing an implied offer price that represents a 26% discount to Sabana Reit's book value. Quarz, which holds a 5% stake in Sabana Reit, argues that the Reit manager should sell personal properties at a 25% discount to valuation. The merger, which would value Sabana Reit units at S$0.377, is set to be put to a vote in October, with a majority of unit holders required to approve the scheme.

site_title: Bitcoin's hedge fund sharks are swimming with the whales
summary: Bitcoin's price has surged to around $11,200 after a 50% slump in mid-March, driven by a speculative frenzy and hopes of a hedge against inflation and currency crisis. Veteran crypto-watchers warn of painful consequences, citing past price swings that have undermined its case as a reliable store of value. Despite its volatility, some big-name investors, including Paul Tudor Jones and Medallion, are talking up Bitcoin as a safe haven, with 71% of fund managers now thinking equities are overvalued, according to a Bank of America survey.

site_title: More people allowed at marriage solemnisations, wakes from Aug 4 as MOH eases Covid-19 limits
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that marriage solemnizations, wakes, and funerals can now accommodate more guests, starting August 4. Up to 50 people, excluding the solemnizer and vendor staff, will be allowed at weddings, while up to 30 people can attend wakes and funerals, up from 20 and 30 respectively. The changes aim to facilitate more family members and friends paying their respects, while adhering to safe management principles based on event venue capacity.

site_title: Thai court accepts budget carrier Nok Airlines' petition for bankruptcy protection
summary: Thailand's bankruptcy court has accepted Nok Airlines' petition for bankruptcy protection, citing the worsening effects of the coronavirus pandemic on the airline industry. The court's acceptance gives Nok Airlines an automatic stay on debt worth 26 billion baht. This decision follows the bankruptcy filing of Thai Airways, which holds a 13% stake in Nok Airlines, and the liquidation of NokScoot Airlines, the airline's subsidiary. Nok Airlines has booked losses since 2014 and continues to operate despite its request for bankruptcy rehabilitation. The first day of hearings is set for October 27.

site_title: US: Wall St slips as Trump raises possibility of delaying elections
summary: US stock indexes fell on Thursday as President Donald Trump raised the possibility of delaying the November presidential election, despite it being enshrined in the US Constitution. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all opened lower, with the Dow down 172.15 points, or 0.65%, to 26,367.42. The delay possibility sparked market uncertainty, with investors weighing the potential impact on the election and its outcome.

site_title: US economy collapsed 32.9% in Q2 amid pandemic
summary: The US economy contracted at a 32.9% annualized rate in Q2, its steepest decline since the Great Depression, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This is the deepest decline in output since the government started keeping records in 1947. The previous record was a 10% decline in the second quarter of 1958. The economy had contracted at a 5.0% pace in the first quarter. A nascent recovery is under threat from a resurgence in new cases of coronavirus.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia X falls to Q1 loss on pandemic impact
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia X reported a net loss of 549.7 million ringgit (S$178.2 million) in its first quarter, a fourth straight quarterly loss due to the pandemic's impact on air travel demand. Revenue fell 21% to 924.1 million ringgit, and passengers carried dropped 25% to 1.14 million. The airline's load factor decreased 11 percentage points to 74%. Unit costs rose 16%, while unit revenue remained flat despite a 8% growth in ancillary revenue per passenger.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.7% due to concerns over the global spread of coronavirus. The Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.2% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.4%. The early gains fueled by dovish Federal Reserve comments gave way to worries about the pandemic's impact on markets.

site_title: Nestle sees growth slow amid confinement
summary: Swiss food giant Nestle reported slower growth in the second quarter, with organic sales increasing 1.3% due to lockdowns and consumer reliance on home reserves. Despite this, net profit rose 18.3% to 5.9 billion francs, driven by restructuring efforts. The company's total reported sales dropped 9.5% to 41.2 billion francs, but divestitures and foreign exchange impacts reduced the overall sales figure by 12.3%. Nestle attributed the slowdown to severe impact of movement restrictions on out-of-home businesses and consumer destocking.

site_title: Hong Kong reverses virus ban on restaurant dining
summary: Hong Kong's government has reversed a ban on restaurant dining, allowing establishments to operate dine-in facilities with restrictions, following public outcry over the ban. The ban, introduced to combat a surge in virus cases, had forced workers to eat on pavements and in public toilets. New guidelines now permit dine-in services during the day at half capacity, with no more than two people per table, and only takeaway meals in the evenings. This decision comes as the city experiences a resurgence in virus cases.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Thursday, down 7.67 points to 1,603.75. Volume reached 11.917 billion lots worth RM6.157 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 688 to 390. This marks the third consecutive day of losses for the index.

site_title: Tuan Sing posts S$6.6m H1 profit, lifted by property income, fair-value gain
summary: Singapore property developer Tuan Sing Holdings posted a net profit of S$6.6 million for the half-year ended June, reversing a S$500,000 loss from the previous year. Revenue fell 39% to S$91.9 million due to weakness in hotels and industrial segments, but was lifted by a S$3.2 million fair-value gain. Excluding the gain, the company recorded a profit before tax of S$3.8 million, up 5% from a year ago. Tuan Sing expects the pandemic to slow its hotels-investment segment but remains committed to growing its portfolio in key regional markets.

site_title: Ex-Nissan executive Kelly to stand trial from Sept 15
summary: Ex-Nissan executive Greg Kelly will stand trial on September 15 for conspiring to under-report the income of former chairman Carlos Ghosn. Kelly denies wrongdoing, while Ghosn has fled to Lebanon after being charged with financial wrongdoing. Kelly is charged with helping Ghosn hide around $85.6 million in compensation. Former Nissan chief executive Hiroto Saikawa will testify at the trial. The trial was initially set to start in April but was delayed due to the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: The trial of ex-Nissan Motor executive Greg Kelly, who is charged with conspiring to under-report the income of its former chairman Carlos Ghosn, has been scheduled to start on Sept 15, public broadcaster NHK said on Thursday.

site_title: Mars-bound: Nasa's life-seeking rover Perseverance launches
summary: NASA's Mars rover Perseverance successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, Florida, on an astrobiology mission to search for signs of ancient microbial life on Mars. The 2-ton rover, equipped with a helicopter-drone and advanced navigation systems, is expected to reach the Red Planet on February 18, 2021. Perseverance will explore the Jezero crater, a 3.5 billion-year-old impact basin, and collect samples that could potentially hold evidence of past life. The mission is the fifth rover to visit Mars, with China's rover set to arrive by May 2021, and will be followed by three active rovers, including NASA's Curiosity.

site_title: Aspial posts 63% fall in H1 net profit; no interim dividend declared
summary: Aspial Corp reported a 63% fall in H1 net profit to S$5.5 million, with revenue down 25.1% to S$234.2 million due to lower sales in its real estate and jewellery segments. The company retained cash for working capital by not declaring an interim dividend. Its financial services segment saw a 11.7% increase in revenue. Aspial expects challenging conditions to persist, citing disruptions in supply chains and retail sentiments due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: STI down 1.9% over the week on earnings declines and misses
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.9% over the week due to earnings declines and misses, closing at 2,529.82. Losers outnumbered gainers 289 to 184, with top losers including Singapore Airlines and top performer Dairy Farm International. Analysts remain positive on Dairy Farm, citing its attractive valuation and ongoing transformation. Regional markets also declined, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index falling 0.26% and 0.69%, respectively.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise again with 1.43m filed
summary: The US saw a second consecutive weekly increase in new unemployment claims, with 1.43 million filed for the week ended July 25. This follows a surge in Covid-19 cases, leading to renewed lockdown measures. The insured unemployment rate rose to 11.6%, indicating a labor market in "stall mode." Despite this, the four-week moving average declined 17.1 million, suggesting some rehiring is occurring. The total number of people receiving benefits is 30.2 million.

images.alt_text: The United States saw its second consecutive weekly increase in new claims for unemployment benefits, the Labor Department said on Thursday, with 1.43 million filed.

site_title: Credit Suisse to reorganise as profits jump
summary: Credit Suisse announced plans to reorganise operations to create a global investment bank, merging several existing units. The move aims to achieve critical scale and improve effectiveness and efficiency. The bank reported a 24% increase in quarterly profits to nearly 1.2 billion Swiss francs, driven by 11% revenue growth. Credit Suisse plans to cut 400 million Swiss francs from operating expenses by 2022. The bank will retain its focus on global wealth management and release the second part of its 2019 dividend payment if shareholders approve.

site_title: Uni-Asia expects net loss for H1 2020 due to Covid-19 impact
summary: Uni-Asia Group, a Mainboard-listed company, expects to report a net loss for the first half of 2020 due to the impact of COVID-19 on its business. The loss is attributed to disruptions in the global supply chain, decreased demand for shipping, and a decline in tourism, particularly in Japan, which contributed 55-61% of the group's total income in 2017 and 2018. The company will disclose further details in its financial results on August 14.

site_title: Singtel chairman Simon Israel steps down
summary: Singtel chairman Simon Israel has stepped down after nine years in the role, concluding his tenure at the annual general meeting. He will remain on the board but not as chairman. Israel's planned retirement was previously announced, and Temasek director Lee Theng Kiat was named chairman-designate. The telco's shareholders passed an amendment to include a scrip dividend scheme in the company constitution. Israel will continue to serve as chairman of Singapore Post and as a director of Stewardship Asia Centre CLG.

site_title: Taiwan's 'Mr Democracy' Lee Teng-hui dies aged 97
summary: Former Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui, known as "Mr Democracy," has died at 97. Lee defied China's drive to absorb Taiwan, achieving Taiwan's first democratic presidency in 1996 and promoting a "country of democracy, freedom, human rights and dignity." His actions led to a brief war scare with China, prompting the US to send a carrier task force to the area. Lee's legacy is marked by his efforts to establish a distinct Taiwanese identity and promote democracy, despite criticism from Beijing, which branded him a "splittist."

images.alt_text: Former Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui, who died on Thursday aged 97, was dubbed "Mr Democracy" for burying autocratic rule in favour of freewheeling pluralism, and thrived on defying China's drive to absorb an island it regards as a wayward province.

site_title: Jardine C&C's H1 underlying profit falls 66% to US$138m
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) reported a 66% drop in its underlying profit to US$138 million for the first half of 2020, primarily due to weaker performance in automotive, financial services, and heavy equipment and mining operations amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue fell 28% to US$6.59 billion, with the automotive group Astra being a major contributor to the decline. The company also declared an interim dividend of 9 US cents per share, half that of the previous year.

site_title: Keppel posts S$697.6m net loss for Q2 due to O&M impairments
summary: Keppel Corp posted a quarterly net loss of S$697 million, its deepest loss in two decades, due to massive impairments of S$919 million in its Offshore & Marine division. The impairments, largely related to the pandemic's impact on the global economy and oil prices, pushed the company to miss certain pre-conditions for Temasek Holdings' S$4 billion partial offer. Excluding impairments, Keppel posted a net profit of S$222 million, and the company declared an interim dividend of 3.0 cents per share.

site_title: 4 new community Covid-19 patients linked to Bukit Panjang transport hub cluster
summary: Four new community Covid-19 patients in Singapore have been linked to the Bukit Panjang transport hub cluster, bringing the total to eight cases. The new patients, including a Singaporean and three work permit holders, were asymptomatic and had likely past infections, making them no longer infectious. The Ministry of Health (MOH) has added several locations, including restaurants and a deli, to the list of places visited by infectious patients, urging close contacts to monitor their health for two weeks. Singapore reported 278 new cases on July 30, bringing the total to 51,809.

site_title: Sias says it does not endorse any Hyflux rescue deal; urges Utico to address concerns
summary: Sias, Singapore's Securities Investors Association, says it won't endorse a potential rescue deal for Hyflux proposed by Utico, a Middle Eastern utility firm, due to concerns over terms. The deal, worth S$485 million, includes an upfront payment option for smaller investors and a stock-only option for larger ones, raising concerns about fairness. Sias urges Utico to address its concerns before considering any deal. The association's role is to facilitate communication and provide information to investors, but it does not intend to endorse any offer.

site_title: Australians likely to withdraw A$42b from pensions to weather coronavirus
summary: Australians are withdrawing 56% more from their retirement savings than expected due to the coronavirus crisis, with around $42 billion expected to be withdrawn under a government scheme. One million have applied to access up to $20,000, with most using the funds to repay home loans and boost cash reserves. Industry experts warn of devastating long-term consequences, citing missed compounding returns and depleted savings. The scheme has also impacted the domestic stock market as pension funds sell assets to pay customers.

site_title: Xihe seeks to restructure business amid OCBC's JM application
summary: Xihe Group, linked to the Lim family of troubled oil trader Hin Leong, plans to restructure its business through a "consensual restructuring" with lenders, selling some vessels and downsizing its fleet. The move comes ahead of a Singapore High Court hearing on August 13, where creditor OCBC Bank seeks to bring Xihe under judicial management. Xihe claims the bank's application will disrupt constructive discussions and is actively pursuing opportunities to re-deploy some of its vessels. A new board of directors is being finalized as part of the restructuring plan.

site_title: SIA cuts all rank-and-file staff's pay by 10%, in talks with unions on more measures
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has implemented a 10% pay cut for rank-and-file staff, while executives will face larger reductions. The airline aims to slash costs amid a first-quarter operating loss. The company will also offer a Covid-19 special early retirement scheme for ground staff and pilots. SIA's CEO, Goh Choon Phong, will see a 35% salary reduction. The airline expects a "long and hard Covid-19 induced winter" and is engaging with staff unions on additional measures.

site_title: German economy shrinks by record 10.1% in Q2
summary: Germany's economy contracted by 10.1% in Q2, its steepest plunge on record, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Household spending, business investment, and exports collapsed, wiping out nearly a decade of economic growth. This is worse than predicted economists' 9% contraction. The decline is the sharpest since 1970, with state spending being the only bright spot. The statistics office reported a 11.7% decline in gross domestic product for the year.

site_title: Uber halts move of Asia-Pacific HQ from Singapore to Hong Kong
summary: Uber has halted plans to move its Asia-Pacific headquarters from Singapore to Hong Kong, citing a lack of progress on ridesharing regulations. The decision comes amid concerns over China's national security law for Hong Kong, which has sparked worries over its future as a hub for international business. Uber plans to extend its stay in Singapore until at least December 2022. The move is seen as a blow to Hong Kong's efforts to attract global tech firms, with other companies such as Facebook and Google evaluating the impact of the security law.

site_title: Singapore Paincare makes Catalist debut at S$0.22, unchanged from IPO price
summary: Singapore Paincare Holdings made its debut on the Singapore bourse, opening at S$0.22 per share, unchanged from its IPO price. The company offered 24.25 million shares for listing on the Catalist board, with 2.6 million shares changing hands at 23.5 cents as of 9:57 am.

site_title: Fed chief says coronavirus surge slowing US economic recovery
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the surge in coronavirus cases is slowing the US economic recovery, with a slowdown in consumer spending and rehiring of furloughed workers. The Fed has vowed to "do what we can, and for as long as it takes" to limit damage and boost growth, with interest rates remaining near zero. Powell emphasized that the path of the economy depends on the resolution of the health crisis, and that policymakers are taking cues from real-time data on the economy's progress.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia agree to resume RTS Link project; due to operate by end-2026
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have agreed to resume the RTS Link project, a cross-border train project connecting the city-state with Johor Bahru, Malaysia. The project, suspended since 2019, is now expected to begin operations by end-2026. The agreement includes a new depot in Wadi Hana, Johor Bahru, and co-location of customs, immigration, and quarantine facilities. The project will be funded and owned by an infrastructure company appointed by both countries, with Singapore's Land Transport Authority and Malaysia's Malaysia Rapid Transit System handling maintenance and renewal.

site_title: US dollar stops digging as investors turn to Congress for stimulus
summary: The US dollar experienced a slight bounce due to the Federal Reserve's lack of clarity on its next moves, despite concerns over the US economic recovery. Investors are now focusing on Congress' impasse on a fiscal rescue package, which may impact the dollar's value. The euro gained 4.7% against the dollar in July, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars retreated due to concerns over global tensions with China, including Sino-US relations and China's lagging on agricultural purchases.

site_title: Japan expresses regret over WTO panel on trade dispute with South Korea
summary: Japan's trade ministry expressed regret over the World Trade Organization's decision to set up a panel to rule on Tokyo's export curbs on technology materials to South Korea. The dispute stems from Japan's decision to stop preferential treatment for shipments to South Korea in July 2019. South Korea filed the complaint, prompting the WTO to establish the dispute settlement body despite Japan's opposition. The WTO's move sets the stage for a potential trade dispute between the two nations.

site_title: Reforms urged to keep Asean connected and competitive
summary: HSBC analysts warn that shrinking foreign direct investment (FDI) poses a threat to the Asean economy, particularly as India competes with the bloc. FDI diversion from China to Asean has slowed due to global uncertainties. To pursue FDI-driven growth, countries must finalize long-standing structural reform plans, as lower investment inflows hinder manufacturing growth and productivity.

images.alt_text: Workers assembling a Mitsubishi Pajero at a factory in Bekasi, West Java, Indonesia.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher on Fed pledge; tech stocks shine
summary: Australian shares closed 0.74% higher at 6,051.1, snapping a two-session losing streak, amid the Federal Reserve's pledge to support the US economy with "full range of tools." Tech stocks led the charge, with gains of 2.4%, driven by Facebook, Apple, and Alphabet's Google. Despite a record spike in COVID-19 cases in Australia, investors remained optimistic, with analysts citing the Fed's dovish comments as a factor.

site_title: Singapore battling third wave of imported Covid-19 cases: report
summary: Singapore is battling its third wave of imported COVID-19 cases, with over 100 cases reported in the past month, accounting for 15.5% of total imported cases since January. The cases come from 9 countries, with India accounting for more than half. The recent increase in cases follows the reopening of Phase Two, which allowed more long-term pass holders to return to Singapore. Experts suggest that pre-arrival testing could help filter out infected travelers, but quarantine remains an effective way to minimize the risk of spread.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as weak earnings offset Fed promise
summary: European shares fell 0.4% on Thursday, weighed down by weak earnings reports from banking and carmakers, despite the US Federal Reserve's promise to keep stimulus taps open. Banking stocks declined 1.5%, with Lloyds Banking Group reporting a rare pre-tax loss, while Volkswagen unveiled an operating loss. Energy stocks were also affected by weak oil prices, but some companies, such as Anheuser-Busch InBev, saw a boost after reporting a global beer sales recovery.

site_title: Wanda sells Chicago property for US$270m to reduce debt
summary: Wanda Hotel Development, a unit of Chinese billionaire Wang Jianlin's business empire, sold its 90% stake in Chicago's Vista Tower for US$270 million to reduce debt. The sale is expected to result in a gain of about HK$94 million (S$16.7 million) before taxes. The disposal is part of Wanda Group's efforts to cut debt after a debt-fuelled shopping binge and challenges from the coronavirus pandemic. The sale will help Wanda Hotel strengthen its financial position and follows previous asset disposals, including the sale of its Ironman triathlon business and stakes in European football clubs.

site_title: Singapore coffee body to host virtual auction in October
summary: The Singapore Coffee Association (SCA) will host its first virtual coffee auction in October, partnering with Food&HotelAsia and Enterprise Singapore to position Singapore as a key trading hub for specialty coffee producers. The auction will focus on micro lots of coffee, sourced from single plots of land or small farms. The event is scheduled to coincide with International Coffee Day on October 1, and aims to tap into Asia's growing coffee market.

site_title: VW cuts dividend after 2.4-billion-euro loss
summary: Volkswagen cut its proposed dividend to 4.86 euros per preferred share after losing 2.4 billion euros in the second quarter due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Global deliveries slumped by more than a quarter, and the company expects markets to recover in the second half. VW's shares fell, and the company stuck to its lowered forecast for a "severely" impacted year, but still expects to make a profit. The dividend cut aims to conserve cash after VW burned through 2.3 billion euros in the second quarter.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit 6-month high on foreign buying, Fed stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean stocks rose for a fourth consecutive session, reaching a six-month high, driven by strong foreign investor buying and hopes of US Federal Reserve stimulus. The Kospi index closed up 3.85 points, or 0.17%, at 2,267.01. Foreigners bought US$187.84 million worth of shares, while the Fed pledged to use its full range of tools for economic recovery. The agreement also included a six-month currency swap deal with the Bank of Korea.

site_title: Adjoining condos at Sophia Road to be up for collective sale with S$64m indicative price
summary: Adjoining condominiums Fairhaven and Sophia Ville at Sophia Road in Singapore will be launched for collective sale by tender on Aug 3 with a combined indicative price of S$64 million. Over 80% of the owners have consented to the sale, and the sites are zoned "residential" with a potential gross floor area of 53,541 sq ft. The collaboration is seen as a win-win proposition, offering higher prices for owners and more flexibility for developers.

site_title: Singapore firms glum about Q3 prospects as Covid-19, US-China tensions stymie recovery
summary: Singapore firms are gloomy about Q3 prospects due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and US-China tensions, with a net-weighted balance of 31% of services firms expecting business decline. Manufacturing sentiment improved slightly, with 7% expecting worse conditions in the second half, but overall sentiment remains subdued. Key sectors like accommodation services and retail trade remain pessimistic, while the semiconductor segment in the electronics cluster shows resilient demand. A net-weighted balance of 29% of services firms expect a drop in operating receipts, and 21% in services and 7% in manufacturing forecast a shrinking workforce.

site_title: French energy major Total Q2 net profit dives, maintains dividend
summary: French energy major Total reported a 96% fall in Q2 net profit to $126 million due to the coronavirus' impact on oil prices and demand. Despite the decline, Total maintained its dividend of 0.66 euros per share. The company attributed its positive adjusted net income to trading activities and reduced spending, enabling it to maintain its dividend at a sustainable level. Total also cut its 2020 investments to below $14 billion and reduced its oil and gas production forecast.

images.alt_text: French energy major Total reported a 96 per cent fall in second-quarter net profit to US$126 million on Thursday as the coronavirus knocked oil prices and demand but said it would maintain its dividend.

site_title: Shell avoids loss with strong trading, takes US$16.8b impairment
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported its first quarterly profit in two years, avoiding a loss, thanks to its strong trading business. The company took a nearly US$17 billion impairment charge due to a lowered oil and gas price outlook. Shell warned of continued pandemic impact on the energy market and announced a US$5 billion spending cut. Adjusted earnings rose to US$600 million, beating forecasts, driven by strong contributions from crude and oil products trading and lower operating expenses.

site_title: Airbus trims A350 output amid larger-than-expected Q2 loss
summary: Airbus has cut A350 production to 5 jets per month, down from 9.5, due to a larger-than-expected Q2 loss of 1.226 billion euros, a 55% decline in revenues. The company aims to avoid consuming cash before mergers and acquisitions and customer financing in the second half of the year. Airbus faces a glut of industry's biggest jets, which are expected to be slow to recover, with demand expected to return until 2023 or 2025. The move follows similar cuts by US rival Boeing.

site_title: Gold steadies after nine-day rally as Fed flags risk from virus
summary: Gold prices paused after a nine-day rally to a record high as investors weighed the Federal Reserve's comments on the economic recovery amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Fed left interest rates near zero and vowed to use all tools to drive the recovery, with Chairman Jerome Powell noting that more fallout from the outbreak still lies ahead. Gold has soared 30% this year, with forecasts predicting a surge to $2,300 an ounce, and real yields on 10-year US Treasuries sinking toward -1%.

site_title: StanChart first-half profit down 33% on higher loan impairments
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 33% decline in first-half profit to $1.63 billion due to higher loan impairments, primarily caused by the Covid-19 pandemic and economic downturn in its main markets. The bank's credit impairment charges increased six-fold to $1.58 billion. Standard Chartered expects lower income in the second half, has accelerated cost-cutting initiatives, and will not pay dividends until further notice. The bank's profit drop compared to analyst estimates of $1.53 billion.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS maintains 'buy' on supermarket plays Sheng Siong, Dairy Farm
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained its "buy" call on supermarket chains Sheng Siong Group and Dairy Farm International, with a target price lifted for Sheng Siong to S$1.91 and lowered for Dairy Farm to US$4.86. The research team cites potential catalysts such as online players taking the online-to-offline route and stronger than expected earnings, driven by the "circuit breaker" period in Singapore. Both companies are expected to benefit from strong balance sheets and cash flow generation capabilities.

site_title: Huawei overtakes Samsung as world's top handset seller in Q2: Canalys
summary: Huawei surpassed Samsung as the world's top handset seller in Q2, shipping 55.8 million devices compared to Samsung's 53.7 million, according to Canalys. Despite a 5% decline in sales, Huawei's dominance in the China market increased, with the company now selling over 70% of its phones in the country. This success is attributed to China's faster recovery from the coronavirus, while Samsung's sales dropped 30% due to disruption in key markets. However, this position may be short-lived as other markets recover.

images.alt_text: China's Huawei overtook Samsung Electronics as the world's biggest seller of mobile phones in the second quarter of 2020, shipping 55.8 million devices compared to Samsung's 53.7 million, according to data from research firm Canalys.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on dovish Fed comments
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending rallies on Wall Street, following dovish comments from the Federal Reserve. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.35% and the Topix index gained 0.31%. The Fed reiterated its accommodative policy of near-zero rates and asset purchases, supporting market sentiment.

site_title: Japan's June retail sales fall for 4th month, but at slower pace
summary: Japan's retail sales fell for the fourth consecutive month in June, with a 1.2% decline from the previous year. The decline was slower than expected, with spending on food, toiletries, and household electronics showing a smaller drop. On a seasonally adjusted basis, sales rose 13.1% from the previous month. The slower pace of decline suggests a potential rebound in private spending, which accounts for over half of Japan's economy, but policymakers remain cautious due to ongoing pandemic risks and a forecasted 20% contraction in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Retail sales in Japan fell for the fourth straight month in June as consumer sentiment remained bruised due to the impact from the coronavirus pandemic, though the pace of decline was slower than expected.

site_title: Vietnam banks buck the trend as regional lenders struggle with profit risks
summary: Vietnam's banks have bucked the trend of regional lenders struggling with profit risks, thanks to income growth and a younger population. Moody's Investors Service attributes Vietnam's resilience to "robust economic growth and the expansion of the middle class." The country's banks have seen improved profitability, with a decrease in cost-to-income ratio from 55% to 45% between 2014 and 2019. Moody's urges regional banks to adapt their business models, pursue digitalization, and expand overseas to cut reliance on domestic markets.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Li Auto raises US$1.1b in IPO
summary: Li Auto, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, raised $1.1 billion in an initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company at approximately $10 billion. The company sold 95 million shares at $11.50 each, above its marketed price of $8 to $10. Li Auto's revenue has surged, with its first-quarter revenue tripling that of 2019, and it plans to launch a premium vehicle in 2022. The IPO is the latest move by Chinese electric-vehicle makers to tap the US capital market.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as Fed signals more support; iron giants boost
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 6,045.3, driven by the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates near-zero and strong earnings from iron ore miners Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals Group. The Fed also warned the economy's recovery would depend on the virus's course. Financials and technology stocks also gained, with the Big Four banks trading in positive territory and Afterpay rising 2.7%. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand rose 0.6%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 4.28 points or 0.27% to 1,607.14, with a trading volume of 1.4 billion lots worth RM527.4 million. Gainers beat losers 313 to 199.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.39% at the start of Thursday's trade, driven by the Federal Reserve's pledge to further support the US economy amid the virus crisis. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,979.24, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up.

site_title: Olympics could have 'limited spectators' says Tokyo 2020 chief
summary: Tokyo 2020 Olympics chief Toshiro Muto suggests the event could be held with "limited spectators" to prevent COVID-19 infection spread. The Games are now scheduled to open on July 23, 2021, with no discussion of further postponement. Organizers are committed to holding the event, with consideration of social distancing and testing for athletes and visitors. Japan's current travel ban and rising infections in the capital have raised concerns, but officials remain optimistic about the event's viability.

images.alt_text: Next year's coronavirus-postponed Olympics could be held in front of a "limited number of spectators" to prevent the spread of infection, Tokyo 2020 chief executive Toshiro Muto has said.

site_title: Hi-P bottom line for H1 inches down 3.3% amid Covid-19 disruptions
summary: Hi-P International, a global contract manufacturer of electronics, reported a 3.3% decline in net profit to S$24.2 million for the half year ended June 30, 2020, due to lower revenue and losses from China operations affected by the novel coronavirus outbreak. Revenue dropped 5.1% to S$543.8 million, but was partially offset by higher turnover in the second quarter and government subsidies. The company's shares ended flat at S$1.29, and no dividend was recommended for the first half of the year.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Airlines slides to two-decade low after posting S$1.12b loss
summary: Singapore Airlines' stock price plummeted to a 22-year low after the airline reported a record S$1.12 billion loss for the first quarter due to a sharp drop in passenger traffic and revenue. The airline's passenger carriage fell 99.4% year-over-year, and its group revenue declined 79.3%. Industry forecasts suggest it will take two to four years for passenger traffic to return to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: US jobless benefit at risk as Congress coronavirus talks stalled
summary: US congressional Republicans and Democrats are struggling to reach a deal on coronavirus aid, with a $600-per-week unemployment benefit set to expire this week. Despite meetings with high-ranking Trump administration officials, no apparent progress was made, with Democrats opposing a temporary reduction in the federal payment to $200 a week. The lack of a deal raises concerns about the impact on tens of millions of Americans affected by the pandemic, with some lawmakers calling for a comprehensive plan.

site_title: MGM Resorts makes acting CEO William Hornbuckle permanent
summary: MGM Resorts International has appointed acting CEO William Hornbuckle as the permanent CEO, succeeding Jim Mirren. The appointment comes as the company navigates the coronavirus crisis, which has devastated the casino industry. Hornbuckle, who previously served as chief marketing officer from 2009 to 2012, was chosen after a national search. He will also serve on the company's board, leading the company through challenging times and into a promising future.

site_title: Singapore bank lending extends fall in June for fourth consecutive month
summary: Singapore bank lending fell 0.7% in June to S$680.36 billion, marking the fourth consecutive month of decline, amid the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Total loans dropped 1% year-on-year, with business loans falling 1.1% to S$425.85 billion, mainly due to weaker loans to transport and communication sectors. The decline is attributed to uncertainty caused by the pandemic, with no signs of a recovery in the near term.

site_title: Samsung sees pickup in chip demand from new phones, Q2 profit jumps
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 23% jump in operating profit in the April-June quarter, driven by strong DRAM chip sales. The company expects a further increase in chip demand in the second half, driven by new smartphone launches, but warns of risks from the pandemic and trade disputes. Operating profit from its chip business rose 60% to 5.43 trillion won, and the company plans to unveil new smartphones and expand mid-tier model sales.

site_title: Hong Kong's commercial lenders on edge as building values tumble
summary: Commercial lenders in Hong Kong are concerned about a 30% drop in building values over the past 12 months, prompting consideration of loan defaults or restructuring. Lenders, including banks and non-bank lenders, have lent billions of dollars in the city's real estate market. Mezzanine investors are seen as most at risk due to their high loan-to-value ratios. Defaults have already occurred, and banks are discussing the gap between economic realities and market valuations, with some lenders demanding new property valuations to ensure loan-to-value limits are not breached.

site_title: Japan braces for spike in virus cases amid domestic travel campaign
summary: Japan is bracing for a surge in coronavirus cases after exceeding 1,000 new cases for the first time, amid a national travel campaign to revive the tourism industry. Tokyo reported 365 cases, with infections spreading rapidly in other regions, including remote islands. The campaign, launched on July 22, has been criticized by the World Health Organization's influenza panel member, Norio Sugaya, who calls it ill-timed and warns of a potential hospital and ICU crisis. Tokyo plans to urge shorter operating hours for restaurants and karaoke parlours to tackle the recent spike.

site_title: MAS to extend US$60b swap facility with US Fed
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced the extension of a US$60 billion USD swap facility with the US Federal Reserve until March 31, 2021. This facility provides up to US$60 billion of funding to banks for USD lending to businesses in Singapore and the region. Since its launch in March 2020, the facility has provided about US$22 billion.

site_title: China Aviation Oil H1 profit sinks 57% to US$23.6m
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 57% decline in net profit to US$23.6 million for the half year ended June 30, due to a decrease in gross profit from trading activities and lower contributions from its associates. Revenue fell 44.5% to US$5.37 billion, primarily due to lower oil prices and trading volume. The company attributed the decline to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the aviation industry. Despite this, CAO's businesses remained stable, and no interim dividend was declared for the period.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at open as banks lead losses; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 2,567.28, led by banking stocks, which declined 2.7% to 1.9% as DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell. Real estate investment trusts, such as Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust, rose 1.1%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore urged banks to cap dividends at 60% of the previous year's amount. Globally, stocks in the US and Asia rose, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gaining 0.6% and 1.2%, respectively.

site_title: Brazil reopens international flights to tourists even as virus deaths spike
summary: Brazil reopened international flights to tourists, despite a record number of new coronavirus deaths and confirmed cases. The decision allows tourists from all countries with health insurance for the duration of their trip. This move comes as other countries in the region, such as Colombia and Peru, remain closed to international commercial flights. However, many countries, including the US and EU, do not allow tourists from Brazil due to the severity of the outbreak.

site_title: Hot stocks: DBS, OCBC, UOB tumble after MAS asks to cap dividends
summary: Singapore's local lenders DBS, OCBC, and UOB plummeted after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) requested they cap dividend payouts for FY20 at 60% of FY19's total. DBS fell 4.2%, OCBC dropped 5.1%, and UOB declined 3.7%. The MAS also offered shareholders the option to receive dividends in scrip instead of cash. The move follows the central bank's efforts to manage bank profits amid the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Despite the short-term hit to share prices, the dividend cap is prudent and will place Singapore banks in a stronger position to combat challenges ahead, the DBS research team pointed out.

site_title: Sembcorp completes divestment of Chilean water business, exits market
summary: Sembcorp Industries has completed the divestment of its Chilean water business to Spanish construction and engineering service group Sacyr for 27.8 billion Chilean pesos (S$53.6 million). The divestment resulted in an impairment of S$64 million, with a net charge of S$27 million to earnings per share. Sembcorp has exited the Chilean market and the transaction is not expected to have a material impact on its net asset value per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Goldman bets on warehouses with virus spurring online shopping
summary: Goldman Sachs' merchant banking division has invested in 46 warehouses across the US, valued at approximately $500 million, in anticipation of accelerated e-commerce demand during the COVID-19 pandemic. The warehouses, known as "last-mile" facilities, are located in major metro areas and are already 94% occupied with tenants such as Amazon and Frito-Lay. This investment reflects the growing demand for logistics facilities as online shopping surges, with warehouses emerging as a "safe haven" during the crisis.

site_title: Ascott's co-living brand lyf adds 6 new properties in Australia, China, Philippines
summary: Ascott's co-living brand lyf is adding 6 new properties in Australia, China, and the Philippines, with over 1,000 units across 14 properties, totaling 2,700 units. The new properties include lyf Malate Manila, lyf Shougang Park Beijing, lyf Midtown Hangzhou, lyf Zhangjiang Shanghai, lyf Dayanta Xi'an, and lyf Collingwood Melbourne. Despite the challenges in the global hospitality industry, Ascott's portfolio remains strong, with long-stay guests comprising locals, expatriates, and corporates. The company aims to expand lyf to key gateway cities globally.

site_title: PayPal volume surges with consumers flocking to online shopping
summary: PayPal's second-quarter revenue surged 25% and payments volume jumped 30% as the pandemic accelerated the shift to online shopping. The company expects full-year revenue to climb 22% and adds 70 million active accounts in the latter half of the year. Digital payments on Venmo, PayPal's digital wallet, surged 52% to $37 billion. Executives believe the shift away from cash is permanent, citing consumer adoption of e-commerce as a durable and profound behavioral shift.

site_title: GM says it can pay off US$16b loan if US recovery continues
summary: General Motors (GM) stated it can pay off its $16 billion US loan by the end of 2020 if the US economy continues to recover from the coronavirus pandemic. The company expects adjusted operating earnings of $4 billion to $5 billion in the second half of the year, with a potential cash flow of $7 billion to $9 billion. However, a resurgence in COVID-19 cases in the US has raised concerns about the recovery, and analysts question whether GM's vehicle sales will return to pre-pandemic levels soon.

images.alt_text: General Motors on Wednesday said if the US economy continues to recover from the coronavirus pandemic and the auto industry does not experience any further production shutdowns, the No 1 US automaker should be able to generate enough cash to pay off a US$16 billion loan by the end of the year.

site_title: Mary Chia foresees fiscal 2020 net loss worsening
summary: Mary Chia Holdings, a beauty and wellness company, expects a significant increase in its net loss for the full year ended March 31, 2020, to S$1.4 million, compared to the six months ended Sept 30, 2019. The company's operations in Singapore and Malaysia were impacted by government measures in response to the novel coronavirus pandemic, including closing outlets during the "circuit breaker" and "movement control order". The expected net loss is also due to impairment on assets and property plant and equipment.

site_title: IndoAgri sinks deeper into the red with H1 loss of 429.42b rupiah
summary: IndoAgri Resources reported a net loss of 429.42 billion rupiah (S$41 million) for the first half of 2020, widening from 274.33 billion rupiah in the previous year. The loss was driven by changes in fair value of biological assets, associate company losses, and higher income tax expenses. Revenue rose 5.7% to 6.87 trillion rupiah, mainly due to higher selling prices of palm oil and edible oils. Loss per share was 308 rupiah, compared to 197 rupiah in the previous year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Singapore banks, Sheng Siong, Hongkong Land, Sembcorp, Japfa
summary: Singapore stocks saw mixed performance on Thursday, with SIA plummeting S$1.12 billion in net loss for its first quarter, and DBS, OCBC, and UOB declining due to the Monetary Authority's dividend cap. Sheng Siong Group's net profit more than doubled to S$46.2 million, while Hongkong Land announced a net loss of US$1.8 billion for the first half. Japfa's net profit grew six times to US$76.8 million, and Dairy Farm International posted a 35% drop in net profit. Sembcorp Industries and Sembcorp Marine's proposed demerger sparked concerns among shareholders.

site_title: Singtel shareholders approve scrip dividend scheme even as outlook remains hazy
summary: Singtel shareholders have approved a scrip dividend scheme, allowing shareholders to receive shares instead of cash. The move comes as the company's outlook remains hazy due to the coronavirus pandemic. Despite provisions for bad debts increasing, Singtel expects its network and operations to remain resilient. The company has also reiterated its focus on financial prudence and investing in 5G wireless technology, which it sees as a long-term growth opportunity. A dividend payout of 12.25 Singapore cents per share was previously announced, down from 17.5 cents last year.

site_title: Europe: Earnings drive big swings in stocks ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Europe's main stocks benchmark closed nearly flat on Wednesday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 down 0.1% due to healthcare and bank stocks dragging on the main index. However, individual stocks experienced significant swings, with retailers jumping 1.4% in a busy earnings day. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting, hoping for an accommodative stance to support financial markets.

site_title: CRCT evaluating tenant mix; posts H1 DPU of 3.02 Singapore cents
summary: Capitaland Retail China Trust (CRCT) posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.02 Singapore cents for the first half of 2020, down 41.4% from the year-ago DPU. The Reit's gross revenue declined 7.8% to S$101.5 million, while net property income dropped 17.9% to S$65.3 million. CRCT's tenant mix is being reassessed amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with the possibility of phasing out non-viable tenants. The Reit's total portfolio occupancy fell to 91.5% as of June 30.

site_title: Arizona leads multi-state probe into older iPhones slowing, shutting down
summary: Arizona is leading a multi-state investigation into whether Apple deliberately slowed older iPhones, violating deceptive trade practice laws. The probe, started in 2018, seeks data on "unexpected shutdowns" and throttling of devices. A majority of US states are involved, with Arizona and Texas attorneys general offices declining to comment. Apple acknowledged reducing power demands to slow aging phones but denied slowing devices to encourage users to buy new ones. The company has agreed to pay up to $500 million to settle a related class-action lawsuit.

images.alt_text: Arizona is leading a multi-US state investigation into whether Apple's deliberate slowing of older iPhones violated deceptive trade practice laws, documents reviewed by Reuters on Wednesday showed.

site_title: Biofourmis' remote monitoring platform used by MOH for Covid-19 patients
summary: Biofourmis, a digital therapeutics company, has developed a remote monitoring platform called Biovitals Sentinel to track Covid-19 patients. The platform uses a clinical-grade biosensor worn on the patient's upper arm to measure physiological signals. The data is analyzed in real-time and triggers alerts to healthcare workers if abnormalities are detected. The platform has been deployed in Singapore, the US, the UK, Australia, and Hong Kong, and is being used in community care facilities and health systems to monitor patients with Covid-19. This remote monitoring system aims to detect signs of deterioration early and enable timely intervention.

site_title: European software startup Infobip raises over US$200m in Series A funding: sources
summary: European software startup Infobip has raised over US$200 million in Series A funding from private equity firm One Equity Partners, valuing the company at over US$1 billion. The investment will aid Infobip's expansion in the US through potential acquisitions, as it competes with rivals like Twilio. Founded in 2006, Infobip provides cloud communications technology for omnichannel marketing, with global firms like Uber, Costco, and Unilever as customers. The company is now focusing on expanding its business and considering an initial public offering in the US.

site_title: Emmy awards show to go virtual
summary: The Emmy Awards show, originally scheduled for September 20, will go virtual due to the coronavirus pandemic. Host Jimmy Kimmel and producers have written to nominees confirming a traditional gathering in Los Angeles will not take place, instead opting for a virtual celebration. The show will still be the industry's biggest night out, with celebrities potentially appearing in pajamas or from their bedrooms.

site_title: Australia's Macquarie says Q1 profit lower, provides no 2021 guidance
