summary: Macquarie Group, an Australian financial conglomerate, reported a lower first-quarter profit due to lower investment income from its market-facing operations. The company attributed this to the pandemic-induced uncertainty and global economic fallout. Macquarie also incurred A$1.04 billion in credit and investment impairments. The bank will not provide guidance for fiscal 2021 due to the ongoing pandemic uncertainty. Despite this, clients rebalanced their portfolios, supporting Macquarie's commodities and global markets division.

site_title: Trump defends use of Covid-19 bill to fund new FBI office near his hotel
summary: US President Donald Trump defended using a coronavirus relief package to fund a new FBI headquarters near his Washington hotel, despite opposition from fellow Republicans. Trump cited his background as a real estate developer and claimed he was "very good at real estate." The provision, which would cost $1.8 billion, has drawn scrutiny, with some accusing Trump of seeking to prevent a private developer from buying the site and competing with his hotel. The matter is currently under review by the Department of Justice.

site_title: Competition to heat up at District 21 with upcoming launch
summary: The launch of Forett At Bukit Timah in District 21 is set to increase competition in the area, offering 633 freehold units with indicative prices starting from S$1,800 per square foot. The project, developed by Qingjian Realty (South Pacific) Group and Perennial Real Estate Holdings, was acquired via a collective sale in 2018 for S$610 million. This addition is expected to test demand for Singapore prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark.

site_title: Qualcomm forecasts sales above estimates, settles dispute with Huawei
summary: Qualcomm forecasted fourth-quarter revenue above Wall Street estimates, driven by 5G device sales and a settlement with Huawei. The company expects to make up for a delayed flagship phone launch, with chip shipments slightly below expectations. Qualcomm resolved a licensing dispute with Huawei, which will pay a catch-up payment of $1.80 billion. The company forecast current-quarter adjusted revenue of $5.50-$6.30 billion, with licensing revenue exceeding estimates. Shares rose 13% in extended trading.

site_title: White House to lure US firms to Latam from Asia, senior adviser says
summary: The Trump administration plans a "Back to the Americas" initiative, aiming to lure US firms to Latin America and the Caribbean with financial incentives. The project could bring $30 billion to $50 billion in US investment back to the region, focusing on infrastructure, energy, and transportation. This initiative will include both reshoring (bringing investment to the US) and nearshoring (moving investment to Latin America and the Caribbean).

site_title: Best World founders should make exit offer to minority shareholders
summary: Best World, a Singapore-based company, is under scrutiny after a probe by PwC found potential control issues with its major customer Changsha Best and marketing agent Vicstar. The findings raise concerns about whether sales made to these entities should be classified as inter-company transactions, which can be used to inflate sales. The company's founders, Dora Hoan and Doreen Tan, have a 47.14% stake and are urging them to consider making an exit offer to minority shareholders to put the past in the past.

site_title: Sembcorp, Sembmarine investors express concerns about 'demerger'
summary: Sembcorp Industries and Sembmarine are set to demerge, with Sembcorp taking up S$1.27 billion of Sembmarine's shares in a rights issue. Investors have expressed concerns about the timing, citing poor macroeconomic conditions and the potential for a dilution of ownership. Sembcorp executives claim the demerger will bring greater flexibility and allow shareholders to capture market opportunities. Proxy adviser ISS has recommended voting in favor of the resolutions, citing enhanced value for Sembcorp shareholders and clearer investment propositions.

site_title: 3 to 4-year timeline proposed for dropping Sibor
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore has proposed a 3-4 year timeline to discontinue the SGD Singapore Interbank Offered Rates (Sibor) and replace it with the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA). The final verdict is expected in November, with both Sibor and SOR phased out and replaced by SORA. The shift aims to deepen SORA markets, increase transparency, and promote efficient risk management. The proposed transition will also support the development of a risk-free rate (RFR)-centred approach, benefiting retail consumers and SMEs with SORA-pegged products.

site_title: US: Wall St closes higher after Fed vows more support for virus-battered economy
summary: US stocks closed higher on Wednesday, driven by the Federal Reserve's pledge to support the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Fed repeated its commitment to use its "full range of tools" to support the economy, with interest rate targets remaining unchanged. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.61%, the S&P 500 gained 1.24%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 1.35%. Despite uncertainty surrounding the virus, investors felt certain that monetary stimulus will remain accommodative, driving gains in sectors like energy and finance.

site_title: Facebook, Google absorb US lawmakers' jabs in rare Big Tech hearing
summary: Google and Facebook CEOs, along with Amazon's Jeff Bezos and Apple's Tim Cook, testified before the House Judiciary Committee, facing accusations of market abuse and allegations of censorship. The CEOs defended their companies, with Zuckerberg taking the most damage, and Pichai facing criticism from conservatives. The hearing, which was initially expected to be a major event, was marred by technical issues and poor audio quality. A detailed report with antitrust allegations is expected to be released by late summer or early fall.

site_title: SIA S$1.12b in the red for Q1; analysts see FY21 loss of S$1.83b
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a net loss of S$1.12 billion in Q1 2020, compared to a net profit of S$111 million a year ago, due to weaker operating performance and financial impact from the liquidation of NokScoot. Group revenue fell 79.3% to S$851 million, primarily due to a sharp drop in passenger revenue. Cargo load factor improved significantly, and the airline expects to incur a material impairment of its older generation aircraft by the end of FY21. Analysts project a net loss of S$1.83 billion for FY21, but a DBS Group Research report suggests that a vaccine could lead to a faster recovery.

site_title: NTUC, 3 affiliated unions slam 'unfair' layoffs at P&W-SIA Engineering joint venture
summary: NTUC and three affiliated unions have condemned the "unfair" layoffs at Eagle Services Asia, a joint venture between Pratt & Whitney and SIA Engineering Company, which affected over 100 workers. The layoffs were halted after NTUC authorized the unions to prepare for legal industrial action. The unions and NTUC negotiated with the company to adjust the selection criteria, safeguarding the "Singaporean core" while considering foreign workers. A fair-compensation package and training grants were also offered to affected workers. The Ministry of Manpower acknowledged the incident, emphasizing the importance of openness, transparency, and consultation with unions and workers.

site_title: US dollar falls to two-year lows before Fed decision
summary: The US dollar fell to a two-year low of 93.41 against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, as investors await the Federal Reserve's decision on policy. The dollar's weakness is attributed to rising coronavirus cases and demand for riskier currencies. Despite expectations of a dovish policy stance, some analysts predict strong forward guidance from the Fed on further policy actions. The euro strengthened, and the Australian dollar hit a 15-month peak, while the yen fell to a four-month low.

site_title: Far East H-Trust DPS for H1 slides 43.4% to 1.03 S cents
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 43.4% to 1.03 Singapore cents for its first half, down from 1.82 cents a year ago. The managers retained part of the distributable income to provide rental rebates and deferment for tenants amidst the Covid-19 period. Income available for distribution decreased 42.3% year-over-year to S$20.2 million.

site_title: FDA could soon authorise Covid-19 treatment with antibody plasma: WSJ
summary: The US FDA may authorize emergency use of antibody-rich blood plasma from recovered Covid-19 patients as early as next week, allowing faster access to a therapy for the pandemic. This treatment, known as convalescent plasma, has been transfused into critically ill patients since the beginning of the pandemic. The European Union has also expressed interest in fast-tracking funding for the treatment. If approved, it could provide a new treatment option for the over 660,000 people worldwide who have lost their lives to Covid-19.

site_title: Kodak CEO's fortune swells US$79m as stocks rally on US government loan
summary: Eastman Kodak CEO Jim Continenza's net worth increased by $79 million as his stock options turned from worthless to lucrative due to a $765 million US government loan for pharmaceutical ingredients. Kodak's stock surged 1,167% in two days, making Continenza's options worth $59 million. The company's market capitalization rose to $1.5 billion, enriching all shareholders. However, key insiders, including board directors, booked the majority of the gains, while the company emerged from bankruptcy in 2013 with a value of over $100 million.

images.alt_text: Eastman Kodak chief executive officer (CEO) Jim Continenza added US$79 million to his net worth on Wednesday when his options in the imaging company turned from worthless to lucrative thanks to a US government loan for a pharmaceutical ingredients supply deal that super-charged the value of his shares.

site_title: Muslims begin downsized haj amid pandemic
summary: Muslim pilgrims began a downsized haj in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, amid the COVID-19 pandemic, marking a significant reduction in attendance. The five-day pilgrimage, a must for able-bodied Muslims, has been scaled back to prevent a coronavirus outbreak. The haj, usually one of the world's largest religious gatherings, has been dramatically reduced, a drastic measure taken by the Saudi hosts to contain the spread of the virus.

site_title: The 2020 Gold Rush
summary: A 2020 Gold Rush occurred, likely referring to the gold price surge during that year. Although the article does not explicitly discuss the gold rush, it mentions a gold-related stock, PSC, and a mandatory offer at S$0.40 a share. The article primarily focuses on the stock market, discussing rallies in Singapore, Asia, and the US, as well as the ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Hybrid business models present new opportunities
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted various industries, but it has also created new opportunities for businesses to adapt and innovate. Hybrid business models, such as online and offline services, are emerging as a way to foster human connection while minimizing costs and logistics. Companies like Microsoft, Ultimate Performance gyms, and a networking platform have seen increased membership numbers and success in online events. As the pandemic continues, businesses are expected to adopt a hybrid approach, integrating digital and traditional services to deliver better education, training, and networking opportunities at lower costs.

site_title: Big Tech CEOs to defend their companies before US Congress
summary: Big Tech CEOs, including Amazon's Jeff Bezos, Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Google's Sundar Pichai, and Apple's Tim Cook, will testify before a US Congress panel investigating antitrust concerns. They argue that intense competition from each other and other rivals forces them to innovate and remain relevant. The CEOs will defend their companies' business practices and data gathering, with Pichai citing the competitive threat from China and Zuckerberg calling for government regulation to address concerns over social media and election integrity.

site_title: Indonesian labour unions protest influx of Chinese workers
summary: Indonesian labour unions are protesting the influx of 500 Chinese workers brought in by PT Virtue Dragon Nickel Industry and PT Obsidian Stainless Steel for multi-billion dollar projects amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The unions claim the arrival of foreign workers hurts local workers and Indonesian people, who are already struggling to find jobs. The Confederation of Indonesian Trade Unions is calling for the repatriation of Chinese workers and prioritizing domestic workers, citing the need to save jobs in an economy devastated by the pandemic.

site_title: Heathrow airport slams Britain over lack of passenger testing
summary: Heathrow Airport has criticized Britain for not introducing a passenger testing regime, warning that the UK risks losing a significant portion of its global business if it doesn't act soon. The airport's CEO, John Holland-Kaye, stated that without a testing regime, the UK is playing "quarantine roulette" and losing to European competitors who have implemented passenger testing. The airport, which has seen a 96% drop in passenger numbers, has urged the government to introduce a nationwide testing program to support the struggling travel industry.

site_title: Hong Kong economy down 9% in Q2, extending first recession in a decade
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted 9% in the second quarter, extending its first recession in a decade, with the decline worse than the median forecast of -8.3%. The territory has suffered four consecutive quarters of economic contraction, following the global financial crisis period, and its unemployment rate has surged to a 15-year high. The government attributes the decline to the coronavirus pandemic and political tensions, but hopes the economy will gradually recover once the local epidemic is contained and external environment improves.

images.alt_text: "The outlook for Q3 remains very challenging. Another quarter of negative growth is highly probable", says Raymond Yeung, greater China chief economist with ANZ.

site_title: Nomura cuts dozens of jobs at US investment-banking unit
summary: Nomura Holdings cut dozens of jobs at its US investment bank, with less than 10% of staff affected. The move is under new CEO Kentaro Okuda, who has reviewed business operations amid the pandemic. The job cuts come as the company swings back to profit, benefiting from buoyant trading conditions, but investment banking revenue declined. This is part of a larger restructuring effort, which has also led to the closure of its Instinet equity-research division.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest four under new security law in move slammed by rights group
summary: Hong Kong police arrested four students aged 16-21 under the city's new national security law, suspected of being involved in an online group that pledged to fight for an independent Hong Kong. They were charged with subversions, organising, and inciting secession. This is the first arrest under the law since its implementation a month ago, sparking criticism from rights groups.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong police have arrested four people aged 16-21 for suspected offences under the city's new national security law, the first such detentions outside of street protests since the legislation took effect a month ago.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Q2 net profit more than doubles to S$46.2m
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket chain, reported a net profit of S$46.2 million in its second quarter, more than doubling from S$18.4 million a year ago. Revenue rose 75.8% to S$418.7 million due to strong demand from Covid-19 and government grants. Gross margin improved to 28.1%, driven by higher selling prices and increased house-brand sales. The company declared an interim cash dividend of 3.5 cents per share and plans to open new retail spaces, despite competition from e-commerce platforms.

site_title: A brand new BT Lifestyle
summary: A new BT Lifestyle section is launching in Singapore, focusing on relaxing content for the weekend, including stories on spending habits, home decor, and local businesses. In contrast to the pandemic's economic impact, affluent travelers are boosting local businesses with their spending, particularly in fine dining, furniture, and jewelry. The section will also feature articles on design, lifestyle, and entrepreneurship, aiming to provide a break from economic news and inspire readers.

site_title: From Succession to Schitt's Creek, Emmy nominations put premium on diversity
summary: The 2020 Emmy nominations list showcases a record number of Black actors, with 35% of acting nominations going to Black actors, a significant increase from 2018. Netflix led with 160 nominations, followed by HBO with 107. Shows like Watchmen, The Marvelous Mrs Maisel, and Schitt's Creek received multiple nods, with Watchmen scoring 26 nominations and Schitt's Creek scoring 15. The nominations highlight a shift towards greater diversity in the entertainment industry, with many shows featuring diverse casts and crews.

site_title: Airbus cuts jobs in Singapore due to pandemic impact
summary: Airbus has cut jobs in Singapore due to the pandemic's impact on the aviation industry, with the company retrenching some employees in its customer services operation and related support functions. The exact number of employees let go is not disclosed, but Airbus has been working with local associations and government agencies to find new jobs for affected workers. The move is part of a broader effort by Airbus and its rival Boeing to reduce their global workforce in response to declining demand for new aircraft and maintenance services.

site_title: Trump may yet surprise detractors come Nov 3
summary: Donald Trump may surprise detractors on November 3, as economic recovery and international tensions centered on China could come to his rescue. Trump has altered the US political landscape by moving the center of gravity further rightwards, making it difficult for opponents to define what "left" means. His polarizing style and lack of charisma may benefit him, especially if Democratic candidate Joe Biden moves leftwards, potentially alienating some centrist voters. Trump's economic gamble appears to be paying off, with near-full employment and negligible inflation, and his isolationist foreign policy may also work in his favor, particularly if the US economy experiences a V-shaped recovery.

site_title: Barclays signals economic pain ahead with bad loan charges
summary: Barclays has downgraded its economic forecasts due to high US and UK unemployment, which is expected to remain high, leading to prolonged economic contraction and bad loans. The bank reported a £1.6 billion charge for bad loans, bringing the total to £3.7 billion this year. Barclays' CEO Jes Staley attributed the gloomy outlook to exceptional economic contraction, particularly in the US and UK, where unemployment may surge to 6.5% next year. The bank's stock fell 4% in London trading.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts' DPS for H1 tumbles 63.7% to 1.51 Singapore cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts' distribution per stapled security (DPS) plummeted 63.7% to 1.51 Singapore cents for the six months ended June 30, 2020, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Gross revenue declined 44.5% to S$52.1 million, and net property income fell 56% to S$29.7 million. The trust's managers cited low occupancies and travel restrictions as major factors. Despite this, a "substantive" S$32.1 million contribution to portfolio rental income partially insulated the trust. The distribution will be paid out on August 27.

site_title: MAS calls on local banks to cap dividend, offer scrip option
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has called on local banks to cap their total dividends per share (DPS) for FY2020 at 60% of the previous year's amount, aiming to bolster their resilience and support lending to businesses and individuals amid the uncertain economic climate. Shareholders will also be offered the option to receive dividends in scrip instead of cash. The 60% cap balances capital conservation with shareholder interests, and the move is seen as prudent to support the banks' ability to absorb economic shocks.

images.alt_text: MAS noted that the 60 per cent cap on FY2020 dividends "balances the objective of capital conservation with the interests of shareholders".

site_title: Data ethics: How we do right by customers in a digital economy
summary: The digital economy relies heavily on data, which is being generated and stored at an unprecedented scale. As data becomes increasingly interconnected, it's essential to establish responsible data use principles to protect human rights, align with laws, and uphold customer trust. Industries must set up bodies to ensure sustainable data use, and companies should prioritize transparency and customer-centric approaches. Partnerships between industries and regulators can help establish common standards for data ethics, and leading companies are setting the example by championing responsible data use.

site_title: US pending home sales exceed forecast as mortgage rates fall
summary: US pending home sales exceeded forecasts in June, rising 16.6% after a 44.3% jump in May. This marks the highest level since February 2006, driven by falling mortgage rates. The National Association of Realtors' index is up 12.7% from last year, with all US regions experiencing gains. Housing market activity is seen as a key source of strength for the economy, despite ongoing challenges from Covid-19 and elevated unemployment.

site_title: Chip designer Arm in escalating fight with ousted CEO of its China venture
summary: Arm, the UK chip designer, is in an escalating dispute with Allen Wu, the ousted CEO of its China venture, over undisclosed breaches of conduct. Wu, who was fired in June, has refused to step down and remains in control of the operation, citing key registration documents that give him an advantage. The dispute has deteriorated, with Arm accusing Wu of hurting its business in China and creating a culture of fear among employees. The situation has raised concerns about Beijing's willingness to protect foreign investment in the world's second-largest economy, potentially impacting the global semiconductor industry.

site_title: 'Recession-proof' US apartment buildings seeking buyers
summary: Jones Lang LaSalle is seeking buyers for over $12 billion worth of US apartment buildings, targeting investors who raised money before the Covid-19 pandemic and those shifting funds from hotels and shopping malls. The move tests demand for a recession-proof asset class despite the pandemic's impact. The firm is also targeting investors looking to diversify their portfolios.

site_title: iX Biopharma sinks 9.7% after proposing S$10.2m placement at discount
summary: iX Biopharma's shares dropped 9.7% after proposing a S$10.2 million placement of 44.5 million new shares at a 27.7% discount to the previous day's closing price. The placement will support the company's future growth as it transitions from research and development to commercialization. About 60% of the proceeds will be used for development and marketing activities, and the remaining 40% for general working capital.

site_title: Axington, Citicode to become healthcare plays
summary: Singapore-listed companies Axington and Citicode are set to transform into healthcare companies. Axington, a professional advisory services group, plans to change its name to NETX Inc. and acquire a Malaysian medical products distributor for S$12 million. Meanwhile, Citicode has proposed a S$72 million reverse takeover deal to acquire Livingstone Health, a specialist healthcare services provider. The acquisitions aim to create liquidity for the stocks and restore free floats. The companies will seek shareholder approval for the proposed resolutions.

site_title: Aw & Sons Capital buys another 10 shophouses at Teck Chye Terrace
summary: Aw & Sons Capital, a low-profile developer, has acquired 10 freehold shophouses along Teck Chye Terrace in Singapore for S$39 million, bringing its total ownership to 15 units. The shophouses are fully leased and have a plot ratio of 3.0, making them suitable for redevelopment into a serviced apartment or co-living project. The acquisition price works out to S$1,008 per square foot per plot ratio, and the developer has the option to either keep the properties as an investment or redevelop the land into a new residential project.

images.alt_text: The group is said to be mulling redeveloping all 15 shophouses into a serviced-apartment or co-living project. The property is near Serangoon MRT interchange and Kovan MRT stations.

site_title: Utico seeks Sias endorsement as potential Hyflux judicial management looms
summary: Utico has urged the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) to endorse its proposed rescue package for Hyflux, a distressed water treatment firm, in order to avoid judicial management. A group of bank lenders plans to file an application with the Singapore High Court to place Hyflux under judicial management by August 7. Utico's proposal is seen as the only viable binding offer, offering investors a 50% return for the smallest holdings and at least a 10% recovery for the largest holdings. However, other potential white knights' offers require support from 25.1% of senior debt and may offer only 5% recovery.

site_title: Layoffs double in Q2; total employment dives by quarterly record of 122,000
summary: Singapore's total employment shrank by 121,800 in Q2, its worst quarterly contraction on record. This is nearly five times the 25,700 seen in Q1. Economists warn that the worst may not be over, with the actual numbers likely to be bigger. The contraction was broad-based across manufacturing, services, and construction sectors.

site_title: US malls seek to evolve amid pandemic-induced retail overhaul
summary: US malls are reconfiguring to stay relevant as the retail landscape evolves amid the pandemic. About 200 of the strongest malls will remain by 2030, according to observers. Brookfield Properties is redeveloping its Stonestown Galleria in San Francisco, adding Whole Foods, a healthcare provider, and a Sports Basement store. The mall will also feature expanded Target and Regal Cinemas, with plans for apartment construction. Experts say malls must adapt to incorporate a mix of uses, including retail, dining, entertainment, and healthcare, to survive.

site_title: Clicking to buy? Do a good deed at the same time
summary: In Singapore, the #Blessings movement, started on Carousell, encourages users to re-gift pre-owned items to those in need. Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, Carousell co-founder Marcus Tan launched the #ChooseToGive initiative, urging the community to donate essential items. The platform is also part of Retail for Good, a movement supporting National Day 2020. Companies like Amazon, Shopee, and Fave are participating, with initiatives such as Amazon's Covid-19 donation efforts and Fave's "Fave Cares" campaign to support migrant workers. These efforts aim to promote togetherness and giving back during the pandemic.

site_title: Thailand extends state of emergency to curb Covid-19
summary: Thailand's Cabinet extended the country's state of emergency for a fourth time, through August 31, to curb the spread of COVID-19. The move comes as the country hasn't detected new local cases for about two months, with 3,298 reported cases and 58 deaths. Critics accuse the government of targeting anti-government protests, while the Prime Minister says he's concerned about the potential for divisions in society. The government also approved a plan to ease border lockdowns for medical tourists, trade exhibition attendees, and foreign film crews, and a new central bank governor was appointed.

site_title: Japan's ANA logs record quarterly 108.8b yen loss as pandemic hits demand
summary: Japan's All Nippon Airways (ANA) recorded a record quarterly loss of 108.8 billion yen ($1.41 billion) in the April-June period due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has significantly reduced air travel demand. This is the airline's worst quarterly loss since it began reporting financial data in 2003. ANA's net loss is a sharp fall from the 11.4 billion yen profit the airline reported a year ago.

images.alt_text: ANA's cargo operations were less affected, but could not offset the unprecedented impact of the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Meghan and UK tabloid trade blows in court dispute
summary: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, is suing Associated Newspapers over articles in the Mail on Sunday that included parts of a handwritten letter she sent to her estranged father. Her lawyer claims the newspaper used court documents to create a "sensational" article, breaching her privacy and copyright. A full trial is expected next year, with Meghan seeking a court order to prevent disclosure of the names of five friends who gave anonymous interviews to a US magazine. Associated Newspapers argues that publishing the names would breach the principle of open justice.

site_title: Global public investors AUM hit US$39.5 trillion in 2019: OMFIF report
summary: The world's largest global public investors (GPIs) held US$39.5 trillion in assets in 2019, with 40% of portfolios in riskier and more illiquid assets. This represents 43.4% of the world's economy. GPIs are diversifying into safe assets amid Covid-19, with many considering a return to safety. The increase in assets outpaced the estimated 2.9% global economic expansion, driven by a booming year for equities. Sovereign funds have the greatest exposure to equities, while pension funds are more conservative with a focus on government bonds.

site_title: GM reports smaller-than-expected coronavirus hit in Q2
summary: General Motors reported a smaller-than-expected second-quarter loss of $758 million, or 56 cents per share, as high-margin pickup truck sales and cost-cutting helped mitigate the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The company's retail sales showed signs of recovery, with a decline of 20% in May and June compared to the same period in 2019. GM ended the quarter with $30.6 billion in cash and expects to generate $7-9 billion in cash flow during the second half of the year, depending on the US economy's recovery.

site_title: Shopify beats estimates as more merchants sign up for online boom
summary: Shopify reported stronger-than-expected quarterly revenue and profit, driven by a surge in online shopping amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's gross merchandise volume doubled to $30.1 billion, and revenue nearly doubled to $714.3 million. US-listed shares rose 7% before the bell. The increase in online shopping has benefited Shopify, which generates revenue from subscription fees, payment processing, and logistics services. New stores created on the platform jumped 71% in the second quarter, further fueling the company's growth.

site_title: Britain secures 60m doses of Sanofi/GSK coronavirus vaccine
summary: Britain has secured 60 million doses of a potential coronavirus vaccine being developed by Sanofi and GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), its latest deal in a race to tame the pandemic. This brings the country's total to 250 million doses, with regulatory approval possible by mid-2021 if clinical data is positive. The move comes as the UK, the US, and EU secure large quantities of vaccines, sparking concerns about unequal access to the life-saving treatments.

site_title: Portfolio valuation, Covid impact leads to Hongkong Land's US$1.8b H1 net loss
summary: Hongkong Land reported a net loss of US$1.8 billion in the first half of 2020, primarily due to a US$2.18 billion net non-cash loss from investment property revaluation. Underlying profit fell 24% to US$353 million, impacted by pandemic-related retail rent relief and fewer residential completions. The company expects second-half profits to benefit from higher development completions, but uncertainty remains about the pandemic's impact. An unchanged interim dividend of 6 US cents per share was declared.

site_title: Animal protein, dairy segments drive six-fold increase in Japfa's H1 earnings
summary: Japfa's net profit for its first half grew six times to US$76.8 million due to improved operating profits in its animal protein and dairy segments, driven by high average selling prices for fattened pigs and raw-milk prices in China. Revenue dipped 3% to US$1.8 billion, primarily due to a poor performance by its Indonesian unit. Earnings per share increased to 3.82 US cents from 0.69 cents a year ago.

site_title: STI down 0.37% on muted trading, regional markets' performance mixed
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 9.52 points, or 0.37%, to 2,573.45, due to muted trading. CapitaLand Mall Trust and CapitaLand Commercial Trust were the biggest losers, down 3.98% and 2.89% respectively, after weak earnings last week. Venture Corporation was the biggest gainer, rising 3.58%. The STI saw more losers than gainers, with 215 versus 185 transactions.

site_title: Thai PM's advisor Sethaput named central bank chief
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved Sethaput Suthiwart-Narueput, an economic advisor to Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha and former World Bank economist, as the new central bank governor for five years. He will succeed Veerathai Santiprabhob and face the challenge of steering the country's economy through the coronavirus pandemic. Analysts see limited monetary policy implications from Sethaput's appointment, citing his experience as a member of the Bank of Thailand's Monetary Policy Committee since 2014.

site_title: Foreign workers: Boon or bane to Singapore?
summary: Singapore's reliance on foreign workers has sparked debate over whether they are a boon or bane to the country. Proponents argue that foreign labor brings benefits such as lower costs and increased competitiveness, while opponents cite concerns over worsening income inequality and social friction. A rational approach would require weighing the benefits and costs, with a sector-based calibration to determine the optimal size of the foreign labor force. The market mechanism can achieve allocative efficiency, but dynamic efficiency and equity concerns necessitate intervention. Ultimately, a finely calibrated policy is needed to minimize the negative impacts on migrant workers, while also maintaining Singapore's competitiveness and growth.

site_title: Lian Beng posts 12.8% drop in net profit
summary: Lian Beng Group posted a 12.8% drop in net profit to S$28.7 million in FY20 due to a higher share of loss of associates and investment properties. Revenue rose 43.8% to S$556 million, driven by construction projects. The group expects to incur additional costs due to the COVID-19 pandemic and a controlled restart of construction activities. It has an order book of S$1.6 billion, supporting its activities through FY23, subject to time extensions. Performance in FY21 is expected to be affected by the pandemic and other challenges.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong shares ended higher, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.45% to 24,883.14. The Shanghai Composite Index jumped 2.06%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index rallied 2.90%. Investors await a Federal Reserve policy decision and US stimulus talks, which may influence markets.

site_title: Prada flags recovery in Asia after virus hits H1 sales
summary: Prada reports a sharp recovery in Asian sales after the COVID-19 pandemic hit the luxury fashion group in the first half of 2020. Sales declined 40% globally, with analysts initially forecasting a 35% decrease. However, Prada saw a 60% increase in retail sales growth in mainland China and 66% in July, with e-commerce sales surging 300%. The company aims to break even by the end of 2020, citing cost-cutting measures and direct control over its supply chain.

site_title: Thailand extends state of emergency for fourth time to curb Covid-19
summary: Thailand's Cabinet extended the country's state of emergency for a fourth time, through August 31, to curb the spread of COVID-19. The decision comes after two months without local transmission cases, but officials remain cautious due to recent outbreaks in other countries. The extension has sparked criticism, with anti-government protesters calling for Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha's resignation. The government denies targeting protesters, citing the need to control the pandemic.

site_title: China denies harboring 1MDB fugitive Jho Low
summary: China denies protecting fugitive financier Jho Low, who is being sought by global investigators over the multi-billion dollar 1MDB scandal. Malaysia's national police chief claims Low is hiding in Macau, but Chinese authorities reject the accusations as "groundless and unacceptable". China states it will continue to assist Malaysia in its investigations, despite Low's previous claim of asylum in an unidentified country. The 1MDB scandal has led to charges in Malaysia and the US against Low, and former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak, who co-founded the fund.

site_title: OUE and Fragrance Group expect net losses for H1 2020
summary: Singaporean property companies OUE and Fragrance Group are expected to record net losses for the first half of 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. OUE expects a loss of S$61.9 million, reversing from a net profit a year ago, mainly due to the disposal of US properties and weaker hospitality division performance. Fragrance Group also expects a net loss for the six-month period ended June 30, with no specific details provided. Both companies will release their full financial results on August 14 and 15, respectively.

site_title: GE reports quarterly loss as coronavirus pandemic hits hard
summary: General Electric reported a US$2.18 billion quarterly loss due to the coronavirus pandemic, with free cash outflow from industrial operations totaling US$2.1 billion. Total revenue fell 24% to US$17.75 billion, with a loss per share of 27 cents from continuing operations. This marks a significant decline from the same period last year, when the loss was 3 cents per share.

site_title: Hin Leong owners try to block OCBC from picking at shipping units
summary: The family of Hin Leong Trading's founder, Lim Oon Kuin, is attempting to block a request from creditor OCBC to appoint judicial managers for Xihe Holdings and four of their subsidiaries to recoup debt. OCBC seeks to freeze the Lim family's assets to protect its interests as a lender to Hin Leong and its shipping company Ocean Tankers, which owes OCBC $250 million. The case has been adjourned until August 13, with the companies working towards a consensual restructuring.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on upbeat earnings; Fed in focus
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Wednesday, driven by positive earnings updates and expectations of a dovish Federal Reserve tone. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.03%, the S&P 500 gained 0.27%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.70%. Hopes for government support plan next steps were overshadowed, allowing earnings reports to dominate the market. The Fed's upcoming decision will be closely watched, with investors seeking a dovish tone to support the market.

site_title: India's top airline IndiGo to raise at least 20b rupees via leaseback
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, plans to raise at least 20 billion rupees (S$367.1 million) through the sale and leaseback of planes and assets to boost finances. The airline reported its steepest quarterly loss in five years, with a net loss of 28.49 billion rupees in April to June. IndiGo aims to operate 40% of its average seat capacity from July to September and 60-70% in the following quarter, if rules allow. The airline is also cutting 10% of its workforce and reducing employee costs by 30% by the end of the year.

site_title: EU executive signs remdesivir deal with Gilead
summary: The European Union's executive has signed a contract with Gilead for remdesivir, a COVID-19 medicine, worth 63 million euros to treat 30,000 patients with severe symptoms starting in early August. The EU will cover immediate needs, with a joint procurement plan to cover additional needs from October onwards.

images.alt_text: The European Union's executive said on Wednesday it has signed a contract with Gilead for its Covid-19 medicine remdesivir that would cover 30,000 patients in the bloc from early August.

site_title: MAS calls on local banks to cap FY20 dividends at 60% of previous year's
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has urged local banks to cap their total dividends per share for FY2020 at 60% of the previous year's amount to bolster their resilience amid the uncertain economic climate. Shareholders will also be offered the option to receive dividends in scrip instead of cash. The move aims to conserve capital and support lending to businesses and individuals during a prolonged period of uncertainty. The 60% cap balances capital conservation with shareholder interests and applies to the revised FY2019 period.

site_title: 10-year-old boy among imported Covid-19 patients in Singapore
summary: A 10-year-old boy from India, among four imported COVID-19 patients, was confirmed to have the virus in Singapore. The other imported patients are a 36-year-old Singaporean woman, a 26-year-old Filipino work pass holder, and an 18-year-old Indonesian student. All four were placed on 14-day stay-home notices and tested positive for COVID-19. Meanwhile, 327 migrant workers living in dormitories were also confirmed to have the virus, bringing Singapore's total cases to 51,531.

site_title: Boeing unveils sweeping production cuts as pandemic hammers sales
summary: Boeing announced sweeping production cuts amid the COVID-19 pandemic, slashing production on its widebody programs and delaying the 737 MAX's return to service. The company reported a bigger-than-expected quarterly loss, with sales tumbling 25% to $11.81 billion. Boeing also confirmed the demise of its iconic 747 and reduced production rates for its 787 and 777/777X jets. The company is working closely with airlines and suppliers to manage the downturn, with CEO Dave Calhoun stating that air travel has proven resilient.

site_title: Dairy Farm's H1 net profit drops 35% on Covid-19 impact
summary: Dairy Farm International reported a 35% drop in net profit to US$115 million in the first half of the year, attributed to reduced contributions from its health and beauty segment and the impact of COVID-19 on customer behaviors. Despite a 6% increase in total sales to US$14.5 million, the company's sales by subsidiaries fell 9% due to store closures and pandemic-related restrictions. An interim dividend of 5 US cents per share has been declared, 23% lower than the 2019 interim dividend.

site_title: Spotify revenue hit as coronavirus deters advertisers
summary: Spotify's revenue declined 21% in the second quarter due to a decrease in ad revenue from the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite a 29% increase in monthly active users and 138 million paid subscribers, the company missed quarterly revenue expectations. Spotify forecast a soft current quarter, with ad revenue expected to grow but at a "pretty minimal" rate. The company still expects to hit its full-year financial targets, but analysts noted a "mix shift" to lower price tiers and geographies weighing on subscription average revenue per user.

images.alt_text: Spotify Technology missed quarterly revenue expectations on Wednesday and forecast a soft current quarter, due mainly to a decline in ads as the Covid-19 pandemic kept advertisers at bay.

site_title: US goods trade deficit narrows; global flow of goods improving
summary: The US goods trade deficit narrowed to $70.6 billion in June, a 6.1% drop, as exports rebounded after months of decline. Exports of motor vehicles and parts surged 144.1%, while imports of the same category increased 107.7%. Despite a smaller deficit, the economy's overall performance remains weak, with GDP expected to contract at a 34.1% annualized rate in the second quarter. Retail and wholesale inventories also declined, offsetting the smaller deficit.

site_title: Hong Kong's recession extends with 9% drop in Q2
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted 9% in the second quarter, its fourth consecutive quarter of decline, due to the coronavirus pandemic and political tensions. This marks the first recession in a decade. The economy contracted 0.1% in the three months to June, with tourism and the event industry heavily impacted. The outlook for Q3 remains challenging, with another quarter of negative growth likely. The recession follows a revised 9.1% drop in the first quarter, the worst since 1974 data.

site_title: Japan's ANA posts 159b yen Q1 loss as Covid-19 curbs travel
summary: Japan's ANA Holdings reported a Q1 operating loss of 159 billion yen ($2.08 billion) due to Covid-19 travel curbs. The airline did not provide an annual forecast, citing slow recovery to pre-Covid demand. ANA's CFO, Ichiro Fukuzawa, plans to issue guidance for the current fiscal year in its half-year results announcement, which has not yet been scheduled. This marks a change from the airline's recent mid-year results announcement in October or November.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Q2 net profit surges on Covid-19 demand, doubles dividend
summary: Sheng Siong's Q2 net profit more than doubled to S$46.2 million, driven by strong revenue growth, improved gross margin, and government grants. Revenue rose 75.8% to S$418.7 million, mainly due to elevated Covid-19 demand. The company also increased its interim cash dividend to 3.5 cents per share, double the previous year. Sheng Siong expects the Covid-19 demand to ease with the economy's gradual reopening, while competition in the supermarket industry may remain keen due to e-commerce platforms' growing visibility.

site_title: Surbana Jurong, Nippon Koei tie up to create urban development solutions
summary: Surbana Jurong and Nippon Koei have partnered to deliver sustainable and resilient urban development solutions worldwide. They signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to harness their combined knowledge and expertise in climate change adaptation, resilience enhancement, and smart technologies. The partnership aims to promote sustainable urban development, especially in Asia, through public-private partnerships and smart technologies. This collaboration builds on their existing work on sustainability and resiliency projects since 2018, including the New Clark City project in the Philippines.

site_title: Nomura cuts dozens of jobs at US investment-banking unit
summary: Nomura Holdings cut dozens of jobs at its US investment bank, affecting less than 10% of its US investment-banking staff, amid the coronavirus pandemic's clouding business prospects. This move is the first under new CEO Kentaro Okuda, who has ordered managers to review business operations. The cuts are separate from earlier reductions in the Tokyo-based company's Instinet equity-research division. The move comes as rivals such as Morgan Stanley and Citigroup also start retrenching due to uncertain macroeconomic conditions. Nomura swung back to profit last quarter, benefiting from buoyant trading conditions.

site_title: Australia: Shares give up gains on virus worries; Fed decision awaited
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 6,006.4 on Wednesday, reversing early gains amid concerns over the worsening domestic coronavirus crisis and ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy decision. Investors exercised caution, with the mining sector losing 1.6% and key earnings reports from US tech companies set to impact the market. A record decline in Australian consumer prices also dampened sentiment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.48 points to 1,611.42. Volume reached 10.537 billion lots worth RM6.953 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 685 to 398.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at 6-month high on Samsung Electronics rally, foreign buying
summary: South Korean shares reached a 6-month high on Wednesday, driven by a surge in Samsung Electronics and strong foreign buying. The Kospi index rose 0.27% to 2,263.16 points, with foreigners investing $244.46 million in shares. This is the largest foreign buying in nearly seven years. The gains were capped by US economic stimulus negotiations, but the rally extended into a third session.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as yen rises
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.15% to 22,397.11, extending its losing streak for a fourth trading day. A strong yen and declines on Wall Street contributed to the downturn. The broader Topix index also dropped 1.28% to 1,549.04.

site_title: Europe: Equities waver in early deals
summary: Europe's main stock markets wavered in early deals on Wednesday, with London flatlining, Frankfurt sliding 0.2%, and Paris shifting higher by 0.4%. London's FTSE 100 index remained unchanged, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index dipped to 12,811.67 points. The Paris CAC 40 index, however, rose to 4,948.65 points, driven by gains in the mining and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Singapore Airlines reports S$1.12b Q1 loss due to pandemic
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a net loss of S$1.12 billion in its Q1, primarily due to weaker operating performance and the financial impact of NokScoot's liquidation. Revenue fell 79.3% due to a sharp drop in passenger traffic, but cargo load factor improved. The airline expects passenger capacity to recover to less than half of pre-pandemic levels by FY21, with a projected net loss of S$1.83 billion for FY21. The company is scaling back operations and reviewing its fleet size and mix to mitigate losses.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines on Wednesday reported a S$1.123 billion first-quarter net loss after drastically cutting capacity due to the decline in demand and travel restrictions associated with the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong could postpone Sept 6 election for city legislature: report
summary: Hong Kong's government may postpone the September 6 election for the city legislature due to a resurgence in coronavirus cases. This move could hinder the opposition pro-democracy camp's attempt to win a majority in the assembly, following Beijing's imposition of a new security law. The delay would be a blow to the pro-democracy camp, which won a majority in lower-level district council elections last year.

site_title: Barclays trading surges, offsetting British retail turmoil
summary: Barclays' traders reported a 60% gain in foreign-exchange, rates, and credit trading revenue in the second quarter, offsetting the bank's struggles in its British retail market. The bank took a £1.6 billion charge for anticipated bad loans, bringing the total to £3.7 billion. Barclays' chief executive officer Jes Staley attributed the trading surge to market volatility, but warned that the bank may experience stronger capital headwinds in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Barclays' traders had a blockbuster second quarter, overshadowing the misery for retail and business customers in its home British market.

site_title: Five Singapore listcos warn of losses; ISDN expects 50% rise in H1 profit
summary: Singapore-listed companies have issued profit guidance, with five warning of net losses. ISDN Holdings expects a 50% rise in net profit for the first half year, while BRC Asia, Aspen, AEI Corporation, and Metal Component Engineering anticipate losses for the half year. Yinda Infocomm expects a net loss for the full year. The companies will disclose further details of their financial performance on or before August 14.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's total employment in Q2 shrank by 121,800, a record quarterly contraction. A consultation report recommends phasing out Sibor in 3-4 years and replacing it with SORA to deepen SORA markets. NTUC and unions censured layoffs at a joint venture between P&W and SIA Engineering. Utico offers to help Hyflux, potentially saving the water treatment firm from judicial management. TD Ameritrade Singapore removes commissions on online trades, and DBS to pilot face-verification technology for digital banking signups. The STI fell 0.37% due to muted trading.

site_title: Australia hopes for 'magnificent' wheat crop in pandemic economy
summary: Australia is expecting a "magnificent" wheat crop this season, with mid-season crops in major eastern grain-growing areas thriving after a three-year drought. The country's chief commodity forecaster has lifted wheat production forecasts to 26.7 million tonnes, more than 75% above the prior year's level. Tractor sales are booming, with over 2,000 tractors sold in June, and demand for equipment finance surged 27% in the same period. However, uncertainty remains over crop production, particularly in Western Australia, which needs a good rain to reach its full potential.

site_title: Consultation report recommends phasing out Sibor in 3-4 years, and replacing it with SORA
summary: A consultation report recommends phasing out Singapore Interbank Offered Rates (Sibor) in 3-4 years and replacing it with the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA) as the main interest rate benchmark for SGD financial markets. The report aims to deepen SORA markets, increase transparency, and facilitate efficient risk management. The shift will also avoid market fragmentation and promote the development of deep and efficient SGD financial markets. The transition will be done in a phased approach, with contracts referencing 1M and 3M Sibor transitioning after the industry completes the transition from SOR to SORA.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of Federal Reserve decision as US lawmakers haggle
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with investors hoping for continued dovish monetary policy. Gold prices remained steady at record highs, driven by ongoing uncertainty over the coronavirus, a weaker dollar, and geopolitical worries. The Fed concludes its policy meeting later in the day, with expectations of no new measures but hopes for extended stimulus guarantees. The US is also struggling to pass a new stimulus package, with lawmakers haggling over a $1 trillion plan.

site_title: Fintechs face pressure to grow up as coronavirus casts a chill
summary: Fintech companies face significant challenges due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with venture capital investments decreasing by 41% in the second quarter to $6.3 billion. Fintech startups are struggling to secure funding, with Dozens founder Aritra Chakravarty seeking £15 million through crowd funding and government-backed schemes. The decline in investments is attributed to a "bearish market" and decreased investor confidence. Fintech companies must adapt to these market conditions to survive and continue growing in the industry.

site_title: Australia fast-tracks plan to send solar power to Singapore
summary: Australia has granted "major project status" to a plan to send solar power from a giant solar farm in the Northern Territory to Singapore and Indonesia via a 3,700 km undersea cable, valued at A$22 billion. The project, backed by Mike Cannon-Brookes and Andrew Forrest, aims to supply a fifth of Singapore's power needs and create thousands of jobs. The Australian government's support includes a single entry point for national approvals and assistance with state and territory approvals, with commercial operations planned to begin in 2027.

site_title: Axington proposes to change core business to medical, consumer wellness services
summary: Axington Inc, a Catalist-listed professional advisory services group, has proposed a name change to NETX Inc and a shift in its core business to medical and consumer wellness services. The company will acquire Malaysian medical products distributor Vesta Apex Trading for S$12 million. Axington also plans to raise funds through a S$6 million share placement, a compliance placement, and a S$9.4 million two-for-one rights issue to support its new business direction.

site_title: GSK profit misses target as vaccine sales disappoint, stockpiling eases
summary: GSK reported a quarterly profit miss, falling short of expectations due to disappointing vaccine sales and easing stockpiling of pain and lung medication. Sales of existing vaccines fell 29% to £1.1 billion, while Shingrix sales were above estimates at £323 million. Despite this, GSK maintains its 2020 forecast of a 1-4% decline in adjusted earnings per share, depending on vaccination rates, particularly in the US. The company has instead focused on contributing its adjuvant technology to other firms and developing a Covid-19 vaccine in partnership with Sanofi.

site_title: NTUC, unions rebuke 'unfair' layoffs at P&W, SIA Engineering joint venture
summary: NTUC and three unions have publicly censured and halted "unfair" layoffs at a joint venture between Pratt & Whitney and SIA Engineering, affecting over 100 workers. The management had released specific employees before finalizing the name list with the unions, despite ongoing negotiations. The unions and NTUC have since secured better outcomes for the affected staff, including a fair-compensation package and additional training grants, after reviewing the selection criteria and negotiating with the management.

site_title: Citicode proposes to buy Livingstone Health for up to S$72m in RTO
summary: Citicode has proposed to acquire Livingstone Health for up to S$72 million in a reverse takeover (RTO), with a base consideration of S$47 million and deferred consideration of S$25 million. The deal will reduce Citicode's shares outstanding from 41.3 billion to 82.6 million and transfer its listing status to the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. The acquisition aims to reposition Livingstone for growth opportunities in Singapore and Asean, with Citicode seeking to expand and diversify into the healthcare sector.

site_title: Business group urges Asean-level effort to curb plastic waste
summary: ASEAN governments were urged to develop a circular economy focused on plastic waste to drive sustainable growth. The EU-Asean Business Council proposed waste collection, separation, and reuse systems, as well as formalizing the waste management sector and setting regional recycling standards. A regional framework agreement on plastic pollution and research into sustainable polymers were also recommended. The council expects a circular approach to lower production costs, create jobs, and boost trade and investment. A circular economy will be vital in addressing climate change and waste complications, according to council chairman Donald Kanak.

site_title: Heathrow steps up calls for passenger tests to limit quarantine
summary: London Heathrow airport is urging the UK government to introduce Covid-19 testing for arriving passengers to boost travel demand. The airport posted a £93 million loss in the second quarter due to lockdowns and a 96% decline in passengers. Heathrow CEO John Holland-Kaye calls for a passenger testing regime to end the "quarantine roulette" and allow for more predictable travel planning. The UK's 14-day quarantine for arrivals is weighing on demand, with airlines and the airport seeking a solution to revive the industry.

site_title: Japan to forecast real GDP will shrink around 4.5% in FY2020: Nikkei
summary: Japan's government forecasts its real GDP will contract by 4.5% in FY2020, a significant revision from its initial 1.4% expansion projection. The country is expected to recover in the current quarter and grow 3.5% in FY2021. Japan's economic outlook is more optimistic than other projections, driven by stimulus packages worth US$2.2 trillion. The government's target to reach nominal GDP of 600 trillion yen by 2020 has been delayed to 2023.

site_title: China Three Gorges mulling US$4b stake sale in overseas unit: sources
summary: China Three Gorges is considering selling a US$4 billion stake in its overseas unit, potentially 10-20% of its international assets, to sovereign funds like Singapore's GIC and China Investment Corp. The move aims to reduce debt and implement mixed-ownership reform, increasing efficiency and competitiveness. The overseas portfolio could be valued at US$20 billion, with potential listing or asset sales considered later. Talks are progressing slowly due to severe flooding and the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. No final decision has been made, and the stake size may change depending on the assets included.

site_title: Arm accuses China venture ex-CEO of blocking its business
summary: Arm, a UK-based chip designer, has accused the ousted CEO of its China joint venture, Allen Wu, of blocking its business there after he refused to step down despite being fired. Wu has hired security and is refusing to negotiate, sparking a dispute over foreign investment in China. The situation has raised concerns about Beijing's willingness to protect overseas investors, with both parties urging the Chinese government to intervene and resolve the disagreement. The dispute has cast uncertainty over SoftBank's plans to sell Arm, a major player in the global smartphone and computing industry.

site_title: Temasek's US$3b bid in focus as Keppel set to post weak results
summary: Temasek's US$3 billion bid to acquire a controlling stake in Keppel Corp may be at risk due to Keppel's weak quarterly results, which include a 21% drop in net profit and material impairments in its offshore and marine segment. Analysts say Keppel needs to meet specific profit thresholds to avoid invoking material adverse change clauses, but the company has a long-stop date and Temasek has the right to waive pre-conditions. The deal has a deadline of October 21, and Temasek's stake is currently around 21%.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holding's US$3 billion bid to acquire a controlling stake in Keppel Corp will be under scrutiny on Thursday as a big quarterly profit drop at the conglomerate could raise the risk of the state investor dropping its proposal, analysts said.

site_title: With 1,592 new deaths, US daily virus toll at highest in 2.5 months: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US recorded 1,592 new coronavirus deaths in 24 hours, the highest daily toll in 2.5 months, according to Johns Hopkins University. This brings the total US deaths to over 643,000. The country also saw over 60,000 new cases in a single day. The surge in cases and deaths is attributed to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: AI tech startup ComplyAdvantage nabs US$50m in Series C funding
summary: ComplyAdvantage, a London-based AI startup, has secured US$50 million in Series C funding led by the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board. Existing investors Index Ventures and Balderton Capital also participated in the round. The startup will use the investment to expand its product and market presence across the US, Europe, and Asia-Pacific regions.

site_title: China records highest new-case count in three months
summary: China reported 101 new coronavirus cases on July 29, its highest single-day figure in three months. The majority of cases (98) were domestic infections in the northwestern region of Xinjiang, linked to a cluster at a food processing plant in Dalian. Authorities have closed gyms, bars, and museums in the city and increased oversight of imported goods and people leaving Dalian. With over 84,000 infected and 4,634 related deaths, China continues to face challenges in controlling the virus.

site_title: China halts HK extradition treaties with Canada, Australia, UK in retaliation
summary: China has suspended extradition treaties with Canada, Australia, and the UK in retaliation for their decisions to rescind or suspend similar treaties due to Hong Kong's new security law. Western nations have criticized the law as an erosion of Hong Kong's civil liberties, while China defends it as necessary to restore order. The US is also preparing to rescind Hong Kong's special trading privileges.

site_title: German ministers face grilling over Wirecard collapse
summary: Germany's finance and economy ministers, Olaf Scholz and Peter Altmaier, will face questioning by lawmakers over the Wirecard collapse, amid criticism that authorities failed to act on early warning signs of massive fraud. Wirecard filed for insolvency after admitting 1.9 billion euros missing from its accounts did not exist. Former CEO Markus Braun has been arrested, and both ministers have vowed full transparency in the case, which has drawn comparisons to the Enron accounting scandal. The scandal has also led to calls for reforms to the German finance watchdog Bafin.

site_title: Ant's IPO bonanza for Silver Lake, Warburg, Carlyle
summary: US private equity firms Silver Lake Management, Warburg Pincus, and Carlyle Group, backed by US pension funds, are set to reap significant gains from Ant Group's highly anticipated IPO. The firms invested at least $500 million each in Ant in 2018, valuing the fintech giant at $150 billion. If Ant's valuation reaches $210 billion, the funds could generate a 40% return. The investments are part of a larger trend of US pension funds supporting China's tech giants, sparking scrutiny from US lawmakers.

images.alt_text: A raft of US private equity firms backed by the country's largest endowment and pension funds stands to reap big gains from Ant Group's highly anticipated initial public offering (IPO), even as US lawmakers push funds to halt investments in China.

site_title: Global airlines less hopeful on Covid-19 recovery
summary: Global airlines have cut their coronavirus recovery forecast, expecting passenger traffic to return to pre-crisis levels in 2024, a year later than previously expected. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) cited slow virus containment, corporate travel decline, and new restrictions weighing on recovery. June passenger numbers dropped 86.5% year-on-year, and IATA predicts a 55% decline in 2020 passenger numbers, with business travel facing a sustained slump. A reasonably priced testing regime is seen as crucial for international travel to rebound significantly.

site_title: TD Ameritrade Singapore removes commissions on online stock, ETF and option trades
summary: TD Ameritrade Singapore has announced it will eliminate commissions on online stock, ETF, and option trades for clients trading US markets in Singapore, effective August 3. The move slashes fees from $10.65 to zero, with options clients paying $0.70 per contract with no exercise or assignment fees. The decision is seen as a response to growing demand for US stock trading services in Singapore, with TD Ameritrade Singapore's business model diversifying its offerings.

site_title: Deutsche Bank posts Q2 loss amid restructuring and coronavirus crisis
summary: Deutsche Bank posted a Q2 net loss of 77 million euros, narrower than a 3.3 billion euro loss last year. The loss is attributed to the bank's costly restructuring amid the coronavirus crisis. Despite expectations, the result was slightly better than analysts anticipated. This comes as the bank continues to navigate the ongoing pandemic and economic uncertainty.

site_title: DBS to pilot face-verification tech to lure more digital banking signups
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has partnered with the Government Technology Agency of Singapore to pilot its SingPass face-verification technology to attract more digital banking signups. The pilot aims to reach 1 million DBS customers who are SingPass holders but do not use digital banking services. The technology, which uses facial recognition to verify identities, will also be available for other products and services by the end of 2020. This move follows digitalization trends accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, with seniors increasingly turning to digital banking.

site_title: Utico seeks Sias endorsement as Hyflux judicial management looms
summary: Utico is seeking the endorsement of the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) for its proposed rescue package for Hyflux, a distressed water treatment firm. The proposal, which could "save" Hyflux from judicial management and guarantee the highest possible recovery for holders of Hyflux's perpetual securities and preference shares, has been met with skepticism by a group of bank lenders. Despite Utico's emphasis that its deal is the only viable option, the lenders and some investors have expressed doubts about the proposal, citing concerns over the need for 25.1% support from senior debt holders and the lack of a concrete plan to resolve debts owed to perpetual securities and preference shareholders.

site_title: Credit Suisse to merge investment bank and trading in revamp: sources
summary: Credit Suisse plans to merge its investment bank and trading units into its global markets trading unit, combining risk and compliance units in a bid to increase profitability and tighten controls. The move aims to address recent losses and scandal-related deals, including those linked to Luckin Coffee and Wirecard. CEO Thomas Gottstein seeks to revamp the business, following a series of high-profile incidents, including a spying incident and a turbulent phase during the coronavirus outbreak. The changes are expected to be announced as part of the bank's second-quarter results.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 0.51 points to 1,610.45, driven by a 0.03% increase. The market saw 511.99 million lots traded worth RM199.84 million, with gainers beating losers 240 to 113. The rally follows a 5-day streak of gains in Singapore's STI index, which rose 0.4% on Thursday despite US tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day slightly down, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.25% to 24,710.51. Investors are awaiting the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, hoping for continued easy money policies. The benchmark Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also slipped, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.19% and the Shenzhen Composite Index easing 0.23%. Market focus is shifting to the US Federal Reserve's meeting, with investors seeking indications on the continuation of its monetary policies.

site_title: Singapore's total employment in Q2 sees biggest quarterly contraction on record
summary: Singapore's total employment in Q2 2020 saw its largest quarterly contraction on record, declining by 121,800, a more-than-fourfold fall from Q1. This brings the total employment decline for the first six months of 2020 to 147,500. The contraction was broad-based across the manufacturing, services, and construction sectors. The country's employment decline was triggered by the "circuit-breaker" period to curb the spread of Covid-19.

site_title: Fitch lowers credit outlook on Japan to negative on Covid-19 impact
summary: Fitch has lowered Japan's credit outlook to negative due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on its economy. The country's economy is expected to contract by 5% in 2020 and rebound to 3.2% growth in 2021. Japan's fiscal support and recovery in external demand are expected to help the economy return to quarterly growth in the second half of 2020, but larger fiscal deficits could add to public debt. The Bank of Japan is expected to keep interest rates at current levels until at least 2022.

images.alt_text: Rating agency Fitch on Wednesday revised its outlook on Japan's long-term foreign currency debt rating to negative from stable, citing the sharp coronavirus-induced domestic economic contraction.

site_title: Thai tourist arrivals slump 66% y-o-y in Jan-June amid pandemic
summary: Thailand recorded a 66% year-on-year decline in tourist arrivals from January to June, with 6.69 million visitors, and a 65% decline in spending to 332 billion baht (S$14.52 billion). The country has maintained its border closures amid the pandemic, with no foreign tourist arrivals in June for the third consecutive month. This slump marks a significant downturn from the record 39.8 million tourist arrivals in 2020.

site_title: TransferWise's valuation jumps to US$5b; firm partners Singapore neobank Aspire
summary: TransferWise, a fintech firm focused on foreign-exchange transactions, has raised US$319 million in a secondary share sale, valuing the company at US$5 billion. The UK-based company, which serves eight million customers, processes £4 billion in cross-border payments monthly. New investors include US hedge fund D1 Capital Partners and Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen's Vulcan Capital. TransferWise has seen an uplift in customers during the Covid-19 pandemic and plans to launch new products, including savings and investment products in the UK and passive investment products in Singapore.

site_title: eBay beats second-quarter profit estimates, raises FY outlook
summary: eBay Inc. beat second-quarter profit estimates, with adjusted profit per share between $3.47 and $3.59, exceeding analysts' expectations. The e-commerce company benefited from increased online shopping due to the pandemic. Despite this, shares fell 3% to $54.75 in extended trade, likely due to concerns over the new CEO's potential impact on the company's competitive position. Revenue rose to $2.87 billion, beating estimates, and the company raised its full-year outlook.

site_title: Singapore equities under pressure amid US stimulus impasse; STI dips 0.3% at open
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 2,574.84, following a negative lead from the US due to an impasse in US economic stimulus negotiations. Local lenders DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank slipped into the red, while Ascendas India Trust gained 5.3%. The STI has dipped 0.3% at the open, with 96 losers outnumbering 78 gainers.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam warns city on verge of large coronavirus outbreak
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam has warned the city is on the brink of a large-scale coronavirus outbreak, urging people to stay indoors as strict new measures take effect. The new regulations ban gatherings, close dining, and make face masks mandatory, with measures in place for at least seven days. This comes after a spike in locally transmitted cases, with 98 new cases reported on Tuesday, bringing the total to over 2,880 infected since January, with 23 deaths. The measures aim to protect the city's healthcare system and prevent a collapse of the hospital system.

site_title: Oil falls as US stimulus package faces tough talks
summary: US oil prices fell on Tuesday as lawmakers struggled to agree on an economic stimulus package, raising concerns about demand and market sentiment. Brent crude futures dropped 0.4% to $43.22 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 1.4% to $41.04 a barrel. The US stimulus package is facing opposition from Democrats and some Republicans, and investors are worried about a rise in coronavirus cases worldwide, which could weigh on oil demand.

site_title: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine worked well in monkeys: study
summary: A study published in the New England Journal of Medicine found that Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine induced a robust immune response and prevented the coronavirus from replicating in the noses and lungs of monkeys. The vaccine prevented the virus from replicating in the nose, a crucial factor in preventing transmission, and also induced the production of neutralizing antibodies and T-cells. The results suggest that the vaccine is effective in preventing severe disease and transmission, and its unique technology bypasses the need to manufacture viral proteins in the lab, enabling mass production.

site_title: Thai June factory output falls 17.66%, better than forecast
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index (MPI) fell 17.66% in June compared to the previous year, beating forecasts of a 20.4% contraction. The decline was attributed to lower production of cars, petroleum, and tires during the coronavirus outbreak. Capacity utilization in June was 55.21%, a slight increase from May's 52.34%. The results indicate a partial recovery from the pandemic's impact on the country's manufacturing sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen rises
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.50% to 22,543.01, and the Topix index dropping 0.54% to 1,560.61. The decline was driven by a strong yen and drops on Wall Street. This marks the third consecutive day of losses for Tokyo stocks.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with investor sentiment dampened by a strong yen and drops on Wall Street.

site_title: Nissan shares dive 6% after record loss warning
summary: Nissan shares plummeted 6% in early trade on Wednesday after the automaker warned of a record $4.5 billion operating loss this year due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on its turnaround efforts. The warning comes despite a recent bond sale. Nissan's struggles are a result of the ongoing pandemic's effects on the global automotive industry. The company's operating loss is expected to be its highest on record.

site_title: Europe: Defensive stocks help close higher as focus turns to US stimulus
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Tuesday, driven by defensive sectors such as healthcare, food & beverage, and utilities. Travel stocks rebounded from losses on Monday amid concerns of a coronavirus resurgence. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's conclusion on Wednesday, when policymakers are expected to reaffirm their supportive stance and discuss potential fiscal stimulus for the US economy.

images.alt_text: European shares closed modestly higher on Tuesday, as investors assessed a batch of mixed earnings reports while holding out for more US stimulus to limit the economic damage of Covid-19.

site_title: iX Biopharma sees share price slip after proposing S$10.2m placement at discount
summary: iX Biopharma proposed a private placement of 44.5 million new shares at 23 cents apiece to raise S$10.2 million. The placement represents a 27.7% discount to the volume-weighted average price of 31.8 cents per share. The funds will be used for product development, manufacturing, and marketing, with 60% allocated for these activities and 40% for general working capital. The company's directors believe the placement will support future growth as the group transitions to commercialization.

site_title: Gold hits new high; equities struggle on virus fears
summary: Gold reached a record high of $1,981.27 per ounce on Tuesday, driven by virus uncertainty and China-US tensions, with a nearly 30% gain this year. Meanwhile, US equity markets fell amid concerns over a potential fiscal package and rising COVID-19 cases. The global economic outlook remains clouded, and investors are watching for the Federal Reserve meeting and second-quarter GDP estimate. The US stock market closed lower, with lawmakers far apart on a spending plan to boost the economy, and supplemental unemployment benefits set to expire this week.
