site_title: Westpac to move 1,000 overseas call centre jobs to Australia
summary: Westpac Banking Corp plans to bring back 1,000 overseas call centre jobs to Australia, with the process expected to take a year. The move aims to enhance customer assistance and is driven by growing demand during the coronavirus pandemic. The roles will be spread across regional and metro areas, and will result in a rise in costs of approximately A$45 million per year. This move comes as Australia's unemployment rate reached a 22-year high of 7.4% due to the pandemic.

site_title: UOL obtains S$120m green loan from UOB to redevelop Pan Pacific Orchard
summary: UOL Group has obtained a S$120 million green loan from United Overseas Bank (UOB) to redevelop Pan Pacific Orchard into a biophilic hotel with eco-friendly features and a green replacement ratio of over 200%. The hotel, set to open in 2021, will incorporate sustainable features such as rainwater harvesting, solar cells, and a food waste management system. The green loan demonstrates UOL's commitment to greening the urban habitat and aligns with the government's vision to transform Orchard Road into a green oasis.

site_title: HC Surgical's half-year earnings slide 73.6%
summary: HC Surgical Specialists posted a 73.6% decline in net profit to S$1.3 million for the six months ended May 31, 2020, due to Singapore's Covid-19 "circuit-breaker" measures and non-operating items. Revenue fell 29.4% to S$7 million, with a full-year net profit more than halving to S$3.5 million. The company recommended a final dividend of 0.7 Singapore cent per ordinary share, down from FY2019's 1.2 cents per share.

site_title: Zuckerberg to urge US to update 'rules for the Internet'
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is set to testify before the US House Judiciary Committee, urging the need for updated 'rules for the Internet'. Zuckerberg stated that US laws fostering competition were crucial to Facebook's success but acknowledged concerns about tech companies' size and power. He called for a more active role for governments and regulators in updating internet rules. The hearing also features CEOs from Apple, Amazon, and Google, amid growing scrutiny of tech giants' market dominance.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOL, UOB, CapitaLand Retail China Trust, Ascendas India Trust, CDLHT
summary: UOL Group and United Overseas Bank (UOB) saw new developments, with UOL securing a S$120 million three-year green loan from UOB to finance the redevelopment of Pan Pacific Orchard. CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) posted a 41.4% decline in distribution per unit to 3.02 cents for the half year ended June 30. In contrast, Ascendas India Trust (a-iTrust) reported a higher DPU of 4.64 cents for the same period. CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) saw a 63.7% decline in distribution per stapled security to 1.51 cents for the six months ended June 30.

site_title: EU to restrict exports to Hong Kong over security law
summary: The European Union has agreed to restrict exports to Hong Kong of equipment that could be used for surveillance and repression following Beijing's imposition of a new security law. The EU expressed "grave concern" over the law, which it says would severely erode freedoms in Hong Kong. The move comes as EU member states struggle to agree on a united response to China, with some seeking to cooperate and others standing up to Beijing. The decision aims to protect Hong Kong's autonomy and freedoms under the terms of its handover from Britain to China.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on gains in banks as regulator lifts dividend freeze
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Wednesday, boosted by financials and gold stocks, after the country's regulator lifted a dividend freeze due to the coronavirus. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6051.1 points, with top lenders Commonwealth Bank and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group gaining over 2.4% and 3% respectively. Gold stocks also rose, while concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus and an impasse in US economic stimulus negotiations weighed on investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Australian shares edged higher on Wednesday, boosted by strength in financials and gold stocks, although gains were capped as concerns lingered over the economic impact of the coronavirus.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts DPS for H1 tumbles 63.7% to 1.51 S cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts' distribution per stapled security (DPS) plummeted 63.7% to 1.51 Singapore cents for the six months ended June 30, 2020. Gross revenue declined 44.5% to S$52.1 million due to the COVID-19 pandemic's travel restrictions and social distancing measures. Most of the trust's properties were closed or operating at low occupancies from March onwards.

site_title: MacKenzie Scott gives nearly US$1.7b of Amazon fortune to social causes
summary: MacKenzie Scott, ex-wife of Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, has donated nearly $1.7 billion to over 100 nonprofits focused on social causes, including racial equity, economic mobility, and climate change. The largest portion of her philanthropy went to racial equity groups, receiving over $586 million. Scott signed a "giving pledge" last year to donate the bulk of her wealth to charity, citing the need to address complex challenges and the consequences of the Covid-19 pandemic. Her donations aim to create lasting change and promote social justice.

site_title: Half of Mumbai's slum residents have had coronavirus: study
summary: A study in Mumbai found that 57% of slum residents and 16% of non-slum residents have had coronavirus, raising doubts about India's official case numbers. The city has reported 110,000 infections and 6,000 deaths, but deaths in the largest slum, Dharavi, have not exploded due to effective containment efforts. The study suggests asymptomatic infections are common and the virus death rate is likely to be low, contradicting India's official statistics.

images.alt_text: Over half the people living in the slums of Mumbai have had the coronavirus, according to a city-commissioned study released on Tuesday that raises fresh doubts about India's official case numbers.

site_title: Quest advances to recreate sun's energy on earth
summary: Scientists in southern France have begun assembling a giant machine, ITER, designed to demonstrate nuclear fusion, the process powering the sun, as a safe and viable energy source on Earth. The 14-year project, a multinational experiment, aims to produce 500 megawatts of thermal power, equivalent to 200,000 homes. The machine, comprising a million components, will be assembled over the next few years, with initial experiments set to begin in 2025. If successful, fusion power could offer "clean, no-carbon, safe and practically waste-free energy" and potentially supply humanity for millions of years.

site_title: Virgin Galactic unveils space plane's cabin, poised for commercial flights
summary: Virgin Galactic unveiled the interior of its space plane VSS Unity, featuring custom seats and a "space mirror" for commercial flights. Passengers will strap into tailored, teal-colored seats with 12 circular windows, offering zero-gravity conditions at 97km above Earth. The $250,000 ticket price includes a suborbital experience with the ability to float in zero gravity. Virgin Galactic's chief space officer, George Whitesides, emphasized the comfort and unique experience passengers will have.

site_title: McDonald's profits tumble, shifting focus to value amid US economic woes
summary: McDonald's reported a 68% drop in profits to $483.8 million in Q2 2020, amid the coronavirus pandemic. Despite a 30% decline in revenues to $3.8 billion, the company expects the second quarter to be the low point for the year. CEO Chris Kempczinski plans to focus on affordability and value in upcoming marketing campaigns, citing mounting recession fears and economic concerns outweighing public health concerns. The company's sales have been boosted by US fiscal spending, but a potential reduction in unemployment benefits could negatively impact sales.

site_title: US, Australia seek new military cooperation in face of China
summary: The US and Australia have strengthened military cooperation amid escalating tensions with China. The two countries agreed to bolster interoperability in areas such as hypersonic, electronic, and space-based warfare, and to deter malign behavior in the region. The cooperation comes after Australia's foreign and defense ministers expressed support for a hawkish shift on China by the Trump administration. The move is seen as a response to China's growing influence and actions in the South China Sea, as well as cyberattacks against Australia.

site_title: CRCT posts H1 DPU of 3.02 S cents on Covid-19 disruptions
summary: CRCT, a China shopping mall real estate investment trust, reported a half-year distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.02 Singapore cents, down 41.4% from the year-ago DPU of 5.13 cents. Gross revenue fell 7.8% to S$100.6 million, and net property income declined 17.9% to S$65.3 million, due to disruptions from the Covid-19 pandemic and provision of tenant relief packages. The distributable amount to unitholders came in at S$37 million, down 27.7% from the year-ago period.

site_title: ECB urges banks to pause shareholder payouts for longer
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has urged banks to pause shareholder payouts and moderate bonuses until January, extending a request by three months. The ECB aims to conserve capital as the economy recovers from the coronavirus outbreak. Banks, including BNP Paribas, have lobbied to resume dividend payments. The ECB will review its stance in the fourth quarter, considering the economic environment and banks' capital levels.

site_title: Gold loses momentum after hitting record as volatility roils silver
summary: Gold futures hit a record $2,000 an ounce, but momentum waned after touching the high, with prices retreating as investors locked in profits and assessed the market's sustainability. Silver fell the most since March. The US dollar recovered some losses, and investors may seek more bullish signals before pushing prices higher. The economic turmoil caused by the coronavirus pandemic and expected further stimulus may continue to drive prices.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit posts 2.5% rise in Q2 DPU to 3.36 Singapore cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 2.5% increase in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.36 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from Japan's nursing rehabilitation facilities and higher rent from Singapore properties. Gross revenue rose 4.9% to S$30.3 million, and net property income grew 5.3% to S$28.2 million. The Reit's "resilient performance" was attributed to favorable rental lease structures, effective debt management, and prudent financial risk management.

site_title: Hello from the other side - Asia's bigger structural challenges unmasked
summary: Asia's economies face significant structural challenges post-Covid-19, with rising debt-to-GDP ratios and decreased global growth potential due to trade tensions. However, some countries may benefit from diversification of supply chains and lower-cost economies. Productivity reforms, accelerated by the pandemic, can help mitigate these challenges. Economies with lower debt, favorable demographics, and strong institutional reforms are expected to outperform, with India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and China in the strongest structural growth stories. Conversely, Malaysia and Thailand are expected to have weaker structural stories.

site_title: Close to 10% of Singapore mortgages, or over S$15b, under debt moratorium
summary: Singapore's three local banks have granted payment deferments to over S$15 billion worth of mortgages, accounting for almost 10% of all outstanding mortgages. This represents nearly 80% of approved mortgage debt relief applications. Over 34,000 mortgages are undergoing deferment, which is approximately 7% of total outstanding home loans. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is studying how to ease virus relief measures to mitigate debt accumulation.

site_title: Asia needs predictable US policy towards region: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for a stable and predictable US policy towards Asia and Europe to help countries dependent on the US. He urged the next US president to develop bipartisan consensus to ensure policy longevity. Lee also expressed concern over the deteriorating US-China relations, which he believes could have far-reaching consequences, and hoped for the US to rejoin the Trans-Pacific Partnership. He believed that a stable US-China relationship is crucial for Asia's security and predictability.

images.alt_text: A stable and predictable policy towards Asia and Europe with bipartisan consensus will be of great help to countries that are looking to depend on the United States, Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said on Tuesday night.

site_title: US-China tension also playing out in race for WTO top post
summary: The US and China are engaged in a rivalry for the top post of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) amid tensions between the two nations. The Trump administration views the WTO as being influenced by China, while China seeks to expand its diplomatic influence and install key personnel. Two candidates, Amina Mohamed from Kenya and Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala from Nigeria, are vying for the position, with the US and China backing different candidates. The US is seeking a candidate with strong ties to the US and a commitment to WTO reform, while China is looking for someone with a "firm belief in the multilateral trading system".

site_title: Squeezed by superpowers, HSBC eyes next step of reboot
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc is reviewing its US and European operations as the bank faces pressure from superpowers Washington and Beijing. Chairman Mark Tucker is overseeing a review to unload underperforming businesses and cut jobs, with the goal of doubling down on Asia, where HSBC earns nearly all its profit. The bank's shares have fallen to their lowest level in over a decade amid concerns about its future. HSBC has been criticized for its role in the US pursuit of Huawei Technologies Co. official Meng Wanzhou and its support for China's tough new security law in Hong Kong.

site_title: Great Eastern Q2 profit up 76% to S$297.5m
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a net profit of S$297.5 million for Q2 2020, a 76% increase from the previous year, driven by higher operating profit and investment valuations. Despite a slowdown in new business volume due to restricted sales activities, the company's Singapore business registered strong growth, with total weighted new sales rising 7% to S$584.9 million. The board declared an interim one-tier tax-exempt dividend of 10 Singapore cents per share, and expects a challenging economic outlook due to volatility in financial markets and low interest rates.

site_title: US hotels promoting the nostalgia of the family road trip
summary: US hotels are promoting the nostalgia of family road trips to entice Americans to travel this summer. As the country slowly reopens, hotels are focusing on regional destinations and short-haul markets, with marketing campaigns highlighting outdoor activities and local attractions. Hotels are also using social media and data analytics to understand what travelers are searching for and promoting nearby parks, scenery, and simple activities that maintain social distance. The campaigns aim to convince people to drive, rather than take unnecessary plane trips, as many travelers are reluctant to do so due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: One of the Fairmont Scottsdale Princess Hotel's drive-in movie nights, with kid-friendly movies playing in its parking lot in Scottsdale, Arizona.

site_title: Corruption trial of ex-PEMEX boss begins in Mexico
summary: The trial of Emilio Lozoya, former boss of Mexican state oil giant PEMEX, began in Mexico City on Tuesday, accused of taking bribes to fund a presidential campaign. Lozoya, 45, is accused of authorizing the $485 million purchase of a rundown fertilizer factory, a price considered suspiciously high. He is also charged with $4 million in bribes from Brazilian construction giant Odebrecht, allegedly used to pay for Enrique Pena Nieto's 2012 presidential campaign. Lozoya entered a plea of not guilty, claiming he is not responsible for the crimes attributed to him.

images.alt_text: Emilio Lozoya is accused of corruption for authorising PEMEX's acquisition between 2013 and 2015 of a rundown fertiliser factory for US$485 million, a price prosecutors considered suspiciously high given it had been unused for 14 years.

site_title: 'Big Bang' moment for Cambodian stock market
summary: Cambodia's stock market is experiencing a significant milestone with the listing of Acleda Bank Plc, the country's largest commercial bank, on the Cambodia Securities Exchange (CSX). The listing, which took place on May 25, raised US$17.5 million, although below its target of US$34 million. The event is seen as a "big deal" and "game changer" by CSX officials, and is expected to attract more investors to the market. The CSX has set a target to list at least two more companies by the end of 2020, and the government is working to promote access to finance for private companies and improve corporate governance.

site_title: Remote working creates higher risk of online attacks for firms: specialists
summary: Remote working increases the risk of online attacks for firms, as home networks are often less secure than corporate networks. According to the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore, this expanded attack surface makes businesses more susceptible to cyber attacks. Specialists warn that remote employees can inadvertently expose organizations to hacking attempts, highlighting the need for enhanced cybersecurity measures to protect against these threats.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble amid partisan fight on stimulus
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones dropping 0.8%, the S&P 500 shedding 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 1.3%. The decline comes amid a partisan fight over a new stimulus package, with Republican and Democratic proposals differing significantly. The expiration of supplemental unemployment benefits this week adds pressure on Washington to act, and investors await key economic reports and a Federal Reserve meeting. Market strategist Art Hogan described the market's frustration with the Washington gridlock, saying the spread between proposals has not closed.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks tumbled on Tuesday following mixed earnings, and as legislators in Washington appeared far apart on another round of fiscal support for the coronavirus-battered economy.

site_title: America's cult of selfishness is doing the country in
summary: The US response to the coronavirus has been marred by a "cult of selfishness," prioritizing economic growth over public health, resulting in a surge in infections and stalled job growth. The Trump administration and Republican governors ignored mask mandates and social distancing measures, despite the risks to the economy. This self-serving approach is rooted in the modern US right's ideology, which emphasizes the pursuit of self-interest and limited government intervention. The consequences of this ideology are evident in the country's lagging economic recovery and high infection rates, highlighting the need for a more responsible approach to public policy.

site_title: It's too early to write off Trump
summary: The article assesses Donald Trump's presidency, stating that while the probability of his defeat in the November election has increased, it's not certain. Trump's economic buoyancy, driven by tax cuts, is now threatened. His handling of the coronavirus crisis has been less competent than expected, but US pandemic performance is in the mid-ground of international rankings. Trump's unorthodox economic policies, including his stance on debt, have been a surprise to many economists. Despite his shortcomings, the article concludes that it's too early to write him off, and he could still win a second term.

site_title: Tencent offers US$2.1b for Chinese search giant
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd has offered to buy out and take private search engine Sogou Inc for US$2.1 billion, aiming to integrate Sogou's AI technology with its own services and devices to gain an edge over rivals like ByteDance Ltd. The deal is part of a trend of Chinese technology giants seeking to delist from US bourses. Tencent's shares climbed 4.7% on the news, fueling speculation about the potential for further integration and expansion. The takeover is expected to help Tencent solidify its position in the social media market.

site_title: The key investing lessons from Covid-19
summary: Covid-19 has taught investors key lessons, despite its short duration. Two key takeaways are: investing in companies with strong balance sheets, which can be resilient to shocks, and having expectations rather than predictions when making investment decisions. This approach can lead to robust or even antifragile portfolios that can handle various outcomes. The article cautions against jumping to conclusions, such as investing heavily in technology stocks, and emphasizes the importance of understanding the fundamental nature of the stock market and the underlying business performance.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust looking at rental housing; DPS down 69% for H1
summary: Ascott Residence Trust is considering expanding its rental housing portfolio to improve resilience. The trust, citing rental housing's proven resilience, is more selective in its asset acquisitions. CEO Beh Siew Kim noted a longer stay segment in the portfolio. Despite this, the trust's DPS (Distribution Per Share) decreased by 69% for the first half of the year. The trust's managers aim to balance growth with caution, focusing on a longer-term approach.

site_title: Pimco sees defaults rising in Asia as stimulus is wound back
summary: Pimco expects rising defaults in Asia as policymakers cut back on stimulus measures. The investment firm's co-head of Asia-Pacific portfolio management, Robert Mead, warns that companies with high leverage may struggle and be allowed to fail. Analysts, including Goldman Sachs and Moody's, predict a rise in debt delinquency due to a prolonged pandemic. A growing number of Asian firms are deferring bond payments and slipping into junk territory, with Pimco favoring well-managed investment-grade companies and new distressed debt deals. Defaults could be "double digit," according to Mead.

site_title: UK house prices seen growing as much as 3% for rest of 2020
summary: UK house prices are projected to grow by up to 3% for the rest of 2020, driven by a sales-tax break and increased demand following the coronavirus lockdown. In June, prices rose 2.7% from a year earlier, the fastest pace in nearly two years, according to a Zoopla report. This rebound marks a six-month high in homebuyer demand.

site_title: US consumer confidence falls in July
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 92.6 in July, dropping from 98.3 in June, amid a rise in Covid-19 infections threatening the economy's recovery. Economists had forecast a drop to 94.5. The decline in consumer confidence is a concern for the economy's recovery from an unprecedented recession caused by the pandemic.

site_title: Doctor's in, but prognosis is for a slow recovery amid weak medical tourism
summary: Singapore's healthcare sector is experiencing a slow recovery from the pandemic, with patient volumes still below pre-pandemic levels. The resumption of elective treatments and adult vaccinations has boosted hospital and clinic operators, but the loss of earnings from medical tourism is expected to hinder the recovery. Analysts predict that it will take time for patient volumes to return to normal, with many firms reporting net losses or slower-than-expected earnings. Telehealth investments are also being made to mitigate the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: SMEs appear ill-prepared for greater risks of cyberattacks as online workforce rises
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face increased risks of cyberattacks due to the rise of the online workforce during the pandemic. Cybersecurity firms have reported a significant increase in phishing e-mails and malicious URLs related to Covid-19, with some SMEs being inadequately prepared to deal with these threats. Specialists estimate that up to 80% of SMEs in Singapore lack basic cybersecurity measures, which could lead to costly data breaches. Experts advise SMEs to invest in basic cybersecurity tools and implement cost-effective measures to improve their cybersecurity posture.

site_title: Biden proposes Fed focus on closing racial wealth gaps
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden proposed requiring the Federal Reserve to report on closing racial economic gaps, including jobs, wages, and wealth. He aims to amend the Federal Reserve Act to track data and trends, and the Fed's actions to address these gaps. This move is part of Biden's efforts to address persistent racial disparities in the US economy.

site_title: Euro retreats from 2-year high before Fed meeting
summary: The euro retreated from a two-year high due to declining US dollar sales ahead of the Federal Reserve's two-day meeting. Investors expect no monetary policy changes but speculate about a shift in the Fed's forward guidance. The meeting starts on Tuesday, with traders anticipating a reaffirmed outlook.

site_title: Eastman Kodak signs US deal for drug ingredients, says White House's Navarro
summary: Eastman Kodak has signed a deal with the US government to produce pharmaceutical ingredients domestically, worth $765 million under the Defense Production Act. The move aims to reduce reliance on foreign sources. White House trade adviser Peter Navarro announced the agreement, citing the need for speed in domestic production. Eastman Kodak did not immediately comment on the deal.

site_title: Healthcare, mining stocks drive activity; STI up 0.28%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.28% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,582.97 points. Jardine Matheson and Wilmar International were the biggest gainers, while Dairy Farm International was the biggest loser. Penny stocks in the gold-mining and healthcare sectors led trading activity. Regional markets had mixed performances, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 0.26% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index up 0.69%.

site_title: Nissan forecasts sharp sales, profit drop
summary: Nissan Motor Co forecasts a wider-than-expected operating loss of 470 billion yen (S$6.2 billion) for the current fiscal year due to the pandemic's impact on sales and costs. The company plans to accelerate cost-cutting measures, shut three production lines, and cut 14,000 jobs globally. Nissan also skips its dividend, citing the need to restore profitability and sales after reporting its biggest loss in two decades. The company's shares have declined 35% this year, and its performance will reduce Renault's net income by 1.2 billion euros.

site_title: Directors should be required to say if they will take part in cash calls
summary: Singapore Airlines' directors were required to disclose their intention to participate in a $15 billion fundraising exercise, which was oversubscribed. However, only six of the nine directors took up their rights shares and bonds. This raises the question of whether listed company directors should be required to positively disclose their intention to subscribe or not subscribe in a fundraising, particularly when making recommendations to retail investors. The advantages of mandatory disclosure outweigh the disadvantages, promoting a more informed and empowered investing public.

images.alt_text: Unlike in Singapore, it is a common practice among listed companies on the London Stock Exchange to disclose their directors' intention to participate in the proposed fundraising.

site_title: Leader of the Opposition to lead scrutiny of government, receive confidential briefings
summary: Singapore's new Leader of the Opposition, Pritam Singh, will lead the scrutiny of the government, receive confidential briefings, and have double the allowance of a regular MP. Singh, the Workers' Party chief, will present alternative views in parliamentary debates, attend official state functions, and have longer speaking durations in Parliament. He will also receive additional resourcing, parliamentary privileges, and a total annual package of S$385,000, with half donated to charitable causes.

images.alt_text: With more resources for Pritam Singh, more will also be expected of the opposition, SMU professor Eugene Tan said.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit posts lower DPU due to income retention, distribution deferment
summary: Starhill Global Reit posted a 0.7 Singapore cent DPU for its second half, down 68% from last year due to retained income for working capital and deferred distribution. Gross revenue fell 18.5% to S$84.1 million and net property income fell 27% to S$58 million, largely due to rental assistance and lower contributions from Starhill Gallery. The Reit has given out S$32.2 million in rental rebates and S$15.2 million in property tax rebates to eligible tenants during the pandemic.

site_title: Pratt & Whitney JV in Singapore in talks with unions
summary: Pratt & Whitney's majority-owned joint venture, Eagle Services Asia, in Singapore is in talks with unions amid a decline in volumes due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has clarified that no employee has been retrenched, but is reassessing staffing levels. The joint venture, which operates an MRO unit, has seen a significant impact from the pandemic, with P&W's 51:49 partner SIA Engineering Company also affected. The company is monitoring the business environment to make necessary adjustments.

site_title: Fashion designer Kansai Yamamoto, dies at 76
summary: Fashion designer Kansai Yamamoto, known for his flamboyant and unconventional style, died at 76 due to leukemia. A pioneer in Japanese fashion, Yamamoto's work influenced David Bowie and helped define the look of his alter ego, Ziggy Stardust. He was a key figure in the London fashion scene in the 1970s and collaborated with musicians like Elton John and Stevie Wonder. Yamamoto's designs combined traditional Japanese elements with bold colors and shapes, earning him recognition as a leading figure in the fashion industry.

site_title: Teckwah Industrial urged to raise dividend amid earnings downtrend
summary: Activist fund Quarz Capital urges Teckwah Industrial to increase annual dividends to S$7.4 million or 80% of net income, citing the company's lack of cash discipline and operational efficiency. The firm notes that Teckwah's profits have declined, with a 10-year low of S$7.1 million in 2018 and S$8.9 million in 2019. Quarz also criticizes the company's acquisition of Profoto Digital Services, which is likely to be loss-making due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The fund wants Teckwah to professionalize its non-print business and bring in industry expertise to grow its non-print segment.

site_title: Gold's glitter sign of what's to come for the rest of 2020
summary: Gold prices surged past the September 2011 record high of $1,921/oz, reaching an all-time high of $1,941.1/oz, amid the relentless Covid-19 pandemic and economic uncertainty. The precious metal's value has risen over 30% year-to-date, driven by factors such as negative real yields, massive money printing, and the European Union's $2 trillion stimulus deal. The Federal Reserve's expected dovish tone has also fueled the rally, with some predicting gold could reach $3,000/oz over the next 18 months, potentially signaling a gloomy outlook for the rest of 2020.

site_title: UK retailer Matalan to file for US bankruptcy protection
summary: UK discount retailer Matalan will file for Chapter 15 court protection in the US to bolster its balance sheet amid pandemic-induced closures. The company will seek "certain interim relief" and recognition for its debt restructuring in the UK, with £474 million in net debt. As part of the deal, Matalan will obtain £50 million in fresh financing and may trigger the payout of default insurance on its notes. The move comes after the retailer placed over 90% of employees on furlough during the UK lockdown.

site_title: Filipino firms still willing to spend on information technology
summary: Filipino businesses continue to invest in information technology, with 84% of enterprises increasing their ICT budget in 2020, up from 66% in 2019. Key areas of spending include managed cloud services and team collaboration applications, aimed at improving operational efficiency and customer satisfaction.

site_title: Grab plans S$0.30 platform fee but timing draws flak; CCCS seeks feedback
summary: Grab has applied to Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) to impose a platform fee of S$0.30 per ride, or S$0.32 with Goods and Services Tax (GST). The fee aims to cover operating costs and enhance safety measures, with a third of the funds committed to driver welfare benefits. Industry experts have mixed views, with some arguing that the fee is in line with industry norms, while others express concerns that it may reduce demand and negatively impact consumers. The CCCS is inviting public feedback on Grab's request until August 11.

site_title: Najib's guilty verdict could strengthen new government's hand
summary: Malaysia's High Court sentenced former Prime Minister Najib Razak to 12 years in jail after finding him guilty of all seven charges related to RM42 million deposited in his personal accounts from the 1MDB scandal. This verdict is seen as a test of the new government's anti-corruption credentials, potentially strengthening their hand amid months of political turmoil. The conviction brings closure to a long-standing corruption case and sets a precedent for accountability in Malaysia's government.

images.alt_text: Najib Razak (centre), must also pay a fine of RM210 million or face an additional five years imprisonment.

site_title: Johnny Depp: loveable loner tarnished by lurid claims
summary: Johnny Depp's tumultuous private life, marked by substance and alcohol abuse, has been revealed in a London court during his libel battle with ex-wife Amber Heard. The 57-year-old actor, known for his iconic roles, has a history of indulgence, including spending $30,000 a month on wine and lavishing on art and property. Depp admitted to taking drugs but denied any physical violence towards Heard or others, stating it "would never happen". His reputation as a Hollywood maverick has been tarnished by the allegations, which have sparked controversy over his upcoming role as Gellert Grindelwald in the Harry Potter film series.

site_title: Investors lead the rush back into India's offices
summary: Investors, led by Singapore's GIC and MAS, are signaling a shift back to offices in India, with the IPO of Mindspace Business Parks valued at up to $2.2 billion. The company, backed by K Raheja and Blackstone, has delivered a 22% total shareholder return since its float last year, and its tenants include affiliates of Amazon and Facebook. The IPO is seen as a solid endorsement for the Indian office space market, which is expected to benefit from a labor shortage and developers facing financing challenges, potentially leading to reduced supply and increased rents.

site_title: Harley-Davidson posts first loss in more than a decade
summary: Harley-Davidson posted its first quarterly loss in over a decade due to the global pandemic's impact on its restructuring plans. CEO Jochen Zeitz, who took over in February, aimed to shrink the company and focus on core US market sales. However, the move to clear out excess inventory through dealers was hindered, leading to the loss. Zeitz stated that the company will prioritize its legacy over volume growth, despite a five-year sales slump in its core US market.

site_title: Telcos could tap tech to eSIM-plify business
summary: Singapore's telcos are exploring the use of eSIM technology to simplify business operations and tap into the growing demand for embedded SIM cards. M1 and Circles.Life have already launched pre-paid tourist eSIMs and enterprise-focused eSIMs, respectively. A tie-up between Singtel and China Unicom allows enterprise customers to remotely change SIM configurations across borders, enabling cost-effective IoT roll-outs. StarHub is also eyeing the IIoT prize with its eSIM-enabled NumberShare service. The adoption of eSIMs is seen as a way for telcos to adapt to the post-Covid-19 economy and capitalize on emerging trends in IoT and 5G technology.

site_title: UK department store Selfridges to cut 450 jobs due to pandemic hit
summary: UK department store chain Selfridges plans to cut 450 jobs, approximately 14% of its workforce, due to the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic on sales and the UK retail industry. The decision comes as the company aims to make fundamental changes to recover from the crisis. Selfridges, which operates on Oxford Street in London, is one of the latest UK retailers to face significant challenges, including high rents and business taxes. The company's recovery is expected to be slow.

site_title: Covid-19 rule breakers risk setbacks to crew change progress
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is enhancing safety measures in the Port of Singapore to prevent the spread of COVID-19, amid recent cases of crew members testing positive upon arrival. MPA is working with the industry taskforce to provide more detailed guidelines for "safe-corridor" procedures, including self-isolation and accurate COVID-19 testing. The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has condemned non-compliance with crew change protocols, warning that such actions risk setbacks to progress and could lead to the shutdown of crew change processes.

site_title: Global air traffic won't return to pre-crisis level before 2024: Iata
summary: Global air traffic is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels by 2024, a year later than previously forecast, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA). The delay is largely due to uncertainty over border reopenings and the spread of COVID-19. IATA now projects a 63% drop in air traffic for 2020, worse than its previous forecast of 55%, and expects airlines' income to be halved compared to 2019. Factors such as rising COVID numbers in some countries and the lack of widespread reopening, particularly for long-haul travel, are contributing to the slower-than-expected recovery.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on tough stimulus talks, mixed earnings
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, July 28, 2020, amid tough stimulus talks and mixed earnings reports from major companies. The Dow Jones fell 0.21%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.16%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.26%. Investors are weighing the coronavirus relief deal and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Traveloka raises US$250m from unnamed financial institution, EV Growth and others
summary: Traveloka, a Southeast Asia-based online travel startup, has raised $250 million from an undisclosed financial institution and existing investors EV Growth. The funding comes at a critical time as the pandemic affects leisure and business travel. The company plans to use the money to strengthen its balance sheet and expand its offerings in key markets. Despite the challenges, Traveloka has seen encouraging recovery in its key markets, including Vietnam and Thailand, with promising momentum in Indonesia and Malaysia.

site_title: Redefining the status quo in healthcare
summary: Dean Ho, 41, is leading efforts to develop AI-based solutions for personalized patient care and novel drug development. As research director, he aims to make high-quality healthcare more accessible at lower costs. His institute is working on AI-based platforms for clinical trials, including optimal drug combinations to treat Covid-19. Ho's vision is to scale the validation, deployment, and implementation of these platforms, revolutionizing the healthcare industry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 18.46 points to 1,609.94, closing higher on Tuesday. Volume reached 11.852 billion lots worth RM7.245 billion, with 631 gainers outnumbering 500 losers. This follows a broader market trend, as stocks in Asia and globally continue to rally despite uncertainty.

site_title: UBS shakes up dealmakers, names Paz-Galindo global M&A co-head
summary: UBS has made significant changes to its dealmakers, naming Nestor Paz-Galindo as global M&A co-head alongside Marc-Anthony Hourihan. Philipp Beck will take over as head of M&A for Europe, Middle East, and Africa in 2021. Other key appointments include Greg Peirce as co-head of global banking for Australasia and David Descoteaux and Solon Kentas as co-heads of mergers and acquisitions for the Americas. These changes come as UBS sees a surge in M&A activity, ranking No 6 globally with $95 billion in deals.

site_title: Pratt & Whitney JV in Singapore in talks with unions, 'no employees retrenched yet'
summary: Pratt & Whitney's majority-owned joint venture, Eagle Services Asia, is in talks with unions amid a decline in volumes due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite a media report claiming 144 employees were retrenched between July 22-24, a spokesperson confirmed no employees have been let go, and all remain on payroll. The company is assessing staffing levels to adjust to the business environment and ensure they align with current needs.

site_title: Saudi Arabia posts US$29b deficit in Q2 as oil revenues slump
summary: Saudi Arabia posted a Q2 deficit of US$29.12 billion due to low oil prices, which declined 45% year-on-year. Total revenues dropped 49% to nearly US$36 billion, while expenditures dropped 17% to around US$65 billion. The country has introduced austerity measures, including removing cost-of-living allowances and tripling value-added tax, to bolster state revenues amid a deep recession forecasted to shrink the economy by 6.8% this year.

site_title: Scientists revive microbes from 100m years ago
summary: Scientists have revived microbes from 100 million years ago by incubating ancient sediment samples from the South Pacific seabed. The team, led by the Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, successfully coaxed nearly all microorganisms out of their long slumber. The microbes thrived in the low-oxygen environment, with energy levels 1 million times lower than those of surface microbes. The study sheds light on the remarkable survival power of primitive species, which can exist for tens of millions of years before springing back to life.

site_title: SunMoon's losses persist in FY20
summary: SunMoon Food Company reported a net loss of S$4.3 million for its fiscal year ended March 31, 2020, due to a 75% decline in revenue to S$18.4 million. The company attributed the losses to business restructuring and the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on its operations. Loss per share was 0.57 cents, compared to 0.81 cents in the previous year. The company did not declare a dividend for FY20 due to its loss-making status.

site_title: Pfizer lifts forecast, expecting return of medical activity
summary: Pfizer reported a 32% drop in second-quarter profits to $3.4 billion due to reduced medical activity caused by the coronavirus pandemic. However, the company lifted its full-year forecast, citing expectations for a gradual recovery. Pfizer temporarily suspended clinical trials and marketing meetings, resulting in a $500 million hit. The company also saw higher sales for Covid-19 treatment products. Pfizer expects a gradual increase in patients' visits with physicians and vaccination rates, boosting its full-year adjusted earnings targets to $2.85-$2.95 per share.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust posts higher DPU for H1 FY20; makes higher provision for doubtful debts
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a higher distribution per unit (DPU) of 4.64 Singapore cents for its first half of FY20, up from 3.75 cents last year, due to the reversal of its dividend distribution tax (DDT) provision. Total property income rose 3% to SGD 99 million, driven by income from a completed building and positive rental reversions, but was partially offset by lower utilities and carpark income due to the Covid-19 lockdown.

site_title: North Korea steps up curbs after first possible coronavirus infection
summary: North Korea has introduced stricter coronavirus curbs after a possible infection was reported in the town of Kaesong, on the border with South Korea. The country has locked down the town and implemented quarantine measures, screening districts, and supplied test kits and protective gear. This comes after North Korean leader Kim Jong Un declared an emergency after a defector returned to Kaesong with Covid-19 symptoms. The World Health Organization had previously reported 696 people under quarantine, and North Korea has a limited healthcare system with inadequate resources.

site_title: Hiap Seng Engineering and subsidiary apply for judicial management
summary: Hiap Seng Engineering and its subsidiary HS Compression & Process (HSCP) have filed applications for judicial management in the High Court. The applications will be heard on a date to be fixed by the Court, with RSM Corporate Advisory proposed as judicial managers. The move comes after the company reported a widening net loss of S$5.43 million in its third-quarter results, with revenue falling 31.7% year-on-year. The suspension of trading of the company's shares, which began in November, continues. The JM applications will manage the company's affairs and property during the JM period.

site_title: Leader of the Opposition to take lead in scrutiny, be privy to confidential briefings
summary: Singapore's new Leader of the Opposition, Pritam Singh, will take the lead in presenting alternative views in parliamentary debates and may be privy to confidential briefings. He will also have longer speaking durations, double the allowance of an elected MP, and be accorded parliamentary privileges. Singh's duties include leading scrutiny of the government's positions and actions, attending official state functions, and being consulted on opposition member appointments to select committees. The Leader of the Opposition's role was formally designated following the July 10 General Election, reflecting citizens' desire for greater diversity in politics.

site_title: British Airways faces strike threat over job cuts: report
summary: British Airways faces a strike threat from trade union Unite over planned job cuts, pay, and conditions. The airline plans to cut up to 12,000 jobs to survive the pandemic, with Unite accusing BA of seeking to fire and rehire workers on less favorable contracts. Unite has refused to engage in consultations and is moving towards industrial action. The airline's struggles come as it tries to recover from the pandemic, with new quarantine rules in place for travelers returning to Britain from Spain.

site_title: Fed announces extension in lending facilities until end of the year
summary: The US Federal Reserve announced an extension of several lending facilities through the end of the year to help the economy recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. The three-month extension aims to provide certainty for businesses and households, as the US continues to struggle with the virus. The facilities, including the Paycheck Protection Program, will remain available to keep credit flowing and prevent long-term economic harm. The move comes as relief programs are set to expire and fears grow that the situation could worsen again.

site_title: Legislative measures to mitigate impact of Covid-19 pandemic on SMEs
summary: The Singapore government has introduced legislative measures to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs). The COVID-19 Act (COVID Act 1) and the enhanced COVID-19 Act (COVID Act 2) provide temporary relief to SMEs, including loan repayment holidays, moratoriums on contractual obligations, and caps on late interest charges. The measures aim to safeguard against unfair outcomes and provide respite to cash flow stresses. The government plans to supplement these measures with further amendments to ease repayment obligations and consider modifying existing restructuring laws to cater to SMEs.

site_title: McDonald's global sales suffer as Covid-19 lockdowns limit operations
summary: McDonald's reported a 23.9% drop in global same-store sales for the second quarter due to Covid-19 lockdowns, limiting operations to drive-thru and delivery. In the US, same-store sales fell 8.7%, better than expected, as most locations stayed open with drive-thru and delivery options. The company's revenue fell 30.5% to $3.76 billion, but beat estimates. McDonald's implemented face coverings and reduced seating capacity to aid recovery, with 96% of restaurants operating with drive-thru, delivery, or reduced seating.

site_title: Healthcare, mining stocks drive activity; STI up 0.28%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 7.18 points, or 0.28%, to 2,582.97, driven by gains in healthcare and mining stocks. Jardine Matheson and Wilmar International were the top gainers, while Dairy Farm International was the biggest loser. Penny stocks in the gold-mining and healthcare sectors led trading activity, with Medtecs International and Hyphens Pharma recording significant gains. Regional markets were mixed, with some indices up and others down.

site_title: Gold hits a high, more precious as US dollar loses value
summary: Gold prices surged to record highs, reaching $1,980 an ounce, before profit-taking helped the US dollar rebound from two-year lows. The precious metal's gains were driven by investors' expectations of the US Federal Reserve reaffirming its easy monetary policies and potentially signaling a tolerance for higher inflation. The dollar's decline was also linked to economic performance, with commodity producers and economies closely tied to China performing better.

site_title: Najib gets 12 years jail, fine for abuse of power
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak was found guilty of corruption and sentenced to 12 years in jail, a fine of RM210 million, and 10 years in jail on three charges of criminal breach of trust and three charges of money laundering for his role in the 1MDB scandal. The verdict, seen as a test of the nation's resolve to stamp out corruption, could have big political implications. Najib had pleaded not guilty but plans to appeal the verdict in Malaysia's Federal Court.

site_title: Hong Kong considers postponing legislative elections
summary: Hong Kong's government is considering postponing the September 6 legislative elections due to a recent surge in coronavirus cases. The decision could be announced as early as early August, according to reports. Pro-democracy candidates are criticizing the potential delay, which could impact their chances of winning the election. The announcement was initially planned for after the nomination period ends on Friday, but the timing is now uncertain.

site_title: China halts Hong Kong extradition treaties with Canada, Australia, UK
summary: China has suspended extradition treaties with Canada, Australia, and the UK, in response to the countries' decision to suspend similar treaties with Hong Kong, following the implementation of a new security law. The move is seen as a tit-for-tat response, with China accusing the countries of politicizing judicial cooperation. The suspension affects Hong Kong's extradition treaties with Canada, Australia, and the UK, as well as criminal justice cooperation agreements. Critics have long argued that the security law erodes civil liberties and human rights in Hong Kong.

site_title: Disinfectant demand boosts Reckitt Benckiser's quarterly sales
summary: Reckitt Benckiser Plc reported better-than-expected quarterly sales of 10.5% growth, driven by increased demand for Lysol and Dettol disinfectants and Mucinex cough syrup during the coronavirus pandemic. The company now expects high-single-digit underlying revenue growth in 2020, beating initial expectations of mid-single-digit sales growth. This is attributed to cautious customers stocking up on essential products amid the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 0.26% and the Topix index losing 0.48%. Investors took profits from recent rebounds, awaiting major company earnings later in the week.

site_title: Europe: Equities mixed at open
summary: European stocks experienced mixed trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.6% to 6,142.32 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 increased 0.3% to 12,878.53 points. In contrast, Paris' CAC 40 index fell 0.3% to 4,924.66 points. Investors are watching for a potential US stimulus package, which may impact European markets.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover names Thierry Bollore as CEO, succeeding Speth
summary: Jaguar Land Rover has appointed Thierry Bollore as its new CEO, replacing Ralf Speth, who will retire in September. Bollore, former CEO of Renault, takes over at a challenging time for the UK luxury carmaker, which is struggling with record losses and a prolonged sales slump exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic. The company aims to save £5 billion by March 2021 through cost-cutting measures, including reducing capital spending by 25%. Bollore's appointment aims to steer the company out of its financial struggles and lift vehicle sales.

images.alt_text: Jaguar Land Rover has named Thierry Bollore as its new chief executive officer to help steer the money-losing British luxury carmaker out of a prolonged sales slump.

site_title: 3M posts 12% fall in revenue as coronavirus crisis hammers demand
summary: 3M reports a 12% drop in quarterly revenue to $7.2 billion due to the coronavirus crisis, which has hammered demand for its products. However, net income increased to $1.29 billion, or $2.22 per share, on an adjusted basis. The decline in revenue is attributed to the global economic slowdown caused by the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with gains on Tuesday, driven by hopes for a US stimulus package and potential monetary easing measures from the Federal Reserve. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.69%, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.71%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 1.37%. The positive sentiment was expected ahead of the Fed's policy meeting, which could unveil fresh measures to boost the economy.

site_title: HSBC aims to double number of senior Black staff by 2025
summary: HSBC aims to double the number of Black staff in senior roles by 2025, following internal meetings where employees expressed feelings of being overlooked for career opportunities. The bank's CEO, Noel Quinn, acknowledged systemic racism and promised concrete actions to create opportunities for advancement. HSBC will hire a recruiting firm to engage Black and ethnically diverse talent for leadership roles, following similar moves by other banks worldwide. This move aims to address the lack of senior Black role models and promote diversity and inclusion.

site_title: MAS revokes capital markets services licence of Apical Asset Management on anti-money laundering breaches
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) revoked the Capital Markets Services (CMS) licence of Apical Asset Management for breaching Anti-Money Laundering/Countering Financing of Terrorism (AML/CFT) requirements. MAS is the only entity to have revoked a CMS licence for AML/CFT offences in the past five years. Apical Asset Management's CEO and director were also reprimanded for failing to ensure compliance with laws and regulations.

site_title: US Mint has reduced silver, gold coin supplies to purchasers
summary: The US Mint has reduced the supply of gold and silver coins due to the coronavirus pandemic, which has slowed production at its West Point complex in New York. The facility is taking measures to prevent the spread of the virus, resulting in reduced capacity and forcing it to choose between producing gold or silver coins. This move comes as investors seek safe-haven assets amid global uncertainty, driving up prices for gold and silver. The Mint will now ask dealers for demand forecasts to inform production decisions.

site_title: Amazon steps up challenge in UK grocery delivery
summary: Amazon is launching a grocery delivery service in the UK, starting with London, with the aim of rolling out the service nationwide by year's end. The "Fresh" service offers free and fast deliveries of essentials for orders above £40, with no shipping charges for Prime members. This move follows a 14.6% rise in grocery sales in Britain in the four weeks to July 12, driven by the coronavirus lockdown. The service is set to compete with major British grocery retailers.

site_title: Of wine, hand gel and heartbreak
summary: France's wine industry is facing a crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic and a 25% US tax on French wines imposed by the Trump administration. Thousands of winemakers, including those in Alsace, are having to distill their unsold wine into hand sanitizer. The economic downturn has led to a significant loss of sales, with wholesale wine traders facing losses of 70%. Winemakers are struggling to come to terms with the decision, with many describing it as a "heartbreak" and a "catastrophe." The French government is subsidizing the operation, but many winemakers are concerned about the long-term impact on their businesses.

site_title: Walmart's Flipkart to offer 90-minute deliveries in India
summary: Flipkart, a Walmart-owned e-commerce platform in India, plans to offer 90-minute deliveries for groceries and home accessories through its hyperlocal service, dubbed Flipkart Quick. The service will debut in select locations in Bengaluru and will also sell mobile phones and stationery items. This move aims to compete with Amazon's quick-delivery service and other players like BigBasket and JioMart, which have been gaining traction in the Indian e-commerce market, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Leader of the Opposition, Pritam Singh, will lead in parliamentary debates and may attend official state functions. PUB has awarded a S$449.6m contract for the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. Teckwah Industrial is urged to raise its dividend amid declining earnings. All companies must file controllers' details in a new central register starting July 30. The National Environment Agency (NEA) has launched a site for a funeral parlour development in Woodlands. Grab is seeking feedback on its proposed S$0.30 platform fee. The STI rose 0.28% to 2,582.97 on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Leader of the Opposition Pritam Singh with Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan-Jin on July 28, 2020.

site_title: Egypt and Sudan criticise Ethiopia at start of new Nile dam talks
summary: Egypt and Sudan criticized Ethiopia for unilaterally filling its Blue Nile dam, citing concerns over water shortages in their own countries. The Blue Nile is a key source of fresh water for Egypt's 100 million people. After nearly a decade of negotiations, talks to regulate dam filling and operation have failed to yield an agreement, with Egypt and Sudan fearing the US$4 billion dam could exacerbate water scarcity issues.

site_title: ECB tells banks not to pay dividends until Jan 2021 over virus crisis
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has urged banks in the eurozone to refrain from paying dividends or offering bonuses until January 1, 2021, to ensure they have sufficient buffers to survive the economic storm caused by the coronavirus crisis. The ECB, which has taken unprecedented action to stimulate growth, expects lenders to make their own extraordinary efforts to absorb losses and support lending to the real economy. The move aims to preserve banks' capacity to absorb losses and maintain capital buffers.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank on Tuesday urged banks to refrain from paying dividends or offering bonuses until January 1, 2021, in order to ensure lenders have sufficient buffers to survive the economic storm unleashed by the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: China's Ctrip in talks with investors to delist from Nasdaq: sources
summary: China's Ctrip, the country's largest online travel firm, is in talks with investors to delist from the Nasdaq due to rising US-China tensions and the coronavirus-driven hit to its business. Ctrip has reached out to financial and strategic investors about joining a take-private deal, citing a desire to avoid stricter US audit requirements. The company's management has been exploring alternative options, including a possible secondary listing on a Hong Kong exchange, amid a decline in its shares and valuation.

site_title: ING to book impairment of 300m euros on coronavirus impact
summary: ING Groep, a Dutch bank, will report a 300 million euro (S$485.4 million) goodwill impairment in its second-quarter results due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The impairment is related to past acquisitions and will be reported under operating expenses, without affecting the company's capital ratios. The bank expects significant risk costs above the average due to the pandemic and IFRS-9 methodology, impacting its net profit for the quarter.

site_title: 8-year-old girl one of two new imported coronavirus cases in Singapore
summary: An 8-year-old American girl and a 39-year-old Indian male are the two newly reported imported coronavirus cases in Singapore. The girl, a dependant's pass holder, tested positive on Monday, while the male work pass holder tested positive on Sunday.

site_title: Oil prices steady as demand concerns offset US stimulus hopes
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Tuesday, erasing earlier gains, as rising coronavirus cases dampened demand concerns and US stimulus hopes. Despite Senate Republicans' proposal for a stimulus package, the passage is likely to be delayed, affecting oil demand. Brent crude futures were unchanged at US$43.41 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 14 US cents to US$41.46 a barrel. The steady prices countered optimism over stronger US demand, driven by US stimulus efforts.

site_title: China starts building southern part of China-Russia East gas pipeline
summary: China has begun construction on the southern part of the China-Russia East natural gas pipeline, a 5,111-km pipeline that will pump natural gas from Russia's Siberia region to China's Yangtze River delta. The pipeline, expected to be completed by 2025, will transmit 18.9 billion cubic meters of natural gas to China each year. The project aims to strengthen energy cooperation between the two nations, with the southern part of the pipeline starting at Yongqing in Hebei and ending at Shanghai.

site_title: Fujifilm gets US$265m US contract to boost output of potential virus vaccine
summary: The US Department of Health and Human Services has awarded a $265 million contract to Fujifilm's Texas facility to boost production of Novavax's coronavirus vaccine candidate, NVX-CoV2373. The expansion is expected to be completed this fall, accelerating the production timeline. This contract is part of a larger pact between the US government and Fujifilm Diosynth Biotechnologies to produce bulk drug substances for the vaccine.

site_title: PetroChina eyes wind and solar after US$38b pipe bounty
summary: PetroChina, China's largest oil company, plans to use some of the $38 billion it will receive from selling its pipelines to start new businesses focusing on wind and solar power. The company aims to transform into a "green and low-carbon model" with investments in wind, solar, and geothermal energy. While the specifics are unknown, analysts expect the new lines of business to bring higher returns than the company's pipelines segment. This move reflects China's growing concern about climate change and the country's push to boost clean energy to 15% of its energy mix.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close higher on Samsung Electronics rally, robust foreign buying
summary: South Korean shares rose nearly 2% on Tuesday, driven by Samsung Electronics' rally and robust foreign buying, reaching 2,256.99. Foreign investors bought $1.09 billion worth of shares, the largest since 2013. The US Senate proposed a $1 trillion coronavirus aid package, which may benefit chipmakers like Samsung and TSMC. The Kospi index saw 851.33 million shares traded, with 339 advancing issues.

site_title: Virus surge a major blow for Spain tourist sector
summary: Spain's tourist sector faces a significant setback due to a surge in virus cases, with Britain's decision to impose quarantine on all travelers coming from Spain being a major blow. The sector had hoped to recover from lockdown losses in the summer, but cancellations and lost bookings are expected, with estimated losses of up to 8.7 billion euros. Spain's hotels association urges tourists to be tested before traveling and again before returning home to avoid quarantine. The Canary Islands and Balearic Isles are being considered for exemptions, but the health ministry believes the quarantine will discourage travel from the UK.

site_title: All companies must file controllers' details in new ACRA central register
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) has introduced a new Central Register of Controllers, requiring all companies, foreign companies, and limited liability partnerships to file their controllers' details by September 29. This information was previously maintained in the Register of Registrable Controllers (RORC). Companies must comply with the new requirement unless exempted, marking a significant change in regulatory requirements for corporate governance in Singapore.

site_title: Brazil mayors say UK dam case vital in David-Goliath struggle with BHP
summary: Brazilian mayors are suing BHP in an English court over a 2015 dam collapse that killed 19 and contaminated a river, citing a lack of justice in Brazil. The case, the largest group action in English legal history, alleges BHP ignored safety warnings and provided inadequate compensation. The hearing, which began in Manchester, aims to determine the company's liability and damages. The Brazilian government has also filed a class action, but claimants believe the English case is the only way to secure proper justice, despite BHP calling it pointless and wasteful.

site_title: Local tours now allowed for groups of up to 10: Singapore Tourism Board
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board has updated its guidelines to allow local walking, cycling, and kayaking tours to accommodate up to 10 participants, doubling the previous limit of 5. Tour operators must still adhere to safe management measures, including a maximum tour duration of 8 hours, and transport capacity caps of 50 people. The move aims to encourage locals to support tourism businesses amid low Covid-19 community cases and a newly-launched campaign, the SingapoRediscovers campaign, which offers staycation deals and promotions.

images.alt_text: Tour guide from Monster Day Tours briefing the group on Jewel. Tour operators and guides have been allowed to resume operations from this month, subject to MTI approval.

site_title: China steel futures rise on resilient demand
summary: China's steel futures rose on Tuesday, with the rebar contract increasing 0.5% to 3,769 yuan per tonne. Hot-rolled coil futures also rose 0.6% to 3,789 yuan a tonne, driven by firm demand in the infrastructure and real estate sectors. Analysts attribute the price increase to domestic demand, citing expected stimulus for infrastructure and property to hedge downward risks. Benchmark iron ore futures jumped 1.6% to 835 yuan a tonne.

images.alt_text: China's steel futures rose on Tuesday, with the most-traded contract of rebar snapping three consecutive sessions of declines as prices propped up firm demand outlook in the infrastructure and real estate sectors.

site_title: Australia: Shares give up gains on fears of stricter Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Australian shares fell 0.39% to 6,020.50 points, giving up early gains, as concerns of stricter Covid-19 restrictions in the state of Victoria drove down the market. The state reported six deaths and 384 new cases, prompting a potential extension of the six-week lockdown. Employment data also showed a 1.1% decline between mid-June and mid-July, adding to the economic pain. Mining stocks rose, however, driven by robust iron ore prices, while energy and gold stocks fell.

site_title: Iconic French cinema shuts for August as audiences plummet
summary: The iconic Grand Rex cinema in Paris will close its doors for the month of August due to plummeting audience numbers and the lack of Hollywood summer blockbusters. The cinema's manager cited social distancing rules and the postponement of popular films as major factors. The Federation of French Cinemas is demanding state aid to help the industry, which has seen a 70% decline in box office revenue compared to last year.

site_title: Indonesian mining sector to bank on refined metals for growth
summary: Indonesia's mining sector is shifting its focus to refined metals for growth, driven by increasing demand in China. Fitch Solutions forecasts a significant increase in exports of steel, nickel, and nickel pig iron, with nickel production expected to triple from 2019 to 2025. In contrast, unprocessed metal exports are "on borrowed time" due to export bans and shifting government policies. The country aims to move its mineral industry up the value chain through policies such as investment incentives and bans on raw mineral exports.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts downgrade Raffles Medical on foggy prospects of foreign patient load recovery
summary: Analysts from Maybank Kim Eng and CGS-CIMB have downgraded Raffles Medical Group to "hold" due to limited upside, citing insufficient visibility on foreign patient load recovery. Foreign patients account for 25-30% of hospital services revenue, and the downgrade comes despite local patient volumes recovering. The lowered target price is 96 Singapore cents from 97.6 cents previously, with upside risk tied to a faster lifting of travel restrictions.

site_title: Nissan to skip annual dividend, seeks to conserve cash
summary: Nissan Motor Co announced it will skip its annual dividend to conserve cash and turn the business around. The automaker reported a quarterly operating loss of about 150 billion yen (S$1.93 billion) for the April-June quarter. This decision is a blow to Renault SA, Nissan's largest shareholder, and comes as the company struggles to restore profitability and sales following the 2018 arrest of former Chairman Carlos Ghosn and the COVID-19 pandemic. Nissan aims to return to positive cash flow for its automotive business during the January-March quarter.

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor Co isn't planning to pay a dividend for the current fiscal year as it seeks to conserve cash and turn the business around.

site_title: ByteDance AI research head to leave as pressure mounts on TikTok
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, announced that Ma Wei-Ying, its AI research head, will leave the company. Ma, a vice-president and former Microsoft Research Asia executive, joined ByteDance in 2017. His departure comes amid US scrutiny of TikTok's security and privacy practices, with a potential ban by the US government looming. Ma plans to join China's Tsinghua University, while ByteDance expands its engineering and research team in California. The move is seen as a response to regulatory pressure on TikTok.

site_title: France to ban cafe terrace heaters as no longer cool
summary: France plans to ban outdoor cafe heaters from early next year to accelerate its low-carbon economy. The ban, which will not take effect until after the winter season, aims to reduce unjustified energy consumption. There are approximately 12,500 heated outdoor terraces in France, which can emit as much CO2 as a car circling the earth three times. The move is seen as a necessary step to protect the environment, with some restaurant owners expressing concerns about the timing but others welcoming the change.

site_title: Under Armour probe may loosen Plank's grip on operations
summary: Under Armour founder Kevin Plank remains chairman and largest shareholder despite stepping down as CEO in January. A federal accounting investigation into the company's disclosure of sales in 2015 and 2016 may loosen Plank's grip on operations. The SEC is likely to allege violations of federal law, and Plank's involvement may be reduced if charges are filed. Under Armour shares rose 2.3% on the news, despite the company's stagnant sales and restructuring efforts.

site_title: Travel app Traveloka raises US$250m as lockdowns ease
summary: Traveloka, Southeast Asia's largest online travel app, has raised $250 million in funding to bolster operations amid the COVID-19 crisis. The eight-year-old startup, which has over 60 million downloads, has seen an encouraging recovery in domestic travel in key markets such as Vietnam and Thailand. The funding round was led by a global financial institution and includes existing investors. Traveloka plans to use the funds to boost its balance sheets and domestic travel offerings. The company's CEO notes that domestic travel is picking up in the region of 650 million people as lockdowns ease.

site_title: France to reconsider plans to build 4th terminal at Paris CDG airport
summary: France plans to reconsider its proposal to build a fourth terminal at Paris Charles de Gaulle airport due to the impact of the coronavirus crisis, according to Transport Minister Jean-Baptiste Djebbari. The project, aiming to handle 40 million more passengers by 2030, is no longer justified. Instead, the government will focus on upgrading existing airports and ensuring new plane types, like hydrogen-powered planes, can land safely.

site_title: Australian total payroll jobs fall 1.1% between mid-June and mid-July
summary: Australian employment fell 1.1% between mid-June and mid-July, with payroll jobs decreasing 2.2% in Victoria due to re-introduced COVID-19 restrictions. Nationally, payroll jobs are 5.6% below mid-March levels, when Australia first recorded COVID-19 cases.

site_title: Germany plans mandatory tests for those returning from high-risk countries
summary: Germany plans mandatory free COVID-19 tests for travelers returning from high-risk countries, including Turkey, Egypt, and the US, to slow the spread of infections. The move comes as infection numbers rise and travel resumes after months of lockdown. Health Minister Jens Spahn said the tests are necessary to prevent new chains of infection. The decision is a victory for Bavarian state premier Markus Soeder, who had advocated for airport testing. The move may impact Frankfurt Airport, Lufthansa, and Deutsche Bahn, which rely on tourism for a recovery.

site_title: NEA launches Woodlands site for development of funeral parlour
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) in Singapore has launched a 5,002.8 square meter land parcel at Woodlands Industrial Park E8 for the development of a purpose-built funeral parlour complex. The complex, expected to be operational in four years, will offer a range of services, including 10-14 wake halls, embalming facilities, and commercial spaces. The development aims to provide a dignified experience for mourning families while minimizing disruptions to nearby stakeholders. This is the first of four sites to be launched for funeral parlour complexes, with a projected increase in resident deaths in Singapore to around 40,000 by 2040.

site_title: Peugeot maker PSA sticks to financial outlook despite virus drag
summary: PSA Group, the maker of Peugeot, Citroen, and Opel vehicles, maintained its financial outlook despite a 68% decline in net income to 595 million euros in the first half of 2020. The company attributed the resilience to sales in June and July being good, and reiterated its forecast of a positive automotive adjusted operating margin in 2020. PSA expects the European auto market to shrink by 25% this year, but aims to maintain an average operating margin of over 4.5% for 2019-2021. The company remains on track to close its merger with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles by the end of 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong tension may hasten Daiwa's shift to mainland
summary: Daiwa Securities Group may accelerate plans to scale back its presence in Hong Kong if tensions worsen, according to deputy chief Keiko Tashiro. The Japanese brokerage has already been slimming down its Hong Kong footprint and is in talks with Chinese authorities to start a joint venture by the end of the year. The move comes as Hong Kong's status as a global financial hub is threatened by the introduction of a security law, prompting over a third of Japanese companies operating in the city to review their presence.

site_title: New Zealand suspends extradition treaty with Hong Kong
summary: New Zealand suspended its extradition treaty with Hong Kong on July 28, 2020, due to concerns over China's new security law, which erodes civil liberties and undermines Hong Kong's unique status. The move joins similar actions by New Zealand's allies, including Canada, Britain, and Australia, and the US is reportedly preparing to follow suit. The suspension risks damaging New Zealand's largest trading partner, Hong Kong.

site_title: Japan government persists with 'Abenomask' giveaway, reignites social media outcry
summary: Japan's government continues to distribute its "Abenomask" despite criticism, with 130 million masks already given out, despite commercially made masks being available. The masks have been criticized for quality issues and being a waste of public money. The government claims they are a low-cost measure to curb demand, but a recent poll found that two-thirds of respondents are in favor of reintroducing a state of emergency to address rising coronavirus cases in Tokyo, which has seen over 200 new cases in six days.

site_title: UK hospitality industry sales slump 87% as coronavirus lockdown bites
summary: UK hospitality sales plummeted 87% in the second quarter, with revenue from April to June totaling £4.6 billion, down from £34.2 billion in the same period last year. The industry's "catastrophic collapse" is attributed to the coronavirus lockdown, and businesses are seeking extensive government support. Despite partial reopening, recovery appears slow due to ongoing concerns and hesitancy to use public transport. Industry leaders are calling for a nine-month rent-free period to help prevent business failures and job losses.

site_title: Competition watchdog seeks feedback on Grab's proposed S$0.30 platform fee
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) is seeking public feedback on Grab's proposed S$0.30 platform fee for its ride-hailing services in Singapore.
