The fee, which includes S$0.32 with goods and services tax, aims to cover operating costs and enhance safety measures. A third of the funds will be allocated to driver welfare benefits. The CCCS will assess Grab's application and determine whether the fee is in line with industry norms. Public feedback is invited until Aug 11.

images.alt_text: The proposed fee amounts to S$0.30 per ride, or S$0.32 with goods and services tax.

site_title: Malaysian ex-PM Najib guilty of all charges in first 1MDB trial
summary: Malaysian ex-Prime Minister Najib Razak was found guilty on all charges in his first trial related to the 1MDB scandal, a multi-billion-dollar financial fraud. Najib could face decades in jail after being convicted of abuse of power, criminal breach of trust, and money-laundering. The verdict was a test of Malaysia's rule of law, coming after Najib's party returned to power as part of a coalition just five months prior. Najib had vehemently denied wrongdoing, but the judge found him guilty after considering all evidence. Sentencing is pending, with Najib likely to appeal.

site_title: PUB awards S$449.6m contract for Tuas Water Reclamation Plant to Sinohydro
summary: Singapore's national water agency PUB has awarded a S$449.6 million contract to Sinohydro to construct the civil and structural components of domestic liquids modules for the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. The plant will treat 650,000 cubic metres of domestic used water per day, equivalent to 245 Olympic-sized swimming pools. The project aims to increase the plant's capacity to receive both domestic and industrial used water streams from two separate deep tunnels for treatment. The project's completion is expected to support PUB's efforts to improve water recycling and reduce wastewater discharge.

site_title: Investors lead the rush back into India's offices
summary: Investors are signaling a shift back to in-office work in India, with sovereign wealth funds leading the rush into the country's commercial real estate market. Mindspace Business Parks' IPO, valued at up to $2.2 billion, is backed by investors such as GIC and Blackstone. The company, which includes Amazon and Facebook tenants, has delivered a 22% total shareholder return since its float last year, outperforming the Nifty 50 Index. This trend suggests work-from-home may be a passing fad in India, with investors seeking long-term value in physical office space.

site_title: ARA Logos DPU for Q2 rises 0.4% to 1.326 S cents
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust's distribution per unit (DPU) rose 0.4% to 1.326 Singapore cents for Q2, driven by higher revenue from new leases. Gross revenue increased 4.3% to S$29 million, while net property income rose 7% to S$21.9 million. The distributable income rose 1.3% to S$14.5 million, with S$500,000 retained for potential mandatory rental deferment.

site_title: Westpac hands regulator more transaction info, says not all break money-laundering laws
summary: Westpac Banking Corp disclosed to Australia's financial regulator that it provided updated information on over 500,000 threshold transactions, some of which may have breached anti-money laundering laws. The lender claims not all of these transactions, valued at A$10,000 or more, were reported or were incomplete. Westpac is facing allegations that it enabled millions of illegal payments, including between known child sex offenders, amid a major management overhaul and a possible A$900 million penalty. The lender's actions may have breached anti-money laundering laws, but the extent of the breaches is still unclear.

site_title: Share surge propels Taiwan chip giant TSMC into top ten
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) briefly became the world's 10th largest company after a surge in its stock price, propelling the island's exchange to a record high. TSMC's worth reached $410 billion, surpassing US firms Johnson & Johnson and Visa. The company's stock rose 10% on Tuesday, adding $35 billion to its value, and its share price is up 17% this year. Analysts attribute the surge to reports of US chip titan Intel's delayed production, which is expected to benefit Asian chip giants like TSMC and Samsung.

site_title: Volkswagen has paid US$9.5b to US drivers over 'dieselgate'
summary: Volkswagen has paid US$9.5 billion to US drivers since 2016 as part of a settlement for misleading them about devices installed in their vehicles to cheat emission standards. The company admitted to cheating emissions tests on 11 million vehicles worldwide in 2015. As part of the settlement, over 86% of affected owners chose to return their cars for compensation or modification. The total bill for the Volkswagen scandal is expected to exceed 30 billion euros.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen has paid some US$9.5 billion since 2016 to US motorists misled by devices installed by the German automaker to cheat emission standards, the US federal consumer protection authority said on Monday.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% or 12.17 points to 2,587.96 on Tuesday, tracking overnight Wall Street gains led by technology stocks. Gainers outnumbered losers 111 to 22, with banking stocks and tech counters advancing. In the US, the Nasdaq Composite Index finished up 1.7%, while Tokyo stocks opened flat.

site_title: Banksy to donate sale of artwork to Palestinian hospital
summary: British street artist Banksy is donating the proceeds from the auction of his artwork "Mediterranean Sea View 2017" to a Palestinian hospital, valued at over $1 million. The work, which depicts views of raging seas and shoreline littered with orange life jackets and buoys, will be auctioned at Sotheby's in London. The sale will fund the construction of an acute stroke unit and children's rehabilitation equipment at the hospital in Bethlehem. This is the latest in a series of philanthropic efforts by Banksy, who has previously donated works to hospitals and charities.

site_title: Digitalisation of local SMEs could add up to US$24b to GDP by 2024: survey
summary: A survey of 1,400 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the Asia-Pacific region, commissioned by Cisco and conducted by IDC, found that digitally mature SMEs in Singapore could add up to US$24 billion to the country's GDP by 2024. This growth is attributed to increased revenue and productivity gains from digital transformation. In contrast, SMEs with an indifferent approach to digitalization only enjoy half of these benefits.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.07 points, or 0.32%, to 1,596.55, with 330 gainers surpassing 94 losers. The market opened higher on Tuesday with 673.38 million lots traded worth RM247.37 million.

site_title: Even trading floor diehards are now embracing work from home
summary: Financial professionals in Japan, including those at Mizuho Securities and Goldman Sachs, are embracing work-from-home arrangements amid the coronavirus pandemic. Despite initial concerns about the impact on productivity, traders and employees report that remote work can be effective and even relaxing. Many firms are investing in remote infrastructure, and some, like CLSA, are exploring the possibility of reducing office space. The shift towards remote work is seen as a lasting change, with employees expressing a preference for the flexibility and reduced stress of working from home.

images.alt_text: Like many traders in office-obsessed Japan, the deputy head of fixed income at Mizuho Securities Co had never even considered working from home until the pandemic hit. Now, for the first time since he stepped onto the trading floor 25 years ago, Motokawa spends at least one day a week outside the office and plans to keep it up.

site_title: 'Already punished': Acquitted Hong Kong protest couple rebuild
summary: Hong Kong couple Henry Tong and Elaine To were acquitted of rioting charges related to 2019 pro-democracy protests. The acquittal has significant implications for hundreds of other protesters facing similar charges. The couple, who were set to spend their first wedding anniversary in separate prison cells, were declared not guilty after prosecutors failed to prove their involvement in clashes with police last July. The ruling has sparked relief and potential consequences for other protesters.

site_title: Hong Kong credit-card fraud syndicate stole details from Singapore victims: police
summary: A Hong Kong-based credit-card fraud syndicate, believed to be operating from Hong Kong, was arrested for stealing credit card details from Singapore victims via phishing emails. The syndicate made fraudulent online purchases in Hong Kong, totaling over HK$270,000, and is also suspected of using stolen details from US and European victims for other transactions. Five suspects, including two foreign men and three Hong Kong women, aged 26-37, were arrested in a joint probe by the Singapore Police Force and Hong Kong authorities.

site_title: Vaccine alliance eyes range of prices for Covid-19 shots, says US$40 would be maximum
summary: The GAVI vaccine alliance, co-leading the COVAX facility, is exploring a wide range of potential prices for Covid-19 shots, with a maximum of $40 per dose for high-income countries. The alliance has no specific target price and will negotiate tiered pricing for richer and poorer countries. COVAX aims to deliver 2 billion doses globally by the end of 2021 and is currently in talks with manufacturers to determine final vaccine pricing.

site_title: Chile judge calls for water study on 'fragile' lithium-rich Atacama salt flat
summary: A Chilean environmental judge, Mauricio Oviedo, has called for a government-vetted water study to address concerns about the sustainability of lithium mining in the Salar de Atacama, a fragile salt flat in the world's driest desert. The study is needed to provide certainty for sustainable mining practices, following a court's dismissal of a remediation plan for lithium producer SQM. A third-party hydrological survey has been delayed since 2018, and the decision reignites concerns over SQM's ability to meet growing demand for lithium.

site_title: Tokyo, Sydney aim to lure edgy HK financial firms, but Singapore a top draw
summary: Hong Kong's imposition of a national security law has prompted global financial institutions to reassess their operations, with Japan, Australia, and other nations offering incentives to attract banks and asset managers. However, experts say Singapore is the most likely beneficiary due to its similar corporate tax rate, business-friendly environment, and ease of doing business, making it an attractive alternative for institutions concerned about the law. Despite efforts by other countries to woo them, many firms are hesitant to relocate, citing high costs, cultural differences, and language barriers.

site_title: Hutchison Port Holdings trims first-half distribution to 4.3 HK cents per unit
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust reported a 28.3% decrease in first-half distribution to 4.3 HK cents per unit, down from 6 cents a year ago. Revenue declined 11.9% to HK$4.78 billion, primarily due to lower container throughput. The combined throughput of its Hong Kong terminals decreased 2.9% year-over-year, mainly caused by reduced intra-Asia, US, and transshipment cargoes.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on US stimulus hopes; gold index scales fresh peak
summary: Australian shares rose 1% to 6,102.3 on Tuesday, driven by hopes of a US$1 trillion coronavirus aid package and gold stocks scaling a fresh peak. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose, with gold stocks like AngloGold Ashanti surging 40.1% and top miners BHP and Rio Tinto also rising. However, concerns about the resurgence of COVID-19 cases in Australia tempered the gains.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose more than 1% on Tuesday, driven by optimism over a proposed US stimulus package. The Hang Seng Index climbed 1.38%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The gains followed a rally in US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The news boosted investor confidence, with traders expecting a potential surge of cash to support the world's top economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.04% and the Topix index slipping 0.08%. The positive lead from Wall Street was countered by a stronger yen. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a surge in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US. Meanwhile, Airalo raised $220 million in funding, valuing the eSIM platform at over $1 billion.

site_title: Financial settlement network EMQ raises US$20m led by WI Harper
summary: EMQ, a Hong Kong-based fintech startup, has raised US$20 million in Series B funding led by WI Harper Group. The funding round also included participation from various investors, including AppWorks and Abu Dhabi Capital. EMQ operates a cross-border financial settlement network across the Asia-Pacific, Africa, Europe, and North America, with plans to use the investment to accelerate its international growth and product development.

site_title: Great Eastern Q2 profit up 76% to S$297.5m on improved financial market conditions
summary: Great Eastern Holdings posted a net profit of S$297.5 million for Q2 2020, 76% higher than the previous year, driven by improved financial market conditions. Operating profit rose 16% to S$185.7 million, while non-operating profit reversed to S$35 million. However, new business volume fell 4% due to restricted sales activities, particularly in the bancassurance channel. The company declared an interim one-tier tax-exempt dividend of 10 Singapore cents per share. Despite a challenging economic outlook, Great Eastern expects to continue adapting to the situation.

site_title: Hotels are promoting the nostalgia of the family road trip
summary: Hotels in the US are promoting road trips as a safe and appealing alternative to air travel amid the ongoing pandemic. Many hotels are leaning into nostalgia, evoking memories of classic family road trips, and using data analytics to understand consumer interests. To adapt to the uneven reopening, hotels are focusing on regional and short-haul markets, promoting nearby parks, scenery, and simple activities that can be done while maintaining social distance. This approach aims to convince Americans to take a drive rather than a plane trip, helping hotels stay afloat during the pandemic.

site_title: Lawyers for Huawei's Meng demand release of Canadian spy documents
summary: Lawyers for Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou demanded the release of unredacted Canadian spy service documents, claiming they would reveal a plot between the FBI and Canada to "trick" their client. Meng, charged with violating US sanctions, was arrested in 2018 and has been fighting extradition. Meng's lawyers argue that the redacted documents, already released, do not provide sufficient proof, and that the unredacted versions would prove a conspiracy. The Canadian government opposed the release, citing potential risks to Canadian security. The hearing will resume behind closed doors on Thursday.

site_title: UK house prices seen growing as much as 3% for rest of 2020
summary: The UK housing market is expected to see a 3% growth in house prices for the rest of 2020, driven by a sales-tax break and resurgent demand after the coronavirus lockdown. This is the fastest pace of price growth in nearly two years, according to a report from Zoopla Ltd. The UK housing market was previously frozen in March but has since seen deals resume, with prices growing 2.7% in June from a year earlier. The growth is expected to continue into 2021, with any declines more likely in the first half of next year.

site_title: Gold forges record high as investors seek safety
summary: Gold prices surged to a record high of $1,945.72 per ounce on Monday, driven by concerns over heightened China-US tensions, spiking virus infections, and a lack of stimulus in Washington. The dollar's weakness against major currencies also contributed to the rise. The gold price has jumped over 25% this year, with investors seeking safety in the commodity amid economic uncertainties. The US-China tensions, including embassy closures, and the ongoing pandemic have fueled market volatility.

site_title: Trump bets on Covid-19 vaccine for political shot in arm
summary: US President Donald Trump has expressed hope that a Covid-19 vaccine will help defeat the virus and revive his re-election chances. Trump visited a vaccine facility in North Carolina, where a contract has been awarded to mass-produce an experimental vaccine developed by Novavax as part of the Operation Warp Speed initiative. The administration believes that a vaccine is the only solution to contain the US's still-raging epidemic, despite the country's high number of confirmed cases and deaths.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump vowed to defeat the coronavirus by "unleashing American scientific genius" as he toured a Covid-19 vaccine facility in the swing state of North Carolina on Monday.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust DPS down 69% to 1.05 S cents for H1
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) reported a 69% drop in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.05 Singapore cents for the half year ended June 30, 2020. Revenue declined 16% to S$208.5 million, mainly due to divestments and lower revenue from its existing portfolio. Gross profit slipped 28% to S$88.6 million. ART retained 15% of its income due to ongoing rent negotiations and Covid-19 uncertainty, with plans to distribute the retained amount in the full year if income permits.

site_title: 7 local design projects to get up to S$35,000 in R&D funding
summary: The DesignSingapore Council has announced the inaugural Good Design Research (GDR) programme, providing up to S$35,000 in R&D funding to 7 local design projects. The programme aims to support innovative and impactful design work tackling global and societal challenges.

site_title: Teckwah Industrial urged to raise dividend amid earnings downtrend
summary: Activist fund Quarz Capital Management urges Teckwah Industrial to increase its annual dividend payout to S$7.4 million or 80% of net income, citing the company's lack of cash discipline and operational efficiency. The firm points to a 10-year low in net profit and high remuneration for executive directors. Quarz also criticizes the acquisition of Profoto Digital Services, which it believes will be loss-making due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The fund wants Teckwah to professionalize its non-print business and bring in industry expertise to expedite growth.

images.alt_text: Teckwah is led by chairman and managing director Thomas Chua (pictured), the eldest son of the late Chua Seng Tek, who founded the company.

site_title: Singapore third in Asia-Pacific for mobile network experience ahead of 5G rollout: study
summary: Singapore ranks third in the Asia-Pacific for mobile network experience ahead of 5G rollout, according to a study by Opensignal. The city-state ranked second in upload speed experience and tied for second in video experience, but third in 4G availability and download speed experience. Singapore's 5G operators have access to large quantities of mmWave spectrum, but the humid climate may limit indoor penetration. To improve its mobile network experience, Singapore's operators must rapidly deploy 5G coverage and give customers compelling reasons to upgrade their smartphones.

site_title: US: Tech companies rally ahead of earnings, hearing
summary: US tech shares rose ahead of a high-stakes congressional hearing on Wednesday, with Amazon, Apple, and other major companies gaining. The Nasdaq Composite Index finished 1.7% higher, while the Dow Jones and S&P 500 also rose. Investors are anticipating another round of stimulus to support the coronavirus-affected economy and are optimistic about the hearing, which will examine Big Tech's dominance. The Federal Reserve is also set to complete a two-day policy meeting on Wednesday.

site_title: Wells Fargo files to register exchange-traded funds
summary: Wells Fargo has filed to register its own exchange-traded funds (ETFs), joining banking giants JPMorgan Chase & Co and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. in the growing industry. The San Francisco-based bank's approval would allow it to issue its own ETFs, expanding its asset management capabilities. This move comes as the ETF industry continues to grow, with Wells Fargo's entry marking the latest development in the sector.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Great Eastern, MNACT, Ascott Residence Trust, StarHub, Parkway Life Reit
summary: Stocks to watch on Tuesday included Great Eastern Holdings, which posted a net profit of S$297.5 million for the second quarter, a 76% increase from last year. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) saw a 10.7% drop in gross revenue and a 19.5% decline in net property income. Ascott Residence Trust (ART) reported a 69% drop in distribution per stapled security. StarHub announced the retirement of its CEO on October 31, while Parkway Life Reit's distribution per unit rose 2.5%.

site_title: Johnson wants Britons to cycle way out of lockdown
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced plans to build thousands of kilometers of new bike lanes to encourage physical activity and combat obesity, following months of coronavirus lockdown. The £2 billion "cycling and walking revolution" aims to promote biking and walking to work, with a focus on creating protected cycle routes in towns and cities. The government also plans to release £50 "bike repair vouchers" to help people fix their old cycles. Johnson hopes the initiative will boost active travel and contribute to a healthier, more active nation.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson's pledge comes on the heels of a plan to force restaurants to display calories on menus as part of a broader effort to win the battle of the bulge.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE says NetLink a 'buy' as yields more stable than telcos, Reits
summary: Maybank Kim Eng reinitiated coverage of NetLink NBN Trust with a "buy" call and target price of S$1.08, citing its more stable business compared to telcos and Reits. Analysts estimate NetLink's FY21 DPU yield to be 5.2%, comparable to Reits' FY20 average yield of 5.6% and telco players' yields of 5.5%. NetLink shares rose 0.5 cent or 0.5% to 97 Singapore cents, following the positive analyst assessment.

site_title: Neiman Marcus to close its store at Manhattan's Hudson Yards
summary: Neiman Marcus to close its store at Manhattan's Hudson Yards, along with three other US locations, as part of its bankruptcy proceedings. The luxury retailer cited the need to ensure long-term success and provide unparalleled luxury experiences. The closures, which include Fort Lauderdale and Palm Beach, Florida, and Bellevue, Washington, come after the pandemic further challenged the retail industry and accelerated bankruptcies. The developer Related Cos sees the departure as an opportunity to create attractive office space.

site_title: M+S bags record green loan for Marina One integrated development
summary: M+S Pte Ltd, a national joint venture between Malaysia and Singapore, has secured a record S$1.95 billion green loan for its Marina One integrated development from DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank. This is the largest green loan for a real estate company in the Asia-Pacific region. The loan will partially finance Marina One's office and retail components, valued at S$5 billion, and aims to bolster Singapore's reputation in sustainable financing.

site_title: Yen, Swiss franc up, US$ falls on US-China row, economic woes
summary: The US dollar fell to its lowest since September 2018 as investors sought safe-havens amid deteriorating US-China relations and economic concerns. The dollar index dropped 0.6% to 93.777, while the Japanese yen and Swiss franc strengthened, with the Swiss franc reaching a five-year high. The Federal Reserve's upcoming meeting may confirm recent hints about an average inflation target, which could keep interest rates lower for longer.

site_title: Oil rises on hopes for US stimulus measure
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude increasing 7 cents to $43.41 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate rising 31 cents to $41.60 a barrel, driven by hopes for a US stimulus measure. However, gains were limited by rising coronavirus cases and tensions between the US and China. A new US$1 trillion coronavirus aid package was expected to be unveiled by US Senate Republicans on Monday.

site_title: US sees manufacturing growth ahead of Federal Reserve meeting, GDP data
summary: The US economy is expected to see manufacturing growth ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting, despite a 35% shrinkage in the April-June quarter due to the pandemic. The Commerce Department releases its advance GDP estimate on Thursday. Lawmakers in Washington are debating a stimulus package, with lawmakers seeking to follow up on the $2.2 trillion CARES Act. The Federal Reserve meeting comes as surging coronavirus cases threaten the economy's gains.

site_title: CapitaLand expects H1 total Patmi to sink 85-95% on share of CCT, CMT losses
summary: CapitaLand has updated its profit guidance for the first half of 2020, expecting a 85-95% decline in total Patmi due to losses from its listed investments, CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) and CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT). The losses total S$553.9 million, with CMT posting a Q2 loss and CCT reporting a Q2 loss on revaluation of its properties. Operating Patmi and cash Patmi are also expected to decline by 25-35% and 40-50% respectively, compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Europe: Travel stocks drag Stoxx 600 lower after UK's quarantine move on Spain
summary: European stocks fell 0.3% on Monday, with travel stocks leading the decline after the UK imposed a two-week quarantine on travelers returning from Spain. The Stoxx 600 closed at a two-month low, extending its 40% loss this year. Airlines and tour operators, such as TUI and British Airways-owner IAG, dropped 6-11.3%. Spanish stocks fell 1.7%, while German stocks rose 2.7% thanks to a software company's announcement. Global investors were on edge due to deteriorating US-China ties.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit posts 2.5% rise in Q2 DPU to 3.36 S cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit posted a 2.5% rise in its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.36 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from acquired nursing rehabilitation facilities in Japan and higher rent from its Singapore properties. Gross revenue grew 4.9% to S$30.3 million, while net property income increased 5.3% to S$28.2 million. The Reit's distributable income rose 2.5% to S$20.3 million. CEO Yong Yean Chau attributed the "resilient performance" to favourable rental lease structures and prudent financial risk management.

site_title: Tritech to appoint former executive director charged with corruption as consultant
summary: TRITECH Group has appointed former executive director Cai Jungang as a consultant despite him facing seven corruption charges. Cai resigned on July 23 after being charged by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau for allegedly giving loans as gratification to a former LTA deputy group director. The loans totalled S$285,000 and are not considered material to the group. Cai will defend the charges and has taken steps to do so, while Tritech expects his appointment to have minimal impact on its business.

site_title: China's industrial profit growth quickens in June, signals firming economic recovery
summary: China's industrial firms saw a 11.5% year-on-year profit growth in June, the fastest pace in over a year, as the country's economic recovery from the coronavirus crisis gains momentum. Industrial firms' profits rose to 666.55 billion yuan in June, with significant improvements in profit in steel, oil, and gas extraction. However, analysts warn that the rebound is heavily reliant on state-led investment and domestic demand remains weak, with uncertainties over the sustainability of profit growth.

site_title: US orders for durable goods surge due to motor vehicle demand
summary: US durable goods orders surged 7.3% in June, led by a 85.7% increase in motor vehicle and parts demand. Manufacturing appears to be stabilizing, with core capital goods orders rising 3.3% and shipments increasing 3.4%. While demand remains below pre-pandemic levels, the recovery has been largely V-shaped, unlike the services sector. A decline in commercial aircraft demand and weak demand for commercial aircraft orders contributed to the mixed results.

site_title: The worst for US renters and apartment owners is yet to come
summary: US renters and apartment owners face a worsening financial situation as expanded unemployment benefits and eviction bans expire at the end of the month. One in three renters failed to make full payments in July, and nearly 12 million could receive eviction notices in the next four months. Experts warn of a potential "dark fall and winter" for housing, with landlords facing $22 billion in missed rent payments and long-term occupancy declines.

site_title: Google misled users over data privacy issues: Aussie regulator
summary: Australia's competition regulator accused Google of misleading consumers over data privacy issues, alleging the company did not explicitly get consent or properly inform users about combining personal information with browsing activities on non-Google websites in 2016. The regulator seeks a fine "in the millions" and aims to establish a precedent. Google claims the change was optional and consent was sought through prominent notifications, but the regulator says this was misleading. The case could shape how tech companies behave worldwide.

site_title: Defensive stance helps GIC post 20-year annualised real rate of return of 2.7%
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, posted a 20-year annualised real rate of return of 2.7% despite the Covid-19 pandemic, driven by its defensive stance and focus on preserving and enhancing its portfolio. The fund's portfolio achieved an annualised nominal rate of return of 4.6% over the same period. GIC's CEO Lim Chow Kiat attributed the reduction to the way the 20-year rolling return is computed, and not due to the pandemic or recent market movements. The fund remains cautious, with a focus on value emerging in sectors sold down 30-50% by the market, and is poised to invest the country's foreign reserves to enhance long-term returns.

site_title: Malaysian court to deliver verdict in Najib's first 1MDB trial
summary: A Malaysian court is set to deliver a verdict on Tuesday in Najib Razak's first corruption trial related to the 1MDB scandal. Najib, the former prime minister, denies wrongdoing and claims ignorance in the case, which centers on the transfer of RM42 million into his bank accounts. The verdict is a test of the rule of law in Malaysia and could lead to a conviction and sentence of up to 20 years in prison, or a ban from politics for several years. Najib faces four charges of corruption and three of money-laundering, with the outcome expected to be announced at 10am local time.

images.alt_text: A Malaysian court will hand down its verdict in Najib Razak's first corruption trial on Tuesday following a long-running case probing the former prime minister's role in the multi-billion-dollar 1MDB scandal.

site_title: Brookfield said to have picked banks for US$500m Reit IPO in India
summary: Brookfield Asset Management has selected Bank of America, Citigroup, and Morgan Stanley to arrange an initial public offering (IPO) of its US$500 million India real estate investment trust (Reit). The offering, which could be listed on the Mumbai stock exchange by the end of this year, would add to India's growing number of Reit listings. Brookfield, which owns 22 million square feet of office properties in India, aims to raise at least US$500 million through the IPO, joining other Reit listings such as Mindspace Business Parks Reit, which is seeking to raise about US$600 million.

images.alt_text: Brookfield Asset Management's India Reit offering could be listed on the Mumbai stock exchange as soon as end-2020.

site_title: It's official: A Sino-US Cold War is on
summary: A Sino-US Cold War is unfolding, with the US viewing China as a major global rival. The Trump administration, fueled by "China bashers" in Washington, is pushing for a long and costly confrontation with Beijing, including new international alliances and military presence abroad. This shift marks a significant departure from the post-Cold War consensus that the US could engage China in the economic and diplomatic spheres. The US is now considering regime change in China and forming a new alliance of democracies to counter the Chinese Communist Party. The "Trump Doctrine" aims to use harsh actions, sanctions, and isolation to change China's behavior, but its effectiveness and impact on the US are uncertain.

site_title: End of Hilton contract revives question of HPL's plan for its hotel on Orchard Road
summary: Hilton's contract renewal with Hotel Properties Limited (HPL) for the Hilton Singapore hotel on Orchard Road ends in late 2021, prompting questions about HPL's plan for its own hotel on the same street. The HPL hotel is set to undergo a S$90 million revamp and will be the only Hilton hotel along Orchard Road when it opens in early 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong to ban dine-in services and social gatherings of more than two people
summary: Hong Kong has banned dine-in services and social gatherings of more than two people not from the same family, starting Wednesday, amid its worst coronavirus outbreak. The city also requires masks in outdoors areas, except for medical exemptions, and has shut sports venues, swimming pools, and other closed businesses. The restrictions are for one week, with officials scrambling to slow a third wave of infections and boost healthcare facilities reaching capacity. The city reported 142 local cases, the sixth consecutive day above 100, with 40% of cases of unknown origins.

site_title: New roles for laid-off Singapore workers may not be perfect fit
summary: Singapore's government has unveiled an SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package to support 100,000 job seekers with new jobs and training positions amid the coronavirus pandemic-fuelled recession. Over 12,000 workers have been found roles since March, mostly in the public sector, and 7,000 immediate vacancies have been posted, including PMET opportunities. However, analysts warn that these new roles may not be a perfect fit for displaced workers, especially white-collar job seekers, and that the overall package may not significantly cushion the downturn in the labor market.

site_title: Americans hunker down, threatening the self-storage industry
summary: The US self-storage industry is facing significant challenges due to the coronavirus pandemic, aggressive competition, and overexpansion. The industry's traditional reliance on the "Four Ds" (death, divorce, displacement, and disaster) is no longer sufficient, and the industry's growth has slowed. Rising rents and improved customer service have attracted new competitors, making the industry vulnerable to economic downturns. As a result, Americans are hunkering down, leading to a decline in storage space usage and threatening the industry's long-term stability.

site_title: No dancing, just listening: Berlin club Berghain reopens doors
summary: Berlin's iconic techno nightclub Berghain has reopened its doors with an unusual sound exhibition, allowing just 50 visitors at a time to experience an immersive, 3D soundscape. The "Eleven songs - Halle am Berghain" exhibition, curated by artistic duo Sam Auinger and Hannes Strobl, features a unique soundscape of rhythmic throbbing, city noises, and helicopter blades, designed to interact with the space's concrete architecture. The event runs until August 2 and has drawn visitors eager for an alternative experience after weeks of confinement.

site_title: Family office advisers can sharpen capabilities with new skills map
summary: The Institute of Banking and Finance Singapore (IBF) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) launched a Family Office Advisor Skills Map to enhance Singapore's family office ecosystem. The map outlines required skills and competencies for professionals advising family offices, including wealth planning administration and corporate governance. The initiative aims to deepen specialist skill sets among family office advisers, promoting the growth of Singapore's family office sector.

site_title: RMG benefits from early investment in healthcare app; H1 net profit falls 38.2%
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 38.2% drop in net profit to S$17.2 million for the first half of 2020, due to revenue losses from elective surgeries and foreign patients amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite this, the company's early investment in its digital healthcare platform, RafflesConnect, has allowed for seamless integration of offline and online services. The group plans to continue developing and investing in RafflesConnect to provide enhanced access to services and improve customer experience.

site_title: SCMP to put up paywall amid HK slump
summary: The South China Morning Post (SCMP), a Hong Kong-based English-language newspaper backed by Alibaba Group, will introduce a paywall next month due to declining advertising revenue caused by the coronavirus pandemic and months of political unrest. Readers will be limited to a few free articles per month. This move is a response to the economic slump in Hong Kong and the impact on the newspaper's advertising business.

site_title: Gold's rally breaks 2011 record with sights set on US$2,000
summary: Gold prices broke the 2011 record, reaching $1,944.71 an ounce, as investors sought havens amid global economic concerns and a weak US dollar. Silver also surged, hitting nearly a seven-year high, with expectations of US monetary policy to remain accommodative. Analysts predict gold could reach $2,000 an ounce, citing rising geopolitical tensions, negative real rates, and stimulus measures. The metal's rally is seen as a sign of a post-GFC environment similar to the one in the 2000s, with some predicting stagflation and a potential for more unconventional monetary policies.

images.alt_text: Gold is getting support from a long list of factors: geopolitical tensions are rising, real rates have tumbled, the US dollar is weaker, and government and central banks worldwide have unleashed vast stimulus measures to try and boost economies.

site_title: Logistics firms focus on staying agile, seizing opportunities
summary: Logistics firms in Singapore are adapting to the economic fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic by diversifying their services and forming partnerships. According to Enterprise Singapore, transport and logistics companies are utilizing strategies such as broadening services and in-market partnerships to drive growth. These efforts are enabling the firms to remain agile and intensify their business growth despite the challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: SPH and SPH Foundation award scholarships to 29 recipients
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and the SPH Foundation have awarded 29 scholarships to recipients, including two for the SPH journalism scholarship. The awards aim to support students from modest backgrounds in their studies at local universities. This year's recipients include Wong Yang and Osmond Chia, who will pursue degrees in comparative literature and communication studies, respectively. The scholarships also support children of SPH staff and newspaper vendors, and 13 students from modest family backgrounds received the bond-free Lim Kim San Memorial Scholarship.

site_title: E50 awards: 'Champion mindset' needed to overcome Covid-19 challenges
summary: Singapore's 26th Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards, recognizing the 50 most enterprising privately-owned local companies, emphasizes the need for a "champion mindset" to overcome Covid-19 challenges. The awards' theme, "Extraordinary Times, Exceptional Resilience," highlights businesses' perseverance in a challenging economic climate. To win, companies must adopt a mindset of overcoming adversity, turning setbacks into opportunities, and demonstrating sustainability practices. The awards will feature special awards for overseas expansion and enterprise transformation, with nominations closing on September 15.

site_title: CapitaLand to begin construction of third IT park in Chennai
summary: CapitaLand is starting construction on the first phase of its International Tech Park Chennai (ITPC), a 9.3ha development along Chennai's IT corridor. The first phase will offer 2.6 million sq ft of office space, with 4.6 million sq ft of potential development space. Located near the city's IT hub, the project is expected to contribute to Chennai's growing tech industry.

site_title: Overseas travel is out, why not spend at home?
summary: Singapore is launching a $45 million campaign to encourage domestic tourism, "SingapoRediscovers," to salvage its tourism industry devastated by the Covid-19 pandemic. The city-state's compact size and efficient transport system may hinder the effort, but hotels are focusing on staycations with luxury packages and promotions. To attract residents, Singapore is highlighting the tranquility and less crowded attractions, similar to Japan's "Empty" tourism campaign. However, higher domestic prices may deter some, and a vaccine may not be available until 2021, making overseas travel unlikely.

site_title: Covid-19 by far the worst global health emergency it has faced: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has described the COVID-19 pandemic as the worst global health emergency it has faced, with over 16 million infected and 650,000 deaths. Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus emphasized the need for strict adherence to health measures to control the virus, citing countries like Canada, China, and South Korea as examples of successful control. The WHO stressed the importance of saving lives and suppressing transmission while protecting vulnerable groups, and acknowledged that it's impossible for countries to keep borders shut indefinitely.

site_title: Sing Investments' Q2 net profit down 22% due to allowances made for Covid-19
summary: Sing Investments' Q2 net profit declined 22.2% to S$3.9 million due to additional allowances made for Covid-19's impact on the macroeconomic situation. The company provided S$3.3 million in allowances for credit losses, resulting in a 19.7% decline in net profit for the first six months. Revenue dipped 1.1% to S$21.1 million in the quarter, but rose 3.2% to S$43.1 million for the six-month period. The company maintained adequate loss allowances and has been supporting customers with working capital needs via Enterprise Singapore loans.

site_title: GIC must keep its eye on containing risks
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) must maintain its defensive position amidst the ongoing public health, economic, and financial crisis. The extraordinary times have led to swift responses, including drastic measures, record stimulus, and wild financial movements. GIC's focus should be on protecting and enhancing its reserves under management, ensuring it navigates the challenging environment with caution and resilience.

site_title: Hibiki, minority unitholders call for Accordia Golf Trust EGM
summary: Minority unitholders of Accordia Golf Trust, led by Hibiki, have called for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on August 18, requesting the trustee manager to convene the meeting. They aim to block the sale of the trust's 88 golf courses in Japan to sponsor Accordia Golf for a price deemed too low. The unitholders also seek to exclude Daiwa Securities Group from voting in the EGM due to its vested interest in the proposed transaction and want funds to be distributed quickly.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, a significant success. In other market news, US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo by US President Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks ended a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: China's new mini-IPO market opens to frenzied trade, triggers circuit breakers
summary: China's new mini-IPO market opened on Monday, with 32 companies raising a combined 9.5 billion yuan (S$1.87 billion) via initial public offerings. Trading was characterized by heavy volumes and volatility, with circuit breakers triggered for both surging and slumping stocks. Despite the frenzied trade, the market is seen as a step towards helping small firms access capital quickly and growing innovative companies. The New Third Board aims to feed bigger bourses, including Shanghai's STAR Market and Shenzhen's ChiNext, as China seeks to build a multi-tiered capital market.

site_title: SPH chairman Lee Boon Yang donates another S$100,000 to School of the Arts Endowment Fund
summary: SPH chairman Dr. Lee Boon Yang has donated $100,000 to the School of the Arts Endowment Fund, his second donation to the fund, which supports bursaries, scholarships, and financial aid to arts students. The fund aims to make arts education more accessible, and Dr. Lee hopes to see more organizations and individuals contribute to this effort. The donation has helped alumna Ashley Jane Leow, who received a bursary to study film in the US and France, easing her family's financial burden and giving her confidence in her artistic pursuits.

site_title: Cat tests positive for coronavirus in England
summary: A cat in England has tested positive for the coronavirus, marking the first confirmed case of an animal infected with the virus in Britain. The cat, whose owners had both tested positive, recovered without transmission to others. The UK government attributes the infection to contact with its owners, who had contracted Covid-19.

site_title: Heavy is the head that wears the semiconductor crown
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) has solidified its position as the global leader in chips, but this increased power comes with risks. After Intel Corp delayed its next-generation chip production, TSMC jumped to a record high after Intel placed an order for 180,000 wafers, a significant contract. This development, combined with Apple's plan to set up a display R&D plant within TSMC, puts pressure on the company to meet the demands of its numerous clients, including Nvidia, Qualcomm, and MediaTek. As TSMC expands, it faces concerns from regulators and clients, who worry about the company's growing power and potential anti-competitive practices.

site_title: GIC sees 4 major shifts that threaten future returns, raise volatility
summary: A Singapore sovereign wealth fund, GIC, has identified four major shifts threatening future returns and raising volatility, including worsening US-China tensions, diversification of supply chains, and the economic pain from the pandemic. Global supply chains are likely to see "significant" structural change post Covid-19, which will hurt productivity growth. The fund's report also notes China's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: 'Landing zone' opens up for London and Brussels to reach Brexit deal
summary: The UK and EU have narrowed bilateral differences in Brexit talks, potentially paving the way for a trade deal in coming weeks. Key concessions include the EU's willingness to consider an alternative enforcement mechanism and the UK's openness to a "bare bones" agreement. However, significant issues remain, such as fair competition guarantees and fishing rules, which could still sink the proposed deal. The EU has warned the UK that a deal must be agreed by October to meet the December deadline for a legally operational treaty, with the window of opportunity closing rapidly.

site_title: Office vacancies in China's cities soar despite economy's reopening
summary: Office vacancies in China's major cities, including Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Beijing, have reached their highest levels in over a decade, with vacancy rates reaching 20% in Shanghai and 21% in Shenzhen. Despite the economy's reopening, corporate tenants are adopting a cautious attitude, putting relocation or expansion plans on hold. This trend is attributed to ongoing uncertainty and caution in the market, with no clear signs of a significant recovery in the near future.

site_title: More diversity in Parliament, Cabinet part of future
summary: Singapore's new government, led by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, emphasizes the importance of greater diversity in Parliament and Cabinet, reflecting the country's desire for more debate and views in politics. The Cabinet, with seven out of 20 full ministers being non-Chinese, aims to maintain cohesion and national purpose while accommodating diversity. Lee also stressed the need to prepare for the future, including transforming the economy, upgrading skills, and building a better society, as the country navigates the Covid-19 crisis and beyond.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust to sell Guangzhou, Paris properties above book value
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) has entered into conditional agreements to sell its Guangzhou and Paris properties to two unrelated parties for S$191.4 million, resulting in estimated net gains of S$23.2 million. The Guangzhou serviced residence is being sold at a 52% premium to its book value, while the Paris property is being sold at a 69% premium. The sales are expected to complete in the first and fourth quarters of next year, allowing ART to rejuvenate its portfolio and unlock underlying value.

images.alt_text: For the French serviced residence, the divestment price is 69 per cent above the property's book value and 60.4 per cent higher than the acquisition price in 2010.

site_title: StarHub CEO to retire, global search for successor starts
summary: StarHub CEO Peter Kaliaropoulos to retire on Oct 31, marking the end of his two-year tenure. A global search for his successor will begin immediately. Despite concerns about near-term share price pressure, analysts believe the impact will be mild due to the telco's intact fundamentals. An interim board executive committee will oversee the transition process, with Kaliaropoulos joining as a co-opted member until a new CEO is appointed.

images.alt_text: The abrupt announcement of Peter Kaliaropoulos comes on the back of a family member being seriously ill, necessitating his return to Sydney.

site_title: New travel curbs as world comes to grips with second Covid-19 wave
summary: Nations in Asia imposed new travel restrictions and quarantines amid a surge in Covid-19 cases, as the world grapples with a possible second wave of infections. Australia, Vietnam, and China reported record daily rises, while Papua New Guinea shut its borders. The World Health Organization warned that travel restrictions alone cannot contain the spread of the virus, urging countries to adopt proven strategies like social distancing and mask-wearing. Europe's summer reopening was disrupted by Britain's quarantine on Spain, and officials in affected countries are determined to prevent a second wave, despite potential economic costs.

site_title: As bankers return to office, industry body warns of new risks of bad conduct
summary: Banks returning to office poses new challenges for enforcing good conduct among staff, as most employees worked from home during the pandemic. The Financial Markets Industry Body warns of increased risks of bad conduct due to the shift. During lockdowns, dealers faced compliance challenges while trading from home, and many firms did not allow remote work before the pandemic. The industry body emphasizes the need for banks to adapt their policies and procedures to ensure compliance with regulations.

site_title: Ideas flow on continued help as Jobs Support Scheme nears expiry
summary: Singapore is considering proposals to extend the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) as it nears expiry in August. The scheme, which provides wage subsidies to retrenched workers, aims to smooth the transition pain and ensure economic recovery. Ideas include better wage subsidies, tighter immigration rules, and a return of a pre-Independence "Workers' Brigade" to keep Singaporeans employed. Economists and experts suggest refining the scheme to focus on sectors still lagging and providing support for lower-wage employees.

site_title: Canadian real estate firm QuadReal taps green bond demand for price advantage
summary: Canada's QuadReal Property Group Ltd issued C$350 million of 10-year green bonds at a price three basis points tighter than comparable regular bonds, providing a pricing advantage for borrowers. The firm, which manages US$28 billion in real estate assets, saw 57 investors in its inaugural green bond deal, up from 35 for its sale of regular bonds last month. Borrowing costs for investment-grade firms are at historically low rates, helping firms weather the Covid-19 pandemic. This is part of a larger trend, with Canadian provinces and firms pricing over C$6 billion of green bonds this year.

site_title: Louis Vuitton owner's sales slide in Q2 after virus hit
summary: LVMH, the world's largest luxury goods group, reported a 38% decline in comparable sales in Q2 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Louis Vuitton owner noted a recovery since June, with fashion and leather goods division experiencing a 37% fall in like-for-like sales. Overall, LVMH's revenues decreased to 7.8 billion euros, down 38% on a like-for-like basis.

site_title: Stamford Tyres reverses into losses for FY20, halves dividend
summary: Stamford Tyres reported a net loss of S$4 million for FY20, reversing from a profit of S$474,000 in FY19. The loss was due to one-time expenses related to the closure of a loss-making operation in Australia and higher allowance for doubtful receivables. Revenue fell 14.7% to S$199.9 million, mainly due to lower sales in South-east Asia and the rationalization of non-profitable operations. The group has recommended a 0.5 cent per share dividend, halved from last year. The company aims to diversify product offerings and improve sales productivity.

site_title: A*Star co-develops test that can tell within 15 minutes if someone's been exposed to the coronavirus
summary: A*Star co-develops a rapid antibody test kit, called Assure, that can determine if someone has been exposed to the coronavirus within 15 minutes. The test kit detects IgG and IgM antibodies, which are produced by the human immune system after exposure to Sars-CoV-2. Studies have shown that these antibodies are correlated with the severity of Covid-19, making them a good marker for previous infection. The kit has been granted provisional authorisation and is ready for deployment, with production ramping up to meet global demand.

site_title: BMW vows to tie executive pay to climate goals
summary: BMW has committed to tying executive pay to its carbon emissions reduction targets, aiming to lower CO2 emissions by millions of tonnes by 2030. CEO Oliver Zipse stated that the company will report on its progress annually and tie board compensation to these targets. BMW aims to sell seven million electric or hybrid vehicles by 2030 and reduce emissions per vehicle by at least one third. The company will also measure its entire lifecycle environmental sustainability, from supply chains to production, to achieve these goals.

site_title: Group of bank creditors to file for Hyflux judicial management
summary: A group of bank creditors will file an application to place Hyflux under judicial management, citing a lack of trust in the company's management to lead restructuring efforts. The creditors, including Mizuho, Bangkok Bank, and Standard Chartered Bank, argue that Hyflux's management has presented a "fait accompli" and cannot be trusted to lead any restructuring effort. The move comes as Hyflux faces criminal investigations and has received unsolicited proposals from potential investors, including Utico and Aqua Munda. The creditors believe that a judicial management application is necessary to protect their interests and prevent liquidation.

site_title: Next financial crisis may be looming, former HKMA chief says
summary: A former Hong Kong Monetary Authority chief, Joseph Yam, warns that another global financial crisis may be looming due to quantitative easing by central banks during the coronavirus pandemic. He cites volatile international capital, a problematic culture, and a large budget deficit as concerns. Yam, a member of Hong Kong's Executive Council, has confidence in the city's exchange-rate system and foreign reserves, but fears a third financial crisis similar to the 1990s Asian crisis and the 2008 great financial crisis.

site_title: How GIC stress-tests and diversifies its portfolio
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) has successfully navigated the Covid-19 pandemic by stress-testing its portfolio and diversifying its assets. The fund reduced risk asset exposure and increased its defensive positions, helping to cushion the portfolio against market damage. GIC has been investing in stable sectors and companies with long-term contracted incomes, and has also been acquiring equity stakes in fintech, health-tech, and enterprise software companies. The fund's defensive approach has helped protect the portfolio against significant market damage, with the pandemic's impact on GIC's returns being "not large".

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust reports dismal Q1 results due to Covid-19
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust reported a 10.7% drop in gross revenue to S$93.7 million and a 19.5% decline in net property income to S$68.5 million for Q1 due to Covid-19. Rental reliefs granted to tenants and lower occupancy rates contributed to the decline. The retail environment in Hong Kong remained challenging, and the Reit extended S$18.1 million of rental reliefs to support tenants. The uncertain Covid-19 situation and US-China tensions continue to unsettle the retail market, with the Reit preparing to continue supporting tenants.

site_title: Darco to exercise option to scrap Nambo deal
summary: Darco Water Technologies' board has directed its management to exercise the reversal option for the Nambo project in Indonesia due to the West Java government's refusal to re-negotiate terms. The reversal option will allow Darco to unwind the sale-and-purchase agreement and recover its investment. In return, the seller will pay Darco US$300,000 and US$400,000, and the target company will pay US$600,000. The completion of the repurchase is expected within 14 days.

site_title: CEO of StarHub retires, global search for his successor to begin
summary: StarHub's CEO, Peter Kaliaropoulos, will retire on October 31, marking the end of his two-year tenure. The company will begin a global search for his successor, with an interim executive committee established to oversee the transition. Kaliaropoulos will serve as a co-opted member on the committee until a new CEO is appointed.

site_title: US durable goods orders advanced more than forecast in June
summary: US durable goods orders rose 7.3% in June, exceeding forecasts, driven by a surge in demand for motor vehicles and business activity as states reopened their economies. This marks the second-straight robust increase, suggesting manufacturing is stabilizing. However, spending on goods remains below pre-pandemic levels, with core capital goods orders increasing 3.3% and shipments of core capital goods rising 3.4%. Despite this, the durable goods orders are experiencing a largely V-shaped recovery, unlike the service sector.

site_title: Europe: Equities diverge at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets traded mixed at the open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.2% and the Paris CAC 40 index shedding 0.3%. In contrast, Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.3%. The mixed performance was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks propelling shares higher.

site_title: Amazon announces 1,000 Jobs in Ireland, new Dublin campus
summary: Amazon has announced plans to create 1,000 jobs in Ireland and open a new Dublin campus, marking an increase in demand for cloud services. The new campus will be a 170,000 square foot facility that will be used by Amazon Web Services' cloud computing employees, set to open in 2022. The hires will bring Amazon Ireland's permanent workforce to 5,000 over the next two years.

site_title: Diversity in Parliament and Cabinet for the future: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for greater diversity in Parliament and Cabinet, citing the July 10 General Election's results, where the ruling PAP's vote share fell to 61.2% and opposition parties won 10 seats. Lee vowed to give expression to the trend of wanting more debate and diversity, while maintaining cohesion and national purpose. He also highlighted the importance of unity and support for the new Cabinet, formed to navigate the Covid-19 crisis and beyond.

site_title: WHO says Covid-19 by far its worst global health emergency
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the Covid-19 pandemic its worst global health emergency, citing over 16 million infected cases and 650,000 deaths. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus emphasized the need for strict health measures, such as mask-wearing and physical distancing, to control outbreaks. Resurgences of the virus in various regions are alarming, and nations must balance the need to suppress transmission with identifying vulnerable groups and saving lives. The priority remains saving lives, with the goal of keeping death rates to zero or a minimum.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.87 points to 1,591.48 on Monday, driven by a higher volume of 11.612 billion lots worth RM6.235 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 582 to 505, indicating a positive trading session.

site_title: Darco to exercise reversal option to scrap controversial Nambo deal
summary: Darco Water Technologies' board directed management to exercise the reversal option for the Nambo project, scrapping the deal due to the West Java government's refusal to re-negotiate terms. The seller Emsus Co. had previously informed Darco that the government was not agreeable to re-negotiations. As a result, Darco will issue a notice to the seller to exercise the reversal option, allowing it to unwind the sale and purchase of shares. The seller will pay Darco US$1 million, and the target company, PT Jabar Bersih Lestar, will also pay US$600,000.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open higher on stimulus, dovish Fed hopes
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose at the open on Monday, driven by hopes for more stimulus and a dovish signal from the Federal Reserve to revive the US domestic economy. The S&P 500 gained 4.21 points, or 0.13%, to 3,219.84, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 58.52 points, or 0.56%, to 10,421.70. In contrast, the Dow Jones fell 22.22 points, or 0.08%, to 26,447.67. Investors are shrugging off surging Covid-19 cases and US-China tensions, betting on economic recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with more losses
summary: Hong Kong shares closed lower on Monday, extending losses from last week due to coronavirus concerns. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.41% to 24,603.26, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.26%. The city has imposed containment measures, including a ban on gatherings of more than two people in public. This news contributed to the decline in Hong Kong stocks, which were already impacted by global market uncertainty.

site_title: GSH joint venture breaks ground for luxury mixed-use project in Chongqing
summary: GSH Corp's joint venture, GSH Properties (Chongqing) Co, broke ground for a luxury mixed-use project in Chongqing's Bishan district. The project, valued at over S$98.5 million, will feature a 300-room hotel and 1,600-unit residential condominium. Construction of the hotel is expected to be completed by end 2022, while the condominium will be completed by end 2024. The project is strategically located near Chongqing's second international airport and overlooks Yuhu Lake, marking the first luxury project in the Bishan district.

site_title: GL Limited, Oxley expect FY2020 net losses
summary: GL Limited and Oxley Holdings expect FY2020 net losses due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on their hospitality and oil-and-gas businesses, respectively. GL Limited expects impairment losses and lower income from its oil royalty interest, while Oxley Holdings' preliminary assessment indicates a net loss for the second half of FY2020 and the full year. Both companies have adequate liquidity and plan to release their results by August 26 and August 29, respectively.

site_title: Gold rush drives penny stocks in sector; STI down 0.14%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.14% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 3.72 points to 2,575.79. Losers outnumbered gainers 250 to 179, driven by a weak finish on Wall Street last week. Hongkong Land and Sats were the biggest losers, down 2.84% and 2.47% respectively, amid concerns over a potential decline in office rents due to a new Covid-19 wave in Hong Kong.

site_title: STI down 0.14%, while penny gold miners ride gold rush
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.14% to 2,575.79 on Monday, with 250 losers outnumbering 179 gainers. Hongkong Land and Sats were the biggest losers, down 2.84% and 2.47% respectively, amid concerns over office downsizing and a bleak aviation outlook.

site_title: Certis to extend free temperature-tracking platform to SMEs
summary: Certis, a security firm, will extend its temperature-tracking platform, iTemp, to over 270,000 businesses in Singapore, including small and medium-sized enterprises, to help combat Covid-19. The platform provides real-time insights into employee health and will be rolled out on August 11. This move aims to give back to the community amid the pandemic.

site_title: SPH and SPH Foundation award scholarships to 29 recipients
summary: SPH and the SPH Foundation awarded 29 scholarships to recipients, including 2 journalism students, Osmond Chia and Wong Yang, who will pursue degrees in communication studies and comparative literature, respectively. The scholarships aim to support students from modest family backgrounds, as well as children of SPH staff and newspaper vendors. The awards ceremony highlighted the importance of journalism in providing credible news and information during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: AstraZeneca bets up to US$6b on new Daiichi cancer drug
summary: AstraZeneca has agreed to pay up to $6 billion to Japan's Daiichi Sankyo for the development and marketing of a new cancer treatment, DS-1062, an antibody drug conjugate targeting the TROP2 protein. The deal includes an upfront payment of $1 billion and further payments based on regulatory and sales milestones. The company expects the drug to bring in $1 billion or more in annual sales, and the agreement is part of AstraZeneca's efforts to bolster its portfolio of cancer therapies.

site_title: Wanted: Leadership values, higher path to US greatness
summary: The US economy, which had experienced a 128-month expansion, abruptly ended in February due to the pandemic, leading to a recession and significant job losses. Despite a $2 trillion economic relief package, analysts predict a gradual recovery, with GDP expected to decline by 8% this year. Donald Trump's re-election campaign is struggling, as his economic strategy has been criticized for blowing off-course, with a budget deficit projected to reach $3.7 trillion and public debt nearing 100% of GDP. Historians may view Trump's tenure as a period of callous indifference to presidential obligations, and his leadership style is seen as lacking the capacity and desire to unite society and represent American interests.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: M+S bags S$1.95b green loan from DBS, OCBC, UOB, the largest green loan for a real estate company in the Asia-Pacific. Fitch Solutions forecasts Singapore dollar to stabilise with a stronger S$1.3950 per US dollar. Ascott Residence Trust sells serviced residences for S$191.4m, expected to realise total estimated net gains of S$23.2m. Hyflux receives letter from North American fund manager with a "strong" track record of investing in infrastructure and real estate. Singapore shares dipped 0.14% with the Straits Times Index down 3.72 points.

site_title: Nordea warns of compliance job cuts, reversing hiring boom
summary: Nordea Bank Abp is cutting compliance jobs, reversing a hiring boom that added thousands of positions in 2016 and 2017. Head of financial crime prevention Mikael Bjertrup says automation will improve quality and "it's simply too expensive" to maintain the current headcount. The bank's compliance job cuts come as other top banks have also reduced staff in the department, with headcounts growing 10-fold in some cases.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors forecasts 140b yen full-year loss on falling car sales
summary: Mitsubishi Motors forecasts an operating loss of 140 billion yen (S$1.83 billion) for the year to March due to a significant decline in car sales, largely attributed to the coronavirus pandemic. The company reported a 53.3 billion yen operating loss in the first quarter, with vehicle sales more than halving between April and June from the previous year. As part of its restructuring plan, Mitsubishi will stop producing the Pajero SUV model in the first half of 2021 and close a central Japan plant.

site_title: Carrefour expands Uber Eats service to more French cities, Belgium
summary: Carrefour, a French supermarket retailer, is expanding its Uber Eats partnership nationwide in France and launching the service in Belgium, with 330 stores already participating. Initially launched in April to aid Parisians during the lockdown, the 30-minute home delivery service will now be available to a wider range of stores. The expansion aims to increase convenience for customers, particularly in Belgium, where the service will be launched in September.

site_title: Singdollar likely to stabilise along with Covid-19 caseload, says Fitch Solutions
summary: Fitch Solutions has revised its forecast for the Singapore dollar's (SGD) average exchange rate to S$1.3950 per US dollar (USD) for 2020 and S$1.3800 per USD for 2021, citing stability in the currency and a likely global economic recovery. The firm expects the SGD to remain broadly stable around current levels for the remainder of 2020, with a slight strengthening in 2021 due to sustained risk-on conditions and a weakening US dollar.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher on gold stocks, central bank comments
summary: Australian shares rose 0.34% to 6,044.2, driven by a record rally in gold stocks and reassurances from the Reserve Bank of Australia's Assistant Governor Chris Kent that the central bank would intervene if market conditions worsened. The gold stocks added over 4% to hit a record peak amid a US-China diplomatic row that weakened the US dollar and boosted gold prices.

site_title: Male bosses across European retail still decide what women want
summary: Women in European retail are underrepresented in corporate suites, despite being the sector's biggest customers and workforce. Only 3% of the 87 main consumption and retail goods companies are female-run, and less than a quarter have women in top leadership roles. Despite efforts to promote women, such as Adidas' search for a new global head of human resources, major obstacles remain, including biased selection processes and the need for greater flexibility in work arrangements. The pandemic has accelerated the need for change, with some companies hoping it will boost opportunities for women.

site_title: Nominations open for 2020 Enterprise 50 Awards
summary: Nominations are open for the 2020 Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards, recognizing the 50 most enterprising, privately-owned local companies in Singapore. The awards, organized by KPMG in Singapore and The Business Times, aim to encourage companies to grow and develop despite the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The theme of this year's event is "Extraordinary Times, Exceptional Resilience." Nominations close on September 15, with winners to be announced at a ceremony in January 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes lower on US-China tensions
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed 0.16% lower on Monday, following a four-day weekend, amid intensifying US-China tensions. Global risk aversion led to a sharp opening, with the broader Topix index gaining 0.24%. The US-China tensions, coupled with rising tariffs, have sparked worries on Wall Street, causing stocks to fall for a second session in a row.

site_title: Hong Kong to ban all restaurant dining, mandate masks outdoors
summary: Hong Kong will announce a ban on all restaurant dining and mandate facemasks outdoors, effective from Wednesday, to curb the surge in coronavirus cases. The move comes as the city faces a critical period to contain the virus, with over 2,600 people infected and 19 deaths since late January. This will be the first time the city has completely banned dining in restaurants, as authorities seek to slow the spread of the virus.

site_title: Chinese electric SUV maker seeks up to US$950m in US IPO
summary: Li Auto Inc, a Chinese electric SUV maker, is seeking up to $950 million in a US initial public offering. The company plans to sell 95 million shares at $8 to $10 apiece. This move follows other electric-vehicle makers in tapping the US capital market, with NIO Inc shares having doubled since its 2018 IPO. Li Auto's listing could further demonstrate the growing interest in electric vehicles and China's expanding global presence in the industry.

site_title: Indonesia says to lend more to regions to support economy
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, announced a 11.5 trillion rupiah (S$1.1 billion) state fund placement with regional development banks to support economic recovery amid the pandemic. The funds will be used to revive economic activity in top economic hubs, with a 15 trillion rupiah loan scheme for Jakarta and West Java. The aim is to restart postponed projects and support economic growth while maintaining Covid-19 health protocols, as Indonesia's economy is expected to contract this year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain on stimulus hopes; Sino-US tensions persist
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.79% on Monday, with Samsung Electronics leading gains, driven by hopes of a US$1 trillion coronavirus relief package. Tensions between the US and China persisted, with the closures of consulates in Houston and Chengdu escalating the situation. Foreigners were net buyers of 155.5 billion won worth of shares. The won rose 0.45% against the US dollar, while the benchmark Kospi index closed at 2,217.86.

site_title: As bankers return to the office, industry body warns of new risks of bad conduct
summary: Banks and brokerages face new challenges as employees return to the office after working from home during the pandemic, according to the FICC Markets Standards Board. The industry body warns of emerging risks of bad conduct, including difficulties in detecting domestic violence and substance abuse, and the potential for employees to feel pressured to maintain certain behaviors. Regulators will scrutinize firms' ability to maintain good trading standards while employees work remotely, with a focus on clear audit trails and addressing potential biases.

site_title: Von Furstenberg's brand is left exposed by the pandemic
summary: Diane von Furstenberg's fashion brand is facing a crisis after the COVID-19 pandemic exposed its financial struggles. The company, which had been losing money for years, relied on an old business model and was unable to adapt to the shift to online shopping. Von Furstenberg was forced to close 18 stores and lay off over 60% of its US, British, and French staff. The company is now focusing on its intellectual property value and e-commerce initiatives, with von Furstenberg's granddaughter, Talita, set to take over the brand in the future. Von Furstenberg has admitted to making mistakes and has implemented a restructuring plan, but the future of the brand remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Diane von Furstenberg's glamorous personal brand had masked the fact that her fashion line had been losing money for years.

site_title: SAP plans Qualtrics IPO two years after record deal
summary: SAP plans to sell a stake in its Qualtrics customer-survey software unit through a US public offering, marking a quick turnaround from its $8 billion purchase in 2018. The IPO will give Qualtrics greater autonomy, with founder Ryan Smith retaining a majority stake. SAP expects the IPO to be well-received by investors and will continue to fully participate in Qualtrics' growth potential. The move aims to help SAP compete with Salesforce and other cloud-based software companies.

images.alt_text: SAP SE said it will sell a stake in its Qualtrics customer-survey software unit through a US public offering less than two years after buying the firm to help compete with Salesforce Inc.

site_title: Young adults majority of new virus cases in Canada
summary: Canada's chief public health officer Theresa Tam warned that young adults, particularly those aged 20-39, are not "invincible" to Covid-19. According to recent data, 63% of new cases involve people under 39 years of age, with 30-39-year-olds having the highest incidence rate. The country has recorded 113,800 cases and 8,900 deaths. As Canada lifts lockdown restrictions, Tam called for caution and adherence to social distancing and hygiene measures.

site_title: US dollar squashed as Fed seen softening inflation stance
summary: The US dollar declined to a four-month low against the yen, a 22-month trough on the euro, and a five-year low against the Swiss franc, amid concerns over the US economic recovery. The Federal Reserve is expected to soften its inflation stance, potentially leading to lower interest rates. Investors are increasing bets on a potential accommodative shift, driving short dollar positions to a two-year high. The euro rose 0.5% to a four-and-a-half-month high, while the pound and other Antipodean currencies also gained.

images.alt_text: The dollar crumbled on Monday as cracks in the US economic recovery drove investors away from the world's reserve currency as they increased bets the Federal Reserve could flag another accommodative shift in its outlook this week.

site_title: Australia's Victoria to take longer than current lockdown period to slow virus
