summary: Victoria, Australia's second-most populous state, will take longer than the current six-week lockdown to slow the spread of the coronavirus, according to authorities. The state reported its deadliest day since the pandemic began with 10 deaths and 459 new cases, and Deputy Chief Medical Officer Nick Coatsworth said the virus is "embedded" within the community. Authorities have urged people to avoid non-essential travel and social gatherings, and to wear masks indoors, with the lockdown set to continue for an extended period.

site_title: Reliance overtakes Exxon to become world's No 2 energy firm
summary: Reliance Industries Ltd has surpassed Exxon Mobil Corp to become the world's second-largest energy company, overtaking Saudi Aramco. Reliance's shares rose 4.3% in Mumbai, increasing its market value to $189 billion. Chairman Mukesh Ambani's focus on digital and retail expansion has attracted $20 billion in investments, including from Google and Facebook. The company's energy business accounts for 80% of its revenue, but Ambani is pivoting towards technology and retail growth areas. Reliance's shares have jumped 46% this year, while Exxon's have fallen 39%.

site_title: China's industrial profit growth quickens, signals firming economic recovery
summary: China's industrial firms saw their profits rise 11.5% year-on-year in June, the fastest pace in over a year, as the country's economic recovery from the coronavirus crisis gains momentum. This marks the sector's second straight month of growth and the first monthly growth since November 2019. The increase in industrial profits adds to signs of a strengthening economy, although some analysts caution that China's GDP growth is expected to slow in the near future.

site_title: Hong Kong tightens quarantine rules for sea and flight crews
summary: Hong Kong has tightened quarantine rules for sea and flight crews to curb a third wave of coronavirus cases. Starting Wednesday, ships will only be allowed to change crews if the crew's freight is destined for Hong Kong, with crew members not allowed to mingle in public. The move aims to address public concerns about the health risk, with over 1,000 new cases confirmed since early July, bringing the total to 2,634 with 18 deaths.

site_title: Iraq sees self-sufficiency in wheat for a third year in 2021
summary: Iraq is expected to be self-sufficient in wheat for a third consecutive year, with a forecasted harvest of over 5 million tons. The country has sold 4.9 million tons to the government, exceeding the 4.5 million tons needed for its subsidized national food program. This boost in food production is expected to reduce imports and ease pressure on the economy, which has been affected by the coronavirus pandemic and oil price fluctuations.

site_title: Assyakirin Mosque, Din Tai Fung at Northpoint City among places visited by infectious coronavirus patients
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Health (MOH) has released a list of places visited by infectious Covid-19 patients while they were still contagious. These locations include Assyakirin Mosque, Din Tai Fung at Northpoint City, and Queensway Shopping Centre. MOH also announced 15 new imported cases, including a one-year-old baby boy, and 452 migrant workers in dormitories. The average number of new daily community cases has decreased, and 171 patients were discharged on Monday, bringing the total number of recovered patients to 45,677.

site_title: Oil slips as rising virus cases, US-China tensions weigh on markets
summary: Oil prices fell Monday as rising coronavirus cases and US-China tensions pushed investors toward safe-haven assets. Brent crude dropped 0.3% to $43.20 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.2% to $41.19 a barrel. Despite concerns, oil prices are on track for a fourth straight monthly gain in July due to supply cuts and falling US output. Global coronavirus cases exceeded 16 million, and US-China tensions remain a concern, with investors nervous about demand uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.98 points or 0.25% to 1,593.59. Volume reached 315.8 million lots worth RM125.06 million, with 275 gainers outpacing 73 losers. The rally follows a 5-day streak of gains in Singapore and comes ahead of GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Hin Leong, Ocean Tankers judicial management applications adjourned
summary: Hin Leong Trading and its sister firm Ocean Tankers had their judicial management applications adjourned due to a "pure inadvertence" in publishing the required applications in newspapers and government gazette. The applications were meant to inform creditors about the firms' applications and safeguard their interests. The hearing, which had several creditors participating via video-conferencing, was adjourned to August 7. Lawyers for creditors expressed disappointment and requested payment of their legal costs for the hearing, which was reserved by the judge. The interim judicial management orders for both firms remain in force.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 2,597.49 on Monday, boosted by local bank stocks and index counters. DBS, UOB, and OCBC were among the gainers, while Thai Beverage and CapitaLand Mall Trust held steady. The gains came despite US-China tensions and global risk aversion, which led to a decline in Wall Street stocks.

site_title: AXA Insurance offers free GP teleconsultations, medicine delivery till Dec 31
summary: AXA Insurance is offering unlimited free teleconsultations with general practitioners (GP) and waiving delivery fees for medication in Singapore from July 23 to Dec 31. Patients will only pay for medication costs. The initiative is in partnership with Fullerton Health and can be booked through the FHN3 app from 8.30am to 5.30pm, Monday to Friday. After Dec 31, those who sign up will pay S$10 per teleconsultation, excluding medications. This is in response to ongoing Covid-19 pandemic concerns, providing safe and convenient access to medical support.

site_title: Gold hits record high of US$1,930 per ounce on haven demand
summary: Gold prices reached a record high of US$1,930.48 per ounce on July 27, 2020, driven by haven demand amid the global spread of the coronavirus. The surge was also supported by a weaker US dollar. Analysts predict gold could break the US$2,000 mark soon. Traders are flocking to gold as a safe bet in times of crisis and uncertainty, with no signs of the disease letting up.

site_title: Family office advisers get a lift with skills map launched by IBF, MAS
summary: The Institute of Banking and Finance Singapore (IBF) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have launched a Family Office Advisor Skills Map to enhance Singapore's growing family office ecosystem. The map sets out required skills and competencies, including wealth planning administration and corporate governance, to be possessed by professionals advising family offices. The launch aims to deepen specialist skill sets, improve training and hiring practices, and propel efforts to lift family office capabilities. The map is expected to benefit training providers, financial institutions, and family offices, with subsidies and grants available for relevant courses.

site_title: Britain to consider bolstering consumer protection in retail bankruptcies
summary: Britain will launch a consultation to improve consumer protection in retail bankruptcies, following the coronavirus crisis that has increased consumer pre-payments. The existing law may leave consumers vulnerable if a retailer becomes insolvent, as goods paid for in advance are considered business assets. The consultation aims to update the law to provide clarity and better protection for consumers, particularly in the online market.

site_title: CapitaLand starts building 9.3 ha IT park in India
summary: CapitaLand is building a 9.3-hectare International Tech Park Chennai (ITPC) in India, with the first phase consisting of two buildings offering 2.6 million square feet of office space for IT and ITeS companies. The park, located along Chennai's IT corridor, is expected to be operational by Q4 2022 and Q2 2024. The development will feature green features and sustainable amenities, catering to the growing demand for environmentally friendly office spaces. The park will be CapitaLand's third IT park in India and eighth property in Chennai.

images.alt_text: Located along Chennai's IT corridor, International Tech Park Chennai, Radial Road has been pre-certified with a Platinum rating by the Indian Green Building Council.
Artist's impression of the entrance promenade of International Tech Park Chennai, Radial Road.
Artist's impression of a building lobby in International Tech Park Chennai, Radial Road.

site_title: Ryanair posts smaller than expected loss for three months to June 30
summary: Ryanair reported an after-tax loss of 185 million euros for the three months to June 30, despite reduced traffic by 99% due to Covid-19. Revenue fell 95% to 125 million euros, while costs decreased by 85%. The airline said it cannot provide FY21 profit guidance due to uncertainty. Ryanair plans to fly 60% of its normal schedule in August and 70% in September, with expected smaller losses in the current quarter. Shares closed at 10.91 euros, down 25% since the start of the year.

images.alt_text: Ryanair reported on Monday an after-tax loss of 185 million euros (S$299 million) for the three months to June 30 after Covid-19 reduced traffic by 99 per cent, and the airline said it was impossible to say whether it might turn a profit this year.

site_title: Australia: Gold stocks, central bank comments give shares modest lift
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Monday as gold stocks advanced due to heightened Sino-US tensions and positive comments from a Reserve Bank of Australia official. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,037.4. Gold stocks, including AngloGold Ashanti and Newcrest Mining, gained 8.4% and 2.8% respectively, while shares of Lynas surged 12%. Despite a decline in the energy index, financials edged 0.4% lower.

site_title: Vacation trips, easing of travel rules fuel hopes of business jet rebound
summary: Business jet demand is increasing due to leisure trips and eased European travel restrictions, fueling hopes for a rebound in the industry. Private flights, which offer less risk of COVID-19 exposure, have fared better than commercial airlines. US business aviation traffic is down 20% year-to-date, compared to a 48% decline in commercial airline traffic. Charter companies like Private Fly and VistaJet report increased bookings, with new customers making up 60% of bookings. Industry executives caution that the rebound will depend on company travel, which is still down significantly.

site_title: China records highest surge in virus cases since April
summary: China has recorded its highest surge in virus cases since April, with 61 new cases on Monday, mostly in the Xinjiang region. The bulk of 57 cases were found in Urumqi, and a cluster broke out in the northeastern province of Liaoning. Authorities have launched mass testing in affected areas, including the port city of Dalian, and have placed residential communities under lockdown. Experts are still investigating the origin of the Xinjiang cluster, which has infected 178 people, and there are currently 331 people ill with Covid-19 across the country.

site_title: Lynas to advance US rare earths plan on Pentagon funding deal
summary: Lynas, a key rare earths producer outside China, has secured funding from the US Department of Defense to plan a rare earths processing plant in Texas. The deal will allow Lynas to complete studies and designs for the facility, expected to be completed by mid-2021. The US government aims to reduce dependency on Chinese rare earth imports, which supply about 80% of America's imports. The project will add 10,000 tonnes of processing capacity, sufficient to meet military needs, and will help diversify the global market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.83% to 24,909.96, following last week's losses. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, increasing 0.43% and 0.48% respectively. The positive start is attributed to investors seeking bargains after recent losses.

site_title: RH Petrogas warns of Q2, H1 loss on 'significantly lower' realised oil prices
summary: RH Petrogas expects to record a higher loss for Q2 2020 due to "significantly lower" realised oil prices averaging US$28 per barrel, down 59% from US$69 per barrel a year ago. The company also anticipates a loss for the first half of 2020, compared to a profit in 2019. This is primarily attributed to lower revenue resulting from the decline in oil prices.

site_title: Credit Suisse invested US$100m in Ant, setting up windfall
summary: Credit Suisse invested nearly US$100 million in Ant Group during its 2018 fundraising round, valuing the company at US$150 billion. The investment, made by the Zurich-based lender, could result in a 40% increase in value if Ant's IPO gets a strong reception, with estimates projecting a valuation of US$210 billion. Credit Suisse plans to retain its stake in the company, joining other banks such as Goldman Sachs and China International Capital in investing in private companies.

site_title: Investment firm gets S$25,000 fine, S$955,580 penalty for incorrect declaration in tax returns: Iras
summary: Hwa Luck Investments, a Singaporean investment firm, and its controlling director Tan Hwa Luck were convicted of incorrectly declaring directors' fees in corporate income tax returns. The court ordered Tan to pay a fine of S$25,000 and a penalty of S$955,580, while Hwa Luck Investments was also fined S$25,000 and penalized S$955,580. The incorrect declarations resulted in a tax undercharge of S$763,285 from 1995 to 2007. The case highlights the importance of accurate tax declarations and the potential consequences of giving incorrect information without a reasonable excuse.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump on stimulus hopes, Samsung Elec leads gain
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.11% on Monday, led by Samsung Electronics' 2.8% gain, as hopes for a US coronavirus relief package boosted sentiment. The benchmark Kospi jumped 24.52 points to 2,224.96. Foreigners bought 158.8 billion won worth of shares, and the Korean won strengthened against the US dollar. The US Treasury yield fell, while the three-year bond yield rose 0.5 basis points. Top US officials agreed on a $1 trillion relief package, boosting market confidence.

site_title: Thai police to examine dropping of hit-and-run charges against Red Bull heir
summary: Thai police will investigate why charges against Red Bull heir Vorayuth "Boss" Yoovidhya, accused of a 2012 hit-and-run killing, were dropped. The decision has sparked public anger over the country's culture of impunity for the rich and well-connected. A committee will report its findings in 15 days, while the Office of the Attorney-General also probes the decision. The move comes amid calls to boycott Red Bull products on social media.

site_title: Global prospects dim for China's tech champions as great powers clash
summary: China's tech champions, including Huawei, ByteDance, and Alibaba, face significant challenges due to strained relations with the US, India, Australia, and Britain. New US sanctions and security concerns have led to contract cancellations, product bans, and investments being blocked. The US may consider banning TikTok, worth at least $20 billion, and Huawei could lose billions in revenue from bans on its network equipment. Despite some less sensitive sectors remaining open, investors warn of dampened entrepreneurial spirits and limited global ambitions.

site_title: Tritech to appoint former executive director charged with corruption as consultant
summary: TRITECH Group has appointed former executive director Cai Jungang as a consultant, replacing him after he resigned amid corruption charges. Cai faces seven charges of corruption related to loans given as gratification to a former LTA deputy group director. Despite the allegations, Tritech believes the appointment will not impact its business, citing Cai's expertise in geology and underground space development. Cai will work for one year, with the company deciding his scope of duties and remuneration.

site_title: Gazans get first taste of coffee-to-your-door
summary: A Gaza Strip resident, Shaaban Hamuda, has launched a coffee delivery service, using a bicycle to deliver hot Arabic coffee, mint tea, and cafe au lait to customers. The service, which charges only for the beverage, has been a hit, with customers praising the convenience and speed of delivery. Hamuda, 31, hopes the business will bring in a steady income and improve his family's financial situation, as poverty and unemployment rates in Gaza are above 50%. The service is seen as a positive innovation in the territory, where economic activity has been depressed by the pandemic.

site_title: UOB Asset Management launches robo-advisory mobile app for retail investors in Singapore
summary: UOB Asset Management has launched a robo-advisory mobile app for retail investors in Singapore, offering personalized investment portfolios based on risk profile, financial goals, and investment horizon. The app, UOBAM Invest, allows investors to start with a minimum investment of S$1, with no fees for account opening or closing. It provides dynamic portfolios using exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and offers risk management features, including a "glide path" formula. The app aims to simplify investing and bring the benefits of UOBAM's risk-based approach to retail investors.

site_title: South China Morning Post to put up paywall amid Hong Kong slump
summary: The South China Morning Post, a Hong Kong-based English-language newspaper backed by Alibaba Group, will introduce a paywall starting next month. The move comes after months of political unrest and the COVID-19 pandemic led to a significant decline in advertising revenue. The newspaper will limit free articles to a few per month, citing that the century-old advertising model is no longer enough to sustain high-quality news. The decision follows other Hong Kong newspapers struggling to adapt to the new national security law and declining advertising income.

site_title: Trump team, Senate Republicans agree on virus aid offer to Democrats
summary: US President Donald Trump's team and Senate Republicans have agreed in principle on a $1 trillion coronavirus relief package, which will include extended unemployment benefits replacing 70% of a laid-off worker's previous wages. The package is expected to be unveiled on Monday, with details still being finalized. It will also include direct payments to individuals, reduced federal supplement to unemployment benefits, and liability protections against coronavirus-related lawsuits. The move comes as enhanced unemployment benefits, which have been propping up consumer spending, are set to expire on Friday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Singapore Airlines, Keppel, ART, Tiong Seng, Tritech
summary: Singtel extended its contract with Foxtel for satellite services until 2031. Singapore Airlines announced arrangements for long-term pass holders and travelers to cross the border with Malaysia, with operational details to be published soon.

site_title: Japanese government to urge more telecommuting as virus cases surge
summary: Japan's economy minister, Yasutoshi Nishimura, urged businesses to adopt 70% telecommuting amid a record surge in coronavirus cases in Tokyo and other major urban areas. The surge has experts worried about a potential second wave, with Tokyo reporting 366 daily cases and Fukuoka 90. To combat this, Nishimura called for enhanced social distancing measures, including staggered shifts and avoiding large gatherings. The government aims to maintain high levels of telecommuting, despite a lag in adoption due to Japan's paper-driven culture and technological shortcomings.

site_title: No dancing, just listening: Berlin club Berghain reopens doors
summary: Berlin's legendary club Berghain has reopened its doors with an unusual sound exhibition, allowing just 50 visitors at a time to experience an eerie soundscape created by rhythmic throbbing, city noises, and helicopter blades. The "Eleven songs -- Hall at Berghain" project, curated by Sam Auinger and Hannes Strobl, runs until August 2, providing a unique listening experience in the club's imposing Kessel Hall. Despite initial concerns about attendance, visitors have been queueing to get in, wearing face masks, and appreciating the experience as a way to escape confinement and connect with others.

images.alt_text: The coronavirus is keeping Berlin's legendary clubs closed but techno mecca Berghain has found a way to throw its doors back open, luring visitors with an unusual sound exhibition.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower amid US-China tensions
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday due to intensifying China-US tensions, falling 1.12% or 255.66 points to 22,495.95. The broader Topix index lost 1.04% or 16.29 points to 1,556.67. This follows a four-day weekend and amid global risk aversion.

site_title: M+S bags S$1.95b green loan for Marina One from DBS, OCBC, UOB
summary: M+S Pte Ltd, a joint venture between Malaysia and Singapore, has secured a S$1.95 billion green loan from DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank to partially finance Marina One's office and retail components. The largest green loan for a real estate company in the Asia-Pacific, it will support sustainable development with features such as energy-efficient technologies and green architecture. The loan will help M+S meet its sustainability goals while maintaining design and quality standards.

site_title: Moderna gets further US$472m US award for coronavirus vaccine development
summary: Moderna has received an additional $472 million from the US government's Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (Barda) to support the late-stage clinical development of its coronavirus vaccine. The funding brings the total Barda support to $955 million. The vaccine, which uses synthetic mRNA, will undergo a phase three study involving about 30,000 participants, with the company aiming to deliver 500-1 billion doses per year starting in 2021. Moderna's CEO expressed optimism about the vaccine's potential to aid in addressing the pandemic and preventing future outbreaks.

site_title: Office vacancies in China's cities soar even as economy reopens
summary: Office vacancies in China's major cities have surged to their highest levels in over a decade, with prime office buildings in Shanghai and Shenzhen experiencing vacancy rates of 20% and 21%, respectively. The nation's economy, which was the first to reopen after the coronavirus outbreak, is showing only a modest domestic recovery, making corporate tenants cautious. The supply glut in many cities is also contributing to the issue, with estimated increases in office stock in Shenzhen and Shanghai expected to lead to rent declines.

images.alt_text: Office vacancies in China's biggest cities are at the highest in more than a decade even as the nation's economy has largely swung back into action after the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Germany rejects Trump's proposal to let Russia back into G-7: foreign minister
summary: Germany has rejected US President Donald Trump's proposal to invite Russian President Vladimir Putin back into the Group of Seven (G-7), citing a lack of progress in solving the conflict in Crimea and eastern Ukraine. German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas stated that Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014 was a major reason for its expulsion from the G-7, and that meaningful progress was needed before Russia could be considered for re-admission.

site_title: Bitcoin jumps above US$10,000 for the first time in six weeks
summary: Bitcoin surged above US$10,000 for the first time in six weeks, reaching a peak of US$10,169, before settling at US$10,080. The gains were driven by concerns over the global economy and the US dollar, as well as the US Office of the Comptroller of the Currency's decision to allow banks to provide custody services for crypto assets. Analysts remain bullish on Bitcoin, predicting it could reach US$10,500 as part of its technical profile, with some citing above-average flows and high investor interest.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin had been hovering near its 50-day moving average for weeks before pulling above it in the past couple of days.

site_title: CapitaLand expects H1 total Patmi to sink 85-95% on share of CCT, CMT losses
summary: CapitaLand has updated its profit guidance, expecting its total Patmi (profit after tax and minority interests) to drop 85-95% from last year's S$875.4 million, mainly due to losses from listed investments CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) and CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT), totaling S$553.9 million, including a S$159.9 million effective share of revaluation losses.

site_title: China's Tigermed to raise up to US$1.38b in Hong Kong listing
summary: Hangzhou Tigermed Consulting, China's largest clinical research trial provider, plans to raise up to US$1.38 billion in its Hong Kong listing, the largest healthcare transaction in Asia this year. The company will sell 107.06 million shares at a price range of HK$88 to HK$100, with a potential increase of US$1.58 billion. The deal will be the largest healthcare IPO in Asia this year, surpassing WuXi Biologics' US$984 million deal in May.

site_title: Access restricted near US consulate in Chengdu as closure deadline looms
summary: China restricted access to the US consulate in Chengdu as a 10am deadline loomed for the US to vacate the premises after 72 hours' notice. The move follows Washington's shutdown of China's consulate in Houston, escalating tensions between the two nations. Police blocked access to the consulate area on Monday morning, with a crane removing equipment on Sunday night and workers removing fittings on Saturday evening. The US has been given 72 hours to leave the consulate, which is expected to be closed by the deadline.

site_title: Singtel Optus, Foxtel extend satellite services contract to 2031
summary: Singtel's Australian subsidiary Optus has extended its contract with Foxtel for satellite services until 2031. The partnership, which began in 1998, provides premium content such as sports, movies, and news to regional and metropolitan areas across Australia. Optus managing director Ben White sees the extension as providing resilience for existing services and an opportunity for future expansion. The contract reaffirms Optus Satellite's leading position in the ANZ satellite market.

site_title: Australian regulator sues Google over expanded personal data use
summary: Australia's competition regulator, the ACCC, has sued Google for allegedly misleading consumers about the expanded use of personal data for targeted advertising. The regulator claims Google did not obtain explicit consent nor inform consumers about combining personal information in Google accounts with non-Google websites. The move comes amid heightened data privacy concerns globally, with the regulator seeking to address Google's use of combined data to boost targeted advertising and changes to its privacy policy. The case has been filed on a confidential basis pending Google's response.

site_title: Hyflux receives letter about possible investment by North American fund manager
summary: A North American-based fund manager, with a strong track record in infrastructure and technology investments, has expressed interest in investing in Hyflux, a distressed water treatment firm. The fund manager, represented by The Spectrum Solutions Group, is seeking to structure a deal that addresses the interests of all major shareholders, including perpetual securities and preference shares. This is the latest in a series of potential investors, following Utico, Pison Investments, and Unilegend Investments, which have also expressed interest in the firm.

site_title: Hang Seng to launch new index of benchmark-beating tech stocks
summary: The Hang Seng Index is launching a new index, Hang Seng Tech Index, to track 30 of the largest tech companies in Hong Kong, including Tencent Holdings, Alibaba Group Holding, and Meituan Dianping. The index aims to provide investors with greater access to China's growing tech dominance and fill the gap in the current Hang Seng Index, which is overstuffed with old economy banks and insurers. The new index is expected to attract investors, facilitate the issuance of index-linked funds and derivatives, and boost turnover at Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing.

site_title: Los Angeles luxury real estate market back in full swing after virus shutdown
summary: The Los Angeles luxury real estate market is experiencing a resurgence after the COVID-19 shutdown. A 2,400-square-foot craftsman-style home listed by independent developer Lillian Lim for $2.495 million received a firm offer within a week, followed by an all-cash offer above the asking price. This marks a significant turnaround from the market's slowdown during the pandemic. The sale is expected to close in escrow, indicating a strong demand for luxury properties in the area.

site_title: Keppel unit's Qatar sewage-treatment contract terminated
summary: Keppel Seghers Engineering Singapore, a wholly owned unit of Keppel Corp, has ceased operations at the Doha North Sewage Treatment Works in Qatar due to contract termination. The client, Ashghal, implemented a new framework contract to operate and maintain Qatar's sewer network. Keppel Corp stated the contract termination was effective from July 25, following the implementation of the new framework.

site_title: SAP to float Qualtrics, partly unwinding US$8b buy
summary: SAP plans to float Qualtrics, a US-based customer sentiment specialist acquired for $8 billion in 2018, as part of its efforts to rebalance back to its German roots under CEO Christian Klein. The IPO will help Qualtrics increase its autonomy and expand its market presence. Qualtrics has achieved 40% sales growth under Klein's leadership, and he has agreed with founder Ryan Smith that an IPO is the best way for the company to grow and explore acquisitions. SAP will retain a majority stake in Qualtrics.

site_title: Britain unveils plans to tackle 'obesity time bomb'
summary: Britain is introducing measures to tackle obesity, described as an "obesity time bomb." The plans include banning junk food adverts before 9pm, ending "buy one get one free" deals, and displaying calorie counts on menus. The goal is to reduce health risks, especially from coronavirus, and put pressure off the NHS. The government aims to help people take control of their lifestyle through weight management services and evidence-based tools. With over 60% of adults considered overweight or obese, the measures are part of a "Better Health" campaign.

site_title: China expands state jobs for graduates as coronavirus hits private sector
summary: China is expanding state jobs for graduates amid a record number of students graduating into a job market hit by the Covid-19 pandemic. Thousands of state-owned enterprises, local governments, and public institutions are hiring, with some offering up to 3,500 new positions. The move aims to address concerns about job stability and follows President Xi Jinping's call for more hiring to prevent "negative energy." Available positions for graduates fell by 22% in the recent pre-graduation recruiting season, and unemployment among young graduates is more than three times the national average.

site_title: Tailors know New Yorkers' pandemic secret: 'Everybody got fat!'
summary: During the pandemic, tailors in New York City have seen a surge in business as people gained weight due to lockdowns and lack of exercise. Many customers have asked for alterations to make their clothes more comfortable, with some businesses experiencing a 80% increase in sales. However, some tailors are concerned that the industry may not recover if the traditional workplace culture shifts to remote work, potentially leading to more sweatpants and fewer bespoke suits.

site_title: Raffles Medical H1 profit falls 38.2% to S$17.2m on deferred surgeries
summary: Raffles Medical Group posted a 38.2% drop in net profit to S$17.2 million for its first half, primarily due to deferred surgeries and fewer offshore patients. Revenue declined 5.4% to S$241.4 million, with hospital services division revenue falling 14.5%. However, the healthcare services segment grew 6.8% due to telemedicine and air-border screening activities. The company expects to remain profitable for the rest of the year as patients return to its hospitals and preparations are underway for the opening of Raffles Hospital Shanghai.

site_title: Breakout may occur in oil prices
summary: Crude oil prices may experience a breakout after a prolonged period of decline due to the Covid-19 pandemic and the Russia-Saudi Arabia oil price war. Oil prices have formed an ascending triangle on the daily charts, indicating higher lows and a flat resistance level. If a breakout occurs, it could signal the continuation of the upward trend, with potential target levels at US$54-60 per barrel. However, a lower breakout is also possible, with target levels at US$33.60-39.50 per barrel.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust to sell Guangzhou, Paris serviced residences for S$191.4m
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) has entered into conditional agreements to sell its serviced residences in Guangzhou, China, and Paris, France, for S$191.4 million. The sales are expected to result in estimated net gains of S$23.2 million. The Guangzhou property, which carries a book value of S$155 million, will be sold for 780 million yuan (S$155 million), while the Paris property, with a book value of S$71 million, will be sold for 23.6 million euros (S$36.4 million). The sales are seen as "opportunistic" to rejuvenate ART's portfolio and unlock underlying value.

site_title: StashAway raises US$16m in Series C round led by Square Peg
summary: StashAway, a Singapore-based robo-advisor, has raised US$16 million in its Series C funding round led by Square Peg Capital. Existing investors Burda Principal Investments and Eight Roads Ventures also participated. The funding will enable StashAway to accelerate product development and expand its wealth management offering in Singapore and Malaysia. The company has generated annualized returns of 11.6% for its highest risk portfolio and 4.9% for its lowest risk portfolio since its launch in 2017, with assets under management growing 4.3 times in the past year.

site_title: Insurance par policy primer: What smoothing and cross subsidy mean for you
summary: A small proportion of policyholders from AIA, AXA, and Tokio Marine Life Insurance will experience bonus reductions this year, despite strong 2019 returns. The reductions are due to non-investment factors, such as claims and lapse rates, which insurers use to smooth out returns. Smoothing allows insurers to continue paying promised bonus rates in poor years and withhold returns in good years. Cross-subsidization among policyholders also occurs, with insurers creating sub-funds to distinguish between types of policies. Insurers aim to maintain a stable return, and LIA reviews illustration rates annually to ensure they remain relevant.

site_title: Renewed US-China tensions keep investors on edge
summary: US stocks retreated slightly last week due to increased unemployment data and US-China tensions. The S&P 500 tested new record levels before a diplomatic clash between the two countries stalled the rally. Investors await a compromise on a stimulus bill, tech earnings, or improved Covid-19 statistics to ease concerns about global economic growth and comity. Gold futures reached a record high near $1,900-an-ounce, and the US Congress may reach a middle ground on a second stimulus package, potentially fueling bulls.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for July 24-30, 2020, reveals a week of significant declines in tanker and dry bulk markets. The capesize market plummeted, with the 5TC index dropping from $25,085 to $17,285. Bunkers rose, further eroding owners' earnings. Panamax rates in the Atlantic were under pressure, while ultramax and supramax rates showed mixed signals. The Handy market rose, driven by the Atlantic basin, but the Pacific basin showed signs of softening. VLCC rates remained under pressure, with Suezmax and Aframax rates steady in the Mediterranean market.

site_title: No beer or chicken but South Korean fans are back at the ball game
summary: South Korean baseball fans returned to stadiums for the first time this year, marking the start of the KBO league season. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, fans were allowed to attend games with 10% capacity, following strict health guidelines, including mask-wearing, temperature checks, and social distancing. No food or alcohol was permitted, a departure from the usual experience. Fans expressed excitement, with some competing for limited tickets that sold out in 25 minutes, and others expressing hope for a safe and successful season.

site_title: New Cabinet favours continuity with eye on renewal
summary: Singapore's new Cabinet prioritizes continuity amid the Covid-19 crisis and US-China tensions, with renewal taking a backseat. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong introduced the lineup, striking a balance between continuity, exposure, and renewal. The Cabinet retains key ministers, including Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, who now holds a Coordinating Minister for Economic Policies role. The government has also given ministers exposure and experience through portfolio changes, such as Ong Ye Kung moving to the Ministry of Transport. This approach aims to reassure citizens and investors while tackling economic and public health challenges.

site_title: Tropical Storm Hanna flattens Covid-hit Texas coast
summary: Tropical Storm Hanna made landfall in south Texas on Saturday as a Category 1 hurricane, causing widespread destruction and power outages. The storm flattened sugar cane fields, downed powerlines, and levelled trees, with at least three tractor-trailer trucks overturned. Over 283,000 homes and businesses initially lost electricity, but the figure decreased to 230,000 by Sunday. The storm's centre was about 40 miles from McAllen, Texas, and posed a threat of life-threatening flash flooding and isolated minor to moderate river flooding.

site_title: Germany must toughen audit rules after Wirecard scandal, says Bundesbank president
summary: Germany must strengthen its audit and accounting rules to prevent another large-scale scandal like the Wirecard scandal, according to Bundesbank president Jens Weidmann. Wirecard filed for insolvency after admitting 1.9 billion euros did not exist in trustee accounts. Former CEO Markus Braun and two other executives were arrested on suspicion of orchestrating a years-long criminal racket. Finance Minister Olaf Scholz proposed reforms to give financial watchdogs greater powers and tougher penalties for lax auditors to prevent similar scandals in the future.

images.alt_text: Payment services company Wirecard filed for insolvency last month after admitting that 1.9 billion euros (S$3.04 billion) supposedly held in trustee accounts by overseas partners probably did not exist.

site_title: Ray Dalio warns of US-China 'capital war' that would hit US dollar
summary: Billionaire investor Ray Dalio warns of a potential "capital war" between the US and China that could harm the US dollar. He suggests a trade war, technology war, geopolitical war, and capital war could escalate, impacting the dollar's value. Dalio also criticizes the US for loose fiscal policy and ideological divisions, which he believes are contributing to the country's decline. The US dollar has fallen against major currencies in the past three months, and Dalio emphasizes the need for the US to adopt sound fiscal policies and be productive to maintain currency stability.

site_title: Dollar slump continues on US economic worries
summary: The dollar slumped to a near two-year low against major currencies due to US economic concerns, including rising coronavirus cases, delayed stimulus package, and simmering US-China tensions. The yen rose to its highest in four months, while the euro surged against the dollar. Analysts attribute the decline to the US Federal Reserve's negative interest rates, economic growth differentials turning against the US, and the expiration of unemployment benefits. Senate Republicans plan to unveil a new coronavirus aid proposal, but House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is not considering a temporary extension of enhanced unemployment benefits.

site_title: QAF unit shuts Melbourne meat processing plant after employees catch Covid-19
summary: A meat processing plant in Melbourne, Australia, operated by QAF's subsidiary Rivalea, has been temporarily shut down after five employees tested positive for Covid-19. The shutdown, which took effect immediately, will be for an undetermined period. The company is undertaking deep cleaning and sanitization, engaging with government officials, and working with customers to mitigate supply chain disruptions. Rivalea's operations at other locations remain unaffected, and the temporary closure is not expected to have a significant impact on the company's financial results for the current year.

site_title: Garmin says outage continues but user data 'not affected'
summary: Garmin reported that its smartwatch and GPS services have been offline since Thursday due to a suspected ransomware attack, but claimed that user data, including activity and personal information, has not been compromised. The company stated that it has "no indication" that the outage has affected client data. Garmin assured users that their information remains secure, despite initial fears of a potential data breach.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Koh Brothers Group and its subsidiary Koh Brothers Eco Engineering expect to report net losses for the six months ended June 30 due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on construction and real estate revenue. QAF's meat processing unit, Rivalea, has temporarily shut down its Melbourne plant after five employees tested positive for COVID-19. The group's first-half results will be published on or before August 14.

site_title: Pandemic forces digital change on Japan's businesses
summary: Japan's businesses are embracing digital change due to the pandemic, with 90% of Idemitsu Kosan's non-manufacturing employees working from home. Department-store chain Isetan Mitsukoshi Holdings is using video chats for online shopping suggestions, while smaller enterprises are adopting digital tools. The pandemic is accelerating Japan's transition to the digital workplace, building on existing automation efforts due to a declining population. Japan ranked 23rd out of 63 nations in digital competitiveness last year, but the shift is expected to boost the country's digital capabilities.

images.alt_text: The coronavirus pandemic may be a drag on economies across the globe, but in Japan it's bringing long-overdue change in work habits and tools.

site_title: HSBC denies Chinese media reports that it 'framed' Huawei
summary: HSBC has denied allegations by Chinese media that it "framed" Huawei Technologies, with the bank stating it did not participate in the US Department of Justice's investigation into Huawei's CFO, Meng Wanzhou. HSBC claims it provided factual information to the US authorities in response to information requests and did not distort facts or harm customers. Meng is fighting extradition to the US, accused of bank fraud for misleading HSBC about Huawei's relationship with a company operating in Iran. The bank's statement comes after reports by Chinese media accusing HSBC of being an accomplice of the US.

site_title: SGX warns against use of 'earnings before coronavirus' metric
summary: Singapore's market regulator, SGX RegCo, warns against using the "earnings before coronavirus" metric, Ebitdac, in interim financial reports. The regulator considers this measure "unreliable" and "misleading" to investors, advising issuers to present alternative performance measures instead. This comes as the pandemic's impact on financial performance is still being assessed, and using Ebitdac could give a false picture of earnings.

images.alt_text: The SGX joins other regulators such as the European Securities and Markets Authority and the UK's Financial Reporting Council in calling for caution against Ebitdac adjustments.

site_title: SMEs in Indonesia most confident of surviving Covid-19: survey
summary: Indonesia's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are the most confident in surviving and thriving after the Covid-19 pandemic, according to a survey by HP. 60% of respondents were confident of surviving, and 72% of those in Indonesia expected to thrive. In contrast, Singaporeans were less optimistic, with only about half expecting to survive. The survey found that Indonesia and Thailand have the largest shares of respondents seeing digital adoption as "essential" for SME success, while Singaporeans and Vietnamese respondents were more likely to see it as "very important" or "important".

site_title: Jump in Aussie borrowing costs
summary: Australian companies face higher borrowing costs as the country's economy shrinks due to the coronavirus pandemic. Average three-year loan margins have jumped to 143bp for investment-grade borrowers and 348bp for speculative issuers, the highest levels in six years. This is due to a glut of financings from hard-hit sectors and banks growing more risk-averse. The country's recession, if confirmed, would be its first in nearly three decades, with Asia Pacific expected to lose US$2.7 trillion in economic output this and next year.

site_title: Emerging stronger from the storm
summary: Businesses are adapting to the economic gloom by focusing on innovation, digital transformation, and workforce resilience. Many companies are streamlining processes, investing in technology, and exploring new revenue streams. Some industries, such as healthcare and finance, have seen opportunities for growth, while others, like real estate, are facing challenges. Experts highlight the importance of agility, collaboration, and community support in navigating the crisis. While the pandemic has presented significant challenges, it has also accelerated the adoption of digital technologies and fostered a greater appreciation for mental health and wellness.

site_title: Hin Leong's Lim family seeks to halt Rajah & Tann from taking court role
summary: The Lim family of Hin Leong's oil trading empire has asked a court to stop law firm Rajah & Tann from working with court-appointed supervisors for two of their companies, Ocean Tankers and Hin Leong Trading. The Lim family claims R&T has access to confidential information that could be misused to benefit the supervisors. R&T denies advising or acting for the Lim family, stating it only acted to file for judicial management and continued to act for the companies and supervisors under certain conditions. A hearing on the matter is set for August 11.

site_title: Passion for purple revives ancient dye technique in Tunisia
summary: A Tunisian man, Mohamed Ghassen Nouira, has successfully revived an ancient technique for producing the prized purple dye, Tyrian purple, using the guts of a sea snail. After years of trial and error, Nouira has mastered the method, which was previously guarded as a secret by the ancient Phoenicians and Carthaginians. The dye, valued at up to $4,000 per gram, is highly sought after by collectors, artists, and researchers. Nouira sells his product internationally, but hopes to one day exhibit his work in Tunisian museums and conduct workshops, despite authorities showing little interest in the craft.

site_title: Air freight rates ease, but yet to come back down to earth
summary: Air freight rates have eased slightly from their peak in April, with rates out of Singapore decreasing by 10-15%. However, rates remain elevated due to the ongoing capacity crunch in the air cargo market. Freight volumes have dropped 30-50% since the pandemic, with niche sectors such as medical and healthcare industries experiencing firmer volumes. Airlines are adapting by deploying passenger aircraft on cargo operations, with some operators like Singapore Airlines using passenger planes to carry cargo. Despite this, air freight rates are expected to remain high, with some operators charging 50% more than normal rates, and capacity constraints expected to persist into the year-end.

images.alt_text: In recent months, some airlines have started using some of their passenger aircraft for purely cargo operations. A wide-body aircraft, for instance, can carry about 20-30 tonnes of cargo.

site_title: Distressed properties sold via private treaty as auctions remain no-go
summary: Auctioneer Joy Tan of Edmund Tie sold seven distressed properties via private treaty in Q2, totaling S$10.6 million, with discounts of up to 32% from guide prices. The sales came during the circuit breaker period when auctions were not allowed due to COVID-19 restrictions. Despite eased restrictions, auctions remain no-go. Tan plans to host a webinar next week to showcase properties to keen investors, with over 50 registrations from China and Hong Kong. Homeowners have been granted mortgage relief through the end of the year, and foreclosures are expected to pick up only when the economic climate improves.

site_title: Some insurers cut bonuses on par policies despite strong 2019 return
summary: Three Singapore insurers, AIA, AXA, and Tokio Marine Life Insurance, have cut bonuses or dividends for some policyholders despite strong 2019 returns. AIA revised its bonus and dividend rates for a small block of policies, while AXA cut rates for 4% of par policyholders. Tokio Marine Life Insurance cut bonuses for its Asia Hi-Saver and Asia Education plans, which affect around 2,000 policies. The moves are part of the "smoothing" mechanism, where bonus payouts are maintained in poor years but cut in good years. The insurance industry is reviewing standard illustration rates for par policies due to a lower-for-longer interest rate environment.

site_title: Gold's rally means world economy is in trouble
summary: Gold prices surged to a 30-year high, reaching $1,902.02 an ounce, amid concerns over the global economy and inflation. The rally is driven by a combination of factors, including government stimulus packages, central bank printing of money, and a decline in inflation-adjusted bond yields. Analysts predict further gains, with Bank of America targeting $3,000 an ounce, and investors seeking safe havens from potential stagflation.

images.alt_text: "When interest rates are zero or near zero, then gold is an attractive medium to have because you don't have to worry about not getting interest on your gold," says Mark Mobius.

site_title: IBM, Shopee among firms offering training courses for mid-career job seekers
summary: Mid-career job seekers in Singapore can apply for training courses offered by companies like IBM, Shopee, and PBA Robotics, with a monthly allowance of S$1,500. The SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways Programme aims to provide 14,500 traineeships and training programs to boost employability, focusing on sectors like healthcare and e-commerce. The program is part of the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package, which aims to create 100,000 jobs and skills training opportunities.

site_title: Boeing to delay all-new 777X jet as demand drops for big jets
summary: Boeing is preparing to delay its all-new 777X jet by several months or up to a year due to a drop in demand for large jetliners caused by the Covid-19 crisis. The delay would be the latest setback for Boeing, which has already faced issues with its General Electric GE9X engines. The company hopes to bring the jet to market as passenger travel rebounds, but a delay could cause problems in Boeing's supply chain and tougher scrutiny from the US Federal Aviation Administration.

site_title: Singapore-Malaysia travel arrangements for permit holders, business travellers finalised
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have finalized arrangements for long-term pass holders and business travelers to cross the border, with applications set to start on August 10. The reciprocal green lane and periodic commuting arrangement will be implemented, allowing eligible travelers to take Covid-19 swab tests and submit itineraries. The two countries also plan to develop a proposal for daily cross-border commuting for work purposes, taking into account health protocols and medical resources.

site_title: Koh Brothers Group, Koh Brothers Eco Engineering warn of H1 losses due to Covid-19
summary: MAINBOARD-listed Koh Brothers Group and its subsidiary Koh Brothers Eco Engineering expect to report a net loss for the six months ended June 30, due to the adverse impact of Covid-19. The companies' construction and building materials divisions have been severely impacted, with Koh Brothers Eco Engineering citing delays and disruptions to project schedules and management. The companies will publish their first-half results on or before Aug 14.

site_title: Hedge fund Bridgewater Associates sued by former co-CEO Murray
summary: Bridgewater Associates, the world's largest hedge fund, has been sued by former co-CEO Eileen Murray, who alleges the firm withheld up to $100 million in deferred compensation after she publicly disclosed a gender discrimination dispute. Murray, who stepped down as co-CEO earlier this year, claims the withheld compensation is an "improper gambit to silence her voice" and part of a plan to intimidate her. The lawsuit was filed in federal court in Connecticut, where Murray now chairs the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.

site_title: Bankers who profited from Nordic hiring boom now in the firing line
summary: Nordic banks, which hired thousands of compliance jobs in response to financial scandals, are now facing significant job cuts. Danske Bank plans to axe at least 1,000 jobs, while Nordea Bank aims to automate 1,500 positions created to combat financial crime. Analysts say the surge in compliance headcount was unsustainable, and automation is the most cost-effective solution. The need for cuts is urgent, particularly after the Covid-19 crisis, with compliance costs boosting banks' expenses 7% annually.

site_title: China's rebound points to weakness in economy
summary: China's economy shows a strong rebound in its latest GDP data, with a 4.8% increase in industrial production and 6.8% growth in the first quarter. However, analysts note that the rebound is driven by investment rather than consumption, and that demand remains weak. The current stimulus measures have fueled debt, with China's debt reaching over 270% of its GDP. Experts warn that the V-shaped recovery may be unsustainable and that China faces challenges from an uncertain global environment, including rising tensions with trading partners and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Singapore extends consular aid to citizen who acted as illegal foreign agent in US
summary: Singapore is extending consular aid to Dickson Yeo, a Singaporean who pleaded guilty to acting as an illegal foreign agent in the US. Yeo, a PhD student, collected sensitive information from Americans with security clearances on social media sites, sending it to Chinese intelligence without their knowledge. Investigations have not revealed a direct threat to Singapore's security. The Ministry of Home Affairs stated that Singaporeans must abide by the laws of the country they visit or reside in.

site_title: Hyflux's PnP holders still waiting for concrete terms: Sias
summary: Hyflux, a water treatment firm, remains in financial distress despite over two years of uncertainty. Several white knights have emerged to offer rescue plans, but none have progressed to a satisfactory conclusion. The company's preference and perpetual (PnP) securities holders, who invested S$900 million, are still waiting for a fair plan to emerge. Utico, Pison, and Aqua Munda have made offers, but details of their financial standing and backing remain unclear. Sias, the court-appointed receiver, aims to ensure a fair settlement for all stakeholders, including PnP holders, and has called for Hyflux to appoint an independent board to oversee restructuring.

site_title: China's soybean imports from Brazil rise to record in June
summary: China's soybean imports from Brazil reached a record high of 10.51 million tonnes in June, a 91% increase from the previous year. This surge is driven by growing demand for soybeans as China's pig herd recovers from African swine fever outbreaks. China's overall soybean imports in June were 11.16 million tonnes, with the US seeing a 56.5% decrease in imports due to lower demand. The increased imports are part of China's efforts to fulfill its Phase One trade deal with the US.

site_title: China reports 34 new coronavirus cases, including 20 in Xinjiang
summary: China reported 34 new coronavirus cases, including 20 in Xinjiang, on July 24, with 74 asymptomatic cases. The confirmed case total reached 83,784, and the death toll remained at 4,634.

site_title: Hong Kong recovery may take longer than expected: financial secretary
summary: Hong Kong's economy may take longer than expected to recover due to the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak and global economic uncertainties. Financial Secretary Paul Chan warned that business and economic activities that showed signs of recovery have been hit by the fresh wave of the virus. The city has reported over 100 local cases daily, with the government introducing measures such as mask-wearing and ban on large gatherings to curb the spread. The economy suffered a record 8.9% contraction in the first quarter, with the second quarter's situation still considered severe.

site_title: Malaysia faces crucial graft test as Najib's first 1MDB verdict looms
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak is set to face his first verdict in a landmark corruption case involving the multi-billion-dollar 1MDB scandal. Najib, who was voted out in 2018, faces seven charges over receiving 42 million ringgit from 1MDB unit SRC International in 2014. If convicted, he could face up to 15-20 years in jail. The verdict comes amid speculation that Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin may call elections soon, and could have significant implications for the country's efforts to combat corruption.

site_title: Singapore-Malaysia travel arrangements for permit holders, business travellers finalised
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have finalized arrangements for long-term pass holders and business travelers to cross the border, with applications set to begin on August 10. The two countries have agreed on a reciprocal green lane for essential or official business travelers, as well as a periodic commuting arrangement for residents working in each other's countries. Daily commuting plans are also being discussed, with health protocols and testing requirements to be implemented. Additionally, arrangements for compassionate travel and cross-border travel for Malaysian and Singaporean families will be explored.

site_title: Brookfield picks banks for US$500m Reit IPO in India
summary: Brookfield Asset Management has selected Bank of America, Citigroup, and Morgan Stanley to arrange an initial public offering (IPO) of its India real estate investment trust (Reit) that could raise at least US$500 million. The IPO, if successful, will add to India's growing number of Reit listings and provide a fundraising avenue for the country's cash-starved property sector. Brookfield owns and operates 22 million square feet of office properties in India, and the listing could happen as soon as the end of this year.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Li Auto aims to raise up to US$950m in growth push
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Li Auto is launching an initial public offering (IPO) of up to $950 million, selling 95 million American depositary shares (ADS) at $8-$10 per share. Private equity firm Hillhouse Capital plans to invest $300 million in the float, with proceeds mainly used for capital expenditures and new product development. The IPO is the latest gauge of US investor demand for Chinese companies going public, following rising listings by companies like Xpeng and Kingsoft Cloud. Li Auto plans to price the float on July 30 and begin trading on the Nasdaq under the symbol "Li".

site_title: North Korea locks down border town as first suspected Covid-19 case reported
summary: North Korea has declared an emergency and lockdown in a border town after a person suspected of having COVID-19 returned from South Korea. The person, who defected to South Korea three years ago, crossed the fortified border and returned to the town of Kaesong with symptoms of the virus. This is the first suspected COVID-19 case officially acknowledged by North Korean authorities, which could be a sign of the country seeking international aid.

site_title: Vietnam back on coronavirus alert after first local infection in 3 months
summary: Vietnam has gone back on high alert for the novel coronavirus after a 57-year-old man from Danang tested positive for the virus, despite the country's low 415 cases and 100-day streak without local transmissions. The man, who had not left Danang for nearly a month, is being isolated, and 103 people connected to him were tested negative. Authorities have reinstated mask-wearing in public places and Vietnam's ban on international commercial flights remains in place.

site_title: Azeus Systems sees growing demand for e-AGM solution
summary: Azeus Systems Holdings, a Mainboard-listed IT solutions provider, sees growing demand for its e-AGM solution due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has already deployed its product to 60 customers in Singapore, mostly listed companies, who were forced to hold virtual annual general meetings. The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority has opened a public consultation on proposed amendments to the Companies Act, which may facilitate digital meetings permanently. Azeus is cautiously optimistic about the increasing take-up of its e-AGM solution.

site_title: 'Everyone is panicking' over quarantine, says UK tourist in Spain
summary: The UK government has abruptly implemented a 14-day quarantine for all British tourists returning from Spain, citing a rise in coronavirus cases. This decision, effective immediately, has left travelers with no time to prepare and has caused widespread panic. The move is expected to severely impact Spain's economy, which relies heavily on tourism from the UK, with Britons accounting for over 20% of foreign visitors. The decision is seen as a "tough blow" for the country, with the mayor of Benidorm calling it an "absolute disaster" for the recovery.

site_title: Buybacks, director deals muted amid earnings focus
summary: The Straits Times Index declined 0.4% over five trading sessions, bringing its 2020 year-to-date decline to 16.9%. In contrast, the iEdge S-Reit Index strengthened 3.2% and its 2020 year-to-date decline narrowed to 5.5%. Meanwhile, share buybacks and director deals were muted amid focus on earnings reports, with companies prioritizing financial performance over special dividends.

site_title: Q2 GDP may be lowered from estimates as factories disappoint in June
summary: Singapore's factories experienced a second consecutive month of output decline in June, with industrial production falling 6.7% year on year. The decline was largely attributed to the biomedical cluster, which dropped 30.6% after a five-month winning streak. Private-sector economists now expect the second-quarter GDP to be downgraded, with a contraction of 0.7% or 13.2% possible, citing coronavirus containment measures, supply chain disruptions, and a poor external environment.

site_title: 481 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 5 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 481 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 50,369, with 5 community cases and 4 imported cases. The majority of cases are migrant workers in dormitories. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is on track to clear all dormitories by the beginning of next month, except for 17 standalone blocks serving 28,000 workers. The average number of new daily cases in the community has decreased, with 7 cases in the past week.

site_title: How privatisation affects bondholders
summary: Privatization of public companies can negatively impact bondholders, who often lose access to timely updates and significant changes to the company. Privatized companies are not subject to public shareholder scrutiny, allowing them to take on more debt, dispose of core assets, and withdraw significant cash. Examples of companies that have negatively affected bondholders include CWT, Global Logistics Properties, and Neptune Orient Lines. To mitigate risks, bondholders should watch out for covenants, the strength of the controlling shareholder, and the premium attached to the shareholder. Direct covenants such as delisting put and change of control put can protect bondholders, while indirect covenants, such as financial covenants, can also provide some protection.

site_title: The message behind gold's rally: the world economy is in trouble
summary: Gold prices have surged to a 30% gain since March, reaching a record high of $1,902.02 an ounce, driven by concerns over the global economy and the pandemic. The US Federal Reserve's decision to print money and push stimulus packages has triggered stagflation fears, causing investors to seek safe-haven assets like gold. Real interest rates continue to plummet, and investors are looking for attractive hedges as yields on Treasuries fall below zero. Analysts predict gold will continue to rise, with some forecasting a price target of $3,000 an ounce in the next 18 months.

site_title: 'We need to do something': Moms and dads rally behind Portland protesters
summary: A social media post by Bev Barnum, a Portland mother, sparked a movement of mothers and fathers to stand in solidarity with Black Lives Matter protesters in Portland, Oregon. The "Wall of Moms" formed a human barrier between police and protesters, with mothers wearing bright yellow T-shirts and bike helmets, while fathers joined in with leaf blowers and orange shirts. The movement has gained international attention and has led to similar chapters in other cities, with fathers and mothers showing up to nightly marches to support the cause and advocate for change.

site_title: HSBC denies reports that it 'fabricated evidence' on Huawei
summary: HSBC has denied reports that it "fabricated evidence" on Huawei, stating it has no malice against the company and has not concealed facts. The bank's statement comes amid US investigations into Huawei for allegedly violating US sanctions on Iran. The probe led to the arrest of Huawei's chief financial officer, Meng Wanzhou, in Canada in 2018. HSBC has faced pressure as US-China relations sour, including criticism for backing a security law in Hong Kong that limits political freedoms. The bank's statement was blocked by China's internet censors within hours of publication.

site_title: South Korea reports 113 new coronavirus cases, most since March
summary: South Korea reported 113 new coronavirus cases on July 25, the largest one-day increase since March, bringing the country's total to 14,092. Of the new cases, 86 were imported and 27 were domestic infections. Health authorities warned that imported cases could drive the number of new cases to over 100. The country's total cases surpass the previous peak in March.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter remove accounts of Bolsonaro supporters following court order
summary: Facebook and Twitter removed 28 accounts, including those of high-profile Bolsonaro supporters, following a Supreme Court order in Brazil. The accounts were taken down for allegedly disseminating disinformation and threats against Supreme Court officials. The move is part of an ongoing probe into illicit funding of such activities. The court's decision highlights the challenges faced by social media platforms in complying with jurisdictional laws and regulations.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (July 27)
summary: Big advertising opportunities are emerging in the mobile gaming world, according to Tom Simpson, SVP of AdColony. A special Covid-19 fund has been launched by Vulpes Investment Management, led by Field Pickering, to support venture and impact investing. Meanwhile, BT is seeking feedback on its products and services. The market focus has been on various topics, including the impact of Trump's tariffs on the US dollar and the potential of structured notes. Additionally, private equity is being explored as a viable investment option for regular investors.

site_title: China orders US to close Chengdu consulate in retaliation move
summary: China ordered the US to close its consulate in Chengdu, China, in retaliation for the US shutting down the Chinese mission in Houston. The move, announced by China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, comes after the US accused the Chinese consulate of spying and influence operations. The closure will also impact a key listening post for developments in neighboring Tibet. China's state broadcaster live-streamed footage of the consulate's entrance as police searched the area. The move reflects worsening relations between the two countries, with the US accusing China of seeking global hegemony.

site_title: Office rents flat in Q2, but vacancy rises to 12.1%
summary: Singapore's office market saw a record 55,000 square meters of net lettable area decline in Q2, with the island-wide office vacancy rate rising to 12.1% from 11% in Q1. The drop was largely driven by businesses tightening their belts, with leasing activity primarily fueled by renewals or relocations. Experts expect office rents to fall in the second half of the year, with some predicting a 12% decline in gross effective average monthly rental value for the CBD Grade A office market.

site_title: Spotlight on Joe Biden as his VP reveal nears
summary: US President Joe Biden is nearing the announcement of his vice-presidential running mate, expected in early August. Biden, 77, is under pressure to choose a woman, with many Democrats calling for an African American pick, given the recent protests against racial injustice. Potential candidates include Senator Kamala Harris, former national security adviser Susan Rice, and others. Biden's choice is seen as crucial in appealing to a new generation of voters, with the coronavirus pandemic and Trump's presidency complicating matters.

site_title: Alibaba, Jack Ma summoned by Indian court on former employee's complaint
summary: An Indian court has summoned Alibaba and its founder Jack Ma in a case filed by a former employee, Pushpandra Singh Parmar, who claims the company censored content and showed false news to cause social and political turmoil in India. Parmar alleges Alibaba's UC News and UC Browser apps in India displayed false news and censored content seen as unfavorable to China. The court has issued a summons for Alibaba, Jack Ma, and others to appear in court or provide written responses within 30 days. This case comes after India banned 59 Chinese apps, including UC News and UC Browser, citing security concerns.

site_title: Australia rejects Beijing's South China Sea claims, backing US
summary: Australia has rejected Beijing's territorial and maritime claims in the South China Sea, aligning itself with the US in the escalating row. In a UN statement, Australia said there is "no legal basis" to China's claims, including those related to artificial islands in the sea. This move strengthens ties between Australia and the US, opposing China's growing influence in the region.

site_title: Indian firms struggle to lure migrant workers back
summary: Millions of migrant workers who fled India's cities during the COVID-19 pandemic are reluctant to return, despite offers of free air tickets, accommodation, and higher pay. The shortage of workers has severely impacted the economy, with over 10,000 building sites lying abandoned in Mumbai. Analysts warn of a "double whammy" as the pandemic erodes demand and construction workers are not available, leading to a slump in growth and stalled projects. The crisis has left many workers, including those who went hungry, desperate to return to work to avoid starvation.

site_title: US records over 1,000 coronavirus deaths for fourth straight day
summary: The US recorded over 1,000 COVID-19 deaths for the fourth consecutive day, with a total of 145,352 deaths, according to a Reuters tally. This marks the first time since early June that the country has seen a four-day streak of over 1,000 deaths. Despite rising cases and deaths, the US death toll remains lower than the April peak of 2,000 daily deaths. The outbreak has been attributed to younger, healthier individuals, and hospitals have found better treatments, such as the use of Remdesivir.

site_title: Johnny Depp and Amber Heard's courtroom faceoff: an explainer
summary: Johnny Depp is suing the owners of The Sun and its executive editor, Dan Wootton, for libel over an article that called him a "wife beater" and said there was "overwhelming evidence" that he assaulted his ex-wife Amber Heard during their marriage. Depp denies all claims, while Heard has testified that Depp was violent towards her, including an incident in Australia where she claims he threw bottles at her. The case has generated significant publicity for The Sun, with some speculating that it could have implications for both actors' careers and the #MeToo movement.

site_title: Singapore Q2 private home prices surprise with 0.3% uptick
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 0.3% in Q2, a surprise reversal from a 1.1% decline in the initial flash estimate. However, analysts expect economic headwinds and weaker employment prospects to put downward pressure on prices later in the year. Transaction volumes slumped 38% quarter-on-quarter, and resale transactions accounted for 35% of all private homes sold in Q2. Experts predict a decline in prices, with Cushman & Wakefield estimating a 3-6% drop for 2020, while PropNex expects a 1-2% decline.

site_title: NTUC proposes framework on responsible retrenchment practices
summary: NTUC proposes the Fair Retrenchment Framework to guide companies on responsible retrenchment practices amid an uncertain economic outlook. The framework has three guiding principles: implementing fair selection criteria to protect the "Singaporean Core" jobs, preserving jobs by minimizing downtime and early intervention, and providing job support to affected workers. NTUC urges companies to ensure openness, transparency, and consultation with unions and workers, and to observe the framework to protect workers' rights.

site_title: Why we need more space
summary: Several space agencies and private companies are sending missions to Mars, with the goal of exploring the planet's surface and searching for signs of life. The UAE's Hope Probe, China's Tianwen-1 Mars probe, and NASA's Perseverance rover are among the missions set to launch in the coming years. Meanwhile, SpaceX plans to send space tourists to low Earth orbits and the International Space Station by 2021 or 2022, while a privately-funded Mars Base1 in China is set to simulate Martian conditions for visitors. The Mars missions aim to pool resources and promote international cooperation in space exploration.

images.alt_text: On July 23, China's Long March 5 rocket blasted off from Hainan island carrying a very special payload - the Tianwen-1 Mars probe. The mission involves a seven-month slingshot through space with an orbiter, a lander, and a rover that will be deployed in February 2021 to carry out numerous experiments while it hunts for invaluable water ice.

site_title: Europe: US-China tension, virus worries weigh on stocks; Centrica soars
summary: European stocks fell 1.7% on Friday, their largest monthly drop, amid US-China tensions and concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic. The Stoxx 600 index also fell 1.5% for the week. Despite Germany's manufacturing sector avoiding contraction, business activity remained below pre-crisis levels, according to PMI data. Meanwhile, Centrica surged 16.8% after announcing plans to sell its North American business, while technology stocks led losses.

site_title: Red Bull distances itself from Thai heir after fatal case dropped
summary: Red Bull's Thai heir, Vorayuth "Boss" Yoovidhya, has had charges dropped in a fatal hit-and-run case after five years. The decision sparked public outrage, with the hashtags #BossRedBull and #BoycottRedbull trending on Twitter. Red Bull's Thai parent company, TCP Group, distanced itself from Vorayuth, stating he has no involvement in the company's management or operations. The case is considered a personal matter, but it has highlighted the culture of impunity among Thailand's rich, fueling a pro-democracy protest movement demanding an end to such practices.

site_title: Move over gold. Wood is the shelter of choice in the pandemic
summary: Lumber futures have doubled since early April, outperforming gold and silver, as North Americans spent on home renovations during the pandemic. Despite lockdowns and supply cuts, demand for building materials remained strong. This trend suggests wood may be a new "haven" commodity, overshadowing traditional safe-haven assets like gold and silver. Economies' struggles and US-China tensions may be driving investors towards this unexpected alternative.

site_title: 10 ways to lower your blood pressure without medication
summary: High blood pressure can be managed through lifestyle changes, rather than medication. Ten ways to lower blood pressure without medication include exercising regularly, cutting salt intake, and losing weight. Quitting smoking, treating obstructive sleep apnea, eating potassium-rich foods, and consuming magnesium-rich foods can also help. Additionally, reducing stress, consuming cocoa, and taking folate supplements may aid in lowering blood pressure. By incorporating these lifestyle changes, individuals can reduce their risk of heart disease, stroke, and other cardiovascular-related complications, with a potential 25% reduction in cardiovascular death.

site_title: Seven new office-holders, six promotions in new Cabinet; Parliament to open on Aug 24
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a new Cabinet lineup with seven new office-holders and six promotions, including two to full minister. Tan See Leng, a new MP and former healthcare CEO, is appointed as a full minister holding three roles. The new Cabinet has 37 office-holders, the same number as the previous cabinet. The lineup was announced two weeks after the July 10 General Election.

site_title: Q2 net demand for retail space shrinks by record 93,000 sq m
