site_title: Oil slips as US posts surprise rise in crude inventories
summary: Oil prices fell as US crude inventories unexpectedly rose, and fuel demand decreased due to the resurgence of coronavirus cases. Brent crude futures dropped 3 cents to $44.29 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 2 cents to $41.90 a barrel. The US-China tensions also contributed to the decline in oil prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged lower on Wednesday as government data showed a surprise rise in US crude inventories and as tensions escalated between the United States and China.

site_title: Airbnb approached about blank-cheque company merger for public listing: CEO
summary: Airbnb's CEO Brian Chesky said the company has been approached about a merger with a blank-cheque acquisition company, a novel way to list on the stock market. This method, known as a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), allows companies to quickly go public without the lengthy IPO process. Chesky stated that Airbnb is "looking at everything" and hasn't ruled out the possibility, but hasn't speculated on the details.

site_title: US general sees Iraq troop drawdown as IS threat dims
summary: A US commander, Major General Kenneth Ekman, has stated that the diminished threat of the Islamic State (IS) in Iraq is paving the way for a further troop drawdown. Currently, there are approximately 5,200 US troops in Iraq, with a potential slow reduction of US forces over time. The reduced threat is attributed to IS's inability to hold territory, with its activities now limited to a low-level insurgency in rural areas. The objective is to maintain pressure on IS and strengthen Iraqi security forces, with several military bases already handed over to Iraqi forces.

site_title: SK Hynix Q2 profit triples as stay-at-home demand lifts chip prices
summary: SK Hynix, the world's No.2 memory chip maker, reported a tripled quarterly operating profit to 1.9 trillion won (S$2.26 billion) in the April-June period, beating analysts' forecasts. The company attributed the increase to strong demand for cloud services and online education during the COVID-19 pandemic, which drove up chip prices. Despite this, SK Hynix expects uncertainties to continue in the second half due to the pandemic and global trade disputes, and forecasts improving demand for chips used in 5G smartphones and game consoles.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust Q2 DPU down 23.2% to 1.69 S cents
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust's (CCT) 2Q20 DPU fell 23.2% to 1.69 S cents, down from 2.20 S cents a year ago. Gross revenue and net property income declined 8.1% and 9.7% respectively to S$92.8 million and S$70.8 million. Lower income from Singapore properties, occupancies, and rental waivers offset gains from Main Airport Center and Gallileo. Income available for distribution declined 28.2% to S$59.2 million. The distribution will be paid out on Aug 28.

site_title: AIMS Apac Reit posts 20% drop in Q1 DPU to two S cents
summary: AIMS Apac Reit reported a 20% drop in its Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) to 2 Singapore cents, down from 2.5 cents last year. The decline was due to lower gross revenue and net property income, mainly caused by rent waivers and lease conversions. Despite this, the Reit's large tenant base in essential services helped it achieve a stable performance. The Reit's units closed 0.8% lower at S$1.21.

site_title: Naiise to shutter Paya Lebar outlet on July 26
summary: Naiise, a Singapore-based multi-label retailer, will close its store at Paya Lebar Quarter on July 26 due to a lease expiry. This marks the retailer's second store closure in Singapore, leaving it with one store at Jewel Changi Airport and an office and retail shop in Kuala Lumpur. Naiise has been undergoing cost-cutting measures, including halving its headcount earlier this year, and has shifted focus to building its online store presence.

site_title: US: Stocks gain despite rising China tensions
summary: US stocks rose 0.6% on Wednesday, driven by progress towards a coronavirus vaccine, despite rising tensions with China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 climbed, while the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.2%. The US government agreed to pay $2 billion for a potential vaccine, and existing home sales jumped 20.7% in June. Individual companies like Best Buy and Nike also saw gains, while United Airlines reported a $1.6 billion loss.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished a choppy session higher on Wednesday as investors weighed progress towards a coronavirus vaccine against worries over worsening US-China relations.

site_title: Europe: Stocks in reverse as US-China tensions spike
summary: European stocks slid 0.9% on Wednesday, their sharpest one-day drop in a month, as escalating US-China tensions and rising coronavirus cases dented sentiment. Energy stocks fell 2.8% after a bigger-than-expected inventory build-up in the US, while healthcare stocks marked their worst session in a month. Despite a positive EU-wide debt deal, expectations for second-quarter corporate profits in Europe have further deteriorated, with companies forecast to report a 58.6% decline in quarterly earnings.

site_title: Tensions soar as US orders China consulate shut
summary: The US ordered the closure of the Chinese consulate in Houston within 72 hours, escalating tensions between the two countries. This move came after the US indicted two Chinese nationals for allegedly hacking hundreds of companies and stealing virus vaccine research. China condemned the US action, with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stating that the Chinese Communist Party needs to behave accordingly. The closure marks the latest deterioration in US-China relations, which are already strained due to the coronavirus pandemic and Beijing's crackdown in Hong Kong.

site_title: More tourism layoffs expected despite redeployment strategy
summary: Singapore's tourism sector is expected to continue shedding jobs despite efforts to avoid "catastrophic job loss". Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing warned of inevitable job losses due to the freeze on mass-market travel. The Singapore Tourism Board is redeploying workers to other sectors and working with government agencies to find new roles. The tourism board's chief executive, Keith Tan, emphasized the need for flexibility in the job market to cushion the impact of job losses and maintain economic stability.

site_title: SPH Ventures leads US$3.5m Series A fundraise for Partipost
summary: Singapore-based influencer marketing startup Partipost has raised US$3.5 million in a Series A funding round led by SPH Ventures, with Quest Ventures and other investors also participating. Founded in 2016, Partipost allows brands to tap a wide base of influencers for marketing campaigns. The funding will enable the startup to develop better technology and collect more data to help brands connect with the right influencers. Partipost has onboarded over 200,000 influencers and conducted 2,500 influencer marketing campaigns for 850 brands in the past year.

site_title: Sembmarine independent shareholders have deciding say in 'critical' SCI deal
summary: Sembcorp Marine's independent shareholders will decide whether a proposed rights issue involving parent Sembcorp Industries proceeds, despite SCI owning 61% of SMM shares. The transaction aims to raise S$2.1 billion to fund ongoing commitments and compete for new high-value projects. If approved, the rights issue will allow SMM to chart a new way forward with a stronger balance sheet. Shareholders will vote on a whitewash resolution at extraordinary general meetings in August and September.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hong Leong Asia has appointed Stephen Ho Kiam Kong as its new CEO, effective August 17, replacing the previous CEO. The bank has also been ranked 640th globally by The Banker, up 27 spots from last year, attributed to its 7.8% growth in Tier 1 capital. Meanwhile, the group expects a net loss for H1 FY20 due to losses in its hospitality business, but maintains sufficient liquidity to meet operational needs. AEM Holdings acquired California-based DB Design Group for $3.3 million to expand product offerings and customer portfolio.

site_title: Markets resume risk-on rally, shrugging off US-China spat
summary: Currency markets resumed their risk-on rally on Wednesday, despite US-China tensions, as traders shrugged off concerns about a potential halt to the US-China trade deal. The dominant mood remained optimistic, following the European Union's agreement on a 750 billion-euro recovery fund. The dollar index fell 0.1% to 95.028, while the euro reached a new high of US$1.1584, and the Australian and New Zealand dollars also gained. Sterling fell against the dollar and euro due to concerns about a delayed US fiscal stimulus.

site_title: WeWork to lose major tenant in Japan as e-commerce giant Rakuten exits
summary: WeWork is set to lose a major tenant in Japan as e-commerce giant Rakuten exits its co-working space in Tokyo, leaving about 700 desks empty. Rakuten's financial tech arm will move staff into new offices. WeWork's short leases and dense office layouts make it vulnerable to budget cutbacks, and the pandemic has accelerated the shift to remote work. Despite this, WeWork is on track for positive cash flow in 2021, according to its executive chairman.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts Q2 DPU of 0.93 Singapore cent
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) posted a Q2 DPU of 0.93 Singapore cent, unchanged from a year ago, despite a 35.8% year-over-year increase in distributable cash flow to S$62.2 million. The trust's businesses, including City Gas and Ixom, performed well, with City Gas recording higher distributable cash flow due to a timing lag in adjusting gas tariffs. KIT's profit attributable to unitholders increased 64.4% to S$26.2 million. The trust will continue to monitor the Covid-19 situation and review potential acquisition opportunities to strengthen its long-term income stream.

site_title: China's central bank, wary of over-stimulus, likely to pause easing
summary: China's central bank is unlikely to ease monetary policy further, citing concerns over excessive stimulus and its potential side effects, such as rising debt and property market bubbles. Despite a stronger-than-expected economic rebound in the second quarter, policymakers want to maintain a stable monetary policy to support a recovery in the world's second-largest economy. The People's Bank of China will keep conditions accommodative to support growth, but may slow the pace of easing and consider further cuts if the economy falters again.

site_title: US orders up to 600m doses of Pfizer, BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The US has ordered up to 600 million doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, worth $1.95 billion for 100 million doses, with the option to acquire an additional 500 million doses. Analysts estimate the vaccine's price at $20 per dose, resulting in a potential windfall of over $15 billion for Pfizer. The US government will pay for the doses after regulatory approval, and the vaccine will be available for free to the American people.

site_title: Australia mortgage defaults mainly due to income loss, negative equity
summary: Australia's mortgage defaults are primarily driven by income loss and negative equity, according to Reserve Bank of Australia research. The unemployment rate and net income are key variables in evaluating financial stability risks. Housing prices play a significant role in foreclosures, especially when borrowers have negative equity. The government has extended a wage subsidy program and granted four-month loan extensions to help households, but 800,000 Australians may lose support if the extension is not renewed. The jobless rate has climbed to a 22-year high of 7.4% in June, with an effective unemployment rate of 11.3%.

site_title: Maybank KE ups Top Glove target price, sees 'small impact' from US detention order
summary: Maybank Kim Eng has upgraded its 12-month target price for Top Glove to RM28.60 from RM21.90, citing a potential premium in the glove market due to supply chain issues. The research house expects Top Glove's average selling price (ASP) to remain high in the next six months, driven by a glove shortage, but anticipates a decrease in ASP premium against peers starting from Q2 2021. A recent US detention order on two of Top Glove's subsidiaries is expected to have a small impact on the company's net profit estimates.

site_title: Positive outlook for infrastructure demand as countries try to boost economies
summary: Singapore's construction sector contracted 54.7% in Q2 2020, but demand for infrastructure is expected to remain strong, driving economic recovery. Analysts predict a pick-up in infrastructure investment and spending within the next 12 months. However, changes in priorities, such as healthcare and telecommunications systems, may impact the sector. Some companies, like Yongnam Holdings, are securing contracts, while others, like Koon Holdings, are winding up divisions. The industry is expected to see a new normal with accelerated technology adoption, but credit risk remains high due to large fixed costs and uncertain earnings outlook.

site_title: COE prices mostly drop across the board, except for rise in Open category
summary: COE prices in Singapore mostly dropped at the latest tender, with prices for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closing at S$32,699, a 2.45% decrease from the previous close on July 8. This marks the second tender after a three-month suspension.

site_title: Asiaciti Trust fined S$1.1m for poor money-laundering controls
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has fined Asiaciti Trust S$1.1 million for poor money laundering and terrorism financing controls, including failing to monitor unusually large transactions by "politically exposed" customers. The company committed serious breaches spanning over a decade, including failing to assess suspicious transactions and not subjecting business contacts to independent audits. The MAS has taken remedial measures, and lawyers consider the fine a significant reminder to the financial industry to prioritize anti-money laundering and terrorism financing.

images.alt_text: This is the second-largest penalty MAS has imposed on a licensed trust company to date.

site_title: Cathay delays Airbus deliveries to stem crippling cash drain
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd has agreed to delay Airbus deliveries by up to two years, from 2020-2023 to 2020-2023 and 2020-2025, to cut its monthly cash losses in half due to the coronavirus pandemic. The move could also help the airline stay afloat financially.

site_title: Retail players are focusing too much on returns and not enough on risk
summary: Retail investors, fueled by zero-commission fees and the "fear of missing out," have surged into the stock market, with 820,000 online broking accounts opened in Japan between February and April. Similar trends are seen in Singapore, the US, and other markets, with many retail investors taking advantage of the economic downturn to try their luck in trading stocks. However, experts warn that this complacency may be misplaced, as day trading consistently yields profits for only a small percentage of players, and the disconnect between economic reality and stock prices is widening.

site_title: Employers have role in tackling domestic violence
summary: Employers play a crucial role in supporting employees at risk of domestic violence. Regular check-ins, such as over calls or texts, can help identify those in need. Employers can also signpost support services like Aware's Women's Helpline. The COVID-19 work-from-home boom has blurred the line between public and private lives, making it essential for employers to be aware of domestic violence's impact on the workplace. By providing support, employers can help prevent abuse and create a safer work environment. This approach can also foster a culture of understanding and empathy.

images.alt_text: Many victims disclose their abuse to trusted colleagues, making these colleagues an invaluable bridge to provide information about helpful resources, such as family violence specialist centres and shelters.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit posts Q2 DPU of 1.56 US cents
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit reported a Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.56 US cents, 4% higher than a year ago. The half-year DPU was 3.10 US cents, a 3.3% increase year-over-year. Second-quarter distributable income rose 18.5% to US$14.7 million, driven by higher rental income from new leases and positive rental reversion. Despite a slowdown in property tours, the Reit achieved a 14.7% rental reversion in H1. Units closed down 0.74% to US$0.675 on Wednesday.

site_title: Tokyo prepares for Olympics in 2021 despite Covid-19 issues
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers, led by CEO Toshiro Muto, are preparing to host the 2021 Games despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Organisers are assuming the virus will remain a major problem and are working to ensure the event's safety. The delay will incur additional costs, estimated at $800 million, and two-thirds of corporate sponsors are undecided on continuing their support. Muto hopes that bringing in new sponsors and implementing measures to reduce the virus threat will help bridge the financial gap and create a legacy for the post-pandemic world.

site_title: Retro revival and a farewell note
summary: Weekend Magazine, a standalone publication, will cease print publication on July 31 and be replaced by a new section within The Business Times. The final issue focuses on a retro revival, featuring vintage fashion, luxury watches, and a renewed interest in Korean cuisine and home design. The article also highlights the growing demand for sustainable products and the rise of homegrown businesses catering to the trend. Additionally, James Liang, co-founder of Trip.com, shares his assessment of the travel industry now.

site_title: Mega sourcing trade show goes online
summary: A three-in-one mega sourcing virtual trade show will be staged by Sphere Exhibits Pte Ltd, filling the void left by physical sourcing events due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The virtual trade show will feature corporate gifts, office solutions, printing, packaging, signage, and labelling solutions. The event aims to connect buyers with sourcing specialists and provide a platform for businesses to explore and purchase products. The virtual trade show will be a three-in-one event, offering a unique experience for attendees.

site_title: EU recovery fund seen as turning point for eurozone financial assets
summary: The European Union has agreed on a 750-billion-euro recovery fund, seen as a turning point for the eurozone's financial assets and a landmark step towards fiscal integration. The fund, hailed as an unprecedented act of solidarity, has boosted the single currency to one-and-a-half-year highs. Investors view the move as a game changer, signaling a shift towards greater financial cooperation and stability in the region. The deal is expected to have a positive impact on the bloc's equities, marking a significant shift towards a more unified and resilient eurozone.

site_title: Analysts raise target prices for Keppel DC Reit as unit price climbs
summary: Analysts at DBS Group Research, OCBC Investment Research, and CGS-CIMB have increased their target prices for Keppel DC Reit, citing the real estate investment trust's (Reit) rise this year. OCBC raised its fair value to S$2.86, while DBS analysts Dale Lai and Derek Tan raised their price target to S$2.80. CGS-CIMB analysts Eing Kar Mei and Lock Mun Yee raised their target price to S$2.88. The Reit's units have rallied 8% in the past two weeks, with analysts attributing the growth to acquisitions and improved efficiency. All three research teams maintain a "hold" call, with growth expected from second-half acquisitions.

site_title: Biden attacks US$51b real estate tax break in a jab at Trump
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden is targeting a $51 billion tax break for the real estate industry, which President Donald Trump has used to his advantage. The plan would eliminate a provision that allows property developers to avoid capital gains taxes on property sales, with the revenue raised going towards childcare and elderly services. This move is seen as a jab at Trump, who has boasted about using the tax code to his benefit. Biden's proposal aims to close a loophole that benefits the real estate industry.

site_title: Decisive policymaking crucial for economic resilience
summary: Emerging markets have demonstrated resilience in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, driven by decisive policymaking, effective execution, and social cohesion. Countries with robust balance sheets, such as China, India, and South Korea, have proven to be sources of resilience. The crisis has also accelerated secular trends in emerging markets, including increased institutional resilience, a shift towards domestic consumption and technology, and innovation. As the global economy reopens, emerging markets are poised to benefit from these trends, with ESG considerations becoming increasingly important.

site_title: Multi-million-dollar marketing budget may get top-up if needed
summary: Singapore is prepared to extend its S$45 million domestic tourism campaign, SingapoRediscovers, if needed, according to the country's tourism bureau head. The nine-month initiative aims to lift the tourism industry, which was severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The campaign's success will be evaluated in the context of other measures to stimulate demand and consumption, including four budgets that delivered household support and business relief. The tourism board is prepared to allocate more resources if necessary, but the exact budget extension is uncertain.

site_title: LTA opens applications for bike-sharing licence
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has opened applications for bike-sharing licences in Singapore, allowing companies to expand their fleets. Anywheel, the largest operator, will increase its fleet size from 10,000 to 15,000 bicycles. New firms can apply for a sandbox licence to start operations on a small scale, with existing operators allowed to expand their fleets. The application cycle is open until August 26, with firms required to meet the LTA's new licensing regulations to tackle indiscriminate parking and controlling fleet sizes.

site_title: China vows retaliation after US shuts down Houston consulate
summary: The US government forced China to close its Houston consulate within three days, a move described as an "unprecedented escalation" by Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin. This move is seen as a significant blow to diplomatic ties between the two countries. The closure of the consulate is a response to US allegations of intellectual property theft and espionage. China has vowed retaliation, but no further details have been released.

site_title: US Senate panel approves ban on using TikTok app on government devices
summary: The US Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs voted unanimously to approve a bill banning federal employees from using TikTok on government devices, citing national security concerns over the app's ownership by China's ByteDance. This comes after the House of Representatives voted 336-71 to bar federal employees from downloading the app on government devices as part of a $741 billion defense policy bill. The prohibition could soon become law in the United States.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler, Waymo expand autonomous vehicle partnership
summary: Fiat Chrysler and Waymo are expanding their autonomous vehicle partnership to commercial vehicles, focusing on light commercial vehicles for goods delivery. The companies will develop fully self-driving vehicles exclusively with Waymo, starting with integrating Waymo's technology into Ram ProMaster vans. This partnership aims to accelerate profits by leveraging delivery and commercial uses of autonomous vehicles, shifting investment and engineering focus from passenger vehicles. The collaboration will cover ride-hailing, commercial delivery, and personal-use vehicles globally, with a focus on level 4 autonomous driving capabilities.

site_title: Takedown or trip: One Championship gets into the ring with reality TV
summary: One Championship, a Singapore-based MMA promoter, has launched its own reality TV show, The Apprentice: One Championship Edition, hosted by chairman and CEO Chatri Sityodtong. The 16-contestant competition aims to find Sityodong's new business protege. The show, produced by One Studios, will air on traditional and digital platforms later this year. One Championship's financials have faced scrutiny, with barter transactions making up a significant portion of revenue in the past. However, the company expects barter revenues to flatten out to less than 5% in the next five years.

site_title: Afghan girl who killed Taleban gunmen 'ready to fight again'
summary: A 15-year-old Afghan girl, Qamar Gul, shot and killed two Taliban fighters who attacked her home, killing her parents, in a village in Ghor province. She said she was ready to fight again after "anger took over" and she used her father's AK-47 to defend herself and her brother. Officials confirmed the gunmen were killed by a woman, and the government has pledged to protect Qamar Gul and her family, with President Ashraf Ghani praising her for defending her family against a "ruthless enemy".

site_title: Wellness company Crigen debuts on 1exchange, eyes listing in Australia
summary: Malaysia-based wellness and aesthetics services operator Crigen Resources debuted on Singapore's 1exchange, listing 28% of its shares at an aggregate value of S$2 million. The company, which operates Danai Spa, aims to pursue further domestic growth and expansion into new markets. Danai Spa plans to open 12 outlets and expects revenue to grow at a compounded rate of 28.6% annually from FY2019 to FY2022. The listing supports the company's long-term goal of a public listing in Australia.

site_title: TikTok gave rural Indian women fame, fun and more
summary: TikTok provided rural Indian women with a platform to gain fame, fun, and financial stability. Despite the government's ban on the app in India, many women, such as stay-at-home mum Mamta Verma and housewife Rupali Manoj Bhandole, accumulated millions of followers and earned money through their videos. The app's simplicity and accessibility made it accessible to those who don't speak or read English or Hindi, breaking the "glass ceiling" for common people in rural India. The ban has left many women without a source of income and confidence, with hopes that the benefits will last.

site_title: CAAS signs aviation health safety commitment with EU agency
summary: CAAS and the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) have signed a memorandum of cooperation to validate and harmonize aviation health safety measures for air travel. The agreement aims to protect the health and safety of passengers, air crew, and airport staff, as well as strengthen traveler confidence to facilitate the recovery of air travel between Singapore and Europe. Singapore Airlines and the Changi Airport Group will participate in the EASA Aviation Industry Charter to implement operational guidelines developed by EASA and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.

site_title: Say hello to GPT-3, the weird and wonderful future of AI
summary: GPT-3, a general language model developed by OpenAI, has been unveiled, granting computers the ability to generate text like humans. Trained on 175 billion parameters, GPT-3 can converse, translate, answer emails, and perform programming tasks, among others. Its potential applications include serving as a therapist, writing poetry, and answering search queries, making it a powerful tool that could outperform Google. While it has the potential to generate an entire ecosystem, concerns about its accuracy and potential misuse, such as surveillance and impersonation, have been raised.

site_title: Private housing projects facing delays of six to nine months
summary: Construction projects in Singapore are facing delays of six to nine months due to manpower issues and health and safety measures. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has given the go-ahead to over 2,500 projects, including 900 residential projects, to restart work. Contractors are prioritizing health and safety measures before allowing more workers on site, resulting in a significant slowdown in construction activity. Only about 10% of construction work is currently happening, according to SCAL president Ng Yek Meng.

site_title: Government agencies commit S$40m to National Innovation Challenges
summary: Singapore's Enterprise Singapore, Infocomm Media Development Authority, and National Research Foundation have committed S$40 million to National Innovation Challenges (NICs). The NICs, launched on July 22, 2020, aim to create cross-industry collaborations to co-innovate solutions for safe reopening amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Seven NICs have been announced, with each allocated up to S$2 million in funding, to accelerate innovation efforts and help enterprises develop solutions to overcome post-Covid-19 challenges.

site_title: Shopify teams up with PayPal co-founder in battle with Amazon
summary: Shopify partners with Affirm to offer flexible payment plans, allowing US consumers to split purchases into four payments. This partnership is expected to roll out before the end of the year and aims to attract younger consumers looking to avoid high-interest credit cards. The move is Shopify's latest effort to compete with Amazon, with Affirm CEO Max Levchin citing the partnership as an opportunity to convert younger shoppers.

site_title: US existing home sales post record increase in June
summary: US existing home sales surged 20.7% in June to a record 4.72 million units, driven by low mortgage rates, but low inventory and high unemployment amid the pandemic continue to cloud the housing market outlook. This marks the largest gain since 1968. Existing home sales remain below pre-pandemic levels, and home resales fell 11.3% year-over-year. The median existing house price increased 3.5% to a record $295,300 in June, while homebuilding increased by the most in nearly four years.

site_title: ByteDance to invest in education technology business
summary: ByteDance, owner of TikTok, plans to invest a significant amount of capital into its education technology business. The unit, established in 2016, is unlikely to profit in the next three years, according to senior executive Chen Lin. ByteDance has prioritized education technology alongside TikTok, amid scrutiny over user data concerns in Washington. The company aims to leverage education technology to diversify its business and mitigate potential risks.

site_title: Spotify signs new licensing deal with Vivendi's Universal Music Group
summary: Spotify has signed a multi-year licensing agreement with Universal Music Group, reinforcing its catalogue and products. The deal also includes collaboration on marketing campaigns and UMG's role as an early adopter of future products, providing valuable feedback to Spotify's development team. This follows recent launches of Spotify's video feature for podcasts and its music streaming service in Russia, its fastest-growing international market.

site_title: Wirecard and Merkel's office had regular contact before collapse
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel had regular contact with Wirecard before its collapse, according to a chronology of events by her office. Merkel promoted the digital payments company during a trip to China in September 2019 after being informed of ongoing investigations. Opposition lawmakers are pressing Merkel's administration for clarification on its pursuit of Wirecard amid allegations of fraud. A parliamentary finance committee will hold a special session on July 29 to discuss the firm's collapse, and Munich prosecutors are set to hold an ad hoc press conference to inform about the latest developments in their Wirecard probe.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to widen scope of privatisations, finance minister says
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to expand its privatization efforts, targeting sectors like healthcare and education, which were previously off-limits. Finance Minister Mohammed al-Jadaan expects the program to generate over $50 billion in revenue over the next four to five years. The country may also tap international debt investors again this year, although a decision on the issuance currency has not been made.

site_title: German prosecutors search offices in Fiat, Iveco emissions probe
summary: German prosecutors searched offices at Fiat Chrysler and CNH Industrial as part of an international investigation into potential emissions fraud. The probe targets software in Fiat, Alfa Romeo, Jeep, Iveco, and commercial vehicles, which allegedly switched off emissions filtering while driving. The investigation focuses on nine individuals in Italy from 2014 to 2019. Fiat Chrysler and CNH Industrial are cooperating with authorities, with the investigation coordinated by the EU justice agency Eurojust. The searches were made in Germany, Italy, and Switzerland.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust mulls over lease restructuring amid bleak Q2 results
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) is considering flexible lease structures to share risks with tenants, allowing them to participate in upside on turnover. The Reit's merger with CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) remains on the table, with a deadline of September 30. CMT's Q2 results showed a 39.8% decline in revenue and 48.9% drop in net property income, with distributable income falling 27.5%. The Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 27.7% to 2.11 Singapore cents, and portfolio valuation dropped 2.5% to S$10.1 billion.

site_title: Ryanair to shut Frankfurt hub after pilots refuse pay cuts
summary: Ryanair plans to close its Frankfurt-Hahn base in Germany due to German pilots' rejection of proposed 20% pay cuts. The airline had sought to axe 3,000 jobs, but pilots voted against the plan. Other hubs, including Berlin Tegel and Duesseldorf, may also be closed before winter. Ryanair blamed the pilots' union, VC, for rejecting the pay cuts, which would have preserved jobs. The airline will close Frankfurt-Hahn base on November 1, with job losses expected.

site_title: US orders up to 600m doses of Pfizer, BioNTech Covid vaccine
summary: The US government has agreed to pay $1.95 billion for 100 million doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine, with the option to acquire up to 600 million doses. The deal, worth $20 per dose, follows regulatory authorization and approval. The US has already ordered experimental vaccines from other developers, and experts estimate that the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine could generate over $15 billion in revenue if it prevents disease after one use.

site_title: Surge in Covid-19 cases weigh on markets, STI down 1.3%
summary: Singapore shares fell 1.3% on Wednesday, following a surge in Covid-19 cases, as optimism over a vaccine and EU recovery fund was dented by US President Trump's comments on the pandemic's gravity. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 34.92 points to 2,594.53, with 1.55 billion shares changing hands. Decliners outpaced advancers 314 to 163. The decline came after a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Several trends for investment portfolios post-Covid-19
summary: Investors are positioning for the post-Covid-19 world, focusing on resilient sectors such as technology, healthcare, and automation. Companies in these areas are well-positioned to integrate supply chains and acquire competitors, leading to stronger growth potential. Governments and central banks will drive global growth, but higher debt loads may lead to lower trend growth. Investors should look beyond developed markets for emerging market bonds and selectively invest in healthcare, digital consumption, and automation. A U-shaped recovery is expected, requiring resilient portfolios with long-term growth trends.

site_title: Nike job cuts to cost as much as US$250m in one-time charge
summary: Nike is implementing a new strategy to refocus on selling directly to consumers, resulting in a net loss of jobs across the company. The move, part of its Consumer Direct Acceleration plan, will cost the company between $200 million and $250 million in one-time charges. The company has not disclosed how many jobs will be eliminated. As part of the shift, Nike is introducing new leaders in key regions and restructuring its organization to become "nimbler and flatter." The move is in response to the pandemic's impact on physical storefronts and the growing demand for online shopping.

site_title: Humans lived in North America more than 30,000 years ago
summary: Scientists have discovered tools in a central Mexico cave, dated 30,000 years ago, which suggests humans lived in North America at least 15,000 years earlier than previously thought. The findings, published in the journal Nature, include 1,900 stone tools and radiocarbon dating results that put the oldest samples at 33,000 to 31,000 years ago. The discovery challenges the widely accepted "Clovis-first" model of human migration to the Americas, which suggests humans arrived via a land bridge from Russia to Alaska around 13,500 years ago.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow open lower as Sino-US ties worsen
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Wednesday due to worsening tensions between the US and China, offsetting optimism about fiscal stimulus for the virus-stricken economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.06% and the S&P 500 fell 0.06%. This marks a reversal from previous days, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The decline is attributed to the escalating tensions, which have raised concerns about the impact on global trade.

site_title: GLP to build industrial park in Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City
summary: GLP, a global logistics property player, has secured two industrial-land plots in the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City and plans to invest 300 million yuan (S$59.3 million) to build a "smart logistics" industrial park. The 8.44-hectare park will be located in the Eco-Innovation Park, near transportation nodes and major cities in north China. The "smart logistics" model will utilize AI, IoT, and other technologies to improve park management. GLP's investment is expected to create employment opportunities and inject vitality into the local economy.

site_title: Qatar Air seeks US$5b from Saudi-led bloc on airspace ban
summary: Qatar Airways is seeking at least $5 billion from Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain, and Egypt for stopping the airline from using their airspace. The airline has initiated four international investment arbitrations, claiming the boycotting countries' actions to remove it from their markets and airspace are unjust. The International Court of Justice previously ruled that the International Civil Aviation Organization has jurisdiction to oversee negotiations on a ban on Qatar-registered aircraft in the boycotting countries' airspace. Qatar denies charges of supporting terrorism and maintaining ties with Iran.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists partners Heliconia to pursue healthcare investments in South-east Asia
summary: Asian Healthcare Specialists has partnered with Heliconia to pursue healthcare investments in South-east Asia through a co-investment vehicle, Fansipan 2. Heliconia takes a majority stake, with AHS holding a 23.8% stake. The venture aims to invest up to S$33.6 million in healthcare-related investments, funded by convertible bonds and internal resources. This partnership enables AHS to gain knowledge and insight for future investments and may increase its visibility in the capital markets.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore launched a $45 million marketing campaign to boost domestic tourism, targeting "mini-holidays" in districts such as Chinatown and Orchard Road. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) fined Asiaciti Trust $1.1 million for money laundering breaches. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore and the European Union Aviation Safety Agency agreed on health safety measures for air travel between Singapore and Europe. The government committed $40 million to National Innovation Challenges. Singapore banks may cut dividends amid capital review, while Sembcorp and SMM proposed a separation plan with potential benefits for shareholders.

site_title: Wirecard ex-CEO, board members arrested for fraud: German prosecutor
summary: German prosecutors have arrested Wirecard's former CEO and two board members for "commercial fraud". Investigations show that trickery began in 2015, involving banks in Germany and Japan, and investors providing up to 3.2 billion euros. The sums are now "very likely lost" due to Wirecard's insolvency. The case has been described as an "unparalleled scandal" by Germany's finance minister, with significant implications for the nation's economy.

site_title: Japan kicks off domestic tourism campaign as critics point to virus surge
summary: Japan launched a national travel campaign, "Go To Travel", to revive its tourism industry, but it has drawn criticism as major cities experience a surge in new coronavirus cases. The campaign offers 50% subsidies for trips to prefectures except Tokyo, which was dropped due to high infections. Despite the government's efforts, many governors and the public want the campaign cancelled, citing concerns over the spread of the virus. The campaign's timing has been met with frustration from the travel industry, with many calling for clearer information and a more prepared approach.

site_title: ECB to extend capital relief, dividend ban for banks
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to extend its capital relief and dividend ban for euro zone banks until October, amid a severe recession caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The measures, initially introduced in March, aim to prevent unpaid loans and a potential second wave of the pandemic. ECB supervisors fear that expiring government guarantees and a potential second wave of the Covid-19 pandemic could lead to a new wave of unpaid loans, prompting the extension of the relief measures.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank is set to grant euro zone banks further relief from its capital requirements and renew a recommendation not to pay dividends amid a severe recession.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 8.95 points lower at 1,586.98, with 557 losers and 510 gainers. The market saw 9.373 billion lots worth RM4.891 billion.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts Q2 DPU of 0.93 Singapore cent
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) posted a Q2 DPU of 0.93 Singapore cents, unchanged from a year ago, despite a 35.8% year-over-year increase in distributable cash flow to S$62.2 million. The increase was driven by better performance in its distribution and network segment. KIT's businesses, classified as essential services, continued to operate during the Covid-19 pandemic. The trust also reported a 64.4% increase in profit attributable to unitholders to S$26.2 million.

site_title: Maersk to stop taking waste to China, Hong Kong from Sept
summary: AP Moller-Maersk, the world's top container shipping firm, will stop accepting solid waste shipments bound for China and Hong Kong from September 1, 2020, to comply with China's environmental campaign to reduce solid waste imports to zero by the end of 2020. This decision follows similar moves by German container shipping line Hapag-Lloyd and MSC Mediterranean Shipping Company. The policy change affects solid waste materials, including wastepaper, scrap metal, and used plastics, and aims to fully comply with China's government requirements.

site_title: Kitchen Culture to get S$9.5m through new share placement
summary: Kitchen Culture, a company pursuing a new medical supplies business, has announced a proposed share placement involving 21 investors, offering approximately S$9.5 million in net proceeds. The placement, priced at S$0.235 per share, represents a 9.62% discount to the volume-weighted average price. The funds will strengthen the company's financial position, improve cash flow, and increase resources to pursue new business opportunities, with expected post-deal net borrowings lowered to S$4.2 million.

site_title: South African anti-apartheid campaigner Andrew Mlangeni dies at 95
summary: South African anti-apartheid campaigner Andrew Mlangeni, who was jailed alongside Nelson Mandela from 1964, has died at 95. Mlangeni spent 26 years in jail and was the last of the eight defendants in the treason trial to pass away. President Cyril Ramaphosa described Mlangeni as a "beacon of ethical leadership and care for humanity," marking the end of a generation of history. His death leaves the future in the hands of those who remained, with Ramaphosa praising Mlangeni's fight for racial equality and an end to white minority rule.

site_title: Surge in Covid-19 cases weigh on markets, STI down 1.3%
summary: Singapore shares fell 1.3% on Wednesday, following a surge in coronavirus cases and US President Donald Trump's comments on the pandemic's severity. Trump stated the pandemic will "get worse before it gets better," while US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's comments on China weighed on markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,594.53, with no constituents registering gains. Decliners outpaced advancers 314 to 163, with local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank also falling.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 2.25% on Wednesday, following a previous day's rally, due to concerns over a record surge in infections that may lead to stricter containment measures. The Hang Seng Index fell to 25,057.94, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.37% and 0.84%, respectively. Investors are cautious ahead of potential changes in the city's COVID-19 policies.

site_title: Malaysian court orders ex-PM Najib to pay 1.69b ringgit tax bill
summary: A Malaysian court ordered former Prime Minister Najib Razak to pay 1.69 billion ringgit (S$549.7 million) in unpaid taxes over seven years while in office. The ruling, made by High Court judge Ahmad Bache, found Najib not exempt from paying tax. Najib, who faces multiple corruption charges linked to 1MDB, has denied all wrongdoing. The tax bill includes penalties and interest accumulated between 2011 and 2017. A separate corruption trial against Najib is set to begin on July 28.

site_title: First Reit Q2 DPU plunges 79.5% to 0.44 Singapore cent amid Covid-19 challenges
summary: First Reit's Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) plummeted 79.5% to 0.44 Singapore cents due to Covid-19 challenges, down from 2.15 cents last year. Income available for distribution fell 46% to S$18.4 million, while rental income decreased 33%. The Reit's gearing remained stable at 34.9%, and interest cover stood at 3.3 times. The company expects year-on-year declines of 40-50% in DPU and income, with potential further relief measures in the second half.

site_title: Nasdaq quarterly profit soars on record trading volumes
summary: Nasdaq reported a 38.5% increase in quarterly profit to US$241 million, driven by record trading volumes amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Trading in technology stocks soared as more people bought these stocks while under lockdown, and commission-free trading also boosted volumes. Revenue rose 22% to US$276 million, and the company narrowed its adjusted operating expense forecast for 2020 to between US$1.33 billion and US$1.36 billion.

site_title: Yuan slumps after China threatens retaliation over consulate closure in US
summary: China's yuan slumped after Beijing threatened to retaliate against the US order to close the Chinese consulate in Houston. The US foreign ministry's decision was described as an "unprecedented escalation" by China's foreign ministry spokesperson. The yuan breached its highest levels in over four months, falling past the seven-per-US-dollar level, as investors reacted to the potential escalation of tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Three-in-one sourcing trade show goes online
summary: A three-in-one mega sourcing virtual trade show, featuring the Singapore Gifts & Premiums Fair, Office Expo Asia, and PrintPack+Sign, will be held online from October 28 to 30. The event aims to connect local and international exhibitors and attendees through live chats, video calls, and webinars, overcoming physical sourcing event limitations due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Registration for exhibitors and visitors is now open at the respective event websites.

site_title: Banks scramble to cut derivatives losses on eve of market reset
summary: Banks worldwide are scrambling to limit derivatives losses ahead of a market reset, as European interest-rate derivatives markets transition to a new benchmark, the euro short-term rate (ESTR), starting next week. The change will trigger sudden price shifts, affecting hundreds of billions of euros of swaption contracts. While a European Central Bank-backed committee has proposed a framework for reimbursement, the market is largely left to iron out its own deals. US financial firms are watching for clues ahead of a similar transition planned for October.

site_title: COE prices mostly fall except for marginal rise in open category
summary: COE prices in Singapore mostly fell in the latest tender, with the exception of the open category, which rose 0.03%. Cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closed at S$32,699, 2.45% lower than the previous close, while commercial vehicles dipped 2.51% to S$23,888. Motorcycles saw the largest drop, 15.48% to S$6,510. The price drop is attributed to pent-up demand being partially cooled by increased COE supply.

site_title: Malaysia judge drops Rohingya caning after outcry
summary: A Malaysian judge has overturned a decision to cane 27 Rohingya refugees for entering the country illegally, calling the sentence "inhumane." The men were jailed and sentenced to three strokes of the cane each for arriving by boat in April, but the High Court judge threw out the sentence following an appeal. The refugees, who are fleeing persecution in Myanmar, will be allowed to stay in Malaysia after serving their seven-month jail sentences. Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch had called for the punishment to be dropped.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit posts Q2 DPU of 1.56 US cents
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit reported a 4% increase in Q2 DPU to 1.56 US cents, driven by positive rental reversion from lease renewals and income from new leases. The Reit's semi-annual distribution will be paid on September 24. For the half year ended June 30, DPU rose 3.3% to 3.10 US cents, with distributable income increasing 18.5% to US$14.7 million. The Reit attributed its better performance to higher rental income from new leases and positive rental reversion, despite a slowdown in property tours due to the pandemic.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI upgrades UMS to 'neutral' on likely outperformance
summary: KGI Securities upgraded UMS Holdings to 'neutral' from 'underperform', increasing its FY20 sales estimate to S$148 million and raising its price-to-earnings peg to 12 times, leading to a higher target price of S$0.89. The upgrade follows an "imminent" upswing in growth for UMS's key customer Applied Materials, which has seen its second-highest backlog for its semi systems segment. Analyst Kenny Tan believes UMS will produce quarter-on-quarter outperformance, driven by returned production capacity and a lack of demand fall-off in the semiconductor capital industry.

site_title: Indian tea prices jump to record as floods, Covid-19 slash output
summary: Indian tea prices have reached a record high due to floods and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on tea production in the northeastern state of Assam, which accounts for over half of India's production. Output was already reduced by labor movement restrictions to contain the virus. The price rise could support the struggling Indian tea industry but may limit exports and boost shipments from rival countries such as Kenya and Sri Lanka.

images.alt_text: Tea prices in the world's second-biggest producer India have jumped to a record after intense floods and coronavirus movement restrictions trimmed output in the main producing region.

site_title: Japan's travel ban has hit 85% of European businesses there
summary: Japan's strict travel ban, restricting entry from 129 countries, has hit 85% of European businesses, with 44% reporting financial losses, according to a survey by the European Business Council. The ban, which also affects permanent residents unless granted humanitarian exceptions, runs counter to international treaties and may trigger investment disputes. Japan's economy has already been impacted, entering its first recession in 4.5 years, and the travel ban is expected to prompt CEOs to rethink their policies regarding Japan. Immigration officials are considering ways to ease the ban but prioritize contagion controls.

images.alt_text: Japan's travel ban to stop the spread of the coronavirus has hit a majority of European firms in the country and could prompt those businesses to rethink their future in the world's third-largest economy, a European business lobby said on Wednesday.

site_title: Sembcorp, SMM proposal to bring 'tangible' benefits; public shareholders get deciding say
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) and Sembcorp Marine (SMM) have proposed a $2.1 billion recapitalization for SMM, which will be met by a rights issue and a demerger, resulting in Temasek Holdings holding a stake in the marine arm. The proposal aims to strengthen both companies' financial positions and is in the best interest of shareholders. SMM's independent shareholders will have the deciding say in the matter, and the proposal is expected to improve the company's cash position and balance sheet. The transaction is seen as a way forward for SMM to fund ongoing commitments, compete for new projects, and ensure long-term viability.

site_title: US-Vietnam JV plans to invest up to US$6b in LNG power project
summary: A US-Vietnamese joint venture, Chan May LNG, plans to invest up to $6 billion in a liquefied natural gas (LNG) power project in Vietnam. The project, scheduled to begin construction in 2021, will include a 4-gigawatt power plant and LNG terminal. The project aims to address Vietnam's rising electricity demand and help narrow the trade deficit between the US and Vietnam. The US government has shown support for the project, with US LNG suppliers involved. Construction is expected to be completed by 2027.

site_title: CAAS, EASA to coordinate health safety measures for air travel between Singapore, Europe
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) have signed a memorandum of cooperation to validate and harmonize aviation health safety measures for air travel between Singapore and Europe. The agreement aims to protect the health and safety of passengers, air crew, and airport staff, and strengthen traveller confidence. Singapore Airlines and the Changi Airport Group will participate in EASA's Aviation Industry Charter, implementing operational guidelines to minimize Covid-19 transmission risks. This collaboration may support the recovery of air travel between Singapore and Europe.

site_title: Australian regulator won't appeal court ruling in Westpac home lending case
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, will not appeal a court ruling dismissing its lawsuit against Westpac Banking Corp over allegations of failing to meet responsible lending obligations in mortgage approvals. The Federal Court found Westpac had used an automated system rather than manually checking each applicant's living expenses. The decision was made in challenging economic circumstances, and consumer rights groups expressed disappointment over the decision not to appeal.

site_title: Europe: Defensives drag down shares from 4-month highs
summary: European shares slipped 0.3% on Wednesday, easing from four-month highs, due to a surge in coronavirus cases and earnings reports. Defensive sectors, including healthcare, utilities, and consumer companies, led the decline. Despite a 750 billion euro coronavirus recovery fund deal reached by the EU, investors turned cautious. Swiss firm ABB rose 2.4% after improving order situations, while French Valeo fell 5% after posting a significant loss. Investors remain optimistic about US stimulus and EU-US trade talks.

site_title: Temasek's STT GDC prices S$400m bonds at 3.13% on strong investor interest
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) priced S$400 million worth of senior unsecured bonds at 3.13% coupon, maturing on July 28, 2028. The deal saw over S$3 billion in books from 120 accounts, with 54% of orders from fund managers and sovereign wealth funds. Strong investor interest was evident, with 35% coming from private banks and the rest from banks and corporates.

images.alt_text: STT GDC's MediaHub data centre in the One-North business park. STT GDC will use the bond issuance proceeds for general corporate purposes.

site_title: Three conservation shophouses in Chinatown up for sale at S$30.5m total guide price
summary: A portfolio of three shophouses in Singapore's Chinatown is up for sale at a total guide price of S$30.5 million. The properties, zoned "Commercial" under Master Plan 2019, can be bought individually or as a portfolio. The sale is open to locals and foreigners, with no additional buyer's stamp duty and seller's stamp duty imposed. Knight Frank Singapore has been appointed to offer the portfolio for sale.

site_title: Japan's crowdfunding firms report surge in business during pandemic
summary: Japanese crowdfunding firms saw a surge in business during the pandemic, with revenue rising 61% and funds raised increasing by six times compared to the same period last year. Companies such as Makuake and Readyfor reported significant growth, with funds raised through crowdfunding reaching 4 billion yen and 28.4 million yen, respectively. Experts predict that crowdfunding will become increasingly popular as people continue to struggle financially, but warn that the boom could slow if supporters' income dwindles due to ongoing pandemic disruptions.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end flat as virus fears offset optimism of EU deal, US stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares ended flat on Wednesday, despite optimism around the European Union's 750 billion euro stimulus plan and US stimulus talks. US President Donald Trump's comments on the coronavirus crisis escalated worries, offsetting the positive sentiment. The benchmark Kospi fell 0.17 point, while the won rose and the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners were net sellers of 103 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Ping An-backed Lufax seeks US IPO as early as this year: sources
summary: Lufax, a Chinese online wealth management platform backed by Ping An Insurance Group, is seeking a US initial public offering (IPO) as early as this year, according to sources. The company, valued at $38 billion in 2018, has enlisted major banks to work on the offering, which has not yet decided on the amount to raise or valuation. This would be one of the largest IPOs by a Chinese fintech company in the US, following OneConnect Financial Technology, also backed by Ping An.

site_title: Singapore launches S$45m marketing blitz to boost domestic tourism
summary: Singapore launches a S$45 million marketing campaign, "SingapoRediscovers," to boost domestic tourism and drive recovery in its hard-hit tourism sector. The nine-month campaign targets locals for "mini-holidays" in districts like Chinatown and Orchard Road, with promotions for attractions, tours, and hotel stays. The move comes as the country seeks to divert S$34 billion spent on overseas travel into local tourism and lifestyle businesses, following a 39% year-on-year decline in tourism receipts in the first quarter of 2020.

site_title: Taiwan parliament passes proposal to rebrand China Airlines
summary: Taiwan's parliament approved a proposal to rebrand China Airlines, the island's largest airline, to avoid confusion with Air China on the Chinese mainland. The move comes amid the COVID-19 pandemic, where China Airlines aircraft were used to send medical aid overseas, sparking confusion. Lawmakers want the transport ministry to develop short- and long-term rebranding plans for the carrier, which is partly government-owned, to make it more identifiable internationally with Taiwanese images. The proposal does not set a timeline for the airline's eventual renaming, which has sparked concerns from critics that it may provoke China.

site_title: Japan's MUFG installs robots to scan millions of 'hanko' documents
summary: Japan's Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) is installing giant robot scanners to digitize 300 million pages of "hanko" documents, a type of personal seal used to verify identities. The machines, provided by US startup Ripcord, can extract staples and scan files much faster than human workers, reducing the time from 510 years to five days. The move aims to break Japan's paper-heavy culture and improve efficiency, particularly in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. This initiative is part of MUFG's efforts to digitize its customers' identities and move away from traditional paper records.

site_title: Naiise to shutter Paya Lebar store this weekend
summary: Naiise to close its Paya Lebar store this weekend due to lease expiry, leaving the retailer with one store at Jewel Changi Airport and an office in Kuala Lumpur. The company has taken cost-cutting measures, including halving its headcount, and has no plans to open new physical stores. Naiise will focus on building its online store presence, following a series of payment delays with vendors that led to some brands removing their products from its shelves.

images.alt_text: With the closure at Paya Lebar Quarter (pictured), the retailer is left with one store at Jewel Changi Airport as well as an office and retail shop in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Indonesia investment chief questions Asean pact as FDI falls
summary: Indonesia's investment chief questioned the benefits of being part of the Asean Economic Community after data showed a 6.9% drop in foreign direct investment (FDI) in the April-June period. FDI fell to 97.6 trillion rupiah (S$9.29 billion), down 6.9% from the previous year and 3% from dollar terms. The decline follows a 9.2% fall in FDI in the first quarter due to the pandemic. The investment chief suggested reconsidering the benefits of being part of Asean.

site_title: Thailand to extend emergency decree until end of August: official
summary: Thailand's state of emergency is set to be extended until the end of August, following nearly two months without local COVID-19 transmission. The decision comes as the country prepares to reopen for business meetings and tourism. Secretary-General Somsak Roongsita stated that the emergency decree is necessary to contain virus outbreaks, but not for rallies or gatherings. The extension maintains the measure despite protests against the government over the weekend.

site_title: Resurgent 'techlash' overshadows Silicon Valley earnings
summary: Big Tech companies, such as Silicon Valley giants, are expected to report quarterly earnings overshadowed by antitrust probes, growing activist and politician complaints, and concerns over privacy, data protection, and liability. Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, these companies have played a lifeline to consumers, but their dominant role in the economy is under scrutiny. The results may be impacted by policy discussions and regulatory pressures, highlighting the need for greater transparency and accountability from these tech giants.

site_title: Thai rice exporters cut 2020 forecast to lowest in 20 years
summary: Thai rice exporters have cut their 2020 forecast to 6.5 million tonnes, the lowest in 20 years, due to drought and a strong baht currency. The industry group attributed the decline to a five million tonne reduction in production and higher prices, making Thai rice uncompetitive. The revised forecast is lower than the previous expectation of a seven-year low of 7.5 million tonnes.

site_title: Changi Village Hawker Centre among new places visited by infectious Covid-19 patients; 3 new dorm clusters
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has added three new places to its list of locations visited by infectious Covid-19 patients while they were still contagious, including Changi Village Hawker Centre, a Kopitiam outlet at Pasir Ris West Plaza, and G7 Sinma Live Seafood Restaurant in Geylang. Three new dormitory clusters have also been identified, with six other worker dorms cleared of the virus and now housing only recovered individuals. There were 310 new coronavirus cases confirmed, including seven community cases and six imported cases, bringing Singapore's total to 48,744.

site_title: South Korea scales back capital gains tax on stocks
summary: South Korea has scaled back plans to impose a capital gains tax on stock investments, following complaints from retail investors. The revised tax will apply to those with annual capital gains exceeding 50 million won, rather than the previously proposed 20 million won. The government will also hike taxes for top earners, with income tax rates increasing to 45% for earnings above 1 billion won. The changes aim to support retail investors and build financial wealth in a low-interest rate environment.

site_title: Armani, YNAP sign deal to integrate online and store networks
summary: Giorgio Armani has signed a 20-year deal with Yoox Net-a-Porter (YNAP) to integrate its online and store networks. The partnership, called "Next Era," aims to offer Armani customers access to all products across online and offline channels, with full integration expected by 2022. Armani's main online store, Armani.com, is already managed by YNAP, which is owned by Richemont.

images.alt_text: Italian fashion house Giorgio Armani has struck a deal with online retailer Yoox Net-a-Porter (YNAP) to better integrate the luxury group's e-commerce site with its network of physical stores.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as record virus cases dent investor sentiment
summary: Australian shares fell 1.3% on Wednesday, dragged down by the healthcare sector due to record Covid-19 cases. The country recorded 501 new infections, with Victoria state accounting for nearly 97% of the cases. Healthcare stocks fell 3.2%, while technology stocks dropped 2.4%. BHP Group's shares were downgraded to "neutral" by Citi due to Covid-19 concerns, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Credit Suisse set to score a smaller role on Ant's mega IPO
summary: Credit Suisse is likely to play a smaller role as a joint global coordinator for Ant Group's Hong Kong IPO, which could raise around $10 billion. The bank had previously advised Ant's Alibaba parent on a $33 billion deal but not on its latest fundraising round, giving other banks priority. Ant has selected four sponsors, including China International Capital, Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase & Co, and Morgan Stanley, and is still finalizing its bank lineup. This marks a break from history, as Credit Suisse was once a top underwriter for Alibaba's record-breaking IPO in 2014.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks flat as pandemic worries eclipse EU recovery deal
summary: South Korean stocks remained flat on Wednesday as concerns over the pandemic outweighed the positive impact of the EU's 750 billion euro stimulus plan and US stimulus talks. The benchmark Kospi index rose 0.1% to 2,231.09, while the Korean won strengthened against the US dollar. The EU deal and US stimulus talks were overshadowed by US President Donald Trump's warning about the worsening pandemic. Foreigners were net sellers of 77.4 billion won worth of shares, and the MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index rose 0.04%.

site_title: Waymo, Fiat Chrysler expand autonomous vehicle partnership
summary: Waymo and Fiat Chrysler are expanding their autonomous vehicle partnership to commercial vehicles, with Fiat Chrysler developing fully self-driving vehicles exclusively with Waymo. The companies will integrate Waymo's self-driving technology into Ram ProMaster vans for goods delivery, starting with the Ram ProMaster vans. The partnership aims to commercialize autonomous vehicles, shifting focus from passenger vehicles to delivery and commercial uses. Fiat Chrysler will end its work on autonomous commercial vehicles with startup Aurora, and Waymo will collaborate on "level 4" autonomous driving with Fiat Chrysler.

images.alt_text: Self-driving car company Waymo and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles are expanding their autonomous vehicle partnership to commercial vehicles, and Fiat Chrysler will develop fully self-driving vehicles exclusively with Waymo going forward, the companies said on Wednesday.

site_title: Asia: Equities fluctuate after vaccine rally, eyes on Capitol Hill
summary: Asian equities fluctuated on Wednesday, following a strong rally the previous day, amid concerns over the slow progress of US lawmakers in drafting a new stimulus package. The European Union's $860 billion deal was seen as a positive step, but optimism over a possible vaccine was tempered by profit-taking and worries about the US economy. Despite this, stocks remained largely positive, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul rising, while Tokyo and Sydney fell. Experts warn that the rally may be nearing an end, citing concerns over the next catalyst for market growth.

site_title: Singapore banks' upcoming dividends may be cut amid capital review: analyst
summary: Singapore banks may cut upcoming dividends amid capital review amid prolonged economic uncertainty. Analysts expect banks to shore up capital and potentially reduce payouts, with DBS and OCBC's dividend payout ratios potentially exceeding 65-70%. UOB's dividend payout ratio may be lower due to reduced earnings, with a possibility of a cut. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is reviewing banks' capital plans, and a dividend cut could be a precautionary measure to address potential earnings decline and lower net interest margins.

site_title: Australia posts record number of new Covid-19 infections
summary: Australia reported a record 501 new COVID-19 infections on July 22, nearly four months after the pandemic peaked in the country. Most cases were in Victoria state, where authorities are struggling to contain an outbreak. The country has now recorded almost 13,000 cases and 128 fatalities. Melbourne residents will be required to wear masks outside from midnight, and further behavior change is expected. The outbreak has dampened hopes of a speedy economic recovery and has raised concerns about infection control breaches.

site_title: Insect tech startup Protenga snags US$1.6m from Roslin Technologies, SEEDS Capital
summary: Singapore-based insect technology startup Protenga has raised US$1.6 million in seed funding from Roslin Technologies and SEEDS Capital. The investment will support the development of circular food system innovations using insect protein for livestock, aquaculture, and pet food markets. Protenga plans to ramp up production, conduct genetic research, and expand its Smart Insect Farm model. The funding also enables the startup to hire for key roles and build a new genetic nucleus facility. The investment builds on existing focus in agrifood technologies and further develops the alternative protein ecosystem in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore government agencies commit S$40m to National Innovation Challenges
summary: Singapore's Enterprise Singapore, Infocomm Media Development Authority, and National Research Foundation have committed S$40 million in funding to National Innovation Challenges, a series of seven initiatives launched to accelerate innovation efforts and address post-Covid-19 challenges. The challenges, announced by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, aim to create cross-industry collaborations to develop solutions for safe reopening and tackle immediate needs. The funding will support enterprises in overcoming challenges and developing innovative solutions.

site_title: MAS fines Asiaciti Trust S$1.1m over money laundering breaches
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has fined Asiaciti Trust S$1.1 million for inadequate safeguards against money laundering and terrorism financing. The trust breached MAS regulations by failing to monitor "politically exposed" customers and failing to establish the source of wealth for an effective controller. The breaches occurred between 2007 and 2018, but the trust has taken remedial measures, including terminating higher-risk accounts and filing suspicious transaction reports. The MAS found that Asiaciti Trust's measures against money laundering and terrorism financing were not subject to independent audits.

site_title: Tesla hiring servicing staff in 'unsupportive' Singapore
summary: Tesla has advertised for servicing staff in Singapore, a country previously criticized by Elon Musk for its lack of support for electric vehicles. The listings are for servicing and repair positions, with no clear location specified. This move comes despite Musk's previous comments on Singapore's unsupportive stance on electric vehicles. Tesla aims to phase out petrol and diesel vehicles by 2040, a goal that may be hindered by the country's limited electric vehicle adoption. The company's decision to enter the market through its own showrooms also poses challenges for traditional dealerships.

site_title: Australia: Shares retreat on Trump's virus comment
summary: Australian shares declined 0.9% to 6,100.7, their best session in over a month, after US President Donald Trump's comments on a surge in coronavirus cases. Tech stocks fell 2.8%, with Afterpay and BHP Group among the top losers. In contrast, gold prices rose to a record high, and Resolute Mining jumped 6% after meeting its full-year guidance.

site_title: Chinese football gets go-ahead after 2,000 negative virus tests
summary: China's Chinese Super League (CSL) is set to begin on Saturday after all 1,870 players and coaching staff registered negative for coronavirus as part of a testing program. The league, delayed and revamped due to the pandemic, will conduct weekly tests during the season. This move comes after a successful initial testing phase, which aimed to create a "bubble" environment to prevent infections.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on pre-holiday profit taking
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.58% on Wednesday, closing at 22,751.61, ahead of a four-day holiday weekend in Japan. The Nikkei 225 index lost 132.61 points, while the Topix index dropped 9.78 points. Investors took profits, likely due to the upcoming holiday weekend.

site_title: Wellness company Crigen debuts on 1exchange, eyes public listing in Australia
summary: Malaysia-based wellness company Crigen Resources has listed 28% of its shares on 1exchange (1X), Singapore's regulated private securities exchange, with a total value of S$2 million. The listing marks a key step towards Crigen's goal of a public listing in Australia. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, Crigen's Danai Spa has remained resilient, with sales returning to 70% of pre-lockdown levels. The company expects a compound annual growth rate of 28.6% in revenue and 56.8% in net profit from 2019 to 2022.

site_title: Rich Russians fuel private jet demand to skirt virus lockdown
summary: Rich Russians are using private jets to bypass coronavirus lockdowns and travel internationally, with flights from Moscow more than doubling between April and mid-June. To avoid restrictions, travelers provide evidence of necessary work trips or health reasons, and some companies offer jet rental services with prices starting at $6,390 for a one-way ticket. With borders closed, some Russians are also opting for medical tourism or traveling to neighboring countries like Belarus or Serbia. The trend is expected to continue even after Russia reopens its borders.

site_title: US accuses Chinese nationals of hacking spree for Covid-19 data, defence secrets
summary: The US Justice Department indicted two Chinese nationals, Li Xiaoyu and Dong Jiazhi, for a decade-long hacking campaign targeting defence contractors, Covid-19 researchers, and hundreds of other victims worldwide. Li and Dong, contractors for China's Ministry of State Security, stole sensitive data including weapons designs, drug information, and personal data. US officials say China has turned a blind eye to prolific hackers operating within its borders, joining a "shameful club" alongside Russia, Iran, and North Korea.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE ups Top Glove target price, sees 'small impact' from US detention order
summary: Maybank Kim Eng maintained its "buy" call on Top Glove, increasing its 12-month target price to RM28.60 from RM21.90, citing a high average selling price (ASP) premium that will dissipate starting in 2Q2021. The company's earnings per share are expected to rise 13% in FY2020 and 103% in FY2021, driven by the ASP premium. However, a US detention order on two of its subsidiaries may have a small impact, with potential re-routing of shipments to other markets at a lower ASP.

images.alt_text: Hikes in the average selling price (ASP) of gloves in the next six months could continue to support Top Glove's share price, said Maybank Kim Eng on Wednesday.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts raise target prices for Keppel DC Reit on acquisitions, AEIs
summary: Analysts at DBS Group Research and CGS-CIMB have raised their target prices for Keppel DC Reit to S$2.80 and S$2.88, respectively, citing expected acquisitions and asset enhancement initiatives. The analysts maintain their "hold" calls, citing the Reit's high unit price and low weighted average cost of capital. Keppel DC Reit posted a 13.6% increase in DPU for the half year ended June 30, driven by the acquisition of data centers in Q4 2019 and Q2 2020. The Reit is evaluating a range of deals, including new and existing countries, with cap rates between 4-7%.

site_title: Sime Darby ramps up palm replanting with new high-yielding seedlings
summary: Sime Darby Plantation, the world's largest producer of sustainable palm oil, has launched a new high-yielding seedling that is 20% more productive than its previous best planting material. The "GenomeSelect" seeds will be used for replanting unproductive trees, with the company aiming to scale up production to meet all replanting needs within the next three years. This move is expected to increase palm oil output and support the company's sustainability goals.

images.alt_text: Sime Darby Plantation, the world's largest producer of sustainable palm oil, rolled out the replanting of unproductive trees with its new higher-yielding seedling which it says is 20 per cent more productive.

site_title: Australia mortgage defaults due to income loss, negative equity
