summary: Australian mortgage defaults are primarily driven by income loss and negative equity, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia. The unemployment rate and net income are key variables in evaluating financial stability risks. Housing prices play a significant role in foreclosures when borrowers have negative equity. The government has extended its wage subsidy program and granted more time for hard-pressed borrowers to repay loans, but the jobless rate remains high at 7.4%. The RBA warns that prolonged negative equity may increase foreclosures, highlighting the need for balanced policies to reduce the risk.

site_title: Marriott sees Greater China occupancy rates recovering by early 2021
summary: Marriott International forecasts room occupancy rates in Greater China to reach 60% by early 2021, with an average occupancy rate of 37% in July. The company expects the pace of recovery to be "encouraging," with Asia leading the global industry recovery. This recovery is driven by increasing domestic travel in China. The forecast suggests Marriott's Greater China business is on track to return to pre-coronavirus levels by the start of 2021.

site_title: Google women seek class-action status for gender-pay lawsuit
summary: Four former Google employees are seeking class-action status for a gender-pay lawsuit against the company, alleging women received approximately $16,794 less per year than similarly-situated men. The lawsuit claims Google violated California's Equal Pay Act and Unfair Competition Law from 2011 to 2017. If granted class status, the case could seek over $600 million in damages, with a class certification hearing set for December 2.

images.alt_text: Four female former employees of Alphabet Inc's Google are trying to persuade a state court to let them represent more than 10,000 peers in a gender-pay disparity suit against the company, setting the stage for the next big battle over class-action status.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate's privatisation offer turns unconditional
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has accepted an unconditional offer to be taken private by a consortium led by Primero Investment Holdings. The offer, initially set for Aug 3, has been extended to Aug 17, with a cash price of S$0.95 per share. The consortium, comprising Perennial's CEO and chairman, aims to delist the company and raise funds more easily, operate efficiently, and focus on strategic pursuits such as developing integrated projects near transportation hubs.

site_title: Lockheed's new CEO rules out commercial aerospace in deal hunt
summary: Lockheed Martin's new CEO, Jim Taiclet, has ruled out searching for deals in the commercial aerospace industry due to its collapse. Taiclet stated that the company will focus on the defense sector, calling it the "field we're playing on." However, he mentioned that the company may explore expanding into adjacent areas, such as artificial intelligence, to strengthen its defense capabilities. Lockheed's earnings estimates exceeded Wall Street expectations, and the company raised its 2020 financial forecasts.

site_title: New framework for Singapore business events to resume safely; STB to trial hybrid events
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has developed a risk management framework for business events with up to 50 attendees, allowing for the safe resumption of business-to-business events in Singapore. The framework, to be trialed with two hybrid events, includes infection control measures, crowd density limits, and emergency preparedness. Event organizers and venues must demonstrate readiness to implement these measures. The resumption of B2B events is subject to prior approval from the Ministry of Trade and Industry, and non-compliance may result in enforcement action and loss of government assistance.

site_title: Moderna, Merck will not limit price of virus vaccines to company cost
summary: US vaccine manufacturers Moderna and Merck will not limit the price of their coronavirus vaccines to the cost of production, despite concerns they may not be accessible to all. Moderna's chief patient officer and a representative from Merck declined to comment on their pricing plans during a Congressional hearing. In contrast, Pfizer and AstraZeneca have stated they will price their vaccines at no profit or at a reduced cost during the pandemic. The hearing focused on developing safe and effective vaccines for COVID-19, which has claimed 600,000 lives globally.

images.alt_text: Moderna and Merck & Co on Tuesday told a US Congressional panel that they expect to profit from their coronavirus vaccines once approved, amid concerns the vaccines may not be accessible to all.

site_title: New Lockheed CEO says 5G networks key to military vehicle autonomy
summary: Lockheed Martin CEO James Taiclet emphasizes the importance of 5G networks in enhancing military vehicle autonomy. In his first interview as CEO, he stated that the military application of 5G is simpler than the commercial application. Lockheed Martin recently raised its full-year profit and revenue forecasts, overcoming coronavirus-driven supply disruptions. The company's focus on 5G networks aims to improve autonomous capabilities, with Taiclet noting that the technology could play a significant role in bolstering military capabilities.

site_title: New Zealand's Ardern sacks minister over office affair
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern dismissed Immigration Minister Iain Lees-Galloway due to an office affair with a former colleague who worked under him. The affair involved workplace relations, making Lees-Galloway's position untenable. This move comes ahead of a general election in September, as scrutiny on lawmakers' behavior increases. Ardern cited Lees-Galloway's role as minister for workplace relations as the reason for his dismissal.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following a 2.1% rally the previous day. The Hang Seng Index decreased 0.24% to 25,575.25, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.17% to 3,315.18. The Shenzhen Composite Index also slipped 0.19%. The decline was attributed to profit-takers moving in.

site_title: Silver jumps to 2013 high, gold nears record on virus concerns
summary: Silver jumped to its 2013 high, trading at US$22.5821 an ounce, amid concerns over the coronavirus pandemic and slowing global economic growth. Gold also rose, nearing its record high of US$1,921.17 an ounce, as investors seek safe-haven assets and stimulus. Supply concerns and bets on industrial demand are also contributing to the metals' surge. Analysts expect silver to remain strong, with some investors potentially switching to silver from gold.

site_title: Australian June retail sales rise 2.4% m-o-m, extend strong rebound
summary: Australian retail sales rose 2.4% in June, exceeding expectations, as the economy continued to recover from coronavirus lockdowns. The total retail sales reached A$29.7 billion, a 8.2% increase from the same month last year. Increases were seen in cafes, restaurants, takeaway food services, and clothing retailing. The rebound was partly driven by stockpiling of goods and a new outbreak of the virus in Victoria, which led to a Melbourne lockdown. This marks a strong rebound after a record 16.9% surge in May.

site_title: Tapestry CEO resigns amid internal investigation at Coach owner: source
summary: Tapestry CEO Jide Zeitlin resigned amid an internal investigation into allegations of posing as a photographer to lure a woman into a romantic relationship over a decade ago. The company's board hired a law firm to investigate the claims, which were made by a woman who had a relationship with Zeitlin. Zeitlin had agreed to lead the fashion house for three years but stepped down for personal reasons, citing a desire not to create a distraction. The company has named an interim CEO and CFO, and will consider internal and external candidates for a permanent CEO position.

site_title: WeWork said to lose major tenant in Japan as Rakuten exits
summary: WeWork is set to lose a major tenant in Japan as Rakuten exits its contract in August, leaving about 700 desks empty in Tokyo. The move is a significant blow to the co-working giant, which has seen occupancy plummet to 60% in Japan, down from 90% in late last year. WeWork's dense office layouts and short leases make it vulnerable to budget cutbacks, while the shift to remote work has reduced demand. The loss of Rakuten, a key client, further exacerbates the situation, highlighting WeWork's struggles in Japan despite its profitable operations at the time of its initial public offering attempt.

site_title: Delayed and downsized, but will Tokyo Olympics be greener?
summary: The Tokyo 2020 Olympics, delayed due to the pandemic, will be smaller and simpler, but sustainability remains a core concept. Despite initiatives like recycled metal medals and hydrogen flames, environmental activists and experts criticize the organisers for setting unambitious targets and loopholes in procurement policies for fishery products, timber, and palm oil. The delay did not allow for significant changes, and industry associations may have influenced the lack of robust policies, leading to a perceived lack of progress in sustainability.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.4% to 2,617.86 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 64 to 59, with 80.8 million securities worth S$65.8 million changing hands. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Twitter will suspend accounts tweeting about conspiracy theory group QAnon
summary: Twitter will permanently suspend approximately 150,000 accounts globally that promote QAnon, a fringe group claiming "deep-state" traitors are plotting against President Donald Trump. The suspensions will also block QAnon-related URLs from trending and recommendations. This move comes after the FBI designated QAnon as a potential domestic extremist threat and more than 7,000 accounts have been removed for violating Twitter's rules against spam, manipulation, and ban evasion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 1.76 points or 0.11% to 1,594.17. Trading volume reached 627.68 million lots worth RM239.66 million. Gainers beat losers 250 to 136.

site_title: Dam collapse in China could point to a 'black swan' disaster
summary: A dam collapse in China's Guangxi region has raised concerns about the country's aging dam infrastructure, which may be vulnerable to extreme weather events due to climate change. The 1965 dam, built to hold 195,000 cubic meters of water, collapsed after heavy rain, inundating nearby villages and fields. Experts say the incident could be a "black swan" disaster, highlighting the need for more robust dam designs and maintenance. China has been reinforcing and raising old dams, but climate change is bringing new extremes, and flood-risk policies may no longer be sufficient.

site_title: Chief executive of CDL's hotel arm quits after four months
summary: City Developments Limited's (CDL) hotel arm, Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C), has seen its CEO, Clarence Tan, resign after four months in the position. Tan, 52, will step down on August 2, citing a desire to spend more time with his family. He was appointed in April after the British company was delisted from the London Stock Exchange. Under Tan's leadership, M&C implemented cost-cutting measures, including a 30% reduction in staff and executives accepting salary cuts of up to 30%.

site_title: Australian banking regulator flags change to dividend freeze, calls for prudence
summary: Australia's banking regulator, APRA, plans to update its capital return policy, allowing banks to consider dividend payments again. Chairman Wayne Byres said the economy is less uncertain than in April, when banks halted or cut dividend payments worth over A$7 billion. Stress-tests indicate banks are "well-placed" to withstand major headwinds, with capital management practices prioritizing ongoing prudence and flexibility. The updated policy will focus on the longer-term viability of the financial sector, shifting from a short-term emergency response.

site_title: South Korea's Naver shifts data from Hong Kong to Singapore
summary: South Korea's internet giant Naver has shifted its backup servers storing user data from Hong Kong to Singapore, citing a need to better manage and protect data. The move comes as China tightens its grip on Hong Kong with a new national security law, prompting US tech giants to suspend processing government requests for user data. Naver had not received any requests to hand over its data and did not mention the law as a reason for the relocation. The company has deleted all data stored in Hong Kong.

site_title: Nissan offers to postpone Barcelona plant closure, to talk on 'everything'
summary: Nissan is willing to postpone the closure of its Barcelona plant until June 2021, pending a deal with unions, to discuss compensation and production resumption. The three plants, which employ around 3,000 workers, were originally set to close by December this year. Nissan maintains its plan to fire at least 2,500 workers, but will not conduct layoffs until the end of 2020. The talks between the company and union representatives are ongoing, with the industry ministry supporting the potential outcome. A deal would require workers to accept compensation for the closure.

site_title: Scientists report that airborne coronavirus is probably infectious
summary: Scientists at the University of Nebraska have found that airborne coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2, can replicate in lab conditions when taken from microdroplets expelled by patients when they speak and breathe. This study boosts the hypothesis that normal speaking and breathing, not just coughing and sneezing, are responsible for spreading Covid-19, and that infectious doses of the virus can travel distances greater than 2m. The results, considered preliminary, have not yet appeared in a peer-reviewed journal but provide evidence that microdroplets are capable of infecting people, contradicting previous assumptions about the virus's transmission.

site_title: Israel's largest health VC boosts fund to US$750m on virus
summary: Israel's largest health VC firm, AMoon, has boosted its fund to US$750 million, exceeding its initial target of US$660 million, following a surge in demand for healthcare technology during the coronavirus pandemic. The fund, AMoon II, was initially valued at US$660 million last year, with existing and new investors contributing to its growth. The investment came after investors "panicked" at the onset of the pandemic but later returned with increased interest, with co-founder Yair Schindel attributing the change to a "defrosting" of investor confidence.

site_title: Cathay Pacific reaches deal for Airbus delivery delays, in advanced talks with Boeing
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has reached an agreement with Airbus to delay the delivery of A350s and A321neos due to arrive in 2020-2023, rescheduling them for 2020-2023 and 2020-2025, respectively. The airline is also in advanced talks with Boeing to defer its 777-9 orders. This deal is expected to produce cash savings for the Cathay Pacific Group in the short to medium term, according to a prospectus lodged with the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

site_title: Airlines ask EU, White House to adopt Covid-19 testing programme for passengers
summary: Major US and European airlines, including American Airlines, United Airlines, Lufthansa, and International Airlines Group, have asked the EU and White House to adopt a joint Covid-19 testing program for passengers traveling between the US and Europe. The program would allow for the safe and swift restoration of air travel between the two regions, currently restricted due to the pandemic. The airlines believe a pilot testing program could help overcome obstacles and protect health, build confidence, and safely restore passenger travel. US and EU officials previously discussed the idea in June but did not reach an agreement.

site_title: Kanye West's erratic behaviour puts spotlight on bipolar disorder
summary: US rapper Kanye West's recent erratic behavior has raised concerns about his mental health. His rambling speech during his presidential campaign launch revealed incoherent rants, a desire to abort his daughter, and emotional breakdowns. West has previously spoken about his struggles with bipolar disorder, but his actions have sparked questions about his treatment and overall well-being.

site_title: Burger King wins dismissal of vegans' lawsuit over Impossible Whopper
summary: A US federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit against Burger King, accusing the company of deceiving vegan and vegetarian customers about the cooking method of its "Impossible Whopper". The plaintiffs claimed Burger King cooked the plant-based patty on different grills than those used for beef and chicken, but the judge found the claims "too individualised" and that the company's advertising did not promise cooking on a different surface. The judge ruled that Burger King "promised a non-meat patty and delivered".

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare warns of H1 loss
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare expects a net loss for the six months ended June 30, 2020, due to the impact of the global Covid-19 pandemic on its equity-accounted investees, particularly First Real Estate Investment Trust (First Reit). The group's profit warning follows a similar announcement by First Reit's manager, which expects a 40-50% drop in available income and a 50-60% decline in total return after tax. OUE Lippo Healthcare's shares closed 9.5% lower on the news.

site_title: China Sunsine to buy dangerous-waste treatment firm for 43m yuan
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings is set to acquire Heze Yongshun Environmental Protection Technology for 43 million yuan (S$8.5 million). The deal aims to better manage China Sunsine's production process, as it generates hazardous waste materials. Heze Yongshun, which treats 15,000 tonnes of hazardous waste annually, is the only qualified company in the area to meet China Sunsine's demands. The acquisition is expected to promote long-term sustainable growth and reduce costs on waste treatment and disposal.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.34% to 22,805.79, and the Topix index down 0.28%. Investors grew cautious ahead of a four-day Japanese holiday weekend, amid a higher yen.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday with investors growing cautious over a higher yen and ahead of a four-day holiday weekend in Japan.

site_title: US offers US$5m reward for arrest of Venezuela chief justice
summary: The US has offered a $5 million reward for the arrest of Venezuela's chief justice, Maikal Jose Moreno Perez, who faces US money laundering charges. Perez allegedly received bribes to influence civil and criminal cases in over 20 cases, and has been on the US Treasury's sanctions blacklist since 2017. The US has also added Perez and his wife to the State Department's list, making them ineligible for entry into the US indefinitely. This move is part of the US administration's pressure on Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro and his entourage.

images.alt_text: Moreno Perez, who has been on the US Treasury's sanctions blacklist since May 2017, was added to the State Department's separate list on Tuesday, along with his wife, for "involvement in significant corruption."

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust Q2 DPU down 27.7% to 2.11 S cents
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust reported a 27.7% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.11 Singapore cents for its Q2 2020 results, down from 2.92 cents a year ago. Gross revenue fell 39.8% to S$114.1 million and net property income (NPI) almost halved to S$68.1 million. The decline is attributed to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the retail sector.

site_title: US virus crisis to 'get worse before it gets better': Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump warned that the coronavirus crisis in the US is likely to "get worse before it gets better." Trump stated that some areas are doing well, while others are struggling, and urged Americans to wear masks to prevent the spread of the virus. He also emphasized the importance of vaccines, saying they will "disappear" the virus. Trump's comments come as the US has reported over 141,000 deaths from the virus.

site_title: Oil prices up on virus vaccine hopes, EU stimulus deal
summary: Oil prices rose about $1 a barrel, reaching a four-month high, driven by a European Union stimulus deal worth $1.2 trillion and hopeful news on coronavirus vaccine trials. Brent crude futures settled at $44.32 a barrel, and West Texas Intermediate at $41.96 a barrel, despite US crude inventories growing by 7.5 million barrels. The EU deal, allowing for billions of euros to be raised on capital markets, and promising vaccine data also supported oil prices, with world shares and the euro reaching their highest levels in several months.

site_title: LinkedIn cuts 960 jobs as pandemic puts brakes on corporate hiring
summary: LinkedIn is cutting 960 jobs, approximately 6% of its global workforce, due to the sustained impact of the coronavirus pandemic on demand for its recruitment products. The layoffs will be across sales and hiring divisions globally. CEO Ryan Roslansky announced the plan, offering at least 10 weeks of severance pay and health insurance for a year for US employees. Affected staff will be able to keep company-issued equipment to work from home during career transitions. The company will hire for newly-created roles from laid-off staff.

site_title: Wells Fargo appoints CFO as part of leadership shakeup
summary: Wells Fargo appoints Mike Santomassimo as its new CFO, replacing John Shrewsberry who will retire in the fall after more than two decades at the firm. The move is part of a leadership shakeup led by CEO Charles Scharf, who has installed former colleagues in top positions. Santomassimo, who previously served as CFO at Bank of New York Mellon, will receive an annual base salary of $1.75 million and a minimum variable compensation of $9.25 million. The change comes as Wells Fargo gears up to launch a cost-cutting initiative amid ongoing regulatory and operational problems.

site_title: Saudi king chairs cabinet meeting from hospital, in stable condition
summary: Saudi King Salman held a cabinet meeting via video call from a hospital in Riyadh, where he is in stable condition after being admitted with gall bladder inflammation. The 84-year-old monarch, who has ruled Saudi Arabia since 2015, was chairing the meeting without speaking, with his son Mohammed bin Salman in attendance. The king's health was reportedly calm, with no sense of panic, and he received phone calls from leaders of neighboring countries. The meeting was broadcast on Saudi state TV, marking one of the king's first public appearances since March 19.

site_title: Fewer ships lost, but new threats loom
summary: The shipping industry has seen a record low in losses, with 41 ships lost worldwide in 2019, a decline of over 70% from a decade ago. Major marine insurer Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty (AGCS) attributes this trend to the COVID-19 pandemic and reduced crew changes, but warns of potential risks, including rising geopolitical tensions, fire incidents, and emissions rules. The industry is also facing concerns over ro-ro vessel safety and the need for improved design and operating practices to prevent accidents.

site_title: Campus housing owner can survive digital migration, analysts say
summary: Analysts predict American Campus Communities, a real estate investment trust, will continue to attract students to off-campus housing despite pandemic fears and university shifts to online or hybrid classes. Despite 45% of revenue coming from Covid-19 hotspots, pre-leasing data shows 82.6% of properties are pre-leased, and analysts believe the outlook may not be as bad as it seems. Some schools may partner with off-campus housing, benefiting American Campus, which has 86% apartment-style housing allowing for easier sanitation and social distancing.

images.alt_text: American universities face immense pressure to reopen in order to offset the negative financial impact from missed tuition and sports revenue.

site_title: BCA to get new CEO
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore is set to get a new CEO, Kelvin Wong, who will take over from Hugh Lim on November 2. Wong, 49, is currently the executive vice-president of the Economic Development Board, and will serve as CEO (Designate) from July 27 to November 1. Lim, 55, led BCA to strengthen partnerships and build capabilities, championing the transformation of the construction industry through innovation and technology. The leadership change was announced by the Ministry of National Development (MND) and BCA in a joint statement.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX inches towards flying again
summary: The Boeing 737 MAX is moving closer to flying again after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) announced it will accept public comments on a roadmap to recertify the jet. The FAA plans to issue a proposed airworthiness directive seeking comments on design changes and crew procedures to mitigate safety issues following two deadly crashes. The public comment period will be open for 45 days, with additional steps including a final report and review of Boeing's design documentation. The FAA will lift the grounding order only after ensuring the aircraft meets certification standards.

site_title: Euro hits new 4-month high after recovery deal
summary: The euro reached a 4-month high of US$1.1470 after the European Union struck a deal for a massive stimulus plan to revive its coronavirus-hit economies, boosting market sentiment. The single currency rose 0.2% in Asian trading hours, its strongest since March 9. Analysts expect little new momentum for the euro, citing the breakdown between grants and loans, but predict the recovery fund agreement could lead to further gains against the US dollar later this year.

site_title: Sunak kicks off UK spending review with warning of 'tough choices'
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak has kicked off a comprehensive review of government spending, warning of "tough choices" amid a deteriorating fiscal backdrop due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The review aims to reduce economic disparities and boost infrastructure, with budgets expected to grow above inflation. The government has also announced inflation-busting pay rises for hundreds of thousands of public-sector workers, including NHS staff and teachers.

images.alt_text: Mr Sunak also cautioned that departments would have to "reprioritise and deliver savings".

site_title: US airlines worry business travel may never fully recover
summary: US airlines are concerned that business travel, which accounts for up to 70% of industry sales, may never fully recover due to technological advancements that have reduced the need to fly. According to Avitas, a leading aviation consultant, it is likely that business travel will not return to pre-Covid levels. This development is a significant concern for US airlines, which have been heavily impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Temasek's one-year return turns negative, portfolio value dips to S$306b
summary: Temasek Holdings' one-year total shareholder return (TSR) has fallen to -2.3% for the 12 months ended March 31, 2020, marking a decline from the previous fiscal year's TSR of 1.49%. This is the first time Temasek has seen a negative return since 2016, attributed to a sharp market correction earlier in the year. The portfolio value has dipped to S$306 billion.

site_title: US: Strong oil shares boost Dow as Nasdaq retreats from record
summary: US stocks ended the day with a 0.6% gain in the Dow, driven by strong oil shares and a 7.1% jump in Exxon Mobil. Chevron also rose 5.1%. The Nasdaq retreated 0.8% from its record close, with profit-taking cited as a factor. Banking shares also led the market, with JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America gaining more than 2%. Investors remain hopeful for another round of stimulus to cushion the economy's continued COVID-19 downturn.

site_title: Koufu focuses on homeground expansion amid Covid-19 pressures
summary: Koufu Group, a Singaporean food and beverage company, is shifting focus to homeground expansion amid the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Earlier plans for overseas expansion have been put on hold due to travel restrictions. Despite this, the company aims to grow its domestic business, particularly through its "Koufu Eat" mobile app and expansion of coffee shops and food courts in Singapore. Koufu has also acquired Deli Asia and other companies to strengthen its supply chain, and plans to integrate production into its new headquarters building. The company remains committed to reinvesting half of its net profit back into the business.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit over 4-month highs after EU recovery fund sealed
summary: European stocks closed above four-month highs, with the Stoxx 600 index rising 0.3% and euro zone blue-chip stocks gaining 0.5%, following the EU's landmark 750-billion-euro recovery fund deal. The deal, aimed at reviving the bloc's economies, boosted oil stocks and tech major SAP SE, while Spain and Italy saw their main indexes gain 0.2% and 0.5% respectively. The global mood brightened on growing optimism about Covid-19 treatment and vaccine trials, with the healthcare index being the worst performer, down 1%.

images.alt_text: European shares closed above four-month highs on Tuesday, with Germany's blue-chip DAX erasing almost all its losses for the year, after EU leaders agreed on a landmark stimulus package to revive the bloc's economies from a coronavirus-induced slump.

site_title: STI ticks up on fresh hopes of virus vaccine and EU stimulus deal
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, reversing Monday's lackluster performance, driven by hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine and the European Union's 750-billion-euro stimulus deal. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed 13.15 points to 2,629.45. Technology shares led the gains, with promising trial results and a record closing high on the Nasdaq. The top performer was City Developments, gaining 2.2%. The EU stimulus deal and potential vaccine news outweighed concerns about the COVID-19 resurgence and lockdowns.

site_title: Cargo could blunt some of the pain for SIA's Q1 earnings, but recovery remains elusive
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is expected to report a material operating loss of S$770-800 million in its Q1 earnings, marked by a decline in passenger traffic due to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the cargo business is expected to provide some relief, with yields rising by 50% due to a capacity crunch and surge in demand for medical gear. Analysts estimate SIA's cargo earnings could surprise on the upside, but overall, the airline's recovery remains elusive, with travel demand not expected to recover to pre-Covid levels for three to four years.

site_title: Top Glove factory raided, no evidence of forced labour found
summary: Malaysian authorities completed a raid on Top Glove Corporation's factory, finding no evidence of forced labor. The raid, conducted two days before the US Customs barred two Top Glove units due to forced labor issues, revealed the company had flouted movement control orders and provided cramped accommodation for workers. Top Glove maintains it has upheld good labor practices, citing an "A" rating from a global business association and previous third-party audits. The company will engage with US authorities to resolve the issue, which has impacted Malaysia's international credibility and foreign investor confidence.

site_title: Real estate fund outperforms with absolute return mandate
summary: A Singapore-based real estate fund, Straits Global Property Strategy (SGP), has outperformed the global real estate index despite its relatively short track record. The fund, managed by Straits Investment Management, has assets under management of S$100 million and aims for "steady risk-adjusted returns" over the long term. Its absolute return mandate allows it to invest in listed real estate securities without conforming to any index, and it has found a receptive audience among high net worth investors. The fund charges an annual management fee of 1.25% and a performance fee of 5%.

site_title: China plans quarterly look into banks' green finance performance
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), plans to review banks' green finance performance quarterly starting next year. The review will assess metrics such as green finance share and risk exposure, with external evaluation accounting for 20% of the weighting. The proposal aims to promote sustainable finance and reward or punish banks accordingly. China has been actively promoting green finance, being the world's largest green bond seller and largest investor in renewable energy, with over $750 billion invested in clean energy projects.

site_title: Safeguard workers' employability with a skills-based approach
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted the workforce, displacing jobs and increasing unemployment risks. To mitigate these risks, a skills-based approach can facilitate re-deployment from "at-risk" to "opportunistic" sectors. A report by EY identified transferable skills across sectors, enabling a re-imagination of the talent pool and individual workers' employability. Employers and individuals must adopt a mindset of change-readiness, agility, and lifelong learning to grow skills-based employability, with digital skills being a key area of focus. The government plays a crucial role in enabling and supporting a workforce landscape that values skills.

site_title: Want more diversity? Reward CEOs for it, say some experts
summary: Some corporate executives are being incentivized to prioritize diversity and inclusion by tying their bonuses to achieving diversity goals. This approach is rare in corporate America, with only 78 of 3,000 companies reporting a connection between pay and diversity goals. Companies like FirstEnergy, Microsoft, and Uber have implemented this practice, with varying degrees of success. Experts say it's a step in the right direction, but more needs to be done to hold executives accountable for promoting diversity and inclusion in the workplace.

site_title: MIT's DPU down 7.4% for Q1; S$7.1m withheld due to virus worries
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 7.4% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for the first quarter, to 2.87 cents, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company withheld S$7.1 million in tax-exempt income to mitigate the impact of mandated rental reliefs. Despite this, distributable income rose 11.6% to S$70.6 million. The company raised S$410 million through a private placement to fund the proposed acquisition of US data centres. As of June 30, MIT's aggregate leverage ratio stood at 38.8%.

site_title: California restaurant accused of turning away patrons wearing masks
summary: A California restaurant, Apple Bistro in Placerville, has received a warning from local officials after numerous complaints from customers about staff not wearing masks and patrons being discouraged from wearing face coverings to protect against Covid-19. The restaurant's sign explicitly states that masks are not required, despite California Governor Gavin Newsom's recent order to wear masks in public settings. Customers have taken to Yelp and Twitter to criticize the establishment and call for a boycott, while others have expressed no issue with the restaurant's stance on health guidelines.

images.alt_text: A restaurant in northern California is in hot water following reports that its staff failed to wear masks and patrons were discouraged from using face coverings to protect against the coronavirus.

site_title: Eight ways Asean consumer habits will change by 2030
summary: Asean's consumer market is poised for significant growth by 2030, with the region set to become the world's fourth-largest economy and boasting a US$4 trillion consumer market. Despite the current economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, long-term fundamentals are expected to drive socio-economic progress. The Asean region is expected to evolve differently, but will offer opportunities for growth, with a majority of CEOs predicting economic recovery by mid-2021.

site_title: Today's world calls for pragmatism, not tribal politics
summary: The US is experiencing a partisan divide over face masks, highlighting the impact of tribal politics on policymaking. As the coronavirus worsens, communities are torn over mask mandates, leading to a widening national divide that could have deadly consequences. Historically, pragmatism was seen as the US's philosophical approach to problem-solving, but tribal politics is now impeding sensible policymaking. Former leaders Franklin D. Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan applied an empiricist approach, recognizing when to change direction to address economic challenges. Today, leaders like Boris Johnson and Joe Biden are adopting pragmatic stances, recognizing the need to reassess policies to address the pandemic.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit posts 13.6% rise in H1 DPU
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 13.6% rise in half-yearly distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.375 Singapore cents, driven by acquisitions and a private placement. Distributable income increased 38% to S$75 million, while net property income rose 32.1% to S$114.2 million. The Reit's assets under management (AUM) grew to S$2.8 billion, with 70% in the Asia-Pacific region. The manager expects robust prospects for the data centre market, driven by digital trends, and has resumed asset-enhancements works at Keppel DC Dublin 1.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel DC Reit, Top Glove, CapitaLand Mall Trust, MIT, OCBC
summary:
Key developments in Singapore's stock market include:

- Keppel DC Reit's DPU rose 13.6% to 4.375 Singapore cents for the first half-year, while its units closed at S$2.75.
- Top Glove shares rose 1.1% to S$8.24 after Malaysian authorities found no evidence of forced labor at a factory.
- CapitaLand Mall Trust's DPU fell 27.7% to 2.11 Singapore cents for the second quarter due to lower gross rental income.
- Mapletree Industrial Trust's DPU fell 7.4% to 2.87 Singapore cents for the first quarter despite higher net property income.
- OCBC Bank filed an application to appoint judicial managers over Xihe Holdings and its subsidiaries due to "strong distrust" in management.
- OCBC shares rose 0.3% to S$9.21.
- China Sunsine Chemical Holdings gained 1.4% to close at 35.5 cents after announcing a proposed acquisition.
- Koufu Group plans to focus on home-ground expansion this year amid the Covid-19 situation.
- CSE Global secured S$114.9 million in new orders for the second quarter, an 8.5% increase from a year ago.
- Thomson Medical Group's subsidiary Thomson Kids Pte Ltd will start a learning centre for children with learning difficulties.

site_title: Senoko partners Electrify, Engie Factory in trial for P2P solar energy trading
summary: Senoko Energy, in collaboration with Electrify and Engie Factory, has launched a six-month pilot project to introduce peer-to-peer (P2P) solar energy trading in Singapore. Individuals and companies can buy and sell solar energy to power their homes and businesses, with dynamic pricing and real-time data tracking. The pilot aims to test commercialization and eventually roll out the service to all households and businesses in Singapore, promoting a "prosumer" culture and reducing carbon footprint.

site_title: Procedures for issuers dual-listed on SGX, Nasdaq to be smoothed out
summary: A new agreement between Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) and Nasdaq aims to facilitate the regulatory exchange of information on dual-listed issuers. The streamlined framework for issuers seeking a secondary listing on SGX allows documents to be based on US listing information, reducing the need for duplicate filings. The cooperation enhances oversight and enforcement of regulatory actions, protecting investors' interests and streamlining processes between both exchanges. The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was signed by SGX RegCo and Nasdaq to promote regulatory cooperation and access to capital markets funding in both jurisdictions.

site_title: JB-Singapore rail link deal to be inked on July 30; construction to start in Jan
summary: Malaysia and Singapore will sign agreements on July 30 to finalize the Johor Baru-Singapore Rapid Transit System (RTS) Link project, a 4km rail link connecting Woodlands North station in Singapore to Bukit Chagar in Johor Baru. Construction is set to start in January 2026, with operations expected to begin by the end of 2026. The project, estimated to cost RM3.7 billion ($1.21 billion), aims to alleviate traffic congestion at the Johor Baru-Singapore Causeway, with the rail link to have a capacity of 10,000 commuters at peak hours.

site_title: Singapore firms feel full force of economic shock more acutely than global peers: HSBC survey
summary: Singapore firms feel the economic shock more intensely than global peers, with 87% of respondents saying they felt the impact "strongly", compared to 72% globally. The survey, conducted by HSBC, found that Singapore firms prioritize supply chain digitization and securing their supply chains, with 36% planning to digitize their supply chains in the next 1-2 years. The firms also look to regional partners to bolster trade flows, with 28% intending to increase intra-regional trade. Only 34% of Singapore firms felt prepared to handle pandemic-related challenges, the lowest figure among Asia-Pacific countries.

site_title: Surging virus erodes Trump's support
summary: US President Donald Trump's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic has eroded his re-election chances. His initial plan to provide guidance through press briefings with experts like Anthony Fauci and Deborah Birx was overshadowed by his dominating and confrontational style, which created the impression that he was not in control. Trump's refusal to wear a mask, insistence on reopening the economy too quickly, and politicization of the crisis have led to a catastrophic outcome, with the virus spreading to hot zones and the death toll reaching 100,000. As a result, Trump's public support has collapsed, and his presumptive Democratic rival Joe Biden is now leading him in opinion polls by 15 percentage points.

site_title: CSE Global bags S$114.9m in new orders for Q2, order book up 57% y-o-y
summary: CSE Global secured S$114.9 million in new orders for Q2 2020, a 8.5% increase from the same period last year. The growth was driven by the infrastructure and mining-and-minerals segments, with orders rising 19.9% and 65.5% respectively. The oil-and-gas segment saw a 10.6% decline in order value.

site_title: Silver hits four-year high on investment, industrial demand
summary: Silver prices have reached a four-year high of US$20.3150/ounce, driven by investors seeking safe-haven assets amid global economic concerns and rising Covid-19 cases. The metal climbed 3% overnight, surpassing the US$20.00/ounce threshold. This surge is attributed to investors' desire for precious metals as a safe-haven asset during uncertain economic times.

site_title: Digibank aspirants have viable path ahead, despite Covid-19 challenge: analysts
summary: Digital bank aspirants in Singapore face challenges despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Analysts suggest new entrants must demonstrate strong fundamentals, innovation, and post-crisis support for businesses. The flexible timeline for full setup allows aspirants to navigate these hurdles. Regulators require sound models and sustainable deposit-attracting strategies. The path forward for digital banks in Singapore remains viable, but it demands adaptability and a focus on supporting businesses in recovery.

images.alt_text: Grab has said its digital banking plans have not changed because of the pandemic, and that the firm's transport business is "slowly recovering" across South-east Asia.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance snags 640th spot in global ranking of 1,000 finance institutions
summary: Hong Leong Finance has been ranked 640th among the world's top 1,000 banks by The Banker for the third consecutive year. The bank attributed its rise in the ranking to 7.8% growth in its Tier 1 capital to US$1.33 billion as of December 2019. This marks a 27-spot improvement from last year's ranking.

site_title: Tech firms moving out of Hong Kong over security law
summary: Hong Kong's tech scene is facing a significant exodus due to China's national security law, which has raised concerns among overseas clients and suppliers about the implications of running data and internet services. Startups are moving data and people out or planning to restructure their operations away from Hong Kong, with some already making contingency plans. The law's expanded online policing powers and potential for non-compliance with foreign regulations are driving the decisions. Major tech firms like Facebook, Google, and Twitter are taking time to assess the impact, while sentiment in Hong Kong is dour, with many entrepreneurs considering relocation to Singapore or other countries.

site_title: Finnish prodigy, 24, appointed conductor of Orchestre de Paris
summary: Klaus Makela, a 24-year-old Finnish conductor, has been appointed as the new musical director of the Orchestre de Paris, succeeding Briton Daniel Harding. Makela began training to be a conductor at 12 and has made a name for himself in the classical music world. This appointment marks the latest "Flying Finn" to achieve success in the field, following in the footsteps of renowned conductors.

site_title: EU reaches 'historic' 750b euro deal on post-pandemic recovery after marathon summit
summary: EU leaders reached a historic 750 billion euro deal on a post-pandemic recovery plan after a marathon 5-day summit. The deal, reached at 5:15am, includes 390 billion euros in non-repayable grants and 360 billion euros in repayable loans. The agreement aims to support workers and families affected by the pandemic and is seen as a pivotal moment in Europe's journey. The deal is expected to be seen as a demonstration of the EU's ability to step up to a crisis and stay united, with the euro rising to a fresh four-month high.

site_title: SGX and Nasdaq to streamline exchange of regulatory information for dual listings
summary: SGX and Nasdaq have agreed to streamline the exchange of regulatory information for dual-listed companies, including those seeking a secondary listing on SGX. The streamlined framework allows issuers to base SGX listing documents on US listing information, reducing the need for duplicate disclosure. This cooperation aims to enhance oversight and enforcement of regulatory actions, protecting investors' interests in both jurisdictions. The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between SGX RegCo and Nasdaq will facilitate the monitoring and assessment of dual-listed issuers, improving the overall efficiency of the regulatory process.

site_title: Surbana Jurong, NTU to develop system for cleaner energy from LNG
summary: Surbana Jurong and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) are developing the Cryo-Polygen system, a hybrid power generation system that harnesses cold energy from liquefied natural gas (LNG) regasification, producing cleaner and more sustainable energy. The system will be tested on NTU's campus by 2022 and aims to reduce Singapore's carbon footprint and reach its 36% carbon emissions reduction goal by 2030. The cold energy can be used to power data centers, warehouses, and buildings, and the project is part of the SJ-NTU Corporate Laboratory, a sustainable innovation initiative.

site_title: Defaults will climb but some credit sectors are attractive
summary: Singapore's economy contracted by 41.2% in Q2 due to circuit breaker measures and coronavirus restrictions. However, corporate credit markets have shown an impressive recovery, with SGD corporate high-yield and investment-grade bonds up 4.7% and 2.8% respectively. Despite this, banks may play a significant role in corporate insolvencies due to high loan-loss provisions. In contrast, sectors such as healthcare and technology are expected to emerge winners from the crisis, with Chinese real estate also showing resilience. Investors with higher risk appetite may consider investing in Chinese real estate, while conservative investors should focus on issuers with high liquidity visibility.

site_title: OCBC Cycle 2020 called off, replaced with free virtual ride event
summary: OCBC Cycle 2020 has been cancelled due to the Covid-19 pandemic, replaced with a free virtual event, OCBC Cycle 2020 Virtual Ride, from Nov 1-15. Full refunds will be made by Sept 14 for those who have already registered, and participants can donate registration fees to charity. A virtual event with three categories will be held, with participants receiving medals and tote bags upon completion. Limited slots are available, and home-based training programs will be offered to participants.

site_title: SCCCI adapts to new virtual normal amid pandemic; says China is still key market
summary: The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) has adapted to the new virtual normal amid the COVID-19 pandemic, offering online courses, digital trade fairs, and consultancy services to its members. SCCCI president Roland Ng said the pandemic has created opportunities for firms to go digital and expand globally. The organization has polled its members six times since February, finding that revenue decline and cash flow issues were major challenges. SCCCI is leveraging its ties with China to monitor promising areas such as 5G and artificial intelligence, and is helping firms expand into the Chinese market.

site_title: MAS seeks more teeth to regulate financial services amid emerging cyber risks
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is proposing new laws to enhance its regulatory powers in the financial sector, addressing emerging cyber risks and digital token services. The proposed laws would allow the central bank to impose technology risk management requirements, license and regulate overseas digital token service providers, and issue prohibition orders against individuals deemed unsuitable to operate in the industry. The MAS aims to strengthen the financial sector's safety and soundness and protect against money laundering and terrorism financing.

site_title: UBS flags buyback possibility after US$1.23b Q2 profit beats forecast
summary: UBS, the world's largest wealth manager, reported a Q2 profit of $1.23 billion, beating forecasts, driven by a strong performance from its investment bank and core wealth management division. The bank's capital position is solid, allowing it to consider resuming share buybacks and paying the second half of its 2019 dividend later this year. CEO Sergio Ermotti's departure in November may signal a shift in the bank's strategy. UBS' shares rose 2.1% to 4% in Zurich trading, driven by strong capital and revenue.

site_title: Apple pledges to be fully carbon neutral by 2030
summary: Apple pledges to be fully carbon neutral across its entire business, including manufacturing supply chains, by 2030. The company aims to reduce emissions by 75% by 2030 and develop innovative carbon removal solutions for the remaining 25%. This move builds on Apple's existing carbon neutrality for corporate operations, ensuring no climate impact from all devices sold.

site_title: Hoe Chiang Road site offered via EOI
summary: Fragrance Group has appointed JLL to conduct an expression of interest (EOI) exercise for the freehold 15 Hoe Chiang Road property in Singapore. The guide price is S$715 million, translating to S$2,138-2,877 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) depending on the redevelopment scheme. This move comes after receiving unsolicited interest from potential buyers for the property.

site_title: Big Pharma to step up and pull for new antibiotics
summary: The International Federation of Pharmaceutical Manufacturers & Associations (IFPMA) has launched a nearly $1 billion AMR (antimicrobial resistance) Action Fund to support the development of new antibiotics. Many major pharmaceutical companies, including GlaxoSmithKline, have signed on to the initiative, which aims to address the growing scarcity of effective antibiotics. The fund's success will depend on significant new "pull" incentives from governments and the industry to bring new treatments from start to finish. The move is a step towards addressing the AMR crisis, which could reach 10 million deaths per year by 2050 and result in cumulative economic losses of $100 trillion.

site_title: Swarovski to cut a third of jobs at its Austrian headquarters
summary: Swarovski plans to cut a third of 4,600 jobs at its Austrian headquarters, approximately 1,000 this autumn and 600 by 2022, due to tough competition and coronavirus-related losses. The company expects revenues to drop 35% to below 2 billion euros. As part of a restructuring program, Swarovski will merge its businesses, including jewelry, home accessories, and attractions.

site_title: UK music magazine Q to close after 34 years
summary: UK music magazine Q is closing after 34 years due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the media sector. Editor Ted Kessler announced the closure in a tweet, citing the pandemic's effect on the magazine's business. This marks the end of the monthly publication after nearly three decades of operation.

site_title: Thai premier 'worried' as pro-democracy student protests grow
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha expressed concern over growing student protests calling for his government's dissolution, despite denying accusations of stifling freedoms. Thousands of mostly young protesters gathered at Bangkok's Democracy Monument, with more than a dozen rallies planned across the country. The students' organisational savvy has drawn comparisons to pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong, prompting warnings that the government's response could escalate dissent and opposition.

images.alt_text: Mr Prayut's comments come days after thousands of protesters massed at Bangkok's Democracy Monument in one of the city's largest shows of defiance in years.

site_title: Sias says contact with potential Hyflux investor Widjaja was a courtesy call
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Sias) clarified that a meeting with potential Hyflux investor Johnny Widjaja was a courtesy call, not a proposal for the holders of Hyflux's perpetual securities and preference shares (PnPs). Widjaja did not offer any terms for the PnP holders and intended to address their concerns later this year. Sias stated that any proposal must include a firm offer and be made public, and will not support a plan to rescue Hyflux without a concrete proposal.

site_title: Hertz to pay US$650m to halt lender fight over rental fleet
summary: Hertz Global Holdings agreed to pay US$650 million to lenders controlling its rental fleet as part of a deal to suspend a bankruptcy court fight over the vehicles. The company will halt its effort to cancel nearly 500,000 leases on the cars for the rest of the year. The agreement resolves a standoff over how to shrink the Hertz fleet and maintain regular payments to lenders. The company will ask a US Bankruptcy Judge to approve the settlement at a court hearing on July 24.

site_title: Call goes out for proposals to develop advanced electricity meters
summary: The Energy Market Authority of Singapore has issued a call for proposals to develop and test-bed advanced electricity meters that can operate on Narrowband Internet-of-Things (NB-IoT) technology. The meters will enable secure and cost-effective remote reading and data transmission, supporting Singapore's national drive towards greater energy efficiency. The proposal deadline is September 24, 2020, with the goal of rolling out the meters to over 1.4 million households by 2024. The initiative is part of Singapore's broader effort to leverage wireless technologies and promote a greener future.

images.alt_text: Advanced electricity meters will be progressively rolled out to Singapore households, under a national drive towards greater energy efficiency.

site_title: Covid-19 presents opportunity to reset economies: DBS chief
summary: DBS chief Piyush Gupta says COVID-19 has hit the reset button on world economies, presenting an opportunity to shift from consumption-focused stimulus packages to investment-driven approaches. He emphasizes the need for governments to develop "exit plans" that prioritize investment and environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) agendas. Gupta also highlights the importance of creating fair wages, community engagement, and social safety nets, citing the potential for universal basic income or negative income tax rates.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on upbeat corporate earnings, stimulus hopes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by positive earnings reports from companies like IBM and Coca-Cola, and hopes of domestic stimulus to support the economy. The Dow Jones rose 152.27 points, or 0.57%, to 26,833.14, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, reaching new records.

site_title: Taiwan rejects permits for 2 Hong Kong officials as visa row escalates
summary: Taiwan has rejected visas for two Hong Kong officials, escalating tensions between the two regions. The Hong Kong government had asked Taiwanese officials to sign a document supporting Beijing's "one China" policy in exchange for visa renewal, but the acting chief of the de facto consulate refused. The two Hong Kong Economic, Trade and Cultural Office staff have returned home after their permits for residence in Taiwan were rejected. This move comes after Taiwan criticized Beijing's security law imposed on Hong Kong, which has been widely condemned abroad.

site_title: Asia-Pacific banks need to learn from fintechs and evolve digitally
summary: Asia-Pacific banks are at a tipping point, with the "digital banking revolution" nearing, amid the COVID-19 crisis. To stay relevant, banks must evolve digitally, learning from fintechs' agility and flexibility. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is evaluating digital banking licence applications, with successful players expected to start operations by the end of 2020. Established institutions must undergo a cultural overhaul to remain competitive, adopting composable banking architectures to deliver rapid, intuitive, and responsive services.

site_title: OCBC files application to place OK Lim's Xihe Group under interim judicial managers
summary: OCBC Bank has filed an application to appoint judicial managers over Xihe Holdings and four of its vessel-owning subsidiaries, citing "strong distrust" in Xihe's management following evidence of fraud at sister company Hin Leong. The move comes after Hin Leong's collapse led to the insolvency of Ocean Tankers, another Lim family business. OCBC Bank accuses the Lim family of fabricating fictitious gains, forging documents, and misusing secured inventory, leading to billion-dollar insolvencies. The bank seeks to appoint independent managers to investigate and prevent further prejudice to creditors.

site_title: Wirecard hires Alix Partners for forensic investigation
summary: German payments company Wirecard has hired Alix Partners for a forensic investigation into the accounting scandal that led to its collapse, owing creditors almost US$4 billion. The investigation will examine which employees, including executives and supervisory board members, knew about potentially criminal incidents. Asset sales are underway, with about a dozen subsidiaries valued at 100 million euros, and the administrator is seeking buyers for Wirecard's core European operation and lending arm. This could yield up to 500 million euros from asset sales.

site_title: Unilever's India unit beats estimates as consumers stockpile
summary: Hindustan Unilever, the Indian unit of Unilever, reported a 6.8% rise in net income to 18.8 billion rupees for the quarter ended June 30, beating analysts' estimates. The company's revenue rose 4.3% to 104.1 billion rupees, driven by stockpiling of household essentials during the lockdown and the integration of GlaxoSmithKline's local consumer business. The company's shares have climbed 21% this year, but the Indian economy's slow rebound poses a risk to consumer spending.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters gather on anniversary of mob attack
summary: Small groups of Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters gathered on Tuesday to mark the first anniversary of the Yuen Long train station attack, which left 45 people injured. Demonstrators chanted slogans demanding justice and freedom, while police fired pepper spray during a skirmish. The attack, which was criticized for the police's slow response, exacerbated tensions during last year's protests. Protesters also held blank sheets of paper to oppose the new national security laws imposed by Beijing, which have raised international criticism and fears for the city's liberties.

site_title: Thomson Medical unit to focus on children's education and development
summary: Thomson Medical Group announced that its subsidiary, Thomson Kids Pte Ltd, will focus on children's developmental health and well-being. The learning centre will offer structured educational programmes based on evidence-based interventions to help children with learning difficulties learn more effectively. The centre will be supported by psychologists, speech and language therapists, and trained teachers. Shares in Thomson Medical Group rose 1.79% to close at 5.7 Singapore cents.

site_title: AIG to relocate New York headquarters to midtown office space
summary: American International Group (AIG) plans to relocate its New York headquarters to a midtown office space at 1271 Avenue of the Americas, occupying eight floors. The company will also consolidate its New York metropolitan area office space into two locations in Manhattan and Jersey City. This move is part of AIG's "AIG 200" initiative to modernize its real estate strategy. The relocation is expected to take place next year, with CEO Brian Duperreault citing the new location's proximity to clients and stakeholders.

site_title: Deutsche Bank says Q2 results slightly above consensus
summary: Deutsche Bank reported Q2 results slightly above consensus, with revenue down slightly from the previous year at 6 billion euros. The bank expects a net loss of 133 million euros, narrower than a 3.2 billion-euro loss last year. The CET1 ratio is expected to be above market expectations at 13.3%, higher than the previous quarter's 12.8%. The bank will report detailed earnings on July 29.

site_title: Duke-NUS' vaccine approved for clinical trials ahead of predicted date; first study to involve 108 volunteers
summary: Duke-NUS Medical School and Arcturus Therapeutics' jointly developed COVID-19 vaccine, Lunar-Cov19, has received approval for clinical trials in Singapore. The vaccine, which uses mRNA to trigger an immune response, will be tested on 108 healthy adult volunteers to evaluate dose levels and safety. The trials could potentially bring human trials forward from September to August, with promising pre-clinical study results showing a robust immune response with a single dose. The vaccine's development is seen as a promising step towards a potential commercial vaccine.

site_title: Coca-Cola results hit by halt to pro sports, live events
summary: Coca-Cola reported a 32% drop in second-quarter profits to $1.8 billion due to a decline in away-from-home consumption, particularly during the coronavirus lockdowns. The company's sales declined 28% to $7.2 billion, with volumes bottoming out in April before improving gradually. Coca-Cola expects the second quarter to be the most severely impacted period of 2020, with the full-year impact uncertain. The company's reliance on sporting events, movie theaters, and entertainment has been significantly affected by social distancing protocols.

site_title: European banks face more than 400b euros in Covid loan losses
summary: European banks face estimated losses of over 400 billion euros in the next three years due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with loan losses to small and mid-size enterprises and unsecured consumer loans being the most at risk. The losses compare to the eurozone crisis of 2012-14 but are less than 40% of the losses experienced in the 2008-10 global financial crisis. Experts warn that banks will need ambitious restructuring efforts and government support to recover, with potential benefits from consolidation and a single banking market.

site_title: First votes in US election to be cast in Sept
summary: US voters in battleground states Michigan, Pennsylvania, and North Carolina will begin casting ballots in September. The first absentee ballots will be sent out in North Carolina on September 4, followed by Pennsylvania on September 14 and Michigan on September 19. This gives President Donald Trump and his Democratic challenger Joe Biden around six weeks to make their cases to voters before the first votes are cast.

site_title: Indonesia industrial estates to gain from Japan factory relocation: report
summary: Japan's government is subsidizing companies to relocate factories from China to Japan or other countries, including Indonesia, to diversify its supply chain. Indonesia's industrial estates, such as Puradelta Lestari and Bekasi Fajar, are expected to gain from this relocation due to existing Japanese companies as strategic shareholders. Seven corporates have agreed to relocate, with another 17 on the way, for an estimated $39 billion in investments and over 100,000 jobs. The government's efforts are expected to attract foreign direct investment and benefit industrial estate players.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.48 points to 1,595.93, closing higher on Tuesday. The market saw 9.342 billion lots traded worth RM5.389 billion, with 634 gainers and 428 losers.

site_title: Massive meteor shower 'hit Earth and Moon' 800m years ago
summary: Scientists from Osaka University found evidence of a massive meteor shower that hit Earth and the Moon 800 million years ago, releasing 40-50 million billion tonnes of meteors. The impact, estimated to be 30-60 times greater than the one that killed the dinosaurs, created large craters on both bodies. Researchers used images from the Kaguya lunar orbiter to analyze the craters' ages and conclude that the shower occurred just before the Cryogenian period, a planet-wide ice age. The impact likely had profound effects on life on Earth, including marine biogeochemical cycles and climate system perturbations.

site_title: TikTok plans to add 10,000 jobs in US over next 3 years
summary: TikTok plans to add approximately 10,000 jobs in the US over the next three years, expanding its current workforce of 1,400 employees. The company, owned by China's ByteDance, aims to strengthen its presence in the US market. Following a US national security panel's inquiry into its data handling practices, TikTok has been seen distancing itself from Beijing. The company is also considering London as a potential headquarters location.

images.alt_text: Short-form video sharing app TikTok is planning to add about 10,000 jobs in the United States over the next three years, the company said on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than two percent on Tuesday, mirroring a global advance, amid hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine. The Hang Seng Index rose 2.31%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained. The positive results from early trials fueled optimism among investors.

site_title: Precision-farming startup Taranis bags US$30m in Series C round
summary: Precision-farming startup Taranis has raised US$30 million in a Series C round led by Vertex Growth and Kuok Group's Orion Fund. The funding will be used to develop more scouting products and expand its footprint in Asia. Taranis' proprietary AI2 SmartScout technology enables farmers to identify crop issues efficiently and create accurate prescription plans to customize treatments and application rates. The company aims to use the funds to launch new programs that will help farmers predict crop threats and gauge yields.

site_title: Uber faces UK fights that threaten its biggest European market
summary: Uber faces significant challenges in the UK, with a Supreme Court dispute over whether its drivers are self-employed or workers, potentially entitled to minimum wage and holiday pay. A previous ruling found drivers are "workers," and a loss could force Uber to reimburse drivers for unpaid holiday pay and pay value-added tax on fares. The company's operating licence in London, its biggest European market, is also set to expire, with a decision expected this year. If Uber loses, it could be forced out of London and face significant financial and reputational consequences.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies is bracing for a long summer of legal battles that could see the end of its reign in London and entitle its drivers to a long list of workers' rights.

site_title: ERP charges to be reinstated at some parts of CTE during morning and evening peak hours
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has announced that Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) charges will be reinstated at three gantries on the Central Expressway (CTE) during morning and evening peak hours starting July 27. The charges will be S$1 for motorists driving southbound between 8am and 9am and S$1 for those driving northbound between 6pm and 7pm. The reinstatement is due to traffic jams observed during peak hours, despite general traffic conditions remaining optimal elsewhere. The LTA will review ERP rates every five weeks, starting from the next review cycle.

site_title: South Korea's SK Bioscience in deal with AstraZeneca on vaccine
summary: South Korea's SK Bioscience has agreed to manufacture AstraZeneca's experimental Covid-19 vaccine, AZD1222, to support global supplies. The vaccine has shown promise in early-stage clinical trials, with the World Health Organization's chief scientist calling it the leading candidate in the global race to halt the pandemic. SK Bioscience will start producing undiluted vaccine solutions this month, with a manufacturing contract set to last until early next year. This partnership aims to help AstraZeneca meet its agreement to supply over two billion doses of the vaccine.

site_title: Jeff Bezos adds record US$13b in single day to fortune
summary: Jeff Bezos added $13 billion to his net worth in a single day, the largest single-day jump since the Bloomberg Billionaires Index was created in 2012. His net worth has increased $74 billion in 2020 to $189.3 billion, making him the world's richest person. Amazon shares surged 7.9% and are up 73% this year. This surge is partly driven by people staying at home and the boost given to markets by stimulus efforts. Bezos' ex-wife, Mackenzie, also gained $4.6 billion, making her the 13th-richest person in the world.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit posts 13.6% rise in H1 DPU
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 13.6% rise in half-year distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.375 Singapore cents, driven by acquisitions and a private placement. Distributable income rose 38% to S$75 million, while net property income increased 32.1% to S$114.2 million. Portfolio occupancy was 96.1% as of June 30, 2020, with a weighted average lease expiry of 7.4 years. The Reit's assets under management increased to S$2.8 billion, and net asset value per unit rose to S$1.17.

site_title: LinkedIn cuts 960 jobs as pandemic puts the brakes on corporate hiring
summary: LinkedIn is cutting 960 jobs, approximately 6% of its global workforce, due to the sustained impact of the coronavirus pandemic on demand for its recruitment products. The layoffs will be across sales and hiring divisions globally. CEO Ryan Roslansky assured affected staff that they will receive at least 10 weeks of severance pay and health insurance for a year. The company will also hire for newly-created roles from laid-off staff, allowing them to continue working from home with company-issued equipment.

site_title: Malaysia's approved investments in 2020 likely to halve from 2019: UOB
summary: Malaysia's approved investments in 2020 are likely to halve from 2019, according to UOB economists. In the first quarter, total approved investments were down 34% year-over-year at RM37.4 billion, with 70.4% being domestic investments. Manufacturing investments accounted for 67.5% of approved investments, while services sector investments fell 58.1% and primary sector investments plunged 91%. The economists expect full-year investment approvals to reach RM100 billion, down from RM211 billion in 2019, and forecast a 12% decline in real private investment growth for 2020.

site_title: MIT's DPU down 7.4% for Q1; S$7.1m withheld due to virus uncertainty
summary: MAPLETREE Industrial Trust's (MIT) DPU fell 7.4% to 2.87 Singapore cents for Q1, driven by a 11.6% increase in distributable income. However, $7.1 million in joint venture distributions will be withheld due to COVID-19 uncertainty, providing flexibility to mitigate rental relief impacts.

site_title: Be more patriotic, China's Xi tells companies as he targets economic upturn
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged companies to be more patriotic and expand overseas to boost economic growth. China's economic recovery is seen as better than expected, with the economy returning to growth in the second quarter. The government plans to implement fiscal, monetary, and macro-economic policies to support the recovery, cutting taxes and fees to benefit businesses. In the face of rising protectionism and a slowing global economy, Xi emphasized the need for China to take advantage of its large domestic market and press ahead with economic reforms, understanding international rules and risks.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping said the government will target a good growth rate this year, making fiscal policy more proactive, prudent monetary policy more flexible, and macro-economic policies more targeted and timely.

site_title: Caesars' US$17b sale saved by bettors racing back to tables
summary: Eldorado Resorts successfully completed its $17 billion takeover of Caesars Entertainment Corp, selling $8.8 billion in debt and stock to finance the deal. The sale was aided by strong returns from casinos reopening in May, with higher-end bettors returning quickly to tables. The combined company, now adopting the Caesars name, has transformed into the largest US casino operator with 55 properties. Despite a $1 billion loss in the second quarter due to the COVID-19 pandemic, profitability has increased since reopening, with the company pursuing further sales and a possible initial public offering of its sports and online-betting business.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek's one-year total shareholder return fell to -2.3% due to a dip in its portfolio value to S$306b. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposed new powers to regulate financial services amid emerging cyber risks. DBS chief Piyush Gupta stated that COVID-19 may drive the worst economic collapse in recent years, but also presents an opportunity to reset. Singtel Dash partnered with Ezra to offer migrant workers extra airtime credit, and the STI rose 0.5% on fresh hopes of a virus vaccine and EU stimulus deal.

site_title: Singapore's Agritrade has potential investors: source
summary: London-based Nithia Capital Resources Advisors is seeking to acquire Singapore's Agritrade International (AIPL) and its shares in its Hong Kong-listed subsidiary, Agritrade Resources, after the company's court-appointed restructuring due to fraud allegations. AIPL owes US$1.55 billion to at least 20 banks. Nithia Capital proposes a Special Purpose Vehicle to invest US$65 million, with US$35 million allocated for debt repayment and US$30 million for working capital and security release. The deal requires Agritrade Resources' CEO, Ng Xinwei, to remain as director and work out arrangements with creditors to avoid bankruptcy.

site_title: Singtel Dash partners Ezra to offer migrant workers extra airtime credit
summary: Singtel Dash, a mobile payments platform, partners with global aid initiative Ezra to offer extra airtime credit to migrant workers in Singapore. From July 22 to August 23, Singtel will provide up to double the value of top-ups to migrant workers using Dash for international mobile airtime to their families. The initiative aims to show appreciation to the migrant community that has contributed to Singapore's growth through digital and financial inclusion.

site_title: China plans quarterly look into banks' green finance performance
summary: China plans to review banks' green finance performance on a quarterly basis starting next year, with the People's Bank of China grading banks based on metrics such as green finance share and risk exposure. The review will cover financing tools including loans, securities, and investments, and will account for 20% of the evaluation. China aims to promote sustainable finance and has been a major player in green bond issuance and renewable energy investment. The review is part of China's efforts to step up sustainable finance and address its role as the world's largest emitter of greenhouse gases.

site_title: CSE Global bags S$114.9m in new orders for Q2, order book up 57% y-o-y
summary: CSE Global, a Mainboard-listed firm, secured S$114.9 million in new orders for Q2 2020, an 8.5% increase from last year. The growth was driven by infrastructure and mining-and-minerals segments, with order values rising 19.9% and 65.5%, respectively. The order book grew 56.6% to S$293.8 million, driven by a 57% year-over-year increase.

site_title: STI up 0.5% on fresh hopes of virus vaccine and EU stimulus deal
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, reversing Monday's lacklustre performance, due to renewed hopes for a Covid-19 vaccine and the European Union's 750-billion-euro stimulus deal. The Straits Times Index (STI) tracked overnight gains on Wall Street, boosted by technology giants. The positive sentiment also followed a successful EU stimulus deal and promising news from clinical trials.

site_title: Zoom to open tech centre in India's Bengaluru
summary: Zoom Video Communications Inc plans to open a technology centre in Bengaluru, India, as part of its expansion push in the country. The centre will focus on research and development, IT, security, and business operations. This move comes after the company has already established offices and data centres in Mumbai and Bengaluru. Zoom faces concerns over privacy and security issues in India, but the company has engaged with the Indian government and is optimistic about its future.
