The centre is expected to hire staff, although investment and hiring details have not been disclosed.

site_title: Covid-19 may drive the worst economic collapse in recent years, but also presents opportunity to reset: DBS chief
summary: DBS chief Piyush Gupta warns that the COVID-19 pandemic may lead to the worst economic collapse in recent years, with global GDP potentially shrinking since the Great Depression. However, he also sees the pandemic as an opportunity to reset and adopt a more forward-looking approach towards investments, prioritizing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) agendas. Governments and the private sector should focus on creating sustainable and equitable recovery plans, with a focus on investment and job creation rather than consumption. Gupta emphasizes the need for leadership and a "value prism" that prioritizes growth with social responsibility.

site_title: India's Vikram to invest US$726m to make solar equipment
summary: India's Vikram Solar Ltd plans to invest 54.32 billion rupees (US$1.01 billion) to build a 3-gigawatt solar energy equipment factory in Tamil Nadu, aiming to reduce imports and boost domestic manufacturing. The plant, expected to be completed in five years, will produce wafers, cells, and modules. This move supports the government's goal of expanding renewable energy capacity to 450 gigawatts by 2030 and reducing imports, particularly from China, which supplies 80% of India's solar modules.

site_title: Soundcloud founders launch Berlin-based e-bike subscription startup
summary: SoundCloud founders Eric Quidenus-Wahlforss, Alexander Ljung, and Christian Springub are launching DANCE, an e-bike subscription startup in Berlin. The company aims to provide a sustainable alternative to bike sharing, with a subscription model that allows users to keep an e-bike for several weeks or months. DANCE plans to expand internationally once its bike design, app, and operating model are refined. The startup has received a 4.4 million euro seed round backing from BlueYard and individual investors, with an invite-only service launching in Berlin this week.

site_title: Surbana Jurong, NTU develop hybrid system for cleaner energy from LNG
summary: Surbana Jurong and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) are developing a hybrid system called Cryo-Polygen to generate cleaner energy from liquefied natural gas (LNG). The system combines electricity, gas, cold energy, steam, and hot water production into a single plant. A pilot testbed is expected to be built on NTU's campus by 2022 to test and validate the technology. The system aims to reduce Singapore's carbon footprint and help the country reach its goal of a 36% reduction in carbon emissions by 2030.

site_title: Huawei will not be prevented from investing in France: finance minister
summary: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire stated that France will not ban Huawei from investing in the country, protecting national security interests while condemning China's alleged abuses against minority Muslims. In contrast to Britain, France will not purge Huawei from its 5G network by 2027. Le Maire reaffirmed France's position to Chinese authorities, but emphasized that sensitive locations will be protected.

images.alt_text: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said on Tuesday that France would not ban China's Huawei from investing in the country, in contrast to Britain which has decided to purge the firm's equipment from its 5G network by 2027.

site_title: Ted Baker beats expectations as turnaround continues
summary: British fashion retailer Ted Baker has exceeded expectations with its turnaround under new CEO Rachel Osborne, with online sales jumping 35% and group revenue down 55% year-over-year. The company's shares rose 16% before paring gains, driven by increased social media engagement and targeted digital marketing. Ted Baker has also implemented cost-cutting measures, including £12 million in job cuts, to save £21 million in the current financial year. The company will continue to withhold forecasts for the financial year.

site_title: China requires negative Covid-19 tests for arriving air passengers
summary: China has implemented a new requirement for air passengers arriving in the country, mandating negative Covid-19 test results before boarding flights. Passengers must undergo nucleic acid tests within five days of embarkation at designated facilities recognized by Chinese embassies in host countries. This measure aims to reduce the risk of imported coronavirus cases amid increased international travel. The Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) will assess testing capacity and formulate travel procedures with host countries.

site_title: Nokia rolls out 5G networks for industrial clients
summary: Nokia has rolled out 5G stand-alone wireless networks for industrial clients, enabling them to become independent in their onsite connection needs. The move aims to accelerate digitalisation in demanding use cases such as automotive manufacturing. Nokia has secured an order to build a 5G network for mining technology firm Sandvik in Finland. This marks a significant step in the growing role of mobile technologies in manufacturing industries, with Nokia's Enterprise unit head Raghav Sahgal stating that the company is "paving the way to accelerate digitalisation".

site_title: Average number of new daily Covid-19 patients in community falls for 8th day in a row
summary: Singapore's average number of new daily Covid-19 patients in the community has fallen for the 8th consecutive day, with 10 cases reported in the past week. The number of new unlinked community cases has also decreased, from 7 to 6 cases per week. The country's total cases have reached 48,434, with 399 new cases confirmed on Tuesday, including 9 community cases linked to previous cases or clusters. Meanwhile, 213 cases have been discharged, and 44,569 patients have recovered from the disease.

site_title: Adapting to the Future of Work in a remote environment
summary: During the pandemic, companies globally launched the largest remote workforce enablement experiment, driven by the need to maintain business continuity, protect workers, and address evolving regional requirements. Many companies adapted seamlessly, while others encountered challenges. Key insights and best practices include getting business inputs, considering factors such as business and customer requirements, and ensuring business continuity. Effective communication, developing an employee value proposition, and providing flexibility are also crucial. As remote working becomes the new norm, companies must balance business results with maintaining a culture of connectivity and inclusion, and treat all workers equally.

images.alt_text: Paul Churchill, vice president of Southeast Asia, Vertiv

site_title: Barclays, Handelsbanken lead initiative to help UK cut carbon emissions
summary: Barclays and Handelsbanken are leading a group of five lenders in the Bankers for NetZero initiative, which aims to provide financial support to UK businesses transitioning to a carbon-neutral economy. The initiative, also including Triodos, Ecology Building Society, and Tide, will explore ways to help businesses reduce risks associated with sustainable practices. The UK government has committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2050, and the group plans to issue recommendations on accelerating Britain's transition by the end of the year.

site_title: BHP hits record iron ore output but warns of risks from virus
summary: BHP Group reported a 7% rise in fourth-quarter iron ore output to a record 67 million tonnes, exceeding expectations. However, the company warned of risks from the resurgence of COVID-19 outbreaks, which may impact demand for its key commodities. BHP widened its 2021 guidance range for iron ore production to 244-253 million tonnes, citing uncertainty over demand from China and other countries. The company attributed its stronger-than-expected production to improved Chinese domestic industrial activity.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on vaccine hopes, EU stimulus deal
summary: Europe's stock markets rose on Tuesday, driven by hopes for a coronavirus vaccine and a landmark 750-billion-euro EU stimulus deal. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.6%, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 indices rose 1.1% and 1.5%, respectively. The positive market sentiment followed news of the EU stimulus deal and optimism over vaccine development, with investors seeking safe-haven assets amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore Flyer to reopen on July 23
summary: The Singapore Flyer will reopen on July 23 with strict safety measures, including limited capacity, advance reservations, and social distancing. Each capsule will host up to 7 guests, and guest-occupied capsules will be disinfected after each rotation. Visitors must make online reservations and follow one-way traffic flow for crowd control. The attraction has been closed since April 7 due to the pandemic, and shares of Straco Corp, its operator, rose to S$0.52 on the news.

site_title: UBS flags buyback possibility after Q2 earnings
summary: UBS, the world's largest wealth manager, reported Q2 earnings of $1.23 billion, beating expectations due to strong performance from its investment bank and solid profit in its core wealth management division. The bank's capital position is at the upper limit of its target, allowing it to pay its 2019 dividend and consider resuming share buybacks in the fourth quarter. Despite a 2% fall in operating income, UBS's resilient focus on wealth management has helped it weather the pandemic better than many European peers.

site_title: Dividends come crashing down as Asian companies preserve cash
summary: Asian companies are slashing dividends at the fastest pace in over a decade due to the coronavirus pandemic. About 23% of MSCI Asia Pacific Index members have scrapped or reduced payouts, with China and Hong Kong firms making up the majority. Global payouts could contract by 15-35% this year, and earnings for companies in the region tumbled by over 60% in the first quarter. The uncertain pandemic duration is increasing pressure on firms to preserve cash, with some sectors like consumer discretionary and materials seeing the highest instances of scrapped payouts.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close up on high-tech gains
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.73% on Tuesday, driven by gains in the high-tech sector, following the US Nasdaq's record close. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 22,884.22, while the Topix index rose 0.36% to 1,582.74. The rally came despite US President Trump's recent threats to extend the stock market rally.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shares closed higher on Tuesday as investors bought on dips in the high-tech sector after the US Nasdaq powered to another record.

site_title: Seoul: Shares strengthen on vaccine hopes, EU stimulus deal
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.39% on Tuesday, driven by promising COVID-19 vaccine trial data and a European Union stimulus deal. The Kospi benchmark closed at 2,228.83, with investors also buying net 442.4 billion won worth of shares. The won strengthened to 1,197.8 per US dollar, and the 10-year yield rose 2 basis points to 1.354%. Meanwhile, South Korea's economy likely contracted in the second quarter, the largest in over 20 years, due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares rose nearly 1.5 per cent on Tuesday as investors cheered promising data from trials of three potential Covid-19 vaccines and the European Union stimulus deal. The Korean won and the benchmark bond yield both rose.

site_title: Tesla share rally propels some early fan investors to riches
summary: Retail investors worldwide, mostly early fans of Tesla, have reaped significant profits after the company's share price surged over six-fold, making it the world's highest-valued automaker. Some, like Orestis Palampougioukis, a software developer, invested in Tesla at $230 a share and now hold shares worth over $10,000. Others, like Choi Jong-wan, a Korean Tesla owner, have also profited from the company's success, with some investors buying vehicles and others planning to sell shares to cash out. Elon Musk's net worth has soared, with his options potentially worth up to $4 billion.

site_title: From egg hunter to protector, Malaysian battles to save turtles
summary: Aziz Mustaffa, a former egg collector, now protects turtles' nesting sites in Malaysia, where several endangered species lay eggs on its coasts. Green turtles, Hawksbills, and Leatherbacks nest on Malaysian beaches, attracting tourists. However, the country faces an uphill struggle to defend these creatures. Mustaffa's transformation is one success in efforts to conserve the reptiles, which swim ashore from the South China Sea to lay eggs in the sand. Conservation efforts are crucial to protect Malaysia's turtle population and its unique natural spectacle.

images.alt_text: Several species, including Green turtles, Hawksbills and Leatherbacks, nest on Malaysia's coasts, where the spectacle of babies hatching and scurrying into the sea has long been a major tourist draw.

site_title: Geely's Volvo Cars sees wider market recovery on solid growth in China
summary: Volvo Cars, owned by Geely Holding, expects a wider market recovery in the second half of the year despite an operating loss for the first half. The company saw solid growth in China during the second quarter and is anticipating a similar upturn in the US and Europe. Volvo's recovery is attributed to the easing of pandemic-related lockdowns and strain on supply chains.

site_title: Wall Street is throwing billions at once-shunned gold miners
summary: Wall Street is investing heavily in gold miners, with $2.4 billion in secondary equity offerings raised in the second quarter, the most since 2013. This surge in funding is driven by soaring gold prices and the Covid-19 crisis, making precious-metals companies attractive to a broad range of investors. The sector, once seen as high-risk, is now attracting mainstream investors, marking a significant shift in investor sentiment.

site_title: TikTok's former chief to oversee investment at ByteDance
summary: TikTok's co-creator and former chief, Alex Zhu, is set to oversee ByteDance's investment arm, focusing on finding the company's next breakthrough app. Zhu, who previously led the world's most successful Chinese-made app Musical.ly, will step away from TikTok as it faces increasing global scrutiny. ByteDance has hired Walt Disney's former streaming czar Kevin Mayer as TikTok's new global CEO, amid US-China tensions and a ban on TikTok in India. Zhu will lead ByteDance's strategy, investment, and product design, and help build content for its family of apps.

images.alt_text: TikTok's co-creator and former chief will oversee ByteDance's investment arm, heading up the search for the company's next breakthrough app and stepping further away from the viral video sensation that's been caught in the cross-hairs of US-China tensions.

site_title: MAS proposes new powers to regulate financial services amid emerging cyber risks
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed new laws to regulate financial services amid emerging cyber risks and the growing provision of digital services. The proposed omnibus Act will give the central bank more powers to manage technology risks, license and regulate digital token service providers, and issue prohibition orders against unsuitable individuals. The MAS aims to enhance dispute resolution by providing statutory protection to mediators and adjudicators. The proposals, which include a maximum penalty of S$1 million, are open for public comments until August 20.

site_title: Sixty-nine more dormitories cleared of Covid-19: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has cleared 69 more dormitories of Covid-19, bringing the total cleared to 891. This includes 41 blocks for recovered workers in 11 purpose-built dormitories. The cleared dormitories are now ready for workers to resume work, with some pending movement to accommodations. To minimize the risk of new infections, workers must complete three steps: staggered pick-up/drop-off timings, updated residential addresses, and downloading health status-tracking apps. Most dormitories completed these steps in a week or less.

site_title: Novartis profits climb despite virus sales swings
summary: Novartis reported higher profits in the first half of the year, with net profit reaching $4 billion, a 9% increase. Sales rose 6% to $23.6 billion, but were affected by the coronavirus pandemic, with a 11% increase in the first quarter reversing to a 1% decline in the second quarter. The company expects mid-single digit sales growth for the year and a low double-digit gain in core operating income.

images.alt_text: Swiss pharma giant Novartis reported Tuesday higher profits in the first half of the year despite the coronavirus pandemic causing swings in sales.

site_title: Gojek appoints former Amazon exec Severan Rault as CTO
summary: Gojek appoints Severan Rault as its new chief technology officer (CTO), replacing Ajey Gore, who stepped down for a personal break. Rault, a former Amazon executive, brings expertise in cloud solutions, artificial intelligence, and software development. He will oversee Gojek's technology and manage engineering teams in South-east Asia and India. Rault's appointment comes as Gojek enters a critical phase of maturation, and he expressed excitement to be part of the company's journey, citing the "fascinating" engineering challenges ahead.

site_title: Microsoft, Nike, Unilever announce global carbon-neutral group
summary: Microsoft, Nike, Unilever, and other major companies, including Mercedes-Benz and Wipro, have formed a global consortium called Transform to Net Zero to reduce carbon emissions. The alliance aims to share resources and tactics for cutting emissions, investing in carbon-reduction technology, and coordinating on public policy goals. Microsoft has pledged to be carbon negative by 2030 and remove equivalent emissions since its founding by 2050. The group will work with the Environmental Defense Fund and recruit other members to tackle climate change.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on stimulus, vaccine hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 2.6% on Tuesday, their best session since June 10, after the Reserve Bank of Australia urged the government to boost public spending and fiscal stimulus. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,156.30. RBA Governor Philip Lowe's comments boosted demand for riskier assets, driving the rally. The central bank's call for further stimulus follows vaccine hopes and economic recovery concerns.

site_title: KKR raises US$950m for fund dedicated to riskiest CMBS
summary: KKR has raised US$950 million for a fund focused on buying the riskiest slices of commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS), known as "B-pieces." These slices are the first to take losses when mortgages underpinning the securities sour. The fund targets annualized returns of 12% before fees and has already invested over US$1.25 billion in CMBS since 2017. KKR is among the most active buyers of B-pieces, purchasing about 60% of deals' required risk-retention portions in the first half of 2020.

site_title: UBS Q2 net profit dips as Swiss business dampens trading bonanza
summary: UBS, the world's largest wealth manager, reported a 11% drop in net profit to $1.23 billion in Q2, beating analyst expectations. The decline was driven by a pandemic-induced slump in retail and corporate banking, despite higher trading activity. Wealth management assets rose 11% to $2.60 trillion, while investment banking division grew pre-tax profit by 43%. The bank's focus on wealth management has helped it weather the pandemic better than many European peers, but its results fell short of those of US trading powerhouses.

site_title: Giant wireless sale in US offers 5G spectrum sliced into 22,631 pieces
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is hosting a historic auction for 5G wireless spectrum, with over 200 companies registered to bid. The auction, set to begin on July 23, offers 22,631 licenses, divided into seven per county, allowing smaller companies and utilities to participate. The goal is to promote competition and provide more affordable internet access, with estimated proceeds ranging from $10 billion. The auction includes major players such as AT&T, Verizon, and cable providers, and is seen as a key step towards a future of super-fast internet and connected devices.

site_title: Singapore-based ANZ trader sues employer for defamation, seeking US$20m
summary: ANZ trader Bogac Ozdemir is suing the bank for defamation over its criticism of one of his social media posts, seeking US$20 million in damages. Ozdemir, a Singapore-based global head of credit, wrote a post blaming China for the coronavirus pandemic and criticizing US society and politics. ANZ responded, stating the post didn't reflect the bank's views and showed a lack of judgment. Ozdemir claims the bank's comments were defamatory and made in response to pressure from Chinese regulators. The lawsuit was filed in New York.

site_title: Hoe Chiang Road site in CBD up for sale with S$715m guide price
summary: A prime development site at 15 Hoe Chiang Road in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) is up for sale with a guide price of S$715 million. The 39,337 sq ft freehold site has been approved for hospitality use and can be redeveloped into a mixed-use project with Grade A offices and luxury residential units, capitalizing on the CBD Incentive Scheme. The site is located near established office buildings, hotels, and high-end residential developments, with proximity to several MRT stations.

site_title: India seeks new preferential treatment from US on drugs, other goods: sources
summary: India is seeking preferential treatment from the US on pharmaceutical exports in exchange for opening its dairy markets and slashing tariffs on farm goods. The US is a major importer of Indian generic drugs, including hydroxychloroquine, and India has proposed a quota-based system to allow US dairy imports. The two sides are negotiating a limited trade pact, with India offering to roll back tariff hikes on almonds, walnuts, and apples. The US has raised concerns about India's dependence on China for sourcing raw materials for generic drugs, but differences remain on e-commerce and data storage rules.

site_title: South Korea's first military satellite launched
summary: South Korea successfully launched its first military communications satellite, ANASIS-II, via a Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida. The satellite aims to enhance the country's defense capabilities against North Korea. Launched by private operator SpaceX, the mission marks a significant step for South Korea in building its defense capabilities.

site_title: Finnish prodigy Makela takes classical music by storm
summary: At 24, Finnish conductor Klaus Makela has been appointed musical director of the Orchestre de Paris, marking a rare instance of a young conductor taking on the role. Makela began conducting at 12 and has since trained under renowned conductor Jorma Panula, graduating from the Sibelius Academy in Helsinki. He credits his natural leadership abilities and ability to connect with musicians, saying "leadership is quite a complicated thing" that comes from proving one's skills. Makela's appointment has sparked optimism about classical music's future, with him believing that its unique qualities can make it "cool" in a world increasingly seeking slower-paced experiences.

site_title: UK taxi, private hire vehicle drivers to undergo criminal record checks every 6 months
summary: The UK's transport ministry has introduced new regulations requiring taxi and private hire vehicle drivers to undergo criminal record checks every 6 months. Local authorities are expected to implement these standards to improve consistency in the licensing system and reduce harm to vulnerable passengers. Drivers will also be trained to identify and respond to potential abuse. The move follows a series of high-profile abuse cases in UK cities, with Transport Secretary Grant Shapps stating that more must be done to protect passengers. CCTV installation in cabs is also being considered as part of the new standards.

site_title: Bauer shuts eight magazines in Australia due to virus downturn
summary: Bauer Media, a German media conglomerate, has shut eight Australian magazines due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The affected titles include Harper's Bazaar, Elle, InStyle, Men's Health, and Women's Health. The decision was made after a drastic fall in advertising revenue caused by business closures and travel restrictions. Bauer paused publication of many Australian and New Zealand magazines in May and has now closed eight of its Australian titles.

site_title: UK music magazine Q to close after 34 years, hurt by coronavirus pandemic
summary: UK music magazine Q is closing after 34 years due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on its business. Editor Ted Kessler announced the closure in a tweet, citing the pandemic's effect on the media sector. This is the latest in a series of job cuts in the industry, following announcements from British newspaper publisher Reach Plc and broadcaster BBC. Q's closure is the latest blow to the UK's music and media landscape.

site_title: Dubai expatriates race for new jobs after virus layoffs
summary: Dubai expatriates are fleeing the city amid a global economic crisis triggered by the coronavirus pandemic. The UAE, a hub for young professionals, is expected to lose 900,000 jobs, forcing 10% of its expatriate residents to leave. Many are being forced to sell their assets and return home, with those who remain facing limited job opportunities. The crisis is expected to have a significant impact on key sectors such as travel, tourism, and real estate, and may lead to a decline in the population of the Gulf Cooperation Council countries.

site_title: Gold hovers near 9-year high as virus fears drive safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices rose near a 9-year high on Tuesday, driven by concerns over COVID-19 cases and expectations for inflation from economic stimulus measures. Spot gold was up 0.1% at $1,817.23 per ounce, its highest since September 2011. Market strategist Stephen Innes attributed the surge to stimulus and future tariff threats, stating it's "eye candy" driving sentiment.

images.alt_text: Gold rose after the US dollar index fell to a more than four-month low against a basket of major currencies.

site_title: Senoko trials peer-to-peer solar energy marketplace in Singapore with Electrify, Engie
summary: Senoko Energy, in collaboration with Electrify and Engie Factory, launched a six-month pilot project to introduce peer-to-peer (P2P) trading of renewable energy in Singapore. The initiative, sponsored by Engie Factory, allows households and businesses to register for the P2P trading platform, enabling them to buy and sell solar energy with one another. The SolarShare platform aims to promote the sharing of excess solar energy and reduce reliance on the grid, with the goal of increasing the adoption of renewable energy in Singapore.

site_title: Starbucks expands Chinese order services to multiple Alibaba apps
summary: Starbucks has expanded its order services to multiple Alibaba apps, including Taobao, Amap, Alipay, and Koubei, allowing Chinese customers to order drinks for in-store pickup or delivery. This move is part of the company's efforts to boost sales in China, its biggest growth market, as the country recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. The expansion follows a partnership signed in 2018 and contrasts with the declining fortunes of local rival Luckin Coffee Inc.

site_title: Singapore firms plan to invest in supply chain digitisation, lean into intra-regional partners: HSBC
summary: Singapore firms are taking steps to build resilience in their supply chains amid the economic shock caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. 87% of respondents in a HSBC survey said they felt the impact strongly, with 36% planning to digitize their supply chains in the next 1-2 years. Firms are also focusing on securing their supply chains and leveraging regional partners, with 28% intending to increase intra-regional trade. The survey highlights the need for firms to develop more resilient contingency plans, with HSBC Singapore head of commercial banking noting the importance of preparedness for future shocks.

site_title: EU leaders agree landmark 750b euro recovery deal
summary: EU leaders have approved a 750-billion-euro stimulus package to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak, the deepest recession in EU history. The package, backed by Germany and France, includes grants and loans to countries hardest hit by the virus, with spending controlled by the European Commission and aligned with EU priorities. The deal marks a historic victory for French President Emmanuel Macron, who has strengthened the EU's commitment to solidarity and economic reform.

images.alt_text: EU leaders on Tuesday approved a landmark stimulus package to fight the withering aftershocks of the coronavirus outbreak that has sunk Europe into its deepest recession in history.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB reiterates 'add' on Singapore hospitality Reits, says market has priced in downside risks
summary: CGS-CIMB has reiterated its "add" call on Singapore hospitality Reits, including Ascott Residence Trust (ART), CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT), and Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT). The analysts believe the market has factored in potential downside risks, with the Reits trading at 0.6-0.8 times book value. Despite a lack of near-term catalysts for share price outperformance, the analysts see value in the sector, citing a significant decline in asset valuation.

site_title: JB-Singapore rail link agreement to be inked on July 30
summary: Malaysia and Singapore will sign agreements on July 30 to finalize the Johor Baru-Singapore Rapid Transit System (RTS) Link project, a delayed rail network connecting Woodlands North to Bukit Chagar. Construction is set to begin in January 2023, with operations expected to start by end-2026. The project is estimated to cost RM3.70 billion (S$1.20 billion). The KTM Tebrau Shuttle Service will cease operations six months after the RTS Link becomes operational.

site_title: Gambling addiction spikes among South Korea's work-from-home day traders
summary: Gambling addiction has tripled in South Korea among day traders working from home due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with 214 calls for help reported in May. Retail investors, known as "ants," surged in the stock market after a virus-induced sell-off, leading to a 50% stock-price surge. Experts warn that the trend may worsen if social distancing measures remain in place, as isolated individuals have fewer mechanisms to check addictive behavior.

site_title: Australia extends stimulus spending as 'Covid recession' looms
summary: Australia's government has extended its record stimulus spending into next year, aiming to shield the labor market from the impact of the COVID-19 crisis. The government will continue to support the unemployed and businesses until at least the end of the year and possibly beyond, with a focus on increasing stimulus spending to around A$86 billion. This move comes as Australia is poised to enter its first recession in almost 30 years, with double-digit unemployment and a new wave of lockdowns in Melbourne. The stimulus program has already helped retain around 3.5 million staff.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 2.58 points to 1,592.03, with a 0.16% gain. Volume reached 435.99 million lots worth RM195.42 million, with gainers beating losers 276 to 83.

site_title: Florida teachers sue to stop school openings as virus rages
summary: Florida's main teachers union, the Florida Education Association, sued Governor Ron DeSantis and authorities to stop schools from reopening in August amid a surge in Covid-19 cases. The union claims the state constitution requires a "safe and secure" environment, which it believes cannot be achieved with the current pandemic situation. Florida reported 10,347 new Covid-19 cases and 90 deaths, bringing the total death toll to 5,072. The union's lawsuit seeks to halt school reopenings until the virus is under control.

site_title: Microsoft president raised Apple issues to US House antitrust group
summary: Microsoft President Brad Smith expressed concerns to the US House antitrust subcommittee about Apple's anti-competitive behavior around its app store, echoing concerns raised by European regulators. Smith, who also led Microsoft's antitrust battle with the US government in the late 1990s, stated that app store rules create a higher barrier to competition than Microsoft's Windows operating software. The issue comes as Apple faces an investigation into its policies, which may force developers to share app store revenue with the company. The House Judiciary Antitrust Subcommittee will hold a hearing on July 27 with Apple and other tech executives.

site_title: Hotels nix mints and breakfast buffets. Hand sanitizer, anyone?
summary: Hotels are drastically changing their amenities due to the coronavirus pandemic, prioritizing guest safety and reducing interaction between guests and staff. Amenities such as free breakfast buffets, mints, and turndown service have been eliminated, and housekeeping services are often by request or eliminated. Hotels are focusing on delivering a sense of safety, with measures like hand sanitizer, plexiglass barriers, and contactless controls. The hospitality industry is reimagining amenities to create a "new normal," with a focus on local clientele and solo travelers, and exploring new revenue streams to offset declining occupancy rates.

site_title: Tech startups leaving Hong Kong due to security law eye move to US, UK, Singapore
summary: Hong Kong tech startups are fleeing the city due to China's national security law, which took effect this month. Many are relocating data and people to the US, UK, and Singapore, citing concerns over online policing powers and implications for overseas clients. Large tech firms, including Facebook, Google, and Twitter, are assessing the impact of the law, while a recent survey found that about half of US business people plan to leave Hong Kong. The move may foreshadow similar decisions from larger firms and signal a significant shift in the city's tech scene.

site_title: With tourists gone, Bali workers return to farms and fishing
summary: Bali, Indonesia, has seen a significant impact from the coronavirus pandemic, with thousands of workers returning to their villages and traditional ways of making a living. Many have left their jobs in the tourism industry, where over half of the island's economy depends, to work on farms, in fishing, or through bartering. The pandemic has forced hotels and tourist facilities to lay off workers, and some have turned to farming or fishing as a means of survival. The island's economy has suffered, with a decline in tourism and a rise in unemployment, with some communities relying on food aid to support those affected.

site_title: Fraud Detection Using Machine Learning Amid Covid-19 crisis
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in e-commerce and illicit activities, with over 164 million sensitive records exposed in 2019 US data breaches. As a result, fraud cost the world economy over $5 trillion in 2019. Traditional rule-based fraud detection systems have become intractable due to exponentially growing transaction volumes. Machine learning has emerged as a solution, but its effectiveness is threatened by rapidly changing patterns and limited data. Companies must invest in talent and robust big-data pipelines to cope with the current situation, and individuals must be vigilant about protecting their personal and transaction details.

site_title: High household energy use could thwart US emissions cuts, a study warns
summary: A US study warns that high household energy use could thwart the country's emissions cuts, accounting for one-fifth of total greenhouse gas emissions. Researchers found that Americans' preference for bigger houses and spacious suburbs contributes to the emissions divide between the rich and the poor. To address this, the study suggests rethinking household living, considering smaller homes, denser neighborhoods, and energy-efficient building materials. The country risks a "carbon lock-in" unless it commits to more energy-efficient homes and neighborhoods, with over 100 million new homes expected to be built in the next 30 years.

site_title: US sanctions 11 Chinese firms over Uighur rights violations
summary: The US Commerce Department has blacklisted 11 Chinese firms for their involvement in human rights violations against the Uighur minority in Xinjiang. The sanctions, which cut off access to American goods, target nine companies for forced labor and two for conducting genetic analyses used to repress Uighurs. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has called China's treatment of Uighurs "the stain of the century." Beijing denies wrongdoing, stating Uighurs are attending vocational training centers, while accusing the US of hypocrisy. The move is part of a growing international pressure on China over its treatment of the minority group.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on vaccine hopes ahead of RBA minutes; New Zealand gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% on Tuesday, rebounding from a 0.6% fall the previous day, ahead of Reserve Bank of Australia minutes on the potential Covid-19 vaccine. Positive trial results from three vaccines boosted sentiment globally. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its highest level in several days.

site_title: Disney's ABC News sacks senior executive over allegedly racist comments
summary: ABC News, a unit of Walt Disney Co, has sacked senior executive Barbara Fedida after an independent investigation found her to have made racially insensitive comments and used inappropriate language. The investigation also found no basis for dozens of HR complaints against her and no evidence of millions of dollars in settlements. Fedida denied the allegations, but her role will be split to enhance the culture of inclusion at ABC.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia sees no need to adjust policy measures, negative rates still unlikely
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has decided not to adjust its policy measures, maintaining the current accommodative approach as long as it's required. The cash rate remains at 0.25% and the RBA will continue to buy government bonds and maintain term funding facilities for banks. Board members reiterated that negative interest rates are "extraordinarily unlikely" and will reassess the situation if circumstances warrant. The decision comes as Australia faces a 22-year high in unemployment and its first recession in nearly three decades due to the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank saw no need to adjust its policy measures in the current environment, minutes of its July policy meeting showed on Tuesday, while board members reiterated that negative interest rates remained "extraordinarily unlikely".

site_title: Pompeo to meet UK PM in heat of China standoff
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is set to meet British Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Tuesday amid a diplomatic standoff with China. The meeting follows London's decision to sever ties with Chinese tech giant Huawei and Beijing's treatment of Hong Kong. Pompeo's previous visit to London in January was frosty, with him accusing Britain of endangering Western intelligence-sharing by partnering with China. The meeting is seen as a response to Britain's move and the US's concerns over China's growing influence in the region.

site_title: SoftBank takes out US$700m from Credit Suisse debt funds: sources
summary: SoftBank Group has redeemed US$700 million from Credit Suisse debt funds that invest in loans arranged by billionaire financier Lex Greensill. The move comes after Credit Suisse reviewed its supply-chain finance funds to address investor concerns about conflicts of interest. The funds, which hold short-term corporate loans, have financed startups backed by SoftBank's Vision Fund. The redemption comes amid outflows from the funds due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Rapper Nicki Minaj announces pregnancy
summary: US rapper Nicki Minaj, 37, has announced she is pregnant, sharing photos on Instagram of her baby bump. This will be her first child, born to her husband music executive Kenneth Petty. Minaj had previously teased her pregnancy in May and announced her retirement from music in September, before later reversing her decision. The news comes after Minaj's surprise marriage to Petty in October, which surprised her 119 million followers.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher after Wall Street gains; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 2,631.53, following overnight gains on Wall Street driven by technology giants. The market saw 108 gainers and 26 losers, with 66.3 million securities worth S$83.5 million changing hands. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: EMA seeks proposals to develop NB-IoT electricity meters for Singapore households
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has issued a call for proposals to develop and test-bed advanced electricity meters using the Narrowband Internet-of-Things (NB-IoT) technology. The meters will enable secure and cost-effective remote meter reading and data transmission, aiming to improve energy efficiency and reduce consumption. The proposal aims to roll out advanced meters to over 1.4 million households by 2024, as part of Singapore's national drive towards greater energy efficiency. The call for proposals closes on September 24, 2020.

site_title: Top Democrats 'gravely concerned' over foreign interference in US election
summary: Top US Democrats expressed concern over foreign interference in the upcoming presidential election, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi stating they are "gravely concerned" about a concerted foreign campaign to spread disinformation. The campaign appears to target congressional activity, public debate, and the presidential election. Senior Democrats, including Chuck Schumer, called for an urgent intelligence briefing from the FBI to discuss the issue.

images.alt_text: "We are gravely concerned, in particular, that Congress appears to be the target of a concerted foreign interference campaign, which seeks to launder and amplify disinformation in order to influence congressional activity, public debate, and the presidential election in November," said House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the Senate's senior Democrat Chuck Schumer and two others in a letter.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally out of blocks
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied 1.47% on Tuesday, driven by hopes for a virus vaccine after promising early test results. The Hang Seng Index rose 369.07 points to 25,427.06. China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also saw gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.49% and the Shenzhen Composite Index up 0.25%. The rally follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes as investors remain optimistic despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Temasek's one-year return turns negative, portfolio value dips to S$306b
summary: Temasek Holdings' one-year total shareholder return (TSR) has turned negative, dropping to -2.3% for the 12 months ended March 31, 2020. The state investment firm's preliminary net portfolio value stands at S$306 billion, 2.2% below the year-ago S$313 billion. Despite a sharp market correction in the first quarter due to the Covid-19 pandemic, Temasek's portfolio has shown resilience, with a 2.3% decline compared to the MSCI Singapore Index and MSCI AC Asia ex-Japan Index. The firm's long-term performance remains strong, with a 16-year TSR of 7.5%.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings' one-year total shareholder return (TSR) has fallen into negative negative territory, to -2.3 per cent for the 12 months ended March 31, 2020, according to its preliminary portfolio performance released on Tuesday.

site_title: China says UK will 'bear the consequences' after Hong Kong extradition treaty suspended
summary: China has warned the UK that it will "bear the consequences" if it continues to interfere with China's internal affairs, following the UK's decision to suspend its extradition treaty with Hong Kong. The UK's actions have repeatedly violated international law and norms, according to China's embassy to the UK. The statement comes after the UK announced the suspension, which has been met with criticism from China.

site_title: Asia: Markets advance on hopes for vaccine, focus on EU summit
summary: Asian markets advanced on Tuesday, driven by hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine and optimism over a potential EU stimulus package. Two clinical trials reported promising results, with a British trial showing a candidate vaccine induced strong immune responses and a Chinese trial showing widespread antibody responses. The positive news pushed Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Tokyo higher, while Sydney, Seoul, and Singapore also saw gains. Traders are keeping an eye on the EU summit, where leaders are battling to reach an agreement on a $860 billion rescue package, with expectations a deal will eventually be reached.

images.alt_text: The positive news from various Covid-19 vaccine trials could be a major step towards the Holy Grail that analysts say will likely send markets soaring.

site_title: WeWork's Neumann selling California "Guitar House" for US$27.5m
summary: WeWork co-founder Adam Neumann is selling his 11-acre "Guitar House" property in California for $27.5 million, after purchasing it for $21.4 million in 2018. The mansion features seven bedrooms, a pool, and organic gardens. Neumann is seeking a buyer amid a legal battle with SoftBank Group Corp over the valuation of WeWork. His wealth has taken a hit due to the valuation decrease, and his family office recently participated in a fundraising round for a shared mobility startup. The sale comes as Neumann faces financial challenges.

site_title: Potential Hyflux investor Johnny Widjaja says funds earmarked for deal; will address PnP holders
summary: A potential investor, Johnny Widjaja, has made a formal offer to rescue Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment company, by purchasing some of its senior debts. Widjaja, a 57-year-old Indonesian businessman, has set aside S$200 million for the purchase and has set a minimum offered discount of 91%. He aims to address concerns of Hyflux's perpetual security and preference share holders in the last quarter of this year. This comes after Aqua Munda, another interested investor, offered to buy back debt at a 85% discount.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.43% to 22,815.60, and the Topix index increasing 0.19% to 1,579.99. The gains followed overnight surges in US high-tech stocks on hopes for strong earnings, despite the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Japan's core consumer prices flat, deflation risks remain
summary: Japan's core consumer prices remained flat in June, contrary to expectations of a decline, but deflation risks persist due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis. The economy is expected to contract more than 20% in the April-June period, with a modest recovery forecasted in the future. The Bank of Japan projects consumer prices to fall 0.5% this fiscal year and stay below its 2% target through 2023. A renewed spike in infections in Tokyo raises concerns about a second wave of infections and potential spending curtailment.

site_title: Singapore property tycoon to open 1,000 cloud kitchens across Asia
summary: Singapore property tycoon Kishin RK is launching 1,000 cloud kitchens across Asia, Europe, and the US, aiming to crack the lucrative home-delivery dining market. The move follows the surge in demand for food delivery services amid the coronavirus pandemic. TiffinLabs, founded by Kishin, will rent kitchens and roll out its own brands, partnering with existing delivery platforms. The company plans to have over 30 restaurant concepts serving 15 cuisines in at least 10 countries within the next 12 months, with the first kitchen set to open in the fourth quarter.

site_title: IBM beats estimates; sees gains as customers accelerate shift to cloud
summary: IBM reported a stronger-than-expected second-quarter profit, beating estimates, as large corporations accelerate their shift to cloud computing due to the coronavirus crisis. The company's cloud business revenue rose 30% to $6.3 billion, driven by demand for modernizing apps, moving workloads to the cloud, and automating IT tasks. Despite a 5.4% decline in total revenue, IBM's earnings per share exceeded analyst estimates, and shares rose 5% in after-hours trading. The company's focus on cloud computing has been boosted by the pandemic, with clients concentrated in large enterprises showing relatively more stability.

site_title: US black kids die at higher rates than white ones after surgery: study
summary: A US study of 172,549 children between 2012 and 2017 found that African-American children are 3.5 times more likely to die from surgery than white children, despite being relatively healthy at the time. The mortality rate was 0.02% among white kids and 0.07% among black children. Post-operative complications and serious adverse events also occurred more frequently in black children. Researchers point to medical, social, and economic factors as possible causes, including limited access to healthcare, poverty, and healthcare provider bias, but conclude that the problem has multiple causes and not a single cause-and-effect relationship.

images.alt_text: African-American children in the United States have a 3.5 times greater risk of dying from an operation than white kids, according to a study out Monday based on tens of thousands of children.

site_title: Pine Capital ordered to release review findings immediately
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has ordered Pine Capital to immediately release the findings of its independent review of Advance Capital Partners Asset Management (ACPAM), its sole operating subsidiary. The review was conducted by KordaMentha in response to allegations of potential conflict of interest and internal control lapses. Pine Capital was given multiple reminders to release the report, but it has yet to comply. Failure to comply may result in SGX RegCo releasing the report and/or its findings. Trading in Pine Capital shares has been suspended since March 2019.

site_title: Campus housing owner can survive digital migration, analysts say
summary: Analysts expect American Campus Communities Inc to attract students to off-campus housing despite pandemic fears and university shifts to online or hybrid classes. Students want the college experience, and off-campus housing offers easier sanitation and social distancing. Pre-leasing data shows 82.6% of properties were pre-leased as of May 31, surpassing last year's 84.9%. With time running out to make decisions, American Campus may benefit from universities' efforts to partner with off-campus housing to reduce dorm density. The company's shares have fallen 29% this year, but analysts expect a more positive outlook.

site_title: Europe: Stocks boosted by vaccine hopes, EU rescue fund optimism
summary: European stocks rose 0.9% on Monday, boosted by encouraging data on coronavirus vaccine candidates and EU leaders' framework agreement on a 750 billion euro recovery fund. An experimental AstraZeneca vaccine was safe and produced an immune response in its first human trial, while Pfizer and BioNTech provided promising data. The defensive healthcare index rose 1.2%, and the euro jumped to a four-month high, reversing earlier losses.

site_title: Oil steady as virus infections rise but hopes for vaccine lends support
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Monday as coronavirus cases increased globally, but hopes for a potential Covid-19 vaccine lent support. Brent crude rose 14 cents to $43.28 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate increased 22 cents to $40.81 per barrel. Despite a surge in infections, prices found support after promising vaccine results from AstraZeneca and Pfizer, and ongoing talks over a European Union recovery fund. However, fuel demand remains below pre-pandemic levels, and rising tensions between China and the US continue to put pressure on prices.

site_title: Scaled-down hajj pilgrimage to start July 29: Saudi authorities
summary: Saudi authorities announced that this year's hajj pilgrimage, scaled back due to the coronavirus pandemic, will begin on July 29. Only around 1,000 Muslim pilgrims will participate, with the stand of pilgrims on Mount Arafat taking place on Thursday. The scaled-back event marks a significant reduction from previous years, highlighting the ongoing impact of the pandemic on global travel and religious gatherings.

images.alt_text: This year's hajj, which has been scaled back dramatically to include only around 1,000 Muslim pilgrims due to the coronavirus pandemic, will begin on July 29, Saudi authorities said Monday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Reit, Mapletree Logistics Trust, First Reit, Singapore banks
summary: Stocks to watch on Tuesday include Keppel Reit, Mapletree Logistics Trust, and First Reit, with Keppel Reit's DPU exceeding expectations despite a 7.2% drop in net property income. Mapletree Logistics Trust's DPU rose 1% for the first quarter. First Reit warned of a 40-50% decline in available distribution income due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Singapore banks DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank also saw price movements, with DBS and UOB falling, and OCBC rising.

site_title: US: Nasdaq jumps 2.5% to fresh record as big tech shares soar
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index surged 2.5% to a fresh record of 10,767.09, driven by strong gains from tech giants such as Amazon and Microsoft ahead of their upcoming earnings reports. In contrast, the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained less, with the latter rising 0.8% to 3,251.84. The strong performance was seen as a sign of investor confidence despite ongoing trade uncertainty and tariff threats.

site_title: Global banks look to Taiwan expansion in shift away from Hong Kong
summary: Global banks are shifting their focus to expanding in Taiwan due to China's passage of a security law in Hong Kong, which has prompted some firms to reevaluate their Asian strategies. Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission is welcoming foreign banks with assets in the country, including Citigroup, Standard Chartered, and HSBC Holdings. The island aims to capitalize on a potential exodus of financial professionals from Hong Kong, which has seen record immigration and investment from the territory in 2019. Taiwan plans to relax rules and align its financial regulation to international standards to lure foreign investment and increase its competitiveness.

site_title: Creditors reject Argentina's debt restructure, make new offer: statement
summary: Argentina's proposal to restructure US$66 billion of debt has been rejected by three creditor groups, who made a counter offer to the government. The creditors stated that Argentina's offer is "short of what the creditor groups can accept" and would not meet the August 4 deadline to find an agreement. The rejection marks a setback for President Alberto Fernandez's government, which was seeking to find a solution to the country's debt crisis.

site_title: UK housing mini-boom is gathering pace
summary: The UK housing market is experiencing a mini-boom after a tax cut by finance minister Rishi Sunak, with agreed sales in England jumping 35% in the five days following the July 8 announcement. Prices sought by home sellers rose 3.7% to a record high average of £312,625, and buyer enquiries jumped 75% across Britain. This recovery is seen as a sign of activity returning "quite strongly" in the housing market, according to Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey.

site_title: Logitech raises FY outlook, quarterly operating profit jumps more than 75%
summary: Logitech International raised its 2021 fiscal year outlook and reported a 75% increase in non-GAAP operating income in its first quarter. The increase was driven by demand for webcams, video conferencing products, and headsets due to the COVID-19 lockdowns that led to an increase in homeworking. The company now forecasts 10-13% sales growth for the year, up from a mid single-digit percentage gain in constant currency.

images.alt_text: "Logitech's business was already positioned to grow from these long-term trends, and since early March they have accelerated, making Logitech more relevant to customers than ever before," said chief executive Bracken Darrell.

site_title: Keppel Reit's Q2 DPU up 0.7% at 1.4 Singapore cents
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 0.7% increase in its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.4 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from T Tower in Seoul and lower borrowing costs. Despite a 7.2% decline in net property income, the company's distributable income rose 0.4% to S$47.5 million. The company has implemented tenant-support measures, including rent deferrals and security deposit offsets, to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: August looms as uncertain deadline for jobless Americans
summary: Unemployed Americans face uncertainty as a $600 per-week jobless benefit payment set to expire on August 1. The payment, financed through July 31, has been a lifeline for millions affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. With hiring not yet picking up in many areas, lawmakers must act to extend the payment to support those struggling financially. The expiration of the benefit poses a critical challenge for those relying on it to stay afloat.

site_title: Julius Baer posts record H1 profit but shares slip on fears boost might be unsustainable
summary: Julius Baer, a Swiss wealth manager, reported a record 4% jump in first-half net profit to 491 million Swiss francs, driven by frenetic client trading during the Covid-19 pandemic. However, shares fell 4% on concerns that the boost may be unsustainable, with analysts citing a dependence on trading and declining gross margins. The bank's assets under management fell 6% to 401.8 billion francs, despite inflows from Europe and Asia.

site_title: MBS settling lawsuit with US$9.1m payment
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) has agreed to settle a lawsuit with a former casino patron, Wang Xi, for US$9.1 million. As part of the out-of-court settlement, MBS will allow Wang Xi to re-enter the casino as long as he adheres to its policies. The non-admission of liability from both sides is part of the agreement, which ends a dispute that triggered probes into MBS' anti-money laundering procedures. The settlement also comes as Singapore considers tighter regulations at its casinos to prevent money laundering and financing for terrorism.

site_title: Balestier Road mixed-use building up for sale with S$22m guide price
summary: A freehold, four-storey mixed-use building at 320 Balestier Road in Singapore is up for sale with a guide price of S$22 million. The building has a total GFA of 18,310 sq ft, featuring two shop units on the ground floor and six apartments on the third and fourth floors. The second floor can be used for retail, offices, or student housing, and the basement has nine carpark lots. The property is zoned for commercial and residential use, with a potential rental yield of 4% per annum.

site_title: Thai labour minister resigns, 6th to quit PM Prayut's Cabinet
summary: Thai Labour Minister Chatumongol Sonakul resigned, becoming the sixth minister to quit Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha's Cabinet since last week. The resignation is part of a Cabinet reshuffle as Thailand recovers from the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stocks rallied for the 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data, driven by a 9.8 times oversubscription of NTT DC Reit's public offer. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls for the 2nd half of the year. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. MAS and the PBOC also announced plans to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. The US stock market opened lower amid fresh tariffs on Canada.

site_title: Vaccine studies offer new hope as WHO warns on Africa
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warns of a possible acceleration of the COVID-19 pandemic in Africa, particularly in South Africa, where the death toll has surpassed 5,000. Meanwhile, two vaccine studies published in The Lancet medical journal show progress towards a vaccine, with one trial inducing strong antibody and T cell immune responses in Britain and a separate trial in China showing widespread antibody immune response. European leaders are struggling to reach a consensus on a 750-billion-euro coronavirus aid package for the EU, while the US sees a surge in new cases, with President Donald Trump tweeting a picture of himself wearing a face mask.

site_title: Opec has new competitor as China ships oil from swelling storage
summary: China is shipping oil from its swelling storage tanks to international buyers, marking a new competitor to OPEC in the global market. One million barrels of crude have been procured via the Shanghai futures exchange and shipped to regional refiners, primarily in South Korea. This move underscores the fragility of oil's recovery, as China's purchases slowed and some stockpiles are now hitting the market. The shipments are being driven by rising inventories and attractive prices, with traders taking advantage of arbitrage opportunities facilitated by Saudi Arabia and other OPEC producers.

site_title: Billionaires hunt for real estate bargains in shadow of pandemic
summary: Billionaires are actively investing in real estate as the pandemic subsides, with 121 family offices surveyed by UBS Group seeking to increase their property allocations. This is driven by the pandemic's impact on the market, creating opportunities for cash-rich investors with long-term outlooks. Many wealthy individuals, including David and Simon Reuben, are targeting residential property, and the pandemic has highlighted the importance of diversification for ultra-high-net-worth individuals.

site_title: Jonas Kaufmann's intimate and sublime singing
summary: Jonas Kaufmann's intimate and sublime singing has been showcased through online performances during the coronavirus pandemic. The Metropolitan Opera began streaming nightly operas from its video archive, featuring singers from around the world. This free offering has been well-received but raises concerns that listeners may take free performances for granted as cancellations continue.

site_title: Saudi Real Estate Refinance to buy mortgage portfolio from pension agency
summary: Saudi Real Estate Refinance Co (SRC) agreed to buy a mortgage portfolio worth over 3 billion riyals (S$1.11 billion) from the Saudi Public Pension Agency. The deal aims to provide liquidity to the real estate financing market, potentially lowering prices and increasing mortgage originations. SRC's goal is to improve homeownership rates in Saudi Arabia, which aims to reach 70% by 2030. The move comes amid a severe economic downturn in the kingdom, caused by the coronavirus crisis and lower oil prices. The deal is expected to help the Saudi Public Pension Agency provide more mortgages to people.

site_title: Chevron buys Noble Energy in US$5b deal
summary: Chevron has agreed to buy Noble Energy in an all-stock deal valued at US$5 billion, or US$10.38 per share, representing a 7.5% premium to Noble's Friday close. The deal would add assets in the DJ Basin of Colorado and the Permian Basin, as well as potential annual cost savings of US$300 million. This comes after Chevron was forced to abandon its takeover bid for Anadarko Petroleum Corp last year. The deal values Noble at roughly US$13 billion, including debt.

site_title: A refined 'Gift' for a changed world
summary: The Governance Index for Trusts (Gift) has made adjustments to assess governance and business risk of Reits and business trusts, aiming to make the scoring more relevant to investors. The changes include broadening the desired experience of independent directors, incorporating disclosure of remuneration alignment and key performance indicators, and reallocation of audit points to the business risk component. The revised scoring methodology also includes a more graduated scale for awarding points and incorporates the latest available interim results. The adjustments aim to improve the relevance of the index to investors, particularly in light of the sector's current challenges and the impact of Covid-19.

images.alt_text: Developments, such as the discontinuation of mandatory quarterly reporting and the impact of Covid-19 on annual general meetings, have prompted other adjustments to Gift in 2020.

site_title: Creating Covid-19 vaccine not easy despite 2,000 ongoing clinical trials: scientists
summary: Scientists conducting over 2,000 Covid-19 vaccine trials worldwide are facing a challenging process, with many trials failing or showing limited efficacy. The trials, mostly focused on safety and immune response, are expected to take at least a year to complete, with some analysts predicting it may take two years or more for a successful vaccine to be ready. Despite efforts to fast-track development and share intellectual property, scientists acknowledge the difficulty in creating an effective vaccine, with some noting that even HIV vaccines, developed decades ago, remain elusive.

site_title: India plans to reduce number of state-owned banks to just five: sources
summary: India plans to privatize more than half of its state-owned banks, aiming to reduce the number of government-owned lenders to just five. The plan involves selling majority stakes in six state-owned banks, including Bank of India, Central Bank of India, and Punjab & Sind Bank. The move is part of an overhaul of the banking industry and aims to raise funds for the government due to the coronavirus pandemic's economic impact. The proposal is currently being formulated and will be put before the Cabinet for approval, with potential divestment plans delayed due to unfavorable market conditions.

site_title: Netflix show on Indian matchmaker stokes debate on wedding culture
summary: A new Netflix series "Indian Matchmaking" has sparked debate on arranged marriages in India, featuring real-life matchmaker Sima Taparia. The show highlights the high demands of potential brides and grooms, often centered around caste, height, and skin color. Critics have mocked the show's portrayal of picky individuals and their parents, while others have praised the series for shedding light on the complexities of Indian wedding culture. The show has become a top-ranked India series on Netflix, fueling the ongoing discussion about arranged marriages and cultural expectations in the country.

images.alt_text: A new Netflix show about an Indian matchmaker catering to the high demands of potential brides and grooms, and their parents, has stoked an online debate about arranged marriages in the country.

site_title: Acra seeking public feedback on proposed changes to Companies Act
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) in Singapore is seeking public feedback on proposed amendments to the Companies Act, which include 36 legislative reforms aimed at facilitating digitalisation, simplifying financial reporting, and safeguarding shareholders' interests. The reforms cover aspects such as digital meetings, financial reporting obligations, and reduced financial statements for micro companies. The public consultation exercise will run from July 20 to August 17.

site_title: Global banks suspend HK return-to-office plans as virus cases jump
summary: Global banks, including Citigroup and UBS Group, have suspended their return-to-office plans in Hong Kong due to a surge in coronavirus cases, with Citigroup asking most staff to work from home starting Monday. JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs also requested workers stay away from the office. The move follows a daily record of over 100 new cases in Hong Kong, prompting banks to prioritize employee safety.

site_title: Euro hits 4-month high as hopes rise for EU recovery fund deal
summary: The euro reached a 19-week high of US$1.1467 on Monday, driven by hopes for a European Union recovery fund deal to revive economies hit by the Covid-19 pandemic. EU leaders made progress in Brussels, but remain at odds over the fund's composition. Analysts say a smaller grant amount would negatively impact the euro, while a deal would boost confidence and push the currency higher. A US$1.1495 level could take the euro to a year-and-a-half high, and analysts expect the euro to continue to rise if a deal is reached.

site_title: BP Singapore oil traders placed on leave amid disputed deals
summary: BP plc has placed several personnel from its Singapore-based crude oil team on leave amid disputes between banks and other trading houses. Three trading staff and one manager were put on leave after they were mentioned in court documents, focusing on BP's oil sales to Chinese customers. The company is conducting internal investigations into the matter.

site_title: LNG traders store fuel at sea in oil-style bet ahead of winter
summary: Liquefied natural gas (LNG) traders are expected to store fuel at sea ahead of winter, taking advantage of a "contango" pricing structure and low freight rates. The strategy involves locking in higher prices for future months when demand is expected to peak. Currently, 27 LNG vessels are floating storage, a record high, and this number is expected to increase to 50 by late October. Traders see opportunities for price arbitrage, but warn that the contango structure could collapse if forecasts for colder winter weather or economic recoveries from Covid-19 reverse.

site_title: First Reit to extend rental relief - but manager sounds profit warning in H1 results
summary: First Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, is extending rental relief to tenants for two months due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a total cost of S$19.6 million. The extension comes with a profit warning, expecting a 40-50% decline in available distribution income and a 50-60% decline in total return after tax for the first half of the year. The prolonged pandemic has significantly impacted businesses globally, including First Reit's assets, leading to a decline in revenues for its healthcare assets.

site_title: Global market rally may not be irrational
summary: Global stock markets are experiencing a remarkable rally, despite a global economic downturn, with the Straits Times Index in Singapore rising over 400 points since its nadir in March. Economists expect a recovery by the end of 2021, driven by aggressive fiscal and monetary responses to the crisis and the prospect of a vaccine being discovered by mid-2021. The rally may be rational, as investors are anticipating a future economic recovery and pricing in a historical return of 7-10% per year. However, risks remain, including ongoing virus outbreaks and US-China trade tensions, which could lead to a more serious currency crisis or a W-shaped recovery.

site_title: Britain suspends extradition treaty with HK, raising tensions with China
summary: Britain has suspended its extradition treaty with Hong Kong amid a dispute with China over the introduction of a national security law. The treaty suspension and extension of an arms embargo were announced by Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab to Parliament. This move escalates tensions between Britain and China, following concerns over Hong Kong's autonomy and human rights.

site_title: Pandemic inadvertently helps Opec win market battle
summary: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has gained market share and influence due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to a significant decrease in global oil demand. The pandemic resulted in a 16.5 million barrels per day (b/d) drop in oil demand, forcing non-Opec producers to reduce output and some to go bankrupt. As prices rose to around $40 per barrel, some lost output returned, but overall US crude oil production is expected to average 11.74 million b/d in 2020, down from 12.24 million b/d in 2019. Opec+ has also eased its record production cuts, with demand for Opec crude expected to rise to 28.7 million b/d in 2021.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Group seeks US$200b in biggest IPO in years
summary: Ant Group, the parent of China's largest mobile payment company, is seeking a valuation of over $200 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong and Shanghai. The company, valued at $150 billion in its last funding round, generated $2 billion in profit in the fourth quarter. Ant aims to diversify its business and defend its dominance in China's $29 trillion mobile payments space. The IPO, which could be the largest in years, is seen as a triumph for Shanghai's STAR board and a renaissance for tech listings in Hong Kong.

site_title: Sabana Reit has more to gain in proposed merger with ESR-Reit
summary: Sabana Reit is set to gain more from a proposed merger with ESR-Reit, with the deal expected to be 18.7% accretive to Sabana Reit's distribution per unit (DPU). The merger will see ESR-Reit take on Sabana Reit's $460 million debt and lower its interest rate, while also providing Sabana Reit with a $58.6 million upfront payment. The deal has led to a 26% discount in Sabana Reit's implied offer price, but analysts see it as an attractive trade-off for unitholders. The merger is expected to make ESR-Reit a more competitive player in the S-Reit sector, potentially leading to index inclusion and higher unit prices.

site_title: Tesla, Toyota Motors help obscure Japanese supplier to thrive
summary: Odawara Engineering Co., a Japanese manufacturer of coil-winding machines, is thriving despite the COVID-19 pandemic due to its strong ties with major clients like Tesla and Toyota Motors. The company's shares jumped 21% after BloombergNEF predicted a 10% annual growth in the global market for coil-winding machines, reaching $1.3 billion by 2024. Odawara Engineering maintains its forecast for operating profit and revenue, citing robust demand for its machines and its focus on innovation, including "hairpin" winding machines to improve efficiency and performance.

site_title: MLT's Q1 DPU up one per cent at 2.045 Singapore cents
summary: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust (MLT) has declared a 1% increase in its first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.045 Singapore cents, driven by a 5.7% growth in distributable income to S$77.8 million. Net property income rose 12% to S$118.8 million, while gross revenue increased 10.5% to S$132.4 million. Portfolio occupancy remained stable at 97.2%, and the weighted average lease expiry was unchanged at 4.3 years. MLT's diversified geographic presence and tenant mix continue to provide resilience to the pan-Asia portfolio.

site_title: EU tax ruling on Apple in Ireland puts focus back on taxation of MNCs
summary: The European Union's General Court ruled that US tech giant Apple did not receive 13 billion euros in state aid from Ireland, despite an initial European Commission order in 2016. The ruling, which dates back to 2016, has sparked debate on taxation of multinational corporations (MNCs) in the EU. The decision has been seen as a victory for free marketeers, but also raises concerns about MNCs shifting profits to lower-tax jurisdictions. The EU is now exploring new measures to crack down on tax deals with big companies and ensure a level playing field among member states.

site_title: Once a model for infection control, HK grapples with new coronavirus wave
summary: Hong Kong, once a model for controlling the coronavirus, is experiencing a new wave of infections, with 73 cases reported on Monday, the highest total since the pandemic began. The city's robust contact tracing system has failed to determine the origin of many cases, and health officials are struggling to contain the spread. The government has imposed new restrictions, including mask mandates and dining bans, and is expanding testing of high-risk residents. The situation has been described as "very serious" by Carrie Lam, the city's chief executive, and there is concern that the outbreak may not be under control.

site_title: Cyber resilience key as SMEs step up digitalisation efforts
summary: Singaporean Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) are stepping up digitalization efforts, but must prioritize cyber resilience to protect against increasing threats. As remote work becomes the norm, hackers are targeting vulnerable systems. SMEs can mitigate this risk by conducting simulated spear phishing campaigns, securing digital infrastructure with VPNs and multi-factor authentication, and transferring risk via cyber insurance. By taking these steps, SMEs can confidently navigate the digital landscape and minimize the financial impact of a cyber event.

site_title: Japan exports sink again in June, raising economic risks
summary: Japan's exports plummeted 26.2% in June, the fourth consecutive month of decline, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global demand. Shipments to the US, Japan's main export market, fell 46.6% due to a decline in car exports. Exports to China and Asia also declined, with China's exports falling 0.2% and Asia's exports dropping 15.3%. The decline reinforces expectations of Japan's economy sinking into its deepest recession in decades, with a forecasted 5.3% contraction this fiscal year and a 3.3% bounce next year.

site_title: SBS Transit trials plastic shields on buses to protect drivers
summary: SBS Transit has begun a two-week trial of plastic shields on six buses in Singapore to minimize contact between drivers and passengers during the COVID-19 pandemic. The shields, made of polycarbonate, have modifications to allow drivers to easily exit their seats and maintain visibility. The trial aims to assess the usability and effectiveness of the shields, with results to be shared with the Land Transport Authority. The shields are part of a broader effort by ComfortDelGro, SBS Transit's parent company, to provide protective measures for its drivers.

site_title: Trio of Geylang shophouses on market with S$12m guide price
summary: A trio of freehold, two-storey shophouses at 223, 225, and 227 Geylang Road in Singapore are up for sale by expression of interest with a guide price of S$12 million. The site, zoned for commercial use with a plot ratio of 3.0, has 15m of unobstructed main road frontage and is a 10-minute walk from Kallang MRT station. The buyer can explore increasing the built-up area to 12,955 sq ft, subject to approval.
