summary: Singapore's physical retail landscape is slowly coming back to life as shops reopen in the second stage of the city state's phased reopening. However, retailers are urged to focus on digitalization to meet customers' new expectations, as the COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated online shopping and changed consumer behavior permanently. Experts warn that a full recovery for physical retail is not on the horizon, with sales remaining around 15% below pre-Covid peak. Retailers must adapt to the new normal by investing in digitalization, creating seamless omnichannel experiences, and leveraging data to drive growth.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for July 17-19, 2020, shows resistance in the capesize market, with all routes experiencing a small uptick in value. The market confidence is reflected in a backwardated forward curve, with a capesize 5TC spot level of $25,085, down to Q4 at $17-18k. The Atlantic basin has widened its premium over the Pacific to $9532. Panamax rates eased in all areas, with the Atlantic basin showing a wider premium. Ultramax/Supramax rates improved, but sentiment wavered in the US Gulf and east Mediterranean.

site_title: Yangzijiang thrives despite downturn, as LNG usage fuels demand for new ships
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (Holdings) has secured over half a billion dollars worth of new orders for commercial vessels, defying the economic downturn. The Singapore-listed shipbuilder plans to build four more vessels, following previous announcements. According to Yangzijiang executive chairman Ren Letian, the company has emerged stronger from previous market cycles, and its recent orders demonstrate resilience. This surge in demand for new ships is largely attributed to the increasing use of liquefied natural gas (LNG) as a fuel.

site_title: SkillsFuture Month 2020
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Month 2020 will feature mostly virtual and a few physical events, focusing on mid-careerists affected by the pandemic. Over 80 partners, including community, education, and industry organizations, are participating. Key activities include a virtual Jobs and Skills Fair, online workshops, and a week-long virtual programme on employability and lifelong learning. The events aim to reach 15,000 learners, including fresh and recent graduates, and are expected to run until August 16.

site_title: Minding the well-being of migrant workers
summary: In Singapore, social enterprises and a non-governmental organization partnered to provide mental health support to migrant workers during the pandemic. Hush TeaBar, SDI Academy, and The Art of Living Foundation (AOL) collaborated with Swiss Re Foundation and The Majurity Trust's SG Strong Fund to deliver self-care kits, online resources, and interaction services in Singapore Sign Language. The initiative aimed to address the well-being of migrant workers, who have been disproportionately affected by the pandemic.

site_title: National security laws shouldn't harm banks' operations: HK regulator
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission chief executive Ashley Alder has reassured global banks that China's new national security laws for the financial hub will not harm their operations. The regulator stated that the laws will not affect the "free flow" of information, a fundamental attribute of Hong Kong's status as an international financial centre. The move aims to alleviate concerns about the independence of analysts' research and the impact of retaliatory US sanctions on financial institutions. The laws, which punish activities deemed as secession or subversion, have been opposed by Britain and the US.

site_title: Sias objects to potential rescue offers for Hyflux that exclude PnPs
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association (Sias) has expressed opposition to potential rescue offers for Hyflux that do not include a "concrete proposal" to resolve the debts owed to its perpetual and preference share (PnP) holders. Sias has urged potential white knights, such as Utico, to make public the detailed terms of their offers and provide due diligence rights to PnP holders. The organization has also raised concerns over the arbitrary S$10,000 threshold for PnP holders and the lack of information on the share component of Utico's offer.

site_title: Intesa raises offer for UBI by adding 652m euros in cash
summary: Intesa Sanpaolo has sweetened its takeover offer for UBI Banca by adding 652 million euros in cash, increasing the premium to 45% as it tries to win approval from Italian investors hit by the pandemic. The offer, first announced in February, now includes an additional 57 cents for each share tendered. The move reverses Intesa's earlier refusal to change the terms, and two groups of local investors have accepted the offer, citing confidence in Intesa's ability to improve the terms. The offer period runs until July 28.

site_title: Gold climbs as growth risks remain, eyes sixth weekly gain
summary: Gold prices rose 0.7% to $1,808.85 per ounce, poised for its sixth consecutive weekly gain, amid growing uncertainty about an economic recovery due to a record-breaking rise in US coronavirus infections. A weaker US dollar and negative real interest rates also contributed to the surge. The dollar index eased 0.4% against its rivals, while investors await US lawmakers' discussion on new coronavirus aid programs and a proposed EU stimulus package.

site_title: China moves to further integrate trading of US$13.7t bond market
summary: China has further integrated its US$13.7 trillion bond market by allowing bond traders on the interbank market and stock exchanges to trade bonds listed on both venues. The move aims to reduce complexity and attract foreign investors. Analysts say the integration will make it easier for foreign investors to understand and trade in the market. The regulators will also establish a mutual nominal account to record outstanding bond values, further streamlining the process. This move is part of China's efforts to expand its bond market accessibility and attract more global investors.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: NagaCorp, a Hong Kong-listed gaming and leisure company, has received approval from Cambodia's Ministry of Health to reopen its casino businesses in Phnom Penh. The company's casino operations, including mass market, VIP, and slot gaming, will resume following the notification on July 18.

site_title: 257 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 8 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 257 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 47,912. The cases include 8 community cases, 5 imported cases, and the majority of cases among migrant workers in dormitories. The average number of new community cases decreased from 18 to 9 in a week, while unlinked community cases dropped from 9 to 5. 256 cases were discharged, with 169 in hospital and 3,626 recovering in community facilities.

site_title: Helping migrant workers amid the pandemic
summary: Citi Singapore, UBS, and The Food Bank have joined forces to support migrant workers amid the pandemic. Citi Singapore raised over S$176,000 through a company-wide fundraiser, while UBS donated S$650,000 to support The Food Pantry 2.0 in dormitories and low-income neighborhoods. The initiative aims to provide immediate basic needs, medical assistance, and counseling to shelter residents. The Food Pantry 2.0, launched in October, has been scaled up to provide 24/7 access to aid, with vending machines stocked with food and essentials.

site_title: Gold quickly approaching key resistance point
summary: Gold prices are approaching a key resistance point, similar to its all-time high in 2011. The metal has staged a U-shaped recovery, and various indicators, including stochastics, Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD), and price action, suggest a potential reversal. A reading above 80 on the stochastics oscillator indicates an overbought condition, while a fall in MACD histogram below the signal line signals a loss of bullish momentum. If all factors align, gold may undergo a reversal, targeting the 23.6% Fibonacci level at US$1,489.92.

site_title: Thailand forges new path for food exports to China amid pandemic
summary: Thailand is exploring a new logistics route to export perishable products to China, bypassing traditional routes through Vietnam or Laos due to pandemic-related disruptions. The country has started using a two-mode system, where products are trucked to Vietnam, then transported on trains to China. This method has reduced costs and delivery time, with potential to become a new system for Thai shipments. The plan to connect Thailand and China via rail is also underway, aiming to increase exports at a lower cost, particularly for tropical fruits that are vulnerable to supply chain delays.

site_title: Gold miners extend rally to longest in a year on metal's surge
summary: Gold miners are experiencing their longest winning streak in over a year, driven by investors seeking safe havens due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis. The metal's price rose 0.7% to $1,809.14 an ounce, with the gold mining sector expected to benefit from strong prices and streaming deals worth up to $3 billion. Analysts attribute the surge to concerns over rising Covid-19 infections and accommodative monetary policy, supporting demand for gold as a safe haven against economic uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore mall operators play key role to widen retailers' online reach
summary: Mall operators in Singapore are being urged to align themselves with the trend of retailers going online, as the Covid-19 pandemic has hastened this shift. Existing tensions between tenants and landlords may also be a factor, with some tenants seeking to build new channels of business. To remain relevant, malls need to reinvent themselves in the digital sphere, innovate, and break away from convention. Some malls, such as CapitaLand's eCapitaMall and Siam Center in Thailand, have already launched digital malls and virtual versions, while others, like Suntec City, have run livestreaming shopping festivals. Providing tenants with e-commerce platforms can benefit both tenants and mall operators.

site_title: LMIRT again extends long stop date for Pejaten, Binjai mall divestments
summary: LMIRT has extended the long stop date for its planned divestment of Pejaten Village and Binjai Supermall to July 23, after discussions with the buyer, NWP Retail. The original long stop date was July 10, and a further extension was made to July 17. The divestment deals, worth 1.28 trillion rupiah, were initially expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2020. The extensions are due to unforeseen circumstances arising from the Covid-19 pandemic in Indonesia.

site_title: Yields rise, but stay in tight range as investors weigh virus risks
summary: US Treasury yields rose 2 basis points to 0.628% on Friday, despite a surge in new coronavirus cases, as investors weigh the economic damage from shutdowns against a possible recovery. The yield has held in a tight range since mid-June, and the yield curve steepened 1 basis point. Home building increased in June by the most in nearly four years, but a resurgence in infections eroded consumer sentiment, threatening the nascent housing and economic recovery. The Treasury will sell $17 billion in 20-year bonds and $14 billion in 10-year TIPS next week.

site_title: Sam Goi adds to Hanwell and Envictus stakes
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a decline over the week, with the Straits Times Index falling 1.1% and the iEdge S-Reit Index falling 1.6%. There were only two primary-listed stocks conducting share buybacks, totaling S$36,051. Notable transactions include Sam Goi's increased stakes in Hanwell Holdings and Envictus International Holdings, with his total interest in Envictus rising to 24.90% and Hanwell Holdings reaching 18.07%.

site_title: Sias objects to Hyflux's potential rescue offers that exclude PnPs
summary: Sias, a Singapore securities association, objects to potential rescue deals for Hyflux that exclude holders of the company's perpetual and preference shares (PnPs). Sias chief David Gerald has expressed concerns over Utico's revised S$485 million cash and stock offer, citing a lack of detailed information for PnP holders and an arbitrary S$10,000 threshold for choosing between upfront and deferred payment options. Sias urges Utico and Hyflux to provide more clarity on the revised offer, including a formal valuation of the shares and release of claims against Hyflux directors.

site_title: Hong Kong tightens coronavirus restrictions as new cases hit record high
summary: Hong Kong tightened coronavirus restrictions on Sunday after reporting a record 100+ daily cases, bringing the total near 2,000 patients with 12 deaths. Non-essential civil servants were told to work from home, and 10 venues, including amusement parks and gyms, remain closed for seven days. Face masks are now mandatory in indoor public areas, and restaurants are restricted to takeaway service after 6pm. The move comes after a violent anniversary event for the 2019 Yuen Long attack, where 45 people were injured, was halted by police in riot gear.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam (centre) said at a news conference on Sunday that "the (coronavirus) situation is very serious and there is no sign of it coming under control".

site_title: US passenger flights to India can resume July 23
summary: US passenger flights to India can resume on July 23, following an agreement between the US and Indian governments. The Indian government had banned scheduled services due to the coronavirus, prompting the US Transportation Department to accuse India of unfair practices. The US Department of Transportation has withdrawn an order requiring Indian air carriers to apply for authorisation prior to charter flights and approved an Air India application for passenger charter flights. This move aims to restore a level playing field for US airlines under the US-India Air Transport Agreement.

site_title: China to connect interbank and exchange bond markets: PBOC
summary: China plans to connect its interbank and exchange bond markets, allowing qualified investors to buy and sell bonds in each other's markets via the "connect" infrastructure. This move aims to unify segregated bond markets, facilitate monetary policy transmission, and improve macroeconomic management. The interbank bond market, formed in 1997, is larger in terms of issuance and trading volume than the exchange bond market. The connection is expected to enhance market efficiency and promote financial integration.

site_title: Mainland China reports 22 new coronavirus cases, including 16 in Xinjiang
summary: Mainland China reported 22 new coronavirus cases, including 16 in Xinjiang's Urumqi city, on July 17. The city launched an emergency response plan to analyze confirmed cases and asymptomatic infections. The regional government attributed all recent new infections to Urumqi, with a total of 83,644 confirmed cases and 4,634 deaths reported. The city's measures, including flight cancellations and subway suspensions, aim to control the epidemic situation, which the director of the disease control centre described as "generally controllable."

site_title: Twitter disables Trump tweet over copyright complaint
summary: Twitter disabled a campaign-style video retweeted by President Donald Trump due to a copyright complaint from Machine Shop Entertainment, citing a Digital Millennium Copyright Act notice. The video featured music from Linkin Park and was removed from the president's Twitter feed. The incident occurred after the White House social media director, Dan Scavino, retweeted the video. This is not the first time Trump's tweets have faced copyright disputes.

site_title: KKR pursues deal for US$4b French clinic chain Elsan
summary: KKR is in talks to acquire French clinic chain Elsan for approximately $5.56 billion, as the private equity firm seeks to preempt a planned bidding process. Elsan's owner, CVC Capital Partners, plans to launch a broader sale process if a deal can't be reached with KKR. This deal would add to KKR's recent acquisitions, which total almost $22 billion since March, amid increased demand for healthcare services during the pandemic.

site_title: EU recovery fund plan hangs in the balance at deadlocked summit
summary: European Union leaders failed to reach a deal on a 1.8-trillion-euro recovery fund to combat the pandemic, with disagreements over spending levels and funding distribution among member states. The proposed 750-billion-euro recovery fund is at risk of being reduced, and a rule-of-law mechanism to freeze funding for countries flouting democratic principles remains unresolved. The impasse has raised concerns about the EU's ability to address the economic crisis and has sparked fears that the bloc's unity is under threat.

images.alt_text: From left: Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz, French President Emmanuel Macron, Luxembourg Prime Minister Xavier Bettel and European Council President Charles Michel.

site_title: NagaCorp gains green light to reopen Cambodian casino business
summary: NagaCorp has received approval from the Cambodian authorities to reopen its casino business in Phnom Penh, following a notification from the Ministry of Health on July 18. The company had signed a memorandum of understanding with the ministry on July 5. This decision comes after the Cambodian government announced in early July that it would permit all casinos in the country to reopen, subject to an agreement with the Ministry of Health. NagaCorp's shares rose 2.01% on Friday.

site_title: Luxury developer's stumble shows rising default risks in China
summary: China's luxury developer, Tahoe Group, has become the first large residential developer to default on a bond in five years, highlighting rising default risks in the country's housing market. The Fuzhou-based home builder, known for luxury villas, defaulted due to a global pandemic's impact on housing and capital markets. This incident underscores the challenges faced by China's developers, who have been paying top dollar for land during a time of low interest rates. The default may signal a broader issue in the Chinese property market, which has been experiencing significant fluctuations.

site_title: Inclusive growth amid Covid-19 is key task post-GE2020: Business leaders
summary: Singapore's General Election (GE2020) has highlighted the need for inclusive growth amid the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Business leaders expect the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) to maintain its global hub status for trade and talent despite calls for redistributive policies. However, they anticipate a focus on low-income groups and social spending to level the playing ground, potentially leading to increased tax increases and demands on Singapore's reserves. Despite this, business leaders believe Singapore will remain a global hub, with a shift towards more emphasis on sustainable growth and workforce development.

images.alt_text: With jobs still a key concern, there may be more focus on Singaporean workers with support for upskilling and incentives for employing locals, say business leaders.

site_title: Australian houses on the brink of collapse as wild seas batter the coast
summary: Wild storms on Australia's east coast have battered the coastline, causing erosion and threatening beachfront homes. Residents of Wamberal, about 90 km north of Sydney, were evacuated after emergency personnel warned their homes might collapse due to 11-meter waves. Plans to build a revetment wall to prevent erosion have been debated for a decade, and some residents are taking matters into their own hands to protect their homes. The situation is expected to continue, with the community expressing frustration and anxiety over the lack of action from authorities.

site_title: In Sweden, a 'second-hand' mall draws big crowds
summary: In Sweden, the city of Eskilstuna has opened a 5,000 sqm 'second-hand' mall called ReTuna, which attracts 250,000-300,000 visitors annually. The mall features 13 stores selling pre-owned items, including tech gadgets, furniture, and home goods, and offers a course in designing recycled products. Eskilstuna aims to be carbon neutral by 2045 and has made efforts to reduce waste and emissions, but critics say more work is needed to meet its climate goals. ReTuna was named the world's first shopping mall for repaired, recycled, and restored items by the Guinness Book of World Records in 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong security law sends jitters through city's feisty press
summary: Hong Kong's status as a bastion of press freedom is under threat due to the city's new national security law, which has sent jitters through the media landscape. The law, imposed in response to pro-democracy protests, grants authorities sweeping surveillance powers and allows them to "strengthen the management" of foreign news organizations. International media outlets, including The New York Times and CNN, are relocating staff or considering relocation due to visa issues. Local media are under pressure, with advertising drying up for critical outlets, and journalists fear self-censorship and increased surveillance.

site_title: US sets another virus record with 77,638 new cases: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US has recorded a record 77,638 new coronavirus cases, surpassing the previous day's total for the third consecutive day, according to Johns Hopkins University. The country has also seen 927 deaths, bringing the total fatalities to 139,128 out of 3.64 million confirmed cases. Experts believe the US never fully recovered from its first wave of infections, with surging cases in the south and west, particularly in California and Texas. Authorities are struggling to cope with the body count, with refrigerated trucks being brought in to deal with the rising number of deaths.

site_title: Twitter says attackers downloaded data from up to 8 non-verified accounts
summary: Twitter revealed that hackers accessed its internal systems and downloaded data from up to 8 non-verified accounts. The attackers targeted 130 accounts, resetting passwords and taking control of 45, including those of US presidential candidate Joe Biden, reality TV star Kim Kardashian, and billionaire Elon Musk. The hackers used these accounts to solicit digital currency, exploiting Twitter's systems. The company has not disclosed the names of the compromised accounts.

site_title: EV startup founder rides cash wave to reboot once-dashed dream
summary: Henrik Fisker, founder of EV startup Fisker Inc, is rebooting his once-dashed dream with a new battery-powered SUV, the Ocean, after securing a $50 million private investment and a reverse merger with a blank-check company. The five-seater SUV will start at under $40,000 and offer a flexible lease model. Fisker aims to be cash-flow positive within 12 months and envisions $3 billion in revenue by 2023, despite the competitive electric vehicle market and limited demand. The company's approach differs from Tesla's, with a focus on outsourcing manufacturing and sharing supply chains with larger automakers.

site_title: TikTok halts plans for global base in UK
summary: TikTok has suspended plans to establish a global headquarters in the UK, citing a backlash from the UK's decision to ban Huawei from its 5G network. The move comes amid tensions between the UK and China, with Beijing warning British companies of potential retaliation. The UK government's decision was reportedly influenced by US pressure, with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo set to visit London this week to discuss trade and other issues. The halted plans would have created 3,000 jobs.

site_title: 140,000 employers to get S$4b in Jobs Support Scheme payouts from July 29
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Finance announced that 140,000 employers will receive approximately S$4 billion in Jobs Support Scheme payouts starting July 29. This will help 1.9 million local employees receive their wages, bringing the total disbursed amount to over S$15 billion.

site_title: Thomson Medical expects net loss in 6M, 18M FY2020 on non-cash impairment
summary: Thomson Medical expects a net loss for the 6 months and 18 months ended June 2020 due to a non-cash impairment loss in Malaysia and weaker contributions from certain segments. The impairment loss occurred due to a decline in the market valuation of a 9.23ha freehold land in Johor Bahru, Malaysia, caused by political uncertainty and the Covid-19 pandemic. Weaker contributions from the specialist segment in Singapore and hospital and fertility operations in Malaysia also contributed to the expected losses.

site_title: US dollar falls, euro hovers at four-month high as EU negotiates rescue fund
summary: The US dollar fell, and the euro rose to a four-month high, hovering at US$1.144, amid EU leaders' struggles to reach consensus on a massive recovery fund to lift the bloc out of recession. Negotiations on a €1 trillion budget and a €750 billion recovery fund are ongoing, with a positive outcome potentially leading to fresh euro highs. A deal could make the euro more attractive as a reserve currency, establishing a central fiscal capacity and making monetary union more stable.

site_title: Singapore banks' H1 dividend unlikely to be shaken by regulator's capital review
summary: Singapore banks' H1 dividend payouts are unlikely to be impacted by the regulator's capital review, according to CGS-CIMB. Instead, payouts will depend on earnings impact from current operating environment and net interest margin (NIM) headwinds. DBS and OCBC are projected to pay S$0.33 and S$0.25 a share, respectively, while UOB's interim dividend is expected to compress to S$0.35-S$0.45 a share. NIM compression and revenue headwinds pose risks to dividend payouts, but banks' strong capital ratios and ability to maintain dividend policies suggest they can weather the challenges.

site_title: Stranded on ships, 200,000 seafarers struggle in virus limbo
summary: Over 200,000 seafarers worldwide are stranded on ships due to the coronavirus pandemic, with many having been trapped for months. The United Nations has warned of a growing humanitarian crisis, with reports of suicides and mental strain among the stranded workers. Several countries have vowed to recognize seafarers as "key workers" to help them get home. The International Labour Organization has highlighted the issue, with many workers completing their tours over four months ago and being exhausted. Efforts are being made to support the stranded workers, with some set to be transferred to other ships or return home in mid-August.

site_title: Good Food Hunting
summary: Singapore's western district is renowned for its food scene, offering a mix of seafood favorites and local delights. This week's "Good Food Hunting" series features seven restaurants, including Dancing Crab, Le Shrimp Ramen, The Alkaff Mansion, Sum Kee, Greendot, Eng's Wantan Noodle, and Penang Culture. These eateries offer a range of cuisines, from seafood to zi char and Asian-fusion, with options for island-wide delivery and various promotions. Prices vary, but most restaurants have a minimum order of $20-$50, with some offering discounts for larger orders.

images.alt_text: Penang Culture Malacca Seafood Cheese Bee Hoon

site_title: Australian brand Lorna Jane fined over 'anti-virus activewear' claim
summary: Lorna Jane, an Australian activewear brand, was fined nearly A$40,000 for claiming its "anti-virus" leggings and tops protected against the coronavirus. The Therapeutic Goods Administration said the claims were misleading and created a false sense of security, leading people to be less vigilant about hygiene and social distancing. Lorna Jane re-branded the clothing as "anti-bacterial" and stated it was meant to provide an added protection, not a full shield. The fine follows a similar punishment handed to celebrity chef Pete Evans for promoting a supposed coronavirus treatment.

images.alt_text: A popular Australian activewear brand has been fined for implying its "anti-virus" leggings and tops are effective at protecting wearers against the coronavirus, health officials said.

site_title: UK asks Japan for Huawei alternatives in 5G networks: Nikkei
summary: The British government asked Japan for assistance in building its 5G wireless networks without Huawei Technologies, following the UK's decision to purge Huawei equipment from its 5G networks by the end of 2027. NEC and Fujitsu are potential alternative suppliers, according to a report by Nikkei. This move is part of a global technology and security war between the US and China. British officials met with Japanese counterparts in Tokyo on Thursday, marking a further escalation in the dispute.

images.alt_text: The British government asked Japan to help build its 5G wireless networks without Huawei Technologies.

site_title: Oil giant Total obtains US$14.9b to finance Mozambique gas project
summary: French oil giant Total has secured a $14.9 billion financing agreement for a liquefied natural gas (LNG) project in northern Mozambique, the largest financing deal in Africa to date. The project, valued at $23 billion, includes loans from eight export credit agencies, 19 commercial banks, and a loan from the African Development Bank. Despite uncertainties caused by the coronavirus pandemic and militant attacks, Total remains committed to the project, which has been plagued by jihadist insurgency and recent attacks on nearby villages.

site_title: Delta will avoid pilot furloughs if they agree to reduced minimum pay: memo
summary: Delta Air Lines has proposed reducing pilot guaranteed minimum pay by 15% for 12 months in exchange for a one-year guarantee of no furloughs. The move aims to prevent involuntary furloughs as the airline struggles with a 91% decline in second-quarter revenue due to the coronavirus pandemic. Delta has already seen over 17,000 employees accept voluntary departure packages, including 1,700 pilots. The airline is seeking to spread the workload among all pilots to preserve jobs.

site_title: EU extends summit to Sunday after deadlock over Covid recovery plan
summary: European Union leaders failed to agree on a massive stimulus fund to revive their economies on Saturday after two days of negotiations, extending their summit for another day. The 1.80 trillion-euro package was blocked by wealthy, fiscally "frugal" northern states, who favour repayable loans over free grants for hard-hit economies. The EU is seeking a deal to provide urgent support for citizens and economies amid the ongoing coronavirus crisis.

images.alt_text: European Union (EU) leaders failed to agree on a massive stimulus fund to revive their coronavirus-hammered economies on Saturday after two days of fraught negotiations, but extended their summit for another day to try and overcome their differences.

site_title: Rex up 4.6% after green light for Oman oilfield
summary: Rex International shares rose 4.6% after Oman authorities approved its plan to develop the Yunma field, part of its Block 50 licence. The oilfield services firm's shares initially dipped to an intra-day low before rebounding to a high of 19.3 Singapore cents. This development comes after the company announced its plan to develop the field.

site_title: Qian Hu swings into H1 loss, hurt by dearth of cargo flights
summary: Qian Hu, a Singapore-listed integrated fish service provider, has reported a net loss of S$525,000 for the first half of 2020 due to the coronavirus outbreak's impact on its sales. The company's fish segment, which accounts for its largest profit, swung into a loss, with fish sales declining 25.7% to S$11.9 million. However, its accessories segment fared better, posting a 2.2% increase in sales. The company's executive chairman, Kenny Yap, stated that the business outlook remains "extremely challenging" and that the company is positioning itself to weather the crisis.

site_title: Cloudflare says some customers are 'experiencing issues'
summary: Cloudflare reported issues affecting its customers worldwide, including Discord and Shopify, on Friday. The disruptions occurred in the US and Europe, impacting multiple websites. Cloudflare confirmed the issue, identified it, and is implementing a fix. The outage had global implications due to the company's widespread use in delivering web content and protecting against denial of service attacks. The company is currently investigating and has not returned calls or messages.

site_title: EU condemns US sanctions policy
summary: The EU's diplomatic chief, Josep Borrell, has condemned the US sanctions policy, criticizing its use of secondary sanctions on European companies. Borrell stated that the EU opposes the US policy of enforcing sanctions against companies and individuals worldwide, citing concerns over the threat of sanctions against European companies and interests. The US move to include the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in sanctions has sparked tension, with Germany, a major player in the project, likely to suffer sanctions for small investments.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly up but Netflix drops
summary: US stocks ended the week mostly higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dipping 0.2% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.3%. Despite a surge in US home construction, consumer sentiment data from the University of Michigan missed expectations due to rising COVID-19 cases. Netflix dropped 6.5% after reporting flat second-quarter profits, while BlackRock jumped 3.7% after attracting $100 billion in new funds.

site_title: F1 reports two positive coronavirus tests at Hungarian Grand Prix
summary: Formula One reported two positive coronavirus tests at the Hungarian Grand Prix, the third race of the delayed 2020 season. A total of 4,997 tests were conducted on drivers, teams, and personnel from July 10-16. The FIA and Formula One stated that the two positive cases were among nearly 5,000 individuals tested.

site_title: All to play for as Premier League enters final week of the season
summary: The Premier League enters its final week of the season, with multiple teams still vying for Champions League and Europa League spots. Chelsea and Leicester City hold top four berths, but Manchester United's form could shake them up. Leicester faces Tottenham, while United hosts West Ham and Chelsea travels to Liverpool. The top four may change significantly before the final round of matches on July 26. The Europa League race is also intense, with sixth-placed Wolves guaranteed to qualify if they win their last two games. Meanwhile, teams like Norwich, West Ham, and Brighton are effectively safe from relegation, while Watford, Bournemouth, and Aston Villa fight for survival.

site_title: Singapore's tourism receipts down 39% to S$4b in Q1
summary: Singapore's tourism receipts decreased 39% to S$4 billion in Q1, primarily due to the Covid-19 pandemic. International visitor arrivals dropped 43.2% to 2.7 million. The shopping sector saw the largest decline, with takings halved to S$656 million. The decrease was observed across the board, affecting various sectors.

site_title: Ayala says it won't improve bid for Australia's Infigen Energy
summary: Philippine conglomerate Ayala Corp has decided not to improve its takeover bid for Australia's Infigen Energy, ending a month-long bidding war. Rival Spanish power generation company Iberdrola, which improved its offer by three cents, has now made its bid unconditional. Infigen Energy shareholders have been asked to reject Ayala's offer, with shares closing above Iberdrola's offer price. Iberdrola's bid values the company at A$856 million, following approval from Australia's Foreign Investment Review Board.

site_title: Some small companies could get second US relief loan: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced that small companies severely impacted by the coronavirus crisis could receive a second round of financing under the Paycheck Protection Program. The program, which launched in April, has $130 billion in unspent funds. Mnuchin favored a revenue test to determine eligible companies, but pledged to work with Congress to determine the size of the second round of financing. The announcement comes as the US unemployment benefits set to expire at the end of July, and economists credit federal support programs with limiting the impact on households.

site_title: Europe: Shares flat as EU recovery plan awaited; Ericsson soars
summary: Europe's stock market remained flat on Friday as investors awaited the outcome of a European Union summit to discuss a 750-billion-euro recovery fund. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's cautious comments suggested a potential delay in reaching a compromise. Meanwhile, shares rose globally, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index up 0.2% due to gains in automakers, commodity, and technology stocks. The US shattered its daily record for coronavirus infections, raising concerns about the world's largest economy.

site_title: SGUnited Skills Programme has over 1,000 sign-ups to date: SkillsFuture Forum 2020
summary: The SGUnited Skills Programme has seen over 1,300 sign-ups for its 113 training courses, with more than 6,500 places available. The programme, launched to support 100,000 job seekers, offers heavily subsidised training and a monthly allowance. A new programme, the SMU SGUnited Business and Digital Transformation Programme, has been launched to help mid-career professionals pivot into new careers, with 8 companies participating. The Education Minister emphasized the need for employers to be open-minded in their selection of trainees.

site_title: US divided over mask wearing and schools reopening as virus cases surge
summary: The US is divided over mask mandates and school reopenings as coronavirus cases surge. States and localities have chosen conflicting strategies, with some, like Georgia, banning mask mandates, while others, like Chicago, plan for in-person and remote instruction. Medical professionals, including over 1,200 nurses who have died from COVID-19, urge people to wear masks to prevent the spread of the virus. The US reported over 77,000 new infections, with nearly 140,000 deaths, prompting public health experts to plead for mask-wearing and caution against reopening schools.

site_title: SIA Engineering Q1 profit drops 74.3% to $10.7m
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) recorded a 74.3% net profit decline to S$10.7m in Q1 2020, mainly due to government support schemes like the Jobs Support Scheme. The company would have recorded a loss of S$36.7m without these schemes. Flight frequencies were severely impacted by the pandemic, with SIAEC handling only 13% of pre-pandemic flights at its Singapore base. Despite this, the company will continue transformation efforts and focus on digital technology.

site_title: Oil prices slip as coronavirus cases surge
summary: Oil prices dropped on Friday amid concerns about the surge in coronavirus cases, which is sapping fuel demand. Despite major crude-producing nations preparing to increase output, fuel consumption remains below pre-pandemic levels. The US reported a daily record of 75,000 new Covid-19 cases, while Spain and Australia also saw significant daily jumps. This led to a decline in fuel purchases as infections rise.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged lower on Friday as concerns about the surge in coronavirus cases sapping fuel demand while major crude-producing nations ready increases in output.

site_title: STI ends at 2,618.48 after dull, directionless session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index ended the day at 2,618.48, down 5.19 points or 0.2% after a dull, directionless session. The index saw 12 gains and 12 losses, with Rex International's shares rising 4.55% after receiving approvals for its Oman oil project. Other beneficiaries of the pandemic rebound included rubber glove makers Top Glove and UG Healthcare, which jumped 15.87% and 24.24%, respectively.

site_title: Singapore must prepare for, and prevent, second wave of Covid-19: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore must be prepared for a potential second wave of Covid-19, but this can be avoided by maintaining responsible behavior and adhering to safe-distancing rules, said Health Minister Gan Kim Yong. The country has seen an average of 12 new community cases per day, with around half linked to cases in Hong Kong, Australia, and Japan. To prevent a second wave, the taskforce will closely monitor symptomatic and unlinked cases, and consider localized control measures, such as shutting down high-risk premises, rather than a nationwide "circuit-breaker" approach.

site_title: 7% of employment contracts at Raffles Hotel not extended due to Covid-19
summary: Raffles Hotel has reported that 7% of its employment contracts will not be extended due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company will provide packages to affected colleagues and offer resume writing and interview coaching classes to help them find new jobs. This move comes as the tourism industry continues to suffer, with Singapore's tourism receipts dropping 39% in the first quarter of the year. Hoteliers are expected to adopt cost-saving measures, weighing the cost of re-hiring staff against letting them go, amid ongoing travel restrictions.

site_title: Plenty of warning signs as the NBA gets set to resume
summary: The NBA is set to resume its season on July 31 with a 22-team, eight-game wrap-up, followed by a possible play-in tournament for the eighth seed and playoffs. However, the return comes at a challenging time, with the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and rising cases in the US. Many players have opted out, including key players for the Brooklyn Nets, while others have expressed concerns about playing during the pandemic. Despite these concerns, the season's restart is expected to feature intense battles, including a potential Clippers-Lakers championship showdown and Giannis Antetokounmpo leading the Milwaukee Bucks to the NBA finals.

site_title: BlackRock takes firm action on companies' sustainability disclosures
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, has taken a firm stance on companies' sustainability disclosures. The company has written to 577 Asian companies, representing over 90% of the MSCI index, putting them on notice that it expects greater disclosures on sustainability. BlackRock will put companies on watch for 12-18 months and take voting action against management if progress is not made. The company aims to double its ESG ETF offerings to 150 globally over the next few years, as investors increasingly recognize climate risk as investment risk.

site_title: Preparing for a dramatically different future
summary: The global economy is shifting towards a dramatically different future, driven by Covid-19, the fourth industrial revolution, and demographic trends. The pandemic has accelerated the disruption, highlighting the need to address systemic vulnerabilities. Governments, individuals, and big business must adapt to this new reality. Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification, while productivity gains are crucial for wealth creation. De-dollarisation and shifting safe havens are also emerging trends, as markets continue to rise despite challenges. The future begins now, and those not prepared risk getting left behind.

site_title: EU summit talks blocked by recovery fund row, EU officials say
summary: European Union leaders' negotiations on an economic recovery fund stalled due to disagreements over the conditions for accessing the scheme. The 26 leaders' views on the stimulus plan were "diametrically different," according to Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babis. The EU leaders will resume discussions on Saturday. The economic recovery fund is aimed at breathing life into economies ravaged by the coronavirus pandemic. The stalemate highlights the challenges in reaching a unified response to the pandemic's economic impact.

images.alt_text: European Union leaders' negotiations over an economic recovery fund ran into difficulty late on Friday because of differences over the conditions for access to the scheme, European officials said.

site_title: Singapore's June export rebound caps expansionary first half
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rebounded in June with a 16.1% year-on-year growth, beating private-sector economists' estimates, and are now on track to outshine the official forecast of a full-year contraction. The rebound is attributed to the low base in 2019 and non-monetary gold, as well as growth in pharmaceuticals and electronics. However, some economists warn that the boost may not last, with pharmaceutical exports potentially faltering and the services sector facing a challenging outlook. NODX growth is now expected to surpass the full-year contraction forecast.

site_title: 7% of employment contracts at Raffles Hotel not extended due to Covid-19
summary: Raffles Hotel Singapore has notified 7% of its foreign employees that their employment contracts will not be extended due to the Covid-19 pandemic, affecting approximately 35 employees. This decision comes after the hotel notified 15% of its foreign employees in June that their contracts would not be extended, with about 7% choosing termination instead of extended leave. The hotel's priority is to retain as many jobs as possible, and affected employees will receive packages, including secondment opportunities to sister properties and virtual career support programs.

site_title: OUE sells Los Angeles tower at below market value as pandemic hits tenants
summary: OUE Ltd has sold its US Bank Tower in Los Angeles for $430 million, approximately two-thirds of its original valuation of $650 million. The sale price was determined amid the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the US property market. The sale is expected to reduce OUE's earnings per share by $0.35 and will help the company increase its cash reserves. The tower, completed in 1989, features a 360-degree observation deck and outdoor glass slide, and its leasehold interest in the observation deck will also be sold separately.

site_title: Biolidics says will take up to 9 months to incorporate A*Star tech into new serology tests
summary: Biolidics, a Singapore-based COVID-19 test kit maker, expects to take up to 9 months to incorporate licensed technology from A*Star into new serology tests. The company licensed non-exclusive worldwide rights to A*Star's technology for detecting COVID-19 antibodies in May. Biolidics is currently in the initial phase of product development, shortlisting potential partners, and assessing regulatory approvals before marketing the new tests. The company has no certainty of successfully developing and commercializing the tests, and its shares closed 2.5 cents higher on Friday.

site_title: Accordia Golf refutes Hibiki's letter, says offer to AGT was made after extensive negotiations
summary: Accordia Golf Trust's largest minority unitholder, Hibiki Path Advisors, alleged that the proposed price to buy over the trust's golf courses is "too low". In response, Accordia Golf said the offer was made after extensive negotiations and cited a market testing process involving Ernst & Young and Daiwa Capital Markets. Accordia Golf also disputed Hibiki's comparison method, citing differences in tax structures and accounting policies between Japanese-listed real investment trusts and AGT. The company's offer is for 61.8 billion yen (S$804.1 million) per unit.

site_title: Covid-19 shines light on real estate transparency
summary: Real estate markets in the Asia-Pacific region are shifting towards greater transparency, driven by investor, business, and consumer pressure. This shift is seen as a key factor in competing with other asset classes. As a result, South-east Asia and established markets like Singapore are prioritizing transparency to gauge market performance and attractiveness. The demand for prime projects above $3,000 per square foot is expected to be tested with the upcoming Q3 condo launches in Singapore. This increased transparency aims to provide a more accurate assessment of the market's performance and potential.

site_title: Reits (July 18-19, 2020)
summary: Reits saw a mixed performance in the week ending July 19, 2020. The S-Reits index declined 1.2% due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the property market. However, the REITs sector as a whole still managed to climb 0.8% despite the decline. The Singapore prime project market is expected to face a test of demand with the upcoming Q3 wave of condo launches, with prices above S$3,000 psf being a benchmark.

site_title: 'Most Asia-Pac banks, insurers not prepped for pandemics'
summary: A recent study by CPA Australia found that most Asia-Pacific banks and insurers were unprepared for the COVID-19 pandemic, with only 1 in 50 banks and 3 in 50 insurers identifying a pandemic as a key risk factor. Japanese companies Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings, Tokio Marine Holdings, and MS&AD Holdings were among those that identified pandemic risk. The study highlighted the need for better risk management and board diversity, with only 17.8% of banks having women on their boards and less than 7% having independent directors under 50 years old.

site_title: Would you like some free money?
summary: Modern Monetary Theory (MMT) allows governments to spend first and fund it later through taxes, borrowing, or printing, unlike individuals who need to earn or borrow money. This concept challenges traditional economic concerns about high government debt levels and inflation, as countries like the US have experienced no signs of currency collapse or inflation despite large deficit spending. MMT proponents argue that governments can create jobs and stimulate the economy without repaying debt, but critics warn of potential abuse and hyper-inflation. Investors should consider shifting their portfolios to inflation-proof assets as MMT gains traction, potentially altering the long-term investment landscape.

site_title: EU heads meet to haggle over multi-billion-euro recovery plan
summary: European Union leaders met in Brussels to discuss a multi-billion-euro recovery plan to revive their economies, with a 1 trillion-euro budget and a 750 billion-euro new recovery fund on the table. The summit, the first face-to-face meeting since the pandemic, aims to address the bloc's economic crisis, which is threatening to expose it to eurosceptic forces and weaken its standing against major powers. The stakes are high, with EU economies in free fall and immediate relief measures running out, and a deal remains elusive, with the summit scheduled to run for two days.

site_title: China's economy rebounds from coronavirus, but shares fall
summary: China's economy rebounded 3.2% in the second quarter, driven by infrastructure investments, but shares fell 4.8% as investors worried about the country's reliance on government stimulus. The recovery points to the government's success in controlling the coronavirus outbreak but also raises concerns about the sustainability of the growth, particularly with domestic consumption still underperforming. China's exports, however, have slowed to 0.5% in June, and the country's trade surplus is expected to decline as commodity prices rise. The government faces challenges in eradicating extreme poverty by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Growth has been driven by a ramping up of infrastructure investments. Beijing has given quick approval for local governments to issue bonds to pay for shovel-ready projects.

site_title: Cathay Pacific warns of HK$9.9b first-half net loss
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd warned of a first-half net loss of approximately HK$9.9 billion due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on air travel. The airline flew just 27,106 passengers in June, down 99.1% from 2019, with a passenger load factor of 27.3%. International aviation remains uncertain due to virus-related border restrictions, according to the airline's chief customer and commercial officer.

site_title: US consumer sentiment posts surprise drop after surge in virus
summary: US consumer sentiment dropped 4.9 points to 73.2 in July, reversing a 5.8-point gain in June, according to the University of Michigan's preliminary sentiment index. Economists forecast a slight increase to 79, but the decline is a concern for the economy and underlines the impact of the coronavirus on consumer confidence and spending. The decline in sentiment is tied to lawmakers' potential failure to extend benefits such as the extra $600 weekly unemployment payment, and a potential longer recession is likely without further action.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: RAFFLES Education is set to acquire Langfang Hezhong Real Estate Development Co after a sale-and-purchase agreement. The vacant land will be used for education facilities instead of residential and commercial development. DYNA-MAC Holdings is expected to report a net loss for the second quarter and a cumulative loss for the half year ended June 30. ARA H-Trust is expected to report net property loss and no distributable income for the first half of 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on hotel occupancies. Shares of glove makers declined, with Top Glove bucking the trend with a 9.3% gain.

site_title: Japan to focus on digital upgrade, disaster relief over debt
summary: Japan's government plans to focus on strengthening digital infrastructure and disaster preparedness, rather than achieving a primary budget surplus by 2025, according to the country's annual strategic plans. The "Digital New Deal" aims to upgrade the public administrative system, which contributed to delays in delivering coronavirus relief measures. The government will instead secure necessary budget funds to make Japan more resilient to natural disasters, following recent heavy flooding in southern Japan. The decision prioritizes economic support over fiscal health, with Finance Minister Taro Aso stating that fiscal reform will continue in the future.

site_title: Olympic chief Thomas Bach to stand for second term
summary: Thomas Bach, the 66-year-old German, announced he will run for a second term as president of the International Olympic Committee in 2021, eligible for a final four-year term. Bach, who took office in 2013, has been approached by numerous IOC members to seek re-election. His second term would follow the 2021 presidential elections in Athens, which are scheduled for June. Bach has overseen several high-profile Olympics, including the 2014 Sochi Winter Games and 2016 Rio Summer Games, and has implemented reforms such as the Olympic Agenda 2020.

images.alt_text: Thomas Bach said Friday he will stand in 2021 for a second term as president of the International Olympic Committee.

site_title: Be a master of your share portfolios
summary: Investors are often driven by a desire to recoup their initial investment, rather than seeking long-term returns. However, investing in risk assets like shares during volatile markets can be beneficial, as central banks have increased the global money supply. To mitigate risks, investors should focus on buying the right shares and developing a disciplined approach, rather than relying on misleading indicators like share prices. Measuring dividend income generated from a portfolio can provide a more reliable gauge of success, and investors can use this approach to master their portfolios.

site_title: Kicked out of China, and other real-life costs of a geopolitical meltdown
summary: A journalist's departure from China highlights the real-life consequences of the country's deteriorating relations with the US. The author, who had spent nearly a decade studying and working in China, faces the dilemma of what to do with their collection of wooden martial arts staffs, symbolizing their connection to the country. The author's experience illustrates how the worsening ties between the US and China affect individuals, particularly those who have invested time and effort in learning about and engaging with the Chinese culture. The expulsion of Chinese journalists from the US, driven by the Trump administration's hard-line approach, further limits outsiders' understanding of China, threatening the country's openness and transparency.

site_title: Lloyds Bank sets target to increase number of senior Black staff
summary: Lloyds Bank has set a target to increase the number of Black staff in senior roles to 3% by 2025, up from 0.6% currently. The bank is introducing a 'Race Action Plan' following Black Lives Matter protests and will publish an ethnicity pay gap report later this year. A new advisory board made up of Black, Asian, and Minority Ethnic staff will inform its diversity strategy, and a race education programme is also being developed. The bank aims to challenge itself to do better and is committed to increasing diversity.

site_title: Post Covid-19: Dark clouds and silver linings
summary: The article discusses the post-COVID-19 landscape, highlighting both challenges and opportunities. Climate change remains a pressing issue, while the global economy is adapting to the new normal. Companies are navigating revenue targets and operating losses, with some, like NTT DC Reit, experiencing oversubscription in public offers. Other news includes fresh tariffs imposed by the US on Canada, a warning from Creative Technology, and an investigation into graft allegations in Indonesia. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank has announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing the current head.

site_title: Sembcorp posts S$131m net loss in H1
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a net loss of S$131 million in the first half of the year, primarily due to a decline in its marine segment and substantial impairments of energy assets. The marine segment lost S$117 million, while exceptional items, including a S$44 million write-off of gasoil inventory, contributed to the loss. This marks a significant decline from the previous year's profit of S$191 million.

site_title: Audi Q3 Sportback review: The Q3 gets its Sportback
summary: The Audi Q3 Sportback is a compact crossover with a sporty twist, blending practicality with style. It's 16mm longer and 28mm lower than the standard Q3, with a sloping roof and muscular stance. The car feels quirky behind the wheel, with a mix of SUV loftiness and sports car vibe. It's available with a 1.4-litre turbo engine and a 2.0-litre quattro model, both offering a seven-speed automatic gearbox and four-wheel drive. The Q3 Sportback is well-packaged and thought out, with plenty of space for five and a large luggage area, making it a practical choice for those who want style and capability.

images.alt_text: The Q3 Sportback plays up its muscular stance with plenty of horizontal lines thrown into its design.
There's lots of high definition real estate on the Q3 Sportback's dashboard.

site_title: Here's how to snap out of doomscrolling
summary: During the pandemic, many people have turned to "doomscrolling" - excessive consumption of negative news - as a way to cope. However, health experts warn that this behavior can lead to increased anxiety, depression, and decreased productivity. To break the habit, experts recommend creating a plan to control time, setting realistic goals, and practicing meditation. Structure can also be achieved by scheduling mundane activities, setting aside time for news consumption, and taking breaks. Connecting with others through video calls, social support groups, or simply thinking about those who have helped in the past can also help combat feelings of isolation and resist doomscrolling.

site_title: Travellers entering Singapore after visiting Japan, HK, Australia's Victoria state must serve SHN at dedicated facilities
summary: Travellers entering Singapore after visiting Japan, Hong Kong, and Victoria, Australia within the last 14 days will be required to serve a 14-day stay-home notice (SHN) at dedicated facilities starting July 20. The cost of each stay is approximately $1,500, and a Covid-19 test costs an additional $200. This measure comes as these places have seen a recent resurgence of Covid-19 cases. The move aims to remain vigilant and control the spread of the virus within the community.

site_title: RWS, MBS must still invest S$9 billion or risk higher taxes: MTI
summary: Singapore's integrated resorts, Marina Bay Sands (MBS) and Resorts World Sentosa (RWS), remain committed to investing S$9 billion in new attractions, despite the pandemic's impact on the tourism industry. Failure to meet this commitment will result in higher taxes under a new casino tax regime set to take effect in March 2022. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) assures that the IRs are committed to delivering their expansion plans, but a broader sectoral depression has led to RWS' recent retrenchment exercise.

site_title: China takes over companies linked to missing financier
summary: China's China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) has taken control of nine financial firms linked to missing financier Xiao Jianhua. The firms, including insurance companies and trust companies, will continue to operate normally and meet their debt obligations. The move aims to maintain financial stability amid the COVID-19 pandemic and rising soured loans. Authorities will seek market-oriented restructurings to avoid systematic financial risks. The takeover is part of China's efforts to curb the influence of Mr. Xiao's investment conglomerate, Tomorrow Group, which was identified as a "financial holding company" requiring scrutiny in 2018.

site_title: Prince Andrew's daughter Beatrice weds in private ceremony
summary: Prince Andrew's daughter Princess Beatrice married her fiancé Edoardo Mapelli Mozzi in a private ceremony at the Royal Chapel of All Saints at Royal Lodge, Windsor, on July 17, 2020, in front of Queen Elizabeth II and a small number of guests. The ceremony took place after the couple postponed their initial May 29 wedding due to the coronavirus outbreak. The royal family confirmed the marriage in a statement, stating it was held in accordance with government guidelines.

site_title: SIAEC reports S$10.7m net profit for Q1; government support lessens bleed from Covid-19
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) reported a net profit of S$10.7 million for Q1 2020, a 74.3% decline from the same period last year. The company attributed its loss to government support schemes, particularly the Jobs Support Scheme, which provided 75% wage support for aerospace maintenance operators. Despite a 13% drop in flights at its Singapore base, SIAEC has taken steps to safeguard its businesses and will continue its transformation efforts, focusing on digital technology.

site_title: Singapore must prep for but try avoiding second Covid-19 wave, says Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore must prepare for a potential second wave of COVID-19 infections, but efforts to avoid it can be made by maintaining vigilance and responsible behavior. The country has seen a steady average of 12 new community cases per day over the past week, with unlinked cases mostly from construction and related sectors. To mitigate the risk, the government is reviewing safe-distancing measures and may implement localized control measures, such as shutting down high-risk premises, rather than a nationwide circuit-breaker.

site_title: LTA awards four contracts totalling S$682.5m for the Jurong Region Line
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) awarded four contracts totaling S$682.5 million for the Jurong Region Line (JRL), a 20km rail line in Singapore. The contracts include design and construction of three stations, elevated viaducts, and signalling systems. The projects, worth S$320.4 million, will be carried out by joint ventures between Daewoo Engineering and Construction and local contractor Yongnam Engineering and Construction. The JRL is expected to start construction later this year, with expected completion in the mid-2020s.

site_title: Yes, you should take a vacation in the middle of a pandemic
summary: Taking a vacation during a pandemic is crucial for preventing burnout, which poses a greater threat to teams and careers than taking time off. A survey of managers and business owners found that workers aren't booking as many vacation days this summer as in years past. Experts advise taking a break to recharge, using the time to reflect on work-life balances, and rekindling hobbies. When requesting time off, consider giving advance notice, communicating with managers, and designating an emergency liaison. By taking a vacation, individuals can return to work with fresh eyes, managing their time differently and improving their overall well-being.

site_title: Sri Lanka court blocks president's sand mining concessions
summary: A Sri Lankan court blocked President Gotabaya Rajapaksa's move to relax sand mining restrictions, citing a 1992 law protecting the environment and eco systems. The court ruled the government had no powers to remove tight controls on sand mining and transport, which conservationists said threatened fragile river ecosystems. High-quality river sand is in demand by the construction industry.

images.alt_text: A Sri Lankan court Friday blocked President Gotabaya Rajapaksa's controversial move to relax restrictions on sand mining and transport which conservationists said threatened fragile river eco systems.

site_title: Glove counters end volatile week up on Friday
summary: Glove makers' shares ended the week with a mixed performance, with UG Healthcare and Riverstone closing lower, while Top Glove bucked the trend with a 9.3% gain. The gains were tempered by US Customs and Border Protection's detention order on Top Glove's subsidiaries over suspected forced labor, and concerns over detention orders on other glove makers. Despite this, analysts remain positive on the sector due to a shortage in glove supply and high average selling prices.

site_title: Norway's Aker Solutions announces merger with Kvaerner, new CEO
summary: Aker Solutions, a Norwegian oil services firm, announced a merger with Kvaerner, controlled by billionaire Kjell Inge Roekke, to form a company with $4 billion in revenue. The merged firm will target the growing renewable energy market, aiming to grow revenue by 10% annually to 2025. Revenue from renewable businesses is expected to reach one-third of total revenue by 2025. The combined company plans to spin off its renewable and carbon capture technology business into separate listings and fundraisings, with the goal of reducing costs and workforce by 2021.

site_title: Sterling headed for worst week in a month as economic outlook sours
summary: The British pound is on track for its worst week in a month due to a bleak economic outlook. Despite Prime Minister Boris Johnson easing some lockdown measures, he announced that local authorities will have power to shut down areas, and normal life won't return until November. The pound fell 0.6% against the dollar, with investors doubting the fiscal stimulus measures will prop up the economy. Unemployment is expected to jump despite fewer job losses in June, and the Bank of England's ability to intervene remains unclear.

site_title: German Finance Minister knew of Wirecard Issues a year before collapse
summary: German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz was informed about potential market manipulation at Wirecard in February 2019, nearly a year before the company's collapse. The Financial watchdog BaFin reported the case to Scholz due to suspected market manipulation. This early knowledge raises scrutiny on Scholz, a key figure in Angela Merkel's government, amid the upcoming election.

images.alt_text: German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz was aware of potential market manipulation at Wirecard almost a year and a half before the company collapsed, putting pressure on a key figure in Angela Merkel's government.

site_title: SCI posts S$131m losses in H1, dragged by weak marine business, huge impairments
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) reported a net loss of S$131 million in the first half of the year due to a weak marine business and significant impairments of investments and assets. The company's top executives, led by group president and CEO Wong Kim Yin, have emphasized the need for a demerger of SCI and Sembcorp Marine to improve metrics and focus on available resources. The proposed demerger aims to create independent balance sheets, allowing for better evaluation of each business and improved credit ratios.

site_title: US homebuilding surges as coronavirus crisis sparks flight to suburbs, rural areas
summary: US homebuilding surged 17.3% in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.186 million units, the largest increase since October 2016, amid the COVID-19 pandemic's shift to suburbs and rural areas. Single-family homebuilding rose 17.2% to 831,000 units, driven by cheaper mortgage rates and increased demand for housing in lower density markets. Permits for future homebuilding rose 2.1% to 1.241 million units, with single-family building permits increasing 11.8% to 834,000 units.

site_title: Gold futures getting very comfortable with US$1,800
summary: Gold futures have consolidated around the US$1,800 level this week, with prices supported by the worsening coronavirus pandemic and escalating Sino-US tensions. Despite optimism over the EU's recovery plan, the ECB's unchanged monetary policy led to profit-taking. Longer-term traders stayed cautious, while shorter-term traders have been taking profits and buying on dips. The next resistance is at US$1,830, and support lies at US$1,757, with a potential high target of US$1,900 if the US$1,800 barrier is breached.

site_title: Britain eyes normal life by Christmas, but preparing for second Covid-19 wave
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson hopes to return to normal life by Christmas, with plans to ease lockdown restrictions starting in November. He set out a phased removal of restrictions, allowing employers more discretion over working from home and potentially dropping social distancing rules. However, Johnson warned that the country must prepare for a second wave of Covid-19 cases, with extra funding for healthcare and new powers for local government. The government has also increased testing capacity and flu vaccination programme to prepare for winter.

site_title: Natixis plans shake-up to focus on greener lending
summary: French bank Natixis is restructuring its commodities and infrastructure operations to focus on clean energy, accelerating a move prompted by loss-making loans to oil traders. The bank, which became the first European bank to introduce environmental penalties, will merge its energy and infrastructure teams and reduce staff. The restructuring, which began before the coronavirus crisis, aims to capitalize on the growing demand for greener fuels. Some jobs will be lost, but the new division is expected to employ around 100 people, up from the energy team's 140 employees.

site_title: HK police arrest pro-democracy politician set to run for legislature
summary: Hong Kong police arrested pro-democracy politician Tam Tak-chi, 47, on charges including incitement to participate in unlawful assembly. Tam, vice-president of the People Power party, won an unofficial primary poll for the Legislative Council vote, which Beijing officials deemed illegal. Tam denied the charges were related to the new national security law, but police said they were linked to a January protest. The arrest comes amid concerns the law will crush freedoms promised to Hong Kong when it returned to Chinese rule in 1997.

site_title: Accordia Golf refutes Hibiki's letter, says offer to AGT made after extensive talks
summary: Accordia Golf has responded to Hibiki Path Advisors' criticism of the proposed price to buy over Accordia Golf Trust's (AGT) golf courses, stating that the offer was made after extensive talks. The proposed price is 61.8 billion Japanese yen (S$804.1 million), which Accordia Golf claims is an attractive opportunity for AGT's unitholders to realize the value of their units at a premium to adjusted net asset value and historical trading prices. Accordia Golf disputes Hibiki's comparison to the Tokyo Stock Exchange Reit Index and notes discrepancies in the tax structure and accounting policies of Japanese-listed real investment trusts.

site_title: STI ends trading week at 2,618.48 after dull, directionless session
summary: Singapore stocks ended the week at 2,618.48, mostly unchanged, after a dull and directionless session. The Straits Times Index rose 5.19 points, or 0.2%, despite 12 components closing higher and 12 lower. Oil exploration company Rex International's shares jumped 4.55% after receiving approvals for its Oman project. Leading beneficiaries of the pandemic rebounded, with rubber glove makers Top Glove and UG Healthcare increasing 15.87% and 24.24% respectively.

site_title: No distributable income for H1 2020, ARA H-Trust says
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust (ARA H-Trust) expects to report a net property loss and no distributable income for the first six months of 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on hotel occupancies. The trust incurred fixed costs despite taking steps to reduce operating costs. ARA H-Trust has maintained positive gross operating profit and is in a secure financial position with adequate liquidity. The trust will report its first half results on August 5.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries reports S$131m net loss for H1 2020 due to Covid-19
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a net loss of S$131 million for the first half of 2020, primarily due to the impact of Covid-19 on its energy, marine, and corporate segments. The company expects full-year losses, with its marine segment incurring a net loss of S$117 million. The energy segment also reported a net loss of S$5 million, while the urban segment generated a net profit of S$38 million. The company's business outlook depends on the return of its workforce to full strength and the recovery of energy demand.

site_title: Thailand delays selection process for new central bank chief
summary: Thailand has delayed the selection process for its new central bank chief due to concerns over the qualifications of some applicants. The head of the selection committee, Rangson Sriworasat, said the process will be rechecked before considering the candidates again. The interviews, originally scheduled for July 21, will now be delayed until a new finance minister is appointed, following the resignation of Uttama Savanayana. The new central bank governor will succeed Veerathai Santiprabhob, who ends his five-year term on September 30.

site_title: Queen knights 100-year-old UK fundraiser
summary: Captain Tom Moore, a 100-year-old UK fundraiser, was knighted "Sir Tom" by Queen Elizabeth on Friday. He raised £33 million by walking 100 laps of his garden during the Covid-19 pandemic, touching hearts across Britain and beyond. Prime Minister Boris Johnson nominated him for the award, recognizing his efforts during the crisis.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets steadied at the open on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.1% to 6,257.57 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 index rose 0.3% to 12,914.68 points, while the Paris CAC 40 remained flat. The European Union's leaders are set to meet for their first face-to-face summit in five months to discuss a post-virus economic rescue plan, but a divide over a stimulus package remains, with northern members opposed to unconditional aid to southern neighbors.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports rose 16.1% in June, driven by specialised machinery exports and pharmaceuticals. Tourism receipts declined 39% in the first quarter, with shopping takings suffering the largest drop. Singapore banks' Q2 dividend payout is unlikely to be affected by a regulator's capital review. OUE sold its US Bank Tower for US$430m, below valuation, while Raffles Education Corporation will raise its stake in a Chinese property firm for 254 million yuan. The Straits Times Index ended trading week at 2,618.48, down 0.2%.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on hopes of stimulus-led economic rebound
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, with the S&P 500 on track for its third straight weekly gain, as investors bet on more stimulus to drive an economic rebound. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.15%, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.27% and 0.25%, respectively. Despite a record jump in domestic coronavirus cases, investors remained optimistic, driven by hopes of further stimulus.

site_title: Qian Hu swings into loss for H1, hurt by dearth of cargo flights
summary: Qian Hu, a mainboard-listed integrated fish service provider, reported a net loss of S$525,000 for the first half of 2020, reversing from a net profit of S$273,000 in the previous year. The company's fish sales slid 25.7% due to reduced cargo flights and a lockdown in China affecting its aquaculture business. However, its accessories segment fared better, with sales increasing 2.2% and its aquaculture business is expected to be a "sustainable engine of growth" for the company.

site_title: South Korea revokes licences of leaflet-sending anti-North groups
summary: South Korea revoked the licenses of two anti-North Korea groups, Fighters for a Free North Korea and Kuensaem Education Center, for sending propaganda leaflets into the North. The move came after North Korea threatened military action and blew up a joint liaison office. The groups, led by North Korean defectors, had sent leaflets, food, and other goods into North Korea for years, infuriating the government. The decision aims to improve ties with the isolated neighbor, but the groups and rights organizations condemned it as a bid to silence critics.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with gains on Friday, ending a tough week for the Hang Seng Index. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.47% to 25,089.17, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained. The gains come after new containment measures were implemented in Hong Kong due to a flare-up of Covid-19 infections. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.13%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.69%.

site_title: Hong Kong demands Taiwan officials sign 'one China' document for visa renewal: source
summary: Taiwan officials in Hong Kong have been told their visas will not be renewed unless they sign a document supporting Beijing's "one China" policy. The move comes after Taipei criticized a new security law imposed on Hong Kong and opened an office in Taipei to help people leave the city. Taiwan officials were asked to sign the document, but some refused, leading to one official's return to Taiwan. The move has been described as an "unnecessary political obstacle" for Taipei-Hong Kong ties.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 23.02 points to 1,596.33. The index saw 636 gains for every 410 losses, with a total volume of 9.498 billion lots worth RM5.851 billion.

site_title: Daimler to stop building sedans in the US after Q2 loss
summary: Daimler, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, announced plans to stop building sedans in the US and Mexico to cut costs.
