The company will halt production of the Mercedes-Benz C-Class sedan in Alabama and a variant of the A-Class in Mexico, instead focusing on higher-margin SUV models. This move comes after posting a smaller-than-expected quarterly loss of 1.68 billion euros. Daimler aims to save 2 billion euros annually through staff cuts, equivalent to 20,000 jobs, as part of its efforts to lower costs and adjust capacity.

site_title: Australian researchers invent 20-minute coronavirus blood test
summary: Australian researchers at Monash University have developed a 20-minute coronavirus blood test that can determine current and past infections. The test uses agglutination analysis to detect the presence of coronavirus in blood samples, allowing for rapid case identification and contact tracing. Hundreds of samples can be tested every hour, and the researchers hope to use the test to detect antibodies raised in response to vaccination to aid clinical trials. A patent has been filed, and commercial and government support is sought to scale up production.

site_title: 327 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 9 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 327 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 47,453. The cases include nine in the community, with six Singaporeans or permanent residents and three work pass holders. Epidemiological investigations are ongoing for the other cases. The Ministry of Health has added new locations visited by infectious patients, including Resorts World Sentosa's casino, and notified close contacts. The average number of new daily community cases has decreased from 16 to 12 in the past week.

site_title: China's fiscal revenue up 3.2% in June as economy rebounds
summary: China's fiscal revenues rose 3.2% in June, reversing a 10% drop in May, marking the first expansion this year. The economy returned to growth in the second quarter after a deep slump, but weak demand underscores the need for more policy support. Fiscal revenues fell 10.8% in the first half, while fiscal spending fell 5.8%. China has issued 720 billion yuan in special treasury bonds to support the recovery, with local governments issuing 2.24 trillion yuan in special bonds. The government will prevent risks from local government debt and maintain controls due to the coronavirus.

site_title: Japan's Abe faces anger over tourism subsidy as Tokyo Covid-19 cases hit record
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is facing backlash for excluding Tokyo residents from a $16 billion tourism campaign amid a record surge in COVID-19 cases in the city. The decision has sparked criticism and anger, with many questioning the government's handling of the crisis. Tokyo reported 293 new cases, a record high, and the government's decision to exclude residents from the travel subsidy program has raised concerns about further economic strain. The move is seen as a potential blow to Abe's support, with critics arguing that his handling of the pandemic has eroded trust.

site_title: China's oil product demand picks up in Q2, still well below year-ago level: energy bureau
summary: China's refined oil product consumption increased in the second quarter, with diesel and gasoline seeing year-on-year growth since April and June respectively. The National Energy Administration reported a 6 percentage point narrowing of the contraction, still below year-earlier levels. China's electricity and natural gas consumption also rose, with electricity consumption increasing 3.9% and natural gas use exceeding last year's level. Analysts estimate gasoline consumption will reach 73.77 million tonnes and diesel consumption 85.69 million tonnes in the second half of 2020.

site_title: Asian palm oil producers offers to work with EU as it readies new food rules
summary: Asian palm oil producers, led by Indonesia and Malaysia, have offered to work with the European Union to draft new rules for the EU's "Farm to Fork" food supply policy. The EU aims to phase out palm-based transport fuels and set limits on food contaminant 3-MCPD esters, citing environmental concerns. The producers, who account for 85% of global palm oil production, want to be part of the discussion and improve sustainability standards, after being criticized for deforestation. This move comes after the EU announced proposals for a sustainable food system, sparking trade tensions between the two parties.

site_title: Singapore banks' Q2 dividend unlikely shaken by regulator's capital review: CGS-CIMB
summary: Singapore banks' Q2 dividend payouts are unlikely to be impacted by the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) capital review, according to CGS-CIMB. Instead, the banks' dividend payouts will depend on their earnings from the current operating environment, including pre-emptive provisioning and net interest margin (NIM) headwinds. The banks' strong capital ratios and ability to maintain dividend policies are expected to withstand the review, but UOB's 50% payout stance may pose downside risks.

site_title: Electrolux sees good demand in near term after June sales recovery
summary: Electrolux, Europe's largest home appliance maker, expects robust demand in the near term due to pent-up demand and stimulus programs. The company reported an operating loss of 62 million Swedish crowns (S$9.5 million) in the second quarter, down from a 1.2 billion crowns profit a year earlier. Despite this, group sales are seen at 23.5 billion crowns after returning to like-for-like growth in June, with a full-year 2020 demand expected to remain negative in most markets.

site_title: France's cabaret queen Zizi Jeanmaire dies aged 96
summary: French cabaret showgirl and dancer Zizi Jeanmaire, known for her iconic performances and glamorous style, has died at 96 in Switzerland. Born Renee Marcelle Jeanmaire in 1924, she left the Paris Opera Ballet at 19 and went on to star in films, musicals, and ballets, collaborating with renowned choreographer Roland Petit. Jeanmaire's leading performances, including her 1949 modern interpretation of "Carmen," cemented her status as a cabaret queen, earning her the nickname "Zizi," which originated from her childhood pronunciation of "Mon zizi" for "Mon Jesus."

images.alt_text: Many of Zizi Jeanmaire's (L) roles were created by her husband Roland Petit, the renowned choreographer who died in 2011.

site_title: Hong Kong's property market sees limited impact from China security law
summary: Hong Kong's property market shows limited impact from China's new security law, with sales and home prices remaining relatively stable. Despite concerns over the law's potential to deter investment, property agents attribute the market's resilience to local support, low interest rates, limited supply, and abundant capital. Data indicates pent-up demand remains strong, with weekend sales picking up after a brief dip in May. Longer-term buyers prioritize stability and profit potential over short-term market fluctuations.

site_title: Abbott sees no hit to demand for Covid-19 tests from vaccine
summary: Abbott Laboratories forecasts full-year profit above analysts' estimates, driven by strong demand for its coronavirus tests despite the potential impact of a vaccine. The company expects adjusted earnings of at least $3.25 per share, exceeding analysts' average estimate of $2.87 per share. Abbott's medical devices sales slumped 21.2% in the quarter, but procedure volumes improved significantly. The company is also betting on new products, including a newly approved continuous glucose monitoring device, to sustain earnings. Demand for tests is expected to remain high even with a vaccine available.

site_title: SIAEC to adopt announcement of half-yearly financial statements
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) announced it will release half-yearly financial statements, providing timely updates on its business performance. This change aims to engage shareholders with clear communication. The company will release its first-quarter update after trading hours on Friday and also post it on its website. SIAEC's shares closed up 1% on the news, ending at 1.96 cents.

site_title: Lyft to provide drivers with partition shields as coronavirus protection
summary: Lyft will distribute 60,000 partition shields to its active drivers to protect against the coronavirus, starting with a pilot program. The shields, made of polycarbonate material, are designed to be self-installed and removable, and will be sold for $50 at production cost. This move follows Lyft's requirement of masks for both passengers and drivers, and comes as the company aims to adapt to the pandemic's impact on ridership. The US CDC had previously recommended the installation of partitions between drivers and passengers.

images.alt_text: Lyft began designing the semi-rigid partition shields, made out of a polycarbonate material, several months ago and has since piloted it with a group of ride-hail drivers to solicit feedback.

site_title: 1,300 people have signed up for SGUnited Skills Programme to date
summary: About 1,300 people have signed up for the SGUnited Skills Programme, which offers over 6,500 training places across 113 courses in sectors such as infocomm, manufacturing, and healthcare. The programme aims to support up to 100,000 job seekers amid the pandemic, with heavily subsidised training and monthly allowances. Education Minister Ong Ye Kung called on employers to target vulnerable groups for training, rather than those who may have an easier time securing jobs.

site_title: EMA, Shell issue joint grant call for SMEs to develop smart, clean energy solutions
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) and Shell have issued a joint grant call to support small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in developing smart, clean energy solutions. The initiative aims to deploy solar energy and energy storage systems (ESS) at Shell's service stations, reducing carbon emissions and supporting Singapore's solar and energy storage targets. Successful SMEs will have their solutions tested and deployed at three Shell service stations, with a registration deadline of August 6, 2020.

site_title: EU stimulus funds attract over 1,000 green projects
summary: The European Union's 2021-27 budget and economic stimulus fund, worth 1.1 trillion euros, is expected to support over 1,000 green projects, including renewable energy, energy storage, and low-carbon transport. These "shovel-ready" projects, worth 200 billion euros, could create over 2 million jobs and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030. The projects, identified by consultancy EY, represent about 10% of green projects currently in development in Europe, and could total up to one trillion euros in investment.

site_title: Tennis: Serena Williams set to play inaugural Kentucky tournament
summary: Serena Williams is set to make her return to the WTA tour at the inaugural Kentucky tournament in August. The 23-time Grand Slam champion will compete alongside Sloane Stephens, with the tournament scheduled to begin on August 10. Williams' last match was in February, representing the US in the Fed Cup, before the pandemic shut down the WTA tour. The Kentucky tournament is one of two new events confirmed by WTA chief executive Steve Simon, with WTA action resuming with the Palermo Open in Italy on August 3.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon Salim wins close shareholder vote on controversial US$3b deal
summary: Indonesian tycoon Anthoni Salim has narrowly won shareholder backing for a $3 billion US takeover of Pinehill Company, a distributor and manufacturer in the Middle East and Africa. Salim's First Pacific controls 51% of Pinehill and needs approval from ICBP shareholders to proceed. Some shareholders raised concerns about the high price paid for Pinehill, citing governance questions under Hong Kong's related-party rules. Despite this, supporters say the takeover could boost ICBP's financial performance. Salim, Indonesia's sixth-richest man, owns 51% of Pinehill and 44.3% of First Pacific.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise on US stimulus hopes, log best weekly gain in six
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.8% on Friday, logging the best weekly gain in six, driven by hopes of US stimulus measures and improved earnings growth at IT companies and carmakers. The Kospi index ended at 2,201.19, with foreigners buying 108.8 billion won worth of shares. The won strengthened against the dollar, and the benchmark bond yield fell. US Congress is set to debate a relief package next week amid fresh lockdown measures in several states.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse proposes new rules for quick DAX expulsion in wake of Wirecard
summary: Deutsche Boerse proposes new rules to quickly expel companies from the DAX index, such as Wirecard, in the event of insolvency. The proposed rules would allow for companies to be removed two trading days after filing for insolvency, potentially preventing Wirecard from staying in the index until September. The exchange operator is seeking feedback from market participants by August 7. The rule change aims to enhance the index's credibility and transparency after Wirecard's dramatic fall from grace.

site_title: China's Wuhan declares red alert as floods disrupt supply chains
summary: China's Wuhan and surrounding provinces have declared red alerts due to severe flooding, with the Yangtze river and lakes reaching critical levels. Heavy rain has disrupted supply chains, including personal protective equipment, and caused economic damage. The flooding is expected to impact third-quarter GDP growth, with estimates suggesting a 0.4-0.8 percentage point drag. Residents in Wuhan are warned to take precautions as water levels approach maximum safety levels, with the Three Gorges reservoir holding back over 50,000 cubic meters of water per second.

site_title: Singapore's tourism receipts down 39% in first quarter
summary: Singapore's tourism receipts plummeted 39% in the first quarter of 2020, reaching S$4 billion, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This decline was observed across all components, with the shopping sector experiencing the largest drop of 52%. International visitor arrivals also declined 43.2% to 2.7 million, with the top five markets being Indonesia, mainland China, Australia, India, and Malaysia. Hotel room revenue shrank 30.9% to S$687.3 million, while the average occupancy rate fell to 58.6%.

site_title: Solid profits at Volvo spur truck industry's recovery hopes
summary: Swedish truckmaker AB Volvo reported a better-than-expected second quarter core profit as production shutdowns caused by the coronavirus were lifted. Despite a 45% year-on-year decline in order intake, Volvo's bookings improved in the second quarter, and the company's adjusted operating profit fell to 3.27 billion Swedish crowns (S$501.2 million). Volvo shares rose 3.5% in early trading, and the company plans to cut thousands of white-collar staff. The pandemic's impact on demand remains uncertain, with Volvo cautioning that it would weigh on demand for the foreseeable future.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on record virus cases
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.32% to 22,696.42, and the Topix index sliding 0.33% to 1,573.85. The decline came after Tokyo's governor announced a record 2,470 daily coronavirus infections. The market sentiment worsened as a result, contributing to the decline in stock prices.

site_title: Tigermed gets HKEX green light for US$1b listing
summary: Hangzhou Tigermed Consulting, a Chinese clinical research service provider, has received approval from the Hong Kong stock exchange (HKEX) for a potential US$1 billion listing. The company's shares have risen 70% in Shenzhen this year, joining a growing number of healthcare and pharmaceutical companies seeking to raise funds in Asia amidst the pandemic. Deliberations are ongoing, and details of the listing, including size and timeline, could still change.

site_title: Thai monetary policy should remain accommodative to help economy: central bank
summary: Thailand's central bank recommends maintaining accommodative monetary policy to support the economy, which was hit by the coronavirus pandemic. The policy rate is expected to remain at a record low of 0.50% until inflation returns to the 1-3% target range in the second quarter of 2021. The Monetary Policy Committee has cut the rate three times this year, with its next review scheduled for August 5. The decision aims to bolster economic recovery and domestic purchasing power after the pandemic is under control.

site_title: Philippines to allow some foreigners to enter country from August
summary: The Philippines will allow foreign nationals with long-term visas to enter the country starting August 1, as the country relaxes COVID-19 restrictions to support the economy. Foreigners must undergo quarantine upon arrival and returning Filipinos have priority on inbound flights. The country has reported 61,266 COVID-19 cases and 1,643 related deaths, ranking second in South-east Asia.

site_title: Hot stock: Rex International up 5.7% after green light from Oman to develop oil field
summary: Rex International's shares rose 5.7% after Oman's authorities approved its plan to develop the Yunma field, part of its Block 50 licence. The Ministry of Oil and Gas in Oman awarded a declaration of commerciality (DOC), allowing Masirah Oil to fully develop the oil field. The Yunma 1 well has produced over 1 million barrels of oil, with daily production of over 8,000 barrels.

site_title: Japanese banks see record demand for corporate loans during pandemic: BOJ survey
summary: Major Japanese banks saw record demand for corporate loans in the three months to July, a Bank of Japan survey revealed. The diffusion index for companies' demand for funds surged to +59, the highest level since 2000, as companies sought to meet funding needs and build cash reserves amid the pandemic. In contrast, households' demand for loans plummeted to a record low of -24 due to lockdown measures. The BOJ has eased monetary policy to pump money into cash-strapped small firms, while the government has deployed stimulus packages to cushion the economic blow.

site_title: Microsoft trims jobs as it enters new fiscal year
summary: Microsoft has trimmed its workforce across geographies and teams as it entered a new fiscal year, although the company declined to elaborate on the roles eliminated, their numbers, or locations. This move follows previous job cuts in the Microsoft Azure cloud division and MSN.com, and comes as the company shifts to an AI-powered algorithmic feed. The cuts are part of a common practice for the company to re-evaluate its business as it enters a new fiscal year.

site_title: Ericsson Q2 core profit beats, margins improve on telecom equipment sales
summary: Ericsson reported Q2 core earnings ahead of market estimates, driven by higher margins on telecom equipment sales. The company won 99 commercial contracts, including deals with China's three largest telecom operators, but took a hit on gross margins due to product inventory write-downs. Gross margin rose to 38.2% from 36.7% in the year-ago period. Ericsson maintained its financial targets for 2020 and 2022 despite economic uncertainty, citing accelerating investments in 5G networks.

site_title: Taiwan's Hong Kong envoy 'forced' to leave over 'political obstacles'
summary: Taiwan's top representative to Hong Kong, Kao Ming-tsun, has returned home due to "unnecessary political obstacles" from the Hong Kong side, including refusing to sign a pro-Beijing statement. The move strains ties between Taiwan and Hong Kong, which have deteriorated since Beijing's new national security law was imposed on the city. Taiwan views itself as a de facto independent nation, while Beijing regards it as its territory. The incident follows a series of tensions between the two sides, including Beijing's economic, diplomatic, and military pressure on Taiwan since President Tsai Ing-wen's 2016 election.

site_title: Punches, water balloons thrown in Taiwan parliament melee
summary: Taiwanese lawmakers clashed in the parliament, throwing punches and water balloons during a vote on the head of a top government watchdog. The altercation, the third in two weeks, involved a Democratic Progressive Party legislator punching an opposition member and KMT lawmakers throwing water balloons at the speakers' podium. The incident highlights ongoing tensions between the ruling and opposition parties in Taiwan's legislature.

site_title: Broker's take: Sabana Reit upgraded to 'buy' on proposed 'safe abode' merger
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Sabana Reit to "buy" from "hold" and lowered its target price to S$0.40, citing the proposed merger with ESR-Reit as a "safe abode" in uncertain times. The merger, if approved, will create a larger industrial Reit with about S$4.1 billion in assets and is expected to add 9.2% to Sabana's FY20 distribution per unit. The enlarged entity will have lower borrowing costs and allow Sabana to unlock the true value of its portfolio, potentially re-rating closer to its peers.

site_title: Trump niece's memoir sells nearly 1 million copies on first day
summary: Mary Trump's memoir "Too Much and Never Enough: How My Family Created the World's Most Dangerous Man" sold nearly 1 million copies on its first day, breaking a company record for Simon & Schuster. The book, written by Trump's niece, portrays the president as a narcissist and criticizes his actions. Despite the White House dismissing the memoir as "a book of falsehoods," the book topped Amazon's sales charts in Canada and Australia, with the publisher ordering more copies to meet demand.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up after steep losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.69% at the open on Friday, rebounding from the previous day's losses. The Hang Seng Index gained 171.37 points to 25,142.06. Shanghai stocks also edged up, with the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index increasing 0.13% to 3,214.40. The move follows bargain-buying following the previous day's painful rout.

site_title: Melbourne sees record rise in coronavirus cases despite lockdown
summary: Melbourne reported a record 423 new coronavirus cases on Friday, surpassing the country's previous daily high since late March. The city has been experiencing a surge in infections since mid-June, despite a week-old lockdown of over 5 million residents. Victoria's chief health officer, Brett Sutton, warned that the outbreak is not yet under control, and officials may consider tougher measures if the numbers don't stabilize. Australia's nationwide cases have reached over 11,000, with 116 deaths, and the country's borders are closed to people from Victoria to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Sanli unit in dispute with supplier over US$530,000
summary: Environmental engineering firm Sanli Environmental's subsidiary, Sanli M&E Engineering, has received an adjudication application from supplier Calgon Carbon (Asia) for a project completed in 2019, with a disputed amount of US$530,000. The company believes the amount is "without merit" and has responded to the Singapore Mediation Centre. Sanli is working with its legal counsel to respond to the claims, and the adjudication determination will be issued in due course.

site_title: Gold steadies near US$1,800 on virus fears, US-China spat
summary: Gold steadied near US$1,800 on Friday due to concerns over the coronavirus pandemic and US-China tensions. Spot gold rose 0.1% to US$1,797.52 per ounce, while US gold futures eased 0.1% to US$1,797.30. The US dollar remained strong, limiting gains. The US reported a record daily increase in Covid-19 cases, and the Federal Reserve's John Williams said the US economy may take years to recover. Gold's appeal as a safe-haven asset remains, despite a stronger dollar, with prices at yearly highs.

site_title: Westpac internal report finds risk governance 'immature and reactive'
summary: Westpac Banking Corp has launched a multi-year programme to address shortcomings in its non-financial risk management, following an internal report that deemed it "immature and reactive". The report found the bank to be overly complex, leading to confusion around accountability and challenges in execution. The bank had previously identified 45 recommendations to fix governance concerns but only 30 had been implemented as of its interim results in May. The new programme will focus on improving risk frameworks, setting leadership standards, and providing staff training.

site_title: Volkswagen sees mild growth in China's premium car segment this year
summary: Volkswagen expects a mild growth in China's premium car segment this year, driven by its joint ventures with local partners. Despite a decline in broader market sales, the company's China chief, Stephan Woellenstein, attributes the growth to increasing demand for premium vehicles. Volkswagen has a significant presence in China, with joint ventures in SAIC Motor, FAW Group, and JAC. The company's premium segment is expected to drive growth, despite the overall market slowdown.

images.alt_text: German automaker Volkswagen AG expects a slight growth in China's premium car segment this year despite a slide in broader market sales, a senior executive said.

site_title: United Airlines, pilots union reach creative deal to limit furloughs
summary: United Airlines and its pilots' union have reached a deal to limit involuntary furloughs in the fall, aiming to keep pilots ready for increased demand once the coronavirus-induced downturn subsides. The agreement includes two packages to reduce furloughs, with the goal of minimizing job cuts. This comes as the US airline industry faces a significant downturn, with tens of thousands of jobs at risk in October when a government bailout expires. The deal is seen as a positive step for the industry, with United Airlines and the pilots' union working together to mitigate the impact of the crisis.

images.alt_text: United Airlines said last week it was sending notices of potential furloughs to 36,000 US-based front-line employees, or about 45 per cent of staff.

site_title: Seattle data startup Qumulo is now a unicorn
summary: Seattle-based data management startup Qumulo has raised an additional $125 million in funding, valuing the company at $1.2 billion. The new round, led by BlackRock, is expected to capitalize on increased interest in cloud services amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has driven more companies to adopt remote data management solutions. The company's CEO, Bill Richter, attributes the growth to the pandemic, citing increased data handling needs and reduced IT employee visits to servers. Qumulo has seen significant interest from customers, including the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation.

images.alt_text: With online activity becoming a defining element of the "next normal", the 44 zettabytes of data expected to be generated by 2020 could pave the way for improved financial inclusion.

site_title: Cathay Pacific flags first-half loss of HK$9.9b as travel demand battered
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a first-half net loss of HK$9.9 billion, its largest half-yearly loss in at least a decade, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on travel demand. The airline had burned through cash of HK$2.50 billion to HK$3 billion each month since February. This loss compared to a HK$1.35 billion profit in the first half of 2019. Impairment charges on 16 planes also contributed to the significant loss.

images.alt_text: The estimated first-half loss would be Cathay's biggest half-yearly loss in at least a decade.

site_title: Dyna-Mac warns of Q2 loss after 'significant disruption' to projects amid pandemic
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings is expected to report a net loss for the second quarter and a cumulative loss for the half year ended June 30, citing "significant disruption" to projects due to the pandemic. The disruptions, including Singapore's "circuit-breaker" measures that restricted migrant workers, led to production activities being suspended. The company will release its unaudited results soon, with the preliminary review indicating a Q2 loss.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.24 points, or 0.40%, to 1,585.01. The market saw a higher volume of 340.08 million lots worth RM256.88 million, with 215 losers beating 130 gainers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by the positive effects of a cheaper yen against the dollar, outweighing falls on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.29% and the Topix index added 0.17%. The gains were largely due to the yen's depreciation, which boosted sentiment.

site_title: Asia: Markets bounce from sell-off but caution lingers
summary: Asian markets recovered from a sell-off on Thursday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai adding 1% and Shanghai climbing a similar amount, respectively. However, recent data showed that the economic recovery may be slower than expected, with China's retail sales below forecasts and US unemployment benefits remaining high. Economists fear that secondary infection outbreaks could pose significant challenges to the recovery, leading to a "lengthy S-L-O-G shaped recovery" rather than a V-shaped one. The European Union's economic rescue package is set to be discussed at a summit today, with low expectations for an agreement this weekend.

site_title: Trump lawyers pledge to continue tax returns fight
summary: US President Donald Trump's lawyers vowed to continue fighting to keep his tax returns private despite a Supreme Court ruling requiring him to hand over financial records to New York prosecutors. Trump's lawyers plan to contest the scope of the investigation, arguing that the subpoena is excessive and amounts to "harassment and bad faith." The records, spanning 2011-2018, are sought in connection with an alleged hush money payment to Stormy Daniels. The records may remain hidden from public view due to grand jury secrecy and are unlikely to be released before Trump's re-election bid in November.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher after upbeat export data; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 2,632.83, driven by upbeat export data, which expanded 16.1% year-on-year in June. Local banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, also gained, with DBS rising 0.2% and OCBC introducing digital banking services via the SingPass Mobile app. Meanwhile, US and European stocks fell, with Wall Street stocks declining after mixed economic data, and European stocks recovering ahead of a European recovery fund meeting.

site_title: British Airways retires entire fleet of Boeing's jumbo jets
summary: British Airways has retired its entire fleet of Boeing 747 jumbo jets due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the travel industry. The move comes as global curbs led to a downturn in air travel, placing airline companies in doubt. The company stated that its iconic "queen of the skies" will no longer operate commercial services for British Airways.

site_title: Rare twin red-ruffed lemurs born at Singapore zoo
summary: Singapore zoo has welcomed twin red-ruffed lemurs, a rare double delivery that is a boost for the endangered species. The twins, born to an 8-year-old mother Minnie, are the first births at the zoo in over a decade. Red-ruffed lemurs, native to Madagascar, are classified as critically endangered due to logging and hunting, with only 103 of 107 species surviving. The zoo's rare birth is a significant event for conservation efforts, highlighting the need for continued protection of the species.

site_title: US mortgage rates reach historic depths below 3%: Freddie Mac
summary: US 30-year fixed-rate mortgages have fallen below 3% for the first time in nearly 50 years, averaging 2.98% with an average 0.7 point. The decline reflects investor demand for safe havens and the Federal Reserve's quantitative easing efforts. This drop is expected to spur increased consumer spending, with refinancing and potential home buying driving economic growth.

images.alt_text: US 30-year fixed-rate mortgages fell below 3 per cent for the first time in records going back nearly 50 years this week, according to data released by Freddie Mac on Thursday.

site_title: Biolidics says will take up to 9 months to incorporate A*Star tech into new serology tests
summary: Biolidics, a COVID-19 test kit maker, says it will take up to 9 months to incorporate A*Star technology into new serology tests. The company licensed the technology for non-exclusive worldwide rights and is currently in the initial phase of product development. Biolidics has shortlisted potential partners and is assessing them, but there is no certainty it will successfully develop the tests. The company must also obtain regulatory approvals and product liability insurance before commercializing the tests.

site_title: Burnt banks claim fraud, fabrications in Asian oil-trading web
summary: Two Singaporean banks, CIMB and Natixis, have filed lawsuits against a web of Asian oil-trading firms, alleging fabrications and fraud in transactions worth US$192 million. The banks claim that Hontop Energy, a unit of China Wanda Group, and Sugih Energy International, now renamed Aeturnum Energy International, misrepresented deals to sell crude oil to BP. The banks accuse Hontop and Sugih of failing to deliver oil and refusing to pay back US$192 million. The cases highlight the risks of financing the commodities trading sector, with lenders facing significant losses amid the oil-price crash.

site_title: Rex to fully develop Oman oil field; Norway well will be drilled in August
summary: Rex International has received approval from Oman's Ministry of Oil and Gas to fully develop the Yunma oil field, which is part of its Block 50 licence. The firm's subsidiary Masirah Oil will be responsible for the development, while continuing to explore the rest of the concession. This move is expected to "fundamentally change" Rex's corporate profile. Meanwhile, Rex's Norwegian operations will see the drilling of the Appolonia prospect in late August, with a potential production start-up by end-2024.

site_title: Xbox cloud gaming service to debut in September
summary: Microsoft's cloud gaming service will debut in September as a feature available to Xbox Game Pass Ultimate subscribers. Ultimate members will be able to play over 100 Xbox Game Pass titles on their phones or tablets. The service will also allow subscribers to access a library of games on Xbox consoles or Windows-powered computers. Microsoft has not yet announced pricing, but the service will be available in time for the Christmas holiday season, when the new Xbox Series X console is set to launch. This move is seen as a response to cloud gaming services like Google Stadia and Sony's PlayStation Now.

site_title: OUE to sell iconic US Bank Tower for US$430m, below valuation
summary: OUE Limited is selling the US Bank Tower for $430 million, a price about two-thirds of its $650 million fair value as of 2019. The sale price was determined by considering the property's market value and current US property market conditions amid the coronavirus pandemic. The sale is a result of OUE's efforts to optimize its portfolio and generate returns. The transaction is expected to be completed soon, although a specific timeline has not been announced.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch lower on unemployment, virus worries; New Zealand recovers
summary: Australian shares declined 0.1% on Friday, weighed by a rise in unemployment and surging coronavirus cases in Victoria. The jobless rate hit a 22-year high of 7.4%, despite record employment growth. Rio Tinto surged 2.4% after beating quarterly iron ore shipment estimates. New Zealand's benchmark index recovered 0.7% after manufacturing activity rebounded in June.

site_title: UN seeks US$3.6b more for virus plan, criticises inaction
summary: The United Nations is seeking an additional $3.6 billion to support its Global Humanitarian Response Plan to combat the pandemic, warning of "the price of inaction" if poorer nations don't receive help. The plan aims to prevent famines in Somalia, South Sudan, Yemen, and Nigeria, and also combat the economic crisis, with funds needed for medical equipment, information campaigns, and humanitarian air bridges. Only $1.7 billion has been donated since March, with a total of $10.3 billion requested.

site_title: Covid-19, electric vehicles to reshape Thailand's auto industry
summary: Thailand's automotive industry, employing 900,000 people, is shifting towards electric vehicles (EVs) due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to factory shutdowns. However, this shift poses a threat to the local auto industry, as EVs require fewer parts, putting 800 auto-parts companies and 325,000 jobs at risk. Thai auto-parts makers are diversifying into industries like medical equipment and aviation, while the government is exploring new measures to attract investors and provide clarity to ensure Thailand's competitiveness in EV manufacturing.

site_title: Netflix shares dive on profit miss despite user growth
summary: Netflix shares plummeted 10% after the streaming service reported flat quarterly profits despite a 10.1 million increase in paid memberships. Revenue reached $6.1 billion, beating expectations, but the company warned that growth may slow as new users rushed to join during the pandemic. Netflix is focusing on restarting productions safely and adapting to local health and safety standards, while facing increased competition from tech giants and entertainment titans. The company also announced executive changes, including Ted Sarandos becoming co-CEO and Greg Peters taking on additional roles.

site_title: US coronavirus cases shatter records and rise by 70,000 in single day
summary: The US reported a record 70,272 new Covid-19 cases on Thursday, surpassing the previous record of 69,070. This marks the seventh time this month that the country has seen a record daily increase. US deaths are also rising, with Arizona, California, Florida, and Texas leading the way. Florida reported a record 15,000 new cases in 24 hours. Health experts warn that cases could soon top 100,000 a day if Americans do not take steps to halt the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: The United States reported at least 70,000 new Covid-19 cases on Thursday, a record daily increase for the seventh time this month, according to a Reuters tally.

site_title: Singapore's hottest stock AEM is set to continue winning streak
summary: AEM Holdings, a Singapore-based chip-testing equipment provider, is set to continue its winning streak in the stock market, with a 53% surge this year. The company is a top supplier to Intel and benefits from emerging trends in the semiconductor industry, driven by growing demand for chips in data centers, autonomous vehicles, and next-generation technology. Analysts expect AEM Holdings to gain 19% over the next 12 months, putting it in the running to be the best performer on the FTSE ST All-Share Index.

images.alt_text: "More AI, more 5G applications, more telecommuting, more cloud services. Overall the macros look positive to us," said AEM chairman Loke Wai San in an interview.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE, Top Glove, Raffles Education, Biolidics, Yeo Hiap Seng
summary: OUE Limited will sell its US Bank Tower for $430 million, below valuation. Top Glove, UG Healthcare, and Riverstone Holdings saw sharp selloffs after a rise in demand for gloves amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Raffles Education Corp is set to take control of a Chinese property firm. Biolidics expects to incorporate A*Star technology into a new serology test kit in up to nine months. Yeo Hiap Seng expects to report a net loss in the first half of 2020 due to the pandemic.

site_title: New York to invest US$750m to expand electric-vehicle infrastructure
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo announced a US$750 million investment to expand electric vehicle infrastructure, including over 50,000 charging stations. The program, funded by state investor-owned utility companies and a 2017 settlement with Volkswagen AG, aims to reduce emissions. This move follows similar initiatives by Florida and aims to increase electric vehicle adoption, which currently accounts for less than 2% of US vehicle sales. The expansion of charging networks is seen as crucial to addressing consumer concerns and increasing wider adoption of electric vehicles.

site_title: Twitter hack raises security questions as US elections near
summary: A massive Twitter hack targeted high-profile users, including Elon Musk, Joe Biden, and others, in an attempt to dupe them into sending Bitcoin. The hack, which occurred on Wednesday, resulted in the theft of nearly $116,000 in cryptocurrency. Twitter has locked down affected accounts and removed the fraudulent tweets, while the FBI is investigating. The incident raises questions about the platform's security ahead of the US presidential election, with some lawmakers calling for a national cybersecurity czar.

images.alt_text: Twitter is probing a massive hack of high-profile users from Elon Musk to Joe Biden that has raised questions about the platform's security as it serves as a megaphone for politicians ahead of November's election.

site_title: Police dismantle counterfeit money-makers, nab 44 in Europe
summary: European police have dismantled a counterfeit money printing gang linked to the Camorra mafia clan, arresting 44 people, including a grandson of French actress Catherine Deneuve. The operation, coordinated by Europol, resulted in the seizure of 8 million euros in cash and property. The gang produced high-quality counterfeit 50-euro notes, valued at 10 million euros, and had ties to the mafia clan, which has a monopoly on the market for counterfeit currency. The investigation, launched in 2017, targeted the gang's sophisticated printing operation.

site_title: Fonterra raises lower-end of 2020/21 forecast farmgate milk price as China demand improves
summary: New Zealand dairy giant Fonterra raised the lower end of its 2020/21 farmgate milk price forecast to NZ$5.90 to NZ$6.90 per kg of milk solids due to improving demand in China, its top market. The decision comes after the initial shock of the Covid-19 pandemic, with Fonterra Chairman John Monaghan citing a recovering dairy consumption in China. Despite uncertainty in global markets, Fonterra lifted the lower end of the price range, citing declining risk levels. The company also narrowed the price range for the 2019/2020 season to NZ$7.10 to NZ$7.20 per kgMS.

site_title: STI slides 25.23 points to 2,623.67 on broadly negative sentiment
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,623.67, down 25.23 points or 0.95% due to a broadly negative sentiment. The market was affected by layoffs at Resorts World Sentosa and uncertainty over the global economic outlook. MAS is in talks with local banks on capital management matters, including possible restrictions on dividend payments. Smaller cap stocks, such as Top Glove and UG Healthcare, also declined, with Top Glove losing 11.1% and UG Healthcare losing 14.3%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end off session lows ahead of EU summit
summary: European stocks ended the session 0.7% lower, reversing earlier losses, ahead of the EU summit on Friday to organize a European recovery fund. The European Central Bank maintained policy steady, with Christine Lagarde suggesting grants over loans in the stimulus scheme. Despite this, strategists at ING expect no agreement on the recovery fund's operation. Italy's FTSE MIB turned positive, while shares in European luxury goods group Richemont fell 4.6% due to halved quarterly sales.

site_title: Oil shrugs off Opec+ cuts taper to trade near four-month high
summary: Oil futures in New York dropped below $41 a barrel after reaching a four-month high on Wednesday, as the Opec+ alliance confirmed it will start tapering output cuts from next month. The move, which will partially offset reduced production from non-compliant countries, was met with confidence by Saudi Arabia and Russia. Despite the tapering, oil prices remain near a four-month high, driven by a strong market rally.

site_title: Oil falls as Opec+ plans to raise output while virus cases increase
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Thursday after Opec+ agreed to ease record supply curbs, citing a rebounding demand worldwide. Despite this, fears of a second wave of Covid-19 cases, particularly in the US, kept prices in check. Brent and US crude prices settled at $43.37 and $40.75 a barrel, respectively. Opec+ plans to scale back oil production cuts from August, reducing them by 2 million barrels per day to 7.7 million bpd through December.

site_title: US announces borders with Mexico, Canada to stay shut to August 20
summary: US Homeland Security Acting Secretary Chad Wolf announced that borders with Mexico and Canada will remain shut to most travel until August 20 to stem the spread of the coronavirus. This decision comes as new US confirmed infections hit a record 67,632 and deaths surpassed 137,000, underscoring the failure of the US government to control the pandemic. The four-month-old shutdown has been successful in collaboration with Canada, but the timing raises concerns about the effectiveness of the US response.

site_title: Answering a tribal call
summary: US President Donald Trump could potentially win a second term in November if Democrats fail to counter the Republican party's leveraging of identity politics. Recent examples include the COVID-19 rescue package, which was signed by Trump with bipartisan support, and the healthcare debate on the individual mandate, where Republicans initially supported the policy but later turned against it. This suggests that Republicans are prioritizing party loyalty over principles, and that voters are willing to accept policy reversals if they align with their tribal identity.

site_title: US: Nasdaq retreats in down day for stocks
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Nasdaq retreating 0.7% to 10,473.83, after two strong sessions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average shed 0.5% to 26,734.71, and the S&P 500 lost 0.3% to 3,215.57. Analysts attribute the decline to a rotation out of tech into cyclicals, citing strong earnings from banking and industrial shares. Economic data showed little improvement, with unemployment claims remaining high and US retail sales rising at a slower pace than in May.

site_title: Business Solutions
summary: Startups have found opportunities in the wake of the pandemic, offering innovative solutions to address changing consumer needs. Four companies, gnômadic, GTRIIP, QIQ POD, and Style Degree, have successfully adapted to the crisis. Gnômadic, a co-living company, has seen an increase in interest from locals, while GTRIIP's contactless entry software has become essential for hotels and offices. QIQ POD, an electric vehicle co-sharing service, aims to improve city transportation efficiency. Style Degree, a home organization brand, has seen a surge in demand for its products during the pandemic. These startups demonstrate how businesses can thrive in the face of adversity.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports jump by 16.1% in June on low base in previous year
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports surged 16.1% in June, driven by specialised machinery, pharmaceuticals, and non-monetary gold exports. This rebound follows a 4.6% contraction in May, beating private-sector economists' estimates of 8% growth. Total trade declined 6.6% year-on-year, with both exports and imports on the decline due to low oil prices. The growth is seen as a positive sign for the economy, but experts caution that external risks remain, and the momentum may not be sustained into the second half of the year.

site_title: Heineken H1 revenue falls 16% due to Covid-19; shares dip
summary: Heineken's first-half net revenue fell 16.4% due to the impact of coronavirus-related lockdowns, with beer volume dropping 11.5% in the period. The company attributed the decline to restaurant and bars closures, which disproportionately affected its operating profit. Heineken reported a 52.5% plunge in January-June preliminary operating profit and a 75.8% drop in net profit. The company's shares fell over 5% following the announcement.

site_title: Old-world distilleries join the rye-whiskey party
summary: Old-world distilleries in Scotland and Europe are producing rye whiskey, a spirit once considered distinctly American. The InchDairnie Distillery in Fife, Scotland, is one of the first to adopt rye as a primary grain, joining a growing trend. This shift is attributed to the increasing popularity of rye whiskey globally over the past decade. Other European distilleries are also experimenting with rye-based spirits, expanding the whiskey category beyond traditional single-malt Scotch.

site_title: Korean biotech firm takes second shot at Singapore backdoor listing
summary: A South Korean biotech firm, BiogenicsKorea, is attempting a second backdoor listing in Singapore. This move comes after the company's initial attempt was unsuccessful. Kossen, a stainless steel manufacturer and key shareholder of BiogenicsKorea, has signed an implementation agreement with Epicentre Holdings and Tardis Capital. The agreement is seen as a significant step towards securing the biotech firm's listing. The backdoor route allows BiogenicsKorea to list without meeting the usual requirements for a direct listing.

site_title: Cartier maker Richemont's sales plummet amid Covid-19 disruption
summary: Richemont's sales plummeted 47% to €1.99 billion in the first quarter, due to the Covid-19 pandemic's disruption to its operations. Store closures and travel restrictions, particularly in China, led to a decline in sales across all regions. However, online sales in China more than doubled, and Asia Pacific saw a 49% increase. Richemont's shares were indicated 3.8% lower, with Bernstein analyst Luca Solca stating that strong Chinese consumer appetite for top brands is reassuring for the company's trading outlook.

site_title: Redevelopment may head off office market blues
summary: Singapore's office rents are easing amid a recession, with the average CBD Grade A office rental value easing 2.7% since last year. The limited completion of new CBD Grade A offices may mitigate the rental drop, but redevelopment of ageing office blocks in the central business district is expected to provide a silver lining. Several owners, including AXA Tower and Fuji Xerox Towers, are considering redevelopment, which could lead to renewed demand for office space. Experts forecast a 10% decline in office rents for the full year, with leasing activity expected to pick up as tenants scout for replacement space.

site_title: Commercial podium of Tedge put up for sale
summary: The entire commercial podium of Tedge, a mixed-use development in Singapore, has been put up for sale. The guide price is over S$18 million or S$3,228 per square foot, with a total strata area of 5,576 sq ft. The sale includes four adjoining commercial units, including two F&B units and two shop units, marketed by Savills Singapore on behalf of Macly Group, the developer.

images.alt_text: Guide price of Tedge is in excess of S$18 million or S$3,228 per square foot, said Savills Singapore.

site_title: Can Ambani take on Tencent, Huawei and Xiaomi?
summary: India's richest man, Mukesh Ambani, is planning to step into the global technology market with his four-year-old Jio Platforms, despite the US-China tech cold war. Ambani has built its own 5G technology, which he plans to offer to other markets. Alphabet's Sundar Pichai has pledged $4.5 billion for a 7.7% stake in Jio and a chance to build an Android operating system, threatening Huawei and Xiaomi. Ambani also plans to use WhatsApp to drive commerce, similar to Tencent's WeChat. The move aims to make India the world's factory, but the country's infrastructure and balance sheet are not yet ready.

site_title: Singapore's First Virtual Fashion Fest
summary: Singapore's first virtual fashion festival, The Front Row, will take place from August 20 to 29. The festival features 24 local and international brands showcasing virtual fashion shows, style presentations, and workshops. Creative director Daniel Boey aims to combat the pandemic's social distancing measures and address industry challenges such as high carbon emissions and wastage. The festival will offer "front row" seats for online viewers, allowing them to purchase items instantly and engage with designers virtually. Boey hopes that the festival will democratize fashion and promote sustainable practices among local labels.

site_title: UOB, Getz tie-up offers lower delivery fees for F&B outlets
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and Getz, a food and beverage payment platform provider, have partnered to offer lower food delivery transaction fees and marketing support to F&B merchants. Under the collaboration, UOB will cap transaction fees at 4% of online sales, a discount of up to 50% from Getz's usual rates. The tie-up also enables F&B merchants to set up online stores and marketing efforts, with UOB featuring them on its The Dining Advisor online marketplace.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's new Asia CEO chooses to relocate to Singapore
summary: Deutsche Bank's new Asia CEO, Alexander von zur Muehlen, will be based in Singapore, relocating from Frankfurt. This decision comes as Hong Kong is experiencing unprecedented political turbulence. Von zur Muehlen's predecessor, Werner Steinmueller, is retiring and Kamran Khan, the bank's new head of environmental, social and governance, will also be based in Singapore. The move marks the first time in at least a decade for the German bank to have its sole Asia CEO outside Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Banks says it remains committed to its dual-hub structure in the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Skyscanner to downsize Singapore marketing team
summary: Skyscanner plans to downsize its marketing division in Singapore, centralising the function in the UK, as the company prepares to retrench about a fifth of its 1,500 employees globally due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company has not made a decision on office space in Singapore, but will give enhanced redundancy pay to affected staff, including time off for interviews and outplacement support.

site_title: BI cuts rate for second month as growth sputters
summary: Bank Indonesia (BI) cut its seven-day reverse repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 4% for the second consecutive month to bolster economic growth, as predicted by 18 of 30 economists surveyed. The central bank expects the economy to grow 0.9-1.9% this year and inflation to remain low. Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that further rate cuts will depend on inflationary pressures and the recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The rate cut may weigh on the rupiah, but the governor believes it remains undervalued and has room to appreciate.

images.alt_text: Inflation has slumped to a two-decade low as the pandemic crippled businesses and rendered millions of people jobless.

site_title: Covid-19 and tech has changed culture consumption
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated a shift in how people consume culture, with virtual travel and experiences on the rise. Online searches for Google Arts and Culture quadrupled in March, and cloud usage has expanded to boost continuity in the arts. Data advancements are also being used to preserve cultural heritage, with non-profit CyArk adding 100 new 3D models and companies like Google and the BBC developing AR and VR experiences. These innovations aim to provide immersive and accessible cultural experiences, and may pave the way for future preservation efforts.

site_title: Moving online now will help businesses emerge stronger on the other side of the crisis
summary: Businesses can emerge stronger from the current crisis by transitioning online. During the 2003 Sars outbreak, Alibaba invested heavily in technology to launch its Taobao e-commerce platform, overcoming workforce challenges. This experience can inform current strategies. Companies that fail to adapt digitally risk losing their competitive edge. By moving online, businesses can improve efficiency, reach new customers, and recover more quickly from future crises.

site_title: Bank of Korea's governor puts recovery before property price concerns
summary: Bank of Korea Governor Lee Ju-yeol prioritized economic recovery over property market concerns, keeping interest rates at a record low of 0.5% due to the resurgence of the pandemic. The central bank now expects the economy to shrink more than initially predicted. This decision was made after a unanimous vote by the board, following the latest economic update. The move aims to support the virus-hit economy despite concerns about the property market.

site_title: KrisEnergy's debt revamp rubs bondholders wrong way
summary: A group of KrisEnergy's bondholders is opposing the company's proposed debt restructuring, citing a disproportionate allocation to its largest shareholder, Keppel Corp. The bondholders, who feel "desperate," are seeking a better deal after the pandemic-led oil shock exacerbated the firm's debt dilemma. The proposed debt-to-equity swap, announced a month ago, has sparked discontent among the disgruntled investors.

site_title: Twitter muzzles temporarily some accounts after internal systems hacks
summary: Twitter temporarily suspended some high-profile accounts, including US presidential candidate Joe Biden, reality TV star Kim Kardashian, and billionaire Elon Musk, after hackers accessed internal systems to solicit digital currency. The hackers, who received over $100,000 in cryptocurrency, used compromised accounts to tweet on behalf of verified users. Twitter is investigating the breach and will restore access when it can do so securely. The incident raises questions about Twitter's cybersecurity, with experts stating that the company is not doing enough to protect itself.

site_title: Second time's the charm as ESR-Reit, Sabana Reit revive merger proposal
summary: ESR-Reit and Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) have revived a merger proposal, aiming to create an enlarged entity with a market value of S$1.8 billion and free float of S$1.3 billion. The deal would increase the enlarged Reit's shot at EPRA NAREIT index inclusion, offering advantages such as a wider investor base, higher trading liquidity, and access to a more competitive cost of capital. The merger is expected to be distributionally accretive to unitholders, with potential benefits including higher debt headroom, operational synergies, and asset enhancement initiatives.

site_title: ECB says 'ample stimulus' still necessary
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) defended its pandemic stimulus package, stating it expected to use the full amount of planned debt purchases to support the eurozone economy during a lockdown-induced recession. ECB President Christine Lagarde said the package is "effective, adequate, and working" and that "ample stimulus" is still necessary to counter uncertainty around the virus and its economic impact. The ECB remains on track to buy up to 1.35 trillion euros in debt through June, with policymakers also urging European Union leaders to agree on a long-delayed fiscal support package.

site_title: Keppel Land achieves 22% reduction in carbon emission intensity from 2010 level
summary: Keppel Land achieved a 22% reduction in carbon emission intensity from 2010 levels in 2019, exceeding its initial target. The company has set a new goal of reducing emissions by 40% by 2030, which would result in a cumulative reduction of nearly 140,000 tonnes of carbon emissions. This new target is part of Keppel Land's sustainability efforts.

site_title: US$ climbs, traders focus on weak Chinese retail
summary: The US dollar strengthened on Thursday as investors focused on weak Chinese retail sales, overshadowing the country's stronger-than-expected Q2 economic growth. The euro remained unchanged after the European Central Bank left monetary policy unchanged. The focus now shifts to the upcoming European Union summit this weekend.

site_title: Glove plays in sell-off after bullish run; Top Glove gets US detention order
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest glove manufacturer, has seen its shares plummet 11.1% after the US Customs and Border Protection issued a detention order on imports made by the company's subsidiaries, citing concerns over forced labor. The US Customs order may be related to a retrospective payment of recruitment fees to agents prior to 2019, without the company's knowledge. Other glove makers, UG Healthcare and Riverstone Holdings, also registered significant price falls, with UG Healthcare dropping 33% and Riverstone shedding 8% this week. The US detention order has triggered a sell-off in the glove sector, with analysts predicting a shortage in supply and high average selling prices.

site_title: Sushi Revival
summary: A surge in new Japanese restaurants in Singapore is reviving the post-pandemic food scene, offering authentic sushi and izakaya experiences. Three eateries, Sushi Kenji, Nishikane, and ARAKI, have recently opened, showcasing the culinary skills of experienced chefs. Sushi Kenji, run by Chef Kenji Nakagawa, serves affordable omakase at S$88 and S$128, while Nishikane, owned by Chef Nobuhiro Nishi, offers high-end omakase with seasonal ingredients. ARAKI, set to open in August, will feature casual kappo, Japanese fusion, and sushi with a focus on simplicity and local ingredients.

site_title: China's June home prices pick up, property investment grows
summary: China's real estate investment grew 8.5% in June, surpassing May's 8.1% growth, driven by robust construction activity and easier credit. Property prices rose 0.6% in June, the fastest pace since July 2019, and home prices expanded 4.9% annually. However, consumer confidence remains soft, and the government continues to crack down on speculation, limiting a sustainable rebound.

site_title: Putting the 'fin' back in fintech
summary: Fintech companies are reevaluating their focus, shifting from relying solely on technology to using it as a key enabler of innovation. The scandal surrounding Wirecard has raised concerns about the sector's regulatory risks, investor demands, and product obfuscation. Experts argue that fintechs should prioritize building trust, managing operational risks, and creating sustainable profit models. The industry is expected to undergo significant changes, with a focus on governance, risk management, and consumer protection. Fintechs are likely to emerge as a strong and sustainable force for the financial sector, with the potential to reach $265 billion in global revenues by 2025.

site_title: Work and Play
summary: Google has released its new Pixel Buds, designed to fit flush with the ear for a low-profile look, suitable for both casual use and intense workouts. The earbuds sit comfortably in place, eliminating concerns of them falling out while exercising or wearing hats or jackets.

site_title: Startups' plug-and-play solutions offer path to digitalisation
summary: Startups in South-east Asia are seeing increased demand from small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to adopt digitalisation solutions due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Plug-and-play solutions offer a "one-stop shop" for businesses to address digital needs at an affordable price. Companies such as Grab, Shopmatic, and KiotViet are providing digitalisation tools, including e-commerce integration, marketing, and training services, to help SMEs navigate the digital landscape. The government's Productivity Solutions Grant and Enterprise Development Grant are supporting the adoption of digital tools, with over 10,000 projects embarked on in the first half of 2020.

site_title: Leadership in the new normal
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the complexity of the world, rendering traditional deterministic approaches to leadership obsolete. Most leadership teams rely on simplifying problems, making assumptions, and generating forecasts, which are no longer effective in today's unpredictable environment. Four practices can help leaders navigate complexity: recognizing and embracing complexity, imagining possible futures, and emphasizing preparedness. By adopting these practices, leaders can cultivate humility, open-mindedness, and a learning mindset, ultimately leading to a greater sense of purpose and resilience in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: A stream of office space leasing deals in pipeline despite uncertain business climate
summary: Despite the uncertain business climate due to the Covid-19 outbreak, a stream of office space leasing deals has been completed in Singapore. Deals include a 50,000-60,000 sq ft lease by Delivery Hero at the Afro-Asia i-Mark project, a 90,000-plus sq ft lease by Amazon at Asia Square Tower 1, and a 60,000 sq ft lease by Fuji Xerox at Mapletree Business City. These deals indicate that some companies are expanding their office space despite the pandemic, with analysts attributing this to the online food delivery business's success during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Amazon is said to be in talks to lease about 90,000 sq ft at Asia Square Tower 1.

site_title: Redesigned Classics
summary: Patek Philippe has released a limited edition stainless steel Calatrava watch to celebrate its new Plan-les-Ouates manufacture. The 40mm watch features a grey-blue dial and calfskin strap, and is powered by the caliber 324 S C movement. TAG Heuer has overhauled its Carrera chronograph to bring it back to its racing roots, with a cleaner and modern design. Audemars Piguet has introduced three new Offshore chronographs with black ceramic cases and textured rubber straps, featuring its trademark Mega Tapisserie dial design.

site_title: Steeper falls likely for Singapore retail rents in H2
summary: Singapore retail rents are expected to decline further in the second half of 2020 due to higher vacancies and lower footfalls amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Activity-based tenants, such as F&B and health and wellness businesses, are likely to shut down, leading to increased vacancies in non-prime locations. However, prime retail rents in sought-after suburban malls are expected to maintain high occupancy levels. Cushman & Wakefield predicts a 10% decline in prime rents and a 5% decline in suburban prime rents for the full year.

site_title: MAS reviewing banks' capital plans, including dividend payouts
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing banks' capital plans, including dividend payouts, amid global economic uncertainty. MAS Managing Director Ravi Menon said banks' capital management should be approached "from a position of strength" to ensure they can continue providing financial services. Despite a potential recession, MAS expects the financial sector to remain resilient and create jobs, with a net increase of 4,900 jobs in financial services and fintech this year. The regulator is also developing a grant scheme for green and sustainability-linked loans.

images.alt_text: For the year as a whole, MAS expects the financial services sector to still be a net creator of jobs, though at a much lower level than in previous years.

site_title: Alpha Energy proposes S$20m fundraising for its foray into education
summary: Alpha Energy is proposing a S$20 million fundraising to diversify into the education business through its acquisition of Kydon Learning Systems Institute (KLSI) for S$12 million in cash and stock. The company has entered into a non-binding term sheet with Didi Investments for the convertible loan, subject to definitive agreements. The loan will primarily fund the KLSI acquisition and future investments in the education sector, with a 6% interest rate and a conversion price of 0.35 Singapore cent per share. The move aims to generate additional revenue streams while waiting for the oil industry to improve.

site_title: US retail sales increase in June; weekly jobless claims remain elevated
summary: US retail sales rose 7.5% in June, exceeding expectations, but the economic recovery is threatened by a surge in new COVID-19 cases and high unemployment. The Commerce Department reported the increase, following a 18.2% jump in May. Weekly jobless claims remained elevated at 1.30 million, double the highest point during the 2007-09 Great Recession. The COVID-19 resurgence, particularly in the South and West, is sparking uncertainty and could worsen unemployment.

site_title: Walmart customers must wear face masks
summary: Walmart will require customers to wear face masks starting July 20, joining a growing list of businesses mandating mask-wearing amid the US COVID-19 spike. The company's move comes as the US death toll approaches 157,000, with some models estimating it could rise above 220,000 by November. The policy change follows other retailers like Best Buy and Kroger, and is seen as a step to protect shoppers' safety.

site_title: MAS, banks to see how best to wean borrowers off Covid-19 reliefs
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is studying how to ease COVID-19 relief measures, as support cannot continue indefinitely. MAS Managing Director Ravi Menon says deferred payments provide temporary relief but come with additional costs. The authority is working with banks, finance companies, and insurers to gradually resume repayments, balancing between borrowers' cashflow situations and the accumulation of debt. MAS expects the global economy to grow 3.5% in the second half of 2020, but warns of potential corporate bankruptcies and restructuring.

images.alt_text: Mr Menon says deferred payments are temporary and come with added costs.

site_title: E-com offers more than just a digital echo of an old world
summary: Singaporean e-commerce merchants are shifting their focus to international markets due to the need for long-term survival and resilience in the post-pandemic economy. The government has encouraged businesses to look abroad, and online retailers must adapt to meet growing demand for mobile-first experiences, personalized shopping, and secure transactions. To succeed, they must overcome logistical challenges, local regulations, and market expertise, while investing in omnichannel experiences and safeguarding against cyber risks.

site_title: Where the jobs are
summary: Singapore is officially in recession, but the jobs market is starting to show signs of recovery. Key sectors such as banking, finance, and sustainability are now hiring. The pandemic has also led to favourable outcomes, including government subsidies for wages and diversified supply chains. Economists and recruiters predict a labour market recovery, with companies prioritizing inclusion and strategic imperatives. Meanwhile, the government is exploring Modern Monetary Theory and its implications for the economy and investors.

site_title: GuocoLand's flagship Guoco Tower strikes gold at real estate's 'Oscars'
summary: GuocoLand's flagship Guoco Tower was named a World Gold Winner in the mixed-use development category at the FIABCI World Prix d'Excellence Awards. This is GuocoLand's second win, following its Leedon Residence in 2018. Guoco Tower, Singapore's tallest skyscraper, was recognized for its high liveability, connectivity, and community building efforts. The award reaffirms GuocoLand's pursuit of quality and excellence in its projects, as it navigates uncertainty in the real estate market.

site_title: Family offices temporarily reduce risk profile amid Covid-19: UBS report
summary: Global family offices have shifted towards risk-averse asset classes such as cash and gold amid the Covid-19 pandemic, with 25% and 21% increasing allocations to these assets between March and May, according to the UBS 2020 Global Family Office Report. Despite this, family offices plan to reinvest cash over the next two to three years, targeting opportunities from market dislocations. They also plan to increase allocations in real estate and private equity, with 45% aiming to raise real estate allocations and 44% for developed market equities.

site_title: Airbnb says IPO plans are back on track
summary: Airbnb has resumed its efforts to go public, despite the pandemic's impact on the home rental business. CEO Brian Chesky told employees the company's gross bookings have rebounded, but warned the trend could change with lockdowns returning. Airbnb has cut costs, raised emergency funding, and laid off 1,900 staff members. The company has also announced changes, including the new role of global head of hosting and the hiring of a marketing leader from Apple. Airbnb is not committing to an IPO this year, but is prepared when the market is ready.

site_title: US sanctions world's top surgical glove maker over forced labour
summary: The US has imposed a ban on importing surgical gloves from two Malaysian subsidiaries of Top Glove, the world's largest surgical glove maker, due to forced labor concerns. The ban affects about half of Top Glove's US sales, amid soaring demand for protective gear during the coronavirus pandemic. Top Glove denies exploiting its workforce, but acknowledges paying recruitment fees to migrant workers. The company hopes to resolve the issue and lift the ban within two weeks.

images.alt_text: The US has banned the import of surgical gloves from two subsidiaries of Malaysia's Top Glove, the world's biggest manufacturer of the product, over forced labour concerns, despite soaring demand during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Siri, Alexa targeted as EU probes 'internet of things'
summary: The European Union is probing US tech giants, including Apple and Amazon, over their handling of data and potential anti-competitive practices in the "internet of things." Voice assistants like Siri and Alexa are under scrutiny. EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager warned that if left unchecked, tech companies could push markets beyond competition, resulting in monopolies. The investigation aims to ensure fair access to data and promote competition in the growing IoT market.

site_title: Charlie Kaufman's Debut Novel Is Brilliant
summary: Charlie Kaufman, the Oscar-winning screenwriter and director, has published his debut novel "Antkind", which is a brilliant and deranged tale of a pretentious film historian named B Rosenberg. After meeting an old African American man named Ingo Cutbirth, B becomes obsessed with a stop-motion animation film that takes 90 years to make. The novel follows B's journey as he tries to recall the film's details, gets entangled in therapy, and navigates a series of surreal and eccentric events. With its unique blend of art, culture, and philosophical musings, "Antkind" is a celebration of the power of art to shape our perceptions of reality.

site_title: Michelle Obama to debut podcast on Spotify
summary: Former US First Lady Michelle Obama is set to debut a podcast on Spotify, "The Michelle Obama Podcast," which will focus on helping listeners have "hard conversations" with loved ones. The first episode will drop on July 29, featuring conversations with Michelle's close family and friends. This is the first podcast originating from Spotify's deal with the Obamas' production company Higher Ground, following a $600 million investment in podcasting since 2019.

site_title: Taiwan fears China 'hostage diplomacy' through HK security law
summary: Taiwan has warned China of using the Hong Kong national security law as "hostage diplomacy" to pressure democratic countries and expand its influence. The law, which allows China to prosecute serious cases globally, has heightened concerns in Taiwan, which China considers its own territory. Taiwan is urging global unity against Beijing's "autocratic" expansion, following China's imposition of the security law on Hong Kong.

site_title: SkillsFuture forum to discuss reshaping businesses and workforce amid Covid-19
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Ong Ye Kung will launch this year's SkillsFuture Month at the SkillsFuture Forum. The event aims to discuss reshaping businesses and the workforce amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The forum is expected to focus on strategies for sustainable growth and development in the post-pandemic era.

site_title: Yongnam secures four contracts worth S$63m
summary: Yongnam Holdings secured four contracts worth S$63 million in Singapore and Hong Kong. Three projects in Singapore will supply and fabricate structural steelwork for a mixed-use development, the Punggol Regional Sport Centre, and Changi East Development. The Hong Kong project involves earth lateral support work at an existing MTR terminus. The contracts are expected to boost the company's performance amid a decline in construction activities due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: UK's U-turn on Huawei risks post-Brexit trade relations crisis
summary: The UK has U-turned on its decision to allow Huawei to supply 5G equipment, banning new purchases after December 31. This move is expected to delay the UK's 5G network rollout and may strain post-Brexit trade relations with China, with the Chinese Ambassador warning that the UK's decision could lead to a deterioration in relations. The decision is seen as a victory for the US, which had pressured the UK to review its stance on Huawei. The move may also ease tension within the Five Eyes intelligence alliance, but is likely to face backlash from China, potentially impacting international relations.

site_title: Interview: Sonu Shivdasani, Founder of Soneva Resorts
summary: Sonu Shivdasani, founder of luxury resort brand Soneva, attributes the company's success to embracing environmental and social responsibility despite the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic. Soneva has implemented various eco-friendly practices, such as using bamboo and eucalyptus, reducing plastic use, and serving purified water. The company has also established the Soneva Foundation, which has raised over $7 million for charitable initiatives, including reforestation, wind power, and low-carbon stoves. Shivdasani believes that sustainability complements luxury and that the hospitality industry must adopt environmentally friendly practices to survive in a post-Covid-19 era.

site_title: Europe's car industry continues slow recovery
summary: Europe's car industry experienced a slow recovery in June, with new passenger-car registrations falling 24% compared to last year. This marks an improvement from May's 57% decline and April's 78% drop. Despite efforts from governments to encourage environmentally friendly car purchases with incentives, sales remain below last year's levels, with most countries in the region experiencing double-digit declines. The industry is hoping for a stronger rebound with state subsidies, but analysts predict a 20% drop in car sales for the year.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia's CEO resigns; no replacement named yet
summary: Hong Leong Asia's CEO, Tan Eng Kwee, has resigned, effective August 16, to "pursue other interests". The 66-year-old joined the company in December 2018, replacing Philip Ting. A replacement has not been named yet, with the company stating it will announce the appointment soon.

site_title: Keeping A Distance
