summary: Designers worldwide showcase creative ways to practice social distancing in public areas, encouraging safe behavior in a more compelling way. The "Where We Stand" project features 15 innovative designs, including individual structures at Bondi Beach, sound-conducting cones at Singapore Botanic Gardens, and sculptural benches at Bryant Park in New York. Other designs include sectioned football pitches, green mounds for gatherings, and a crowd-tracking system at Place Georges Pompidou in Paris, aiming to reshape public spaces and promote safe social distancing.

site_title: Wing Tai's Malaysia subsidiaries sell KL property and land for S$79.4m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings' Malaysian subsidiaries, Seniharta and DNP Jaya, have agreed to sell a Kuala Lumpur development and land for RM243.8 million (S$79.4 million). The 3,849 sqm freehold land includes 132 low-rise apartments, and the sale is expected to contribute to the company's earnings. The disposal is not expected to impact net asset value and is expected to be completed in cash.

site_title: China's economy rebounds strongly in second quarter
summary: China's economy rebounded in the second quarter with a strong rebound, avoiding a recession, as most of the country reopened after nearly two months of lockdown. However, figures show an uneven recovery, with consumption lagging behind supply. Analysts highlight concerns over unemployment and consumer spending, indicating challenges remain despite the economic rebound.

site_title: Cirque du Soleil accepts recapitalisation offer from creditors
summary: Cirque du Soleil accepted a recapitalisation offer from creditors, including Catalyst Capital Group, with a "stalking horse bid" of up to $375 million. This deal comes after the company dismissed an earlier offer from shareholders, including TPG Capital and Fosun International. The Montreal-based company, which has been financially strained due to the pandemic, has slashed 95% of its workforce and suspended shows. The recapitalisation deal aims to inject funds into the company, which filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday.

site_title: Uber acquires public transportation software company in latest transit expansion
summary: Uber acquired Atlanta-based transit software provider Routematch, expanding its public transportation business. The deal allows Uber to power more public transit agencies with routing, matching, and on-demand technology. Routematch provides technology to 550 transit agencies in North America and Australia. Uber's head of transit, David Reich, said the acquisition lets the company "go so much further so much faster" in serving public transit agencies. The companies declined to provide financial details, and Routematch's 175 employees are expected to join Uber. The acquisition aims to show transit agencies Uber's commitment to collaborating.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson in talks with Japan, Gates Foundation to lock in deals on Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Johnson & Johnson is in talks with Japan's government and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation to secure advance allocations of its potential Covid-19 vaccine. The company has agreed to prioritize US allocations as part of a funding agreement with the US government's Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority. The Gates Foundation aims to allocate vaccines to developing countries. Discussions are ongoing, with the goal of locking in a minimum level of vaccine capacity for participating countries. This could help determine pricing for the vaccine, which J&J plans to sell on a not-for-profit basis during the pandemic.

site_title: Thai finance minister resigns amid economic team shake-up
summary: Thai Finance Minister Uttama Savanayana resigned amid an economic team shake-up, adding uncertainty to policy making in the country's worst-performing economy since the Covid-19 crisis. The move comes as the government implements billions of dollars in stimulus measures to support the battered economy. The resignation follows a series of changes in the economic team, which has raised concerns about the stability of the government's economic policies. The departure of Uttama leaves the future of the country's economic recovery uncertain.

site_title: American Airlines notifies 25,000 staff of potential layoffs
summary: American Airlines is notifying 25,000 staff of potential layoffs, with over 20,000 expected to be furloughed due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on business. The airline aims to minimize layoffs through voluntary departures, with a focus on "enhanced leave and early-out programmes". The company's CEO and president cited decreasing demand for air travel amid increasing infection rates and quarantine restrictions. This announcement follows similar warnings from United Airlines and Southwest Airlines, with Delta Air Lines also signaling potential job cuts if voluntary programs do not achieve sufficient savings.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as virus fears eclipse upbeat retail sales
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday as concerns about the economic toll of another coronavirus-driven shutdown outweighed data showing a higher-than-expected rise in domestic retail sales in June. The Dow Jones fell 123.53 points, or 0.46%, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The data showed a 1.1% increase in retail sales in June, beating expectations, but fears of another shutdown and potential recession weighed on investor sentiment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 12.08 points lower at 1,573.48 on Thursday, with 782 losers outweighing 249 gainers. Volume reached 9.280 billion lots worth RM4.144 billion.

site_title: Malaysia's approved Q1 investments down 31% on year, at RM37.4b
summary: Malaysia approved Q1 investments of RM37.4 billion, down 31% from the previous year, due to the coronavirus. Foreign investment accounted for 30% of the total, led by Switzerland, Singapore, US, China, and Japan. Manufacturing was the largest contributor, with a 67.5% share, and domestic investments increased by 180.8% to RM14.6 billion.

site_title: Kimchi bacteria maker gives Singapore listing another shot
summary: A South Korean steelmaker, Kossen, is trying again to secure a listing in Singapore for its biotech firm, BiogenicsKorea, via the judicial management process of an existing listed firm, Epicentre Holdings. Under the agreement, Epicentre will transfer its listing status for S$3 million to an unnamed entity incorporated in Singapore, with Kossen's support. This deal, which allows the shareholders of Epicentre to monetize the shell company, has raised concerns among corporate governance advocates, who question why BiogenicsKorea would list in Singapore instead of its home market.

site_title: A new direction for Corner House
summary: Corner House, a Michelin-starred restaurant in Singapore, has a new head chef, David Thien, who takes a French-Asian approach to local ingredients. The menu is omakase-only and features a mix of Asian bites, French twists, and seasonal ingredients. Reviewers praise the bread basket, century egg, and Wagyu dishes, but find the sambal stingray and lightly sautéed rice noodles lacking. Overall, the meal is considered easy-going, safe, and satisfying, but may not offer anything too original or deep. The restaurant maintains its Michelin star, but the new chef's approach may be seen as superficial.

site_title: Frasers Property backs US smart building software startup Cohesion
summary: Frasers Property Group has joined a US$6.5 million seed funding round for US smart building software startup Cohesion, which aims to integrate building systems, enhance tenant experiences, and provide insights. Frasers Property is a client of Cohesion and plans to leverage data-driven technologies to better manage its global real-estate portfolio. The funding round was led by Hyde Park Angels and includes investors such as Ken Griffin and Michael Sacks. Cohesion plans to fill 25 full-time positions to scale its business over the next year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower, with the Hang Seng Index shedding 2.00% due to concerns over a spike in virus infections globally. Mainland China's markets also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 4.50% and the Shenzhen Composite Index tumbling 5.20%. Despite China's economy expanding more than expected in the second quarter, the glum mood outweighed the positive data.

site_title: Novartis to provide 'no profit' Covid-19 drugs to low income countries
summary: Novartis's Sandoz division will provide 15 generic Covid-19 medicines to 79 low- and lower-middle income countries without profiting from them, the Swiss drugmaker announced. The medicines, including antibiotics and steroids, will be made available for the duration of the pandemic to help vulnerable healthcare systems. The move prompted Doctors Without Borders to call for greater transparency on drug pricing and "no profiteering" initiatives. Novartis aims to work with health authorities and NGOs to eliminate mark-ups and provide essential medicines directly to those in need.

images.alt_text: Novartis's Sandoz division will not profit from 15 generic drugs it is making available to developing countries to treat symptoms of Covid-19 for the pandemic's duration, the Swiss drugmaker said on Thursday.

site_title: Indonesia central bank cuts key interest rate after pledge to buy bonds
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 4% for the fourth time this year, aiming to support the country's largest economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. The move follows a pledge to buy $28 billion of bonds and comes after the government unveiled a $40 billion deficit financing scheme. This is the lowest interest rate since at least 2016.

site_title: India's Reliance seen emerging as bigger threat for US firms like Amazon, Walmart
summary: Reliance, an Indian conglomerate, has raised $20 billion, solidifying its position as a digital giant and threatening US companies like Amazon, Walmart, and Zoom. The company's digital unit Jio Platforms has attracted investors like Google and Facebook, and its e-commerce platform JioMart is expanding to offer electronics and fashion goods. Reliance's CEO, Mukesh Ambani, has stated that the company will continue to disrupt rival businesses, posing a significant threat to US companies in India.

site_title: Nissan plans 30% cut in car output to Dec as virus hits demand
summary: Nissan Motor plans to reduce global vehicle production by 30% year-over-year through December due to falling demand caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The company aims to produce around 2.6 million vehicles between April and December, down from 3.7 million in the same period last year. This production cut is expected to impact Nissan's turnaround efforts, with the company having previously made 4.6 million cars in the financial year ended March. The decision was made in response to reduced demand, with Nissan not immediately available to comment.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: The National Theatre in London is ending its special YouTube program with a live-streamed production of Mozart's "Amadeus" from July 17 to 23. Meanwhile, luxury travel company A2A Safaris has released an e-book featuring recipes from Africa and Latin America. English singer Jessie Ware has released a new album, "What's Your Pleasure?", celebrating disco music. Werner Herzog's documentary film "Family Romance, LLC" is screening exclusively at The Projector. The Esplanade is hosting a live-streamed jazz concert series, Jazz in July, featuring local jazz musicians. A new skincare brand, Two Halves Skincare, has launched a moisturizing formula, while a pop-up restaurant, Capital Kitchen, has opened at Zouk, offering Asian and Western favorites.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS managing director Ravi Menon expressed concerns over a 'highly uncertain' global outlook amid the Covid-19 crisis. He stated that recovery will be uneven across countries, industries, and time, with a possible short-term growth bounce but a weak and gradual long-term recovery.

images.alt_text: MAS managing director Ravi Menon on Thursday said that recovery will be uneven across countries, across industries, and across time and "while a strong short-term growth bounce is plausible, the longer-term recovery is likely to be weak and gradual.

site_title: ECB keeps ultra-easy policy on hold
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its ultra-easy monetary policy stance, pausing after implementing unprecedented measures to combat the coronavirus-induced recession. Despite recent economic data suggesting a recovery, the ECB decided not to take further action, citing a still-uncertain outlook due to the risk of new infections. The ECB continues to buy record amounts of debt and pays banks to take its cash, aiming to temper the recession's impact on output.

site_title: Indonesia tycoon Anthoni Salim risks rare deal defeat over valuation, governance questions
summary: Indonesian tycoon Anthoni Salim's $3 billion deal to buy Pinehill, a distributor and manufacturer of Indomie noodles, faces a high risk of defeat among First Pacific shareholders due to valuation concerns and governance questions. The deal requires a simple majority, but related-party rules in Hong Kong may prevent Salim's associates from voting, making the outcome uncertain. Critics argue the deal overvalues Pinehill by up to $1 billion, citing weaker Indonesian voting rules that may favor related parties.

site_title: India office and home sales fall most in decade: Knight Frank
summary: India's residential sales plummeted 54% and office leasing declined 37% in the first half of 2020, the steepest falls in a decade, according to Knight Frank. The decline is attributed to lockdowns and worsening economic growth. Despite interest rate cuts, higher risk perception has reduced mortgage gains, with chairman Shishir Baijal stating that income uncertainty will hit housing demand. The decline is expected to continue, with residential sales expected to take a hit due to future income uncertainty.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives expecting net loss for H1 2020 due to Covid-19
summary: Kingsmen Creatives expects to report a net loss for the first half of 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has resulted in cancellations, factory closures, and supply chain disruptions. This marks a significant contrast to the same period last year, when the company recorded a net profit. The preliminary review of unaudited financial results for the half year ended June 30 indicates a severe impact on the company's business.

site_title: Stamford Tyres warns of net loss for FY2020
summary: Stamford Tyres expects to book a net loss for FY2020 due to lower revenue from increased competition and oversupply in the tyre market, as well as a one-off expense from a closed loss-making operation in Australia. The company attributes the losses to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and government-imposed lockdowns in key markets. Stamford Tyres reported a 90.9% decline in earnings for FY2019, with a 5.4% decline in revenue. The company will disclose further details of its financial performance upon announcement of its results on or before July 29.

site_title: Former BP manager, businessman found guilty in graft case involving close to US$4m
summary: A former BP manager, Clarence Chang Peng Hong, and businessman Koh Seng Lee, were found guilty of 20 corruption charges each, totaling US$3.95 million in bribes. Chang accepted bribes from 2006 to 2010 to advance Koh's business interests with BP, while Koh also paid S$500,000 to a pre-school where Chang's wife is a director. The duo will be sentenced on September 7, facing up to five years in jail and fines of up to S$100,000 each.

site_title: EU court strikes down EU-US data transfer tool in Facebook case
summary: The European Union's top court has struck down the EU-US data transfer tool, known as the EU-US Privacy Shield, in a Facebook case. The ruling, made on Thursday, backs concerns about US surveillance raised by privacy activist Max Schrems. The court also upheld the validity of standard contractual clauses, but emphasized that data transfers outside the EU must be suspended or prohibited if data protection cannot be ensured. Hundreds of thousands of companies, including Facebook, rely on these clauses to transfer European data worldwide.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit obtains US$115m five-year term loan facility
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) has secured a US$115 million, five-year term loan facility to refinance its borrowings due in November 2021. The loan will be used to pay off existing borrowings and restructure an interest rate swap. The refinancing will improve KORE's all-in average cost of debt and extend its average term to maturity. The loan facility has a condition that if Keppel Corporation and its subsidiaries, or Pacific Oak Capital Advisors and its subsidiaries, cease to own KORE's manager, the company must pay all outstanding loans within 10 business days.

site_title: Antler invests US$1.5m in 15 new startups
summary: Antler, a startup generator and early-stage venture capital firm, has invested US$1.5 million in 15 new companies from its fourth Singapore programme. The funded startups address the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and operate in sectors such as fintech, e-commerce, and healthtech. The programme received 2,500 applications, with 91 individuals from 28 nationalities selected. This investment marks Antler's fourth Singapore programme and its total investment of US$26.9 million since 2019.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on fresh virus surge in capital
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday due to a surge in coronavirus infections in the capital, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.76% to 22,770.36. The Topix index also declined 0.66%. The market sentiment worsened after the capital's governor warned of a record number of daily infections.

site_title: Billionaires look to reduce equities after turning quick profit
summary: Billionaires managed by Swiss bank UBS are shifting their investments away from equities, with many pulling profits from March's sell-off and rapid rebound into illiquid and private assets such as residential real estate and private equity. This trend, seen in Asia, is expected to continue, potentially softening equities markets for the rest of 2020. Despite this, over half of UBS' surveyed family offices plan to increase their equities allocation in the next 2-3 years, indicating a long-term bullish outlook.

site_title: US retail sales increase in June; weekly jobless claims remain elevated
summary: US retail sales rose 7.5% in June, surpassing expectations, but the economic recovery is threatened by a resurgence in COVID-19 cases and high unemployment. This is despite retail sales rebounding in May, the largest gain since 1992. New cases of COVID-19 have led to renewed uncertainty and paused reopenings in some regions, potentially worsening already high unemployment. Weekly jobless claims remained elevated at 1.30 million, and economists warn that the end of additional unemployment benefits on July 31 could further undercut retail sales and consumer spending.

site_title: BMW signs US$2.3b battery order with Goldman-Backed firm
summary: BMW has signed a $2.3 billion deal with Goldman Sachs-backed Northvolt for battery cells to power its electric cars. The Swedish firm will manufacture cells using renewable electricity and deliver them from 2024 as part of a long-term contract. This deal aims to aid BMW's push into electric cars, with plans to introduce five new battery-powered vehicles by 2021 and over 12 electric models by 2023. Northvolt has raised $1 billion from investors including Volkswagen and BMW to build a factory in northern Sweden, further reducing BMW's dependence on Asian battery suppliers.

site_title: Glove counters on SGX see selloff after bullish run
summary: Shares of glove makers on the Singapore bourse plummeted this week after a bullish run over the past six months, driven by Covid-19 pandemic demand. Top Glove, UG Healthcare, and Riverstone Holdings registered significant price falls, with UG Healthcare down 33% and Riverstone down 8% as of Thursday. The decline was sparked by a US Customs detention order on Top Glove over forced labor concerns, and analysts predict more rational trading ahead, with prices stabilizing and finding support.

site_title: STI slides 25.23 points to 2,623.67 on economic-recovery concerns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 25.23 points to 2,623.67, down 0.95%, due to economic concerns and travel restrictions affecting Resorts World Sentosa. The Monetary Authority of Singapore warned of substantial uncertainty over the global economic outlook, and Ravi Menon mentioned discussions on capital-management matters with local banks. Other markets, including Shanghai Composite Index and Hang Seng Index, were also down, with the US authorities barring the import of Top Glove's products and the International Monetary Fund warning of a potential tripling of small and medium-sized business bankruptcies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on mounting US-China tension
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.82% on Thursday, closing at 2,183.76, amid intensifying Sino-US tensions and weak Chinese data. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced visa restrictions on Chinese firms, while the Trump administration considers action on TikTok and WeChat. China's economy returned to growth in the second quarter, but domestic consumption and investment remained weak. South Korea's central bank kept its benchmark rate unchanged, and foreigners were net sellers of $110.58 million worth of shares.

site_title: China to let most cinemas re-open from Monday as pandemic ebbs
summary: China is set to allow most cinemas to re-open from July 20, six months after they were forced to close due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Cinemas in low-risk areas will resume operations with limited film showings and mandatory masks, while those in medium and high-risk areas will remain shut. The country has seen a sharp decline in infections since March, with no high-risk areas currently. The re-opening is expected to boost the film industry, which has been hit hard by the pandemic, with shares in China's largest cinema owner, Wanda Film, jumping 1.1% on the news.

site_title: Skyscanner to cut Singapore marketing headcount amid global layoffs
summary: Skyscanner plans to downsize its marketing division in Singapore as part of a global restructuring amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company, owned by China's Trip.com, is preparing to retrench about a fifth of its 1,500 employees globally, including closing its Sofia and Budapest offices. While the number of Singaporean employees to be affected is not specified, the company will offer enhanced redundancy pay, outplacement support, and time off for interviews. Skyscanner aims to centralise its marketing division in the UK to optimise efficiency and time-zone benefits.

site_title: Malaysia will freeze US$340m PetroSaudi funds linked to 1MDB
summary: Malaysia has obtained an interim order to freeze $340 million in funds allegedly linked to 1MDB, a scandal that has led to global investigations into corruption and money laundering. The funds are currently held in an escrow account in London and are expected to be forfeited. This move is part of Malaysia's efforts to recover the billions of dollars missing from the Malaysian investment fund. The funds were previously linked to former Prime Minister Najib Razak, who was ousted in 2018 and has since returned to power.

site_title: China's pork output slides for 7th straight quarter in shadow of African swine fever
summary: China's pork production declined 4.7% in the second quarter, marking the seventh consecutive quarter of decline due to the ongoing effects of African swine fever. The country's pork output fell to 9.6 million tonnes, a 19.1% drop for the first six months of the year. The pig herd fell 2.2% year-on-year to 339.96 million head, but the sow herd is expected to recover with a 5.4% increase from prior year. Pork output is forecast to fall by 20% this year, but is expected to recover in the long term.

site_title: RWS casino among new places visited by infectious coronavirus patients
summary: Resorts World Sentosa's casino was among locations visited by infectious Covid-19 patients, with three recorded visits on July 4, 5, and 6. The Ministry of Health (MOH) listed these places to monitor the health of individuals who may have come into contact with the patients. Despite the visits, MOH stated that the locations would have been cleaned if needed and there is no need for individuals to avoid them. The ministry also reported a decrease in new community cases and unlinked cases, with 11 new cases announced on Thursday, including four imported cases.

site_title: Aramco joins Exxon, BP, Shell in starting to curb own emissions
summary: Saudi Aramco has joined major oil companies Exxon, BP, and Shell in pledging to curb emissions at their operations. The Oil & Gas Climate Initiative aims to reduce carbon intensity to 20-21 kg CO2 per barrel of crude equivalent by 2025, a 13% reduction from 2017 levels. The move is seen as a significant step towards addressing climate change, with the target removing 52 million tonnes of CO2 emissions per year, equivalent to six million US homes.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.27% to 25,549.40, following a positive lead from Wall Street. Investors await Chinese economic growth data, while Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Cartier maker Richemont's sales plummet amid Covid-19 disruption
summary: Luxury goods group Richemont reported a 47% decline in sales to €1.99 billion in its first quarter due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company cited store closures and Chinese tourists unable to travel as major factors. Despite this, Asia Pacific saw a 49% sales increase in China, driven by online sales growth. Richemont shares fell 3.8% due to concerns over the trading outlook, but Bernstein analyst Luca Solca noted strong Chinese consumer appetite for the company's top brands.

images.alt_text: Richemont said sales had contracted across all regions, channels and business areas. Asia Pacific fared a bit better thanks to a 49 per cent sales increase in China.

site_title: Recruiter Hays flags losses in summer as net fees slump
summary: Hays, a global recruiter, expects to be loss-making in the summer due to a 34% drop in fourth-quarter net fees amid the coronavirus crisis. The company trimmed 9% of its headcount and reduced its cost base by 21% to break even in the quarter. Full-year operating profit is forecast to be between £130-135 million, down from £248.8 million last year. The pandemic has severely impacted the global recruitment market, forcing major players to implement cost-cutting measures.

site_title: China's long-term economic growth fundamentals will not change: Xi
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping stated that China's long-term economic growth fundamentals won't change, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. China's economy grew 3.2% in the second quarter, recovering from a record contraction as lockdown measures ended and policymakers implemented stimulus. This statement comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to maintain economic stability.

site_title: Malaysia estimates 2020 palm oil exports will reach RM65-70b
summary: Malaysia estimates its palm oil exports for 2020 will reach RM65-70 billion, an increase from RM63.73 billion in 2019. The country's export value from January to June 2020 was RM32.47 billion, with the ministry optimistic that the full-year target can be met. This represents a growth of around 5% from last year's exports.

site_title: IMF chief warns global economy 'not out of the woods yet'
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva warns the global economy is not out of the woods yet, despite some signs of recovery. The global GDP is expected to fall by 4.9% this year due to the deeper contraction during lockdowns, with a tepid recovery expected for next year. The recovery faces risks, including a second major global wave of Covid-19, and policymakers must maintain support programs, including paid sick leave and access to healthcare, to prevent further disruptions and increase poverty and inequality.

site_title: MAS sees 'highly uncertain' global outlook ahead amid Covid-19 crisis
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expects a highly uncertain global economic outlook amid the Covid-19 crisis, with recovery likely to be uneven and weak. MAS managing director Ravi Menon said the global economy will grow by 3.5% in the second half of this year, following a 5.5% contraction in the first half. The central bank will return S$5.3 billion in net profit to the government, and is in discussions with banks on capital management and dividend restrictions to ensure their resilience against the crisis.

site_title: Heineken profit plunges as lockdowns pummel sales
summary: Heineken reported a 53% decline in first-half earnings due to lockdowns and COVID-19 restrictions, with net income plummeting 76% and revenue falling 16%. The company took a 550 million-euro asset impairment charge. This decline is part of a broader trend among brewers worldwide as governments consider further restrictions on bars and restaurants to combat the spread of the coronavirus.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: European stocks fell at the open on Thursday, with the Frankfurt DAX 30 index shedding 0.7% and the Paris CAC 40 losing 0.8%. Dealers booked profits ahead of the European Central Bank's update on economic measures. The ECB meeting comes as EU leaders prepare to discuss a proposed $847-billion recovery fund. European markets had risen on Wednesday on hopes for a coronavirus vaccine and US financial stimulus.

images.alt_text: European stocks fell at the open Thursday, with dealers booking profits as the ECB prepares to give an update regarding measures to tackle economic fallout triggered by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Twitter silences some top accounts after internal systems hacked
summary: Twitter confirmed that hackers gained access to its internal systems, hijacking top accounts including US presidential candidate Joe Biden, Kim Kardashian, and former President Barack Obama. The hackers used these accounts to solicit digital currency. The company is investigating potential malicious activity and accessing of information. Twitter is looking into what other actions the hackers may have taken. The incident highlights the vulnerability of social media platforms to internal system hacking.

site_title: Gold holds steady as virus concerns counter positive China data
summary: Gold prices held steady near a nine-year peak on Thursday, despite positive Chinese economic data, as concerns over rising coronavirus cases and US-China tensions offset the gains. Gold prices rose 0.1% to US$1,808.97 per ounce, with spot gold moving in a tight range of about US$5 from its highest since September 2011. China's economy grew 3.2% in the second quarter, but retail sales fell, and investor concerns about the growth outlook outweighed the positive data.

site_title: Australia to continue to support freedom of navigation in South China Sea: PM
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison reaffirmed the country's commitment to freedom of navigation in the South China Sea, stating Australia will "very strongly" advocate for this position. This stance aligns with the US, which has expressed support for countries that believe China has violated their maritime claims in the region. The US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo emphasized the importance of addressing these issues in multilateral and legal forums.

site_title: Australia launches A$2b pandemic retraining plan
summary: Australia has announced a A$2 billion retraining plan to support workers impacted by the coronavirus fallout, with over 300,000 training places to be created. The plan aims to funnel graduates and jobless workers into "growth" sectors. The unemployment rate rose to 7.4% in June, with almost one million Australians out of work, the country's highest level since 1998. The plan is an early indication of how the government plans to follow up on wage subsidies that expire in September, amid a growing outbreak in Melbourne that could impact economic recovery hopes.

site_title: Taiwan holds drills to beat back invasion amid China tensions
summary: Taiwan's air, sea, and land forces conducted live-fire exercises, dubbed "Han Kuang," to defend against a potential invasion by China, amid rising tensions. The drills involved 8,000 personnel and simulated repelling an invading force, with President Tsai Ing-wen emphasizing Taiwan's determination to defend its territory. The exercises come as China has increased military activity around the island, and Tsai has prioritized military modernization to counter China's numerical superiority and advanced equipment.

site_title: Rupert Murdoch's big investment headache: Australia
summary: Rupert Murdoch's Australian media arm, News Corp, is facing significant challenges, including a billion-dollar writedown and a decline in Foxtel's subscribers. The company is struggling to adapt to the shift towards streaming, with Foxtel losing 31% of its earnings in the March quarter. Despite this, Lachlan Murdoch, co-chairman of News Corp, is committed to the Australian operations, citing the company's strength in print and its future prospects. The Australian arm is also shifting focus towards digital publishing, with plans to stop printing regional newspapers and invest in new streaming services.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds rates at record low, but paints bleak outlook
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) held its key policy rate at a record low of 0.5% amid efforts to curb property prices. Governor Lee Ju-yeol painted a bleak outlook for the economy, citing weaker exports and a global resurgence of coronavirus cases. The BOK is unlikely to cut rates further, with 24 analysts predicting rates will stay at the record low through the end of 2020. The central bank is monitoring the impact of government policies and is ready to buy sovereign bonds if local bond yields spike.

site_title: Thai finance minister resigns amid economic team shake-up
summary: Thai Finance Minister Uttama Savanayana resigned amid a cabinet shake-up, adding uncertainty to policy-making in a struggling economy. The move comes as the government rolls out stimulus measures to support an economy hit by the Covid-19 crisis. Preede Daochai is expected to replace Uttama, while Somkid Jatusripitak and Thosaporn Sirisumphand are also expected to leave their positions. The shake-up raises concerns about the impact on the economy, with elevated political uncertainty seen as a headwind to long-term reform and investment.

images.alt_text: "It's an appropriate time to resign" for the economy to move forward, Finance Minister Uttama Savanayana told the briefing. "There was no pressure."

site_title: Deutsche Bank Asia CEO picks Singapore base in snub to Hong Kong
summary: Deutsche Bank's new Asia CEO, Alexander von zur Muehlen, will be based in Singapore, a move seen as a snub to Hong Kong amidst the city's ongoing political turbulence. Von zur Muehlen, who takes over in August, will relocate from Frankfurt, while Kamran Khan, the bank's head of environmental, social and governance, will also be based in Singapore. This decision reverses a trend of major global banks having their top regional executives in Hong Kong, which has long been a hub for Asian finance.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.55 points, or 0.03%, to 1,585.01. Trading volume reached 643.65 million lots worth RM144.74 million. Gainers beat losers 172 to 127.

site_title: Singapore shares muted at Thursday's open; STI up 0.03%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.03% to 2,649.64 on Thursday, driven by Wall Street stocks' gains on vaccine hopes. The index had a mixed day with gains in Singapore Airlines and losses in Genting Singapore and Singtel. Banking stocks were also affected, with DBS and UOB declining, while OCBC Bank rose. This follows a 0.4% gain on Wednesday, and the index has now notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Singapore's CAAS halts fee hikes for aviation firms
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has announced a pause on scheduled fee hikes for aviation firms for the 2020-2021 financial year, due to the impact of the novel coronavirus pandemic. The freeze applies to fees related to aircraft component certification, maintenance, and overhaul, and will save around 170 aviation companies S$200,000. This move complements the government's Enhanced Aviation Support Package, which includes a 50% rebate on regulatory fees and fee deferrals for certain payments. The pause aims to mitigate the significant impact of the pandemic on the aviation industry.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop as virus spikes, China data fails to lift gloom
summary: Asian markets fell on Thursday as virus infections surged and lockdowns were reimposed, despite China's forecast-busting economic growth data. The region's stocks dropped, with Shanghai, Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Seoul declining by 1-0.7%. Investors are concerned about a surge in infections in countries reopening their economies and are wary of a virus that has been sweeping the globe. Despite China's better-than-expected economic growth, analysts say consumers remain reticent about spending, citing the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Some BTO flats may be delayed up to nine months: HDB
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has revised its estimate of delays for Build-To-Order (BTO) flat projects, citing disruptions in the supply of precast components, materials, and manpower as the main causes. Some projects, including West Plains @ Bukit Batok and SkyParc @ Dawson, may face delays of up to nine months, while others, like Northshore Residences I and II, are expected to be completed by the end of the year. Homeowners affected by the delays are advised to contact HDB for assistance and updates on their project's completion date.

site_title: Under-fire Trump replaces campaign manager
summary: US President Donald Trump replaced his campaign manager, Brad Parscale, with former deputy campaign manager Bill Stepien. The move comes as Trump's re-election bid is faltering, with polls showing low popularity four months ahead of the November election. Stepien will lead the campaign's digital and data strategies. Trump also announced Parscale will return to his former duties, citing a need to "shake up" the campaign. The change is seen as an attempt to revitalize Trump's re-election bid.

site_title: Can Ambani take on Tencent, Huawei and Xiaomi?
summary: Indian billionaire Mukesh Ambani aims to challenge tech giants like Tencent, Huawei, and Xiaomi with his 5G technology, developed by his company Jio Platforms. After successfully testing the technology in India, Ambani plans to offer it to other markets, citing its "Huawei-killer" capabilities. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has praised Jio as a clean network, further solidifying Ambani's plans to compete in the global tech market.

site_title: China home prices rise most in 10 months, more curbs imposed
summary: China's new-home prices rose 0.58% in June, the fastest pace in 10 months, as developers offered more projects to boost first-half results. Values in the secondary market gained 0.31%, the largest rise in 11 months. Authorities responded with fresh curbs, including eligibility requirements in Ningbo and harsher rules in Shenzhen. Nomura Holdings forecasts average nationwide house-price growth of 3% for the full year, with diverging performance between large and small cities.

site_title: Lower food delivery transaction fees for F&B merchants in UOB-Getz tie-up
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and Getz have tied up to provide food and beverage (F&B) merchants with lower transaction fees and marketing support. Under the collaboration, F&B merchants will pay capped transaction fees of 4% on online sales, a discount of up to 50% from Getz's usual rates. UOB will also support merchants with marketing efforts, including featuring them on its online marketplace, The Dining Advisor, which attracts 43,000 visitors monthly. This move aims to help F&B merchants increase their online sales and remain profitable amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: China gives go-ahead for human trials of BioNTech's Covid vaccine candidate
summary: China has approved an early-stage human trial of BioNTech's Covid-19 vaccine candidate, BNT162b1, developed in partnership with Pfizer. This move follows the vaccine receiving "fast track" status from the US FDA. The Phase I clinical trial will be initiated as soon as possible. China has licensed BioNTech's mRNA technology to exclusively develop and commercialize Covid-19 vaccine products in mainland China. This is part of a global effort to develop a vaccine against the pandemic, which has infected over 13 million people and killed over half a million.

images.alt_text: China has approved an early-stage trial in humans of German firm BioNTech's experimental Covid-19 vaccine, its local partner Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical said on Thursday.

site_title: Airbnb says its IPO plans are back on track
summary: Airbnb has resumed its efforts to go public after the coronavirus pandemic halted travel and significantly damaged the home rental business. Despite a $31 billion valuation, the company had set aside IPO plans in March but has since slashed costs, raised emergency funding, and laid off 1,900 staff. Gross bookings have rebounded, and Airbnb announced new leadership and initiatives to repair its relationship with hosts and adapt to the pandemic. The company is under pressure to go public, with shares held by early employees expiring this year.

site_title: ST Engineering ties up with Israel defence powerhouse to sell naval missile systems
summary: ST Engineering has partnered with Israel Aerospace Industries (IAI) to set up a joint-venture company, Proteus Advanced Systems, to sell advanced naval missile systems. The JV will have equal stakes and leverage parent companies' strengths to market and sell these systems. This move aims to capitalize on growing demand for naval defense systems, despite a decline in the aerospace sector due to the coronavirus pandemic. The joint venture is expected to have minimal impact on ST Engineering's financials.

site_title: Liang Court redevelopment project moves to next step
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts has completed the sale of its stake in Novotel Singapore Clarke Quay and Ascott Residence Trust has sold its interest in the land for the Liang Court redevelopment project. The sale, announced last November, involves a consortium of CapitaLand, City Developments, and ART, with the goal of redeveloping the site into a mixed-use development. CDLHT received approximately S$370.3 million in net proceeds from the sale, which will be used to fund the acquisition of the W Singapore luxury hotel and repay debt.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as surging Covid-19 cases offset vaccine cheer
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Thursday, as surging COVID-19 cases offset the positivity from a potential vaccine. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.07% to 6,048.7 points. Despite a record quarterly daily alumina production by Alumina Ltd, the mining sub-index fell up to 0.8%. Meanwhile, consumer prices in New Zealand fell by the most in four years due to the COVID-19 lockdown. The top percentage losers included Investore Property Ltd and Tourism Holdings Ltd.

site_title: Australia weighs further curbs as outbreak grows
summary: Australia's most populous states are imposing harsher restrictions on movement if the Covid-19 outbreak isn't quickly contained. Victoria state, which recently forced 5 million people into a 6-week lockdown, reported 238 new cases in the last 24 hours. Nationally, Australia has recorded 10,500 cases and 111 deaths. State premiers warned that further restrictions, including potentially prolonged lockdowns, will be implemented if people don't follow lockdown orders. Over 500 people have been fined for defying lockdown rules, and new restrictions are expected in New South Wales.

site_title: Australia June unemployment jumps to highest since late 1990s
summary: Australia's unemployment rate surged to 7.4% in June, the highest since November 1998, despite a 210,800 job growth, exceeding expectations of 112,000. The participation rate increased to 64% with the jump in jobless rate. Economists attribute the rise to people seeking work, rather than a decline in job openings.

site_title: Australia to spend further A$1.5b on wage subsidies amid coronavirus
summary: Australia's government plans to spend A$1.50 billion to extend a wage subsidy program for apprentices, covering 180,000 workers across various industries until March 2021. This is part of the government's support measures to prop up the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. The program, which currently supports 80,000 workers, will pay 50% of apprentices' wages. The government also plans to spend A$500 million on re-training Australians as unemployment soars due to the pandemic. The move aims to support the economy beyond the September expiry of the A$60 billion wage subsidy package.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia has urged the government to extend its fiscal support, cautioning that the economy will need "considerable" support for some time.

site_title: Top China chipmaker SMIC more than triples in Shanghai debut
summary: Top Chinese chipmaker SMIC surged 246% on its Shanghai debut, selling shares at 27.46 yuan apiece to raise up to $10.58 billion. The company's mainland listing comes amid competition between the US and China for tech supremacy, with SMIC aiming to develop next-generation chipmaking technologies to catch up with rivals like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Proceeds will be used to develop 5nm technology, two generations behind the capabilities of TSMC. SMIC's shares have more than tripled in Hong Kong this year, following a 9.6% loss on the Hang Seng Index.

site_title: ESR-Reit cuts first-half DPU to 1.162 S cents
summary: ESR-Reit's first-half distribution per unit (DPU) fell 42.2% to 1.162 Singapore cents due to the impact of the novel coronavirus pandemic and retention of distributable income. Gross revenue and net property income declined 11.5% and 16.8% year-over-year, respectively. The trust's proposed merger with Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust was announced. ESR-Reit's units closed flat at S$0.39, and the distribution for Q2 will be paid out on Sept 17.

site_title: Coronavirus cases and fatalities continue to rise across US
summary: The US continues to experience a surge in coronavirus cases and fatalities, with Texas and Oklahoma reporting new highs. Texas reported 10,791 new cases and 110 fatalities, while Oklahoma saw a single-day record of 1,075 new cases. Alabama reached a grim milestone with 47 deaths, and California reported its second-highest single-day increase in cases and deaths. Nationwide, over 65,000 new cases were reported, with the death toll projected to rise to over 150,000 by next month, totaling over 136,400 deaths.

site_title: China's economy bounces back from pandemic contraction
summary: China's economy rebounded in the second quarter, growing 3.2% after a historic 3.2% contraction in the first quarter due to the pandemic. Retail sales fell 1.8% year-over-year, missing expectations. The recovery was driven by workers and factories returning to normality after lockdowns controlled the virus. However, policymakers may face pressure to slow the economy, which is expected to grow at a slower pace, and investors are watching for signs of policy easing.

site_title: Japan's domestic tourism campaign under fire as coronavirus cases spike in Tokyo
summary: Japan's "Go To" domestic tourism campaign, set to launch July 22, has faced criticism due to a spike in new coronavirus cases in Tokyo, with officials questioning its timing and methods. The campaign aims to boost tourism in rural areas with subsidies of up to 50%. However, experts and local officials have expressed concerns that Tokyo's high infection rates could spread the virus to less affected regions. Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike has called for the campaign to be delayed or limited to specific areas, citing the need for more stringent containment measures.

images.alt_text: Tokyo raised its coronavirus alert to its highest level on Thursday.

site_title: American Airlines notifies 25,000 workers of potential layoffs
summary: American Airlines is notifying 25,000 workers of potential layoffs, with 2,500 pilots, 9,500 flight attendants, 3,200 maintenance staff, and 1,000 reservations agents at risk. The layoffs are due to a decline in business caused by the coronavirus pandemic, with US carriers receiving government aid under the CARES Act prohibited from laying off workers until after September 30. The airline hopes to reduce the number of furloughs through voluntary departures and leave programs.

site_title: EU chief calls for agreement on economic relaunch
summary: EU chief Charles Michel is urging European leaders to agree on a plan to relaunch the bloc's economy, which has been ravaged by the pandemic. He proposes a 750-billion-euro recovery fund, with 500 billion euros in direct grants to the hardest-hit countries. However, some member states, including the "Frugal Four," are resisting the plan, seeking loans with tough conditions attached. Michel is seeking approval of the bloc's long-term budget and a revised EU budget of 1.074 trillion euros, down from an earlier proposal. The negotiations promise to be lengthy and difficult.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower with eyes on China GDP
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, July 16, 2020, due to cautious trade ahead of China's GDP data. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.25% or 57.04 points to 22,888.46. Investors are awaiting China's GDP data for clues on the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Alpha Energy seeks S$20m funding for diversification bid; KPMG resigns as its auditor
summary: Alpha Energy, a Catalist-listed oil firm, is seeking S$20 million in funding to diversify into the education services business through the proposed acquisition of Kydon Learning Systems Institute (KLSI) for S$12 million. The company has entered into a non-binding term sheet with investor Didi Investments for a S$20 million convertible loan. Didi Investments, familiar in the education services business, will also appoint a director to Alpha Energy's board. The acquisition is seen as a way to generate additional revenue streams while waiting for the oil business to improve.

site_title: Sabana Reit's DPU for H1 tumbles 65.7% to 0.47 S cent
summary: Sabana Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) for the half year ended June 30, 2020, fell 65.7% to 0.47 Singapore cents due to a 55% retention of distributable income to conserve capital. Gross revenue and net property income declined 6.7% and 15.5% year-on-year, respectively. The trust expects pressure on earnings for the rest of the year, and units closed flat at S$0.36.

site_title: OCBC offers SingPass access to its digital banking services
summary: OCBC Bank in Singapore has begun allowing customers to access its digital banking services using their SingPass Mobile app, marking the first bank to offer this service. This move eliminates the need for multiple access codes and PINs, increasing convenience for customers. The bank saw a surge in digital banking transactions, with close to 100,000 new digital users this year, and a 40-48% increase in transactions among older customers. This development follows the Monetary Authority of Singapore's efforts to facilitate adoption of digital infrastructures for seamless integration with the growing digital economy.

site_title: ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit propose merger
summary: ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit have proposed a merger, with ESR-Reit acquiring all Sabana Reit units in exchange for new units. The merger aims to establish ESR-Reit as a leading pan-Asian industrial Reit, diversifying its portfolio and reducing risks. The enlarged entity will have a market capitalization of approximately S$1.8 billion and a free float of S$1.3 billion. The merger is expected to be accretive to distribution per unit, with Sabana unitholders receiving an implied scheme consideration of S$0.377 per unit. The deal is expected to provide operational synergies and access to a wider investor base.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Genting, SGX, Sembcorp Industries, Sembmarine, Biolidics
summary: Singapore Airlines flew 13,900 passengers in June 2020, down from nearly 1.9 million the same period last year, and expects a material operating loss for the first quarter. Genting Singapore closed 1.3% higher after a one-off workforce rationalization, while Singapore Exchange acquired BidFX to unlock foreign exchange potential. Sembcorp Industries sold a 30% equity interest for S$138.8 million, and Sembmarine posted a net loss of S$192 million. Biolidics shares fell 16.4% after a trading halt, and ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit requested trading halts before announcing financial results and a proposed merger.

site_title: WTO leadership rivals pitch path out of 'existential crisis'
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is facing an "existential crisis" due to a lack of trust among its member states, particularly between the US and China, according to leadership candidates. Eight candidates, including Mexico's Jesus Seade Kuri, Nigeria's Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, and Egypt's Hamid Mamdouh, are vying for the position of WTO director-general. The new leader will need to address simmering tensions and the global economic crisis triggered by the coronavirus pandemic. An elimination process based on consensus will start in September, with the winner expected to take office in the near future.

site_title: ECB to take pause even as pandemic worries rise
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to keep its policy on hold, reviewing the effectiveness of its crisis-fighting measures amid rising pandemic worries. The ECB has implemented record debt purchases and bank lending programs to stabilize the economy. However, critics argue that these decisions were made hastily and may be bending the bank's rules too far. The ECB will scrutinize the impact of its measures, aiming to salvage the bloc's economy until Europe reopens after the pandemic.

site_title: Contact tracing: China's health code offers some lessons
summary: China's health code app, introduced in February 2020, has successfully balanced accuracy of contact tracing with privacy protection, with over 1 billion users. The app uses citizens' health particulars for public venue entry and generates a color-coded risk status. Unlike Singapore's TraceTogether and SafeEntry, China's health code has a high adoption rate due to its integration with popular mobile apps and ease of use. However, concerns remain about the potential for mass surveillance and data sharing with authorities. Singapore could learn from China's approach by merging TraceTogether and SafeEntry into a single app, prioritizing Bluetooth-based data collection and maintaining original privacy protection measures.

site_title: Key EU data transfer tools in focus in Facebook, Schrems clash
summary: The European Union's top court is set to rule on the legality of tools used by companies like Facebook to transfer personal data to the US. The case, C-311/18, centers on standard contractual clauses and the EU-US Privacy Shield, which could disrupt hundreds of thousands of companies if deemed unlawful. If the court finds the mechanisms are illegal, companies may have to suspend data transfers or face hefty fines. The ruling could have significant implications for companies, including Facebook, banks, and industrial giants, and follows previous cases that have restricted data transfers.

site_title: Walloped by pandemic and controversy, Trump faces political turmoil
summary: US President Donald Trump is facing increasing political turmoil as the coronavirus pandemic continues to ravage the country, with 136,900 Americans having died and new cases rising in 40 out of 50 states. Despite Trump's efforts to downplay the issue, health experts are warning that the US strategy is faltering, and the president is clashing with infectious disease specialist Anthony Fauci. Trump's approval ratings are also suffering, with Democratic challenger Joe Biden leading him by nine percentage points in national polling. The White House is urging Trump to take a more serious approach to the pandemic, but the president is instead focusing on his re-election campaign and attacking his opponents.

site_title: Metropolitan Opera will livestream its biggest stars
summary: The Metropolitan Opera will test a paid digital content model with its next major initiative during the ongoing lockdown. The company, which has been streaming operas from its video archive for free, will offer a paid livestream of its biggest stars. This move aims to attract a broad audience and generate revenue during the theatre's closure, which is expected to last until the end of the year. The initiative follows the success of its free "At-Home Gala" in April, which was watched by 750,000 people.

site_title: Brazil's Bolsonaro tests positive for coronavirus again
summary: Brazil President Jair Bolsonaro announced he has tested positive for the coronavirus again, despite not experiencing symptoms. He has been taking the anti-malarial drug hydroxychloroquine, which he claims is working. Bolsonaro, 65 and in a high-risk group, will remain in quarantine at the Alvorada Palace residence and continue to work by video conference. He had previously tested positive a week ago and has been confined to the palace alongside others who have contracted the virus.

site_title: Twitter accounts of Apple, Musk, Gates, others hit in major hack
summary: A massive hack compromised the Twitter accounts of Apple, Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos, Joe Biden, Bill Gates, and others, with scammers attempting to dupe users into sending cryptocurrency bitcoin. The hacked accounts posted messages telling users they had 30 minutes to send $1,000 in bitcoin to receive twice as much back. Thousands of dollars in bitcoin may have been sent to the scammers' accounts. Twitter is investigating the incident and has warned users to be vigilant. The hack is believed to be an internal compromise of Twitter's system, not an API attack.

site_title: US economic activity increased; outlook 'highly uncertain': Federal Reserve
summary: The US economy showed signs of life in June, with increased economic activity nationwide, but still below pre-pandemic levels. Retail sales improved, and businesses began to reopen, but new layoffs and employment remain below pre-virus levels. The outlook remains "highly uncertain" due to ongoing health concerns, childcare needs, and generous unemployment benefits. The Federal Reserve's "beige book" survey, conducted before a recent spike in Covid-19 cases, highlights the challenges facing the economy as it prepares for its next policy meeting.

images.alt_text: The US economy showed signs of life nationwide last month, but has not returned to its pre-pandemic level and the outlook remains "highly uncertain," the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday.

site_title: Asia's garment workers say coronavirus used as cover to smash unions
summary: Garment workers in Asia claim the COVID-19 pandemic is being used as a cover to break their unions, as global brands cancel orders worth billions of dollars, leaving hundreds of thousands out of work. Workers in countries such as India, Bangladesh, and Cambodia allege their employers are targeting unionized factories to reduce wages and conditions. The pandemic's economic impact has created an opportunity for bosses to crack down on union activity, with some workers facing retaliation, including dismissal and arrest. Major brands are urged to use their financial muscle to protect vulnerable workers in their supply chains.

site_title: Pompeo says to visit Britain after Huawei ban decision
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo plans to visit Britain and Denmark next week, following London's decision to ban Chinese telecoms giant Huawei. The ban was welcomed by the US, which has urged all countries to shun Huawei, citing its ties to the Chinese state. Pompeo will discuss the threat of Chinese espionage and the need for cooperation to counter the Chinese Communist Party's influence. The visit comes amid increased tensions between the US and China, with the Trump administration pushing for a hard line against Beijing.

site_title: Depp's ex-wife accused of 'stealing' sex abuse story
summary: Johnny Depp is suing The Sun over a 2018 story branding him a "wife beater" after his ex-wife Amber Heard accused him of abusing her on at least 14 occasions. Depp denies the allegations, claiming Heard fabricated the story. A former personal assistant of Heard's, Kate James, testified that Heard allegedly "stole" her own story of being a victim of sexual assault and twisted it for her own narrative, causing her "extreme distress and outrage". Depp's trial continues, with other witnesses set to testify, including his former partner Vanessa Paradis and actress Winona Ryder.

site_title: EU to clamp down on harmful corporate tax systems
summary: The European Commission plans to expand its tax code of conduct to tackle corporate tax regimes that distort the EU's single market. The move aims to aid Europe's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic by clamping down on aggressive tax planning by multinational digital giants and wealthy individuals. The Commission will explore options to sidestep the veto system, which has previously blocked tax reforms. Six EU countries have been identified as having tax systems that could be used for aggressive tax planning, and the Commission proposes automatic exchange of information on income generated by digital firms.

site_title: Bankers mull exit from Hong Kong on shock 45% China tax rate
summary: China's new 45% tax rate on its citizens' global income has sparked fears of a Hong Kong brain drain, with thousands of mainland bankers and professionals considering moving back home due to the high tax rate and living costs. The tax change, which applies to those who transferred from China, has caught workers off guard and could undermine Hong Kong's status as a premier financial center. The prospect of an exodus may further strain the city's economy, and some companies may need to absorb the impact of reduced take-home pay.

site_title: June new condo sales more than double on pent-up demand, foreigner buying
summary: Singapore's new condo sales surged 105% in June to 998 units, the highest sales in seven years, driven by pent-up demand and foreign buying. Affordable homes made up over 90% of units sold. Foreign buyers increased to 169, with 120 permanent residents and 49 non-permanent residents. Prices weakened, with a 2.1% decrease in the first half of 2020. Experts predict a normalization of the market, with transaction volumes stabilizing around pre-Covid-19 levels in the second half of 2020, despite economic uncertainty.

site_title: DBS raises target price on Riverstone on rising glove prices, fatter margins
summary: DBS Group Research has raised its target price on Malaysia-based Riverstone Holdings to S$3.90, citing higher average selling prices for gloves and improved margins. Analyst Ling Lee Keng revised upwards her earnings forecast for Riverstone by 46% for 2020 and 48% for 2021, citing the company's leadership position in the cleanroom segment and expected ASP increases of 45% and 10% for healthcare and cleanroom gloves, respectively. Riverstone's shares closed at S$3.07, down 1%.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents slide further in June: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rental rates continued to decline in June, with private rents falling 0.6% and HDB rents down 0.5% from May. This marks the fourth consecutive month of decline, attributed to the Covid-19 fallout. Analysts note that the rental market remains resilient, with an increase in lease volume, driven by rental renewals and longer-term housing arrangements. Despite this, observers warn that the economic outlook may continue to dampen the rental market.

site_title: Trump ends Hong Kong trade preferences, backs banking sanctions
summary: US President Donald Trump has ended Hong Kong's preferential trade treatment and authorized sanctions on banks over China's clampdown in the financial hub, sparking retaliation from Beijing. Trump declared Hong Kong would be treated like mainland China, stripping it of special economic privileges and sensitive technologies. He signed the Hong Kong Autonomy Act, which authorizes sanctions against Chinese officials and banks involved in infringing on the city's autonomy. China vowed to retaliate, while lawmakers hope the law will force banks to choose between abetting Beijing's efforts or operating in the US market.

site_title: Oil climbs 2% on US stock draw but gains capped as Opec+ set to ease cuts
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Wednesday, driven by a 7.5 million-barrel drop in US crude inventories. Brent crude settled at $43.79 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $41.20 a barrel. However, gains were limited as Opec+ is set to ease supply cuts from August, as the global economy recovers from the coronavirus pandemic. This easing of supply curbs may cap further price increases despite the recent inventory drop.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose 2 per cent on Wednesday, supported by a sharp drop in US crude inventories, but further gains were limited as Opec and its allies are set to ease supply curbs from August as the global economy gradually recovers from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Green buildings are so yesterday. 'Deep-green' ones are actually good for the planet
summary: Deep-green buildings, which go beyond traditional green buildings by incorporating advanced sustainable features, are more effective at reducing environmental harm than their predecessors. These buildings utilize cutting-edge materials and systems to minimize their ecological footprint. Research suggests that deep-green buildings can have a significant positive impact on the planet, making them a crucial component in the fight against climate change.

site_title: US: Vaccine hopes lift stocks as travel shares gain
summary: US stocks advanced on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.9% to 26,869.83, and the S&P 500 gaining 0.9% to 3,226.55. Travel shares, including Delta Air Lines and Marriott International, rose 9.6% and 7.9% respectively. Moderna's announcement of entering the final stage of human trials for its Covid-19 vaccine lifted investor confidence, with Moderna shares jumping 6.9%. The Federal Reserve's "beige book" survey showed a pickup in nationwide activity, but outlooks remained uncertain due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Travel stocks soar as encouraging vaccine study lifts shares
summary: European stocks surged to a five-week high on Wednesday, driven by optimism over a Covid-19 vaccine. Travel stocks such as IAG, Ryanair, and Carnival Plc rose 9.7-11.4% as an early-stage vaccine study from Moderna Inc and AstraZeneca's potential vaccine sparked hope for a recovery. The Stoxx 600 index rose 1.8%, and euro zone blue-chips jumped 1.7% to their highest level since March 5, with expectations of a vaccine being available in the second quarter of 2021.

site_title: Arbitration preferred choice for dispute resolution: Ministry of Law study
summary: A study commissioned by Singapore's Ministry of Law found that 74% of people opting for dispute resolution prefer arbitration, while 26% choose mediation, and 50% opt for international commercial litigation. Mediation excelled in terms of user satisfaction with cost and speed. The study's findings highlight arbitration as the preferred method of dispute resolution in Singapore.

site_title: No sign of panic exit from Singapore investors despite volatility: Endowus
summary: Singapore investors have shown no mass panic despite recent market volatility, according to Endowus, a robo-advisor. Despite market downturns, the company saw steady inflows of funds, with a "very little outflow" throughout the period. This trend is attributed to the ongoing liquidity rush, driving more investments.

site_title: Sony boosts output of PlayStation 5 to meet surge in demand
summary: Sony is boosting PlayStation 5 production to 10 million units this year, doubling its previous target of 5-6 million units, due to sustained demand from the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has informed suppliers and assembly partners of the increased orders, but logistics may pose a challenge for timely delivery, especially during the holiday shopping season. Despite this, Sony expects to assemble 5 million units by the end of September and another 5 million between October and December. The increased production is also driven by concerns about a potential second wave of coronavirus infections.

site_title: The New York Times will move part of Hong Kong office to Seoul
summary: The New York Times will relocate a third of its Hong Kong staff to Seoul over the next year due to challenges securing work permits in Hong Kong. The move comes as Beijing's national security law imposes uncertainty on the global financial centre. The Times will maintain its large presence in Hong Kong and continue to cover the city and China, but the relocation marks a blow to Hong Kong's status as a hub for journalism in Asia.

site_title: Spate of bank runs forces China regulators and police to act
summary: A spate of bank runs in China has prompted regulators and police to intervene, as depositors rush to withdraw funds amid unfounded rumors of bank collapses. The crisis has eroded confidence in the nation's $43 trillion banking system, threatening China's economic powerhouse. Authorities have taken measures to calm depositors, including publicly vouching for bank stability and raising deposit insurance. The situation is attributed to the coronavirus outbreak and its economic fallout, exacerbating existing issues with poorly managed banks and deteriorating debt.

images.alt_text: Confidence in the US$43 trillion banking system is eroding among the nation's more than one billion account holders, threatening a cornerstone of China's rise into an economic powerhouse.

site_title: Axe falls on Resorts World jobs; MBS not expected to be spared
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) in Singapore has undergone a "one-off workforce rationalisation" just two weeks after reopening, resulting in an undisclosed number of job losses. The move is attributed to the ongoing impact of the novel coronavirus pandemic on the tourism industry, with travel restrictions and a "circuit breaker" lockdown affecting visitor numbers. The company's sister company, Genting Malaysia, has already reduced its workforce by 15% due to similar circumstances. Marina Bay Sands (MBS) is also expected to follow suit, with analysts estimating a potential 10-15% staff reduction.

site_title: 'Top Gun' helmet and 'Alien' spaceship in Hollywood props auction
summary: A Hollywood props auction featuring iconic items from 'Top Gun', 'Alien', and 'Rocky' is set to take place in Los Angeles on August 26-27. The auction includes a 'Top Gun' helmet, an 'Alien' spaceship, and items from 'Indiana Jones' and 'Clint Eastwood's Western'. The 'Alien' spaceship model, a 11-foot model of the interstellar tug-ship Nostromo, is expected to fetch between $300,000-$500,000. The live-streamed auction will also feature hundreds of other legendary movie props.

images.alt_text: Maverick's fighter jet helmet, Obi-Wan Kenobi's lightsaber, Rocky's boxing gloves and an 11-foot Alien spaceship tipped to fetch half a million dollars will go up for auction in Los Angeles next month.

site_title: Heathrow Airport deploys cleaning robots to kill viruses
summary: Heathrow Airport is introducing cleaning robots and other measures to reduce virus transmission risk as the UK eases travel restrictions. The airport is deploying ultraviolet rays to kill viruses and bacteria at night, while installing UV technology to disinfect escalator handrails and self-cleaning wraps on touched surfaces. Additionally, 100 workers are being retrained as "hygiene technicians" to monitor the new technologies. These measures come as the UK lifts quarantine-on-arrival rules for 74 countries and territories, with Heathrow seeing a 95% drop in passenger numbers in June compared to last year.

site_title: UK tax break pits landlords against first-time home buyers
summary: The UK government has reversed its previous efforts to favor first-time home buyers by increasing the sales tax threshold for homes to £500,000 until the end of March 2021, benefiting both landlords and buyers. This change affects all buyers, not just first-time home buyers, and is set to raise revenue for the government. The move is seen as a shift in policy, with the government now prioritizing tax revenue over helping first-time buyers compete with investors.

site_title: Lazada helps South-east Asia's malls go online
summary: Marina Square, a Singapore shopping mall, has partnered with Lazada to create a virtual replica of its physical mall, featuring over 30 tenants. This move aims to provide visibility and awareness for the tenants and offline mall amid the COVID-19 pandemic's devastating effects on the retail industry. The partnership follows similar moves by other malls in the region, such as Siam Center in Bangkok, and marks a new concept in Singapore's retail scene.

site_title: Covid-19: Comprehensive shutdown needed in US
summary: The US needs a comprehensive shutdown to safely reopen the economy and schools, according to experts. In contrast, countries like Italy, Germany, and South Korea have managed to control the virus with lower case numbers. The US has the highest growth rate of new cases in the world, with Florida reporting the highest single-day total of 15,300. The White House's approach of "learning to live with the virus" is deemed inadequate, highlighting the need for a scientific approach to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

site_title: To bypass China, India should try a 'costless trick'
summary: India should focus on strengthening trade with its South Asian neighbors to diversify its commerce beyond China, according to experts. Despite India's significant imports from South Asia, the region's trade balance is lopsided, with exports worth US$24.6 billion and imports worth US$4.6 billion. To encourage imports, India can invest in the private sector, improve trading infrastructure, and address non-tariff measures. As tensions with China rise, India's trade with China is already down by 15% since 2018, and intra-South Asian trade may help fill the gap, providing a costless trick for the country.

site_title: Apple wins fight against 13b euro tax order
summary: Apple has won a major court battle against a 13 billion euro EU tax order, with the European General Court rejecting an EU order for the iPhone maker to pay the amount in Irish back taxes. The EU had claimed Apple benefited from illegal state aid via two Irish tax rulings, but the court found that the EU executive failed to show the requisite legal standard that there was an advantage. The ruling is a blow to the EU's attempts to crack down on sweetheart tax deals, and may weaken or delay pending cases against other multinationals.

site_title: Women advance in politics, but what about in business?
summary: Singapore's general election has seen a significant increase in women's representation in Parliament, with 29% of the 93 elected Members of Parliament (MPs) being women, surpassing the UN's 30% target set in 1990. This marks a major gain, with women's parliamentary representation increasing from 21% in 2015. The progress made in politics contrasts with the business world, where women's participation remains lower, with only 16.2% in the largest 100 primary-listed companies on the Singapore Exchange. The article argues that prejudice against women and unequal opportunities are major obstacles to women's advancement in both politics and business, highlighting the need for greater equality and recognition of women's abilities.

site_title: Riskier currencies gain on Covid-19 vaccine hopes
summary: Riskier currencies, such as the New Zealand and Australian dollars, gained ground against the US dollar on Wednesday as investors became more optimistic about a Covid-19 vaccine and a potential economic recovery. The US dollar index fell to a one-month low of 95.866, while the euro reached a four-month high of 1.14475. The Norwegian krone and Swedish krona also strengthened against the US dollar, with the Swedish krona reaching its highest level since February 2019. The euro's gains were boosted by hopes of a European Union agreement on a Covid-19 recovery fund.

site_title: ChildAid raises S$1.95m for underprivileged children
summary: Singapore's digital ChildAid 2020 concert, featuring over 1,150 artists from around the world, raised S$1.95 million for underprivileged children. The concert, which included performances by Nathan Hartono, Abby Simone, and Jasmine Sokko, was held in a fully immersive 360º video format and Ambisonics surround sound. Top sponsors included United Overseas Bank, UBS, Richard Mille, and Citi Singapore, with funds going towards The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, which support arts training and school meals for over 170,000 children.

site_title: Huawei ban turns UK phone market into duopoly
summary: The UK's decision to ban Huawei from its 5G wireless networks has led to a duopoly in the market, with European rivals Nokia and Ericsson splitting the market. Carriers will need to use both companies to avoid becoming reliant on either vendor, resulting in higher prices. The ban removes Huawei's competitive pricing and technological edge, and phone companies will miss an opportunity for steeper discounts in the early stages of the 5G rollout. Nokia and Ericsson are expected to entrench their position against newcomers.

site_title: Shenzhen tightens restrictions on home purchases as prices spike
summary: Shenzhen, China, has introduced new restrictions on home purchases to curb sharp price rises and speculation. The city now only allows residents with residency permits and tax or social security contributions for three years to buy homes. The city also tightened transaction tax policies on big apartments and made it harder for people to divorce to buy homes.
