This move aims to manage the property market and expand home supply, despite the backdrop of broader policy easing. Second-hand home prices in Shenzhen rose 12% in May, the second-highest gain among 70 major cities in China.

site_title: Finding opportunities in a crisis
summary: A recent article highlights four startups that have found opportunities in the COVID-19 crisis, offering innovative solutions such as contactless hotel check-ins and electric co-sharing vehicles. Meanwhile, luxury resort founder Sonu Shivdasani discusses coping with business loss while continuing conservation efforts. The article also touches on the resurgence of Japanese sushi restaurants and fresh watch designs from top brands. Overall, the piece emphasizes that every crisis can present new opportunities, and entrepreneurs are finding creative ways to thrive amidst adversity.

site_title: STI closes 28.71 points higher amid mixed sentiment across the region
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 28.71 points higher at 2,648.90, up 1.1%, despite mixed sentiment across the region. Only four of its 30 component stocks declined, with property counters such as CityDev and CapitaLand rising 2.96% and 2.11% respectively. Analysts see long-term value in these stocks, despite the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic affecting residential property sales and hotel occupancy rates.

site_title: Casinos can't survive on local 'revenge gamblers' alone
summary: Singapore's integrated resorts (IRs) reopened their doors to tourists on July 1, but analysts question whether they can sustain their core casino operations on domestic punters alone. The IRs, operated by Genting Singapore and Las Vegas Sands Corp, rely heavily on international markets, with locals contributing only about two-fifths of overall industry revenue. Analysts predict a slow recovery, with some estimating a halving of full-year Singapore turnover for the two local operators, and a potential return to normal in the second half of 2021.

site_title: Keppel bags two FPSO contracts worth S$73m
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has secured two FPSO contracts worth approximately S$73 million from Modec Offshore Production Systems. In Singapore, Keppel Shipyard will fabricate and integrate modules for an FPSO vessel with a capacity to process 90,000 barrels of oil and 75 million standard cubic feet of gas per day. In Brazil, Keppel O&M's BrasFELS shipyard will fabricate a topside module for an FPSO, with delivery scheduled for Q4 2021. The contracts mark Keppel O&M's seventh FPSO-related project with Modec.

site_title: Naiise exits Design Orchard, cuts headcount, operating costs
summary: Naiise, a Singapore-based design retailer, is exiting its role as operator of Design Orchard's retail showcase after implementing cost-cutting measures, including layoffs and reduced operating costs. The Textile and Fashion Federation (TaFF) will take over the role on August 1. Naiise cited the need to consolidate its business operations and focus on its e-commerce and brick-and-mortar stores amid the economic climate. The company had already cut its headcount by 50% and reduced operating expenses by 20-30%.

site_title: Acquiring full control of BidFX will enable SGX to unlock vast potential of FX OTC market
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has acquired the remaining 80% stake in BidFX, a trading venue used by hedge funds and banks, for $128 million. The move is part of SGX's strategy to expand into the global foreign exchange over-the-counter (OTC) market, which is the largest financial market in the world. With BidFX, SGX aims to offer a transparent, margin-efficient, and well-regulated platform for managing Asian currency risks. The acquisition is expected to propel SGX's reach beyond FX futures into the global FX OTC market, where the bulk of transactions take place.

site_title: Thai motor show underway in first big event since coronavirus outbreak
summary: Thailand's 41st Bangkok International Motor Show has opened to the public, marking the country's first large-scale event since the coronavirus outbreak. The show, which has been postponed twice, features thermal scans and physical distancing measures to ensure attendee safety. With nearly all attendees wearing masks and face shields, the event is expected to attract a significant number of visitors, similar to its previous shows.

images.alt_text: Thailand opened its twice-postponed annual auto show to the public on Wednesday in the country's first large-scale event since coronavirus restrictions eased, with nearly all attendees wearing masks and face shields.

site_title: Italy's Ferragamo raises prices by 5-7% to stem Covid-19 impact
summary: Italian luxury brand Ferragamo raises prices by 5-7% to mitigate the impact of the coronavirus crisis on sales and profits. The move follows similar steps by other luxury brands to limit the impact of lockdown measures and tourist traffic slowdown. Ferragamo's sales fell by nearly a third in the first three months of 2020, and the company is expected to update on sales trends on July 28. The price increase aims to offset rising logistics and retail management costs caused by the pandemic.

site_title: Pandemic-induced recession demands a different response
summary: Singapore has officially entered a recession, with a record 12.6% plunge in gross domestic product (GDP) in the second quarter of 2020. The recession was caused by a combination of the pandemic and circuit breaker measures, but economists view Q2's performance as a trough, with recovery expected to be gradual and uneven. The pandemic's impact on the economy is unpredictable, with the virus's development and spread affecting domestic and global efforts, making economic policy less effective in resolving the recovery path.

site_title: BBC announces further 70 job cuts in news
summary: The BBC has announced 70 additional job cuts in its news operation, bringing the total to 520, following an initial 450 job cuts in January that were postponed due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The cuts are part of the corporation's effort to become sustainable, with a plan to produce fewer, more targeted stories with greater impact. Director Fran Unsworth stated the changes are necessary to ensure the broadcaster's long-term viability.

site_title: Over 2,500 games removed from Apple's China app store
summary: Over 2,500 mobile games were removed from Apple's China app store in the first week of July due to a loophole that was closed to comply with Chinese licence requirements. The games, which included notable titles such as Hay Day, Nonstop Chuck Norris, and Solitaire, generated $34.7 million in lifetime gross revenue in China and had accumulated over 133 million downloads. This is four times the number of games removed in the same period in June. The games will likely be available again in the future, but for now, they have been removed from the storefront for more than five days.

images.alt_text: Apple closed a loophole to comply with Chinese licence requirements.

site_title: Boeing lost 60 Max orders in June amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Boeing lost 60 737 Max orders in June due to the coronavirus pandemic, with 47 previously announced cancellations and an additional 123 orders in peril from shaky buyers. This brings the total lost orders to 60. The company's order stockpile continued to shrink, further impacted by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Boeing's defence business, long overshadowed by booming jetliner sales, is now poised to help the Chicago-based company weather the market turmoil in civil aviation.

site_title: US rare earths miner MP Materials to go public in US$1.47b deal
summary: US rare earths miner MP Materials is set to go public through a merger with Fortress Investment Group-backed blank-check company Fortress Value Acquisition Corp in a deal valued at US$1.47 billion. The listing on the New York Stock Exchange would be the first for a US rare earths company since 2015. MP Materials, which ships over 50,000 tonnes of concentrated rare earths per year to China, plans to use the funds to upgrade processing equipment and aims to resume US production amidst efforts to reduce reliance on China.

site_title: Problem gambling under control: casino regulator
summary: Singapore's problem gambling situation is under control, according to the Casino Regulatory Authority (CRA). The authorities closely monitor patron visits and financial vulnerability, and have introduced measures such as tightened casino entry levies and tax rates. Help is available for addicts, with a National Problem Gambling Helpline and online resources. The CRA will introduce further measures if needed, and casinos are set to gradually reopen in a subdued economic climate. The incidence of problem gambling remains under control, despite the economic uncertainty.

site_title: Oil edges higher on drop in US stockpiles, Opec+ compliance
summary: Oil prices edged higher after a report showed a drop in US crude stockpiles and signs that Opec+ supply cuts may not be as extensive as anticipated. US inventories fell by 8.32 million barrels, the largest drawdown since December, suggesting a supply glut is easing. Oil futures traded near $40.50 a barrel, with Brent rising 0.5% to $43.10. The Opec+ group is seeking compensatory production cuts in August and September to address supply imbalances, but the impact may be limited as the market already prices in the tapering of supply cuts.

site_title: US import prices beat expectations in June
summary: US import prices rose 1.4% in June, beating expectations of a 1.0% gain, driven by a surge in fuel costs. Despite the increase, the overall trend remains weak, suggesting tame inflation. Import prices fell 3.8% in the 12 months through June, after dropping 6.2% in May. The higher import prices may impact the consumer price index, which rose last month.

site_title: Economy past the worst, but recovery will be slow: BOJ head
summary: Japan's economy has passed its worst, but recovery is expected to be slow, according to Bank of Japan (BOJ) Governor Haruhiko Kuroda. The BOJ kept its short-term interest rate at -0.1% and left its asset purchases unchanged, as economists predicted no additional stimulus. The central bank forecasts a 4.7% economic contraction in the next year, with a gradual recovery expected in the following years. The BOJ will continue to monitor the economy and virus developments, but is not ready to introduce new policy measures, citing the need to assess the effectiveness of its current measures.

site_title: Oil steady after Saudi minister signals Opec+ may reduce cuts in Aug
summary: Oil prices steadied on Wednesday, supported by a sharp drop in US inventories, but gains were held in check as Saudi Arabia's energy minister signaled Opec+ may ease supply cuts from August. Oil prices rose 0.3% to $43.04 a barrel for Brent crude and $40.42 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate. Opec+ has been cutting output since May, but is expected to ease reductions as oil demand recovers.

site_title: Business leaders must retain focus as Asia's 'riskscape' evolves
summary: Asia-Pacific businesses are struggling to address climate risks despite the region experiencing increasing natural disasters and economic losses due to climate change. A survey found that only 40% of companies are fully prepared to address climate risks, with 34% believing their organization is significantly exposed to climate risk. The evolving "riskscape" in Asia-Pacific poses a growing threat to businesses, with projected increases in exposure to floods, droughts, storm surges, and extreme temperatures. To mitigate these risks, business leaders must focus on loss prevention strategies, including increasing capital allocation, enhancing disaster recovery plans, and reassessing supply-chain risk management.

site_title: Global consumer confidence plunged in Q2, rebound likely sluggish says Conference Board
summary: Global consumer confidence plummeted to a record low of 92 in Q2, down from 106 at the start of the year, according to the Conference Board. The index, based on a poll of 33,000 consumers in 68 countries, indicates a slow climb back is expected due to ongoing pandemic concerns, job uncertainty, and lack of trust in government. Only Germany, China, South Korea, and Australia are forecast to see a "fairly quick" rebound in consumer confidence. The US index was slightly positive at 101, but the change from the previous year's high was dramatic.

site_title: Neil Montefiore, former Starhub and M1 CEO, dies, aged 67
summary: Neil Montefiore, former CEO of StarHub and M1, has died at 67 due to a heart attack in London. Montefiore led the telcos from 2004 to 2013. Tributes have poured in for the British businessman.

site_title: New job scopes for remaining RWS staff
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) is redeveloping its operations with the "RWS 2.0" project, aiming to create new job scopes for remaining staff. The integrated resort will offer higher-value, redesigned jobs, focusing on technological innovation, sustainable landscaping, predictive analytics, and technical support for augmented reality. RWS Academy will collaborate with public agencies and industry partners to provide re-skilling and upgrading programs for tourism skills. The project aims to add over 164,000 square meters of attractions, including the expansion of the S.E.A. Aquarium into a new Singapore Oceanarium.

images.alt_text: Staff who have escaped the axe at Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) could take up higher-value, redesigned jobs, as the integrated resort pushes ahead with its "RWS 2.0" redevelopment.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps at open on Goldman's profit beat, vaccine hopes
summary: Wall Street opened sharply higher on Wednesday after Goldman Sachs reported a strong quarterly profit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.38% to 27,009.81, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.89% and 0.84%, respectively. The strong earnings and promising early data for a potential Covid-19 vaccine boosted economic recovery hopes, driving market gains.

site_title: Wirecard gets a win as UK court dismisses fraud case over deal
summary: A UK court dismissed a fraud case against Wirecard, a German payments processor, over its 2015 purchase of an Indian company. The former owners of the company alleged Wirecard paid 326 million euros for the business, which had been sold earlier for a fraction of the amount. However, the court ruled that the allegations lack substance and are contradicted by documents and evidence, dismissing the case without trial. The former owners sought 27.5 million euros from Wirecard.

site_title: Thailand's top economic team to resign: media reports
summary: Thailand's Finance Minister Uttama Savanayana and Deputy Prime Minister Somkid Jatusripitak are reportedly resigning or planning to resign, amid the country's struggling economy. The news came as a surprise to Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, who denied knowledge of the reports. The economic team's departure could further impact Thailand's efforts to mitigate the damage from the coronavirus pandemic, which has already slowed big-ticket investment projects and billions of dollars in stimulus measures. The government's spokeswoman did not comment on the matter.

site_title: Sembmarine institutes pay cuts as yard shutdowns bring H1 net loss to S$192m
summary: Sembmarine, a marine and offshore engineering group, posted a net loss of S$192 million in the first half of 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, despite efforts to reduce costs. The company implemented pay cuts for most employees, with CEO Wong Weng Sun volunteering a 50% pay cut. Revenue declined 41% to S$906 million, and the group expects recovery to be pushed out to 2021 and beyond. Sembmarine's net order book was S$1.91 billion, and the company is exploring new projects, including a proposed S$2.1 billion rights issue to strengthen its balance sheet.

site_title: Troubled Epicentre Holdings to sell SGX listing status for S$3m
summary: Epicentre Holdings has agreed to sell its Singapore Exchange listing status for S$3 million to an unnamed entity, backed by South Korea-listed steel manufacturer Kossen. The company, currently under judicial management, has suspended its shares from trading. After the transfer, Epicentre's shares will be delisted and withdrawn from the Catalist board. The transferee plans to undergo an internal reorganisation, with its financial information expected to be available in due course. The sale comes after Epicentre's former CEO and executive chairman Kenneth Lim faced a bankruptcy petition over a debt of S$588,020.

site_title: India's Infosys beats profit estimates on large deal wins
summary: India's Infosys reported a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit, driven by large client deals worth $1.74 billion. The company's net profit rose 11.7% to 42.33 billion rupees, beating analyst estimates. Revenue grew 8.5% to 236.65 billion rupees. Despite softer client spending due to the Covid-19 pandemic, Infosys' results contrast with its rival Tata Consultancy Services, which missed quarterly profit estimates. The company's performance suggests a resilient software services sector in India.

site_title: SGX queries Biolidics on A*Star licence deal
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried Biolidics about the details of a licence agreement with A*Star, a 5-year deal to use the agency's technology for Covid-19 detection. Biolidics announced the deal on July 9, but SGX wants to know about the licence agreement and the timing of its trading halt and announcement. The licence agreement allows Biolidics to use A*Star's technology for detecting Covid-19 viral spike and ACE2 blocking antibodies. The SGX's queries follow Biolidics' recent trading halt and announcement.

site_title: Documenting the year 2020
summary: Museums in the US are working to document the 2020 pandemic and racial justice movement, urging the public to preserve personal materials for future historians. With severe economic collapse and nationwide protests, curators and archivists are facing a daunting task. They are calling on people to donate personal items, such as photographs and artifacts, to museums for possible inclusion in archives. This effort aims to capture the story of a pivotal year in US history and provide a unique perspective for future generations.

site_title: US industrial output jumps 5.4% in June
summary: US industrial output surged 5.4% in June, rebounding from the pandemic's worst impact, according to the Federal Reserve. The April-June quarter saw an annual 42.6% collapse in industrial production, its largest quarterly decrease since World War II. Manufacturing output rose 7.2% in June, but fell 11.1% below pre-pandemic levels. Industrial capacity utilization climbed back to 68.6%, still below the pre-pandemic level of 76.9%.

images.alt_text: American industry saw a rebound in June as businesses began to reopen amid the coronavirus pandemic, with total output jumping 5.4 per cent compared to May.

site_title: Pay cuts at Sembmarine as yard shutdowns bring H1 net loss to S$192 million
summary: SEMBCORP Marine posted a net loss of S$192.1 million in the half-year ended June 30, mainly due to the shutdown of its Singapore yards since April due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue declined 41% to S$906 million. All segments posted losses except repairs-and-upgrades, which reported higher profits due to a better product mix. This is a significant improvement from the net loss of S$6.8 million in the same period last year.

site_title: Sembcorp JV sells 30% stake in Sichuan innovation park developer for S$138.8m
summary: Sembcorp Industries' joint venture, Singapore-Sichuan Investment Holdings, has agreed to sell a 30% stake in Sino-Singapore (Chengdu) Innovation Park Development Co (SSCIP) for S$138.8 million. The stake will be sold to Chengdu High-tech Investment Group, reducing SSIH's share in SSCIP to 20%. The sale price includes a 22.6% premium over the original cost, factoring in SSIH's cost of funds in China. The disposal is expected to be completed by the end of this month, with the consideration expected to be received in cash by March 31, 2021.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 13.19 points to 1,585.56. Volume reached 8.236 billion lots worth RM5.015 billion, with 558 gainers and 456 losers.

site_title: Blow for EU as Apple wins fight against 13b-euro tax order
summary: The European Union's second-highest court rejected an order for Apple to pay 13 billion euros in Irish back taxes, dealing a blow to the bloc's efforts to crack down on sweetheart tax deals. The court found that the European Commission failed to prove Apple received illegal state aid through Irish tax rulings. The decision weakens European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager's cases against other multinationals, including Ikea and Nike, and highlights the need for corporate tax reform in Europe.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, driven by strong gains in Tokyo and Wall Street due to hopes for a coronavirus vaccine and US stimulus. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.8%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also rose 0.9% and 0.8%, respectively. Despite a slight increase in Britain's annual inflation rate to 0.6% in June, traders focused on positive market sentiment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended flat on Wednesday, despite hopes for a vaccine and a potential recovery, due to a spike in infections and Donald Trump's decision to remove its special trading status. The Hang Seng Index rose 3.69 points to 24,481.58, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.56% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.2%.

site_title: Trump on UK's Huawei ban: 'I did this myself'
summary: US President Donald Trump said he was responsible for the UK's decision to ban Huawei from Britain's 5G network, citing security concerns. However, London denied this, stating the ban was motivated by its own security concerns. China accused the decision was highly politicized, with Beijing expressing concerns that the ban will hurt its investment in the UK. The UK will need to take longer to roll out 5G mobile networks without Huawei equipment.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said he was responsible for Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to ban Huawei from Britain's 5G network, a remark that London brushed off and Beijing said proved the British move was political.

site_title: Founder Bak Kut Teh calls for customers' support as Covid-19 pushes it to the brink
summary: Founder Bak Kut Teh, a 42-year-old F&B business, is facing a dire situation due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Sales have plummeted by 85% over the past five months, with the business relying on takeaway orders and deliveries. To save itself, the business will offer discounted set menus from July 17 to Aug 17. The owner, Nigel Chua, is seeking customers' support to continue serving the community.

site_title: Modi's fuel-tax hikes put brakes on India's recovery
summary: India's economic recovery is being hindered by the central government's fuel-tax hikes, which have led to a surge in fuel prices. Diesel prices in New Delhi have risen 30% and petrol prices 16% since April, affecting businesses like transport companies and farmers. The hikes, combined with the world's largest coronavirus lockdown, are causing anxiety among these groups, who rely heavily on fuel for their operations. The government's decision is expected to further slow down the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Retail prices for diesel in the capital New Delhi have jumped 30% since the end of April,while petrol has risen 16%.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Resorts World Sentosa announces 'one-off' layoffs, pledging to protect 'Singaporean core' amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. New private home sales in Singapore surged to 998 in June, more than double May's volume. DBS and Contour completed a secured letter of credit transaction on a blockchain network. Frasers Property brought in a capital partner for Northpoint City (South Wing), while the Singapore Exchange queried Biolidics on a licence agreement. The Straits Times Index closed 28.71 points up at 2,648.90.

site_title: Goldman profit blows past estimates on trading surge
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 93% surge in revenue in its global markets unit, driven by trading surges in stock and bond markets, beating estimates by a wide margin. The bank's net earnings rose 2% to $2.25 billion, with earnings per share increasing to $6.26. Investment banking revenue jumped 36% to $2.66 billion, and overall revenue rose 41% to $13.30 billion. The results exceeded analyst estimates and reflect a resurgence in trading across Wall Street banks in the second quarter.

site_title: Google buys 7.7% of Reliance's digital unit Jio Platforms for US$4.5b
summary: Google invests $4.5 billion in Reliance's digital unit Jio Platforms, gaining a 7.7% stake. This is the second major investment in Jio Platforms after Facebook's $5.7 billion deal in April. Strategic and financial investors have committed $28.16 billion to the company since then. Jio Platforms houses music and movie apps, as well as India's largest mobile carrier, Jio Infocomm, with 387 million users. The deal marks a significant partnership between the Indian conglomerate and the US tech giant.

site_title: Train operating hours to shorten from July 20 to Aug 30 as TEL gears up for year-end Stage 2 opening
summary: The Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) train services will operate shorter hours from July 20 to August 30 to prepare for the opening of Stage 2. Train services between Woodlands North and Woodlands South will end at 9pm daily, and weekend services will start at 6:30am. This change aims to facilitate testing of trains and systems ahead of the year-end Stage 2 opening, which will feature six new stations. Commuters can use existing public bus services or transfer to the North-South Line at Woodlands Station.

site_title: Condo and HDB rents down in June: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rents continued their decline in June, with private rents falling 0.6% from May and HDB rents down 0.5%. Year-over-year, private rents dropped 0.7% and 2.2% in core central and rest of central regions, respectively, while HDB rents fell 2% and 16.1% from their peaks. Leasing demand for private apartments increased by 54.4% and HDB flats by 55.7% in June, but experts predict a 2-4% drop in leasing demand this year due to economic concerns.

site_title: Green Court in Geylang relaunched for en bloc sale; owners expect more than S$28m
summary: Green Court, a freehold mixed-use development in Geylang, has been relaunched for collective sale by tender with a guide price of S$28 million plus a development charge of S$5.24 million. The site, zoned for commercial and residential redevelopment, is near Paya Lebar Central and expected to benefit from the area's rejuvenation. The tender will close on August 18, with owners anticipating offers above the reserve price. The development comprises three ground-floor shops and six two-storey walk-up apartments, offering redevelopment potential of up to 28,216 square feet.

site_title: STI closes 28.71 points up at 2,648.90; key property stocks chart gains
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 28.71 points to 2,648.90, a 1.1% gain, driven by key property stocks such as UOL Group, City Developments, and CapitaLand, which surged 2.96%, 2.66%, and 2.11% respectively. Despite mixed sentiment and a sombre Q2 reporting season, analysts see these stocks as offering decent value for long-term investors.

site_title: Eight in 10 firms expect Covid-19 to change business models: survey
summary: Eight in 10 businesses in Asean expect the Covid-19 pandemic to change their business model or operations, according to a SAP survey of 4,500 firms. 63% have seen changes in customers' purchasing behavior, and a fifth expect to change customer experience strategies. In Singapore, 65% had adapted their business strategy, with top interests in business technology platforms and intelligent enterprise. The survey suggests that businesses are taking proactive steps to transform and improve operations in response to the pandemic's impact.

site_title: 160 turtles caught in plastic waste rescued from Bangladesh beach
summary: About 160 Olive Ridley sea turtles, many injured by plastic waste, have been rescued from Bangladesh's Cox's Bazar beach. The turtles were found entangled in 50 tonnes of debris, with around 30 dying and being buried in the sand. Survivors were released into the Bay of Bengal, but some returned to the beach due to their weakened state. Conservationists believe the turtles may have become stuck in a massive plastic garbage patch in the sea, highlighting the need for pollution management in the Bay of Bengal to protect marine species.

images.alt_text: About 160 sea turtles, many of them injured after getting entangled in plastic waste, have been rescued after washing up on one of the world's longest beaches in Bangladesh.

site_title: WeWork co-founder Adam Neumann invests in vehicle sharing firm GoTo Global
summary: WeWork co-founder Adam Neumann has invested $10 million in GoTo Global, a vehicle sharing service provider, as part of a $19 million funding round. The investment values GoTo Global at $30 million, with Neumann holding a 33% stake. The company plans to expand in Europe and expects the alternative transportation market to exceed $600 billion by 2025. This investment comes after Neumann filed a lawsuit against SoftBank Group in May.

site_title: Low borrowing costs can't save India shadow banks in crisis
summary: India's shadow banks, crucial for lending to small merchants and businesses, face challenges despite low borrowing costs, which declined for a second straight month. The sector's financial health is uncertain, with Moody's Investors Service warning of deeper stress among lenders. The government's $277 billion virus-relief package and central bank rate cuts have provided some relief, but the economy's pandemic-induced woes and rising bad debt concerns remain a major concern for the sector's revival. Prime Minister Narendra Modi must kick-start lending to revive economic growth.

site_title: SIA flew just 13,900 passengers in June; group expects 'material operating loss' in Q1
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) flew just 13,900 passengers in June 2020, a 95.1% decline from the same period last year, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline expects a material operating loss for the first quarter of its financial year, citing a slower-than-expected recovery trajectory and reduced fuel consumption. Industry forecasts predict it will take two to four years for passenger traffic to return to pre-pandemic levels, and SIA has downgraded its revenue generation capability.

site_title: Cambodia, Myanmar, Vietnam to gain most from apparel shifts: Report
summary: Cambodia, Myanmar, and Vietnam are poised to gain from shifts in apparel manufacturing, as China reduces its operations and seeks to move up the value chain. These neighboring countries have high growth potential due to large populations, low labor costs, and participation in free trade agreements. Vietnam has already benefited from the shift, with its apparel exports increasing 30% during the US-China trade war. Cambodia's apparel manufacturing sector has grown at 13% over the last decade, and Myanmar's growth is expected to continue, particularly in low-value garments, due to its numerous seaports and favorable investment policies.

images.alt_text: Workers at a garment factory in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

site_title: Marina Bay floating platform's redevelopment to start in 2022
summary: The redevelopment of The Float @ Marina Bay, a floating platform, is set to begin in March 2022 and be completed by end-2025, according to the Ministry of National Development and Ministry of Defence. The project will transform the platform into a permanent venue for large-scale events and community activities, featuring a swimming pool, water sports centre, and a National Service themed gallery. The redevelopment is part of Singapore's urban development plans to create vibrant public spaces. The design consultancy tender has been awarded to Woha Architects, and the project scope may be adjusted due to the impact of Covid-19.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on hopes of recovery, vaccine
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.59% to 22,945.50, driven by optimism over economic recovery and advancements in coronavirus treatments. The broader Topix index also gained 1.56%. The positive sentiment followed a global rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Naiise exits Design Orchard, halves headcount
summary: Design retailer Naiise is exiting its role as operator of Design Orchard's retail showcase, effective August 1, due to cost-cutting measures amid the economic climate. Naiise, which had already reduced its headcount by 50% and cut operating expenses, will be replaced by the Textile and Fashion Federation. The decision was made to "consolidate" Naiise's business operations and focus on its online and brick-and-mortar stores. The Singapore Tourism Board facilitated a smooth transition, with plans to enhance the existing mentorship programme and increase open calls for local brands.

site_title: Hillhouse invests US$1b in Beigene's share sale
summary: Hillhouse Capital invested approximately US$1 billion in Beigene's share sale, increasing its stake to around 12.7%. The investment, valued at US$2.1 billion, is the largest equity financing by a biotech company. Beigene's shares surged 18% in Hong Kong, outpacing the Hang Seng index, following the approval of its blood cancer therapy by the US FDA last November, positioning the company as a promising Chinese biotech firm.

site_title: Neil Montefiore, former chief executive of StarHub and M1, has died aged 67
summary: Former Singaporean telco executives Neil Montefiore, 67, has died in London after a heart attack. Montefiore, who led M1 and StarHub, was remembered for his candid nature, incredible foresight, and ability to make friends easily. He was a key figure in the Singaporean telco industry, helping to grow M1's market share and StarHub's share price significantly during his tenure. Montefiore's legacy is marked by his straight-talking manner and ability to predict future technological advancements, including the rise of wireless devices.

images.alt_text: Neil Montefiore had moved to Singapore from Hong Kong in 1996 to head MobileOne, which would later be known as M1.

site_title: SGX queries Biolidics on timing, details of A*Star licence announcement
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried Biolidics about the timing and details of its licence agreement with A*Star, a commercialisation arm of the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star), to develop Covid-19 serology tests. Biolidics entered the 5-year licence agreement on July 9 and has been trading halted since July 13. SGX asked for reasons behind the delay, sponsor consultation, and projected timeline for technology development. Biolidics must respond to these queries by Thursday.

site_title: Wavemaker closes third South-east Asia fund at US$111m
summary: Wavemaker Partners, a Singapore-based deep-tech investor, closed its third South-east Asia fund at US$111.5 million, surpassing its target of US$100 million. The fund, anchored by returning investors Temasek and Pavilion Capital, saw 43% of capital come from returning investors. The firm has made 136 investments since 2012, with 85% focused on business-to-business enterprise tech and 32% on deep-tech and artificial intelligence. The fund's closing comes amid the Covid-19 pandemic, which has strengthened Wavemaker's conviction in B2B startups.

site_title: Lockdown computer gaming helps fuel rise in UK inflation
summary: UK inflation rose unexpectedly to 0.6% in June, driven by rising prices for in-demand computer consoles and clothing during the coronavirus lockdown. The Office for National Statistics attributed the increase to changes in demand and availability, as well as the timing of sales promotions. Core inflation rose to 1.4%, well below the Bank of England's 2% target, leaving the central bank under no pressure to rethink its stimulus push. The data contradicts economists' forecasts, which had expected a decrease in inflation.

site_title: Swatch Group free to supply watch movements: Swiss watchdog
summary: Swatch Group can now supply mechanical watch movements to any customer without restrictions, ending a year-long competition procedure. The Swiss competition watchdog Weko made this decision to ensure fair competition, despite the group's dominant market position for these essential watch parts. This ruling affects Sellita, the main competitor in mechanical watch movements, allowing Swatch Group to supply movements to whomever it chooses.

site_title: Burberry's first-quarter like-for-like sales drop 45%
summary: Burberry reported a 45% decline in like-for-like sales in its first quarter due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The decline eased to 20% in June, driven by growth in mainland China and South Korea. The company expects revenue in its second quarter to remain impacted by the pandemic, with a 15-20% decline predicted. Total retail revenue fell 48% to £257 million. Burberry's CEO, Marco Gobbetti, noted that luxury demand will take time to recover with the resumption of overseas travel.

site_title: Young Hong Kong democrats seek new political order under shadow of Beijing
summary: A group of young Hong Kong democrats, known as localists, have secured big wins in primary elections for the democracy camp, outshining veteran democrats. Backed by volunteers, they campaigned for a more assertive stance on saving the city's freedoms, with some supporting independence. The localists' success has drawn attention from Beijing, which condemned the poll as "illegal manipulation." The young democrats aim to secure a majority in the city's legislature, riding a wave of anti-Beijing sentiment, and are seen as a potential game-changer in Hong Kong's politics.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit 5-month closing high on coronavirus vaccine hopes
summary: South Korean stocks rose to a five-month closing high on Wednesday, driven by encouraging results from an experimental Covid-19 vaccine and sharp overnight gains on Wall Street. The Kospi index climbed 18.27 points or 0.84% to 2,201.88, with Hyundai Motor and other shares gaining up to 7.4%. The Korean won strengthened, while bond yields fell, and foreigners bought 267.80 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: German watchdog files new Wirecard insider trading complaint
summary: The German financial watchdog BaFin has filed a complaint with Munich prosecutors over alleged insider trading at Wirecard, a payment company that filed for insolvency. The complaint involves a 6.6 million euro sale of shares by MB Beteiligungsgesellschaft, the investment vehicle of former CEO Markus Braun, on June 24. A further sale of 3.4 million euros is under investigation. The complaint marks the latest episode in a series of alleged insider trading cases linked to Wirecard.

site_title: Indonesia's June trade data beat forecasts, exports grow for first time in 4 months
summary: Indonesia's June trade data beat forecasts, with exports growing 2.28% to $12.03 billion, the first expansion in four months. Imports fell 6.36% to $10.76 billion, driven by a surge in consumer goods. The country posted a $1.27 billion surplus, exceeding forecasts. The improvement in trade data suggests improving demand after countries eased coronavirus-induced restrictions.

site_title: Sony boosting output of PlayStation 5 to meet surge in demand
summary: Sony is increasing PlayStation 5 production to 10 million units this year, roughly doubling its initial target of 5-6 million units by the end of March 2021. The surge in demand is attributed to the prolonged effects of the Covid-19 pandemic, with concerns of a second wave potentially keeping more people at home. Despite the increased production, logistics may pose a challenge to delivering all units on time for the holiday shopping season, and Sony may still face shipping constraints due to its reliance on sea cargo from China.

site_title: Bankers shocked by 45% China tax rate mull leaving Hong Kong
summary: China has introduced a 45% tax rate on its citizens' global income, sparking concerns of a brain drain in Hong Kong, where many mainland professionals work. The new tax rate, which applies to employees who transferred from China, has led to fears of a mass exodus of bankers and other white-collar workers. The tax move is expected to weigh on Hong Kong's economy, further undermining its status as a premier financial center, and has already led to some companies offering interest-free loans or cash payouts to impacted employees.

site_title: New Singapore private home sales surge to 998 in June, more than double May's volume
summary: Singapore's private home sales surged to 998 units in June, more than double May's 486, driven by pent-up demand and increased foreign buying due to reopened show galleries. Affordable homes accounted for over 90% of sold units. Foreign buyers rose to the highest in 10 months, with 169 purchases, mostly permanent residents and non-residents. The sales were the highest for June in seven years, with the previous high in 2013.

site_title: Electric-car subsidies make Renaults free in Germany
summary: Germany's newly generous electric vehicle (EV) subsidies have made Renault's Zoe model free for some buyers, with 3,000 inquiries and 300 signed contracts in just 20 days. The EU is pushing towards decarbonizing transport, and the COVID-19 crisis has accelerated this goal. Other European countries, including France and the Netherlands, are also offering attractive EV incentives, with sales of the Zoe model expected to double in France this year. As subsidies continue, analysts expect EVs to become more competitive with gasoline cars by the mid-2020s.

site_title: Apple Orchard Road store among new places visited by infectious coronavirus patients
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has added several locations, including Apple Orchard Road, Tekka Centre, and Bugis+, to a list of places visited by infectious Covid-19 patients. These locations were visited while the patients were still contagious. The updated list includes other places such as Tat Fong Paint, Cheng Chew Wah, and All India Supermart. The Ministry is working to track and contain the spread of the virus.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars test resistance, offshore buyers big on bonds
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on Wednesday, with the Aussie adding 0.3% to US$0.6998 and the kiwi dollar firming 0.2% to US$0.6552. The gains were driven by progress on a Covid-19 vaccine and strong demand from foreign buyers for an Australian bond sale, which saw 45% of the debt go to offshore investors. The strong demand suggests a potential for future bond sales, supporting the currencies' values ahead of the June peak.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars edged higher on Wednesday as progress on a Covid-19 vaccine buoyed US equities, while details of a bumper Aussie bond sale showed strong demand from foreign buyers.

site_title: Australia weighs further coronavirus curbs as outbreak grows
summary: Australia's most populous states will impose harsher restrictions on movement if a Covid-19 outbreak is not quickly contained. Despite being a global leader in containing the virus, the country has seen a surge in new cases, with Victoria reporting 238 cases in the past 24 hours. The state had previously reimposed a lockdown on Melbourne, but the outbreak continues. If the situation doesn't improve, restrictions will be imposed on movement across the country, highlighting the need for swift action to control the outbreak.

images.alt_text: Australia's most populous states will impose harsher restrictions on movement if a Covid-19 outbreak is not quickly bought under control, state premiers said on Wednesday.

site_title: Tokyo to lift coronavirus alert to highest level: Asahi
summary: Tokyo will lift its coronavirus alert to the highest level after daily cases exceeded 200 for four of the last six days, reaching a record high of 243 cases. The alert level indicates that "coronavirus infections are likely spreading". This move comes after testing in Tokyo's red-light districts uncovered infections among young people in their 20s and 30s.

site_title: Gold steadies above US$1,800 as virus fears, US-China tensions rise
summary: Gold prices held steady above the US$1,800 mark, driven by concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic and rising tensions between the US and China. Spot gold rose 0.1% to US$1,808.61 per ounce, while US gold futures eased 0.1% to US$1,811.40. Investors are hedging against potential economic risks, particularly in the US, where coronavirus cases continue to rise and the Federal Reserve warned of a longer recovery. Simmering US-China tensions also contribute to safe-haven demand for gold.

site_title: World population in 2100 could be 2 billion below UN projections
summary: A major study published in The Lancet predicts that the world population will reach 8.8 billion by 2100, 2 billion fewer than current UN projections. By then, 183 countries will have fallen below the replacement threshold, with over 20 countries experiencing population declines of at least half. Sub-Saharan Africa will triple in size, while China's population will drop to 730 million. The study also forecasts a multipolar world economy, with India, Nigeria, and the US emerging as dominant powers.

site_title: Japan's economy to shrink 4.7% in 2020/21: central bank
summary: Japan's economy is projected to contract 4.7% in the year to March 2021, down from an April projection of 5.0-3.0% contraction. The Bank of Japan expects a gradual recovery from the second half of 2020, with moderate growth, but notes deep uncertainty due to the novel coronavirus. The central bank maintains its monetary easing program and projects Japanese GDP will expand 3.3% in 2022 and 1.5% in 2023, despite core consumer prices expected to fall 0.5% for the year.

site_title: Hot stock: Biolidics down 8.7% after A*Star Covid-19 technology licence pact
summary: Biolidics, a Covid-19 test kit maker, saw its shares fall 8.7% after entering a five-year licence agreement with A*Star's Accelerate Technologies for Covid-19 viral spike detection technology. The company aims to develop new serology tests using the technology. Shares traded at 52 cents on Monday before the announcement, and briefly rose to 55.5 cents before closing at 44 cents.

site_title: Cirque du Soleil set to accept recapitalisation bid by lenders
summary: Cirque du Soleil Entertainment Group is set to accept a recapitalisation bid from lenders, injecting at least $300 million of new capital into the financially strapped company. The proposal would see first-lien creditors, owed $900 million, wind up with virtually all of the company's equity. The offer replaces a previous stalking horse bid from investors, including TPG, and comes after the company filed for bankruptcy protection in June due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The Montreal-based entertainment company has not commented on the proposal.

images.alt_text: The proposal would see first-lien creditors, who were owed more than US$900 million as of March 31, wind up with virtually all of the company's equity.

site_title: New York Times to move part of Hong Kong office to Seoul
summary: The New York Times will shift part of its Hong Kong office to Seoul, South Korea, due to difficulties in securing work permits for its employees. The move affects roughly a third of the Hong Kong staff, primarily the digital team of journalists. This decision comes as Beijing's national security law has chilled the global financial centre, and China has restricted journalists working in Hong Kong from mainland China. The relocation is expected to be completed over the next year.

site_title: Resorts World Sentosa announces 'one-off' layoffs, pledges to protect 'Singaporean core'
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) has announced a "one-off" workforce rationalization, resulting in layoffs, as the coronavirus pandemic continues to impact the tourism industry. The integrated resort aims to protect its "Singaporean core" by retaining a majority of local staff, with efforts to retrain and upskill affected workers. RWS has pledged to provide fair compensation terms and has already matched at least two new job opportunities for every affected local worker. The move comes after earlier cost-cutting efforts, including a 53.1% year-on-year fall in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization.

site_title: Britain's ASOS sees sales rise 10% in lockdown period
summary: ASOS, a British online fashion retailer, reported a 10% rise in sales for the four months to June 30, driven by trading through the Covid-19 lockdown while store-based rivals shuttered shops. The company's sales were £1.01 billion, up from £919.8 million in the same period last year. International sales were up 17%, while UK sales fell 1%. ASOS forecast annual profit towards the top end of expectations, benefiting from its focus on the 20-something demographic.

site_title: Nissan bets on new Ariya electric SUV to symbolise revamp, but sales plans modest
summary: Nissan unveiled the Ariya, its first all-new global model in five years, to symbolize its road to recovery after a year of scandal and earnings losses. The electric SUV features Nissan's latest self-driving technologies and has a comparable driving range to Tesla models. However, initial sales plans are modest, with Nissan aiming to sell 30,000 units in its first full year of global sales, a target described as "underwhelming" by a source. The Ariya will begin sales in Japan in mid-2021, with production plans to ramp up to 100,000 units annually.

site_title: Singtel's Thai associate AIS says Huawei among bidders to build 5G core networks
summary: Thailand's largest mobile operator AIS says Huawei is among five companies bidding to build its 5G core networks. AIS is near the final stage of selecting vendors, with other bidders including Ericsson, Nokia, ZTE, and Samsung. The company aims to spend up to 45 billion baht on infrastructure this year and plans to build the first 5G core networks in Bangkok and Eastern Economic Corridor. AIS has partnered with Huawei to sell 5G smartphones, despite US allegations of security risks, and will include "very important clauses" to protect against possible risks.

site_title: Lazada helps Asia's malls go online after virus upends retail
summary: Thousand of retailers in Asia, including malls, have shifted online due to the coronavirus pandemic. Marina Square Shopping Mall in Singapore has partnered with Lazada to create a virtual replica of its physical mall, with over 30 tenants going online. The move aims to provide visibility and awareness for tenants and balance online and offline opportunities. This follows similar moves by other malls in Bangkok and Indonesia, as the region's e-commerce industry continues to grow. The partnership is seen as a way for retailers to adapt to the devastating changes caused by lockdowns and declining sales.

site_title: Delivery Hero open to a deal with Rappi or Glovo
summary: Delivery Hero, a food delivery company, is open to a potential deal with Rappi or Glovo, its shareholder companies. CEO Niklas Ostberg stated that the company is no longer looking to acquire others and instead prefers to invest in its own business. Discussions with Rappi, valued at $2.5 billion, have centered on a potential acquisition. This comes as the food delivery industry faces consolidation, with recent megadeals including Just Eat Takeaway.com's $7.3 billion acquisition of Grubhub and Uber's $2.65 billion purchase of Postmates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, increasing 0.08 points to 1,600.10, a 1.35% gain. The market saw 230.14 million lots traded worth RM149.57 million, with 316 gainers outpacing 71 losers.

site_title: Keppel awarded S$73m in FPSO contracts from Modec
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) secured two FPSO contracts worth approximately S$73 million from Modec Offshore Production Systems. In Singapore, Keppel Shipyard will fabricate and install modules for an FPSO vessel, set for delivery in Q2 2021. In Brazil, Keppel O&M's BrasFELS shipyard was awarded a contract to fabricate a topside module for an FPSO, with delivery scheduled for Q4 2021.

site_title: Judgement day in Apple tax case at EU court
summary: A European court will decide on Wednesday whether Apple must reimburse Ireland 13 billion euros in back taxes. The decision is part of the EU's campaign to stymie profit-shifting by multinationals and limit US big tech's power. The outcome will be open to a further appeal, with a final ruling not expected until 2021. The EU's executive arm, the European Commission, sees this decision as a key victory in its efforts to regulate multinational corporations.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street rally; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1% to 2,646.38, tracking a Wall Street rally, after a 1% drop on Tuesday. The STI ended in a recession, with Q2 GDP shrinking 41.2% on a quarter-on-quarter basis. Gainers outnumbered losers 143-14, with healthcare and financials leading the gainers. Stocks like Clearbridge, IX Biopharma, and DBS Bank advanced.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up on vaccine, stimulus hopes
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, driven by hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine and US stimulus. The news followed successful human trials for Moderna's vaccine and Pfizer's "Fast Track" designation. Reimposition of containment measures and China-US tensions limited gains. Singapore's stock market notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US.

site_title: Clifford Chance aims for 40% women among global partners by 2030
summary: International law firm Clifford Chance has set ambitious targets to increase representation of women, LGBT+ individuals, and ethnic minorities. By 2030, the firm aims for 40% of global partners to be women and 40% to be men. In the Asia-Pacific region and UK, the goal is to increase female partners by 25% by 2025 and 60% by 2030. The move follows a review of the firm's diversity and inclusion strategy, with current figures showing six women out of 27 partners in the Singapore office.

site_title: DBS, Contour complete secured letter of credit transaction on blockchain network
summary: DBS and blockchain trade-finance network Contour have completed the first digital, end-to-end secured letter of credit (LC) transaction on their network. The transaction, facilitated by DBS, connected parties across the mining value chain, with real-time tracking and a full audit trail. Contour aims to increase the accuracy of LCs and provide a neutral and open network for financial institutions and corporates. The move follows renewed questions over fraud in trade finance, with blockchain technology returning to the spotlight as a way to prevent such practices.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps policy steady, sticks to moderate recovery view
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, sticking to its view of a moderate recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The central bank left its short-term interest rate target at -0.1% and pledged to guide the 10-year government bond yield around 0% by an 8-1 vote. This decision was in line with expectations, following previous stimulus measures in March and April to calm markets and ease corporate funding strains. The BOJ expects Japan's economy to gradually improve from the latter half of this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened sharply higher on Wednesday, driven by hopes for a virus vaccine. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.61% to 25,888.78, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained. The gains offset news that US President Donald Trump had removed Hong Kong's special trade privileges as expected.

site_title: Australia: Shares chase Wall Street higher; New Zealand rises
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% to 6,012.8, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street. The S&P/ASX 200 index bounced back from a 0.6% fall on Tuesday, despite Australia tightening COVID-19 restrictions. Gold stocks led the charge on firm bullion prices. The US stock market jumped between 0.9% and 2.1% overnight, despite a record daily rise in COVID-19 deaths in three Southern US states.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS boosts Riverstone's TP on glove price surge, full order book
summary: DBS Group Research maintained its "buy" call on Malaysia-based Riverstone Holdings, raising its target price to S$3.90 from S$3.09 due to a glove price surge. Analyst Ling Lee Keng increased her earnings forecast by 46% for FY20 and 48% for FY21, driven by higher ASP and improved margins. Riverstone shares fell 2.6% to S$3.02 at 11:03am.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Biolidics, Frasers Property, Sembcorp, GuocoLand, Sri Trang Agro
summary: Key developments in Singapore stocks include Biolidics securing a 5-year licence agreement for Covid-19 serology tests, Frasers Property bringing in a strategic capital partner for Northpoint City, and GuocoLand's CFO resigning. Sembcorp and Sembmarine are facing scrutiny over their S$2.1 billion recapitalisation amid poor economic conditions. GuocoLand shares dropped 2% after the CFO's resignation, while Sri Trang Agro-Industry's share price fell 2.9% despite record highs in June.

site_title: Over 2,500 games removed from Apple's China App Store after loophole shuts: data firm
summary: Apple removed over 2,500 mobile games from its China app store in the first week of July after closing a loophole to comply with Chinese licence requirements. The games, including Hay Day, Nonstop Chuck Norris, and Solitaire, generated $34.7 million in lifetime gross revenue and 133 million downloads in China. This move follows the removal of Plague Inc. in February due to regulatory issues. The games' availability is uncertain, but it's possible they will be reinstated in the future.

images.alt_text: The games removed in the first seven days of July had generated a combined US$34.7 million in lifetime gross revenue in China.

site_title: Burger King's climate solution is a limited-supply Whopper
summary: Burger King has launched a limited-time Whopper made from cattle raised on a diet supplemented with lemongrass, expected to cut greenhouse gas emissions from those animals by about a third. The move comes as the fast-food industry grapples with its sustainability record, with Burger King aiming to make a real impact in the world. The company will openly share its cow diet formula to convince others to follow suit, but the logistics of selling low-methane beef at scale remain daunting.

site_title: Ley Choon Q4 loss narrows to S$4.1m on lower materials consumption
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings reported a net loss of S$4.1 million for its fourth quarter ended March 31, 2020, narrowing from S$5.8 million a year ago. The company attributed the decrease to lower materials consumption, resulting in a gross profit of S$0.4 million. Revenue fell 16.8% to S$23.2 million, mainly due to a decline in big diameter pipe projects and premix sales. The company resumed operations during Phase Two of Singapore's "circuit-breaker" period but expects the earlier halt to impact its current financial year performance.

site_title: Behind in the polls, Trump unloads on Biden at White House press event
summary: US President Donald Trump held a press event at the White House, criticizing Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden and his policies. Trump accused Biden of drifting to the "radical left" and claimed his own policies would "demolish" the economy. He also criticized Biden's stance on China and the energy sector. Trump attempted to shift attention to his own successes, including the border wall and his response to the pandemic. The Biden campaign countered by saying Trump's decision to veer into the campaign during an official event was an "abuse of funds."

site_title: US hails British ban on China's Huawei
summary: The US welcomed Britain's decision to ban China's Huawei from its 5G network, citing national security concerns. The move comes after months of pressure from Washington, with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo hailing it as a "growing international consensus" that Huawei poses a threat to national security. The UK's Prime Minister Boris Johnson initially resisted, but US sanctions in May led to a change of heart. This decision is seen as a victory for President Donald Trump's administration in isolating Huawei, with similar bans in several European states and companies in other countries.

site_title: US clocks up another 63,000 virus cases in 24 hours
summary: The US recorded 63,262 new COVID-19 cases and 850 deaths in the past 24 hours, bringing the total cases to over 3.42 million and the death toll to 136,432. The surge in infections has prompted some states to reverse reopening measures and make masks compulsory. The US CDC has also supported the widespread use of face masks to curb the epidemic. Meanwhile, Moderna announced the final phase of its COVID-19 vaccine clinical trials will begin on July 27.

site_title: Tesla secures tax breaks for cybertruck factory in Texas
summary: Tesla has secured tax breaks worth nearly $65 million in Travis County, Texas, to build a $1.1 billion vehicle factory for its Y sport utility vehicles and cybertrucks. The county approved an 80% rebate on property taxes for 10 years and a 65% rebate for the next 10 years. The factory is expected to create 5,000 low-skilled jobs with an average annual salary of $47,000. This decision marks a step forward for Texas in its bid to attract a new factory from Oklahoma, which has also campaigned for Tesla's presence.

site_title: Covid-19 vaccine enters final stage trial July 27: statement
summary: The US biotech firm Moderna announced on July 14, 2020, that it would enter the final stage of human trials for its Covid-19 vaccine on July 27, becoming the first company to do so. The trial will recruit 30,000 participants in the US, with half receiving a 100 microgram dose of the vaccine and the other half a placebo.

site_title: Digital will be key to Asia's SMEs survival- post-COVID-19
summary: Asia's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are struggling to survive post-COVID-19 due to limited cash reserves and reduced revenue. To adapt, SMEs must adopt a digital-first approach, prioritizing digital payments, mobile site optimization, and mobile app development. This can help increase online sales, reach new consumers, and improve revenue outcomes by understanding cultural drivers such as security and delivery times. With over half of Asia's labor force working for SMEs, embracing digital transformation is crucial for the local and regional economy's survival and growth.

images.alt_text: Cameron McLean, Senior Vice President, International Markets at PayPal

site_title: China bank IPO offers StanChart profitable exit
summary: Standard Chartered has sold its 5% stake in Bohai Bank, a Chinese lender, after the bank raised $11 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong. The sale, which was expected, comes after StanChart's CEO Bill Winters expressed hope for a decent return on the investment. The IPO marks a significant development for Bohai Bank, which has seen its loan book and net interest margins improve, with a 25% increase in its loan book and a 70% rise in net interest margins over the past year.

site_title: Australian consumers shaken as virus lockdowns return: survey
summary: Australian consumer sentiment has taken a downturn due to renewed coronavirus lockdowns in Melbourne, with the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment falling 6.1% in July from June. The index now stands at 87.9, down 8.9% from the same period last year. The lockdown has forced a sharp reversal in economic outlook, with the index measuring the economy's outlook over the next 12 months down 14%. Consumer sentiment on buying major household items has also dropped 2.1%, but housing sentiment has improved, bouncing 4.1% in July.

site_title: France will require face masks indoors as virus picks up
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron announced that face masks will be mandatory in all enclosed public spaces starting August 1, citing a rising virus reproduction rate above one, indicating the potential for increased transmission. The move comes as doctors warn of a potential second wave of infections and a need for new lockdowns. Macron also oversaw a scaled-down Bastille Day ceremony, and his government has secured a massive recovery plan worth 100 billion euros to combat the pandemic and its economic impact.

site_title: Biolidics signs five-year licence with A*Star arm; eyes development of new Covid-19 test kits
summary: Biolidics has entered into a five-year licence agreement with A*Star's commercialization arm, Accelerate Technologies, to develop new Covid-19 test kits using the agency's viral spike detection technology. The technology aims to detect Covid-19 viral spike/ACE2 blocking antibodies, which may provide an indication of protective immunity against the virus. Biolidics aims to develop new serology tests incorporating the technology, which could offer a more accurate detection method. The agreement is non-exclusive and has no material impact on Biolidics' earnings per share or net asset value.

site_title: Trump ends Hong Kong trade preferences, backs banking sanctions
summary: US President Donald Trump ended trade preferences for Hong Kong and signed the Hong Kong Autonomy Act, authorizing sanctions on banks supporting China's clampdown on the city. The move comes as Beijing enacts a national security law, curbing autonomy. Trump stated Hong Kong will no longer receive special treatment and that its freedom has been taken away. The law allows sanctions on Chinese officials, Hong Kong police, and banks involved in transactions with them.

site_title: Airbnb bookings pick up, crosses 1 million mark on a single day
summary: Airbnb reported a record 1 million bookings on July 8, surpassing the previous high since March 3. The bookings are largely for trips starting before August 7, driven by pent-up demand for affordable and closer destinations. The recovery is seen as a positive sign for the company, which had experienced a slowdown in reservations during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Biden unveils US$2t climate plan in new contrast with Trump
summary: US President Joe Biden unveiled a $2 trillion climate change plan, aiming to achieve carbon pollution-free power by 2035 and create jobs in the clean energy sector. The proposal includes spending $2 trillion over four years to promote the plan, rejoining the Paris climate agreement, and upgrading appliance standards. Biden contrasted his plan with that of President Donald Trump, criticizing his environmental policies and lack of technological vision. The plan is more ambitious than Biden's previous climate proposal, and he hopes to win over progressive voters by embracing some of the ideas of his liberal rivals.

site_title: Koon Holdings to wind up precast division
summary: Koon Holdings announced it will wind up its precast division due to operating challenges and losses. The division, which includes six companies, is facing claims from creditors and legal proceedings. This decision is part of the group's ongoing restructuring efforts. In separate news, Koon Holdings completed the disposal of its 74.06% stake in Australian energy company Tesla Holdings for approximately A$8.9 million.

site_title: Federal Reserve official warns US fiscal support remains 'vital'
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard warned that the US economy will continue to face headwinds due to the coronavirus pandemic, making continued government support "vital." The recovery is likely to be challenged by rising virus cases, which could lead to a second wave. Brainard emphasized that fiscal support will remain crucial in addressing these challenges, as the economy continues to navigate its recovery.

images.alt_text: The US economy continues to face headwinds due to the coronavirus pandemic that will make continued government support "vital," Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard said on Tuesday.

site_title: Europe needs bold green tax reform
summary: European Union leaders will meet on July 17-18 to discuss the bloc's proposed 750 billion euros recovery fund, with disagreements over grant and loan shares. To boost demand and support green and digital transitions, policymakers should consider a bold green tax reform, combined with generous compensation and cheap funding for firms and households to adjust. This would make polluting activities more costly, encourage energy conservation, and give businesses and households clarity to invest in innovation and equipment. A green tax reform, along with tax cuts and increased social benefits, could mitigate the impact on workers and households.

site_title: China says Hong Kong democracy activists trying to launch 'revolution'
summary: China has accused Hong Kong democracy activists of attempting to launch a 'revolution' as the city prepares for legislative elections. The Liaison Office, representing China's government, described recent primaries as a "serious provocation" and warned that campaigning for the elections could breach the country's new security law. The law, which was imposed last month, outlaws "subverting state power" and carries penalties of up to life in prison. Pro-democracy parties are seeking to use public anger towards Beijing's increasingly authoritarian rule to win a majority in the legislature, which could give them greater ability to stall budgets and legislation.

site_title: Europe: Tech sell-off weighs as virus fears mount; FTSE 100 outperforms
summary: European stocks fell 0.8% on Tuesday as technology shares dropped 2.6% due to US tech company declines amid fears of new coronavirus restrictions. London's FTSE 100, however, ended slightly higher, with oil stocks rising after crude prices recovered. Euro zone industry output recovered, but lower than expected, while Germany's economy outlook remains unchanged.

site_title: US rescinds order denying visas for foreign students
summary: The US government has rescinded its decision to revoke foreign student visas for online courses due to the coronavirus pandemic. A federal judge, Allison Burroughs, ordered the reversal after universities, including Harvard and MIT, took legal action against the move. The decision was seen as a pressure tactic by the Trump administration to force institutions to reopen in-person. The measure would have harmed students "immensely," both personally and financially, with over one million international students in the US for the 2018-19 academic year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, extending rallies on Wall Street on hopes of economic recovery and advances in coronavirus treatments. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.01% or 228.24 points to 22,815.25, while the Topix index gained 0.85% or 13.35 points to 1,578.50. This follows a similar trend on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, extending rallies on Wall Street on hopes of economic recovery and advances in coronavirus treatments.

site_title: UK plans recommending masks in all public places: Telegraph
summary: The UK is considering recommending face coverings in all public places, including offices, as part of a strategy to avoid a second wave of Covid-19. The plan comes after the government made masks mandatory in shops from July 24. Officials are in talks with employers to develop a "road map" for safely returning to work, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson set to outline a long-term strategy on July 15. The goal is to prevent a second spike in cases without disrupting the economy.

site_title: US: Stocks end up on hopes for more federal stimulus, Dow +2.1%
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 2.1% to 26,642.59, driven by hopes for more federal stimulus spending from Washington. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained, with the S&P 500 rising 1.3% and the Nasdaq advancing 0.9%. The gains came despite mixed results from large banks, with investors focusing on potential stimulus measures to boost the economy.

site_title: Frasers Property brings in capital partner for Northpoint City (South Wing)
summary: FRASER PROPERTY has secured a strategic capital partner, TCC Prosperity, for Northpoint City (South Wing) through its subsidiary Bright Bloom Capital, which subscribed for 50% of North Gem Trust (NGT) units. The deal values the property at S$1.1 billion, allowing Frasers Property to recognize a gain of S$50 million. The transaction also involves TCCP extending a loan of S$174.5 million to pay off half the total amount owed by NGT.

images.alt_text: The transaction values Northpoint City (South Wing) at S$1.1 billion and allows the group to recognise a gain of S$50 million over the asset's last audited book value as at Sept 30, 2019.

site_title: DBS's weak Q2 showing may be cycle's bottom for bank: Citi
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, is expected to report a "cycle-low" return on equity (ROE) of 7.5% in Q2, according to Citi Research, citing a weak earnings report due to the COVID-19 health crisis. Citi projects DBS's Q2 net profit to fall 37% year-on-year to S$1 billion, with a 21-basis-point decline in net interest margin to 1.65%. The bank's wealth management fees and credit card fees are expected to be hit by lockdown measures, but flat costs and treasury flows may mitigate the impact. DBS's Q2 results are due on August 6.

site_title: Geopolitics kindles interest in Indian technology market
summary: Google is investing $10 billion in India over 5-7 years, following other tech giants like Apple's $1 billion investment in Foxconn's India factory and Jio Platform's $16 billion in equity investments. The investments come as India is struggling with the Covid-19 pandemic and economic crisis, but are driven by strategic and tactical reasons, including India's long-term potential and its positioning as an electronics manufacturing alternative to China.

site_title: Lab test error led to wrong Covid-19 diagnosis: TTSH
summary: A human error in a laboratory at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) led to a false diagnosis of a Secondary 1 student as having Covid-19. The student was reported to have tested positive after being in contact with a schoolmate who was previously infected. However, investigations revealed that the student was actually negative, and the laboratory mislabelled the sample of another patient. The student has been discharged, and the mislabelling incident has been apologized for. The hospital has also put in place additional checks to prevent such incidents in the future.

site_title: Massachusetts sues Uber, Lyft over status of drivers
summary: Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey filed a lawsuit against Uber and Lyft, alleging the ride-hailing companies misclassified drivers as independent contractors, denying them benefits. The state claims drivers should be treated as employees, eligible for benefits like sick leave and paid time off. This is the second state to challenge Uber and Lyft's classification, following California. The lawsuit could impact the companies' business model and force them to reclassify drivers as employees.

site_title: US banks set aside billions as buffer against bad loans
summary: US banks, including JPMorgan, Citigroup, and Wells Fargo, have set aside an additional $23 billion as a buffer against bad loans amid the coronavirus pandemic, citing the brittle state of the US economy. The measures come as businesses reopen and consumer spending declines in states with bad Covid-19 trends. The banks expect a more "protracted" economic recovery and have raised their reserve levels to address deteriorating loan quality. The reserve increases led to steep drops in profits, with Wells Fargo reporting a loss of $2.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo chief executive Charlie Scharf said the bank is "extremely disappointed" in the decision, but "our view of the length and severity of the economic downturn has deteriorated considerably from the assumptions used last quarter."

site_title: Spotify expands to Russia and Eastern Europe
summary: Spotify has expanded its music streaming service to Russia and 12 other Eastern European countries, including Albania, Belarus, and Ukraine. The move brings the total number of markets available to Spotify users to 92. The service is now accessible in countries such as Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Kazakhstan, Kosovo, Moldova, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia, and Slovenia.

site_title: STI drifts lower on the heels of estimates showing dive in Q2 GDP
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.41% to 2,620.19, following an overnight dip in US technology heavyweights. Singapore's Q2 GDP shrank 41.2% on a quarter-on-quarter basis, dampening regional markets. Only four STI component stocks closed higher, led by Singtel, which rose 0.8%. Smaller cap stocks Hyphens Pharma and iX Biopharma surged, with Hyphens gaining 50% and iX Biopharma rising 26%.

site_title: Oil rises slightly as Opec+ complies with production cuts
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Tuesday as Opec+ complied with production cuts, with Brent crude futures settling up 18 cents at $42.90 a barrel and US WTI crude futures rising 19 cents to $40.29 a barrel. The market is watching for additional weekly data, with analysts estimating US petrol stockpiles fell by 600,000 barrels and crude oil inventories by 2.1 million barrels last week. Opec+ has delivered 107% compliance with its agreed oil output cuts in June, and is set to taper its record production cut to 7.7 million barrels per day from August through December.

site_title: Turkish house sales surge in June, rebounding with cheap loans
summary: Turkish house sales surged 210% year-on-year in June, reaching 190,012 properties, the highest monthly level since December. The rebound was fueled by cheap loans and interest rate cuts, as the economy recovered from the pandemic. Mortgaged house sales nearly tripled to a record 101,504, making up over half of total sales. The first half of the year saw a 23.5% increase in house sales, while sales to foreigners dropped 38.1% to 1,664.
