images.alt_text: Robinhood's funding round is widely being seen as a precursor to an initial public offering, according to analysts tracking the company.

site_title: UK to make face masks mandatory in shops
summary: The UK government plans to make face masks mandatory in shops and supermarkets in England starting July 24. This follows the existing rule of wearing masks on public transport since June 15. Those who fail to wear a mask could face a fine of up to £100. The move aims to protect individuals and those around them from coronavirus, which has claimed nearly 45,000 deaths in Britain.

site_title: Bruised by the pandemic, New Yorkers head for the suburbs
summary: New Yorkers are fleeing the city in record numbers, driven by the trauma of the coronavirus pandemic, which has pushed real estate prices to the roof in surrounding areas. Many residents, like Nick Barnhorst, who had been a New York resident for 11 years, are leaving due to the pandemic's impact on their daily lives. The suburban real estate market is experiencing a surge, with houses selling for 20% over asking price in sought-after towns like Montclair, New Jersey. Experts predict a six-month to one-year shortage of supply, but some believe the exodus could lure a younger generation back to the city when prices drop.

site_title: SoftBank said to explore sale or IPO of chip company Arm
summary: SoftBank is exploring options to sell or go public with its stake in chip company Arm Holdings, either through a private deal or an initial public offering (IPO) as soon as next year. The company's founder, Masayoshi Son, initially set a 2023 timeline for an Arm IPO, but the improving market for semiconductor companies may accelerate the timeline. Goldman Sachs is advising on a potential deal, and Arm would need time to prepare for a listing, with Marcelo Claure stating he doesn't expect Arm to go public within the next 12 months.

site_title: HP Enterprise to buy Silver Peak for about US$925m
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) announced a $925 million cash acquisition of California-based Silver Peak, a developer of WAN enhancement tools. The deal combines Silver Peak with HPE's Aruba business unit to strengthen its software-defined wide-area network (SD-WAN) capabilities. This move aims to capitalize on increasing demand for SD-WAN services, driven by the shift to remote work due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The acquisition will enhance HPE's capabilities in the SD-WAN market, bolstering its position in the industry.

site_title: Delta may avoid furloughs after demand for buyouts, other US airlines sound alarm
summary: Delta Air Lines may avoid involuntary furloughs this fall after receiving interest from over 15,000 employees for early buyout packages. The airline is trying to encourage workers to leave voluntarily before a government ban on forced job cuts expires on September 30. Other US airlines are sounding the alarm on jobs, but Delta's efforts may help it avoid furloughs. The airline's deadline for accepting early departure or early retirement packages has passed, with many employees opting for the buyout.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall as economy slumps into recession; STI opens 0.5% lower
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 13.18 points to 2,617.90, as the country's economy slipped into recession with a 12.6% year-on-year decline in the second quarter. The downturn comes after a surprise general election outcome that saw the ruling People's Action Party secure a smaller margin of victory. Banking stocks, including DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank, were also in the red, while Top Glove bucked the trend with a 1.4% gain.

site_title: Second virus wave in UK could see 120,000 deaths: study
summary: A UK study predicts a second coronavirus wave this winter could result in up to 120,000 deaths in hospitals, with 74,800 deaths possible with a lower R rate. The Academy of Medical Sciences report urges immediate action to mitigate a second wave, warning of a "serious risk" to health due to people spending more time indoors. The government is advised to intensify preparation, including minimizing community transmission, scaling up the test, trace, and isolate program, and ensuring protective equipment for frontline staff.

site_title: Pompeo says Beijing claims in South China Sea 'unlawful'
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated that Beijing's claims to offshore resources in the South China Sea are "completely unlawful" and part of a "campaign of bullying." This move increases pressure on China, as the US treats Beijing's actions as illegitimate. The statement follows a surge in tensions over the region's disputed waters, with the US seeking to assert its influence and protect its interests.

site_title: Singapore in recession with GDP down 12.6% in Q2, flash figures show
summary: Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) plummeted 12.6% year-on-year in the second quarter, entering a full-blown recession, according to Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) advance estimates. This surpasses economists' expectations and is worse than the first quarter's 0.3% contraction. The manufacturing sector saw a 2.5% year-on-year growth, while services and construction sectors shrank 13.6% and 54.7% respectively due to "circuit-breaker" measures and global travel restrictions.

site_title: Nearly 60,000 new virus cases in US in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US reported 59,222 new coronavirus cases and 411 deaths in the past 24 hours, bringing the total number of cases to over 3.36 million and the death toll to 135,582. This surge has prompted some states, particularly in the Sun Belt, to reimpose restrictions or tighten measures. California, for example, ordered the closure of indoor restaurants and other businesses to slow the spread.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on fresh virus worries
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday due to fresh worries over the coronavirus and renewed US-China tensions. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.58% and the Topix index slipped 0.40%. The declines follow a weaker performance on Wall Street.

site_title: US deficit soars to record amid pandemic relief payments
summary: The US deficit surged to a record $864 billion in June 2020, driven by massive government rescue payments amid the COVID-19 pandemic. This surpasses the previous record of $234 billion set in 2009. The increase was largely due to the Small Business Administration's Paycheck Protection Programme, with weekly payments of $600 totaling $171 billion. The Treasury Department expects further cash expenditures on loan forgiveness under the programme in subsequent months.

site_title: MYP's FY20 loss widens to S$2.1m on revaluation losses
summary: MYP, a Mainboard-listed property investment firm, reported a widened net loss of S$2.1 million for FY20, primarily due to revaluation losses of S$1.5 million. Revenue rose 2.5% to S$23.3 million, driven by improved occupancy rates. The group maintained a loss per share of 0.13 Singapore cents, unchanged from the previous year. No dividend was declared for the full year, and MYP is closely monitoring external factors impacting its performance, including the softening office rental market and bank interest rate fluctuations.

site_title: More constructive engagement across political divide will benefit Singapore
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) won the general election, but with a reduced majority. Despite the PAP's overall satisfaction with the outcome, concerns about jobs and foreign labor remain. The WP secured 10 seats, and Pritam Singh will become the Leader of the Opposition. The PAP and WP need to cooperate to address national issues, with mutual trust essential for constructive engagement. The government will focus on economic recovery, while the WP must work with the PAP to shape legislation and address party interests.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH, ST Engineering, SIAEC, Medtecs, UG Healthcare, Axington
summary: Singapore stocks are affected by the coronavirus pandemic. Media and property group Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) expects lower operating profit due to the pandemic, with shares closing 1.6% lower at S$1.26. Aerospace companies SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) and Singapore Technologies Engineering (ST Engineering) implemented cost-cutting measures, with SIAEC falling 1.6% to S$1.98 and ST Engineering losing 2.4% to S$3.27.

site_title: China imposes sanctions against four US officials in tit-for-tat move
summary: China has imposed sanctions against four US officials, including Senators Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz, in retaliation for US moves to punish Beijing for its treatment of ethnic minorities in Xinjiang. The sanctions, which will begin on Monday, are largely symbolic and aimed at keeping disputes between the two nations from escalating. The US had previously sanctioned a top Chinese official and three others over alleged human rights abuses in Xinjiang. China disputes the claim, saying it's seeking to prevent extremism, and has vowed to take further reactions based on the situation.

site_title: California again shuts indoor restaurants, bars, movie theaters over virus
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom has ordered the closure of all indoor restaurants, bars, and movie theaters due to a surge in coronavirus cases, with 30 of the state's worst-hit counties affected. The decision comes as hospitalizations rise and the positivity rate for tested individuals has increased by over 20% in two weeks. Schools in Los Angeles and San Diego will remain closed when classes resume next month, with lessons moving online to prioritize health and safety. California has reported nearly 330,000 coronavirus cases and over 7,000 deaths.

site_title: Global coronavirus infections top 13 million: AFP tally
summary: The global coronavirus infection tally has surpassed 13 million, with over half of cases in the US and Latin America. The US has recorded 3,341,838 cases and 135,425 deaths, while Latin America has seen 3,380,218 cases and 144,847 fatalities. Europe has 2,849,335 infections and 202,780 deaths. The spread of the pandemic is accelerating, with over 2.6 million new cases detected since July 1.

images.alt_text: More than 13 million coronavirus infections have now been recorded across the world, with more than half in the United States and Latin America, according to an AFP tally of official sources at 2000 GMT on Monday.

site_title: Huawei sales recover from coronavirus slump
summary: Huawei reported double-digit revenue growth for the first half of 2020, with 454 billion yuan (S$90.2 billion) in revenue, a 13.1% year-on-year increase. This recovery comes after a sales slump in the first quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic and US-led efforts to contain the company's involvement in foreign telecom networks. Despite the growth, Huawei's sales remain below last year's levels. The company attributed its recovery to the use of information and communications technologies as a tool for combating the pandemic and an engine for economic recovery.

site_title: China's fresh meat lovers lament death of live poultry markets
summary: China will close all live poultry markets to reduce public health risks amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The move follows years of temporary closures due to bird flu outbreaks, with some cities already restricting live animal sales in containment rooms. Consumers will need to buy chilled or frozen chicken instead, and thoroughly cook the meat. The policy change may affect small businesses like Ms. Wang, a poultry dealer, who fears her business could halve if the birds are processed only at centralized slaughterhouses.

site_title: UK construction looks to cement recovery from virus woes
summary: The UK construction sector has rebounded from the COVID-19 lockdown, with the purchasing managers' index (PMI) soaring to 55.3 in June from 28.9 in May. Activity had slowed significantly during the lockdown, with many sites shutting down, but restrictions are now being lifted, and construction is picking up speed. The sector's resilience was attributed to self-employed workers needing to earn cash, and the government's jobs retention scheme played a role in keeping staff employed. With the sector showing signs of recovery, the UK government is calling for investment in infrastructure to drive growth.

site_title: US: Nasdaq falls on weak day for stocks amid Covid-19 closures
summary: US stocks fell on Monday as California imposed fresh coronavirus restrictions, leading to a 2.1% decline in the Nasdaq Composite Index. The tech-heavy index had surged to record highs in recent weeks, but retreated after news of the restrictions and a massive US deficit due to pandemic spending. Other markets were also affected, including oil prices and Ubisoft shares, which fell after the company's internal investigation into sexual harassment allegations.

images.alt_text: A rally on Wall Street fizzled on Monday following more signs of coronavirus troubles in the United States after European equities were boosted by progress towards a vaccine.

site_title: Britain set to ban Huawei from 5G
summary: Britain is set to ban Huawei from its 5G network, a move expected to anger Beijing but win approval from US President Donald Trump. The decision, made by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, comes amid concerns over national security and the impact of new US sanctions on chip technology. The ban is seen as a response to the US's push to exclude Huawei, with the UK citing the need to protect critical infrastructure from "hostile state vendors". The exact details of the ban are still unclear, but operators are discussing a reduction in Huawei's role from 35% to 0% over the next two to four years.

site_title: Europe: Stocks gain on vaccine, stimulus hopes; earnings eyed
summary: European stocks rose 1% on Monday, driven by optimism over a possible Covid-19 vaccine, upbeat earnings reports, and stimulus hopes. The Stoxx index gained 1.7% on miner stocks, while travel & leisure, banks, technology, and oil & gas sectors rose between 1.9% and 1.4%. Two experimental vaccines by BioNTech and Pfizer received the US FDA's "fast track" designation, boosting confidence in an economic recovery. Earnings season kicks off this week, with European leaders meeting on July 17-18 to discuss the US$750 billion euro recovery fund.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The High Court of Malaya granted Hatten Land subsidiary MDSA Ventures a three-month debt moratorium and leave to call for creditors' meetings, aiming to restructure debt. Qian Hu Corporation expects a net loss for H1 2020 due to Covid-19 disruptions affecting its exports. Pison Investments has made a formal cash offer to Hyflux's creditors to complete debt restructuring.

site_title: Kids flourish with help from two funds
summary: The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund (STSPMF) and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BTBAF) have been helping thousands of socially-disadvantaged children in Singapore since 2019. The funds provide assistance for basic school needs and artistic pursuits, respectively, with over 170,000 children benefiting from the programs. Parents report improved academic performance and increased confidence among their children, with some attributing these positive outcomes to the arts. The funds aim to unlock children's full potential and provide them with better opportunities in life.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit dips toes into data centres; sponsor, EXS set up new fund
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has partnered with Stratus Data Centres and EXS Capital to invest in two European data centre projects, one in London and the other in Frankfurt. The projects will have a combined capacity of 400MW and are expected to be completed in 2021. The partnership aims to provide stable income and strong potential upside for investors, leveraging Cromwell E-Reit's existing portfolio and Stratus's data-centre sector specialisation. The fund is targeting a gross asset value of over US$1 billion.

site_title: Southwest warns of layoffs unless passenger traffic triples
summary: Southwest Airlines warned employees it may resort to layoffs or furloughs unless passenger traffic triples by the end of the year. The airline, which received a $2.2 trillion government loan, is facing significant losses due to the COVID-19 pandemic. CEO Gary Kelly stated that the airline is overstaffed and needs a significant recovery to cut costs. Southwest employed 60,000 people in 2019 and is offering incentives for voluntary departures. The airline must keep workers on the payroll through September under the CARES Act.

site_title: Medtecs and UG Healthcare shares sink, prompting SGX queries
summary: Shares of Medtecs International Corporation and UG Healthcare in Singapore plummeted, prompting SGX queries over "unusual price movements". Biolidics, a healthcare peer, halted trading after a 26.8% surge. The sudden price changes were attributed to unusual market activity, with Medtecs and UG Healthcare dropping 3.9% and 5.9% respectively. The Singapore Exchange is investigating the unusual trading activity.

site_title: Oil drops on signs Opec+ may start to taper production cuts
summary: Oil prices dropped to near $40 a barrel ahead of an Opec+ meeting, where the group may announce plans to taper historic production cuts amid rising coronavirus cases worldwide. The producer bloc will review market conditions on Wednesday, with expectations of unwinding output curbs. Oil futures fell 2.4% on Friday, despite the potential cuts, amid bearish market sentiment due to US President Trump's tariff outlook.

site_title: Muhyiddin's slim victory in House vote underscores his weak position
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's narrow victory in a parliamentary vote to replace the Speaker of the House, with 111 MPs in favor and 109 against, underscores his weak position. The vote confirms the country's uncertain political situation, with the opposition coalition planning to seek a no-confidence vote against him. Analysts say Muhyiddin's administration is not stable, and he may consider snap elections if he cannot shore up his majority before crucial policy changes, including the 2021 budget and the Temporary Measures Bill to counter the pandemic.

site_title: Christie's online sale fetches US$421m despite virus pandemic
summary: Christie's hosted a hybrid online auction, "ONE", which fetched a total of US$421 million, defying the coronavirus pandemic. The sale featured 20 works, including Roy Lichtenstein's "Nude with Joyous Painting", which sold for US$46.2 million. The event saw 94% of works find buyers, with records broken for American abstract painter Brice Marden. The unique format demonstrated the art market's adaptability, with over 20,000 art enthusiasts following the four-hour sale online.

site_title: SPH expects 'significantly lower' operating profit for FY20
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) expects a significantly lower operating profit for FY20 due to the ongoing pandemic, with a decline in print advertisement revenue and digital advertisement revenue. Despite this, the company's "resilient" balance sheet and cash balances of S$810 million will ensure sufficient liquidity across its business segments. Circulation rose 9.5% led by digital circulation, but overall revenue fell due to the pandemic.

site_title: Oil slips on surge in Covid-19 infections, US-China tension
summary: Oil prices slipped 1% on Monday as global coronavirus cases rose by a record daily amount, fueling fears of renewed government lockdowns and US-China tension. The World Health Organization reported over 230,000 new cases, with the US and Latin America seeing significant growth. California's governor imposed new restrictions, and US and European tensions with China continued, including China's sanctions against the US. Oil prices fell to $42.72 a barrel for Brent futures and $40.10 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude.

site_title: First step towards solving the mystery origins of Covid-19
summary: A two-person team from the World Health Organization (WHO) arrived in China to investigate the origins of the coronavirus, which has infected almost 13 million people and killed over half a million. Despite China's initial opposition, the country now supports the resolution after a May meeting of the WHO's decision-making body. The investigation aims to determine the animal origins of the virus, believed to have come from bats, but it remains unclear what China's attitude is towards the effort.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss for H2, and London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with MAS and PBOC planning to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Singapore Paincare Holdings offering 24.25m placement shares at S$0.22 each
summary: Singapore Paincare Holdings is offering 24.25 million shares at S$0.22 each to raise S$3.54m, valuing the company at S$35.6m. The IPO aims to provide more relief options, including minimally invasive procedures, for chronic pain sufferers. The funds will be used to grow services in Singapore before expanding overseas. Founded by Bernard Lee, a pioneer interventional pain specialist, the company seeks to provide more relief options to those suffering from chronic pain.

images.alt_text: Singapore Paincare Holdings CEO Bernard Lee says the group aims to be the "disruptive force" in pain care management.

site_title: How you can help to donate to ChildAid
summary: CHILDAID 2020: Virtually Yours concert premieres on July 15, offering a 360-degree virtual experience to raise funds for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits School Pocket Money Fund. The concert can be viewed on various platforms, including YouTube and Facebook. Donations are also welcome to support these charities.

site_title: Virus outbreak boosts digital payments in India where cash ban failed
summary: India's virus outbreak has led to a surge in digital payments, with the value of transactions on the Unified Payments Interface reaching an all-time high in June. The pandemic has made people wary of close personal interactions, driving a consumer-led move towards digital payments. While India still has a long way to go in shedding its traditional attachment to cash, the country's digital payments per capita have grown over five times since 2015, and the government aims for a billion digital transactions per day. Global tech giants are betting on India's digital payments market, which is forecast to quintuple to $1 trillion by 2023.

site_title: A convincing vote
summary: Singapore sets up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, while graduates are advised to stay calm with better employment rates shown in early data. Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Khong will visit the US for trade talks, and a new grant of up to SGD 100,000 is available for tariff-hit businesses. The country also has the opportunity to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging, according to a study. Additionally, workers are urged to future-proof their careers before a crisis strikes, with support from the Workforce Singapore and Singapore Business Federation.

site_title: Property bellwethers CDL, Ascott sound warning on H1 2020 profit hit
summary: Singapore property bellwethers City Developments Limited (CDL) and Ascott Residence Trust (ART) warned of dour performance in their first-half 2020 results due to the Covid-19 pandemic. CDL expects a "substantial" decline in pre-tax profit from its hotel operations segment, with revenue per available room declining 50-60%. ART's distribution per stapled security is expected to fall 65%, and its available income for distribution is expected to be reduced 55-65%. Both companies have sufficient liquidity to weather the crisis, with CDL's total cash exceeding S$5 billion.

site_title: Germany's Merkel could help secure EU breakthrough
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel is convening the first face-to-face EU summit since the coronavirus crisis, aiming to secure a European recovery fund and a new EU long-term budget. Merkel, who is stepping down as EU president in December, views this as a legacy-building moment and a chance to cap off her remarkable era in office. The summit is crucial, as the European Central Bank forecasts a 15% contraction of GDP in the single currency area, and the EU-27 must work together to address the economic challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: GE results could tilt some policies further left: Citi
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) secured 61.24% of the votes in the recent general election, a decline from 69.9% in 2015. Analysts predict that this shift may lead to policies tilting further left, including a review of foreign worker policies, potentially impacting the property sector and stock market. Citi notes that this could result in lower property demand and a softer balance between supply and demand. However, analysts remain positive on Singapore developers, citing low rates, ample liquidity, and undemanding valuations, and expect policy continuity to support the stock market.

site_title: Google to spend US$10b in digital push in India
summary: Google plans to invest $10 billion over 5-7 years to boost digital adoption in India, driven by the COVID-19 pandemic. CEO Sundar Pichai emphasized the country's digital economy potential. The investments will focus on areas such as digital literacy, digital payments, and online education. This move aims to make technology accessible to all Indians, reflecting Pichai's personal connection to the country.

site_title: ZenRock interim JMs flag doubtful trades, invoices, cash transactions
summary: Interim judicial managers of ZenRock Commodities Trading have uncovered hundreds of "questionable" transactions, including duplicate sales invoices and unusual cash transactions, following a scrutiny into the trader's affairs. The transactions involved HSBC, the firm's largest lender, with liabilities totaling US$175.3 million. The court-appointed managers have raised concerns over ZenRock's dealings with entities HuiTongRong and Shenzhen Qianhai, and have noted a significant reduction in account receivables from US$1.6 billion to US$136 million in a single day. The managers believe ZenRock is unlikely to continue in its core businesses and plan to file for the JM order to be discharged and for ZenRock to be liquidated.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn to invest US$1 billion to expand India factory
summary: Foxconn, Apple's Taiwanese contract manufacturer, plans to invest up to $1 billion to expand its factory in southern India, where it assembles iPhones. The move is part of Apple's shift away from China due to trade war disruptions and the coronavirus crisis. Foxconn will add 6,000 jobs at the Sriperumbur plant in Tamil Nadu state, and some iPhone models will be made there, while others will be produced in a separate plant in Andhra Pradesh. The investment is expected to help Apple save on import taxes and boost its local presence in India, aligning with the country's "Make In India" drive.

site_title: OCBC launches first SORA-based home loan
summary: OCBC has launched Singapore's first SORA-based home loan, available to buyers of completed private properties with a minimum loan size of S$1 million. The interest rate is calculated based on the simple average of the daily SORA rates over the past 90 calendar days, offering greater stability and transparency compared to traditional floating rates. The loan has a one-year lock-in period and allows for pre-payments of up to 50% without penalty fees. This move is part of the industry's shift towards adopting SORA as the new interest rate benchmark for the SGD cash and derivatives market.

site_title: The major factor behind Asia's more effective handling of diseases
summary: Asian countries' more effective handling of diseases, particularly in controlling the Covid-19 pandemic, can be attributed to evolutionary factors. Studies suggest that Asians have inherited "cautious" genes that manifest in personality traits such as lower extraversion, openness to new experiences, and restricted sociosexuality, making them less susceptible to contracting pathogens. Additionally, Asian societies tend to be more collectivistic, law-abiding, and conformist, which are linked to lower Covid-19 death rates. These cultural and behavioral traits have evolved over thousands of years, allowing Asian countries to better prevent and contain contagious diseases.

site_title: MacPherson Road building for sale with S$21m guide price
summary: A 7-storey light industrial building at 463 MacPherson Road in Singapore is up for sale via private treaty with a guide price of S$21 million. The property has a remaining lease of around 44 years and a total gross floor area of 38,287 sq ft. The sale is being handled by Savills Singapore.

site_title: Island mansion with views of Golden Gate Bridge on sale for US$29.5m
summary: A luxurious island mansion on Belvedere Island, off the coast of the Tiburon Peninsula, is on sale for $29.5 million. The 7,500 sq ft, 5-bedroom home was built by renowned architects Joshua Aidlin and Blasen Landscape Architecture, with a 5-year construction process due to strict building codes. The property boasts stunning 280-degree views of the Golden Gate Bridge, San Francisco, and Mount Tamalpais, as well as an infinity pool and hot tub. Todd Chaffee, a venture capitalist, is selling the property after five years, citing family reasons, and plans to build another home in Tahoe.

site_title: Four in 10 Singapore investors eyeing sustainable investments: StanChart
summary: About 4 in 10 Singapore investors, including 42% of affluent and high-net-worth individuals, plan to invest 5-15% of their funds in sustainable investments over the next three years. The top barriers to investing include lack of motivation, knowledge, and advice. Despite apprehension, affluent and high-net-worth investors in Singapore show the highest interest in sustainable investments, with 90% of them indicating they are interested in ESG funds.

site_title: Poor disclosure not only hurts shareholders, but can cost companies too
summary: AGV Group, a Singapore-listed hot-dip galvanising services provider, failed to disclose key information in its July 1 regulatory filing, leading to a 29.5% drop in its share price over the following days. The company initially withheld the identity of a director who had given a police statement, despite being asked by the Singapore Exchange. The director, Albert Ang, was also the company's former CEO. AGV's delayed disclosure and lack of transparency have raised concerns about the company's compliance with disclosure obligations and its ability to manage stakeholder expectations.

site_title: Reopening cinemas offer blockbusters - and a pivot to digital
summary: Singapore cinemas reopened on Monday after a 109-day hiatus, with regulations including social distancing, mandatory face masks, and limited capacity. Golden Village and Shaw Theatres have introduced cleaning and disinfection measures, including an AI robot, to ensure a safe environment. Blockbuster movies such as "Train To Busan: Peninsula" and "Tenet" are set to hit screens, with re-releases of older favorites. Operators expect cautious returns, but anticipate an increase in patronage as confidence grows and more movies are released.

site_title: Huawei reports 13.1% sales rise in H1
summary: Huawei reported a 13.1% year-on-year sales rise in the first half of 2020, emerging from a sales slump at the start of the year. The company also reported a 9.2% net profit margin, citing communications technologies as a tool for combating the coronavirus and driving economic recovery. As the world's top supplier of telecom networking equipment and number-two smartphone maker, Huawei's sales rise suggests a recovery in the tech industry.

site_title: STI bucks regional gains to slip 0.81% in first post-GE session
summary: SINGAPORE stocks slipped 0.81% in the first post-general election session, closing at 2,631.08, down 21.57 points. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) was impacted by City Developments' warning of lower pre-tax profit and declines in ThaiBev, SATS, and ST Engineering. However, analysts expect the impact to be temporary, citing policy continuity. Big price movers included Oceanus Group, which rose 33.3%, and Willas-Array Electronics, which increased 65.2%.

site_title: Over 500,000 HK residents turn out to pick Legco candidates
summary: Over 500,000 Hong Kong residents defied government warnings to participate in an unofficial primary, casting ballots for opposition candidates competing in Legislative Council elections on September 6. The turnout, exceeding 13% of registered voters, signals continued resistance to Beijing's national security law. Despite government warnings of illegality, the event's organizers argue it did not violate the law, and the high turnout may backfire on Beijing's efforts to suppress pro-democracy candidates.

site_title: Over 1,000 singers for ChildAid 2020
summary: The ChildAid 2020 virtual concert, organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times, features two virtual choirs with over 1,150 musicians from 25 countries, including the US, China, and Japan. Led by maestro Kahchun Wong, the concert performs Beethoven's Ode To Joy, marking the composer's 250th birth anniversary, and raises funds for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. The concert, which debuted online on July 13, 2020, showcases cutting-edge technology, allowing viewers to watch and listen in a 360-degree sphere.

site_title: Aerospace firms rechart flight path as pandemic grounds carriers
summary: Aerospace companies in Singapore are repositioning themselves for recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic by upskilling employees, pursuing digitalization, and reducing costs. With international air travel grounded, the industry is expected to experience further consolidation. Companies are also exploring new opportunities, such as reining in costs and reducing headcount, as they navigate the long road to recovery.

site_title: Coronavirus crisis may get 'worse and worse and worse', warns WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that the coronavirus pandemic may worsen if nations do not adhere to basic healthcare precautions. Director General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stated that if "basics are not followed," the pandemic will continue to spread. The global infection count surpassed 13 million, with over half a million deaths, and is expected to rise further. The WHO emphasizes the need for adherence to basic precautions to prevent the pandemic from getting worse.

site_title: B2B digital platforms open new markets for local SMEs
summary: B2B digital platforms are opening new markets for local small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), enabling them to survive the downturn amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Online platforms with local, regional, and global reach are capturing new opportunities, allowing SMEs to diversify their supplier base and support business continuity. This shift has been accelerated by the pandemic, with B2B buyers looking to reduce dependence on traditional methods and secure new suppliers. Digitalisation is crucial for SMEs to operate and thrive in the changing business landscape.

site_title: The digital revolution against trade fraud
summary: A global digital trade ecosystem built on blockchain technology is needed to address gaps in the current international trade ecosystem, which has enabled massive corporate scandals. Singapore's Minister of Trade and Industry has signed a trilateral Digital Economy Partnership Agreement with New Zealand and Chile to guide multilateral cooperation on emerging technologies and digital trade issues. The agreement aims to enable seamless, end-to-end digital trade, secure cross-border data flows, and promote consumer trust. A blockchain-based system can record transactions, establish the validity of transactions, and prevent forgery, revolutionizing the way international trade functions.

site_title: Dollar declines as investors gauge economic data, earnings
summary: The US dollar declined on Monday as investors awaited economic data and corporate earnings to gauge the economic outlook. The dollar had ended its third week of losses, with a 0.2% drop in the midday London currency index to 96.481. Investors are optimistic about the recovery from the pandemic, supporting risk-sensitive currencies like the euro and Australian dollar. The dollar's decline is expected to continue, with some analysts predicting a euro/dollar exchange rate of US$1.15 in three months.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's GE2020 result may not impact the market due to ongoing policy support. Analysts expect continued economic stimulus to drive the market. Meanwhile, ZenRock Commodities Trading's IJMs uncovered hundreds of "questionable" transactions. The MAS-led Project Ubin is on path towards commercial adoption, and SIA has increased flight frequencies. OCBC launched Singapore's first SORA-based home loan, while nearly four in 10 investors consider sustainable investments. The STI slipped 0.81% after the surprise General Election outcome.

images.alt_text: Policy support to ease stresses on businesses caused by Covid-19 will continue to drive the Singapore market, even as the fall in vote share held by Singapore's ruling party after Friday's General Election (GE) could spur some shift in policy over the longer term, analysts said.

site_title: Greenwich mansion owned by shoe mogul to go under the hammer
summary: A 16,300-square-foot Greenwich, Connecticut mansion once owned by late shoe designer Vince Camuto is set to be auctioned off due to its prolonged listing since 2017. The estate features a tennis court, pool, and 4.6 acres of land, capitalizing on the current pandemic-driven demand for luxury suburban homes.

site_title: China renews push for increased global role for the yuan
summary: China is renewing its push to increase the global use of the yuan, amid rising tensions with the US. The move comes as Beijing faces restricted access to US dollars and seeks alternative currencies. Government officials and market watchers have urged greater efforts to promote the yuan, following China's new Hong Kong security law. The push is seen as a strategic move to counter US influence and maintain China's economic influence. China's central bank has also proposed a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus package to counter US tariffs.

images.alt_text: The yuan's share in global payments and central bank reserves remains low, at about 2 per cent.

site_title: Global coronavirus cases rise above 13m, US infections surge
summary: Global coronavirus cases surpassed 13 million, with the US accounting for more than 3.3 million confirmed cases. Latin America is seeing the fastest acceleration in cases, while some countries, like Australia and England, are implementing second lockdowns. The US reported a record 69,070 new infections on July 10, with Florida reporting a record increase of over 15,000 cases in 24 hours. The pandemic has killed over 568,500 people worldwide, with case numbers triple that of severe influenza illnesses annually.

site_title: World's busiest airport prepares for touchless post-Covid travel
summary: The world's busiest airport, Dallas-Forth Worth International Airport (DFW), is preparing for touchless travel post-Covid by leveraging technology. The airport's CEO, Sean Donohue, believes that self-service will be key to reassuring pandemic-wary passengers. DFW aims to implement touchless features, including digital check-in and contactless payment systems, to make travel more convenient and safe. This move reflects the industry's focus on adapting to the 'new normal' of travel post-pandemic, with airlines and airports prioritizing cost-cutting and technology investments.

site_title: With GE over, time for all to set aside differences and close ranks
summary: Singapore's General Election (GE) has concluded with the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) securing 83 out of 93 seats, maintaining a nearly 90% majority in the House. The PAP's popular vote share decreased to 61.24% from 70.33% in 2015. With the COVID-19 pandemic still prevalent, the new government will focus on controlling infection rates and supporting the economy, which is expected to enter a technical recession. The government will also need to address job losses and unemployment, with economists predicting a 11.3% year-on-year GDP contraction in the second quarter.

site_title: MAS-led payments network on path towards commercial adoption of blockchain technology
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Temasek have released a report highlighting the commercial potential of Project Ubin, a blockchain-based payments network. The project, which concluded its fifth phase, has successfully settled payments in different currencies on the same network. The report found that integrating blockchain technology with the payments network prototype could enable faster and cheaper transactions, and has validated the use of smart contracts in various industries. MAS and Temasek plan to support commercialization efforts, with the prototype serving as a test network for developing next-generation cross-border payments infrastructure.

images.alt_text: "Following the successful experimentation over five phases, we look forward to greater adoption and live deployment of blockchain technology," says MAS chief fintech officer Sopnendu Mohanty

site_title: Disney to shut Hong Kong Disneyland again as coronavirus cases rise
summary: Disney to temporarily close Hong Kong Disneyland from July 15 due to rising coronavirus cases, with the Hong Kong Disneyland Resort hotels remaining open. The move comes amid a surge in cases in Hong Kong, with 52 new cases reported on Monday, including 41 locally transmitted. This is the second time the park has closed due to the pandemic. The company had previously reopened its parks in Asia, including Hong Kong Tokyo and Disneyland Shanghai, in June, July, and May, respectively.

site_title: US consumers more secure about jobs but earnings expectations drop: New York Fed survey
summary: US consumers are more optimistic about their job security, with a 15% chance of losing their jobs in the next year, down from 18.6% in May. However, earnings expectations have dropped, with median growth expectations for the next year decreasing to 1.6% from 2.0%. Low-wage workers and those without college degrees are most affected, expecting the slowest growth. Despite this, consumers are more confident in their ability to pay bills, with a 9.8% chance of missing a debt payment in the next three months.

site_title: Hong Kong Democrat voters defy threats with high turnout
summary: Over 610,000 Hong Kong residents defied government warnings to vote in an unofficial primary, exceeding expectations with a 13% turnout. The event, which aimed to narrow down opposition candidates for the Legislative Council, was held despite warnings that it could violate the new national security law. Prominent activists, including Joshua Wong, led in preliminary results, with the opposition hoping to secure an unprecedented majority in the legislature to block Chief Executive Carrie Lam's agenda.

site_title: Essity sales hit by household hoarding and lockdowns
summary: Essity, a Swedish hygiene products maker, reported an 11% drop in second-quarter sales due to COVID-19 lockdowns and inventory adjustments from bulk-buying. Despite lower sales, the company's operating profit rose 13% to 3.64 billion crowns, driven by efficiency measures and lower costs. Essity cited increased market share in some countries and successful product launches during the pandemic. The company expects increased demand for its hygiene products as awareness of hygiene and health importance grows.

site_title: Japan's MUFG to expand lending business in Thailand with Grab's big data
summary: Japan's Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) will start lending to Grab users and drivers in Thailand, leveraging Grab's big data, to monetize its $706 million investment in the ride-hailing firm. The move aims to boost profits from investments made in Southeast Asian banks amid Japan's demographic decline and ultra-low interest rates. The new business model could be brought to Japan if successful, with MUFG's CEO Hironori Kamezawa using Grab's data to establish new credit models and provide financial services.

site_title: Britain set to ban Huawei from 5G, though timescale unclear
summary: Britain is set to ban Huawei from its 5G network, a move that will anger Beijing and align with US President Donald Trump's stance on the issue. The ban, to be announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, comes amid concerns over national security and China's rising economic and technological influence. The decision is seen as a response to US sanctions on chip technology affecting Huawei's reliability as a supplier. The UK's 5G operators had already capped Huawei's role at 35% by 2023, with some warning that a complete ban could delay technology and disrupt services.

site_title: SiriusXM to buy podcast business of Scripps for up to US$325m
summary: SiriusXM Holdings agreed to buy EW Scripps' podcast business, Stitcher, for up to $325 million. The deal aims to bolster SiriusXM's podcast presence, competing with Apple and Spotify. This follows the company's investment in podcasting, including a multi-year deal with Walt Disney for exclusive podcasts. The acquisition is expected to close in the third quarter of 2020, with $265 million in upfront payment and $60 million in contingent payments based on financial metrics.

site_title: GE2020 marks shift to left - but heed lessons from West
summary: Singapore's GE2020 marked a shift to the left with the opposition winning 10 seats in Parliament, including two Group Representation Constituencies. However, this development is tempered by policy constraints such as the country's small size, reliance on globalisation, and need to maintain investor-friendly policies. These constraints have always influenced policymaking in Singapore, but they evolve over time. The outcome highlights the importance of balancing social redistribution with economic considerations to achieve sustainable growth and development.

site_title: G4S to cut over 1,000 jobs as UK cash handling business hit by lockdown
summary: G4S, a UK-based security services provider, plans to cut over 1,000 jobs in its cash business due to declining demand for paper money amid the COVID-19 lockdown. The company, which sold majority of its cash handling businesses to US peer Brinks, aims to reshape its UK cash solutions business. The move is part of G4S' efforts to focus on core operations and follows a review of its operational footprint.

site_title: ELD to thoroughly review what went wrong on Polling Day
summary: The Elections Department (ELD) of Singapore announced a thorough review of the voting process on Polling Day last Friday, citing long queues and slow voting times. The review aims to understand what went wrong and why, particularly at some polling stations. Measures taken to protect voters' health, such as requiring disposable gloves and sanitizing hands, contributed to the delays. The ELD has apologized for the inconvenience, especially to senior citizens, and has promised to study the issues and draw lessons for future elections.

site_title: PepsiCo's results beat estimates as lockdowns boost snack sales
summary: PepsiCo beat analysts' estimates with a 3% decrease in net revenue to $15.95 billion in the second quarter, driven by strong sales of its snack brands, including Tostitos, Cheetos, and Doritos, which rose 7% under the Frito-Lay North America unit. Online sales of potato chips and tortilla chips jumped 93.5% and 101.2%, respectively. The company's shares rose 2% before the bell, despite a 1.6% decline so far this year. CEO Ramon Laguarta attributed the results to consumers spending more time at home and shifting to at-home snacking occasions.

site_title: NUS invents new way to produce Covid-19 swab, 40m to be produced in coming months
summary: National University of Singapore (NUS) researchers have developed a new method to produce nasopharyngeal Covid-19 testing swabs using 3D-printing and injection moulding. The new swabs, named Python, were tested and found to be comparable in accuracy to industry-standard swabs. NUS plans to produce 40 million swabs in the coming months, making Singapore the first country in Asia to use 3D-printing for swab production and the first in the world to use injection moulding. The swabs are being mass-produced by local companies and are free for use in Singapore.

site_title: Japan hospitals cut staff bonuses as coronavirus drives them into the red
summary: Japan hospitals are cutting staff bonuses due to the COVID-19 pandemic, affecting around a third of medical institutions. 115 out of 338 surveyed organizations plan to reduce bonuses below last year's levels. The Japan Federation of Medical Worker's Unions warns that tough working conditions and pay reductions may lead to early retirements among medical staff.

site_title: Fintech M-DAQ and Thai stock exchange tie up to show SET50 prices in 10 currencies
summary: M-DAQ, a fintech startup, has partnered the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) to display SET50 stock prices in 10 currencies, including the Singapore dollar, US dollar, and Japanese yen. The solution aims to enhance investor analysis and expand the investor base, increasing investment appetite. The 10 currencies include the Australian dollar, euro, British pound, and Indonesian rupiah, among others. This partnership is expected to facilitate better securities analysis and investor engagement for both M-DAQ and SET.

site_title: China to sanction US Senators Rubio, Cruz over Xinjiang
summary: China has announced sanctions against US Senators Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz, along with Ambassador Sam Brownback, Representative Chris Smith, and the Congressional-Executive Commission on China, in retaliation for US moves to punish Beijing for its treatment of ethnic minorities in Xinjiang. The sanctions come after the US sanctioned a top Chinese Communist Party official and three others over alleged human rights abuses in Xinjiang. China's move is largely symbolic, but aimed at maintaining diplomatic balance and preventing further escalation of tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.59 points to 1,606.43, with a trading volume of 9.549 billion lots worth RM5.703 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 576 to 499.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Monday, driven by hopes for a virus vaccine. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.17% to 25,772.12, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 1.77% to 3,443.29. China's Shenzhen Composite Index jumped 3.48% to 2,329.40. The gains overshadowed concerns about a fresh wave of infections in the financial hub.

site_title: SPH expects 'significantly lower' operating profit for FY20
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) expects a significantly lower operating profit for FY20, down from S$187 million in the previous year, due to the ongoing pandemic. The media group's operating performance has been hit across various business segments, including media and retail, with print advertisement revenue declining 51% and digital advertisement revenue falling 3.7% year-on-year. However, SPH's "resilient" balance sheet and cash reserves of S$810 million will ensure sufficient liquidity across its business segments.

site_title: Alfa Laval makes US$2b bid for Finland's Neles
summary: Alfa Laval has made a US$1.96 billion bid for Finland's Neles, a valves maker. The bid was recommended by Neles' board but rejected by the company's largest shareholder, Valmet, citing it was not in the interest of the company. Neles' second-largest shareholder, Cevian Capital, supported the bid, and Alfa Laval's CEO said the deal would strengthen its presence in the large industrial valves market.

site_title: 322 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 11 in the community and 5 imported
summary: Singapore reported 322 new COVID-19 cases as of July 13, bringing the total to 46,283. The cases include 11 community cases, with 2 Singaporeans or permanent residents and 9 work pass holders. The higher number of cases is attributed to reduced testing over the public holiday and weekend.

images.alt_text: There are 322 new coronavirus cases confirmed as of Monday noon (July 13), taking Singapore's total to 46,283.

site_title: CEO Pichai says Google will invest US$10b in India
summary: Google plans to invest $10 billion in India over 5-7 years to accelerate digital adoption, according to CEO Sundar Pichai. The investment will focus on affordable access, digital ecosystem, and equity investments, aiming to empower businesses and leverage technology for social good in areas like health, education, and agriculture. This move reflects Google's confidence in India's digital economy, with over 500 million internet users, second only to China.

images.alt_text: Sundar Pichai said the outbreak of the coronavirus has made clear the importance of technology for conducting business and for connecting with friends and family.

site_title: Troubled oil trader ZenRock's IJMs uncover doubtful, 'unusually large cash transactions'
summary: Singapore's troubled oil trader ZenRock Commodities Trading's interim judicial managers have uncovered hundreds of "questionable" transactions, including duplicate sales invoices, back-to-back side transactions, and unusually large cash transactions. Over 200 transactions involved identical sales invoices for essentially the same transaction to obtain two sets of letter-of-credit financing. The report, submitted to the Singapore High Court, raises concerns about the trader's financial dealings. The court-appointed IJMs, KPMG, have identified these issues as part of an ongoing scrutiny into ZenRock's affairs.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on vaccine hopes, Pepsi boost
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Monday, with the Nasdaq reaching a new record high, driven by optimism over Covid-19 vaccine development progress and a strong start to the second-quarter earnings season by Pepsi. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.57% and the S&P 500 gained 0.63%. The Nasdaq Composite surged 1.06% to a new high of 10,729.92, while the Dow Jones rose 149.77 points to 26,225.07.

site_title: SIA group to operate at 7% of pre-Covid-19 capacity in August
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its subsidiaries SilkAir and Scoot will operate at approximately 7% of pre-Covid-19 capacity in August, reaching about 6% in July. The group has increased flight frequencies on existing routes but will not add new destinations. Customers affected by schedule changes will retain the full value of unused ticket portions as flight credits and receive bonus credits upon rebooking. The group will continue to adjust capacity to match demand for international air travel.

site_title: Analog Devices to buy rival Maxim in US$21b chip deal
summary: Analog Devices agreed to acquire rival Maxim Integrated Products for $20.9 billion in a stock deal, creating a larger rival in the US$400 billion semiconductor industry. Analog Devices shareholders will own about 69% of the combined company, valued at $68 billion including debt. The acquisition may lead to further consolidation in the industry, particularly in the market for analog and embedded processor chips.

site_title: STI slips 0.81% after surprise General Election outcome
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.81% on Monday, closing at 2,631.08, following a surprise general election outcome in which the ruling People's Action Party secured a smaller-than-expected margin of victory. The STI's biggest losers included City Developments, Thai Beverage, and ST Engineering, but analysts expect the post-election dip to be temporary due to policy continuity.

site_title: Kenya wildlife reserves threatened as tourists stay away
summary: Kenya's wildlife reserves are facing an economic disaster due to the coronavirus pandemic, with tourism revenues plummeting to $750 million, roughly half of the total revenue in 2019. The Maasai community, who depend on tourism for their livelihood, are struggling to survive, with some selling livestock on the black market and others forced to reduce their earnings. The situation is dire, with some areas experiencing a loss of habitat for wildlife, threatening the existence of the reserves.

site_title: Pfizer, BioNTech's coronavirus vaccine candidates get FDA's 'fast track' status
summary: Pfizer and BioNTech's coronavirus vaccine candidates, BNT162b1 and BNT162b2, have received the US FDA's 'fast track' status, accelerating the regulatory review process. This designation could make the vaccine candidates eligible for the FDA's 'priority review', aiming for a decision within six months. The companies expect to start a large trial with up to 30,000 participants and produce up to 100 million doses by the end of this year, with potential production of 1.2 billion doses by 2021. The news led to a 10% climb in Pfizer's US-listed shares and a 2% rise in Pfizer's stock.

site_title: Hyflux's potential white knight Pison assures investors it is aware of tight timelines
summary: Pison Investments, led by Indonesian magnate Johnny Widjaja, has made a formal cash offer to purchase eligible debts of Hyflux, a beleaguered water-treatment firm. The offer is set to be launched soon, with a minimum discount of 91% and a goal of completing the purchase within tight timelines. Pison has set aside S$200 million to fund the debt purchase, which could potentially allow Hyflux to exit insolvency without paying holders of perpetual securities and preference shares. The move aims to facilitate a fair and equitable debt restructuring exercise for all stakeholders.

site_title: GE2020 result unlikely to move dial for Singapore market: analysts
summary: Singapore's ruling party, the People's Action Party (PAP), secured 61.24% of the votes in the 2020 general election, a weaker show of support compared to 2015. Despite this, analysts expect the market to remain unaffected, citing policy continuity and ongoing support for businesses caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Straits Times Index is trading near its 10-year mean, and experts anticipate a possible shift in policy towards the left, with potential changes to foreign worker policies and property tax structure.

site_title: OCBC launches first SORA-based home loan
summary: OCBC has launched Singapore's first home loan referencing the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA), a benchmark rate that offers greater stability and transparency. The 90-day SORA home loan has an interest rate calculated based on the simple average of daily SORA rates over the past 90 days, updated every month. The applicable SORA-based interest rate is typically lower than the Singapore Interbank Offered Rate (Sibor), averaging 0.35% per annum. The loan package has a one-year lock-in period and allows for pre-payments of up to 50% without penalty fees.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up more than 2.2%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 2.22% to close at 22,784.74 on Monday, following rallies in the US and Asia due to fresh hopes for coronavirus treatments. The broader Topix index surged 2.46%. The gains were driven by positive sentiment from the US and Asia, where stocks have been rallying despite concerns over trade and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Hot stocks: Medtecs and UG Healthcare both sink, prompting SGX queries
summary: Shares of Medtecs International Corporation and UG Healthcare plummeted 35% and 28.9% respectively during Monday's trading, prompting Singapore Exchange (SGX) queries. The companies were flagged for "unusual price movements" and asked to confirm compliance with Catalist Rule 703. Medtecs' shares recovered slightly, while UG Healthcare regained some ground after an intra-day low. Both companies denied any unannounced information explaining the trading activity, pointing to previous filings.

site_title: Life after Zoom: corporate travel agents plot safe return to business trips
summary: Corporate travel agents are developing tools to help companies plan safe business trips as the industry rebounds from the pandemic. Agents are providing on-the-ground information on local health regulations, hygiene standards, and travel requirements. Travelers are seeking expert advice, opting for in-person consultations over online bookings. The industry's annual spending of $1.4 trillion is slowly recovering, driven by companies looking to return to in-person meetings and conferences.

site_title: Malaysian news site faces contempt of court case
summary: A Malaysian news site, Malaysiakini, is facing a contempt of court case after readers' comments critical of the judiciary were published on the site. The comments allegedly eroded public confidence in the courts. Editor-in-chief Steven Gan was taken to court by the attorney general, who claims the site facilitated publication of the remarks. Gan's lawyer argues that the comments were removed quickly and had no intention to publish them. The court will rule on the case, which could have a "chilling effect" on free speech.

site_title: Hot stock: Biolidics halts trading after shares climb 29.3%
summary: Biolidics, a CATALIST-listed company, halted trading after its shares surged 29.3% to an intraday high of S$0.53 due to a trading halt pending an announcement. The company previously clarified its scrapped deal with US virus test kit distributor Aytu BioScience, citing non-delivery of test kits without breaching terms. Biolidics agreed to a mutual release of claims and a full refund for the undelivered kits, as well as potential future collaboration with Aytu.

site_title: Europe: Equities advance at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 1.3% to 6,174.21 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also increasing by 1.4% and 1.2%, respectively. The gains were driven by investor optimism ahead of corporate results season and hopes for a positive tone for the coronavirus stock market rally. Asian markets also rose, recovering from losses at the end of last week, following a strong performance on Wall Street fueled by vaccine hopes.

site_title: Wealthy investors worry about lack of cash if pandemic returns
summary: Wealthy investors are concerned about the potential for another pandemic, with over half fearing they won't have enough liquidity. Many plan to reduce travel, move closer to family, and make permanent lifestyle changes. 70% of respondents reported being financially affected by the pandemic, with younger investors more severely impacted. Despite market volatility, most investors see it as a buying opportunity. Two-thirds plan to work remotely, 70% anticipate traveling less, and over half plan to move closer to family.

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma sells US$9.6b worth shares, stake dips to 4.8%
summary: Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma has sold US$9.6 billion worth of shares, reducing his stake in the company to 4.8% from 6.4%. Ma retired as executive chairman in September and stepped back from formal business roles to focus on philanthropy. His divestment comes as the company's share price has risen 40% since his last reported holding. Alibaba executive vice-chairman Joseph Tsai has also reduced his stake, selling US$4.1 billion worth of shares. The divestments follow Ma's announcement to sell up to 21 million shares in 2019 to support philanthropic efforts.

site_title: Malaysia PM Muhyiddin wins vote to oust Speaker, proves majority
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin successfully removed Speaker Ariff Yusof from office after a heated debate, winning a vote of 111-109. The move ends months of uncertainty over Muhyiddin's parliamentary majority. The opposition had accused the government of trying to install a Speaker under its control, but Muhyiddin's Perikatan Nasional (PN) pact ultimately prevailed. The new Speaker will be installed after the lunch break, despite fierce resistance from the Pakatan Harapan-led opposition.

site_title: Taiwan to enhance scrutiny of Hong Kong, China investment: source
summary: Taiwan plans to enhance scrutiny over investments from Hong Kong to prevent illicit money from mainland China from "infiltrating" its economy, following Beijing's imposition of a new security law on the Asian financial hub. The move aims to differentiate between Hong Kong and Macau investments and mainland Chinese investments, which are already tightly controlled. Taiwan will tweak legislation to review investments from Hong Kong on national security grounds, amid concerns of China's influence.

site_title: Thailand plans 100b baht soft loans to help tourism, services
summary: Thailand plans 100 billion baht (S$4.43 billion) in new soft loans to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the tourist and services sector affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The loans, offered by the Government Savings Bank, will have more relaxed conditions than the central bank's existing 500-billion baht scheme, aiming to reduce operators' costs and provide liquidity to keep jobs. The move follows various relief measures that employ 80% of the total workforce, as Thailand's economy is forecast to contract by a record 8.1% this year.

images.alt_text: Thailand plans 100 billion baht (S$4.43 billion) of new soft loans to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the tourist and services sector hit by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Hundreds of rivers swell as China summer flood season revs up
summary: China is experiencing severe summer flooding, with record levels reported across central and eastern regions. Over 140 people are dead or missing, and 37.89 million others have been affected. The Yangtze River, which runs through Wuhan, has hit its third-highest levels in history, and 33 rivers have reached record highs. The government has issued alerts on 433 rivers, with the worst-hit provinces including Jiangxi, Hubei, and Hunan. President Xi Jinping has urged authorities to mobilize and help affected residents, warning that the situation is "worsening".

images.alt_text: Floods across large swathes of central and eastern China that have left more than 140 people dead or missing are hitting record levels, with authorities warning the worst was yet to come.

site_title: Coronavirus leaves Spain's interior a tourist desert
summary: Spain's interior, particularly Cordoba, remains largely deserted due to the coronavirus pandemic, with many tourist attractions experiencing a significant decline. The Mezquita, a popular site, is still visited, but its surroundings, such as the Santos Bar, are now quiet. The owner of the bar attributes the decline to the pandemic, stating that "everything's dead." This decline is not limited to Cordoba, as other tourist destinations across Spain are also struggling to recover from the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Ambani's Jio adds Qualcomm to backers for digital services push
summary: Qualcomm Ventures has invested approximately $135.2 million in Jio Platforms, taking the total investments to around $15.6 billion since April. The investment will support the introduction of 5G wireless networks in India, with Qualcomm committing up to $7.3 billion. The deal gives Jio an estimated equity value of $65 billion, with Reliance Industries aiming to "digital transform India" through Jio's services.

site_title: Singapore's SWAT Mobility partners Toyota in Philippines for corporate transport
summary: Singapore-based startup SWAT Mobility has partnered with Toyota Motor Philippines to launch a corporate smart transportation solution in Manila. The service allows employees and clients of KMC Solutions to book rides and plan routes through an app, utilizing SWAT's technology to track system activity and navigate drivers. This partnership aims to provide efficient and convenient transportation for KMC Solutions' clients, leveraging Toyota's expertise in mobility solutions.

site_title: China is winning the trillion-dollar 5G war
summary: China is rapidly expanding its 5G network, aiming to reach 5 million base stations by the end of the year, surpassing the US and South Korea. The country plans to spend $1.4 trillion by 2025 to boost industrial innovation and further integrate the Internet of Things. China's aggressive 5G rollout could revive domestic supply chains, allowing the country to maintain its position as a global manufacturing hub, even as the COVID-19 pandemic forces a rethink on globalization. This move could give China a renewed advantage in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post sharpest gain in month on virus drug hopes
summary: South Korean shares surged 1.67% to a one-month high, closing at 2,186.06, driven by positive results from an antiviral drug analysis for Covid-19 treatment. The benchmark Kospi index gained 35.81 points. Foreign investors were net buyers of 100.20 billion won worth of shares, while the won rose 0.3% against the US dollar. Exports to China and the US rose 9.4% and 7.3%, respectively, despite a 1.7% decline in overall exports.

site_title: Four in 10 Singapore investors eyeing sustainable investments: StanChart
summary: Nearly four in 10 investors in Singapore are considering allocating 5 to 15% of their funds to sustainable investments over the next three years, according to a report by Standard Chartered Private Bank. The survey of 1,080 investors found that 42% plan to invest in sustainable investments, with affluent and high-net-worth investors showing the highest interest. Despite apprehension about sustainable investing, the bank expects the healthcare sector to benefit from the trend.

site_title: Spot gold still targets US$1,831
summary: Spot gold prices remain steady at US$1,831 per ounce, breaking through a resistance level of US$1,796. This move may signal a potential gain to US$1,856. The price drop from US$1,817.71 on July 8 is considered a pullback, which may have completed after stabilizing around US$1,796.

site_title: Poland's incumbent Duda wins presidential election: majority results
summary: Poland's incumbent President Andrzej Duda has won the presidential election with 51.21% of the vote, surpassing opposition candidate Rafal Trzaskowski's 48.79%. The difference in votes is approximately 500,000, with remaining uncounted votes unlikely to change the outcome. Duda, an ally of the ruling nationalists, is expected to continue the Law and Justice party's judicial reforms and social spending programs, which have been criticized by the European Union.

site_title: Tycoons plead for higher taxes to help pay for Covid-19 aid
summary: A group of over 80 millionaires from the US and six other countries, including Walt Disney heiress Abigail Disney and former BlackRock managing director Morris Pearl, are calling for higher taxes on the rich to help pay for COVID-19 aid. They signed an open letter, "Tax us. Tax us. Tax us," and plan to present their appeal ahead of the Group of Twenty meeting. This is not the first such appeal, as a similar group, the Patriotic Millionaires, has been pressing for a more progressive tax system.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on fresh vaccine hopes, eyes on earnings
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, driven by hopes for a coronavirus vaccine and strong performance on Wall Street. The Dow and S&P 500 surged over 1%, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq reached a record. Tokyo led gains, with Seoul, Sydney, and Jakarta also climbing over 1%. However, concerns about the pandemic's spread, including a spike in cases in Hong Kong and South Africa, capped gains. Analysts remain optimistic, predicting a multi-year recovery for the global economy once a vaccine is found.

site_title: Rethinking your diversification strategy? Look no further than ASEAN
summary: ASEAN stands out as an investment destination, particularly in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, due to its big domestic markets, social and technological infrastructure, and relatively steady growth. The region's leaders have accumulated experience managing past economic crises, encouraging foreign direct investment, and growing intra-ASEAN trade. Standard Chartered economists forecast ASEAN GDP growth to rebound to 6.4% in 2021, making it an attractive region for companies to diversify their strategies and adapt to the new normal.

site_title: One in three South Korean Covid-19 patients improve with remdesivir
summary: South Korea reported that one in three patients seriously ill with Covid-19 showed improvement after receiving remdesivir, an antiviral medication developed by Gilead Sciences. The Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention analyzed data from 27 patients and found 9 showed improvement, 15 showed no change, and 3 worsened. However, more research is needed to determine if the improvement was due to the drug or other factors. This is the latest development in the global battle against Covid-19, with several countries including South Korea adding remdesivir to their treatment lists.

site_title: Analog Devices near deal to buy Maxim for US$17b
summary: Analog Devices Inc is close to an all-stock deal to acquire Maxim Integrated Products Inc for over $17 billion, valuing Maxim at more than its current market capitalization. The acquisition, which could be announced as early as Monday, would broaden Analog's product portfolio and help it close the gap with market leader Texas Instruments. The deal comes as the semiconductor industry experiences a resurgence in demand for analog chips, which convert real-world things into electronic signals, and as companies consolidate to lower costs and serve customers.

site_title: MAS-led payments network on path towards commercial adoption
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Temasek have released a report highlighting the commercial potential of Project Ubin, a blockchain-based payments network prototype. The report validated the use of blockchain technology in commercial applications, including multi-currency payments, international settlement networks, and smart contracts. The MAS and Temasek are paving the way for live adoption of blockchain technology, with the prototype serving as a test network for collaboration with other central banks and financial institutions. The commercial applications of the prototype include cross-border payments, foreign currency exchange, and settlement of securities, with the potential for faster and cheaper transactions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.47% on Monday, driven by hopes for a coronavirus vaccine and the start of the corporate earnings season. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 25,848.80, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.12%. The gains were seen as a relief for investors ahead of the corporate earnings season and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Hong Kong democrat primary voters defy threats with high turnout
summary: In defiance of government warnings and a coronavirus outbreak, over 610,000 Hong Kong residents cast ballots in an unofficial primary, representing 13% of registered voters, to narrow down opposition candidates for the Legislative Council elections on September 6. Despite government claims that the effort could violate the national security law, the high turnout signals continued resistance to Beijing's decision. The opposition hopes to secure an unprecedented majority and block Chief Executive Carrie Lam's agenda, while the government may disqualify pro-democracy candidates to maintain control.

images.alt_text: More than half a million Hong Kong residents defied government warnings and a fresh coronavirus outbreak to vote in an unofficial primary, a strong turnout that signals continued resistance to Beijing's decision to impose a broad national security law just two weeks ago.

site_title: MacPherson Road industrial building up for sale with S$21m guide price
summary: A seven-storey light industrial building at 463 MacPherson Road in Singapore is up for sale with a guide price of S$21 million. The property, completed in 2016, has a total gross floor area of 38,287 sq ft and a remaining lease of around 44 years. It is highly visible, located along MacPherson Road and within walking distance to several MRT stations. Savills Singapore expects strong interest due to its excellent visibility and superior locality, offering a strong branding presence. The property is being sold via private treaty.

images.alt_text: 463 MacPherson Road is a seven-storey light industrial building with a basement car park and a sky terrace.

site_title: Virus spreads beyond nightclubs as Tokyo braces for more cases
summary: Tokyo, Japan is bracing for more coronavirus cases as new outbreaks emerge beyond nightclubs and known hotspot areas. Clusters have been reported at a childcare center and a theater house, with cases topping 200 for the fourth straight day. Despite this, government officials have avoided calling for broader restrictions, citing a localized issue and a stable medical system. Japan's flare-up is part of a broader resurgence in cases across Asia, with countries seeking targeted approaches to reopen their economies.

site_title: Oil Search to write off some PNG exploration assets, power project
summary: Oil Search Ltd plans to write off around US$380 million from exploration assets and a power project in Papua New Guinea due to low oil and gas prices and a shut-down gold mine. The company will record a non-cash, pre-tax charge of US$360-400 million in its half-year results. Assets deemed of low priority will not be pursued, and the Hides gas-to-electricity operation, which supplies power to a gold mine, will be fully written off due to gas supply uncertainty.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE initiates 'buy' call on Frencken, citing 'quality growth, diversity and margins'
summary: Maybank KE initiates a "buy" call on Frencken Group, citing "quality growth, diversity and margins" as reasons. The target price is set at S$1.20. Analyst Lai Gene Lih predicts a 14% year-over-year increase in net profit after tax and minority interests for FY21-22, driven by margin uplift potential from new products and market-leading customers. Frencken's geographic and product diversity, as well as its net cash-to-equity position, offer resilience amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Macau junket Suncity gives insight into VIP finances in rebuttal of online criticism
summary: Macau junket operator Suncity has released a video rebutting online criticism, stating it has a financial reserve of HK$10.58 billion and cash flow of HK$18.6 billion.
