The company's founder, Alvin Chau, denied allegations that Suncity was struggling to cover customer debts and that mainland Chinese authorities had information about its VIP customers. Suncity has also stated it has never received requests for customer information from authorities and has abided by the law in operating tourism and gaming businesses in Macau.

images.alt_text: Macau's biggest junket operator Suncity, which operates VIP gambling rooms across Asia, has given rare insight into its balance sheet during a rebuttal of online criticism, saying it is financially robust and not the target of law enforcement.

site_title: Federer-backed Swiss shoe company eyes an IPO
summary: Swiss sports shoe company On, backed by tennis star Roger Federer, is preparing for an initial public offering (IPO) that could be held in 2021. The company, founded in 2010, is estimated to be worth almost 2 billion Swiss francs. On has 7 million clients worldwide and 6,500 shops globally, with offices in several countries. The IPO comes amid a wave of equity fundraisings as companies seek to secure cash amid the COVID-19 pandemic. On's growth plan is expected to be boosted by Federer's involvement, including the development of new products.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, up 6.49 points or 0.41% to 1,598.33. The index saw 438.35 million lots traded worth RM157.51 million, with 330 gainers and 91 losers.

site_title: Jokowi wants wider virus testing as Indonesia cases top 75,000
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has instructed his ministers to boost nationwide coronavirus testing capacity by 50% to 30,000 daily, following the country's cases exceeding 75,000. The increase aims to intensify testing, tracing, and treatment in 8 provinces, including Jakarta and East Java, which are hotspots. The death toll has risen to 3,606, with a record daily spike reported in Jakarta. The move is part of efforts to combat the pandemic, which has hit Indonesia harder than the 1997 Asian financial crisis.

site_title: Eastward, Ho! Even art is leaving for the Hamptons
summary: East Hampton, New York, has seen a surge in art gallery openings since the start of June, with five major galleries - Pace, Skarstedt, Van de Weghe, Michael Werner, and Sotheby's - setting up shop in the upscale summer town. More galleries are expected to open in nearby Montauk and Southampton. Artists and collectors are embracing the new developments, citing the need for in-person art viewing and relationships with affluent collectors. Veteran dealers and collectors praise the new galleries, saying they bring a fresh international vibe and more opportunities for emerging artists. The influx of galleries is seen as a positive development for the area, which has been a hub for New York art powerhouses for decades.

site_title: China vows 'zero tolerance' towards illegal market behaviour
summary: China has vowed "zero tolerance" towards securities and accounting fraud, and will step up a crackdown on major capital-markets crimes, following a meeting chaired by Vice Premier Liu He. The regulators plan to toughen penalties and establish a crime-busting team to strengthen cooperation between agencies. This move aims to strengthen financial stability and address concerns about market behavior.

site_title: Bank of Japan appoints new monetary policy team head amid battle to curb coronavirus economic impact
summary: The Bank of Japan appointed Seiichi Shimizu as head of its monetary policy drafting department, replacing Takeshi Kato. Shimizu, who previously led the markets department, played a key role in implementing measures to ease market strains caused by the coronavirus pandemic. He will oversee drafting monetary policy and communicating policy intentions, a crucial task as Japan faces the economic impact of the pandemic and struggles with deflation. The BOJ is expected to maintain its policy steady at a two-day rate review ending on Wednesday, with crisis-response measures now in place.

site_title: China's fresh meat lovers lament death of live poultry markets
summary: China will gradually close all live poultry markets to reduce public health risks amid the Covid-19 pandemic, following a temporary ban that has been in place since 2017. The move aims to step up supervision of farmers' markets and address concerns over the origins of the virus, which is believed to have originated from a wet market in Wuhan. The ban will be implemented in phases, affecting markets with containment rooms first, with consumers expected to adapt to buying chilled or frozen chicken instead of freshly prepared products from markets.

site_title: New Zealand mosque shooter to represent himself at sentencing
summary: New Zealand mosque shooter Brenton Tarrant will represent himself at his sentencing hearing on August 24, despite his lawyers withdrawing due to his request. Tarrant has pleaded guilty to 51 murder convictions, 40 attempted murder, and one terrorism charge. High Court judge Cameron Mander has ordered "standby counsel" to be available in case Tarrant changes his mind, amid concerns he may use the sentencing hearing to promote his white-supremacist views, potentially re-traumatizing victims and their families.

site_title: New York City reaches milestone with no reported virus deaths
summary: New York City has reached a milestone, marking the first day with zero confirmed or probable virus deaths since the pandemic hit the city on March 11. This comes after a four-month stretch of reported fatalities, with 18,670 confirmed and 4,613 probable deaths. Despite this, the city has started its Phase Three of reopening, allowing some businesses to reopen, while the US reported 134,904 total deaths from Covid-19.

site_title: Amid Stone flap, Republican senator to allow Mueller testimony
summary: US Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, will allow former special counsel Robert Mueller to testify after Mueller offered a public defense of the Russia collusion probe. The move comes amid controversy over President Donald Trump's commutation of Roger Stone's jail sentence. Mueller defended the investigation in a Washington Post op-ed, stating that prosecutors acted with integrity and that Stone was a convicted felon. The decision is seen as a response to Trump's claims that the Mueller probe was a "witch hunt."

site_title: After 133% rally, SoftBank investors bet there's more to come
summary: SoftBank shares have more than doubled from their March low, driven by buybacks and improving market conditions for its portfolio companies. The company's bonds have recovered to near par, and founder Masayoshi Son's net worth has soared to $20 billion. Despite criticism, multiple factors suggest more room for short-term gains, including recovering earnings, pressure on shorts to cover losses, and significant share buybacks. SoftBank's shares gained 3.6% after the article was published, further fueling investor optimism about the company's prospects.

site_title: Elvis's only grandson dies aged 27
summary: Elvis Presley's only grandson, Benjamin Keough, died on Sunday at 27, reportedly from a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Keough, a musician and actor, was found in Calabasas, near Los Angeles. His mother, Lisa Marie Presley, described him as the "love of her life" and was "heartbroken" over his death. Keough's resemblance to Elvis was noted, and he had attended the 40th anniversary of Elvis's death in 2017.

site_title: Libya's NOC accuses UAE of being behind oil blockade
summary: Libya's National Oil Corp (NOC) accused the United Arab Emirates (UAE) of instructing eastern forces to reimpose a blockade on oil exports, despite a single tanker's departure in six months. The UAE, along with Russia and Egypt, supports the eastern-based Libyan National Army (LNA) of Khalifa Haftar. NOC resumed force majeure on all oil exports and accused Russian mercenaries of occupying Es Sider port, where a tanker loaded oil last week. The blockade was initially imposed in January and the US Libya embassy expressed regret over the blockade's resumption amid diplomatic efforts to lift it.

site_title: Property bellwethers CDL, Ascott sound warning on H1 profit hit
summary: Singapore property developers City Developments Limited (CDL) and Ascott Residence Trust (ART) have warned of a significant decline in profits due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on their hotel operations and property development segments. CDL expects a substantial reduction in pre-tax profit for the first half of the year, while ART's distribution per stapled security is expected to fall by 65%. Both companies have sufficient liquidity to weather the crisis, with CDL having over $5 billion in cash and credit facilities.

site_title: Oil slips as traders eye supply cut easing at Opec meeting
summary: Oil prices slipped in early Asian trade on Monday as traders awaited an Opec meeting to recommend easing supply cuts. Brent crude fell 27 cents to $42.97 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 28 cents to $40.27 a barrel. The planned easing of Opec+ production cuts and potential rebound in US production may add pressure to the supply side, according to analysts. The Opec Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee will meet on Tuesday and Wednesday to make the recommendation.

images.alt_text: Oil slipped in early Asian trade on Monday as traders eyed an Opec technical meeting this week which is expected to recommend an easing in supply cuts that have been propping up crude prices.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn to invest US$1b in India: sources
summary: Foxconn, a major Apple supplier, plans to invest up to $1 billion in India to expand a factory in southern India, where it assembles Apple iPhones. The move is part of Apple's shift away from China due to trade war disruptions and the coronavirus crisis. The investment will add 6,000 jobs and help Apple save on import taxes. This move is seen as a boost for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "Make In India" drive, which aims to create new jobs.

site_title: Ex-Nissan boss Ghosn says helping everyone who stood by him
summary: Former Nissan Motor chairman Carlos Ghosn says he is helping everyone who stood by him, but declined to comment on those accused of helping him flee to Lebanon from Japan. Ghosn, awaiting trial in Lebanon, denied charges of underreporting his salary and using company funds for personal purposes in Japan. He refused to discuss details of his escape, citing the danger to those involved, and criticized Japan for not sending his case file to Lebanon as requested. Ghosn's statements come as US authorities seek to extradite individuals accused of aiding his escape.

images.alt_text: Carlos Ghosn has refused to discuss details of his escape from Japan, saying it would put those who helped him in danger.

site_title: Only a quarter of UK firms ready for Brexit transition
summary: A survey by the Institute of Directors found that only one-quarter of UK firms are fully prepared for the Brexit transition period. Nearly half of the 978 company directors polled said they weren't ready, citing the coronavirus pandemic as a major distraction. Almost a third of respondents need more clarity on forthcoming changes before making adjustments. The director general of the Institute of Directors stated that preparing for Brexit is like trying to hit a moving target, and immediate action could be a nightmare for many businesses.

site_title: Volkswagen to replace head of software division: Handelsblatt
summary: Volkswagen is replacing its head of software development, Christian Senger, following clashes with the company and concerns over software problems with the ID.3 and Golf 8 vehicles. Senger, a former BMW manager, had helped Volkswagen develop its MEB electric car platform. The move comes as Volkswagen transitions to electric vehicles, a key area of focus for the company. Senger's departure is part of a management purge, which has seen several high-profile executives leave their posts, including Andreas Renschler and Stefan Sommer.

site_title: Qian Hu says it expects H1 loss on Covid-19 supply chain disruptions
summary: Qian Hu Corporation, a Singapore-based integrated fish service provider, expects to report a net loss for the first half of 2020 due to Covid-19 supply chain disruptions affecting its exports. Revenue declined, but net profit increased 50.8% year-over-year. The company's working capital position remains healthy despite the disruptions. Qian Hu will announce its half-year results on Friday.

site_title: Handelsbanken model upending perceptions on banker pay theory
summary: A Swedish bank, Handelsbanken, is challenging conventional wisdom on how bonuses affect performance. Harvard Business School professor Dennis Campbell found that despite not offering bonuses to most employees, staff at Handelsbanken were highly motivated due to a flat corporate hierarchy and empowered branch managers. The bank's performance outcomes, including low impairments and high returns on equity, contradict the assumption that bonuses drive results. Instead, Campbell concludes that Handelsbanken's strong culture organization, with a focus on long-term outcomes, is a more potent way to generate profits.

site_title: Hatten Land unit gets three-month debt moratorium
summary: Hatten Land's subsidiary, MDSA Ventures, has secured a three-month debt moratorium from the High Court of Malaya to restructure its debt. This follows an application for a restraining order to prevent any legal proceedings against the company and its assets. The move aims to facilitate a proposed scheme of arrangement and compromise between MDSA Ventures and its unsecured creditors. The company is undergoing debt restructuring amid ongoing pressures from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit to invest in London, Frankfurt data centres
summary: Cromwell E-Reit has signed a heads of terms agreement with Stratus Data Centres to co-invest in 50% stakes in two European data centre projects. The projects include a 100MW data centre in London and a 300MW project in Frankfurt, one of the largest in Germany and Western Europe. Cromwell E-Reit's sponsor, Cromwell Property Group, has entered into a strategic partnership with Stratus to invest in and manage the roll-out of a data-centre property platform across Europe and the Asia-Pacific. The partnership aims to create a platform targeting a gross asset value of over $1 billion.

site_title: Chinese biotech Beigene to raise US$2.1b in share sale
summary: Chinese biotech company Beigene Ltd plans to raise $2.1 billion in a direct offering of 145.8 million shares to fund research and market treatments in the US and China. The shares will be priced at $14.23 each, a 5.6% discount from its closing price. The offering is backed by investment firm Baker Bros Advisors LP and Amgen Inc, which previously purchased a 20.5% stake in Beigene for $2.7 billion. The company's blood cancer therapy received US FDA approval last November, positioning it as a promising player in the global biotech market.

site_title: Top US aide expects tough action on TikTok, WeChat
summary: US trade advisor Peter Navarro expects President Trump to take firm action against TikTok and WeChat, amid rising tensions with China. Trump previously considered banning TikTok due to concerns over data sharing with the Chinese military and intellectual property theft. Navarro also criticized TikTok's new CEO, Kevin Mayer, as an American puppet. The US has over 52 million TikTok users, with many under 30 years old, and Amazon has mistakenly told employees to remove the app from their phones.

site_title: China stock market on a roll; analysts warn of repeat of 2015 bubble
summary: China's stock market has surged 16% in July, reaching nearly 40% gains from its March low, driven by relaxed monetary policy, economic recovery hopes, and government assurances. Analysts warn of a potential repeat of the 2015 bubble, which crashed a year later, as the government faces pressure to act. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, adding to policymakers' concerns.

site_title: Full coronavirus vaccine unlikely by next year: expert
summary: A French epidemiologist, Arnaud Fontanet, warns that a 100% effective coronavirus vaccine is unlikely by 2021, citing the ongoing crisis and the need for continued social distancing measures. Fontanet urges people to take the threat of the virus more seriously, particularly in confined spaces, and expresses concerns about the spread of the virus. He emphasizes the need for targeted measures, such as stay-at-home orders or business closures, rather than nationwide lockdowns.

site_title: CDL's hotel operations segment to sink into red with 'significant' loss
summary: CDL's hotel operations segment is expected to incur a significant pre-tax loss of S$120-140 million for the first half of 2020, primarily due to the novel coronavirus pandemic's impact on global tourism and travel restrictions. Despite cost-containment measures, the segment is anticipated to decline by 50-60% in revenue per available room. The company's overall net attributable profit after tax and minority interests is expected to be "materially and adversely" affected, with total cash and undrawn credit facilities exceeding S$5 billion.

site_title: Virus boosts digital payments in India where cash ban failed
summary: India's digital payments surge amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with the value of transactions on the Unified Payments Interface reaching an all-time high. The surge is attributed to people's fear of handling cash, as well as the government's push for digital commerce. Despite this, cash remains the primary method of payment, with India still relying heavily on cash transactions. The Reserve Bank of India aims for 15% of gross domestic product to be digital transactions by 2021, and global tech giants are betting on India's growing digital-payments market, forecast to quintuple to $1 trillion by 2023.

site_title: Singapore stocks advance at Monday's open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% at Monday's open, with the Straits Times Index gaining 12.85 points to 2,665.50. The ruling People's Action Party won 61.24% of the votes in the General Election, a decline from 69.9% in 2015. Despite the PAP's loss, investors expect Singapore's stability and economic policy direction to continue. Gainers outnumbered losers 122 to 48, with CapitaLand Mall Trust and Biolidics leading the gains.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, SATS, ART, Singtel, Cromwell E-Reit, OCBC, Sembmarine
summary: Key developments in the Singapore stock market include City Developments Limited's expected substantial decline in first-half pre-tax profit, SATS recording a net loss, and Ascott Residence Trust's distribution per stapled security expected to fall by 65-75%. Singtel is set to sell its software to Coupang Corp, while Cromwell E-Reit has signed a heads of terms agreement to co-invest in European data centre projects. OCBC Bank expects its sustainable financing loans to be comparable to last year's commitment, and Sembcorp Marine has secured a contract to supply an offshore wind farm's electrical transmission system.

site_title: WeWork says back on track to profits: FT
summary: WeWork, a troubled office-sharing start-up, is set to achieve positive cash flow by next year, according to its executive chairman Marcelo Claure. The company has turned around after cutting its workforce, renegotiating leases, and selling assets. Strong demand for flexible work space since the COVID-19 pandemic has driven the revival, with major tenants such as Mastercard and Microsoft signing lease deals. WeWork was once valued at $47 billion but faced significant financial struggles after cancelling its share offering in 2019. Claure predicts the company will become a profitable venture with a diverse range of assets.

site_title: Spanish region orders lockdown as global infections gather pace
summary: Spain has ordered a lockdown in the northeastern town of Lerida, as coronavirus cases in the region and globally accelerate. Over 2.5 million new infections have been reported worldwide since July, with cases doubling in just a month-and-a-half. US President Donald Trump wore a face mask for the first time, while hard-hit countries like India and Brazil struggle with high infection rates. The pandemic has infected nearly 13 million people and killed over 565,000, with Europe being the worst affected continent.

site_title: UK's big spending offer small spark to economy, but also huge debts
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak's £190 billion COVID-19 bailout has boosted the British economy, but economists fear massive debts. The government's latest £30 billion package includes £1,000 incentives for employers to keep workers on, tax breaks, and subsidies for restaurants and pubs. However, many businesspeople and economists believe the government's borrowing will reach £350 billion this year, potentially leading to inflation, interest rate hikes, and a decline in the pound. Moody's predicts a 24 percentage point rise in the UK's public debt ratio to 109% of GDP this year.

site_title: US weighs limited options to deal with China over Hong Kong: WSJ
summary: The US is considering limited options to address China's recent moves in Hong Kong, including restricted sanctions and trade measures. However, these steps are unlikely to have a significant impact on Beijing's integration of Hong Kong into the mainland's political and security system. The US imposed sanctions on China's Xinjiang Communist Party Secretary earlier this week, prompting Beijing to warn of reciprocal measures against US officials and organizations. The US government also alerted American citizens to "exercise increased caution" in China amid escalating bilateral tensions.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust H1 2020 DPS expected to fall by 65-75%
summary: Ascott Residence Trust's (ART) distribution per stapled security (DPS) for the first half of 2020 is expected to fall by 65-75% due to the global pandemic's impact. The company's available income for distribution is expected to decline by 55-65% and total return by 55-90%. Despite the uncertainty, ART has sufficient liquidity to meet its operational needs and a geographically diversified portfolio that has provided resilience to its earnings under usual business conditions. The company will release its H1 2020 unaudited financial results on July 28.

site_title: US man, 30, dies from virus after attending 'Covid-19 party'
summary: A 30-year-old US man from Texas died from the new coronavirus after attending a "Covid-19" party hosted by an infected person, according to Dr. Jane Appleby, chief medical officer at Methodist Hospital in San Antonio. The man, who thought the virus was a hoax, was among younger people who face a significant risk of severe illness from the disease. His death highlights the importance of taking the virus seriously, despite its perceived low impact on younger individuals.

site_title: More diverse voices in politics, but policy constraints remain
summary: The 2020 Singapore general election (GE2020) saw the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) secure 61.24% of the votes, a decline from previous years, while the opposition Workers' Party (WP) gained ground. While a more diverse range of voices is present in politics, economic policy constraints remain, including limited resources, a small population, and a reliance on foreign labor. These constraints will continue to shape Singapore's economic and social policies, and a nuanced understanding of them is crucial for informed discourse.

site_title: IMF urges fiscal caution as global debt set to surge to record
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) urges governments to exercise fiscal caution as global debt is expected to reach a record $11 trillion this year, surpassing 100% of global GDP. The fund advises governments to pursue medium-term plans that rely on improving revenue mobilization to avoid unsustainable debt levels. With record-low borrowing costs, the IMF warns that premature withdrawal of fiscal support poses a greater risk than high debt levels, emphasizing the need for credible fiscal plans to ensure sustainable growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, extending Wall Street's rally on fresh hopes for coronavirus treatments. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.27% to 22,572.79, while the Topix index gained 1.28% to 1,554.87.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, extending rallies on Wall Street on fresh hopes for coronavirus treatments.

site_title: June reopening can't save Singapore's Q2 GDP, economists warn
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to contract by a median 11.3% in Q2, with most private-sector analysts predicting a double-digit decline, according to Bloomberg data. The June reopening may not be enough to boost growth, with economists warning of ongoing Covid-19 concerns and potential tightening of social restrictions. The Q2 GDP is forecast to be worse than the first quarter's 0.7% contraction, with some predicting a full-year contraction of 8.5% and a 5.7% decline for the full year.

site_title: Business, labour groups urge G-20 to extend, expand debt freeze for poorer countries
summary: The International Chamber of Commerce, International Trade Union Confederation, and Global Citizen have urged the G-20 to extend and expand a debt freeze for poorer countries, including middle-income nations, to help them weather the COVID-19 pandemic's economic fallout. The groups called for increased participation from private creditors and took note of the global economy's deeper downturn than initially projected. The G-20 finance ministers will meet on July 18 to discuss these issues.

site_title: Britain to spend £705m on EU border infrastructure
summary: Britain plans to spend £705 million on EU border infrastructure to maintain trade flow after its transition deal with the EU expires at the end of the year. The funding includes £470 million for port and inland infrastructure, primarily in south-east England. Cabinet Secretary Michael Gove expressed confidence that borders will be ready and secure by the end of the year, despite concerns about legal challenges and readiness. Discussions with the EU on a post-Brexit trade deal are ongoing, with "hopeful signs" but no clear timeline.

images.alt_text: Britain's Cabinet Secretary Michael Gove said there had been "movement" in the negotiations between Britain and the European Union about a post-transition trade deal.

site_title: Thai massage loses its charm behind masks
summary: Thai traditional massage is struggling to adapt to the Covid-19 era, with the human touch being limited by masks and social distancing guidelines. The industry, a major employer in Thailand's economy, is facing a decline in customers and revenue. Many massage shops have been forced to close, with over 140,000 therapists seeking unemployment assistance. The Thai government's shift towards luxury tourism and reduced mass tourism is expected to further exacerbate the industry's challenges, with the long-term survival of traditional massage in question.

site_title: Majority of US firms in Hong Kong concerned about security law: Amcham
summary: A majority of US companies in Hong Kong, surveyed by the American Chamber of Commerce, are concerned about the new national security law, with 51% extremely concerned and 36.6% somewhat concerned. The legislation has strained relations between the US and China, with 65% worried about its ambiguity and 61% concerned about the independence of Hong Kong's judicial system. Many respondents also fear the law will have a negative impact on their business, with 49% saying so, and consider moving assets or business out of Hong Kong, with 30% doing so in the medium-to-long term.

images.alt_text: A majority of US companies in Hong Kong surveyed by the American Chamber of Commerce (Amcham) are concerned about the sweeping new national security law in the global financial hub, with a third looking to move assets or business longer-term.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KLW Holdings reported a widened net loss of S$9.41 million for FY2020, down from S$1.38 million in FY2019, due to weakened macro-economic demand and the global impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue declined 13% to S$26.46 million. USP Group postponed three resolutions at its EGM due to an interim injunction application. LMIRT extended its long stop date for divestment of two properties to July 17, 2020, amid Covid-19 pandemic discussions.

site_title: US presses again for full school reopening, despite risks
summary: The US government is urging schools to reopen in the fall despite a surge in COVID-19 cases. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos said schools can reopen safely, but some areas may need to return to lockdowns. Top health official Admiral Brett Giroir warned that the virus will continue to rise, and deaths may increase in the next two to three weeks. The administration is preparing for a challenging fall, with the possibility of both COVID-19 and flu cases. President Trump has threatened to withhold federal funding from schools that don't reopen, but DeVos said there is no intention to take money away.

site_title: Empty Tokyo offices drag down property shares
summary: Office vacancies in Tokyo's five major business districts rose to 1.97% in June, marking the fourth consecutive month of increase. This surge is attributed to the pandemic, which has made tenants reluctant to sign leases and raised questions about the future of the office. Shares of real estate developers and owners, such as Tokyu Fudosan Holdings and Ichigo, fell as much as 4.6% and 6% respectively. Analysts predict further increases in vacancies, with some expecting a 3.9% vacancy rate by the end of the year.

site_title: US town grows money from trees during pandemic downturn
summary: Teno, a small town in Washington state, has revived an old idea during the pandemic downturn: printing its own currency on wooden planks. The town, with 1,800 residents, had become a ghost town with struggling small businesses. To boost the local economy, officials created a unique currency, with no trading or selling taking place. This unconventional move aims to stimulate the local economy and revitalize the town's streets.

site_title: A twist, but businesses still see stability, continuity after GE2020
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) in Singapore secured 83 out of 93 seats with 61.24% of the valid vote in the General Election (GE2020). Despite not gaining as strong a mandate as desired, economists and business groups remain optimistic about stability and continuity in the country's economic policy direction. The PAP's victory is seen as a good mandate, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasizing the need for policy continuity and cooperation with the opposition to address the country's economic challenges, particularly in the post-COVID-19 era.

site_title: Dr im Brahm-Droege continues adding to Dutech stake
summary: Singapore stocks gained 0.6% over the five trading sessions from July 3 to July 9, bringing the Straits Times Index's decline in total return for the 2020 year to 15.6%. Share buybacks totaled S$2.4 million, with Singapore Technologies Engineering leading the consideration tally. The market is set for a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, following a 9.8 times oversubscription of NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer.

site_title: Queries jump for developer of luxury apartments opposite Buckingham Palace
summary: Developer Northacre sees a surge in luxury apartment inquiries, tripling in the first half of 2020 compared to the same period last year. The company attributes this to the global pandemic, which is expected to increase demand for upmarket properties, and the UK's offer to provide Hong Kong residents with a path to UK citizenship. Despite Savills' prediction of a 2% decline in London's wealthiest neighborhoods, Northacre expects demand to be driven by buyers from Hong Kong, China, India, Nigeria, and Gulf countries, resulting in £60 million in sales last year.

site_title: Serving a different kind of crowd at Wimbledon
summary: Wimbledon's usual tennis tournament was cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic, but the All England Club has found alternative ways to utilize its resources. The 30 tonnes of strawberries typically consumed during the tournament have been preserved, and Hugh Lowe Farms in Kent will continue to supply the iconic fruit. The farm's pickers, including Katya Busheva, have been kept busy, and the venue's executive chef has adapted its signature dishes for local community members, providing a unique experience during the pandemic.

site_title: The world is drinking less coffee
summary: Global coffee consumption is expected to fall this year for the first time since 2011, with the US Department of Agriculture predicting a 2% decline. The pandemic has led to a significant decline in demand from cafes and restaurants, which account for about 25% of global demand. Many countries are expected to recover in the second half of the year, but a global second wave of infections could halt reopening plans. The decline in demand could have devastating effects on the 125 million people globally who depend on coffee for their livelihood, with futures for arabica beans predicted to drop 10% in the second half of the year.

site_title: Crisis management in the boardroom
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has reinforced the importance of crisis management frameworks for businesses to navigate through tough times. A framework covering three phases - preparing for crisis, responding to crises, and conducting post-crises reviews - is essential. Corporate boards play a crucial role in all phases, with a board risk committee providing oversight and advising management. Key activities include establishing a clear chain of command, calibrating responses, and communicating with stakeholders. Regular simulations and post-crisis reviews can strengthen crisis preparedness, and firms should adopt offensive postures to seize opportunities in the post-crisis landscape.

images.alt_text: Boards can play a role by requiring management to plan for simulations and report learning outcomes.

site_title: WP sees 'ample opportunity' to work with PSP if they take up NCMP seats: Sylvia Lim
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) is open to working with the government and other opposition parties, including the Progress Singapore Party (PSP), to ensure good outcomes for Singaporeans. Following the General Election, the PSP is likely to be offered the remaining two Non-Constituency MP (NCMP) seats, which could lead to a potential collaboration between the parties. WP chairman Sylvia Lim stated that there will be "ample opportunity" for collaboration in the coming years.

site_title: US targets French luxury, beauty giants in tariff retaliation
summary: The US plans to impose a 25% tariff on $1.3 billion worth of French luxury and beauty imports, targeting companies like LVMH, Kering, and L'Oreal, in retaliation for France's planned tax on Silicon Valley tech giants. The US intends to suspend the tariff for 180 days, with the possibility of lifting it if an international solution is reached. France's Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire has stated that France will apply its national tax if no international solution is found, escalating the ongoing digital tax dispute between the two nations.

site_title: Iran says forgetful operator triggered Ukraine jet crash
summary: Iran's Civil Aviation Organization has released a report blaming a forgetful operator for triggering the downing of Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752 in January, resulting in the deaths of 176 people. The operator mistakenly shot down the plane, mistaking it for a cruise missile, after forgetting to adjust the north direction on the radar system. Decoding of the jet's black boxes is expected to start on July 20, with six people arrested in connection with the incident.

site_title: Spain's home prices fall year-on-year for first time since 2017
summary: Spain's home prices have fallen year-on-year for the first time since 2017, according to two major real estate portals. Existing properties excluding new builds cost 1.9% less in the second quarter compared to the same period in 2019, while another portal reported a 2.4% drop. This marks the first time Spanish home prices have declined since 2017, indicating a shift in the country's housing market.

site_title: Positive developments in Covid-19 treatment lift stocks
summary: US stocks rose last week despite concerns about the COVID-19 pandemic, driven by hopes for a treatment and medical advances. The market is betting on a slow and problematic reopening of economies, with "stay-at-home" stocks such as Zoom and Microsoft leading gains. Economic data was mixed, with historic-high jobless claims and companies downsizing due to weak demand. Despite these challenges, the Nasdaq Composite is at a record high, up 20% for the year, with some strategists attributing this to positive developments in COVID-19 treatment and vaccine research.

site_title: A tale of two different but intertwined stories
summary: Global stock markets are retesting highs despite a dire economic situation, with experts attributing the disparity to time and perspective. Stock markets look ahead, anticipating an economic recovery, while the economy reflects the past, with depressed economic indicators. Central banks' intervention in asset markets and low interest rates have increased liquidity, driving investor optimism. However, experts warn of unsustainable levels of irrational exuberance and the risk of a second wave of infections. The current rally is driven by massive stimulus and government assistance plans, but large gains should be treated with caution, and volatility is expected to persist.

site_title: Opec readies next move in bid to avoid oil market's taper tantrum
summary: OPEC+ is poised to begin unwinding its output cuts, aiming to avoid a "taper tantrum" in the oil market. The alliance, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, has successfully doubled crude prices through unprecedented cuts, but fuel demand recovery threatens to undo this progress. As the US and Asia experience a resurgence in pandemic cases, OPEC+ will consider increasing supply to 7.7 million barrels, balancing the risk of prices crashing against the potential for a market tightening. The decision will be made on July 15 during an online meeting of the Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee.

site_title: Uncertainty persists in 3Q20 for STI
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) remains range-bound in the third quarter of 2020, with recent market movement driven by the reopening of countries and the rollback of COVID-19 restrictions. The index has bounced back from its lows in March, supported by a S$900 billion stimulus package and a strong uptrend momentum. However, a strong bullish run may be hard to achieve due to a resurgence in infection numbers, and the index may break below 2,600 if the COVID-19 situation worsens. A bullish scenario suggests the index may reach 2,842 and 3,014 in the near term, while a bearish scenario sees the index retesting March lows if it breaks below 2,600.

site_title: Up for grabs: Tokyo art exhibition invites theft
summary: A Tokyo art exhibition, titled "Stealable Art Exhibition," was open to enthusiastic visitors, but hours after closing, a crowd gathered to steal artworks. The police intervened for crowd control, allowing the pieces to be taken. The event was intentionally set up as a "theft," with all artworks being up for grabs. No damage or harm was reported, and the exhibition's goal was to spark conversation about art ownership and value.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights the correction in the Capesize market, with the timecharter average shedding 18% to $27,644. Pacific round and backhaul routes lost approximately 25% on the week, while Panamax and Supramax markets saw gains. The US Gulf and East Coast South America markets also experienced increases, with Handy vessels fixed at $7,000 and $11,050, respectively. Clean and VLCC markets firmed up, with rates rising 11 points for VLCC voyages and 3 points for Middle East Gulf to USG rates.

site_title: OCBC sees no long-term impact from Covid-19 on sustainable financing ambitions
summary: OCBC Bank expects COVID-19 to have no long-term impact on its sustainable financing ambitions, with a target of S$25 billion by 2025. Despite the pandemic, the bank is on track to meet its previous goal of S$10 billion by 2022, two years early. OCBC's head of structured finance and sustainable finance, Mike Ng, stated that the bank's value of sustainable financing loans in 2020 is expected to be comparable to last year's commitment of over S$5 billion. The bank's focus remains on achieving its sustainable finance goals.

site_title: China's banking watchdog warns of sharp rebound in bad loans
summary: China's banking watchdog, the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC), warns of a sharp rebound in bad loans due to delayed virus-relief incentives. The bad loan ratio rose 8 basis points to 2.1% as of June, with small and medium-sized financial institutions facing deteriorating asset quality and accumulated risks. The CBIRC urges lenders to prepare for a potential surge in non-performing loans, recommending that banks boost profit retention and limit bonuses. A combined shortfall of at least 350 billion yuan is expected in bad loan provisions to meet regulatory requirements.

site_title: NUS fintech course aims to ease supply crunch
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) has launched a two-month fintech course, NUS-FinTechSG, to address the supply crunch in the industry and boost local pipeline of financial technology professionals. The online programme, designed for students and mid-career changers without computing or tech expertise, will teach contemporary issues in fintech and provide opportunities to work with partner companies like UBS and Bank of Singapore. The course aims to make fintech accessible to those from diverse backgrounds and address the shortage of qualified candidates in the market.

images.alt_text: During the two-month NUS course, students will learn to integrate financial know-how across various domains such as lending, payments, insurance and regulation.

site_title: LMIRT further extends long stop date for divestment of two Indonesia malls
summary: LMIRT, the manager of Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust, has extended the long stop date for the proposed divestment of two Indonesia malls to July 17, 2020, due to discussions over amendments to the sale and purchase agreements. The divestments, valued at 1.28 trillion rupiah (S$123.1 million), were initially expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2020. The extension is related to the unforeseen impact of the Covid-19 pandemic in Indonesia.

site_title: USP takes three resolutions off its EGM after major shareholder's injunction
summary: USP Group, a major shareholder, has taken three resolutions off its Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM) agenda following an injunction issued by a substantial shareholder, Tanoto Sau Ian. The resolutions included allotting and issuing shares, granting awards and/or issuing shares under a performance share plan, and adopting a share purchase mandate. The injunction was filed on July 8 and granted on July 9, with USP agreeing not to table the resolutions unless they are limited to rights issues offered equally to all shareholders. The EGM is now scheduled for July 13 without these resolutions.

site_title: US dollar slides as vaccine news offsets surge in virus cases
summary: The US dollar declined last Friday, posting its largest weekly percentage loss in a month, as investors shifted their focus to a potential COVID-19 vaccine, outweighing concerns about rising infections. The dollar index fell 0.2% to 96.624, while the euro rose 0.2% and the British pound 0.1%. The yen reached a two-week low against the dollar, while the Chinese yuan dropped 0.2% to 7.0114. The decline in the US dollar was attributed to increased risk appetite in the market.

site_title: Spain's home prices fall year-on-year for first time since 2017
summary: Spain's home prices fell year-on-year for the first time since 2017, with existing properties costing 1.9% less in the second quarter compared to 2019, according to real estate portals Fotocasa and Hogaria. The downward trend is expected to worsen in the second half of 2020, particularly in secondary and rural markets.

site_title: Venice completes first test of all flood barriers
summary: Venice successfully completed its first test of its MOSE flood defense system, a complex engineering project designed to protect the lagoon city from high tides. The test involved moving all four barriers simultaneously, with each barrier consisting of 20 individual gates. The project, which has cost approximately 7 billion euros, aims to be operational by autumn 2021. The successful test follows years of delays and cost overruns, with Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte stating that the project has reached its "last mile."

site_title: Mandatory masks, Mickey at a distance as Walt Disney World reopens
summary: Walt Disney World reopened in Florida after a four-month closure due to the coronavirus pandemic, with limited capacity and safety measures in place. Guests wore face masks, underwent temperature screenings, and maintained social distancing. The resort welcomed a limited number of guests to its two most popular parks, Magic Kingdom and Animal Kingdom, with other parks to follow on Wednesday. Despite a surge in coronavirus cases in the state, many Disney fans and workers were eager for the reopening, and executives expressed confidence in their plan.

site_title: Startup city: Vietnam's young invest ideas in Ho Chi Minh
summary: Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City is emerging as a hub for innovation, with a young, educated, and digitally active population driving growth in the tech sector. The city has attracted significant investment from venture capital firms, with Vietnamese startups making up 18% of the capital invested in South-east Asia in 2019. Despite cumbersome regulations for foreigners, Vietnam's economy is expected to bounce back from the coronavirus pandemic, with the International Monetary Fund predicting a 2.7% expansion for the year. The country's affordable software engineers and understanding of emerging market consumers also make it an attractive destination for startups.

site_title: KLW Holdings FY2020 loss widens to S$9.41 million
summary: KLW Holdings reported a widened net loss of S$9.41 million for FY2020, compared to S$1.38 million in FY2019. Revenue declined 13% to S$26.46 million due to weakened macroeconomic demand and disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The group's factory in Malaysia was closed, and order shipments were affected. The company posted a loss per share of 0.17 Singapore cent and a net asset value per share of 1.16 Singapore cents. The Covid-19 pandemic is expected to continue impacting businesses worldwide, including KLW's property business.

site_title: 178 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 1 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 178 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 45,961, with one community case and one imported case. The majority of cases are migrant workers in dormitories. A cluster was also linked to a school in Jurong West, with 13-year-old students and staff members tested for the virus. The number of community cases has increased to 19 per day, with unlinked cases rising to nine per day.

site_title: DBS, Neo & Partners Global, win WatersTechnology Asia awards
summary: DBS Bank and Neo & Partners Global won awards at the WatersTechnology Asia Awards 2020, recognizing their excellence in deploying and managing financial information and technology. DBS won three awards, including best cloud migration project, best use of alternative data, and best use of machine learning for its Natural Language Processing Asset Hub. Neo & Partners Global was named the best infrastructure provider for its Trading-Atrium facility platform. The awards acknowledge the banks' innovative use of technology to enhance customer experience and accelerate business growth.

site_title: In first, Trump dons masks in visit to a military medical facility
summary: President Donald Trump wore a mask for the first time in public at a military medical facility outside Washington, marking a shift in his stance on wearing masks during the coronavirus pandemic. Trump had previously refused to wear a mask in public, but said it was a personal choice. The visit came as the US reported nearly 134,000 COVID-19 deaths and new cases surged by over 69,000. Critics say Trump's refusal to wear a mask showed a lack of leadership, and his administration's push to reopen economies despite rising cases has been criticized as irresponsible.

site_title: Falcon Energy Group and subsidiary file affidavits ahead of Monday hearing
summary: Falcon Energy Group and its subsidiary Asetanian Marine have filed affidavits with revised scheme documents ahead of a Monday hearing. The hearing for creditor votes on a compromise or scheme of arrangement will now start at 2.45pm. The companies also applied to hold scheme meetings by video conference and seek a consequential extension of moratoriums. This comes as the companies face debt issues.

site_title: Thailand plans Nov human testing for potential coronavirus vaccine
summary: Thailand plans to begin human trials of a potential coronavirus vaccine in November, with 10,000 doses prepared, aiming for a vaccine ready for use by late 2021. Following favourable results in primate trials, the next step is to manufacture doses for human trials. The vaccine development programme, led by Chulalongkorn University, aims to produce a vaccine that could provide protection against the new coronavirus.

site_title: Wall Street's Big Tech enthusiasm getting stronger
summary: Tech stocks continue to rise, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching records in six of the last seven sessions. Investors' confidence in tech companies benefiting from the "stay-at-home" trade has driven the sector's growth, outpacing the broader market. Analysts predict the biggest tech giants could gain another 30% this year, with some seeing the sector as a clear winner in the current market environment.

site_title: Manchester City to learn fate of Champions League ban appeal
summary: Manchester City is set to learn the fate of its Champions League ban appeal on Monday. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) will deliver its verdict on the English side's appeal against a two-season ban from European competitions, which UEFA imposed in February due to alleged financial fair play (FFP) breaches between 2012 and 2016. City has denied any wrongdoing, with owner Sheikh Mansour's Abu Dhabi United Group linked to the allegations. A decision could have significant implications for the club's Abu Dhabi project and UEFA's FFP rules.

site_title: Italy's government bonds are euro area's 'high-yielding play' of the summer
summary: Italy's government bonds are attracting investors with high yields, making them the "high-yielding play" in the euro area. The 10-year bonds offer a 1.2% yield, higher than Greek notes, and investors are seeking a steady return with low volatility. The global pandemic has not deterred investors, and the European Central Bank's stimulus has helped ease concerns of a debt crisis. Italy's bonds have returned 2% this year, comparable to German debt, and investors are betting on a recovery deal between EU member states to boost the euro area.

site_title: Election outcome may lift 'animal spirits', prompt closer reading of opposition policy ideas
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) won 61.24% of the votes in the General Election, a decline from its 69.9% in 2015. The opposition Workers' Party (WP) unexpectedly gained control of a second Group Representation Council (GRC). The election outcome may boost investor confidence and encourage closer reading of the WP's policy proposals, which could offer alternative perspectives on business issues. The WP's proposals include a national minimum wage, redundancy insurance, and an EXIM Bank to finance SMEs' internationalization. This shift could lead to a more diverse political landscape and influence market sentiment.

site_title: Amazon begins rolling out bigger UPS and FedEx-style delivery trucks
summary: Amazon has begun rolling out a new fleet of larger delivery trucks, similar to those used by UPS and FedEx, to combat delivery delays. The company ordered over 2,200 heavy-duty trucks from Shyft Group and is deploying them to contractors in various locations. The new trucks can carry more and bigger packages, but some drivers have expressed concerns about their weight and maneuverability. Amazon aims to improve its one- and two-day delivery times, which have been affected by the pandemic, to meet customer expectations.

site_title: Ubisoft announces staff departures after misconduct allegations
summary: Ubisoft announced staff departures following an internal review into allegations of misconduct, primarily sexual misconduct charges. The company's chief creative officer, managing director of its Canadian studios, and global head of human resources have resigned, effective immediately. The changes aim to improve "workplace culture." Ubisoft stated the departures were a response to the allegations, which led to the review.

site_title: GE2020: WP sees 'ample opportunity' to work with PSP if they take up NCMP seats: Sylvia Lim
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) is open to collaborating with the Progress Singapore Party (PSP) in Parliament, given the PSP's likely allocation of the two remaining Non-Constituency MP (NCMP) seats. WP chairman Sylvia Lim stated that there will be opportunities for collaboration in the coming years to move the agenda forward and play a constructive opposition role. This collaboration could be a significant development, as WP is the top loser in the General Election, while PSP was the best-performing loser in West Coast GRC.

site_title: Huawei to request UK to delay 5G network removal: The Times
summary: Huawei has requested a meeting with UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson to delay its removal from the country's 5G phone network until after elections in June 2025, in hopes of reversing the decision. The company will pledge to maintain its equipment in the UK's 2G, 3G, and 4G networks. This comes amid pressure from the US and some British lawmakers to ban Huawei due to security concerns. China's ambassador to London warned that removing Huawei would send a "very bad message" to Chinese business.

site_title: Poland votes in tight presidential election
summary: Poles cast ballots in a closely contested presidential election between incumbent President Andrzej Duda, backed by the populist Law and Justice party, and opposition candidate Rafal Trzaskowski, who seeks to restore ties with the European Union. The result will determine the future of the PiS government and its influence over Poland's democratic freedoms. The vote is seen as a clash of visions for Poland, with Duda's conservative views pitted against Trzaskowski's liberal stance.

images.alt_text: The result will be decisive for the future of Poland's Law and Justice (PiS) party government, which critics accuse of rolling back hard-won democratic freedoms three decades after the fall of communism.

site_title: Hong Kong gets zero fee trading in blow to struggling brokers
summary: Huatai International, a Hong Kong arm of China's third-largest broker, has started offering zero-fee trading, with a monthly fee of HK$8, in a move that could deepen the pain for the city's struggling brokers. The firm has seen a surge in customers, with a significant increase in new users over the past month. This move follows Charles Schwab's US discount broker model, which has led to a fee war in the industry. The development could pressure rivals, who are already facing thin margins due to competition from online trading and mainland China rivals.

site_title: Fed watchers rein in estimates of how big balance sheet will get
summary: The Federal Reserve's balance sheet is expected to peak at a smaller size than initially anticipated, falling below $7 trillion, due to improved trading conditions and low demand for emergency lending programs. The Fed's balance sheet fell for a fourth straight week, with estimates now ranging from $7.6 trillion to $8 trillion, down from previous projections of $9 trillion. This decline is attributed to reduced utilization of backstop programs and lower take-up of emergency lending programs, including the Main Street Lending Program.

site_title: Tesla shaves US$3,000 off Model Y price months after sales start
summary: Tesla has reduced the starting price of its Model Y crossover by $3,000, bringing it to $49,990, four months after sales began. This is the second significant price cut in six weeks, following a $5,000 reduction for the Model S and X and a $2,000 cut for the Model Y. The price decrease was seen as a bearish signal of demand, but Tesla still delivered 90,650 cars in the second quarter, beating analysts' estimates and driving up its stock price 269% this year.

site_title: WHO urges aggressive virus measures as flare-ups spark new closures
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has urged countries to step up control measures against the coronavirus, citing exponential growth in cases worldwide. Countries such as Uzbekistan, Hong Kong, and Australia have implemented new restrictions, including lockdowns and school closures. WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus emphasized the need for aggressive action and national unity to turn the pandemic around. The virus has killed at least 556,140 people worldwide and over 12.3 million cases have been registered in 196 countries and territories.

site_title: Motorhomes come of age as Europe relaxes lockdowns
summary: As Europe relaxes lockdowns, motorhomes are gaining popularity, with a recent survey showing 90% of Spaniards preferring to stay in Spain rather than travel abroad. This shift is driven by the desire for social distancing and freedom, with 83% opting to use their own car over public transport. Industry figures show a surge in motorhome rentals, with over 32,500 bookings in Europe in June, and 9,435 in Spain. Experts believe the health crisis will accelerate a shift away from mass tourism and towards national tourism, with motorhomes offering a sense of freedom and flexibility.

site_title: Exxon restarts drilling at offshore hotspot in political crisis
summary: ExxonMobil has resumed drilling operations in Guyana, despite a political crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's four drillships, two of which are currently operational, resumed work after Guyana closed its borders. The resumption comes as Exxon faces a US$6 billion expansion project, the Payara project, which is facing delays due to a political standoff between President David Granger and the opposition. The project's start production date may be pushed back by up to a year, and the prolonged uncertainty is affecting the region's oil and natural gas industry.

site_title: Netflix, Amazon and Nvidia get Street-high targets on Covid-19 lift
summary: Analysts have raised price targets for Netflix, Amazon, and Nvidia, citing the pandemic's acceleration of long-term growth trends. Netflix's target was lifted to $670, while Amazon's target rose to $3,550. Nvidia's target increased to $500. The companies have seen significant gains this year, with Netflix up 65%, Amazon up 65%, and Nvidia up 80%. Despite this, Netflix's target is still 16% below current levels, and analysts are cautious about the company's valuation.

site_title: US slaps French goods with 25% duties in digital tax row, but delays effective date
summary: The US has announced 25% duties on French cosmetics and handbags worth $1.3 billion, in response to France's digital services tax, but will delay implementation for up to 180 days. The decision follows a US Section 301 probe finding the French tax discriminates against US tech firms. The move is part of the US's efforts to address digital service taxes in 10 countries, including Britain and India. The US and France have agreed to defer collection of the French tax, and the US will continue to discuss the issue with the OECD.

site_title: Cash-strapped New Jersey to borrow up to US$9.9b under deal
summary: New Jersey is set to borrow up to $9.9 billion to address a budget shortfall of up to $20 billion caused by the coronavirus economic shutdown. The state will tap into the US Federal Reserve's municipal liquidity facility, with a one-year loan expected to be taken up by the Senate next week. The borrowing will help address the financial crisis caused by the virus, with Governor Phil Murphy stating the state "is out of money." The move comes as the state struggles with 176,575 coronavirus cases, the fifth-highest in the US.

site_title: Amazon's Kuiper satellite plan wins backing of FCC chairman
summary: Amazon's Kuiper satellite plan, aiming to provide high-speed broadband service to consumers worldwide, has received backing from FCC chairman Ajit Pai. Pai requested conditions on the proposed service, which is likely to result in approval in closed-door voting. Amazon founder Jeff Bezos plans to launch 3,236 small satellites in low orbits to address internet coverage gaps. This move follows SpaceX's launch of over 480 satellites, with plans for 12,000 more. The FCC coordinates trajectories and radio-frequency use for such satellite constellations.

images.alt_text: "Satellite constellations like this aim to provide high-speed broadband service to consumers in the US and around the world," Ajit Pai said in a tweet on Friday. Mr Pai added that he had called for conditions on the proposed service by Amazon subsidiary Kuiper Systems without specifying them.

site_title: PAP's narrower margin at stronghold of Marine Parade a surprise
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) secured a narrower winning margin in the Marine Parade Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in a sample count, with 57% of the vote, compared to the Workers' Party's 43%. The results are seen as a surprise, given the PAP's strong campaign and incumbency. Analysts attribute the results to a stable base of voters for the Workers' Party, a strong team, and underlying unhappiness among voters in the constituency. The PAP also performed well in other strongholds, but analysts warn that the incumbent teams will need to establish rapport with residents and address municipal issues to win re-election.

site_title: US records 63,643 new virus cases in 24 hours
summary: The US recorded 63,643 new coronavirus cases in 24 hours, bringing the total to 3.18 million cases and 133,969 deaths, according to a Johns Hopkins University tracker. This marks the worst-hit country in the world by the pandemic.

site_title: Hedge funds would get to keep lots of trades secret in SEC plan
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is considering a plan that would exempt hedge funds with less than $3.5 billion in equities from quarterly reporting of their investments. The proposal would save smaller fund managers $136 million annually and allow them to keep 90% of their trades secret, while still allowing 90% of reported trades to remain publicly disclosed. The move is seen as an effort to ease regulatory requirements for smaller companies, prioritized by SEC Chairman Jay Clayton.

site_title: NHL, players union agree to restart season on Aug 1
summary: The National Hockey League (NHL) and the players' union have agreed to restart the season on August 1, with a four-year extension of the collective bargaining agreement through the 2025-26 season. The deal includes a health and safety framework, with daily Covid-19 testing for all players and staff, and a quarantine bubble of up to 31 players per team. Training camps will open on July 26, followed by a 24-team tournament in Canadian cities Edmonton and Toronto.

site_title: Singapore retains top global shipping hub for 7th year running
summary: Singapore has retained its top position as the global shipping hub for the seventh consecutive year, according to the 2020 Xinhua-Baltic International Shipping Centre Development (ISCD) Index. The city-state's advantages in geographical location, shipping industry ecosystem, and supportive government policies contributed to its pole position. London rose to second place, while Shanghai climbed to third, with Hong Kong falling to fourth due to decreased cargo throughput. Singapore's CEO welcomed the news, emphasizing the need for a global and coordinated effort to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Workers' Party strengthens grip on Hougang
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) secured a victory in the Hougang single-member constituency (SMC) in Singapore, retaining the seat it has held since 1991. WP candidate Dennis Tan won 58% of the votes, while PAP's Lee Hong Chuang secured 42%. This victory strengthens the WP's grip on the ward and reflects the party's successful leadership transition under new leader Pritam Singh. Observers say voters have kept faith with the party, demonstrating its credibility as an opposition party in the constituency.

site_title: Venture-backed Silver Peak is said to explore US$1b sale
summary: Silver Peak Systems, a networking company backed by venture capital firms Greylock Partners and TCV, is exploring a potential US$1 billion sale. The Santa Clara, California-based company, founded in 2004, helps its customers manage their infrastructure and cloud computing services. No plans are final, and the company may opt to remain independent. Competitors include Cisco Systems, Arista Networks, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise. TCV invested US$90 million in Silver Peak in 2018, and the company has raised over US$200 million since its founding.

site_title: Amazon.com bans, then un-bans TikTok app from employee mobile devices
summary: Amazon.com banned and then unbanned the TikTok app from employee mobile devices in a span of a few hours on Friday. The ban was reversed after discussions between TikTok and Amazon representatives. The move came amid concerns over the Chinese-owned social media platform sharing information with the Chinese government, with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo suggesting a potential ban. The reversal of the ban was attributed to a mistake by Amazon executives.

site_title: Google to restrict ads for tracking technology, spyware
summary: Google will restrict ads for spyware and unauthorized tracking technology starting August 11. The policy change will prohibit ads for spyware, GPS trackers, and cameras marketed to spy on individuals without consent. Advertisers found violating the policy will have their accounts suspended. The move aims to prevent the promotion of products that track or monitor people without their authorization, aligning with Google's Enabling Dishonest Behavior policy.

site_title: Libya army says blockade on oil will continue
summary: The Libyan National Army (LNA) led by Khalifa Haftar has announced it will maintain a blockade on oil production and exports, costing the country $6.50 billion in lost revenue. The blockade, which began on Friday, has led to the lifting of force majeure on all exports by the National Oil Corp (NOC). The LNA demands that revenue flow into a new bank account outside Libya, not fund "terrorists and mercenaries," and undergo an audit of central bank accounts. The blockade is the latest development in Libya's ongoing civil war, which has divided the country since 2014.

images.alt_text: Khalifa Haftar's Libyan National Army (LNA) said on Saturday it would maintain a blockade on oil production and exports that the National Oil Corp (NOC) says has cost the country US$6.50 billion in lost revenue.

site_title: Oil rises as International Energy Agency boosts demand forecast
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Friday after the International Energy Agency (IEA) increased its 2020 demand forecast. US energy firms cut the number of oil and natural gas rigs to a record low for the 10th week, supporting prices. Despite this, record-breaking new coronavirus cases in the US tempered expectations for a fast recovery in fuel consumption. Brent crude settled at $43.24 a barrel and US oil at $40.55 a barrel.

site_title: Gold slips as higher equities weigh despite rising virus cases
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,797.89 per ounce, despite rising virus cases, due to gains in US equities. This marks a fifth straight weekly gain for gold, which reached its highest level since 2011. The decline in gold prices is attributed to increased flows into equities, despite surging Covid-19 cases.

site_title: PAP retains Potong Pasir SMC with reduced margin
summary: The People's Action Party's (PAP) Sitoh Yih Pin won his third term for Potong Pasir SMC, securing 60.69% of the votes, a lower margin than his 2015 victory. He defeated Singapore People's Party (SPP) chairman Jose Raymond, who received 39.31% of the votes. This marks the first time the SPP has contested the constituency without the "Chiam" factor, which was previously held by opposition icon Chiam See Tong.

site_title: JetBlue founder bucks airline slump with startup planning October debut
summary: Breeze Aviation Group, a startup airline backed by JetBlue founder David Neeleman, plans to start charter flights in October with an operating certificate from defunct carrier Compass Airlines. The US Transportation Department must approve the purchase. Breeze aims to begin scheduled service in May 2026, initially based in Minneapolis-St. Paul. The faster route to approval allows Breeze to launch charter flights sooner than initially seeking new carrier approval. The price of the certificate has not been disclosed.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps with financials; Gilead data offsets virus fears
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, with the Nasdaq posting its sixth record closing high in seven days, driven by a positive analysis on Gilead Sciences' antiviral Covid-19 treatment and a surge in financial shares. The S&P 500 financials index rose 3.5% and bank shares increased significantly ahead of their financial results next week. Despite a record rise in US coronavirus cases, investor worries were soothed, and the S&P 500 and Dow also reached fresh records.

site_title: What's next for the travel industry?
summary: The travel industry is navigating a challenging period following the COVID-19 pandemic, with hotel occupancy decreasing by an average of 27% in Asia-Pacific. However, organizations should use this lull period to assess their business and plan for new guest scenarios when operations resume. Key considerations include strong leadership, internal communication, and staff training to address post-pandemic concerns. As domestic travel resumes, businesses must be prepared to adapt to new consumer patterns and enhance measures for guests, working closely with government and health authorities to ensure a smooth recovery.

site_title: Brooks Brothers gets bankruptcy loan with zero interest rate
summary: Brooks Brothers, the iconic American clothing brand, has secured an $80 million loan with a zero interest rate and no closing fees as part of its bankruptcy reorganisation. The loan, facilitated by a competition between WHP Global and a partnership between Authentic Brands Group and Simon Property Group, will allow the company to fund its operations case while it tries to find a buyer. The company had previously arranged a $75 million DIP loan from WHP Global, but the new loan provides more time to close any sale and eliminates an early repayment penalty.

site_title: Europe: Upbeat economic data helps shares snap three-day losing run
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Friday, breaking a three-day losing streak, after upbeat industrial output data from Italy and France raised hopes of an economic recovery. Italy's production rose 42.1% in May, and France's production jumped 19.6%. Despite a spike in coronavirus cases worldwide, analysts expect a 53.9% fall in profit for Stoxx 600-listed companies in the second quarter. The European Central Bank meeting and a European Union summit next week are also on investors' radar, with a potential 750 billion euro recovery fund being discussed.

images.alt_text: European shares rose on Friday after upbeat industrial output data from Italy and France raised hopes of an economic recovery, even as a spike in coronavirus cases around the world kept gains in check.

site_title: GE2020: WP takes three constituencies; Pritam Singh says much work to do
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) secured 10 seats in Singapore's Parliament, winning three constituencies, including a newly carved out Sengkang GRC. WP's Pritam Singh was formally designated as the leader of the opposition by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, who congratulated him on the party's showing. WP took 52.13% of the votes in Sengkang, 61.19% in Hougang, and defended their seats in Aljunied.

site_title: LinkedIn sued for spying on users with apps for Apple devices
summary: LinkedIn has been sued for allegedly spying on users with its apps for Apple devices. The lawsuit claims the company's apps used Apple's Universal Clipboard to read and siphon sensitive information without users' knowledge. The apps could also draw information from other Apple devices. The class-action lawsuit seeks to represent users who allegedly suffered from federal and California privacy law violations and a breach of contract claim. LinkedIn has stated it is reviewing the lawsuit, but denies storing or transmitting clipboard contents.

site_title: Local flavours on tap at Ah Sam Cold Drink Stall
summary: Ah Sam Cold Drink Stall, a Singaporean bar, has reopened at Haji Lane after relocating from Boat Quay due to the pandemic. The bar now focuses on "fresh from the tap" cocktails, offering light and refreshing alternatives to traditional spirit-forward drinks. The menu features local flavors, including the iconic Tak Qiu or Milo Old Fashioned, and hawker food options. The bar's new concept aims to provide a welcoming space for patrons to "forget the worries of daily life" and enjoy local flavors.

site_title: Reits (July 11-12, 2020)
summary: Realtors and investors are facing increasing challenges as US mortgage rates climb after five weeks of declines, affecting demand for Singapore prime projects. Manhattan rents hit a record high, with more increases expected. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounds to a six-month high. Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail asset in Seoul. New World Group is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal. Meanwhile, WeWork secures new tenants at its Singapore location, filling more space after its post-bankruptcy recovery.

site_title: WP's young guns win over Sengkang with focus on social issues
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) won the Sengkang Group Representation Consortium (GRC) election with 52.13% of the valid votes, making it the second GRC to fall into opposition hands. The WP team, comprising three first-time candidates and a lawyer, successfully harnessed social media and struck a chord with young families and systemic issues. The victory marks a historic upset and signals a promising future for Singapore's opposition parties, potentially breaching the PAP's supermajority.

site_title: PAP retains Ang Mo Kio with 71.91% of votes
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has retained Ang Mo Kio group representation constituency with 71.91% of votes, winning 124,430 votes. The PAP team, led by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, defeated the Reform Party team with 48,600 votes. This is a decline in PAP's vote share compared to 2015, with 6.72 percentage points lost. Despite this, PAP is expected to remain in power, with Prime Minister Lee thanking voters for their support.

site_title: Elon Musk soars past Warren Buffett on billionaires ranking
summary: Elon Musk's net worth rose $6.1 billion, surpassing billionaire Warren Buffett, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Musk, 49, is now the world's seventh-richest person, with his Tesla stock and majority ownership of SpaceX contributing to his $70.5 billion fortune. Shares of Tesla have surged 269% this year, making Musk the highest-paid CEO in the US. Experts warn of a speculative bubble in the tech market, citing high valuations and economic uncertainty, as Musk's wealth surpasses Buffett's for the first time.

images.alt_text: The fortune of Tesla's founder rose US$6.1 billion on Friday, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, after the carmaker's stock surged 11 per cent. Elon Musk is now the world's seventh-richest person, also ahead of tech titans Larry Ellison and Sergey Brin.

site_title: Top tips for well-designed rooms
summary: A well-designed bedroom is crucial for a restful sleep. To create a bedroom you love, identify the look that makes you feel good and select elements that work together to foster the desired atmosphere. Proper bedding is also essential, considering factors like sleeping position, posture, and personal habits to choose the best mattress and pillows for your needs.
