site_title: Gap plans to compensate suppliers for cancelled orders
summary: Gap Inc plans to compensate suppliers for cancelled orders, working collaboratively to provide full payment for finished goods and goods in production. The company is also extending payment terms and offering low-cost financing to suppliers. This move comes as the apparel industry struggles with economic lockdowns, reduced discretionary spending, and store closures. Gap's net sales fell 43% in the latest quarter, and the cancelled orders represent less than 3% of total value. The company aims to help suppliers liquidate products and find alternative uses for uncut raw materials.

images.alt_text: Gap Inc will work collaboratively with its vendors to compensate them in full for finished goods and goods in production that were cancelled or subject to pack and hold.

site_title: Hyflux gets another letter of interest
summary: Hyflux received a letter of interest from Unilegend Investments, a Singapore-incorporated firm, on behalf of an unnamed investor. The investor is reportedly interested in providing Hyflux with working capital for desalination projects in China. This is the latest in a series of unsolicited approaches from investors, following previous expressions of interest from other parties. The details of the proposed investment remain unclear.

site_title: WP fends off PAP to retain Aljunied GRC with bigger margin
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) retained Aljunied GRC in Singapore's 2020 General Election with 60% of the votes, a nearly 10 percentage-point improvement from the 2015 election. WP's victory is seen as a significant milestone, making it harder for the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) to wrest it away in the next election. Political observers believe WP's strong showing could help the party maintain control over the constituency for an extended period, with some predicting it could become the second party in a two-party system.

site_title: Incumbency advantage, brand name key to PAP wins in SMC strongholds
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) dominated Singapore's 14 single-member constituencies (SMCs) in the 2020 general election, securing 13 seats. In traditional PAP strongholds such as Radin Mas, Mountbatten, and MacPherson, the party's incumbents won by wide margins, with some securing over 70% of the votes. Observers attribute the PAP's success to the brand name and the familiarity of its candidates, who have strong followings on the ground. The party's ability to connect with older voters and younger voters also contributed to its wins.

site_title: Copper stages rare rally with gold, hitting highest in a year
summary: Copper prices hit their highest in over a year, rallying 2.1% to $6,360 a tonne, driven by stronger demand and tightening supply. The metal's 45% gain since mid-March is attributed to an unexpected boom in Chinese demand and supply constraints in South America. Copper is also rallying alongside gold, with spot bullion prices reaching a 11-year high. Goldman Sachs predicts gold prices will reach $2,000 an ounce and copper will hit $6,500 a tonne within the next 12 months.

site_title: PAP scores narrow win against PSP in West Coast GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) secured a narrow win in the West Coast Group Representation Constituency (GRC) with 51.7% of the votes, defeating the Progress Singapore Party (PSP) led by former PAP MP Tan Cheng Bock with 48.3%. The PSP's strong showing, attributed to Dr. Tan's social media engagement and rapport with residents, may lead to the party securing a non-constituency MP seat.

site_title: GE2020: WP retains Hougang SMC with 61.19% votes
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) retained its stronghold at the Hougang single member constituency with 61.19% of the votes, defeating People's Action Party (PAP) candidate Lee Hong Chuang who received 38.81%. WP's candidate, Dennis Tan, has become the fourth WP MP elected since 1991, with victory seen as "never in doubt" by voters.

site_title: In financial services, we don't trust
summary: The financial services industry faces a persistent perception of distrust due to scandals and controversies. A global survey found 45% of respondents believed financial hardships would lead to unethical actions, with the highest fear in North America and lowest in Latin America. To build trust, the industry must demonstrate continuous integrity in practice and culture. A collaborative effort is needed, involving firms, consumers, and regulators. Steps include adopting improved professional codes and standards, prioritizing customers, and enforcing consequences for wrongdoing. Collective action by consumers, regulators, and firms can help create a culture of trust, but the industry must take proactive steps to address its reputation.

site_title: Voting hours extended for the first time amid long queues
summary: Singapore's Elections Department extended voting hours for the first time, keeping polling stations open until 10pm due to long queues. The extension, announced at 7pm, was made to allow all voters to cast their votes amid the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the move was questioned by several parties, citing concerns over its legality and potential impact on the democratic process. As of 8pm, 96% of registered voters had cast their ballots, with 2,565,000 voters voting in the general election.

site_title: World's wealthy can store their riches in a Swiss mountain vault
summary: Switzerland is set to offer wealthy individuals rock vaults carved into the Alps as a secure storage option, following in the footsteps of its existing mountain vaults. The idea comes from entrepreneurs in central Switzerland. The project is located in the Bruenig massif, about 40km south-west of Lucerne. This new option aims to cater to those seeking ultra-secure storage for their prized possessions.

site_title: Top South Korean officials sell apartments amid property price furore
summary: South Korean top officials, including Chief of Staff Noh Young-min, are selling their apartments amid a surge in property prices. The move comes ahead of the government's announcement to tighten property rules and impose heavier taxes on multiple homeowners. Despite over 20 cooling measures in three years, prices continue to rise, and public frustration has led to a decline in President Moon Jae-in's approval ratings. The sale of high-ranking officials' houses is seen as a moral gesture, but its impact on the market is uncertain, with experts stating that it may only provide signals of future regulations.

site_title: Sime Darby seeks details after activist group petitions US to ban its palm oil
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation has asked for more information after an activist group petitioned the US to ban its palm oil due to alleged labor abuse. The Hong Kong-based antitrafficking group made claims of forced and child labor on Sime Darby estates, prompting the company to investigate. If found non-compliant, Sime Darby vows to address the breaches firmly. The allegations could harm Malaysia's efforts to brand its palm products as sustainable, as anti-palm oil sentiment increases internationally.

images.alt_text: Malaysia is the world's second largest producer and exporter of palm oil, which is found in everything from chocolate to lipstick. It has in recent years battled criticisms of rampant clearing of tropical forest for new plantations and poor treatment of workers.

site_title: Harness the power of the home
summary: Post-Covid, homes are being redesigned to prioritize wellness, with changes including clean air systems, hygienic materials, and acoustic upgrades. These updates aim to improve mental and physical health, as well as provide personal space and reevaluate open-plan room layouts. Research has shown that design choices can impact brain activity, hormones, and mood, with targeted design changes potentially boosting immunity, concentration, and creativity. By harnessing the power of the home, individuals can improve their well-being and create a platform for happiness and health.

site_title: People connector
summary: ACCA executive director (Markets) Leong Soo Yee has been instrumental in supporting the local business community, particularly small audit firms, to venture overseas and leverage technology. She has led ACCA's efforts to provide opportunities and promote diversity in the workforce, aiming to connect people around the world. Leong, who has been separated from her child during the pandemic, has spoken about the importance of taking risks and being ambitious, qualities she attributes to her late father's influence. She believes that change in gender diversity will require time and tiny steps, and that the accountancy profession will need to adapt to the changing ecosystem, incorporating skills such as digital intelligence and emotional intelligence.

site_title: GE2020: WP retains Aljunied GRC with almost 60% of votes
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) retained Aljunied GRC with 59.93% of votes, a nearly 10 percentage-point improvement over 2015, defeating the ruling People's Action Party (PAP). images.alt_text: WP candidates for Aljunied GRC Pritam Singh, Leon Perera; Gerald Giam and Faisal Manap at a walkabout at 209 Kovan Hawker Centre on July 8.

site_title: Heng's last-minute move to East Coast GRC pays off
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) won the East Coast Group Representation Constituency (GRC) with 53.41% of valid votes, defeating the opposition Workers' Party (WP). Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat's last-minute move to the constituency is seen as a strategic effort to prevent the WP from gaining a foothold. Analysts attribute the close result to the PAP's efforts, despite expectations of a tighter race.

site_title: Derivatives trading spikes as investors embrace risk in volatile markets
summary: Derivatives trading has seen a surge in Singapore, reflecting a rise in sophistication among retail investors. However, the increased use of these products also heightens the risk of losses due to a lack of understanding. Historically, derivatives have been beneficial during economic downturns, allowing investors to leverage gains. However, the current market volatility has led to a spike in derivatives trading, with brokerages warning of potential losses. Retail traders, in particular, are at risk due to their limited experience and understanding of these complex products.

site_title: GE2020: PAP takes Mountbatten SMC with big win
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) candidate Lim Biow Chuan won the Mountbatten SMC with a decisive victory, receiving 16,227 votes (73.84%) against Peoples Voice's Sivakumaran Chellappa's 5,748 votes (26.16%). Lim improved his majority, citing residents' feedback to the government to make Mountbatten a better place. This is Lim's second win in the SMC, following his 2011 and 2015 victories.

site_title: GE2020: PAP takes 61.24% of the valid vote, loses a second GRC to WP
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) secured 61.24% of the valid vote in Singapore's 2020 General Election, winning 83 out of 93 seats. However, the PAP lost a second group representation constituency (GRC) to the Workers' Party (WP), marking the first time the party has lost a GRC since independence. The WP, which fielded 10 candidates, secured a record 10 seats in the Parliament, while the opposition parties saw significant swings away from the PAP in many constituencies.

site_title: SDP leaders put up strong fight in GE2020
summary: SDP leaders, particularly chairman Paul Tambyah, put up a strong fight in the 2020 general election, winning 46.26% of the votes in Bukit Panjang SMC. images.alt_text: SDP chairman Paul Tambyah, 55, polled 46.26 per cent of the vote in Bukit Batok SMC, against PAP's Liang Eng Hwa.

site_title: GE2020: PAP takes 74.03% of votes for Radin Mas SMC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) won the Radin Mas Single Member Constituency (SMC) in Singapore's 2020 General Election, securing 74.03% of the votes. The constituency has remained unchanged since its formation in 1976.

site_title: US: Wall Street flat at open after record rise in US Covid-19 cases
summary: US stocks opened flat on Friday amid concerns over a record rise in coronavirus cases, which may impact Corporate America. The Dow Jones fell 0.06%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records. Despite this, investors remained cautious due to tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: PAP retains supermajority but with lower vote share
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) is set to retain its two-thirds super-majority in Singapore's General Election, securing 83 out of 93 seats with a record-low vote share of 61.7%. The Workers' Party (WP) claimed 10 seats, including Sengkang, Aljunied, and Hougang, marking its second-ever group representation constituency (GRC) win. The opposition saw a record 10 candidates elected to the next Parliament, with the PSP and SDA also performing well. The PAP's best GRC showing was in Jurong GRC, where the team led by Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam took 74.62% of the sample count vote.

site_title: Coronavirus has brought the welfare state back, and it might be here to stay
summary: Governments worldwide have increased welfare state generosity in response to the Covid-19 crisis, mirroring the post-World War II era. This shift may be permanent if voters perceive the pandemic as a lasting risk to their incomes and demand more social insurance payments. However, the economic and health impacts have disproportionately affected low-skilled workers, raising concerns that a more generous welfare state may only benefit this group. For a permanently more generous welfare state, electorates must believe the pandemic poses an enduring risk to their livelihoods and vote for governments to protect their incomes.

site_title: GE2020: WP beats PAP in Sengkang GRC with 52.13% of votes
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) won the Sengkang GRC in Singapore's 2020 General Election, securing 52.13% of the valid votes with 60,136 votes. Analysts attribute the WP's success to its new chief Pritam Singh's leadership and the concerns of young voters in the area. The win reflects a shift in voter perception, with many looking for alternative perspectives amidst the current crisis.

site_title: PTT sells Asia's longest US dollar bond, raises US$700m
summary: PTT, Thailand's largest energy company, sold a 50-year US dollar bond, raising US$700 million in Asia's longest dollar corporate debt deal. The bond was priced at 3.7% yield. This is the longest tenor for a US dollar debt transaction in the Asian region for a corporate. The deal is part of a trend towards longer-dated tenors in the region, driven by pension funds seeking assets to match distant liabilities and low interest rates.

site_title: The big gets bigger, the expensive more expensive
summary: The US stock market has seen a widening gap between large and small companies since the COVID-19 pandemic, with the top 10 stocks in the S&P 500 performing better than smaller companies. The median market capitalization for the top 10 stocks is around $569 billion, with investors willing to pay a premium for their shares. In contrast, smaller companies have declined by 25% so far this year. This trend is also seen in Japan, where the top 10 stocks outperformed smaller companies. Experts attribute this to the US's globalized economy and the ease of investing in US markets, as well as the limited attention bandwidth of consumers.

site_title: International Healthway co-founders 'conspired' to injure company: High Court
summary: A Singapore High Court has found that two co-founders of Catalist-listed OUE Lippo Healthcare, Fan Kow Hin and Andrew Aathar, conspired to injure the company through a S$20 million standby credit facility. The facility was used to purchase IHC shares from the open market, causing the company's share price to fall. The court ruled that Fan and Aathar are jointly and severally liable for S$8 million in additional interest and damages, as well as S$4.5 million in other losses. The court also dismissed counterclaims against IHC by the Crest funds and Lim Beng Choo.

site_title: GE2020: PAP's Yip Hon Weng wins in Yio Chu Kang SMC with 60.83% of votes

site_title: GE2020: PAP wins Nee Soon GRC with 61.9% of votes

site_title: GE2020: PAP defeats SDP in Marsiling-Yew Tee with 63.18% of votes

site_title: GE2020: PAP's Tin Pei Ling retains MacPherson SMC with hefty margin

site_title: GE2020: PAP holds on to Marine Parade with 57.76% of votes as vote share slips

site_title: GE2020: PAP's Sun Xueling beats WP's Tan Chen Chen in Punggol West SMC

site_title: GE2020: PAP retains Sembawang GRC with 67.29% of votes

site_title: GE2020: PAP beats SDP in Bukit Batok SMC with 54.8% of votes

site_title: GE2020: PAP retains Yuhua SMC with 70.54% of votes

Robin Low, SDP candidate for Yuhua SMC.

site_title: GE2020: PAP retains Holland-Bukit Timah GRC with 66.36% of votes

summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) retained its seat in Pioneer, Singapore, with Patrick Tay winning 61.98% of the votes. Tay defeated Progress Singapore Party's Lim Cher Hong (35.24%) and independent candidate Cheang Peng Wah (2.78%). The turnout was 95.29% of 24,672 registered voters. This was the only three-cornered fight in a Single Member Constituency (SMC) in the 2020 General Election.

images.alt_text: PAP candidate for Pioneer SMC Patrick Tay (right) with PSP candidate Lim Cher Hong (left) at a walkabout on July 4.

site_title: China bank lending hits record US$1.72t in first half after solid June
summary: China's bank lending surged to a record $1.72 trillion in the first half of the year, up 22.3% in June, driven by a 9% increase in monthly lending. The growth beats expectations and follows a 6.8% contraction in the first quarter. The central bank aims to maintain strong credit growth until the economy recovers. Analysts predict further acceleration in credit growth, citing low interest rates, increased lending, and government bond issuance.

site_title: GE2020: PAP retains Potong Pasir SMC with lower margin at 60.69%
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) retained its seat in Potong Pasir SMC with a lower margin of 60.69% to 39.31% in the 2020 Singapore General Election, defeating Singapore People's Party (SPP) candidate Jose Raymond. This was Sitoh Yih Pin's fifth election win, with his previous margins being higher. The constituency, one of the oldest, saw a change in electoral boundaries and was previously a stronghold of opposition icon Chiam See Tong. Experts say the "Chiam factor" is fading, and the SPP has a revitalized chance in future contests.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Hyflux received a letter of interest from Unilegend Investments, an unnamed investor expressing interest in a possible investment in the distressed water-cleaning firm.

images.alt_text: Unilegend Investments's client is prepared to provide working capital for Hyflux if it completes the investment either by becoming a substantial shareholder or by owning the group's debt.

site_title: GE2020: PAP keeps Jurong GRC with 74.62% win
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) secured 74.62% of the vote in the 2020 General Elections (GE) for Jurong Group Representation Constituency (GRC), led by Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. The PAP team defeated Red Dot United (RDU) with 91,692 votes, while RDU secured 25.38% of the vote. The PAP team includes new members Shawn Huang and Xie Yao Quan, who were chosen after a likely candidate, Ivan Lim, withdrew due to online criticism. Tharman thanked RDU for the contest and pledged to work harder to help families and build up Jurong as a strong community.

site_title: EU travel unity unravels into confusion of border controls
summary: The European Union's coordinated opening of borders has unraveled into confusion, with countries imposing varying rules and restrictions. Initially, 14 "safe" countries were designated for non-essential travel, but Italy and Belgium decided to open to none, while others like the Netherlands and Italy have since implemented stricter measures. This patchwork of rules risks re-establishing internal border checks, undermining the EU's Schengen area travel zone. The situation is described as unprecedented and dynamic, with differing opinions among EU diplomats and experts, casting doubt on the EU's ability to work together effectively.

site_title: Six candidates in race to be new Thai central bank chief
summary: Six candidates have applied to be the next Thai central bank governor, replacing Veerathai Santiprbhob whose term ends in September. The new chief will face the challenge of reviving Thailand's economy, which the Bank of Thailand predicts will shrink by 8.1% this year due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Two additional candidates were announced after the application deadline, bringing the total number of candidates to six.

site_title: Tesla rival Rivian adds US$2.5b investment led by T Rowe Price
summary: Rivian, an electric vehicle startup backed by Amazon and Ford, has secured a US$2.5 billion investment round led by T Rowe Price. This brings the company's total investment to at least US$6 billion, as it prepares to launch an electric pickup and SUV in 2021. The new funding joins existing investors including Soros Fund Management, Coatue Management, and Baron Capital Group, amid increasing competition from Tesla and Nikola, both of which are also planning electric pickups.

site_title: French government threatened with fines by top court over air pollution
summary: The French government has been ordered by the Council of State to reduce air pollution in eight zones, including areas around major cities, by 2022. Failure to meet the deadline will result in a 10 million euro fine every six months, with the fines paid to environmental organizations. The government has been criticized for not implementing sufficient measures to reduce pollution, particularly in the Ile-de-France region around Paris. The Council of State has also warned that the fines could be increased.

site_title: Carnival to resume trips in phases, emerge as a 'leaner' company
summary: Carnival, the world's largest cruise operator, plans to resume operations in phases, with a smaller fleet, following a nearly 18-month suspension due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company aims to emerge as a "leaner" company, reducing capital expenditures by over $5 billion and debt. This move is expected to optimize cash generation and position the company for investment-grade credit. The phased re-entry will moderate future capacity, with 9% fewer ships in operation, and some ships may be removed or deliveries delayed.

site_title: S&P warns Dubai economy to shrink 11%, cuts property giants to junk
summary: S&P Global has warned that Dubai's economy is expected to shrink 11% this year due to the coronavirus-containment measures. This contraction is nearly four times worse than the global financial crisis in 2009. The credit ratings of two major property firms were also cut to "junk" status, highlighting the emirate's economic struggles. The fiscal deficit is forecast to balloon to 4% of GDP this year, exacerbating the economic slowdown that began in 2015.

site_title: China Bohai Bank raises US$1.78b in Hong Kong IPO: sources
summary: China Bohai Bank successfully raised US$1.78 billion in its Hong Kong IPO, priced at HK$4.80, surpassing the largest IPO in Hong Kong so far in 2020 by Smoore International. Cornerstone investors, including Yichang Health Pharmaceutical and four funds, accounted for about 30% of the deal. The bank's fundraising eclipses Smoore's US$918 million raise last week.

site_title: Tokyo shopkeepers brace for another slowdown as coronavirus flares
summary: Tokyo shopkeepers are bracing for another slowdown due to a surge in novel coronavirus infections. The city reported record daily highs of 243 and 224 new cases on consecutive days, prompting authorities to step up testing in nightlife districts. Sales at some businesses have begun to recover, but many are struggling to stay afloat, with some cutting back operating hours or closing temporarily. Japan's economy is expected to shrink at its fastest pace in decades, leading the government to compile another stimulus package to mitigate the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Australia approves Gilead's remdesivir for Covid-19 treatment
summary: Australia's Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) has granted provisional approval for Gilead Sciences' remdesivir as the first Covid-19 treatment option in the country. The approval is for adults and adolescents with severe symptoms and hospitalized. Remdesivir has been shown to shorten hospital recovery times in clinical trials, making it a treatment of choice for severely ill Covid-19 patients.

site_title: China books second-biggest US corn purchase on record
summary: China purchased 1.365 million tonnes of US corn, its second-largest single-day purchase on record, as part of its Phase One trade deal obligation to increase US farm product imports. The purchase includes 600,000 tonnes for the current marketing year and 765,000 tonnes for the following year. This marks China's largest single-day corn purchase in 25.5 years. The deal is part of Beijing's agreement to buy $80 billion of US agricultural products over the next two years.

site_title: India panel proposes new regulator for non-personal data: draft report
summary: India's data regulator panel proposes the establishment of a new regulator to oversee the collection, storage, and disclosure of non-personal data, such as anonymized data. The panel recommends requiring companies like Facebook, Google, and Amazon to disclose how they handle this data. This move aims to tighten policies on Indian citizens' data held and processed by these companies, following similar efforts to regulate data in the wake of concerns over data privacy. The panel's draft report is set to inform India's policy on non-personal data.

site_title: Carlsberg expects better than forecast H1 operating profit, shares jump
summary: Carlsberg, the world's third-largest brewer, has revised its first-half operating profit forecast downward by 17 percentage points to a 9% decline, beating analysts' expectations of a 26% fall. The company attributed the better-than-expected result to a strong rebound in its Chinese market during the second quarter. As a result, its shares rose 5% on the news, with the company suspending its full-year guidance due to volatile and uncertain sales developments in the coming months.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with deep losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.84% on Friday, mirroring an Asia-wide sell-off, amid fresh infections and school closures. The Hang Seng Index fell to 25,727.41, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.95% to 3,383.32. The decline was attributed to concerns over the city's containment measures and the reimposition of restrictions.

site_title: Tennis: Wimbledon to disburse prize money in lieu of cancelled Championships
summary: The All England Lawn Tennis Club (AELTC) announced that the prize money set aside for the cancelled 2020 Wimbledon Championships will be distributed to 620 players who were scheduled to participate. This decision comes due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to the tournament's cancellation for the first time since World War Two. The players' world rankings would have allowed them to enter the main draw or qualifying event, making them eligible for the prize money.

site_title: Singapore GE2020: Voting hours extended to 10pm due to long queues at some polling stations
summary: Voting hours were extended in Singapore's 2020 General Election (GE2020) to 10pm due to long queues at polling stations. The polls were initially set to close at 8pm, but the Elections Department (ELD) decided to keep polling stations open until 10pm to allow all voters to cast their votes. This was the first time in Singapore's history that voting hours were extended.

site_title: Tencent in talks to acquire Hong Kong-listed gaming firm Leyou
summary: Tencent Holdings is in talks to acquire Hong Kong-listed gaming firm Leyou Technologies Holdings, joining potential suitors including Sony in a bidding war. Tencent's offer could involve iDreamSky Technology Holdings and Zhejiang Century Huatong Group, and talks are ongoing. Leyou's controlling shareholder Charles Yuk had previously discussed a majority stake sale with Tencent-backed iDreamSky. The acquisition could be announced as soon as Friday, pending a takeover code announcement.

images.alt_text: Tencent Holdings is in talks to acquire Hong Kong-listed Leyou Technologies Holdings, people familiar with the matter said, joining potential suitors including Sony in a battle for the Chinese gaming firm.

site_title: Co-founders of International Healthway 'engaged in conspiracy' against company, court finds
summary: A Singapore High Court has found that two co-founders and shareholders of International Healthway Corp (IHC), now OUE Lippo Healthcare, engaged in a conspiracy to cause the company injury. Fan Kow Hin and Andrew Aathar negotiated a S$20 million standby credit facility, which was used to purchase IHC shares from the open market, leading to a significant decline in the company's share price. The court ruled that Fan Kow Hin and the Crest entities are jointly and severally liable for S$8 million in damages and additional interest, and that they breached their fiduciary duties to the company.

site_title: Philippine lawmakers deny licence to broadcaster at odds with Duterte
summary: Philippine lawmakers voted against renewing ABS-CBN's 25-year franchise, ensuring the broadcaster will remain off the air indefinitely. The decision comes after President Rodrigo Duterte's repeated threats to block the renewal, citing the broadcaster's failure to air paid campaign commercials. Critics call it a "grievous assault on press freedom" and a move solidifying Duterte's "tyranny." ABS-CBN can appeal the decision, but minority lawmakers predict it will fail due to pressure from leadership.

site_title: Global air travel is recovering with big domestic boost in Asia
summary: Air travel is recovering globally, driven by a domestic boost in Asia, where Vietnam, Indonesia, and South Korea saw growth in July. The US and China dominate the number of flights, but domestic flights are down 46% in the US and 4% in India. Cirium reports 413,538 domestic flights in the US and 378,434 in China, with 59% of the global fleet back in service. The air travel market is cautiously resurgent after the worst collapse in its history.

site_title: WHO advance team on way to China to set up probe into virus origin
summary: A World Health Organization (WHO) advance team has left for China to set up a probe into the origin of the novel coronavirus. The two experts will work with Chinese scientists to determine the investigation's scope and itinerary, focusing on whether the virus jumped from an animal species to humans. The WHO will have no role in an independent panel reviewing the global handling of the pandemic, and US President Donald Trump has suggested the virus may have originated in a Wuhan laboratory, although China denies this.

images.alt_text: An advance team from the World Health Organization (WHO) has left for China to organise an investigation into the origins of the novel coronavirus which sparked the global pandemic, a spokesperson said on Friday.

site_title: Vietnam says 31m workers impacted by pandemic, risk of rising unemployment
summary: Vietnam's economy has been severely impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, affecting approximately 31 million workers, with 900,000 out of work and 18 million receiving reduced income. The General Statistics Office warns that if solutions are not implemented, an additional 5 million workers may lose their jobs by the end of the year. The services sector has been the most heavily impacted, with 72% of workers affected, while the industrial and agricultural sectors follow closely. Vietnam's urban unemployment rate reached 4.46% in the second quarter, its highest in 10 years.

site_title: IEA raises 2020 oil demand forecast but warns Covid-19 clouds outlook
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has raised its 2020 oil demand forecast to 92.1 million barrels per day, up 400,000 bpd from its previous outlook. However, the agency warns that the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic poses a risk to the outlook, citing accelerating cases in some countries and potential lockdown measures. Oil refining activity in 2020 is expected to fall, with refining margins facing challenges from tighter feedstock markets and a product stocks overhang.

site_title: Malaysia police question Al Jazeera journalists over documentary
summary: Malaysian police questioned five Australian Al Jazeera journalists over a documentary about migrant detention during a coronavirus lockdown, amid concerns about a widening media crackdown. The documentary was deemed inaccurate and misleading by authorities, who are now investigating the broadcaster for breaking laws against sedition, defamation, and transmitting offensive content. The journalists, including a bureau chief and correspondent, were accompanied by lawyers and defended themselves against the charges, with Al Jazeera standing by the "professionalism and impartiality" of its journalism.

site_title: Hong Kong to suspend all schools due to spike in coronavirus cases
summary: Hong Kong will suspend all schools starting Monday due to a spike in locally transmitted coronavirus cases. The city reported 42 new cases, with 34 locally transmitted, following a second consecutive day of rising infections. The Education Bureau announced the suspension after some recent cases involved students and parents. This marks the second consecutive day of rising local infections, with a total of 1,366 cases and seven deaths since late January.

site_title: Surging truck sales boost China's auto sector revival in June as economy upshifts
summary: China's auto sector experienced a surge in truck sales in June, with a 11.6% increase to 2.3 million units, driven by infrastructure spending and commercial vehicle demand. Passenger vehicle sales rose 1.8% and commercial vehicle sales surged 63% year-over-year. Sales growth is seen as a precursor to the recovery of economic activity, but overall auto sales are expected to fall 10-20% for the year due to earlier collapse.

site_title: Hong Kong leaders, tycoons bid farewell to gaming magnate Ho
summary: Hong Kong leaders, politicians, and celebrities bid farewell to gaming magnate Stanley Ho, who died at 98 on May 26. The third day of ceremonies for Ho, known as the "godfather" of Macau casinos, saw attendance from prominent figures including Carrie Lam, Leung Chun-ying, and Tung Chee-hwa. A public memorial held on Thursday featured hundreds of floral wreaths, and Ho's vast fortune, estimated at HK$50 billion, is expected to be divided among his 15 surviving children. His Sociedade de Jogos de Macau Holdings empire remains a major player in Macau.

site_title: Hyflux gets letter of interest from Unilegend Investments
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water-cleaning firm, has received a letter of interest from Unilegend Investments, a Singapore-incorporated firm focused on clean energy and water. Unilegend's client plans to invest in Hyflux's debt or become a substantial shareholder, with the condition that current management and board members, including CEO Olivia Lum, remain in office. This comes amid investigations into Lum and her team by the Singapore police and financial regulator. Meanwhile, other investors, such as Pison Investments and Aqua Munda, have made offers to buy Hyflux's senior debt at a discount, potentially allowing the company to exit insolvency.

site_title: Australia to halve numbers of returning citizens as virus surges
summary: Australia is halving the number of returning citizens allowed to enter the country each week due to a surge in Covid-19 cases. As of Monday, only 4,000 people per week will be permitted entry, and they will be required to pay for their 14-day hotel quarantine stays. This move aims to contain the outbreak in New South Wales, the country's second most populous state.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower over virus worries
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday due to concerns over a fresh record of daily coronavirus cases in the capital. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.06% and the Topix index dropped 1.42%. This is the third consecutive day of losses for Tokyo stocks.

site_title: Japan's economy to shrink at fastest pace in decades this fiscal year due to pandemic
summary: Japan's economy is expected to shrink 5.3% in the fiscal year through March 2021, the fastest pace in decades, due to the coronavirus pandemic. The Bank of Japan may expand stimulus to cushion the blow. This contraction is the most since comparable data in 1994. The government will compile another stimulus package to address the economic impact.

site_title: Indonesian e-tailer Bukalapak turns street sellers into banking agents
summary: Indonesian e-tailer Bukalapak is partnering with PT Bank Mandiri to turn street sellers, known as "warungs," into banking agents. The partnership aims to provide banking services to around 68 million Indonesians without bank accounts. Warungs will help users set up bank accounts, conduct transactions, and deposit/withdraw cash, with fees split among the warungs, bank, and Bukalapak. The move is part of Bukalapak's strategy to expand its services and tap into the country's large retail market.

site_title: Countries agree to help seafarers marooned at sea due to coronavirus
summary: A dozen countries, including the US, Britain, and Singapore, agreed to speed up efforts to repatriate 200,000 stranded seafarers affected by the coronavirus. Due to travel restrictions, many have been at sea for over 11 months, leading to a "humanitarian crisis" with reported suicides. The countries committed to opening borders, increasing commercial flights, and designating seafarers as "key workers". The International Maritime Organization describes the situation as a crisis, and shipping industry officials say sailors are at breaking point. The UK government hosted a virtual summit to address the issue.

site_title: Indonesian capital seeks more funds, strategic partners for rail expansion
summary: The operator of Jakarta's mass rapid transport network, MRT Jakarta, is seeking 10 trillion rupiah ($972.8 million) in extra funds to complete its second line and is exploring strategic partnerships for third and fourth lines. The funds will be sourced from the Japan International Cooperation Agency and local investors, with the goal of combining government-to-government lending with private sector investment. The project aims to enhance transit-oriented development in Jakarta.

site_title: Europe: Shares enter fourth day of declines, energy firms drag
summary: Europe's shares declined for a fourth consecutive session, with the Stoxx 600 index falling 0.4% due to worries about a stalled economic recovery amid rising global coronavirus cases. Energy firms led the decline, with oil prices falling on concerns about fuel demand. Despite some gains from mining and healthcare sectors, the index was headed for a small weekly loss. Individual movers included a 5.3% drop for Dufry and a 3.1% rise for Qiagen, which reported a 68% rise in quarterly earnings.

site_title: China's aviation industry suffers 34.25b yuan loss in Q2 on coronavirus jolt
summary: China's aviation industry reported a Q2 loss of 34.25 billion yuan, slightly narrower than the 38.1 billion yuan loss in Q1, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite a faster-than-expected recovery in the domestic travel market, the industry continues to face significant financial challenges. The industry's losses are largely attributed to the pandemic's impact, which has affected travel demand and airline operations.

site_title: South Korea to raise real estate tax rate on multiple home-owners by up to 6% per year
summary: South Korea's finance ministry announced plans to raise real estate tax rates on multiple home-owners by up to 6% per year. The tax hike is aimed at discouraging individuals from owning multiple properties. Additionally, capital gains tax rates will be increased by up to 70% for those selling homes after owning them for less than a year. The government also plans to impose higher taxes on top of the basic tax rate for multiple home-owners.

site_title: Muji's US business seeks bankruptcy protection over coronavirus
summary: Muji's US subsidiary filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to the closure of its 18 US stores since mid-March. The Japanese owner, Ryohin Keikaku, cited the pandemic's financial impact on global retailers. This move follows other retailers, such as J Crew Group, to file for bankruptcy protection.

site_title: 191 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 16 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 191 new COVID-19 cases, including 16 community cases, taking the total to 45,613. The cases include seven Singaporeans, nine work pass holders, and one imported case who was placed on stay-home notice. Migrant workers in dormitories account for the majority of the cases. The Ministry of Health has added several locations to the list of places visited by COVID-19 patients, and close contacts have been notified. The country has reported 26 deaths from COVID-19 complications, with 41,631 patients fully recovered.

site_title: Long road ahead for fully self-driving cars, despite Tesla claim
summary: Tesla founder Elon Musk claims to be near "Level 5" autonomy, or fully self-driving vehicles, despite years of refinement needed, according to analysts. Musk expects "basic functionality" of Level 5 to be complete this year, but experts say this is unlikely, citing the complexity of artificial intelligence and the limitations of human brain capabilities. The sector is wary of Musk's claims, with some warning of "dangerous assumptions" among motorists and the need for public education about the differences between autonomy and driver assistance systems.

site_title: Australia: Shares post weekly drop as virus worries deepen
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.61% on Friday, marking a weekly decline of 2.3%, as fresh COVID-19 restrictions in Victoria dampened hopes for economic recovery. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 5,919.2, erasing previous gains. Analysts attributed the decline to concerns about the virus's impact on economic policy and suppressed fuel demand. Energy, gold, and mining stocks also declined, with major companies like Woodside Petroleum and Newcrest Mining losing 2.3% and 1.7%, respectively.

site_title: UK retail warns shoppers face higher prices if no EU trade deal
summary: The British retail industry is urging the UK and EU to reach a post-Brexit trade deal to avoid higher prices for consumers, citing a 4/5ths reliance on EU imports for food and other goods. Without a tariff-free trade deal, consumers could face higher prices due to tariffs of over 20% on food imports and other goods. The British Retail Consortium warns that the industry cannot absorb these increased costs, putting consumers at risk. The UK government must agree a deal by December 31 to avoid higher prices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply lower on Friday
summary: Hong Kong shares opened sharply lower on Friday due to fresh fears over the spread of coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.06% to 25,931.78, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.92%. The decline follows a big sell-off on the Dow on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares started on Friday with a loss on fresh fears over the spread of coronavirus, which sparked a big sell-off on the Dow on Wall Street.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 4.39 points or 0.28% to 1,578.86. Losers beat gainers 285 to 229, with volume reaching 888.29 million lots worth RM443.88 million.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won fall as new Covid-19 cases in US hit record
summary: South Korean stocks closed 0.81% lower on Friday, falling 17.65 points to 2,150.25, amid surging US Covid-19 cases and fears of more restrictions. The Korean won weakened, and foreign investors sold 343.10 billion won worth of shares. The benchmark bond yield fell, and the MSCI Asia-Pacific shares index shed 1.22%. The US death toll rose, and South Korea reported 45 new infections, pushing its tally to 13,338. The won was quoted at 1,204.5 per US dollar, 0.75% lower than its previous close.

site_title: Japan urges nightclubs to act to stem coronavirus spikes
summary: Japan's economy minister, Yasutoshi Nishimura, urged nightclubs to take swift action to prevent the spread of coronavirus, following a surge in infections in Tokyo's nightlife districts. The city reported a record daily high of 240 new infections, with clusters found in host and hostess clubs, as well as cafes. Nishimura called for customers to be provided with enough space and good ventilation, and for measures to be taken to stamp out the surge. Authorities plan to expand PCR testing and meet with nightlife district chiefs to decide on further measures.

site_title: Hardliners show hints of compromise on EU recovery fund
summary: Austria and the Netherlands, two of the "frugal four" opposed to a proposed EU coronavirus recovery package, showed signs of compromise, suggesting they may soften their stance. Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz and Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte indicated that they could support the 750-billion euro package if aid was tied to conditions such as climate protection and rule of law. The move comes ahead of a Brussels summit next week, where EU leaders will aim to agree on the recovery plan.

site_title: US posts new record daily virus caseload of more than 65,000
summary: The US has reported a record 65,551 new coronavirus cases, surpassing the previous daily record of 60,200 cases. The country's total caseload has reached over 3.1 million, with 133,195 deaths. Health experts warn that the death rate may soon follow the spike in infections, particularly in the south and west. US infectious diseases expert Anthony Fauci has expressed concerns about the reopening of states, saying they should pause their opening process. US President Donald Trump has downplayed the spike in cases, attributing it to the country's extensive testing.

site_title: US to announce, but defer, retaliation over French digital tax: USTR
summary: The US Trade Representative, Robert Lighthizer, announced that the US will take actions against France over its digital services tax, but will defer them while France defers tax collections from US technology firms. The US had withdrawn from multilateral talks on digital services taxation due to a lack of progress. The US may impose tariffs on around $500 million worth of French goods, but has not yet decided on specific sanctions. The issue is set to be discussed at upcoming meetings of the Group of Seven and Group of 20 finance ministers.

site_title: Gold poised for 5th straight weekly rise on virus fears
summary: Gold prices are poised for a fifth straight weekly gain, with spot gold near the $1,800-per-ounce threshold, driven by concerns over rising US coronavirus cases. Analysts attribute the trend to unchanged fundamental risks, with US gold futures up 0.2% to $1,806.80. The ongoing uncertainty over US trade policies and the ongoing pandemic has kept gold as a safe-haven asset, supporting its price.

images.alt_text: Gold was set for a fifth straight weekly gain on Friday as worries over a spike in US coronavirus cases kept the safe-haven metal near the technical $1,800-per-ounce threshold.

site_title: Seoul mayor in apparent suicide after #MeToo allegations
summary: Seoul Mayor Park Won Soon, a former human rights lawyer and potential presidential candidate, died in an apparent suicide a day after being accused of sexual harassment by his former secretary. The 64-year-old mayor, who promoted gender and social equality, had won three elections while in office, but his death comes as South Korea continues to grapple with a #MeToo movement sparked by a prosecutor's public accusation of a superior. The police confirmed a complaint had been filed but declined to confirm the details, and an investigation will automatically be closed due to his death.

site_title: US approves sale of 105 F-35 stealth fighters to Japan
summary: The US has approved the sale of 105 F-35 stealth fighter aircraft to Japan for an estimated $23.11 billion. The sale includes 63 F-35A and 42 F-35B aircraft, which will improve Japan's security in the Asia-Pacific region. This deal aligns with Japan's plan to acquire 105 F-35A aircraft and 42 F-35B aircraft over the next decade to counter threats from North Korea and China. The sale is seen as vital to US national interest and will support Japan's efforts to develop a strong self-defence capability.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.07% and the Topix index down 0.37%. Investors were disheartened by falls in US key indices amid concerns over the spike in coronavirus cases in many US states.

site_title: US bans Pakistan International Airlines flights over pilot concerns
summary: The US Department of Transportation revoked permission for Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) to conduct charter flights to the US due to FAA concerns over Pakistani pilot certifications. This decision comes after Pakistan grounded almost a third of its pilots following a discovery of potential qualification falsification. The European Union Aviation Safety Agency had previously suspended PIA's authorisation to fly to the bloc for six months. The revocation affects PIA's operations and follows recent issues with pilot qualifications.

site_title: Crisis management in the boardroom
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has highlighted the importance of crisis management frameworks for businesses. Corporate boards play a crucial role in preparing for crises, responding to them, and conducting post-crisis reviews. Effective crisis preparedness should cover key risks, include activities such as establishing a clear chain of command, calibrating responses, and communicating with stakeholders. Boards can also play a role in crisis response by augmenting management's capacity to assess strategic implications and encouraging offensive postures to seize opportunities. A robust crisis management framework can increase the likelihood of survival, but no framework guarantees success, and firms must continually review and update their frameworks to improve preparedness.

site_title: IMF and World Bank to hold fall meetings virtually
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank Group announced that their annual fall meetings will be mostly virtual due to the coronavirus pandemic. The 2020 IMF-World Bank Annual Meetings, scheduled for October 12-18, will be held in a primarily virtual format to ensure the health and safety of participants. The decision follows the virtual format of the spring meetings in April, which were held due to the pandemic's impact on the US, China, and Europe.

site_title: Ford's quarterly China sales rise for first time in 3 years
summary: Ford Motor reported its China vehicle sales increased 3% in the April-June quarter, its first quarterly rise in nearly three years, reversing a slump that started in 2018. Sales dropped 26% last year, with a 37% decline in 2018. This improvement marks a step towards recovery for the US automaker in China's largest auto market.

site_title: Oil falls US$1/barrel as resurgent pandemic prompts worries about US demand
summary: Oil prices fell US$1 a barrel on Thursday as investors worried about US demand due to renewed lockdowns to contain the spread of coronavirus. Brent crude futures dropped 2.2% to US$42.35 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 3.1% to US$39.62 a barrel. Analysts say the US, Brazil, and other countries' ongoing Covid-19 struggles pose a threat to fuel consumption.

site_title: Top officials in South Korea sell apartments amid property price furore
summary: South Korean top officials, including Noh Young-min, chief of staff to President Moon Jae-in, are selling their apartments amid a public backlash over multiple home ownership. The move comes as Seoul property prices have soared over 50% in three years, prompting the government to announce tighter property rules and heavier taxes on multiple homeowners. Noh's apartment, valued at about $1.3 million, is being sold ahead of the government's efforts to calm the market. This is part of a broader trend of senior officials selling their properties amidst growing public concern over housing affordability.

site_title: California theme parks remain shut but hundreds flock to Disney shops

site_title: A dog's life: Scientists find new formula for canine age

site_title: 'Strong evidence' mothers can transmit Covid-19 virus to newborns
summary: Scientists have found strong evidence that Covid-19-positive mothers can pass the virus to their unborn infants. Researchers in Italy studied 31 pregnant women hospitalized with Covid-19 and found the virus in the placenta, umbilical cord, vagina, and breast milk. While no infants tested positive, the study suggests in-vitro transmission is possible, raising concerns about the risk to newborns. The World Health Organization has stated that breastfeeding is still safe for new mothers infected with Covid-19.

site_title: Panel to review WHO's pandemic response
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has established an independent panel to review its response to the Covid-19 pandemic, following criticism from US President Donald Trump. The panel, co-chaired by Helen Clark and Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, will present an interim report in November and a full report in May. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus called for a "honest reflection" on the international response to the pandemic, including the agency's own actions. The panel will review the pandemic response, including the WHO's role, and provide monthly updates.

site_title: A V-shaped recovery could still happen
summary: A V-shaped recovery from the pandemic-induced downturn is still possible, according to some indicators, including the Bank of England's chief economist Andy Haldane. Classic short-term leading and coincident indicators point to a recovery, and the author has continued to monitor the Global Leading Indicator (GLI) index, which includes US manufacturing PMIs, weekly unemployment claims, and other economic indicators. Despite the challenges posed by Covid-19, these indicators suggest a return to pre-pandemic levels, with the author warning of structural challenges facing many economies in the decade ahead.

site_title: Turbulent times for SIA as Covid-19 calls time out to air travel
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will record a one-off charge of S$123.6 million due to the liquidation of its 49% stake in NokScoot, a Thai mid-haul low-cost carrier, amid the Covid-19 crisis. The airline's impairment of its book value of seven Boeing 777-200 aircraft leased to NokScoot and provisions to cover liquidation costs contribute to the charge. The Covid-19 pandemic has severely impacted NokScoot, which has been unable to record a full-year profit since its inception in 2014.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Coupang to buy assets of Singtel's Hooq, in Asian video entry
summary: South Korean e-commerce giant Coupang Corp is buying the software assets of Hooq Digital, a South-east Asian video streaming service owned by Singtel, Sony, and Warner Bros, as the company files for liquidation. The deal marks Coupang's entry into the competitive over-the-top video streaming arena, pitting it against Amazon and Netflix. This move follows Tencent's recent acquisition of iflix's assets, signaling growing consolidation in the segment. Coupang's investors, including SoftBank Group's Vision Fund, have valued the company at $9 billion, with plans for a potential public listing.

site_title: US Supreme Court rules some Trump financial records can be revealed
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled 7-2 that a New York prosecutor can obtain President Donald Trump's financial records, but prevented the Democratic-led House of Representatives from doing so. The court's conservative Chief Justice John Roberts authored both rulings, allowing a subpoena issued to Trump's accounting firm Mazars to be enforced. However, the court sidestepped a ruling on whether the House committees can obtain Trump's financial documents, allowing the litigation to continue in lower courts.

site_title: Speedy removal of Huawei would cost UK billions
summary: Britain's demand for a speedy removal of Huawei's telecoms equipment from mobile networks could harm the country's economic recovery, warns Vodafone and BT. Removing the equipment would cost "single figure billions" of pounds, with Vodafone estimating £5-7 billion and BT £500 million. The UK government is revisiting its policy on Huawei due to US sanctions on chip technology, which could damage Huawei's ability to supply equipment. A total ban is likely, with Samsung and Nokia seen as potential replacements.

site_title: Viewing creativity through the lens of the pandemic
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has triggered a surge in innovation, with businesses taking bold steps to adapt and remain competitive. Research suggests that crises can induce a prevention mindset, hindering creativity, but also reveals that imagining a future filled with change and progress can break schemas and inspire innovation. By shifting focus from the present to the future, people can overcome mental lockdowns and adopt an innovative posture. This approach can lead to radical innovations, as seen in the repurposing of production lines to produce masks with innovative details.

site_title: Nokia launches data centre networking tools, developed with Apple
summary: Nokia has launched data centre networking tools in partnership with Apple, aiming to help companies manage growing data traffic with 5G and machine learning technologies. The tools will assist firms like Amazon, Google, and Facebook in scaling up resources swiftly. Nokia's new products also target cloud builders, large enterprises, and telecom operators, with customers including BT and Equinix. The partnership reflects Nokia's expansion into networking products and its focus on 5G and cloud infrastructure.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Cinemas in Singapore will reopen on July 13, offering a virtual cinema platform for alternative movie viewing. The platform, in collaboration with the Singapore Film Society and Shaw Organisation, will feature three films available for 14 days after rental or 48 hours after playback. The films include "The Painter and the Thief" and "Spaceship Earth," both premiering this week. Rental costs $12.99.

images.alt_text: ONLINE ARTHOUSE CINEMA: The Painter and the Thief premieres today.

site_title: Biden unveils US$700b economic recovery plan
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden has unveiled a $700 billion economic recovery plan aimed at creating over 5 million new jobs and protecting American workers. The six-pronged approach includes investing in domestic production and research, shrinking foreign supply chains, and promoting new tax rules. The plan, which will be detailed later, aims to bring back jobs lost during the pandemic and challenges President Donald Trump's "America First" agenda. Biden's plan relies on the "full power of the federal government" to bolster American industrial and technological strength.

site_title: Asia-Pacific 2019 wealth growth trails US, Europe: Capgemini
summary: Wealth in the Asia Pacific region grew at a slower pace than the US and Europe in 2019, with an 8% expansion, according to the World Wealth Report 2020 by Capgemini. This marks the first time since 2012 that the Asia Pacific region trailed the US and Europe. The current year's outlook is uncertain due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a predicted 6-8% decline in global wealth until end-April. Sustainable investments emerged as a bright spot, with HNWIs planning to allocate 41% of their portfolio to these products by end-2020.

site_title: Wholesale inventories tumble in May
summary: US wholesale inventories declined 1.2% in May, driven by a 10-year low in goods imports due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This supports expectations of a 35% decline in GDP for the April-June quarter, the steepest since the Great Depression. The trade deficit has widened due to a significant decline in exports, contributing to a record contraction in GDP.

site_title: Ley Choon units win repair and maintenance contracts worth S$36.9m
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings, a construction company, has secured four contracts worth S$36.9 million for repair and maintenance works of underground services and infrastructure. The contracts, awarded to its subsidiaries, are not expected to impact the company's earnings or net tangible assets for the current financial year. Shares of Ley Choon closed up 0.1 Singapore cents, or 7.69%, following the announcement.

site_title: British retailer Boots to cut 4,000 jobs
summary: British retailer Boots plans to cut 4,000 jobs and close 48 optician stores due to the Covid-19 crisis, with footfall down 85% in April. The US-listed owner of Boots, Walgreens Boots Alliance, booked a $2 billion impairment charge due to the pandemic's impact on sales. The company aims to accelerate a restructuring already in place, with a 20% headcount reduction at its support office. This move follows thousands of job cuts by other British brands affected by the pandemic.

site_title: US: Wall St gains as investors cheer declining jobless claims
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday as weekly jobless claims declined, with investors optimistic about the economic outlook despite rising Covid-19 cases. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.11%, 0.20%, and 0.68% respectively. The market is also cautiously optimistic ahead of US-EU trade talks and a potential business shutdown. The decline in jobless claims and positive market sentiment lifted investor confidence, driving stocks to fresh records.

site_title: New ideas, alternative voices needed for the future: SDP
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) and other opposition parties are emphasizing the need for new ideas and alternative voices in Parliament to ensure accountability and transparency. SDP chairman Paul Tambyah criticized the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) for relying on scaremongering and character assassination tactics, while opposing candidates highlighted the importance of putting people first and addressing pressing issues such as housing, healthcare, and climate change. The opposition parties are urging voters to consider the future and choose candidates who will bring transparency and accountability to Parliament.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close marginally lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed marginally lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.25 points to 1,583.25. Volume reached 10.237 billion lots worth RM5.181 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 537 to 496.

site_title: Zhang Chao to retire as CEO of Zheneng Jinjiang Environment
summary: Zhang Chao, CEO of Zheneng Jinjiang Environment, will retire on November 10 after three years. A bourse filing announced his departure, stating he will step down upon expiration of his service contract. The company did not disclose a replacement and will provide updates to shareholders once a new CEO is appointed.

site_title: TikTok removed over 49m videos in second half of 2019
summary: TikTok removed over 49 million videos from its platform in the second half of 2019 for violating its guidelines, which accounted for less than 1% of total posts. The removed content included violent and graphic material, hate speech, and adult nudity. The majority of the removed videos came from India, followed by the US and Pakistan. The move comes amid a challenging period for TikTok, including a ban in India and a threat of a US ban on China-based social media apps.

images.alt_text: Social media app TikTok said on Thursday it removed more than 49 million videos from its platform in the second half of last year for violating its guidelines.

site_title: Darco's deputy chairman to recuse himself from project
summary: Darco Water Technologies' deputy chairman Robert Wang Zhi will recuse himself from deliberations on a controversial Indonesian waste management project due to potential conflicts of interest. Wang had previously acquired a 75% stake in the Indonesian company Panghegar Energy Indonesia (PEI) through Yunnan Water, a unit of Hong Kong-listed Yunnan Water Investment Co. Wang's ties to Yunnan Water have raised concerns among shareholders, prompting the audit committee's recommendation for his recusal.

site_title: VW can face dieselgate suits where cars bought, rules EU court
summary: The European Union's Court of Justice ruled that EU consumers can sue Volkswagen in their national courts for buying cars with emission cheat devices installed. The decision, made in response to a case by the Austrian consumer association VKI, opens the possibility of "masses of legal complaints" from consumers across the bloc. This ruling could lead to Volkswagen facing numerous lawsuits, potentially affecting the company's financial situation.

site_title: GE2020: PM Lee calls for strong mandate to empower PAP to act decisively on Singaporeans' behalf
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong called for a strong mandate for the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) to empower it to act decisively on Singaporeans' behalf in the upcoming General Election 2020. The PAP aims to save jobs, grow the economy, and build a more inclusive society, with a focus on supporting workers affected by the Covid-19 crisis. Lee emphasized that every vote counts and that the party needs the support of every Singaporean to steer the country towards better days ahead.

site_title: PSP stresses need for independent eyes in Parliament to check spending of reserve dollars
summary: The Progress Singapore Party's (PSP) Tan Cheng Bock is urging voters to elect PSP members to Parliament to scrutinize government spending on reserve dollars, particularly for COVID-19 recovery measures. PSP's manifesto calls for reducing dependence on foreign labor, supporting local businesses, and strengthening a safety net for vulnerable groups. Tan emphasized the need for "independent eyes" in Parliament to ensure the government spends reserves wisely and prioritizes both life and livelihood protection.

site_title: Yuan jumps to 4-month high as China stocks rally, breaches key threshold
summary: The yuan rose to a four-month high against the US dollar, breaching a key psychological threshold, as Chinese stocks rallied and capital inflows surged. The onshore yuan ended domestic trading up 0.27% at 6.9862 per US dollar, its strongest close since March 12. China shares extended a blistering run into an eighth day, despite regulators cracking down on margin financing and state media warning of market risks. The yuan's gain is attributed to sustained investor confidence in China's economic recovery and attractive yields in Chinese bonds.

site_title: EU to back Croatia, Bulgaria in first step to join euro: sources
summary: EU officials are set to back Croatia and Bulgaria's bid to join the eurozone, paving the way for their adoption of the euro currency within the next three years. This move would mark the first eurozone enlargement since Lithuania joined in 2015, bringing the total number of members to 19. A decision is expected after a meeting of eurozone and European Union finance ministers, with the move seen as a significant step forward for the two countries.

site_title: WP urges voters to imagine a Singapore 'far better than it is now'
summary: The Workers' Party in Singapore urged voters to imagine a better Singapore where diverse voices are heard, civil society plays a key role, and press freedom is greater. Party chairperson Sylvia Lim acknowledged the country's achievements but urged voters to think of a better future. Singapore goes to the polls on Friday, with the party's message focusing on the need for change and improvement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close on strong note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed on a strong note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.31% to 26,210.16, following advances across Asia. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, with increases of 1.39% and 2.70%, respectively. The rally comes as Wall Street reaches record-breaking highs, despite US-China trade tensions.

site_title: UK retailer John Lewis' shop closures put 1,300 jobs at risk
summary: UK retailer John Lewis plans to close eight stores, including four At Home stores and two full-size department stores, putting 1,300 jobs at risk due to the pandemic's impact on the retail industry. The store closures will reduce John Lewis' store count to 42. This move comes after months of enforced store closures and is the latest blow to Britain's main streets.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Hyflux has received a new S$485m cash and stock offer from Utico, which would provide a return of "more than 10 per cent" to unsecured senior creditors and retail investors under its preference shares and perpetual securities. This is higher than the previously agreed-upon return under the restructuring agreement in November last year.

images.alt_text: Utico said it has upped its proposed rescue package to a minimum of S$485 million comprising cash and stock, details of which were sent to Hyflux and all creditor parties.

site_title: Europe maps out green hydrogen vision on path to net-zero emissions
summary: The European Commission has outlined its vision to promote renewable hydrogen to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. The EU aims to develop carbon-neutral green hydrogen for sectors like steel production, with a goal of increasing production capacity six-fold by 2024 and up to 10 million tonnes by 2030. The EU expects up to 470 billion euros in investment in renewable hydrogen by 2050, with a transitional phase using blue hydrogen. A new alliance, the European Clean Hydrogen Alliance, has been launched to support the development of green hydrogen.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims stay elevated
summary: US weekly jobless claims remain high, totaling 1.314 million for the week ended July 4, down from 1.413 million in the prior week. The number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid dipped to 18.062 million, despite record job growth in June, when 4.8 million jobs were created. Weakening demand and a resurgence in new Covid-19 cases are keeping the labor market fragile, with some businesses struggling with weak demand and furloughs.

site_title: Singapore plant-based meat startup Karana closes US$1.7m seed funding
summary: Singapore-based plant-based meat startup Karana has closed a US$1.7 million seed funding round led by investors including Henry Soesanto, Big Idea Ventures, and Germi8. The funds will be used to launch its first range of plant-based meats and dim sum products in Singapore, accelerate R&D, and build a regional food-tech team. Karana's first product is "pork" made from organic jackfruit, with plans to launch in Singapore this year and expand into Asia.

site_title: Sterling rises on delayed response to Sunak's economic plan
summary: Sterling rose 0.3% against the US dollar as investors responded slowly to UK finance minister Rishi Sunak's economic plan, which includes £30 billion in stimulus measures. The pound also gained 0.1% against the euro. Despite the positive news, Brexit risks continue to weigh on the British currency. The UK and EU are in new talks to discuss their future trading relationship, with a no-deal scenario possible by the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.6% down
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.6% lower on Thursday, falling 16.84 points to 2,652.65, due to a quiet trading day ahead of Friday's polling and US jobless data release. Despite this, regional markets, including Japan, Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea, China, and Australia, posted gains. Trading volume was thin, with 23 counters losing value and 7 gaining. Losses were led by OCBC, DBS, and HongKong Land Holdings, while Biolidics jumped 32.3% on a five-year pact with Hangzhou-based LC-Bio.

site_title: Itochu makes US$5.4b bid for rest of Japan's FamilyMart
summary: Itochu Corp has made a US$5.4 billion bid to acquire the remaining shares of Japan's FamilyMart Co., offering 2,300 yen per share. The tender offer, valued at 580.9 billion yen, represents a 31% premium over Wednesday's closing price. FamilyMart's directors support the offer, and the company's stock surged 23% after the announcement. The acquisition would make FamilyMart a wholly-owned subsidiary of Itochu, allowing it to accelerate digitalization and expansion efforts.

site_title: Zilingo cuts Singapore and global headcount, puts Singapore HQ up for rent
summary: Zilingo, a fashion commerce and technology startup, has laid off 11 employees in Singapore as part of a 12% global cut to its workforce. This move follows an initial wave of 35 layoffs in April. The company has put its Singapore office up for rent. Zilingo, backed by investors such as Temasek and Sequoia Capital, had previously made under 5% of its 796-strong workforce redundant. The layoffs are part of the company's efforts to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: TikTok's Hong Kong exit a 'win-win' business move
summary: TikTok has withdrawn from Hong Kong, citing concerns over the territory's new security law that aims to quash a democracy movement. The move is seen as a "win-win" business strategy, allowing the app to focus on its lucrative American market while ceding some ground to its sister app, Douyin, which shares data with the Chinese government. However, experts say the decision may not shield TikTok from accusations of collusion with China, and the company's US operations remain under scrutiny due to concerns over data sharing and national security.

site_title: Sats sinks S$6.3m into the red in Q4
summary: SATS, a ground handler and caterer, reported a net loss of S$6.3 million in Q4 FY2020, down from a year-ago profit of S$49.9 million, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on air travel demand. Revenue dropped 8.1% to S$433.1 million, with gateway services contributing 17.8% less revenue. The company's net profit declined 32.2% to S$168.4 million for the full year, and no final dividend has been proposed to preserve jobs and capabilities. The CEO warned of a challenging operating environment in the next financial year.

site_title: Australia suspends Hong Kong extradition deal in swipe at China
summary: Australia has suspended its extradition agreement with Hong Kong in response to China's imposition of sweeping national security legislation on the financial hub. The move also includes offering skilled Hong Kong migrants five-year visas with a pathway to permanent residence. The decision comes after Canada suspended its extradition agreement with Hong Kong last week, and Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison has accused China of "fundamental change of circumstances" in relation to Hong Kong. China has strongly condemned the move, labeling it a "serious violation of international law."

site_title: Emirates lays off more pilots, crew in latest round of job cuts: sources
summary: Emirates laid off more pilots and cabin crew in a round of job cuts amid the coronavirus pandemic, sources say. The airline is shrinking its workforce due to a cash crunch, potentially reducing its workforce by almost a third. Airbus A380 pilots were mostly affected, with more redundancies expected. Emirates has already laid off pilots and cabin crew last month. The airline is reviewing its strategy and "right-sizing" its workforce as a responsible business, citing the reduced operational requirements due to the pandemic.

site_title: Thai tech hiring startup GetLinks gets revenue boost from pandemic layoffs
summary: GetLinks, an Alibaba-backed tech hiring platform, saw its revenue double in the first half of 2020 due to a surge in demand from companies expanding digital and online operations amid the pandemic. Layoffs at tech companies like Grab and Agoda enabled firms to hire hundreds of workers, with GetLinks placing candidates at Uniqlo, L'Oreal, and Central Group. The company has also partnered with Kalibrr, expanding its reach to five million candidates and 25,000 companies.

site_title: Asia: Philippines shares hit by virus spike; Chinese stocks see eighth day of gains
summary: The Philippines saw its shares drop 1% due to a record 2,500-plus new coronavirus cases, while other Asian emerging markets gained strength from Chinese stocks' eighth consecutive day of gains. The rally in Shanghai's main index reflects hopes for China's economic recovery, with the yuan trading near a four-month high against the US dollar. However, concerns about the recovery remain, with a fifth of the Philippines' total infections confirmed in the past five days, and officials warning of potential lockdowns.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to cut 240 roles in Singapore due to Covid-19 impact
summary: Rolls-Royce is cutting 240 technical roles in Singapore, representing a 24% reduction of its workforce, due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the commercial aerospace market. The layoffs will start from mid-August as part of the company's global restructuring. This move follows Rolls-Royce's announcement in May to slash at least 9,000 jobs worldwide, or 17% of its global headcount, to right-size operations for the medium term.

site_title: Virus-hit Tokyo's office vacancy rate worsens in June: broker
summary: Tokyo's office vacancy rate rose to 1.97% in June, its fourth consecutive month of increase, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on office relocations and new contract signings. Many employees working from home led companies to reconsider their need for large office spaces, with IT solutions company Fujitsu being the latest example. The vacancy rate had fallen to 1.49% in February, its lowest since 2002, but has now reversed.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on stimulus hopes, NZ falls as power firms hit
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 5,955.5 points, driven by hopes for further stimulus measures to counter coronavirus-led restrictions. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 2.3% due to the closure of Rio Tinto's aluminium smelters, which will impact power companies. Energy stocks jumped in Australia, while tech stocks rose globally, tracking US peers.

site_title: Japan will not reintroduce state of emergency as Tokyo Covid-19 cases jump
summary: Japan's top government spokesman, Yoshihide Suga, stated that there's no need to reintroduce a state of emergency in Tokyo due to a record one-day rise in coronavirus cases, with 224 new cases reported.
