The majority of cases, 80%, were among people in their 30s or younger, and it's impossible to reduce infection risks to zero after lifting the state of emergency in May.

site_title: Google wins Renault contract in first major French cloud deal
summary: Google has secured a multi-year deal with Renault SA to store the carmaker's manufacturing data, marking its first major industrial cloud deal in France. The deal will gather data from Renault factories, robots, and supply chains, and is expected to improve manufacturing processes and industrial automation. Google calls the contract the largest of its kind globally, although details on the payment and duration are not disclosed. The deal is seen as a significant win for Google, which is working to catch up to cloud rivals in big manufacturing contracts.

images.alt_text: Google has won a multi-year deal to store Renault SA's manufacturing data, marking the US tech company's first major industrial cloud deal in France.

site_title: Hot stock: Biolidics shares climb 35.5% on LC-Bio partnership in China
summary: Biolidics shares surged 35.5% to S$0.42 on Thursday after announcing a five-year partnership with China's LC-Bio to develop cancer-diagnostic solutions. The company will provide materials and consumables, while LC-Bio will provide medical laboratories and space. This partnership comes after Biolidics' shares sank 22% in June due to a terminated distribution agreement in the US.

site_title: Bugis Junction, Wisma Atria, Old Airport Road Food Centre among places visited by Covid-19 patients while infectious
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has released a list of locations visited by Covid-19 patients while infectious, including Bugis Junction, Wisma Atria, and Old Airport Road Food Centre. The list is to monitor the health of those who visited these places for two weeks. A 38-year-old Bangladeshi man died from cardio-respiratory failure, becoming the 14th case of a patient who tested positive for the coronavirus but died from other causes. Meanwhile, 123 residents and visitors at a Tampines Street 11 block have been tested for Covid-19, with all results coming back negative.

site_title: Digital-only bank tonik, Mastercard tie up to drive financial inclusion
summary: Digital-only bank tonik has partnered with Mastercard to drive financial inclusion, particularly for the underserved and unserved population. The partnership will enable tonik to issue electronic payments products tapping Mastercard's global network and business intelligence. Tonik CEO Greg Krasnov stated the partnership aims to inject speed, scale, and performance into tonik's business, set to launch operationally later in 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up on US rallies
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose 0.40% to 22,529.29, driven by US rallies, but early gains were erased after Tokyo reported a single-day record of new coronavirus cases. The broader Topix index remained flat.

site_title: Home sales set to bounce back for Britain's biggest homebuilder
summary: Britain's largest homebuilder, Persimmon, reported a significant rebound in home sales reservations since the easing of lockdown measures. The company's average weekly net private sales reservations rose 30% compared to the same period last year, with a total order book 15% higher. However, total home sales in the first six months of the year fell 35% due to the lockdown, and revenue slumped 32% from the previous year. Despite the challenges, Persimmon's forward sales of £1.86 billion suggest a promising recovery in the housing market.

images.alt_text: Britain's biggest homebuilder, Persimmon, says sales reservations have recovered strongly since the government eased its lockdown measures.

site_title: Tata Sons in talks to buy out AirAsia India stake at steep discount
summary: Tata Sons is in talks to buy out AirAsia Group's 49% stake in their Indian airline joint venture at a steep discount. The move comes as AirAsia faces financial difficulties, with its auditor casting doubt on its ability to continue as a going concern. Tata Sons will likely tie up with other financial investors to acquire the stake. This deal could potentially provide AirAsia with a much-needed injection of funds to stabilize the airline.

site_title: Manhattan apartment rents slide after exodus empties buildings
summary: Manhattan's rental market experienced a significant decline in June, with the apartment-vacancy rate rising to a record 3.67% and available listings surging 85% from last year. The median rent dropped 6.6% to $3,242, the first decline in 18 months. The pandemic-fueled exodus from the city led to a surplus of inventory, prompting landlords to offer discounts and incentives to attract tenants. The vacancy rate is expected to continue rising, with a "summer season that is going to be all about supply."

site_title: Rolls-Royce posts cash outflow of £3b in H1 2020
summary: Rolls-Royce posts a £3 billion cash outflow in the first half of 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, which halved engine flying hours. The company expects an improvement in the second half, resulting in a full-year free cash outflow of about £4 billion. To support recovery, Rolls-Royce plans to cut at least 9,000 jobs and achieve a free cash inflow of at least £750 million by 2022. The company has increased its liquidity to £8.10 billion.

site_title: EMA seeking more LNG term importers for Singapore
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore is seeking up to two new liquefied natural gas (LNG) term importers to enhance competition and provide more options for gas buyers. The current LNG term importers, Pavilion Energy Singapore and Shell Eastern Trading, were appointed in 2017. The EMA expects natural gas to be the dominant fuel in Singapore's energy mix in the near future. Proposals must be submitted by November 9, with the goal of appointing new importers by 2024.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Thursday, following a record close on Wall Street and a positive session in Asia. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.1%, the DAX 30 index gained 1.1%, and the CAC 40 index added 0.4%. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Ant Group listing would be fillip for Hong Kong's flagging IPO market
summary: Hong Kong's IPO market is expected to receive a boost if Ant Group's initial public offering (IPO) is completed by year-end. The city's exchange accounted for 7.6% of the global IPO market in the first half, down from 11% last year. A successful Ant Group IPO would help revive Hong Kong's status as a global financial center, which has been cast in doubt by a new security law. Analysts expect new deals worth US$4.17 billion in the first half, with a total of US$7.91 billion in the same period last year.

site_title: Tokyo 2020 expects to secure all venues for Olympics: local media
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers expect to secure all 2021 venues, according to Japanese media outlets citing unnamed sources. Securing venues was a top priority after the games were postponed due to the pandemic. However, Tokyo 2020 spokesperson Masa Takaya described the reports as "optimistic" and said nothing had been officially announced.

site_title: Uniqlo domestic sales rebound in June after bleak quarter for owner
summary: Uniqlo, a Japanese casual clothing chain, reported a 26% increase in domestic same-store sales in June, after a 57% decline in April and an 18% decline in May. This rebound comes after a bleak quarter for owner Fast Retailing due to the global coronavirus pandemic. However, the group's annual operating profit outlook was revised downward to a 50% fall to 130 billion yen.

site_title: Malaysia's May factory output plummets 22.1% y-o-y, but less than forecast
summary: Malaysia's factory output in May plummeted 22.1% year-over-year, slower than the 25% forecast by analysts, marking the third consecutive month of decline due to the coronavirus pandemic. All three main sectors tracked by the industrial production index posted declines, with manufacturing output falling 23.2%, and exports plummeting 25.5% from a year earlier. The decline was attributed to global slowdown and curbs imposed to contain the pandemic.

site_title: 'Consensus' that Notre-Dame spire should be rebuilt as it was
summary: France's culture minister Roselyne Bachelot stated there is a "large consensus" for the Notre-Dame cathedral's spire to be rebuilt exactly as it was before the 2019 fire. This decision will be made by President Emmanuel Macron, who has previously supported a modern architectural gesture. The French National Heritage and Architecture Commission is set to rule on the issue later Thursday, with reconstruction efforts facing delays due to weather, sanitary concerns, and the pandemic. Macron aims for the cathedral's restoration to be completed by 2024 for the Paris Olympics.

site_title: World's rich question high fees with wealth hitting US$74 trillion
summary: The world's rich are questioning high fees, with 1 in 5 planning to switch primary wealth management firms due to cost concerns. A survey of over 2,500 individuals found that 30% of wealthy investors favor equities, while 25% hold cash. The net worth of wealthy individuals reached $74 trillion at the end of 2019, with 20 million millionaires worldwide, up from 12 million in 2012. Wealth managers are under pressure, with younger investors and those focusing on sustainable investing showing promise for growth areas.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars track US equity strength as risk barometer
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars remained stable against the US dollar, tracking US equity strength, despite a new coronavirus outbreak in Australia. The Aussie dollar hovered at US$0.6975, while the kiwi dollar steadied at US$0.6568, as investors viewed the currencies as a barometer of global risk appetite. Economists expect the Australian government to release a budget update and stimulus measures on July 23, which could lead to increased debt and fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Caesars takeover by Eldorado Resorts wins Nevada's approval
summary: Nevada's Gaming Commission approved Eldorado Resorts Inc.'s takeover of Caesars Entertainment Corp, making Eldorado the largest US casino operator. The deal, valued at over $17 billion, includes marquee resorts like Caesars Palace and Paris in Las Vegas. Federal Trade Commission and other reviews are pending. Eldorado CEO Tom Reeg reported strong demand and revenue growth since reopening, with a focus on boosting results at Caesars' properties and integrating them into the Caesars customer-loyalty program. The merger is expected to achieve $500 million in annual expense savings, with about 1,000 job losses.

site_title: Ford's quarterly China sales rise for the first time in 3 years
summary: Ford Motor reported its first quarterly sales rise in China in almost three years, with a 3% increase in vehicle sales from April-June. The company attributed the rise to a stronger vehicle lineup, including new SUVs and locally-made luxury cars, as well as strong demand following the lifting of Covid-19 pandemic restrictions. In contrast, General Motors' sales in China declined 5.3% during the quarter. Ford's US sales, however, plummeted 33% due to lockdowns and travel restrictions. Industry-wide vehicle wholesale sales in China are expected to grow 11% in June.

site_title: China's producer prices extend declines amid sluggish demand
summary: China's producer prices fell 3.0% in June, marking the fifth consecutive month of decline, amid sluggish demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. The industrial sector remains deflationary, with factories and retailers still grappling with low profits and forced layoffs. However, a recent survey showed a quicker expansion in manufacturing activity, and consumer prices rose 2.5% year-over-year. The economic recovery continues, but export orders remain contracted, highlighting the global impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Tesla 'very close' to level 5 autonomous driving technology, Musk says
summary: Tesla is "very close" to achieving level 5 autonomous driving technology, according to CEO Elon Musk. Musk expressed confidence that the technology will be completed this year, despite industry insiders citing the need for time and public trust. Tesla currently builds cars with an Autopilot driver-assistance system and is developing new heat-projection systems to enable more advanced computers. The company's market capitalization has surpassed that of Toyota, and it has become the highest-valued automaker, with Tesla selling nearly 15,000 China-made Model 3 sedans last month.

site_title: Hyflux gets new S$485m cash, stock offer from Utico
summary: Utico, a Middle Eastern utility firm, has revised its proposed rescue package for Hyflux, a Singapore water treatment firm, to a minimum of S$485 million, comprising cash and stock. The offer is higher than the original proposal and provides more than 10% return to creditors, with small PnP holders expected to recover 15-50% of their investment and larger holders to receive at least 10%. The plan, which benefits about 21,000 small PnP holders and 12,000-13,000 larger PnP holders, is set to close by August 30.

site_title: Senior China diplomat urges 'positive energy' in ties with United States
summary: Chinese State Councilor Wang Yi urged "positive energy" in ties with the US, stating that relations face the most serious challenges since 1979, but can return to the right track. He criticized US policy towards China as based on strategic misjudgments and emotional outbursts, calling for more dialogue and cooperation on issues like the coronavirus pandemic. Wang emphasized that China cannot and will not become another America, and that the US should build a more objective understanding of China.

site_title: Gold holds above US$1,800 level as virus casts long shadow
summary: Gold prices held steady above the $1,800 level on Thursday, driven by concerns over the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and economic recovery. Global coronavirus cases surpassed 12 million, and US Federal Reserve officials suggested a stalled economic recovery. The US dollar traded near multi-week lows, supporting gold prices. The metal has enough catalysts to reach record territory before the end of the year, according to market analysts.

site_title: Can Trump keep his finances secret? US Supreme Court to rule on cases
summary: The US Supreme Court is set to rule on two cases related to Donald Trump's financial records, potentially lifting the veil on his finances ahead of the November 2024 election. Trump has refused to release his tax returns, despite promising to do so during his 2016 campaign, raising questions about his true worth and possible conflicts of interest. The cases, involving Congress and New York prosecutors, test the claim by Trump's attorneys that a president is immune from criminal investigation while in office, with a majority of conservative justices on the court.

images.alt_text: The Supreme Court's decision could lift the veil on Donald Trump's finances ahead of the Nov 3 election.

site_title: AirAsia in talks to secure funding of over RM1b
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia Group is in talks to secure over RM1 billion in funding amid a coronavirus-led travel slump, following doubts cast on its ability to continue as a going concern by its auditor. The airline is in discussions with investment banks, lenders, and interested investors, with some financial institutions indicating support for its funding request. AirAsia has also received deferrals from lessors and is working on further extensions. The airline aims to secure a favorable outcome for the group.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.78 points, or 0.05%, to 1,584.28. Volume was 595.15 million lots worth RM115.45 million, with gainers beating losers 283 to 70.

site_title: US soccer league restarts with sombre ceremony, new virus fears
summary: Major League Soccer resumed play with a sombre anti-racism demonstration, marking the league's return from a four-month shutdown due to the coronavirus pandemic. Orlando City SC defeated Inter Miami 2-1, with Nani scoring the winning goal in the 97th minute. The match was played in a fan-less arena at Disney World's ESPN Wide World of Sports complex. Fresh concerns about another coronavirus-stricken team potentially withdrawing from the league have been raised.

site_title: Amid bullion rally, gold ETF most active on SGX in first half of year
summary: The SPDR Gold Shares ETF, backed by physical gold, was the most active on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in the first half of 2020, with a year-to-date return of 16.2% and an average monthly turnover value of S$156.9 million. The bullion prices rose past the US$1,800 per ounce threshold, driven by investors seeking safety from the coronavirus pandemic and central banks' stimulus packages. The ETF's success is attributed to its innovative and cost-efficient way to access the gold market, allowing investors to bypass logistics and storage issues.

site_title: Australia warns citizens in Hong Kong of detention risk
summary: Australia has warned its citizens in Hong Kong of the risk of detention under China's newly imposed national security law. The warning, issued by the foreign ministry, advises Australians to reconsider their stay in Hong Kong due to the law's vague definition of national security grounds. The move is seen as a response to China's embassy criticizing Australia's previous travel warning, which also mentioned the risk of arbitrary detention in China. Australia is reportedly considering offering "safe haven" visas to Hong Kong residents in the country.

site_title: George Floyd said officers would 'kill' him in new recording transcript
summary: George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man, died in Minneapolis police custody on May 25 after a white officer knelt on his neck for nearly nine minutes. New transcripts of police body camera footage reveal Floyd repeatedly saying "I can't breathe" and stating officers would "kill" him. He also called for his mother and children, and his last words were, "They're going to kill me. They're going to kill me. I can't breathe." Floyd's death sparked massive protests against systemic racism and police brutality in the US and worldwide.

site_title: HDB resale volume jumps 570% m-o-m in June on 'circuit breaker' easing: SRX
summary: Singapore's HDB resale volume surged 570% month-over-month in June, with 2,452 transactions, exceeding the highest monthly volume since July 2018. The surge is attributed to pent-up demand accumulated during the "circuit-breaker" period, which has continued to drive sales. HDB resale prices fell 0.2% month-over-month but rose 0.8% year-over-year, with median transaction over x-values (TOX) indicating some buyers overpaid or underpaid for flats. Experts predict the market may return to a more sustainable monthly figure, but for now, the HDB resale market remains buoyant.

site_title: Kenneth Lai named OCBC's head of global treasury, in an internal appointment
summary: OCBC Bank has appointed Kenneth Lai as its new head of global treasury, effective October 1. Lai will report directly to CEO Samuel Tsien and join the management committee. He succeeds Lam Kun Kin, who is retiring after 33 years in the financial industry. The internal appointment is part of the bank's leadership renewal.

site_title: Buyers return to Covid-hit UK property market in June, RICS says
summary: Buyers returned to the UK property market in June, with a net balance of +61% of RICS members reporting a rise in new buyer enquiries, following a reading of -94% in May. Activity remained depressed, with properties on estate agents' books near all-time lows. The RICS monthly house price balance rose to -15% from -32% in May, with London and south east England among the weakest regions. The rebound may be short-lived due to tightening lending criteria and the uncertain macro environment.

site_title: BOJ offers bleakest view on Japan's regions in over a decade
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has cut its economic view for Japan's nine regions for the second straight quarter, the first such downgrade since 2008, citing damage from the coronavirus pandemic. The move reflects a worsening economy, with factory output, consumption, and capital expenditure slumping. The BOJ's governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, stated that consumer prices are likely to fall, but the economy is expected to improve as the pandemic subsides, supported by stimulus measures and an accommodative monetary environment. Japan's economy is expected to contract by over 20% in the April-June period.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan's July report said all of Japan's nine regional areas saw their economies "worsening" or in a "severe state" due to the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Court ruling in Monaco ends one piece of a US$2b art dispute
summary: A Monaco court has upheld a lower court's ruling to dismiss criminal charges against Yves Bouvier, a Swiss businessman who sold $2 billion worth of artworks to Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev. The ruling finds the prosecution to be unfair and biased, ending a long-running dispute that began when Rybolovlev accused Bouvier of fraud and money laundering. Bouvier maintains his innocence, claiming he was simply an art dealer and not an agent or adviser. The case continues in Geneva, where Bouvier faces separate charges of fraud.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index open modestly higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.30% higher at 22,505.13 on Thursday, driven by Wall Street rallies. The broader Topix index remained flat. Investors took heart from market movements, but trade was subdued due to a lack of fresh events.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust completes acquisition of 2 Chinese malls for S$344.1m
summary: DASIN Retail Trust has completed the acquisition of two Chinese malls, Shunde Metro Mall and Tanbei Metro Mall, for approximately S$344.1 million. The acquisition expands the trust's portfolio to 12.1 billion yuan, increasing its gross floor area by 31.7% to 793,752 square meters. Pro forma net property income is expected to increase by 28.3% to S$77 million. The deal strengthens the trust's foothold in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macau Greater Bay Area and is expected to boost its distribution per unit.

site_title: Trump 'bullying' blamed as key impeachment witness quits army
summary: Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman, a key impeachment witness against President Donald Trump, retired from the US Army on Wednesday after being subjected to "bullying, intimidation and retaliation." Vindman, 45, was fired from his position on the National Security Council in February, two days after Trump's acquittal. His attorney stated that Vindman's promotion to full colonel was denied, leading to his retirement. The move comes after Vindman testified that Trump's actions were "impeachable."

site_title: Japan to develop offshore wind farms at 30 sites in 10 years: Nikkei
summary: Japan aims to develop offshore wind farms at 30 sites within the next decade, with a goal of 10 gigawatts of generation capacity by 2031. Industry Minister Hiroshi Kajiyama is expected to announce policy measures, including crafting new rules and supporting infrastructure. The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism plans to build storage facilities and reinforce ports, while the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry will revise power grid rules to scrap restrictions on greener power suppliers. This move aims to speed the expansion of Japan's offshore wind power market, following the enforcement of the Offshore Wind Promotion Act last year.

site_title: Ryanair cabin crew agree pay cuts to save jobs
summary: Ryanair has agreed to retain the jobs of all UK-based cabin crew in exchange for pay cuts of up to 10% spread over four years. The deal was reached after a vote by Ryanair members of the Unite union, following a similar agreement between Irish carrier Aer Lingus and Balpa for pilots. The move comes after Ryanair announced plans to cut 3,000 jobs due to the coronavirus pandemic, with passenger numbers falling 97% in June 2020.

site_title: Cybersecurity startup Aiculus raises US$670,000 led by Cocoon Capital, angel investor
summary: Aiculus, a Singapore-based cybersecurity startup, has raised US$670,000 in a seed funding round led by Cocoon Capital and an angel investor. The company provides software security solutions for businesses using application programming interfaces (APIs), securing operational APIs without accessing confidential user data. With the funding, Aiculus plans to grow its technology team, expand its network of partners, and accelerate growth in Australia and South-east Asia. The funding comes as the API market grows rapidly, driven by open banking regulations and the need for proper safeguards to prevent data breaches.

site_title: Singapore stocks post modest gains after Wall Street rally; STI up 0.2% at open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 2,675.39 at open, following a Wall Street rally overnight. The benchmark index gained 5.90 points, with gains outnumbering losses 104 to 33. Banking stocks, including DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank, were mostly up, while UG Healthcare advanced 4.4%. The market will be closed on Friday, Polling Day, and the US market saw tech stocks lift the Nasdaq to a record close, while European shares ended lower.

site_title: HKMA sells HK$4.29b into market overnight after currency strengthens
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) sold HK$4.29 billion into the market overnight after the Hong Kong dollar strengthened to the strong end of its trading band. The move aims to keep the currency within the pegged range of 7.75-7.85 to the US dollar. This is the largest single daily injection since April and increases the aggregate balance by HK$15.76 billion, taking it to HK$164.89 billion.

site_title: US adds 55,000 new Covid-19 cases in 24 hours
summary: The US reported 55,000 new Covid-19 cases and 833 virus deaths in 24 hours, bringing the total infections to 3,046,351 and the death toll to 132,195. The country has passed the 3 million infection milestone, with actual numbers likely higher due to testing issues in March and April. Southern hotspots like Texas, Florida, and Arizona are experiencing surging cases, while New York and the northeast have seen a decline. US President Trump continues to downplay the numbers, despite calls to ease health and safety requirements.

images.alt_text: The United States recorded 55,000 new coronavirus cases in 24 hours on Wednesday, a tally by Johns Hopkins University showed, bringing its total to 3,046,351 recorded infections since the pandemic began.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on Thursday with a 0.85% gain, reaching 26,351.13 on the Hang Seng Index. The gains follow another record-breaking performance on Wall Street. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index showed minimal changes. The rally in Hong Kong stocks comes as investors remain optimistic despite uncertainty over US tariffs and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Japan rescuers battle to reach thousands trapped by floods
summary: Japanese emergency services and troops are battling to reach thousands of homes cut off by devastating flooding and landslides in the southwestern region of Kumamoto, where dozens have died and widespread damage has been caused. Over 3,000 households are isolated, and the rain front is forecast to continue until July 12, prompting "extreme vigilance" on landslide risks and flooding. Rescuers have managed to reach some 40 residents in the village of Ashikita, but the coronavirus pandemic has reduced capacity at shelters and discouraged people from volunteering to help with the rescue efforts.

site_title: Preparing for a reset after circuit-breaker measures
summary: The Central Region of Singapore, including Core Central Region (CCR) and Rest of Central Region (RCR), saw a dampening of real estate market sentiment in March 2020 due to the Covid-19 outbreak. However, market segments within the region have varied in their response. Industry players are now preparing for a reset, with many ready to woo buyers locally and internationally. New sales in the RCR have shown positive results, indicating a potential recovery in the market.

site_title: Family behind Paris Baguette loses billions by taking on the world
summary: The SPC Group, a South Korean company behind the Paris Baguette chain, has suffered significant losses due to its global expansion efforts, with chairman Hur Young-in's family losing billions of dollars. The company's net income has slumped 77% since 2016, and its shares have slid 84% from 2015. Despite the challenges, Hur plans to increase the number of outlets worldwide to 20,000 by 2030 and venture into new markets, including Canada. The company's struggles serve as a reminder that expanding into new markets can be costly and challenging, but also presents opportunities for growth.

site_title: China state media commentary urges investor respect for market
summary: Chinese state media urged investors to respect the market, manage risks, and pursue rational investments amid a recent rally and multi-year highs in Chinese stocks. The commentary cited the 2015 market crash as a warning, emphasizing the importance of a "healthy and prosperous stock market." China's securities regulator has also taken steps to curb excessive speculation, publishing a list of 258 illegal margin lending platforms. The market's strong performance is seen as crucial for funding a rapidly developing digital economy and strengthening China's influence in global power rivalries.

site_title: India becomes unlikely M&A hotspot as Asian deals disappear
summary: India has emerged as a rare bright spot for dealmaking in 2020, with the country accounting for over 12% of announced deals in the Asia-Pacific region, driven largely by investments in tech venture Jio Platforms from companies like Facebook and Silver Lake Partners. The country's digital economy is witnessing a surge in investment, with the healthcare and infrastructure sectors also seeing a significant influx of capital. Despite recent tensions with China, bankers expect global investors to continue pouring into India, with some predicting a pickup in Chinese investments late next year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Keppel, Clearbridge, Hatten Land, Biolidics
summary: Olam International and Keppel Corporation saw notable developments. Olam Treasury secured a 25 billion yen (S$324.2 million) samurai loan facility, causing Olam shares to close down 0.7%. Keppel Corporation's upstream oil and gas firm KrisEnergy's debt restructuring was extended to Sept 30.

site_title: Fortress Minerals Q1 profit nearly doubles amid strong domestic demand
summary: Fortress Minerals reported a 97.9% surge in Q1 net profit to US$2.2 million, driven by strong domestic demand for its iron ore products. Revenue rose 21.4% to US$7.1 million, driven by a 34.4% increase in sales volume. However, the company's lower realised selling price and no dividend payment were offsetting factors. Despite disruptions to operations due to Malaysia's Covid-19 movement control order, Fortress Minerals' operations resumed normally, and the company remains cautiously optimistic about the iron ore market.

site_title: Clearbridge Health's Philippine unit reports 8 cases of Covid-19
summary: Clearbridge Health's Philippine unit reported 8 cases of COVID-19, prompting a voluntary 14-day cessation of operations and segregation of non-affected areas at its Manila medical centre. The impact on the group's financial performance is expected to be minimal. Meanwhile, Clearbridge Health's spin-off Biolidics entered a collaboration agreement with Hangzhou-based LC-Bio to develop cancer-diagnostic solutions.

site_title: Singapore's Law Society warns of fraudsters targeting law firms
summary: The Law Society of Singapore has warned of fraudsters targeting law firms in a scheme to steal funds through online transfers. Two cases were cited, where fraudsters impersonated the law firm's lawyers or altered invoices to divert funds. The society urged clients to verify payment requests with their law firms before acting, and advised law practices to report incidents to the police and advise clients to do the same.

site_title: Japan's machinery orders tick up, signals resilience in capital spending
summary: Japan's machinery orders unexpectedly rose 1.7% in May, defying analyst projections of a 5.4% drop, indicating that capital spending remains resilient despite the coronavirus pandemic's impact on corporate profits. This rise was driven by a 17.7% increase in non-manufacturer orders, while manufacturers' orders declined 15.5%. The Bank of Japan will review these results at its policy review on July 14-15, but is expected to maintain its current stance. The data suggests Japan's economy is still holding up, with capital expenditure backed by demand for automation and high-tech investment.

site_title: KrisEnergy, Keppel unit extend restructuring completion date in loan agreement
summary: KrisEnergy's debt restructuring completion date has been extended to September 30 from July 15 under an amended loan agreement with Kepinvest Singapore. The agreement, worth up to US$87 million, was inked in April to finance the development project at Cambodia Block A. The extension aims to facilitate a consensual restructuring and support KrisEnergy's management as they discuss and obtain feedback from stakeholders. Keppel reserves the right to evaluate and approve or reject the restructuring plan in its best interests.

site_title: Namibia grounds cash-strapped national airline
summary: Namibia's national airline, Air Namibia, has been grounded due to failing to provide a "safe and reliable service." The transport ministry cited the airline's inability to meet operating requirements, including the need for 7 billion rand (S$584.4 million) to stay airborne. The airline has 10 aircraft and 800 employees. The ministry has given the airline until July 22 to secure funding or risk having its operating licence cancelled, and may only allow humanitarian and repatriation flights during the coronavirus state of emergency.

site_title: US infections top three million as Trump pushes schools reopening
summary: The US has surpassed 3 million confirmed coronavirus cases, with over 131,000 deaths, as President Donald Trump pushes for schools to reopen despite a resurgence in southern hotspots. Trump criticized the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for its guidelines, which the agency's head later clarified were not requirements. Worldwide, the virus has infected 12 million people and killed over 500,000, with countries experiencing fresh waves of disease.

site_title: Twitter shares take wing on plan for subscription platform
summary: Twitter shares surged over 7% after news of a team codenamed "Gryphon" working on a subscription platform spread. The team's plan aims to introduce a paid service, potentially altering the free, one-to-many messaging service's business model. US President Donald Trump frequently posts on the platform, which has become a key online venue for news and commentary. The news boosted Twitter shares, with the stock rising nearly 7.4% at the close of the New York Stock Exchange and more in after-market trades.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda says economy to improve as pandemic impact subsides
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that Japan's economy will remain in a severe state but improve ahead as the pandemic impact subsides. The economy is expected to improve due to pent-up demand, an accommodative monetary environment, and the government's stimulus package. However, core consumer prices are likely to fall for the time being due to sliding oil costs and pandemic impact. The Bank of Japan's outlook contrasts with recent warnings from other central banks about potential economic slowdowns.

site_title: Rio Tinto to shutter New Zealand aluminium smelter, putting jobs and economy in peril
summary: Rio Tinto will close its New Zealand aluminium smelter, putting over 1,000 jobs at risk and dealing a blow to the country's top power producers. The closure, due to high costs and a challenging market, comes amid forecasts of massive job losses and a looming recession in New Zealand. The move puts pressure on Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, who recently launched her re-election bid, promising more jobs and financial assistance to businesses. The closure is also a significant loss for the country's power sector, with the smelter being its single largest user.

site_title: Houston cancels Texas Republicans convention over virus concerns
summary: Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner has canceled the Texas Republican Party's state convention due to concerns over the novel coronavirus, citing the city's surge in cases. The convention, scheduled for July 16-18, will be held online instead. Turner stated that the decision is to protect the health and safety of attendees, citing warnings from the Houston Health Department. The move comes as other major Houston events have been canceled in recent months. The Republican Party chairman accused Turner of a "hypocritical flip flop" on public gatherings, citing the city's earlier authorization of massive protests.

site_title: Offerings beckon in Singapore's 5 regions
summary: In Singapore, buying residential property remains a popular choice for investors and owner-occupiers amid the economic downturn. With a competitive market and low interest rates, developers are launching new projects, offering attractive prices. The five regions in Singapore - Central, East, North-east, North, and West - each have unique features and advantages, such as beachfront properties in the East Region and nature reserves in the North Region. Experts predict a steady recovery in the market, with buyers advised to carefully consider their financial capacity and risk profile before making a purchase.

site_title: Covid-19 has trapped US$111 billion of luxury spending in China
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted China's luxury spending market, with US$111 billion in luxury goods being trapped due to travel restrictions and disruptions to parallel importers. As a result, global luxury houses are rethinking their strategies to reach mainland Chinese consumers, with many expanding their presence in China and offering virtual storefronts on e-commerce platforms. The trend of domestic spending is expected to continue, with over half of Chinese luxury purchases predicted to happen domestically by 2025, according to consultancy Bain & Co.

site_title: Virus crisis sends Canada deficit soaring
summary: Canada's federal budget deficit has soared to over $3 billion for the 2020-2021 fiscal year, with a total of $343 billion, 10 times higher than initial estimates. The pandemic forced several sectors to shut down, significantly reducing government tax revenue. The Liberal government's $230 billion crisis recovery plan aims to support the economy, but the government's debt is expected to explode, rising from 31% to 49% of GDP. International ratings agencies have also downgraded Canada's debt rating, citing the pandemic's impact on the economy.

site_title: Airbus deliveries down 50% in first half of 2020
summary: Airbus reported a 50% decline in plane deliveries for the first half of 2020, with 196 aircraft delivered compared to 389 in the same period in 2019. The company also recorded no new orders in June for the second consecutive month. The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted the aviation sector, with fleets of planes parked at airports worldwide. Airbus expects production and deliveries to be 40% lower than forecast for the next two years, leading to the potential loss of 15,000 jobs.

site_title: Foreign firms surrendering more Hong Kong office space
summary: Hong Kong's vacancy rate has reached its highest in 15 years due to foreign firms surrendering more office space, according to Cushman & Wakefield. In the second quarter, foreign companies made up 61% of the total office space surrender, up from 47% in the previous quarter. This trend is attributed to the city's deteriorating economy amid the pandemic.

site_title: Women in senior management stagnant in corporate Spain at only 16%
summary: Women hold 16% of senior management positions in Spanish listed companies, unchanged from 2019. Despite a 3.6% increase in female representation on boards of directors to 27.5%, this still falls short of the CNMV's targets of 30% by 2020 and 40% by 2022. Only four of the 35 IBEX 35 companies have women on their management boards, with energy group Naturgy having the lowest female representation at 8%. The left-wing government aims to improve gender equality, but corporate Spain remains male-dominated.

site_title: Trump hails 'outstanding relationship' with Mexico president
summary: President Donald Trump welcomed Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador to the White House, praising their "outstanding relationship" and saying the US-Mexico border has "never been closer" than it is now. Trump and Lopez Obrador discussed the newly-launched US-Mexico-Canada Agreement trade deal, with both leaders emphasizing their commitment to fighting corruption and putting their countries' interests first. The meeting was seen as a positive development in US-Mexico relations, with Lopez Obrador expressing gratitude for Trump's "kindness and respect".

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump on Wednesday hailed his "outstanding relationship" with his Mexican counterpart Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador as he welcomed him to the White House for the leaders' first one-on-one meeting.

site_title: Steady home demand shows resilience
summary: The East Region of Singapore, comprising Bedok, Changi, Changi Bay, Pasir Ris, Paya Lebar, and Tampines, continues to attract homebuyers with its lifestyle and living package, characterized by nature and man-made amenities. Despite the COVID-19 circuit-breaker period, new home sales in the East Region remained steady, with demand ranging between 250 and 350 units per quarter from 2019 to Q1 2020. Prices in the main residential areas of Bedok, Pasir Ris, and Tampines increased, with Bedok commanding the highest median rent and average unit prices. Future developments, such as the construction of Terminal 5 at Changi Airport and the relocation of Paya Lebar Air Base, are expected to enhance connectivity and create new employment centers, boosting the region's appeal.

site_title: US airlines move towards federal loans as Covid-19 surge threatens demand, jobs
summary: US airlines, including United, Delta, Alaska Airlines, JetBlue Airways, and Southwest Airlines, have signed letters of intent for federal loans under the CARES Act to help them weather the Covid-19 surge, which is threatening demand and jobs. The loans are part of a $25 billion package, and airlines have until September 30 to decide whether to take the loan. United has warned staff of potential furloughs effective October 1 due to declining bookings, and only a small number of employees have signed up for voluntary departure packages.

site_title: Oil settles higher on improving US petrol demand
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures up 21 cents to $43.29 a barrel and US WTI crude futures up 28 cents to $40.90 a barrel. US petrol consumption showed signs of recovery, with inventories tumbling 4.8 million barrels to 8.8 million barrels per day. However, price gains were limited by rising crude inventories and an increase in coronavirus infections. Refinery utilization remained low, hovering 17% below last year's level. Despite a potential Opec deal on output cuts, the latest surge in US cases reduced hopes for a swift recovery in oil demand.

site_title: Toyota launches financial services arm in Singapore
summary: Toyota has launched its financial services arm in Singapore, offering customers a promotional interest rate of 1.88% for new car loans and a "Buy-now, Pay Later" scheme with zero instalments for one year. The subsidiary, Toyota Financial Services Singapore, has partnered with Borneo Motors Singapore to provide financial services through its showrooms. The move aims to give buyers more financing alternatives, with zero down payments and zero instalments for the first year. With an initial investment of S$23 million, Toyota Financial Services Singapore aims to compete with other car brands and financial institutions in the market.

site_title: Robinhood has lured young traders, sometimes with devastating results
summary: Robinhood, a popular trading app, has lured young investors with its free trading and no account minimums, but at a high cost. The app's business model relies on payment for order flow, where Wall Street firms pay Robinhood for the right to execute trades, and the company makes significantly more from these transactions. This has led to inexperienced investors engaging in riskiest trading practices, resulting in significant losses. The app's tech issues and lack of adequate guardrails have exacerbated the problem, with some customers experiencing losses of millions of dollars.

images.alt_text: Richard Dobatse, a Navy medic in San Diego, dabbled infrequently in stock trading. But his behaviour changed in 2017 when he signed up for Robinhood, a trading app that made buying and selling stocks simple and seemingly free.

site_title: Europe: HSBC and Nokia drag stocks lower amid virus worries
summary: European stocks fell 0.7% on Wednesday, with HSBC and Nokia dragging the Stoxx 600 down due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak and its impact on the global economy. Despite UK finance minister Rishi Sunak's announcement of an additional 30 billion pounds in stimulus, economists say it may not completely change the economic outlook. The US coronavirus outbreak crossed a grim milestone, and investors remain cautious about the progress of a European Union recovery fund and the upcoming earnings season.

site_title: US judge dismisses GM suit against FCA
summary: A US federal judge dismissed General Motors' lawsuit against Fiat Chrysler, citing "holes" in GM's claim that FCA bribed auto union officials to secure an unfair advantage. The lawsuit, which alleged FCA bribed officials to force a merger, was deemed a "waste of time" by Judge Paul Borman, who dismissed it with prejudice, meaning it cannot be appealed. The ruling came after GM failed to provide sufficient evidence to support its claims.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at record high as stocks finish solidly up
summary: US stocks ended at record highs on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 1.4% to a new close of 10,492.50. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained, with the Dow up 0.7% and the S&P 500 advancing 0.8%. Despite concerns over coronavirus cases, investors viewed the pullback as a buying opportunity, citing the Federal Reserve's maximum support for the economy. Large tech companies, including Amazon, Apple, and Microsoft, drove the gains, while Levi Strauss & Co fell 8.3% after reporting a loss.

site_title: How Germany fell back in love with Angela Merkel
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's leadership during the COVID-19 pandemic has revitalized her popularity in Germany, with 82% of Germans saying she's doing her job "rather well." After years of criticism for being absent and listless, Merkel's decisive actions in coordinating with state governors and the European Union have earned her praise. Her ability to connect with the German people, particularly through a televised speech, has also been a key factor in her renewed popularity. Merkel's legacy is now cemented, and her exit from office may be sooner than expected, with the pandemic likely to be her final challenge.

site_title: Japan drafts 'Digital New Deal' to upgrade dated admin services
summary: Japan is drafting a 'Digital New Deal' to upgrade its outdated administrative services, following the Covid-19 pandemic. The plan aims to adapt to a "post-coronavirus way of life" by enhancing digital capabilities. Key focus areas include updating government ministries and public services. Japan's third-largest economy will prioritize digital infrastructure upgrades in 2021, aiming to improve its administrative efficiency and adapt to changing global circumstances.

site_title: China Evergrande to sell bulk of commercial properties
summary: China Evergrande Group, the nation's second-largest property developer, plans to sell a bulk of its commercial properties in an effort to lower its debt ratio. The company will sell around 200 properties, including office towers, shops, hotels, and convention centers, across China. This move aims to address the developer's financial struggles and reduce its debt burden. The sale will likely have significant implications for the Chinese real estate market and the company's stakeholders.

site_title: Facebook blocks accounts linked to Roger Stone, Brazil president
summary: Facebook removed accounts linked to Roger Stone, a longtime ally of US President Donald Trump, after an investigation found links to a network involved in deceptive activity dating back to the 2016 US election. The network, uncovered with the help of the Robert Mueller investigation, was also linked to fake accounts in Brazil, Canada, Ecuador, and Ukraine. Facebook's head of security policy, Nathaniel Gleicher, stated that the goal was to prevent the reactivation of these assets in the upcoming election. The network operated across platforms, including Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and YouTube, and focused on promoting Stone and his allies.

site_title: S-E Asia's first S Korean startup centre opens in Singapore
summary: Singapore has officially opened its first South Korean startup centre, the Singapore K-Startup Centre (KSC), in partnership with South Korea's Ministry of SMEs and Startups. The centre will host its first batch of six startups in October 2020 through an eight-week incubation programme on fintech and cyber security. The centre aims to facilitate collaboration between Singapore and South Korean SMEs and startups, and is expected to benefit from the dynamic innovation and technology expertise of Korean startups.

site_title: Dubai hotels ready to welcome foreign visitors
summary: Dubai hotels have started welcoming foreign visitors after the city reopened to tourists in mid-May. However, bookings are expected to remain soft due to ongoing COVID-19 concerns globally and the seasonal summer lull in the Gulf. Seven hotels in the region have seen an increase in bookings, with Atlantis Dubai managing director Tim Kelly expecting a "solid" fourth quarter. Occupancy rates are currently around 25% at hotels in Dubai, with most bookings coming from the Middle East and Europe.

site_title: UK finance minister offers jobs bonuses, cuts taxes to avert jobs crisis
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak announced a £30 billion plan to combat an unemployment crisis, including paying employers to bring back furloughed workers and cutting taxes for the hospitality sector and homebuyers. The plan aims to support businesses and individuals affected by the pandemic. Sunak stated that he will not accept unemployment as an unavoidable outcome. The move is a response to the UK's economic slowdown, with the economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

images.alt_text: Mr Sunak told Parliament: "I will never accept unemployment as an unavoidable outcome."

site_title: CGS-CIMB upgrades ARA Logos to 'add', citing stronger focus on growth
summary: CGS-CIMB has upgraded its rating on ARA Logos Logistics Trust (ALog) to "add" from "hold" and raised its target price to 71.3 Singapore cents, citing a stronger focus on growth. Analysts attributed the upgrade to the trust's earnings clarity and a shift in focus to growth, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. They also noted the trust's attractive yield and valuation gap compared to peers, which they expect to narrow as uncertainties subside.

site_title: Pritam: Government more responsive with elected opposition MPs in House
summary: Singaporean opposition leader Pritam Singh stated that when opposition MPs are elected into Parliament, the government becomes more responsive and sensitive to the concerns of the people. He emphasized the importance of having a credible opposition party to speak up for workers, particularly with Singapore's ageing population reshaping its society and labour force. Singh also expressed concerns about the ruling People's Action Party dominating Parliament, potentially weakening the country's solidarity.

site_title: Househunt July 2020
summary: Key real estate news includes a report on Good Class Bungalow prices in Singapore, where developers are getting realistic about pricing. US mortgage rates have climbed after five straight weeks of declines. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above $3,000 psf. Manhattan rents have hit a record, with more increases expected. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. Additionally, Goldman Sachs has acquired a significant hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul, and WeWork has secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore.

site_title: HSBC slumps as US weighs moves to punish banks in Hong Kong
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc slumped after US advisers discussed punishing banks in Hong Kong and destabilizing the currency peg to the dollar. The bank, which generates over two-thirds of its pretax income from Hong Kong, was named as a potential target. Secretary of State Michael Pompeo previously singled out HSBC's Asia Pacific CEO, Peter Wong, for signing a petition supporting Beijing's decision to destroy Hong Kong's autonomy. The move is seen as a response to Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests.

site_title: Trump's tactics widening the racial divide in the US
summary: US President Donald Trump's tactics are exacerbating racial tensions and widening the racial divide in the US. Despite the country's progress in civil rights and racial equality, protests and riots sparked by the killing of George Floyd have reignited discussions on racism. Trump's rhetoric and actions, including his attacks on peaceful protesters and threats to employ military force, have further divided Americans. His re-election campaign is now deeply entangled with the cultural war fueled by racial tensions, with the goal of driving fearful middle-class white voters to his side.

site_title: Total disclosed PE and VC deal value down 65% in Q1: EY
summary: Private equity and venture capital activity in South-east Asia declined 65% in Q1 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with total disclosed deal value at US$1.4 billion, down from US$4.1 billion a year ago. The number of deals fell 9% to 141, according to EY. Despite this, investments in some segments are expected to pick up as economies recover from lockdowns.

images.alt_text: It had seemed like a standard boilerplate event in October last year when Singapore's mainboard-listed Mirach Energy announced a change of external auditors from Ernst & Young to BDO, citing, among other things, a potential savings of up to a quarter in audit fees.

site_title: Interactive Brokers opens Singapore office, offers access to local stocks
summary: Interactive Brokers has established a local entity, Interactive Brokers Singapore, and opened an office in the Marina Bay financial district. The brokerage can now offer Singapore-listed stocks to local investors and market offerings globally from a single integrated account. The move strengthens its presence in Singapore and follows other brokers exiting the country. Over 37% of Interactive Brokers' accounts come from Asia, and the firm has been active in Singapore for many years, participating in the Singapore Exchange's derivatives committee and supporting its initiatives.

site_title: Homebuyers drawn to live-work-play lifestyle in a green enclave
summary: The North Region of Singapore is experiencing a surge in popularity among homebuyers and tenants, driven by its affordability, green spaces, and cultural attractions. The region has seen a steady growth in private residential properties, executive condominiums, and landed houses, with median rents increasing by 69.2% between 2000 and 2020. Despite a limited supply of private homes, the leasing market has strengthened, with 297 units sold per quarter between 2010 and 2019. Authorities plan to transform the region into a new eco-tourism destination by 2024, featuring nature and wildlife parks, green public spaces, and recreational facilities. This development is expected to boost the investment and rental potential of properties in the area.

site_title: SDP's Tambyah, PSP's Cheng Bock rue lack of room to engage, debate PAP
summary: Singapore opposition leaders criticize the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) for not engaging in open debates, citing the lack of room for discussion on issues. SDP chairman Paul Tambyah and PSP chief Tan Cheng Bock offered to debate the PAP on the COVID-19 pandemic response, but were met with refusal. Tambyah and Tan expressed concerns that voters may not have seen the opposition's materials, making it difficult to win the election. The opposition parties accuse the PAP of focusing on name-calling and using dubious laws to silence their critics.

site_title: Australia could lose up to A$1b each week with reimposed lockdown in Victoria
summary: Australia is facing an economic hit of up to A$1 billion per week due to Victoria's reimposed lockdown, which has confined 4.9 million people to their homes and closed businesses such as cafes, restaurants, and gyms. The lockdown, in place for at least six weeks, is expected to severely impact businesses, particularly those in the state of Victoria, which accounts for a quarter of the national economy. The restrictions are also likely to delay domestic travel and affect sales and profits for major firms.

site_title: Leaked audio clips taken out of context, 'circulated with ill-intent': Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing released a Facebook post clarifying leaked audio clips of a 2019 conversation, stating they were taken out of context and circulated with ill-intent. The clips initially suggested the PAP's election results were impacted by a crisis, but Chan clarified that the discussion was about the party's response to the crisis, not its election results. The leaked audio clips were published by The Online Citizen Asia, and Chan's clarification aimed to set the record straight.

site_title: Don Don Donki to open ninth Singapore outlet
summary: Japanese retailer Don Don Donki is set to open its ninth outlet in Singapore, putting it on track to reach its goal of 10 stores in the Republic by 2020. The new store location has not been revealed yet. This marks the retailer's continued expansion in the country despite the challenges posed by the novel coronavirus pandemic. Don Don Donki already operates eight outlets in Singapore, with the latest one opening at Jem mall in Jurong.

site_title: No admiring crowd to watch Japan fireflies' magical dance
summary: Japan's Tatsuno town, usually hosting a popular firefly festival, has cancelled the event due to coronavirus prevention measures, resulting in no admiring crowd to witness the fireflies' magical dance. The cancellation follows similar measures taken at other festivals nationwide.

site_title: PM: Jobs the top concern of voters
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has highlighted jobs as the top concern of voters ahead of the July 10 General Election. The PAP candidates have emphasized the need to address economic concerns, including securing jobs, investments, and supply lines. The government has also stressed its efforts to tackle Covid-19, with the Prime Minister acknowledging that the situation is stable but unpredictable. The election is seen as a crucial moment for the government to demonstrate its ability to address pressing economic issues and secure a mandate to tackle the challenges ahead.

site_title: Magnet for private home transactions
summary: The North-east Region in Singapore has seen significant growth in private residential transactions, accounting for 40.3% of the Outside Central Region's total in 2019. The region's total stock of private homes grew by 41.3% from 2015 to 2020, with non-landed units expanding by 78.4%. Amenities and transport connectivity are key attractions, with popular shopping malls, MRT lines, and expressways. Property prices are more affordable compared to prime districts or city fringe, making it an attractive option for home buyers.

site_title: Consider: Is there opportunity in a crisis in the residential market?
summary: The Singapore residential property market has shown resilience despite the pandemic, with flash estimates indicating a 1.1% quarter-on-quarter decline in the private residential property price index in Q2 2020. The HDB resale market saw a 0.2% increase. Interest in the market has centered on Outside Central Region, with 80% of Singaporeans buying private residential properties in April and May. The market's recovery is attributed to developers' ability to sell units during the "circuit breaker" lockdown, primarily to buyers who had visited show galleries earlier.

site_title: Time to look west for opportunities
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience its worst recession since independence, with GDP growth forecasted to shrink 7-4% in 2020. The West Region of Singapore, however, is poised for growth with several new developments, including two MRT lines, a commercial hub, and a high-tech industrial hub. Non-landed private home prices in the West Region have risen 14.9% over the past four quarters, outperforming overall suburban prices. Despite a demand shock in 2020, long-term fundamentals remain intact, making it an opportunity for investors.

site_title: NZ's housing market defies slump prediction as Kiwis flock home
summary: New Zealand's housing market has defied predictions of a slump, with home values gaining 7.4% in June compared to the previous year, according to Quotable Value. The country's success in eliminating COVID-19 transmission has attracted thousands of citizens living abroad, driving demand in the property market. Despite an economic slump and rising unemployment, prices rose 1.3% over the past three months, with the average home price reaching NZ$738,018. Low interest rates and relaxed mortgage lending restrictions have also contributed to the market's resilience.

site_title: Sports Link buckles under overdue debts
summary: Singapore retailer Sports Link Holdings has been ordered to be wound up due to S$3.4 million in overdue debts, with Adidas Singapore leading the charge. The company failed to pay a S$1.3 million debt in 2018 and despite a repayment plan, the amount owed grew to S$991,000. The High Court granted Adidas Singapore's application to liquidate the company, with no objection from Sports Link. The company had over 24 outlets in Singapore but has not filed financial statements in recent years.

site_title: Singapore stocks post modest gains ahead of polls, release of macro data
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% to 2,669.49 on Wednesday, driven by modest gains despite regional peers showing mixed results. Key gauges in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Malaysia rose, while Japan, South Korea, and Australia fell due to caution over virus news. Traders await the release of Japan's machinery orders, China's inflation figures, and US jobless claims.

site_title: US dollar drifts as risk sentiment proves elusive
summary: The US dollar drifted lower against its rivals on Wednesday, as investors weighed hopes for a swift economic recovery against fears of a pandemic resurgence. The euro rose marginally to US$1.1289, while oil prices steadied. The US dollar's stability is attributed to the lack of visibility for global growth, with rising virus cases in the US potentially strengthening the currency as a safe haven. Sterling rose 0.2% to US$1.2561 as trade talks between Britain and the EU resumed.

site_title: All eyes on quartet of 'hot' GRCs
summary: All 17 group representation constituencies (GRCs) in Singapore's General Election are up for grabs. Four battlegrounds, Aljunied, East Coast, Sengkang, and West Coast, have generated significant attention. Opposing camps have reaffirmed their commitment to working for residents in these hotly-contested areas. The election is set to take place on Friday, with all 17 GRCs being contested.

site_title: Party for your party
summary: Singaporeans prepare to celebrate Polling Day with party gatherings, despite social distancing measures. A Weekend magazine guide offers food and drink recommendations, as well as creative catering ideas, to liven up the evening. Locally-inspired cocktails and party attire suggestions are also provided. While election home parties have been toned down, they remain a popular tradition, with some sharing stories of elaborate celebrations in the past.

site_title: GS Holdings explains S$2 sale of subsidiaries' assets
summary: GS Holdings has proposed selling its two cleaning and dishwashing subsidiaries, GS Cleaning Services (GCS) and GS Equipment Supply (GES), to a former subsidiary, GreatSolutions, for S$2. However, the combined adjusted net asset value of the subsidiaries is S$100. GS Holdings cited the difficulty in selling the subsidiaries' assets separately and the fact that the subsidiaries' assets comprised software, property, and cash. There were no discussions with other potential buyers, and shareholder approval was not sought due to the disposal of the cleaning and dishwashing business segment.

site_title: TikTok launches new ad platform as scrutiny increases
summary: TikTok has launched a self-serve ad platform for small and mid-size businesses, offering innovative tools to create authentic content. The move aims to compete with rival social platforms like Facebook, YouTube, and Twitter, amid scrutiny in the US and elsewhere. The platform's launch comes after TikTok was banned in India and US authorities are studying actions against the platform. The company has sought to distance itself from its Chinese owners, denying allegations of data sharing with Beijing.

site_title: AirAsia shares record biggest daily fall after auditor flags 'going concern' doubts
summary: AirAsia shares plummeted 17% on Wednesday, their largest daily fall, amid doubts cast by auditor EY on the airline's ability to continue as a going concern due to the coronavirus travel slump. The airline's 2019 earnings were prepared on a going concern basis, dependent on a recovery from the pandemic and fundraising efforts. AirAsia has posted significant losses, with a first-quarter loss of RM803 million, and its liabilities exceeded its assets by RM1.84 billion at the end of 2019. The airline is evaluating capital-raising proposals to strengthen its equity base.

site_title: Ringo marks 80th online with Beatles hits, celebrity tributes
summary: Ringo Starr celebrated his 80th birthday with an online concert featuring Sheryl Crow, Kenny Loggins, and other musicians, raising funds for causes including Black Lives Matter and MusiCares. The event concluded with a rare archive clip of Ringo and Paul McCartney performing "Helter Skelter."

site_title: Facebook not doing enough to fight discrimination, audit says
summary: Facebook has not done enough to combat discrimination on its platform, according to an independent audit commissioned by the company. The audit found that the company has been too willing to exempt politicians from its rules, allowing them to spread misinformation and divisive rhetoric. Facebook has taken a hands-off approach to political speech, and civil rights campaigners have expressed frustration and anger over the company's lack of action. The audit's findings are likely to add pressure to the company, which is already facing a boycott by 900 advertisers.

site_title: EU states not so different after all, despite divisions
summary: The European Union has seen a remarkable turnaround in its response to the Covid-19 pandemic, with member states agreeing on unprecedented measures to address the economic fallout. Despite initial divisions and national border closures, internal borders have been reopened, and medical equipment is moving freely. Similar economic and epidemiological indicators across countries suggest that fundamental policy choices are not as different as perceived, with most EU states stabilizing infection rates through mandatory social-distancing rules. This convergence has led to a unified approach to tackling the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: Winding-up petitions filed against PappaRich Group
summary: Two winding-up petitions were filed against PappaRich Group Sdn Bhd by Agathisfour and Chen Khai Voon with the High Court of Malaya. The petitions, scheduled for hearing on Sept 21 and Nov 3, are expected to have no impact on the company's business and operations. ST Group Food, the joint venture partner, stated it will continue to hold exclusive rights to the PappaRich brand in Australia and New Zealand.

site_title: Reits should go beyond minimum disclosure standards
summary: A-REIT's manager failed to disclose the background of Larapinta Project, a company behind the rental guarantee, despite its significant purchase of a Sydney logistics property. This lack of transparency raises concerns about the quality of due diligence and the ability of the company to deliver on its commitments. The incident highlights the need for Reits to set a good example and maintain high standards, as foreign Reits have eroded trust in the local market with past failures. The incident underscores the importance of robust processes and competent professionals in the local Reit ecosystem.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued delisting notifications to China Taisan Technology Group and China Hongxing Sports. China Taisan will be delisted due to failure to exit the financial watch list by June 4, 2020, while China Hongxing Sports will also be delisted due to a lack of information on its proposed reverse takeover.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz pulls well ahead of BMW in US luxury car sales
summary: Mercedes-Benz has pulled ahead of BMW in US luxury car sales, with a 14% decline in sales compared to BMW's 28% drop in the first half of the year. Mercedes' refreshed lineup, including the GLE and GLC crossovers, has contributed to its lead. BMW's sales slumped 38% in the second quarter, with the X7 SUV and X3 crossover seeing significant declines. Despite challenges from COVID-19 lockdowns in key luxury markets, Mercedes is now leading BMW by almost 18,000 vehicles.

site_title: Reimagining learning post-pandemic
summary: A global pandemic has disrupted traditional workplace arrangements, leading to a shift towards virtual workspaces and distributed workforces. Companies must adapt by investing in learning and development to thrive. Virtual learning solutions, such as customized asynchronous and synchronous training, have been successfully implemented by SMEs like APRO and Motor Image. However, long-term strategies are needed to address digital skills, cyber security, and authentic learning in virtual environments. Companies must prioritize employee development, create a sense of community, and leverage technology to capture informal learning and promote engagement.

site_title: Covid-19 is a catalyst driving change in Asia
summary: Covid-19 is driving significant change in Asia, accelerating the region's transformation into a global economic powerhouse. The pandemic is reshuffling economic power, with countries re-examining their foreign policies and trade relationships. Companies are reassessing their investments, while governments face long-term implications for political stability. The crisis is also altering domestic politics, with elections and ruling coalitions impacted. Geopolitically, Covid-19 has heightened concerns about China and the US role in Asia, with rising angst ahead of the US presidential elections. The pandemic's longer-term effects will shape the region's societies and economies, making adaptability and innovation crucial for success.

site_title: United Airlines could lay off as many as 36,000 employees
summary: United Airlines plans to notify 36,000 frontline employees that they could be laid off on October 1 due to the severe drop in demand amid the coronavirus crisis. The airline emphasizes that not everyone receiving the notice will be furloughed, but must cut costs to stay afloat. Travel is not expected to normalize until a widely available treatment or vaccine is available.

site_title: US office, apartment vacancy rates rise marginally in Q2
summary: US office and apartment vacancy rates rose marginally in Q2, with office vacancy increasing to 17.1% and apartment vacancy rising to 4.8%. The pandemic has prompted reevaluation of office space needs, leading to potential long-term impacts. Demand for apartments may hold steady, while housing sales are expected to contract due to the pandemic's downturn. Rent declines are forecast for the next two quarters, particularly if government support measures are not renewed.

site_title: Hotels target staycations, as every bit helps
summary: Singapore hotels are launching staycation promotions to attract locals, with many seeing a boost in interest. Analysts believe this will provide a much-needed boost to the industry, but expect modest gains. Hoteliers are offering special room rates, complimentary breakfasts, and parking, as well as discounts for healthcare workers. Despite the reopening of green channels and travel bubbles, analysts caution that the outlook remains cloudy due to limited visibility on travel curbs. The hospitality Reits, particularly CDL Hospitality Trust and Far East Hospitality Trust, are expected to benefit from the new staycation rule.

site_title: US closes in on 3m Covid-19 cases
summary: The US is nearing 3 million confirmed Covid-19 cases, with the virus surging in southern hotspots like Texas, Florida, and Arizona. President Donald Trump downplayed the risks and pushed for schools to reopen, despite experts warning of a potential surge in cases among younger people. The fatality rate has fallen, but the US remains the hardest-hit country, with over 130,000 deaths. Experts attribute the decline to increased testing, better treatments, and a younger population.

site_title: US: Wall St inches up on recovery hopes despite jump in virus cases
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by hopes for an economic recovery, despite a surge in coronavirus cases. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.23%, 0.25%, and 0.63% respectively, reaching fresh records. Investors weighed the recovery signs against potential lockdowns.

images.alt_text: US stocks inched higher at the open on Wednesday as investors weighed early signs of an economic rebound against fears of another lockdown with surging coronavirus cases across the country.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 16.78 points to 1,583.50. The index saw 687 gainers against 369 losers, with a trading volume of 11.808 billion lots worth RM4.355 billion.

site_title: Insurer Allstate to buy National General for about US$4b
summary: US insurer Allstate Corp agreed to buy National General Holdings Corp for approximately $4 billion in cash, expanding its auto insurance business amid the COVID-19 pandemic. National General shareholders will receive $32 per share in cash and $2.50 in closing dividends. The deal, expected to close in early 2021, is expected to boost Allstate's earnings per share and return-on-equity. The acquisition will also make Allstate the fifth-largest US player in the independent agent market.

site_title: New security law changes Hong Kong for activists and businesses
summary: China has passed a new security law for Hong Kong, which criminalizes acts of secession, subversion, and terrorism, and establishes Beijing's firm grip over the city. The law has led to the disbandment of pro-democracy party Demosisto and the departure of prominent members, including Joshua Wong and Nathan Law. The move has also prompted major tech companies like Facebook, Google, and Twitter to suspend processing government requests for user data in Hong Kong, amid heightened tensions between China and the US.

site_title: Gold smashes through US$1,800 level as investors bolt for safety
summary: Gold prices surged past the US$1,800 level on Wednesday, reaching its highest level since September 2011, as investors sought safety amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Spot gold jumped 1% to US$1,811.55 per ounce and US gold futures gained 0.7% to US$1,822. Central banks' stimulus packages and increased liquidity supported the metal, while the dollar's weakening price also contributed to its gains.

site_title: PM Lee lists jobs and incomes as voters' main concerns
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that jobs and incomes are the top concerns of voters ahead of the country's general election, citing the COVID-19 crisis. He acknowledged that younger and older generations have differing views on racial and religious issues, referencing controversy surrounding Workers' Party candidate Raeesah Khan. Lee emphasized the need to address economic concerns and called the election now to focus on these issues, while ensuring the situation is stable to avoid potential risks.

site_title: Don't hold breath for fire sales by owners of Singapore hotels
summary: Singapore's hotel industry continues to struggle due to the ongoing impact of COVID-19, with buyers waiting for owners to throw in the towel. The industry's reliance on international travelers is a major concern, as foreign visitor numbers plummeted from 1.49 million in 2019 to 880 in May. Despite staycation offers, hotels remain pummeled, and the situation is expected to worsen with a Q3 wave of condo launches testing demand for prime projects above $3,000 psf.

site_title: Men's clothier Brooks Brothers files for bankruptcy
summary: Men's apparel brand Brooks Brothers filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on July 8, 2020, joining retailers impacted by the coronavirus crisis. With over 200 years of history, Brooks Brothers has dressed 40 former US presidents. The company listed assets and liabilities between $500 million and $1 billion in a court filing.

site_title: Seven candidates battling for WTO leadership
summary: Seven candidates, including Britain's Liam Fox and Kenya's Amina Mohamed, are vying to become the next head of the World Trade Organization (WTO) to replace outgoing director-general Roberto Azevedo, who is stepping down early. The selection process, which began in May, relies on finding consensus among the 164 member states, with a caretaker leader taking over if a consensus cannot be reached in time.
