The new leader will face challenges such as reviving stalled trade talks and thawing relations with Washington.

site_title: Japan's draft policy roadmap prioritises digitalisation
summary: Japan's government has released a draft policy roadmap that prioritizes digitalization to cope with the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. The focus would be on digitalizing the economy, rather than addressing Japan's public debt. The draft policy was presented at the Council on Economic and Fiscal Policy, leaving open how the huge cost of combating the crisis would be funded.

site_title: AirAsia shares in biggest daily fall as auditor flags 'going concern' doubts
summary: AirAsia shares plummeted 17% on Wednesday, the biggest daily fall, after auditor EY cast doubt on the airline's ability to continue as a going concern due to the coronavirus travel slump. The airline's 2019 earnings were prepared on a going concern basis, dependent on a recovery from the pandemic and fundraising efforts. AirAsia has received 12-month relief from being classified as a financially distressed firm, but its shares have plunged 58% this year, giving it a market value of about US$550 million.

images.alt_text: Shares in Malaysia's AirAsia Group tumbled more than 17 per cent on Wednesday in their biggest daily fall after the auditor cast doubt on the budget carrier's ability to continue as a going concern due to the coronavirus travel slump.

site_title: India's Cipla set to undercut rivals with generic Remdesivir
summary: Indian drugmaker Cipla has launched its generic version of Remdesivir, Cipremi, priced at 4,000 rupees (S$74.33) per 100 mg vial, undercutting rivals Mylan and Hetero Labs. The company aims to supply over 80,000 vials within the first month, targeting government and hospital sales only. This move is expected to increase competition for the treatment, which is being made widely available due to licensing deals with generic producers.

site_title: Govt is more responsive to people when opposition MPs are elected ones: Pritam Singh
summary: Singaporean opposition leader Pritam Singh stated that when opposition MPs are elected to Parliament, the government becomes more responsive to the people's concerns. This is one of the messages the Workers' Party has been trying to convey during its campaign. Singh expressed concerns about the Non-Constituency MP (NCMP) scheme, viewing it as an "outrigger for the PAP" rather than a healthy option for Singapore's democracy.

site_title: Winding-up petitions filed against PappaRich Group
summary: Winding-up petitions have been filed against PappaRich Group Sdn Bhd, a joint venture partner of Australia-based ST Group Food Industries Holdings. The petitions were filed by Chen Khai Voon and Agathisfour with the High Court of Malaya, with hearings scheduled for September 21 and November 3 respectively. ST Group Food expects the petitions to have no impact on its business operations, maintaining exclusive rights to the PappaRich brand in Australia and New Zealand.

site_title: STI posts modest gains of 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 2,669.49 on Wednesday, driven by gains from three banking stalwarts and Wilmar International. The index was boosted by regional peers in China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan, but fell in Japan, South Korea, and Australia. Investors are cautious ahead of US jobless claims and Japan machinery orders, with some expecting extended declines due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Airbus workers stage protest over job cuts
summary: Airbus workers in Toulouse, France staged a brief 1.5-hour strike over plans to cut up to 15,000 jobs due to the coronavirus crisis, which has reduced demand for jets. The strike, involving up to 8,000 workers, was scheduled to take place at Toulouse-Blagnac airport. The airport remained open during the protest. The job cuts are part of Airbus' response to the crisis, which has impacted the aviation industry.

site_title: Olam secures 25b yen medium-term samurai loan facility
summary: Olam International has secured a 25 billion yen (S$324.2 million) medium-term samurai loan facility in the Japanese market, with a three-year tranche of 18.75 billion yen and a five-year tranche of 6.25 billion yen. The facility, guaranteed by Olam, will be used for refinancing existing loans and general corporate purposes. This is Olam's third samurai loan facility since 2017, aiming to diversify its funding mix and extend loan tenor.

site_title: Australia: Shares post worst session in week as fresh lockdown weighs
summary: Australian shares fell 1.5% on Wednesday, their worst session in over a week, due to a lockdown in Victoria weighing on the country's economic recovery. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,924.1. The lockdown could cost Australia up to A$1 billion per week, according to Treasurer Josh Frydenberg. Financial stocks were also impacted, with the financial sub-index losing 1.6% and healthcare stocks dropping 3.3% due to concerns over loan repayments and the impact on bank balance sheets.

site_title: China Evergrande plans to sell bulk of commercial properties: source
summary: China Evergrande Group, the nation's No 2 property developer, plans to sell a bulk of its commercial properties to lower its debt ratio. The company, which has a massive debt pile of 800 billion yuan, will sell around 200 properties, including office towers, shops, and hotels. The sale aims to ease investor concerns about Evergrande's leverage and follows China's efforts to reduce high debt across the economy. Details of the sales remain unclear, including the amount of properties sold and the amount raised.

site_title: Total disclosed PE and VC deal value down 65% in Q1: EY
summary: Private equity and venture capital deal values in South-east Asia declined 65% in Q1 2020, with total disclosed deal value at $1.4 billion and 141 deals, down 9% from the previous year. Exit activity was also muted, with six announced deals in Q1 2020 compared to nine in Q1 2019. Economists expect investments to pick up as lockdowns ease, but for now, the region's PE and VC landscape remains sluggish due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: UK's Sunak announces £30b plan to head off jobless crisis
summary: UK finance minister Rishi Sunak announced a £30 billion plan to combat unemployment by paying employers to bring back furloughed workers and cutting taxes for the hospitality sector and homebuyers. This move aims to mitigate the impact of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic on the economy. The plan is part of Sunak's efforts to ensure that unemployment is not an unavoidable outcome.

images.alt_text: British finance minister Rishi Sunak announced a £30 billion (S$52.4 billion) plan to head off an unemployment crisis by paying employers to bring back their furloughed workers and cutting taxes for the hospitality sector and homebuyers.

site_title: Biolidics ties up with China's LC-Bio to develop cancer-diagnostic solutions
summary: Singapore-based Biolidics has partnered with China's LC-Bio to develop cancer-diagnostic solutions. The five-year agreement will see Biolidics' proprietary technology used in LC-Bio's medical laboratory in Hangzhou, China. Biolidics will provide necessary materials, while LC-Bio will provide laboratory space. The collaboration aims to obtain clinical validation of Biolidics' cancer diagnostic solution by the end of 2020, utilizing Biolidics' circulating-tumour-cell technology to separate cancer cells from blood samples.

site_title: ADB raises US$4b via bonds as it responds to pandemic
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has raised $4 billion through US dollar bonds to bolster its capital and provide pandemic relief to countries in the Asia-Pacific region. This move triples the rescue package to $20 billion and is part of the bank's plan to raise $30-$35 billion from capital markets in 2020. The bank cited global economic losses of $5.80 trillion to $8.80 trillion this year, with developing Asia's GDP expected to barely grow due to the pandemic.

site_title: Japan's service sector sentiment rises 23.3 points in June
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index rose 23.3 points to 38.8 in June, the highest since April, according to a Cabinet Office survey. The increase reflects growing confidence about current economic conditions among workers in the sector. This marks a significant improvement from the record low of 15.5 in April. The government views this as a positive sign, with moves towards picking up in the economy.

site_title: Gold steadies near more than 8-year peak as virus cases surge
summary: Gold prices held steady near an eight-year high on Wednesday, influenced by the surge in coronavirus cases and potential US Federal Reserve stimulus measures. Spot gold was little changed at $1,794.62 per ounce, with investors cautious despite a grim new milestone of over three million US infections. The European Commission forecast a deeper eurozone recession, supporting gold's rally, while Fed officials expressed concern over the virus's impact on consumer spending.

site_title: Market turnover value of securities jumped 74% to S$38b in June: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 74% increase in market turnover value of securities to S$38 billion in June, driven by optimism from the reopening of major economies. The securities daily average value (SDAV) rose 50% to S$1.73 billion, while exchange-traded funds (ETFs) surged 138% to S$487 million. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) gained 3.2% in June, and Asian primary bond markets continued to gain momentum, with new bond listings rising 43%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Wednesday, recovering from a sharp sell-off the day before and regaining their recent upward trajectory. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.59%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw significant gains. Despite a surge in global virus infections, investors remained optimistic, with the benchmark indexes reaching new highs.

site_title: Philippines to borrow more to cover coronavirus response
summary: The Philippines plans to increase borrowing to 50% of GDP to cover the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, with revenues down 16% in the first half of 2020. Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez expects the country's debt-to-GDP ratio to rise, but maintains the government has the capacity to pay its loans. The government is seeking a record 4.30 trillion pesos budget for 2021 to revive the economy, which is projected to shrink by 2-3.4% this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as virus cases surge; HSBC, Nokia slump
summary: European shares fell 0.5% on Wednesday, led by bank and energy declines, as surging coronavirus cases globally dimmed economic recovery prospects. HSBC dropped 3.5% after a report on US President Trump's proposal to undermine Hong Kong's currency peg. Nokia slumped 6.7% after JPMorgan downgraded its stock to "neutral". Meanwhile, Electrolux jumped 5.1% after reporting a smaller-than-expected loss for the second quarter.

site_title: South-east Asia's first Korean startup centre opens in Singapore
summary: Singapore has officially opened its first Korean startup centre, the Singapore K-Startup Centre (KSC), in partnership with South Korea's Ministry of SMEs and Startups. The centre, launched in July 2018, aims to facilitate collaboration between Korean and Singaporean startups, with its first programme focused on fintech and cybersecurity. Six startups will undergo an eight-week incubation programme starting in October 2020, and the centre is expected to host more startups in the future.

site_title: As insurers face hefty pandemic losses, newcomers see chance to step in
summary: Commercial insurers face hefty pandemic losses and rising premiums, prompting new ventures and industry veterans to raise capital or expand into new lines. Following the 9/11 attacks and Hurricane Katrina, the industry hopes to replicate its past response to crises. Companies like Convex are launching new cover for event cancellation, as the pandemic's impact drives premium increases.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end lower as surging virus cases hit risk appetite
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.24% on Wednesday, closing at 2,158.88, due to subdued risk appetite amid surging coronavirus cases globally. The US surpassed 3 million confirmed cases, raising concerns about hospital capacity. In contrast, the won gained, and the benchmark bond yield fell. The decline was attributed to reduced investor confidence in a quicker global economic recovery.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) highlighted securing jobs, investments, and supply lines as major challenges amid the Covid-19 crisis. The Singapore Democratic Party's chairman, Dr Tambyah, expressed regret over the PAP's inability to engage on issues. Meanwhile, a South Korean startup centre opened in Singapore, and Interactive Brokers launched a Singapore office, offering local stocks to investors. China Taisan and China Hongxing Sports were delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to judicial management. The Straits Times Index (STI) posted modest gains of 0.3% on Wednesday.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB upgrades ARA Logos to 'add' citing stronger focus on growth
summary: CGS-CIMB upgraded its call on ARA Logos Logistics Trust (ALog) to "add" from "hold" citing a stronger focus on growth and earnings clarity. The analysts raised their target price to 71.3 Singapore cents from 71 cents, amid a 3.5% increase in unit price.

site_title: Foreign firms surrendering more Hong Kong office space
summary: Foreign firms surrendered 61% of total office space in Hong Kong in the second quarter, pushing the vacancy rate to its highest in 15 years. This is a significant increase from 47% in the previous quarter, attributed to cost-cutting and retraction of head count. Cushman & Wakefield attributes the trend to the deteriorating economy amid the pandemic, with no specific area or industry affected.

site_title: Credit Suisse aims for 100% of securities JV in China growth plan
summary: Credit Suisse aims to acquire full ownership of its China securities joint venture, expanding its market share in the country's growing economy. The bank has gained 51% control of the venture and appointed Janice Hu as chairman, with plans to hire more staff and invest in China. Following China's opening of its financial markets to foreign investors, Credit Suisse sees China as its most significant business opportunity. The bank aims to build out its private and investment banking businesses in China, with the goal of reaching 100% ownership.

site_title: Hong Kong retail vacancies seen rising as global brands downsize: CBRE
summary: Hong Kong's retail vacancies are expected to rise in the second half of the year due to global brands downsizing or leaving the city, with overall vacancy rates reaching 13.5% in the first six months, a four-year high. High street rents have dropped 15.2% and are expected to decline another 5-10% in the rest of the year. The closures of international brands such as Topshop, Victoria's Secret, and Gap are attributed to broader external economic reasons, while falling rents have attracted new businesses like Japanese restaurant brands.

images.alt_text: More retail property in Hong Kong will be left vacant in the second half of the year as large global fashion and luxury brands consolidate their stores or leave the city.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI initiates coverage on Singapore Medical Group with 'outperform'
summary: KGI Securities has initiated coverage on Singapore Medical Group (SMG) with an "outperform" rating, setting a target price of 34 Singapore cents. The brokerage expects SMG to benefit from its diverse network of specialist healthcare services, booming middle class in Indonesia and Vietnam, and supportive government policies in Australia. With a 39% upside, SMG's shares were trading at 24.5 Singapore cents at the time of the announcement.

site_title: Hatten Land bondholders agree to defer repayment again
summary: Hatten Land, a CATALIST-listed property developer, has secured approval from its US$25 million, 8-per-cent guaranteed secured bondholders to defer repayment for the third time. The new repayment date is set for August 8, 2020, after initial deferrals to June and then July 8. Bondholders have also agreed to extend the maturity date to June 8, 2026, on a monthly basis, requiring approval from all parties each month.

site_title: Backing anti-racism protests, renowned intellectuals lament intolerance 'on all sides'
summary: Renowned intellectuals, including Noam Chomsky and Gloria Steinem, signed a letter supporting global anti-racism protests while lamenting an "intolerant climate" that has spread intolerance on all sides. The letter, published in Harper's Magazine, expresses support for demonstrations against police brutality and racial inequality following George Floyd's death, but warns that this has led to a hardening of moral attitudes and erosion of tolerance for differences. The signatories advocate for open debate and freedom of expression, rejecting dogma and coercion in favor of exposure, argument, and persuasion.

site_title: AirAsia in trading halt after auditor notes 'going concern' doubts
summary: AirAsia's shares halted trading after its auditor expressed concerns over the airline's ability to continue as a going concern due to material uncertainties related to the Covid-19 pandemic and fundraising efforts. The airline reported a RM803.3 million loss for the first quarter, its largest since 2004. The trading halt, expected to be lifted at 2:30pm local time, is due to the auditor's unqualified audit opinion on the airline's financial statements. The company is evaluating proposals for raising capital to strengthen its equity base and liquidity.

site_title: 7 more worker dorms cleared of Covid-19 patients
summary: Singapore has cleared 7 worker dormitories of Covid-19 patients, with only recovered individuals and those who recently tested negative remaining. The Ministry of Health has also reported a 69-year-old Singaporean man's death due to cardio-respiratory failure, bringing the country's total deaths to 26. The number of new cases in the community has increased, with 321 cases discharged and 3,734 recovering in community facilities.

site_title: China hires Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs to advise on pipeline asset transfers: sources
summary: China has hired Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs to advise on multi-billion dollar deals transferring key oil and gas pipeline assets into a national energy infrastructure giant. The project, overseen by a government vice-premier, aims to complete the asset transfers and start operation of the new entity by the end of September, valued at over $40 billion. The timeline is considered a "moving target," but the goal is to complete the merger by the end of July.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby to look into report of forced labour
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation has announced it will investigate allegations of forced and child labor in its estates, following a US Customs petition by anti-trafficking group Liberty Shared. The allegations include arbitrary penalties, sexual harassment, and inconsistent pay deductions. Sime Darby, the world's largest palm oil company, claims the allegations contradict its public commitments to responsible agriculture and human rights. The investigation is seen as a blow to Malaysia's efforts to promote its palm products as environmentally friendly and socially responsible.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation on Wednesday said it will look into "serious allegations" of forced and child labour conditions in its estates after an activist group petitioned the US Customs to ban imports of its palm oil.

site_title: China challenges US to cut nuclear arsenal to matching level
summary: China's head of the arms control department, Fu Cong, has stated that China would participate in trilateral arms control negotiations with the US and Russia, but only if the US reduces its nuclear arsenal to China's level, approximately 20 times smaller. Fu called the US request "a ploy to divert attention" and an excuse to walk away from the New START treaty extension. China maintains it is not "shying away from the international nuclear disarmament process" and is willing to discuss nuclear risk reduction within the UN Security Council's framework.

site_title: Tambyah considers PAP's 'inability to engage on issues' his 'biggest regret'
summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) chairman Paul Tambyah has expressed his "biggest regret" as the inability of the ruling party, the People's Action Party (PAP), to engage on issues during the election campaign. Tambyah, a medical expert, advocates for a debate with the PAP to address pressing concerns. He criticized the PAP for using dubious laws to discredit opponents, instead urging a focus on issues. Tambyah is contesting the Bukit Panjang single seat, a key constituency in the upcoming election.

site_title: Covid-19 traps US$111b of luxury spending in China
summary: China's luxury spending, which accounts for over a third of the global industry, has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with US$111 billion in luxury goods sales lost in 2020. Travel restrictions have halted parallel importers and made it difficult for high-end shoppers to find desired items. In response, luxury brands are expanding their presence in China, with some opening virtual storefronts and using live-streaming to reach consumers. The pandemic is expected to accelerate China's shift towards domestic luxury spending, with over half of purchases expected to occur within the country by 2025.

site_title: Trump aides weigh proposals to undermine Hong Kong's dollar peg
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is considering options to punish China for its recent moves to chip away at Hong Kong's political freedoms. Some top advisers have proposed undermining the Hong Kong dollar's peg to the US dollar, but this idea faces strong opposition from others in the administration. The proposal includes limiting Hong Kong banks' ability to buy US dollars, and has not gained traction yet. Other options under discussion include canceling a US-Hong Kong extradition treaty and ending cooperation with Hong Kong's police.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower after Wall Street drop
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.78% and the Topix index losing 0.92%. The decline was influenced by a downswing on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with investor sentiment hit by a downswing on Wall Street.

site_title: COE prices rise all round as bidding resumes after Covid-19 circuit breaker
summary: COE prices rose across all categories at the Singapore tender on July 8, the first since March. COE for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closed at S$33,520, up from S$31,210. COE for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp ended at S$35,889, up from S$30,012. Open COE, which is primarily used for bigger cars, closed at S$34,989, up from S$32,500. The price increases are attributed to the resumption of bidding after the Covid-19 circuit breaker measures.

site_title: Premier League football clubs must donate funds to lower divisions: Bruce
summary: Premier League clubs face financial pressure due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with some lower-division teams on the verge of collapse. Newcastle United manager Steve Bruce suggests that top-flight clubs donate at least £2 million to support English Football League teams. If not, many teams may face financial collapse, and some have already been forced into administration, like Wigan Athletic. Bruce believes that this donation would help keep smaller clubs afloat, allowing them to continue operating for another season.

site_title: 'Trapped' illegal workers in Saudi look to virus for escape
summary: Hundreds of thousands of illegal foreign workers in Saudi Arabia are stranded, despite the COVID-19 pandemic driving an exodus of expatriates. The "kafala" sponsorship system, criticized as modern slavery, binds workers to their employers, making it difficult for them to leave or find work. Campaigners are calling for an amnesty to regularize their status or return to their home countries, as the system risks fueling the pandemic and worsening their already dire living conditions, including overcrowded housing and exploitation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Wednesday, resuming their rally after a steep drop in the previous session. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.40%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.52% and 0.45%, respectively. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Amazon India's unit gets 23.1b rupees in fresh funds from parent
summary: Amazon India's unit, Amazon Seller Services, has received 23.1 billion rupees in fresh funding from its parent company. The investment, valued at 431.2 million Singapore dollars, was primarily made by Amazon Singapore. This move comes as more people shop online to avoid crowded public places, with the Indian arm planning to hire 50,000 temporary workers. The funding strengthens Amazon's business in the country, which is experiencing a surge in online shopping.

site_title: Interactive Brokers opens Singapore office, offers access to local stocks
summary: Interactive Brokers Group has opened its first office in Singapore, marking the expansion of its presence in the city-state. The brokerage firm now offers access to local stocks and can directly market its offerings to investors in Singapore. With 37% of its accounts coming from Asia, the move reflects the importance of Singapore as a wealth management and financial hub in the region. The company aims to support active traders and the wealth management community, and its expansion comes as other brokers have exited or decreased their commitment to Singapore.

site_title: Australia looking to restrict return of citizens amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: Australia is set to slow down the return of its citizens from abroad amid a fresh coronavirus outbreak in the country. Prime Minister Scott Morrison plans to propose reducing repatriation flights to the national cabinet, citing concerns about security lapses and the spread of the virus. The decision comes as Victoria, Australia's second-most populous state, imposes a partial lockdown on its capital, Melbourne, due to a spike in Covid-19 cases. The move is expected to put pressure on other states and has been likened to New Zealand's decision to halt inbound flights.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.37 points, or 0.02%, to 1,567.09 on Wednesday. The index saw a trading volume of 212.94 million lots worth RM88.22 million. The gain was offset by a slight loss, with 145 stocks losing value and 133 gaining.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Wall Street drop
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, July 8, 2020, due to a downswing on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.64% to 22,470.06, while the Topix index declined 0.43% to 1,564.90. This follows a global market trend, as US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: GS Holdings says difficult to sell assets of subsidiaries as consisted of software
summary: GS Holdings has responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange about the sale of its subsidiaries, GS Cleaning Services (GCS) and GS Equipment Supply (GES), for S$2. The subsidiaries' assets consist of human resource and accounting software, making it difficult to sell separately. GCS has a combined adjusted net asset value (NAV) of S$100, while GES has S$8,645 in intangible assets comprising software. GS Holdings has stated that no discussions with other potential buyers have taken place, and shareholder approval was not sought due to the proposed disposal being in its best interests, marking the end of the cleaning and dishwashing business segment.

site_title: Asia: Most equities fall again as virus fears dampen sentiment
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday, with most equities declining due to concerns about the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and fresh spikes in infections worldwide. Despite positive indicators and hopes for a vaccine, investors remain cautious. The US Federal Reserve's Raphael Bostic warned of a "levelling off" of economic activity, fueling concerns. Tensions between China, the US, and other nations also weighed on markets. Gold prices rose, seeking safe-haven assets, while some markets, such as Hong Kong and Singapore, showed gains.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip as hopes of post-pandemic rebound fade
summary: European stocks fell 0.6% on Tuesday, amid surging US coronavirus cases and forecasts of a deeper-than-feared recession in the euro zone. The banking sector declined 1.4%, while real estate, technology, and telecoms shares dropped between 1% and 1.8%. The European Commission revised its forecast, predicting a 8.7% contraction before rising 6.1% in 2021. Renewed coronavirus outbreaks in the US and EU added to downside risks for advanced economies.

site_title: Thai financial system more vulnerable as pandemic hits economy
summary: Thailand's financial system has become more vulnerable due to a weaker-than-expected economic outlook amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Bank of Thailand's monetary policy committee left the one-day repurchase rate unchanged at a record low of 0.50% and cut its 2020 GDP outlook to a record contraction of 8.1%. The committee emphasized the need for timely fiscal measures, accommodative monetary policy, and credit measures to support an economic recovery. The government is advised to focus on supply-side policies to support economic restructuring after the outbreak subsides.

site_title: US posts new daily virus case record of 60,209: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US reported a record 60,209 new COVID-19 cases on Tuesday, bringing the total to 2,991,351 cases, according to Johns Hopkins University. The death toll rose to 131,362 with 1,114 additional fatalities. This marks the country's hardest hit by the coronavirus.

site_title: Britain to reveal post-coronavirus recovery plan
summary: Britain is set to unveil a post-coronavirus recovery plan, including a £2 billion grant for households to insulate homes, £1 billion for public sector buildings, and a mini-budget to kickstart the economy. The plan aims to build infrastructure, boost the property market, and create thousands of green jobs. The government also plans to reduce stamp duty and maintain its emergency jobs retention plan, despite economists warning of a £300 billion financial hole left by the pandemic.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank upgrades AirAsia to 'hold' on higher fares, resumed flights
summary: AirAsia's stock rating was upgraded to "hold" by Maybank due to narrowing downside risk, driven by higher fares and resumed flights. However, the airline's shares plummeted 9.9% after its auditor expressed material uncertainties casting doubt on its ability to continue as a going concern. AirAsia reported a net loss of RM803.8 million for Q1 FY20, but expects to "outlive" the pandemic through cost management and financing. Resumed flights in five countries and rising fares offer a positive outlook.

images.alt_text: Malaysian budget carrier AirAsia Group is now rated "hold", up from "sell", thanks to narrowing downside risk, according to Maybank.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as Victoria lockdown dampens recovery hopes
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 5,983.1 on Wednesday due to a six-week lockdown in Melbourne and concerns over a potential economic hit of A$1 billion per week. Goldman Sachs analysts downgraded the country's economic growth forecast to 3.4% contraction in 2020, citing the lockdown's impact on GDP growth. The S&P/ASX 200 index led by financials and technology stocks declined, while gold prices rose to a record high due to a safe-haven rush amid global coronavirus cases.

site_title: US probing allegations TikTok violated children's privacy: sources
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the Justice Department are investigating TikTok for allegedly violating a 2019 agreement aimed at protecting children's privacy. The allegations include failing to delete videos and personal information about users under 13. The investigation follows concerns over TikTok's Chinese parent company and potential data sharing with the Chinese government. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has suggested banning TikTok, and advocacy groups have met with FTC and Justice Department officials to discuss the matter.

site_title: Kimco Realty debuts green debt as it boosts focus on ESG issues
summary: Kimco Realty, a real estate investment trust, has issued $500 million in green bonds to finance environmentally-friendly projects. The 10-year bonds yield 2.1 percentage points above Treasuries, following strong investor demand. This marks the company's first foray into green debt, as it prioritizes ESG (environmental, social, and governance) issues amid the coronavirus pandemic. The move is part of Kimco's efforts to boost transparency and align its ESG disclosure with industry guidelines.

site_title: Australian banks extend loan holiday for struggling borrowers
summary: Australian banks have extended the loan repayment deferral period for struggling borrowers to 10 months, from the original six months, due to ongoing economic concerns from the coronavirus pandemic. The Australian Banking Association announced the four-month extension, allowing people to restructure existing loans. The move aims to provide relief to those struggling to repay mortgage or business loans as government income support expires.

images.alt_text: Three of the country's top four lenders - Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA), Westpac Banking and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group - immediately announced various options for customers to restructure their loan repayment plans or defer payments.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH, Accordia Golf Trust, Boustead, CSE Global, ASL Marine
summary:
Singapore stocks to watch: 
- Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) filed amended defence and counterclaim in a lawsuit, with shares closing at S$1.30.
- Accordia Golf Trust's unitholders urged to review the proposed divestment after a minority unitholder expressed concerns over the price offered.
- Boustead Singapore's revenue rose 61% year-over-year to S$434.5 million in the second half of the year.
- CSE Global's substantial shareholder emerged after Temasek Holdings acquired a 25.03% stake.
- ASL Marine Holdings secured shipbuilding contracts for two Eco-Ark fish farms.

site_title: China Taisan, China Hongxing Sports to delist from SGX
summary: China Taisan Technology Group and China Hongxing Sports, both listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), will be delisted due to failing to meet exit requirements within the 36-month deadline. China Taisan was under judicial management since August 2018 and failed to record consolidated pre-tax profit or meet the market cap requirement. China Hongxing Sports, which became a cash company in May 2018, was granted several extensions to meet the new listing requirement but was unable to secure sufficient funding due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Tee International to receive 3.38 S cents mandatory cash offer from Tramore Global
summary: Tee International, a Singapore-listed investment holding company, will receive a mandatory cash offer of 3.38 Singapore cents per share from Tramore Global, an investment holding company that acquired a 36.8% stake in Tee International. The offer represents a 25.19% premium over the three-month VWAP price and a 33.73% discount to the 12-month VWAP price. The offer is subject to Tramore Global holding more than 50% of Tee International's voting rights. Tee International's controlling shareholder, Phua Chian Kin, has agreed to accept the offer, while his wife will also accept the offer but not the warrants proposal.

site_title: Pence says US to maintain 'strong stand' on TikTok
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence stated the US will maintain a "strong stand" against Chinese entities threatening US security, including potentially TikTok. This comes after Secretary of State Mike Pompeo suggested banning Chinese social media apps due to concerns over data sharing with the Chinese government. Pence cited the administration's defense of US interests against the Chinese Communist Party, stating they will take a strong stance against entities like Huawei and TikTok that compromise US privacy and security.

site_title: Venture fund backing firms worth US$206b eyes China
summary: Venture capitalist David Chao has raised $880 million for a new fund focused on China, despite rising US-China tensions. Co-founded by Chao and SoftBank Group Corp, DCM Ventures has attracted investors from US endowments and European firms. Chao believes China will continue to grow faster than the US over the next decade, and investors are looking past tensions to opportunities in China and Japan. Chao's unique perspective, shaped by his Japanese upbringing and experience bridging Asian and US markets, has helped him tap into the China-Japan-US triangle, attracting investors and backing successful Chinese startups.

site_title: GIC-backed Traveloka nears fundraising at lower valuation
summary: Traveloka, a South-east Asian online travel startup backed by GIC, is close to raising fresh funds at a private-market valuation of US$2.75 billion, a 17% decrease from its previous valuation. The company is in negotiations with new and existing investors to secure US$250 million, amid a sharp decline in the travel industry due to the coronavirus pandemic. This is the first unicorn in South-east Asia to experience a down-round, reflecting the industry's downturn, but some investors believe the market will recover.

site_title: Many countries may need debt restructuring after pandemic fallout: IMF chief economist
summary: IMF chief economist Gita Gopinath suggests many countries may need debt restructuring after the pandemic's economic fallout. Around 40% of low-income countries were already in debt distress, and the pandemic's impact may lead to a "much more persistent need for debt relief." The World Bank's newly appointed chief economist, Carmen Reinhart, also calls for a revised debt restructuring process, stating that private sector participation has been slow. A high-level conference on debt and sustainable finance is set to discuss options for responding to the pandemic-triggered economic crisis.

site_title: UK set to resume Saudi arms sales despite Yemen concerns
summary: The UK has announced it will resume arms sales to Saudi Arabia, despite ongoing humanitarian concerns in Yemen. The decision was made after a UK court ruling in 2019, which ordered the government to clarify its assessment of whether arms exports to Saudi Arabia breach international humanitarian law. The UK's International Trade Secretary, Liz Truss, stated that Saudi Arabia has a "genuine intent and capacity to comply with IHL" and that exports can be reassessed. The move drew criticism from arms control activists, who are considering further legal action.

site_title: Levi Strauss warns of weak second half on pandemic woes, to cut 700 jobs
summary: Levi Strauss & Co warned of a weak second half due to pandemic woes, despite improving sales at reopened stores. The company plans to cut 700 jobs (15% of workforce) to save $100 million annually. Despite this, net revenue in the second quarter fell 62% to $497.5 million, beating analyst expectations. The company expects margins to be under pressure due to excess inventory, leading to a net loss of $363.5 million in the quarter. Shares fell 4% in extended trading.

site_title: Victoria state coronavirus curbs to cost Australia up to A$1b a week
summary: Australia's economic hit due to Victoria state coronavirus restrictions could reach A$1 billion a week, according to Treasurer Josh Frydenberg. Renewed lockdown measures in Melbourne will last at least six weeks, affecting 4.9 million people and closing businesses like cafes, bars, and gyms. The restrictions are in response to a surge in Covid-19 infections in Melbourne, sparking fears of a broader second wave. The estimated economic impact is based on Victoria accounting for around a quarter of the national economy.

site_title: Travellers are venturing out again but avoiding planes, international trips: survey
summary: A survey by Oracle found that 51% of people in North America and Latin America plan to book domestic trips in the next six months, while 38% in Asia and Europe do. Travelers prefer to drive and avoid international trips due to travel restrictions and lockdowns. Despite this, US coastal towns have seen a rise in hotel occupancy for five straight weeks, with occupancy levels reaching their highest levels since mid-March. 90% of hotels have increased or plan to increase cleaning and disinfecting, and 70% are adopting contactless technology.

site_title: Getting Singapore through Covid-19 crisis is top issue on voters' minds this GE: PAP
summary: Singaporeans' top concerns ahead of the general election are securing jobs, investments, and supply lines amid the Covid-19 crisis, according to the People's Action Party (PAP). PAP officials, including Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing, emphasized the need to address these challenges in the next six to 12 months. The PAP aims to provide a stable economic environment to achieve this.

site_title: UK 'jobs crisis' is underway, recruiters warn
summary: The UK is experiencing a "jobs crisis" as demand for staff continues to fall, with the Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) survey showing a 12.8-point decrease in job placements in June. The supply of available workers soared, but job placements are still below the 50 level, indicating a decrease in hiring. The REC warns that finance minister Rishi Sunak should use the Summer Statement to boost job creation and retain jobs, citing a potential rise in unemployment. The Bank of England previously noted a possible rise in unemployment, further exacerbating the economic challenge.

site_title: Brazil's Bolsonaro tests positive for coronavirus
summary: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro has tested positive for coronavirus, despite being an outspoken skeptic about the seriousness of the virus. Bolsonaro, 65, reported mild symptoms and is taking hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin to treat the illness. He had previously flouted lockdown measures and minimized the risks of the virus, sparking controversy and criticism. Bolsonaro confirmed he will work from home and receive medical treatment while cancelling his upcoming engagements.

site_title: Trump says Harvard move to online courses due to virus 'ridiculous'
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized Harvard University's decision to move all courses online in the fall due to the coronavirus pandemic, calling it "ridiculous" and an "easy way out." Trump, who is campaigning for reelection, urged schools to reopen for the next semester, despite the ongoing pandemic. His administration also announced that foreign students would not be allowed to remain in the US if all classes are moved online. The decision comes as the US is the hardest-hit country in the global pandemic, with over 130,000 deaths linked to the virus.

site_title: Japan issues fresh rain disaster warnings as toll hits 54
summary: Japan issued fresh landslide and flooding warnings on July 8, 2020, as torrential rain moved over the country, raising the death toll to 54. Heavy rains on the island of Kyushu have caused widespread devastation, with rivers bursting their banks and hillsides collapsing. At least 80,000 rescue workers have been deployed, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledging to double the number of troops involved. Non-mandatory evacuation orders have been issued for 1.4 million people, but the coronavirus has complicated evacuation efforts. Authorities warn that the rains are expected to continue through Thursday, and experts say climate change has intensified the risks of heavy rains.

site_title: Renewing the ranks
summary: Singapore GE2020 election results have seen the ruling party, the People's Action Party (PAP), retain its majority seats. Early data indicates improved employment rates for graduates, with DPM Tan See Leng reassuring them to "stay calm." Meanwhile, DPM Gan Kim Kheng is set to visit the US for trade talks, while a new grant of up to S$100,000 has been announced for tariff-hit businesses. The country also explores opportunities to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging and offers training assistance to workers.

site_title: WHO studying evidence on airborne virus transmission
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) will study fresh evidence on airborne transmission of the coronavirus, following a report by 239 international scientists concluding the virus can spread far beyond 2 meters. The WHO will issue a new scientific brief, updating its guidance on transmission modes and precautions. The pandemic is showing no signs of slowing down, with 400,000 new cases reported over the weekend, and WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warning that the outbreak is accelerating.

site_title: Election digest
summary: The Elections Department (ELD) has denied claims that marks made on ballot papers with self-inking pens will disappear after several minutes. The false information has been circulating online, but the ELD assures that the marks will remain visible. This comes as the election is approaching.

site_title: Oil steadies as economic data overshadows coronavirus worries
summary: Oil prices settled little changed on Tuesday, despite concerns over a new surge in coronavirus cases, as US government forecasts for lower production overshadowed demand worries. Brent crude futures settled at $43.08 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate settled at $40.62 a barrel. The market initially jumped on higher forecast demand and bullish jobs data, but later gave up gains as focus shifted to rising coronavirus cases.

images.alt_text: Oil prices settled little changed on Tuesday as demand concerns due to a new surge in coronavirus cases overshadowed US government forecasts for lower production.

site_title: Gojek on expansion track despite Covid-19
summary: Gojek, a Southeast Asian ride-hailing company, is expanding despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The company plans to unify its regional branding to strengthen operations and image. Since entering Vietnam and Thailand, Gojek has created income-earning opportunities for hundreds of thousands of driver and merchant partners, increasing market choice and competitiveness. The company's growth has been exponential over the last two years, making it a significant player in the region.

site_title: Ignoring outrage, Trump makes good on WHO pullout
summary: US President Donald Trump formally initiated the withdrawal from the World Health Organization (WHO), making good on his threat to deprive the UN body of its top funding source. The move, announced after threatening to suspend $400 million in annual US contributions, was met with outrage from public health advocates and Trump's opponents. The Trump administration has sent a formal notice to UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, marking the US's departure from the Geneva-based organization at a time when global COVID-19 cases are rising.

site_title: Microsoft, Zoom join pause on Hong Kong data requests
summary: Microsoft and Zoom have joined other major internet firms in pausing consideration of data requests from Hong Kong's government due to China's new national security law. The law, which has been criticized for its impact on freedom of expression, has been imposed on Hong Kong with severe penalties, including life imprisonment. The companies will review the law and its implications before resuming data requests. Facebook, Google, and Twitter have also paused data requests from Hong Kong, while Zoom is monitoring developments and seeking guidance from the US government.

site_title: Winds of change blowing through London's immigrant enclave
summary: A London grocery store, Nour Cash & Carry, owned by the Shaheen family for over 20 years, faces eviction in Brixton Market due to new landlords' plans for a power substation. The store, a staple for immigrant communities, has been a symbol of gentrification in the area, where rising rents and new developments are displacing long-time residents and businesses. The eviction notice sparked a campaign to save the store, highlighting broader issues of gentrification and displacement of minority communities in the UK.

site_title: Indonesia imposes 10% VAT on tech giants
summary: Indonesia has imposed a 10% value-added tax (VAT) on tech giants, including Amazon, Netflix, Spotify, and Google, in response to the country's booming digital economy and declining state revenue due to the coronavirus crisis. The tax applies to non-resident foreign firms selling digital products and services worth at least 600 million rupiah annually or generating 12,000 users. The move aims to increase state revenue, which is forecast to drop 13% this year. The tax office has already assigned tax identification numbers to the affected companies, and Netflix has confirmed its compliance.

site_title: US: Nasdaq pulls back from record as stocks retreat
summary: US stocks retreated on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq pulling back from a record as the equity rally paused amid surging US coronavirus cases. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.9% to 10,343.89, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 dropped 1.5% and 1.1%, respectively. The pause in the rally comes as investors reassess the market amid rising US cases and uncertainty surrounding US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Teo Tong Lim's family office, Roxy-Pacific to acquire Melbourne office tower for A$145m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings, a Singaporean property developer, and the family office of Teo Tong Lim have agreed to acquire a Melbourne office building for A$145 million (S$140.8 million). The acquisition will be financed by internal funds and bank financing taken out by the trusts. The deal is part of a joint venture between Roxy-Pacific and Teo's family office, TE2 Group, to acquire the building through a Singapore master trust, TE-Roxy Commercial Trust I.

site_title: AmBank 'overweight' on Malaysia's glove makers
summary: AmBank has maintained its "overweight" call on Malaysia's glove sector, citing strong demand and expected exponential growth in sales volume and average selling price in the second-half year. Analysts expect higher selling prices and expanded margins due to low raw material prices, a strengthening US dollar, and ongoing expansion plans. The research team has raised its fair value for Top Glove to RM25.69 per share and maintained a "buy" call, while retaining a "hold" recommendation for Hartalega and a "buy" call for Kossan.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) rejected Tee International's request for an extension to announce its year-end results, forcing the company to submit its results by July 30 and October 15. Accordia Golf Trust urged its unitholders to review its proposed divestment after a minority unitholder expressed concerns over the offered price. CSE Global announced that a substantial shareholder, Heliconia Capital Management, acquired a 25.03% stake in the company.

site_title: Election by the numbers
summary: Singapore's GE2020 election saw a significant increase in voter turnout, with over 80% of eligible voters casting their ballots. The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) retained power with 69.1% of the vote share. The opposition parties won 7.4% of the vote, with the Workers' Party securing a 3-seat win in Hougang. The election results indicate a strong mandate for the PAP, but also a growing demand for change from the opposition parties.

site_title: Boeing settles nearly all Lion Air 737 MAX crash claims: filing
summary: Boeing has reached settlement agreements in over 90% of the wrongful death claims filed in federal court related to the 2018 Lion Air 737 MAX crash in Indonesia, which killed 189 people. The settlement resolves nearly all claims, allowing Boeing to focus on regaining FAA approval to fly the MAX commercially. The crash led to a corporate crisis, including hundreds of lawsuits and probes by the Justice Department and US lawmakers. Boeing is racing to clear remaining hurdles to win FAA approval, potentially later this year.

site_title: Why digital economy deserves a place in every portfolio
summary: The digital economy is expected to drive significant investment opportunities in the coming years, driven by rapid digital transformations across industries and sectors. The Fourth Industrial Revolution is transforming the way people live, work, and interact, with technology playing a crucial role. As traditional businesses struggle to keep up, those that adapt quickly will thrive, making technology an integral part of every investor's portfolio. Investment opportunities abound in areas such as digital disruption, the Internet of Things, and emerging technologies like cloud computing, with ETFs offering diversified exposure to the digital economy.

site_title: Malaysia cuts rates to record low, warns of downside risks
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 1.75%, the lowest on record, to accelerate the pace of economic recovery. The move provides additional policy stimulus amid lingering downside risks, including persistent weakness in the labor market and a tepid global recovery. The decision is seen as dovish, but cautious, with economists predicting another 25 basis-point cut in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Getting telemedicine off the ground successfully
summary: Telemedicine has seen a surge in popularity since the COVID-19 pandemic, with platforms like MyDoc in Singapore experiencing a 60% rise in daily active users. To make it mainstream, patients must be onboard, and security and regulatory frameworks are crucial. Key drivers of success include educating patients about the services offered, making services easy to use, and ensuring payment and insurance policies are clear. Sophisticated technologies, such as facial biometrics and AI, can help verify patients' identities, streamlining the online process. Governments and market innovators must work together to establish best practices and standards of care, prioritizing patient welfare and security.

site_title: More collaboration needed for cleaner hulls, cleaner waters
summary: A global alliance has been launched to tackle two pressing environmental issues: invasive marine species and greenhouse gas emissions from the shipping industry. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has partnered with private sector companies and UN entities to accelerate the development of solutions to prevent invasive species on ships' hulls and submerged structures. The alliance aims to promote sustainable use of ocean resources, reduce carbon footprint, and contribute to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. Four companies have already joined the Global Industry Alliance for Marine Biosafety, with more expected to join.

site_title: Eurozone set for deeper recession, less steep rebound
summary: The European Commission has revised its forecasts, predicting a deeper recession in the eurozone this year, with a 8.7% contraction, before rebounding less steeply in 2021, at 6.1%. France, Italy, and Spain are expected to struggle the most due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The Commission also cut its forecasts for Germany, where the economy is expected to contract by 6.3% this year and rebound by 6.1% in 2021. EU fiscal rules may remain frozen even after growth returns next year to reduce the risk of a second recession.

site_title: Replacing the liberal international order
summary: US President Joe Biden may not aim to revive the liberal international order, but instead establish rules-based institutions with different membership for various issues. The current order, established after World War II, was flawed and excluded many countries, including China and the Soviet bloc. With China and Russia's growing power, a new approach is needed to address transnational threats like climate change, pandemics, and economic instability. Biden must balance cooperation with authoritarian states like China and Russia while promoting democracy and human rights, and establish new norms for cyberspace to counter information warfare.

site_title: Telemedicine in the pink as Covid-19 gives shot in arm of nascent industry
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the growth of telemedicine in Singapore, with both established players and new entrants ramping up their services. User activity on telemedicine apps has soared, with some providers seeing a doubling of consultations. Behavioral change is also evident, with doctors and patients becoming more receptive to remote consultations. New players, including corporate giants, have joined the market, and interest in telemedicine extends beyond healthcare to include financial services and other industries. However, regulatory challenges and high compliance costs remain, and the industry is still in its nascent stages.

site_title: Hullo to a souped-up, virtual ChildAid 2020
summary: A virtual ChildAid 2020 concert will be held on July 15, utilizing state-of-the-art technology to deliver immersive 360-degree views and surround sound. The event, benefiting two children's charities, will feature 13 musicians performing in fantastical environments, such as an intergalactic wonderland and a sepia-tinged Casablanca-style setting. The concert will be streamed online for free on Facebook and YouTube, and is sponsored by several major brands, including UOB, UBS, and Richard Mille.

site_title: WB, IMF to hold annual meetings online
summary: The World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) will hold their annual meetings online in October due to the COVID-19 pandemic. World Bank President David Malpass encouraged countries to prioritize gender diversity in executive director appointments. The institutions have shifted to virtual meetings, with the spring meetings also held online in April. Malpass emphasized the World Bank's commitment to addressing the pandemic's economic impact and helping developing countries recover, with preliminary commitments totaling around $74 billion in 2020.

images.alt_text: World Bank president David Malpass underscored the bank's commitment to helping developing countries recover from the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Panic buying drives China-focused ETF's biggest gain since 2009
summary: The BlackRock iShares China Large-Cap ETF surged 9.5% in its biggest gain since 2009, following a front-page editorial by China's Securities Times that emphasized the importance of a healthy bull market. This boost was attributed to short sellers likely getting scorched by the rally in Chinese shares. The fund reached its highest level since April 2019.

site_title: Singapore's productivity and median wage have grown by a third in the last 10 years: Tharman
summary: Singapore's productivity and median wage have increased by a third over the last 10 years, according to Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. The nation's productivity grew by 2.4% annually per worker and 2.8% per work hour, with a one-third gain. This challenges the "urban myth" that Singapore has failed to raise productivity.

site_title: Australia's central bank sits tight as second-wave risks mount
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates unchanged at 0.25% despite a resurgence of COVID-19 cases in Australia's second-largest city, Melbourne. The decision aims to support the economy, which is recovering despite job losses and high unemployment. The RBA is leaning on fiscal authorities to provide stimulus, while the government prepares to deliver an economic statement on July 23. Australia's economy has endured its first recession since 1991 and faces ongoing risks, including ties with China and the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Wall St investors scored emergency government loans amid pandemic
summary: Several prominent venture capital firms, including Andreessen Horowitz, Index Ventures, and Foundation Capital, were listed as recipients of emergency government loans under the Paycheck Protection Program during the pandemic, despite claiming they did not apply. The firms said they either did not apply or were incorrectly listed due to errors. The Small Business Administration reported over 4.9 million loans totaling $521.5 billion, with many large entities receiving funding, prompting concerns about the program's eligibility.

site_title: Bond investors struggle to see reasons to be upbeat about UK
summary: UK bond investors are pessimistic about the country's prospects, ignoring recent economic growth and betting on an extended period of weakness. Government bonds have reached record highs, with yields near those in Japan. Investors are also expecting negative interest rates in 2021, despite the Bank of England's denial. This sentiment is driven by concerns over the UK's economic future, with traders prioritizing safe-haven assets.

site_title: New York luxury condo developer tries hand at Reit investing
summary: Ziel Feldman's HFZ Capital Group, a luxury condo developer in New York, has launched a real estate investment trust (Reit) fund to invest in undervalued Reits affected by the pandemic. The fund will buy shares of publicly-traded Reits, aiming to capitalize on their undervaluation. Feldman's move marks a departure from the company's focus on ultra-luxury condos, highlighting the group's diversification efforts in the real estate market.

site_title: Indonesia's Telkom unblocks Netflix as it amps digital push
summary: Indonesia's state-owned telecommunications firm Telkom has unblocked Netflix after four years of negotiations. The decision was made following a change in Netflix's approach to the country, which includes offering parental controls and responding to complaints from Indonesia's government or regulators within 24 hours. This move is part of Telkom's push to increase its digital presence and offerings in the country.

site_title: Risk currencies ease after rally and virus flare-ups
summary: Risk currencies, including the Australian dollar, experienced a brief pause in their recent gains on Tuesday as investors took a step back due to new Covid-19 flare-ups and local lockdowns in countries attempting to reopen. The US dollar index rose 0.3% to 97.009, while the Aussie dollar sank 0.65% to US$0.6928 after lockdown measures were reimposed in Melbourne. Investors appear cautious about a potential second coronavirus wave, with the US death toll topping 130,000 and surging infections in the US and India.

site_title: No plans to go back to Phase 1 after GE; rise in cases will be monitored
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry taskforce on Covid-19 announced there are no plans to revert to Phase 1 or a lockdown immediately after the General Election, despite a recent increase in community cases. The taskforce is closely monitoring the situation and will consider revising its measures based on the number and severity of cases. The healthcare system is being stretched, and the taskforce is working on contingencies, including responses to potential clusters. The health minister emphasized that the decision will depend on the severity of cases, not just the number.

site_title: Temasek JV Reefknot eyes at least 3 more investments
summary: REEFKNOT Investments, a joint venture between Temasek Holdings and Kuehne + Nagel, is seeking at least three more startup investments through a US$50 million global fund. The fund focuses on supply chain and logistics companies aiming to transform the industry, particularly through supply chain visibility. Managing director Marc Dragon stated that this area is crucial for the next few months.

site_title: Malaysian funds with over RM1t seek gains overseas
summary: Malaysia's three key state funds, with over RM1 trillion in assets, plan to diversify their investments overseas to manage risks and capitalize on global opportunities. The Employees Provident Fund, Khazanah Nasional Bhd, and Kumpulan Wang Persaraan are seeking to balance domestic and global exposure amid concerns over a snap election and fiscal deficit. Foreign investors have pulled over US$7 billion from Malaysian bonds and stocks this year, prompting state funds to seek international investments. The funds aim to achieve long-term diversification and balance growth.

site_title: Has the US lost its exceptionalism in the face of Covid-19?
summary: The US is struggling to contain the Covid-19 pandemic, with a daily infection rate of around one per 1,500 people, significantly higher than many other countries. Unlike other nations, many Americans do not recognize the need for social distancing and face masks, viewing these precautions as an infringement on their "freedom." As a result, the US Covid-19 death rate is expected to be much higher than other countries, potentially exceeding one death per 1,000 people, a rate seen during the 1918 Spanish influenza epidemic.

site_title: Ho Ching suggests Temasek's portfolio value close to S$300b estimates
summary: Temasek Holdings' CEO Ho Ching has confirmed that the state investment firm's portfolio value is "pretty close" to the estimated S$300 billion, as reported earlier. Ho Ching expressed appreciation for the analyses that speculated on Temasek's portfolio performance, stating that the figures are close to the firm's own management estimates. The audited portfolio performance is expected to be finalized in the next couple of weeks, and major investments make up about 60% of the total portfolio.

site_title: Taiwan warns of countermeasures if new HK law causes 'damage'
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen warned of "countermeasures" if China's new security law in Hong Kong causes "damage" to Taiwan. The law, which claims global jurisdiction, has been condemned by Taiwan's government, which regards Beijing's actions as a threat to its sovereignty. Taiwan is closely monitoring the law's execution, and its top China policy body warned Beijing and Hong Kong governments not to interfere with Taiwanese groups and institutions. The move is seen as a response to Beijing's increasing pressure on Taiwan since Tsai's election in 2016.

site_title: One-time heart of shale may never boom again with Dakota Access shut
summary: The Dakota Access pipeline, a major oil pipeline in the US, has been ordered to shut down by August 5 due to a court ruling on environmental concerns. This shutdown will have devastating effects on the Bakken shale formation, a key oil-producing area in North Dakota, Montana, and Canada. Output is expected to fall by as much as half a million barrels a day, and the closure will make it difficult for oil producers to sell their crude at a viable price. The shutdown is the first of its kind for a major pipeline in the US, and it will likely have long-term consequences for the oil industry.

site_title: GS Holdings looks to scrub out cleaning, dishwashing business
summary: GS Holdings, a Singapore-based company, is proposing to sell two subsidiaries, GS Cleaning Services and GS Equipment Supply, for S$2. The move is part of the company's efforts to focus on newer business lines and distance itself from its dishwashing roots. The sale follows the disposal of another subsidiary, GreatSolutions, which was sold for S$2 million. GS Holdings will book a loss of S$98 from the proposed deal, but expects it to have no material impact on its financial performance.

site_title: PAP giving voters a 'false choice': WP's Sylvia Lim
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) is presenting voters with a false choice by implying that the government will not effectively tackle COVID-19 if opposition MPs are elected, said Workers' Party (WP) chairman Sylvia Lim. This comes after Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's online rally, where he asked for a strong mandate at the upcoming General Election. WP leaders also responded to Lee's comments, with Pritam Singh saying the opposition will outline its plan to tackle the pandemic in its manifesto.

site_title: Covid-19 is turning San Francisco's inequality gap into a chasm
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is exacerbating wealth and racial inequalities in San Francisco, widening the city's existing gap between high-paid tech workers and low-income service industry employees. While tech workers remain largely unaffected, service industry workers like security guard Joe Grandov have seen their hours cut by up to 20 a week due to reduced business travel. Earnings among low-income workers in San Francisco County have fallen 52.1% since January, and the pandemic has deepened existing racial disparities, with Hispanic and Latino communities disproportionately affected by the virus.

site_title: Wirecard collapse puts spotlight on growing regulatory blind spots
summary: Germany's Wirecard collapse highlights the need for stricter regulation of non-traditional financial firms, which often operate like banks but are not subject to the same level of oversight. Wirecard's failure was partly due to regulatory blind spots, with its German bank unit being supervised but the group company as a whole not being classified as a finance company. The incident has sparked a government overhaul of financial regulation and raised concerns about the lack of oversight in the fintech sector, particularly in Europe, where around 31% of fintech firms are not regulated.

site_title: Borders won't protect countries from coronavirus
summary: The coronavirus pandemic is disproportionately affecting lower- and middle-income countries, with many struggling to cope with limited health resources, poverty, and debt burdens. The virus's spread is threatening global economic stability, with potential consequences including factory shutdowns, mining disruptions, and social unrest. Wealthy countries, particularly the US, have a moral and self-interest imperative to support developing countries in fighting the virus and avoiding humanitarian catastrophes. The international community must come together to address the dual emergency of the pandemic, including increasing debt relief for heavily indebted developing countries and ensuring fair access to therapeutics and vaccines.

site_title: US tech giants in HK suspend processing of government requests for user data
summary: US tech giants Facebook, Google, and Twitter have suspended processing government requests for user data in Hong Kong following China's establishment of a sweeping new national security law. The moves come as TikTok also plans to pull out of the Hong Kong market. The tech companies have paused reviews for all services pending further assessment of the National Security Law, which went into effect last week.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after five-day rally as virus cases surge
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday after a five-day rally, as new coronavirus cases surged nationwide. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 115.02 points, or 0.44%, to 26,172.01, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Investors weighed the risks to the economy from the rising cases, which may impact growth and investor confidence.

site_title: B&O sees return to growth after near 30% slide in sales
summary: Bang & Olufsen (B&O) reported a 29% drop in revenue to 2.036 billion Danish crowns for the financial year ending May 31, the lowest in at least 27 years. The company made a loss before tax and interest of 347 million crowns, citing a decline in sales of its luxury televisions and speakers. Despite this, B&O predicted a return to growth next year through new product launches and stronger marketing. The company raised 409 million Danish crowns via a rights issue to help it survive the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Singapore spearheads global digital trade gateway with NTP
summary: Singapore has launched the Networked Trade Platform (NTP), a digital hub for global trade that aims to simplify and streamline trade processes for businesses. The platform, spearheaded by the Singapore government, will connect businesses to trading partners and counterparties worldwide, reducing time and costs. With partnerships with international organizations, governments, and industry players, the NTP is designed to create a secure environment for digital trade documents and mitigate the risk of fraud. Estimated annual savings for companies using the platform are S$600 million, with the potential to further grow Singapore's cross-border trade.

site_title: UK, EU under pressure to strike trade deal, but several issues impede agreement
summary: The European Union and the United Kingdom are under pressure to strike a trade deal, despite several issues impeding agreement. The UK and EU are meeting face-to-face for the first time since March, with both sides committed to resolving differences. Key differences include the role of the European Court of Justice, the UK's desire to control its fishing waters, and the EU's demand for a "level playing field" in competition and trade. Failure to agree by the end of the transition period could result in tariffs and a no-deal exit, with economists warning of a 20-60% probability of an accord.

site_title: US job openings unexpectedly increase as hires climb to record
summary: US job openings unexpectedly increased to 5.4 million in May, surpassing economists' median forecast of 4.5 million. This rise in available positions suggests state economies are recovering as businesses look to hire anew. The increase in job openings is a positive sign for the labor market, indicating a potential boost in hiring activity.

site_title: WHO acknowledges 'emerging evidence' of airborne spread of Covid-19
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) acknowledged "emerging evidence" of the airborne spread of COVID-19, updating its guidance on the virus's transmission modes. WHO expert Benedetta Allegranzi stated the organization has been open to the evidence, but did not provide specific details. This recognition comes after a group of scientists urged the WHO to update its guidance, citing new research on the virus's airborne transmission. The WHO's acknowledgment marks a shift in understanding the virus's behavior, but its implications for public health measures remain unclear.

site_title: SPH files amended defence and counterclaim in StreetSine litigation case
summary: SPH files amended defence and counterclaim in StreetSine litigation case. The amended defence and counterclaim were filed against plaintiffs Samuel Cranage Baker and Jeremy Lee Chuen Yang, who allege minority oppression by SPH and its subsidiary SPH Interactive. SPH acquired a 60% stake in StreetSine Technology Group in 2014, while Baker and Lee each hold a 20% stake. The amended defence and counterclaim aim to address the plaintiffs' allegations.

site_title: Will America ditch rhetoric and go for governance and expertise?
summary: The US may shift away from populist rhetoric and towards governance and expertise, following a similar trend seen in the Brexit vote. The rise of Donald Trump, a business tycoon with no government experience, exemplifies the public's distrust of experts. This sentiment has been fueled by concerns about the "Deep State" and global elitism. As a result, there is a growing demand for leaders who can balance populism with expertise, potentially leading to a more pragmatic approach to governance.

site_title: Will working from home sound the death knell for offices?
summary: Remote working, which has become widespread during the coronavirus pandemic, may not necessarily lead to a permanent decline in office demand. While some companies have already downsized their offices, many businesses will likely revert to pre-pandemic working patterns, with some employees working from home one day a week. The need for social distancing and other safety measures may actually require companies to allocate more space per person, but this may not be feasible for all businesses. The office is still seen as essential for productivity, networking, and face-to-face interactions, and its demand is expected to remain strong in certain sectors.

images.alt_text: Studies suggest that people who work mainly from home often feel isolated and risk becoming demotivated about work.

site_title: STI takes a breather; snaps 5-day winning streak
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Tuesday, snapping a 5-day winning streak, with the Straits Times Index losing 28.19 points or 1.05% to finish at 2,661.42. Most regional bourses also took a breather, except China, which extended gains by 0.4%. The decline comes despite improving trading sentiments as more countries reopened their economies, but caution prevails amid a lockdown return in Melbourne, Australia.

site_title: Britain jeopardising China relationship, says Huawei's UK boss
summary: Britain risks damaging its long-standing relationship with China if it bans Huawei from its 5G networks, UK chairman John Browne said. The decision, driven by US sanctions on chip technology, could jeopardize the UK-China relationship. Despite granting Huawei a limited role in its 5G network earlier this year, new US sanctions have put its status as a reliable supplier in doubt.

site_title: Indonesia imposes 10% VAT on Amazon, Google, Netflix and Spotify
summary: Indonesia has imposed a 10% value-added tax on digital services provided by foreign companies such as Amazon, Google, Netflix, and Spotify. The move aims to boost state finances amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to a 13% drop in state revenue. The tax applies to non-resident firms selling digital products and services worth at least $41,667 annually or generating traffic from 12,000 users. The tax office expects to increase the number of companies assigned to pay VAT for digital products.

site_title: Uber launches grocery delivery, starting in Canada, Latin America
summary: Uber launches grocery delivery service in Canada and Latin America, starting this week, through its acquired subsidiary Cornershop. The new service integrates Cornershop's existing operations in cities such as Brazil, Chile, and Colombia. Uber aims to diversify from its core ride-hailing business, which has been impacted by the global pandemic. The move follows Uber's recent acquisition of Postmates for $2.65 billion, expanding its delivery footprint in the US.

site_title: Temasek unit now a substantial shareholder of CSE Global
summary: CSE Global, a global technology solutions provider, announced that Heliconia Capital Management, an investment firm owned by Temasek Holdings, has acquired a 25.03% stake in the company, making it a substantial shareholder.
