Following the acquisition, Heliconia has requested that CSE appoint its chairman and CEO as non-executive directors. The move is seen as a strong endorsement of CSE's business proposition and track record, and the company's CEO expressed optimism about expanding its businesses in Singapore and overseas markets.

site_title: Boustead Singapore posts 11% higher H2 net profit at S$18.5m
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a 61% year-on-year increase in second-half revenue to S$434.5 million, but a 11% increase in net profit to S$18.5 million, mainly due to gross margin pressure and impairment losses. The company's full-year revenue rose 54% to S$726.6 million, with net profit falling 5% to S$30.9 million. Despite this, the company's net asset value per share strengthened to 70.3 cents, and it proposed a final cash dividend of two cents per share.

site_title: SPH files amended defence and counterclaim in StreetSine litigation case
summary: SPH files amended defence and counterclaim in StreetSine litigation case. The plaintiffs, Samuel Cranage Baker and Jeremy Lee Chuen Yang, allege minority oppression against SPH and its subsidiary SPH Interactive over the acquisition of 60% stake in StreetSine Technology Group in 2014. The amended defence and counterclaim were filed as SSTG seeks judicial management.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay US$150m penalty over Jeffrey Epstein, other compliance failures
summary: Deutsche Bank agreed to pay a US$150 million penalty to settle charges with the New York State Department of Financial Services over significant compliance failures in its relationships with Jeffrey Epstein, Danske Bank Estonia, and FBME Bank. The bank failed to properly monitor Epstein's transactions despite publicly available information about his abuse. This marks the first regulatory enforcement action against a financial institution for dealings with Epstein. Deutsche Bank acknowledged deficiencies in monitoring Danske Estonia and FBME, with CEO Christian Sewing calling it a "critical mistake" to take Epstein on as a client in 2013.

site_title: ASL Marine unit wins jobs for floating fish farms
summary: ASL Marine's wholly-owned unit has secured shipbuilding contracts for two Eco-Ark floating fish farms from the Aquaculture Centre of Excellence (ACE). The two farms, designed to generate higher fish yields in smaller spaces, will be anchored off Singapore's northern coast by the first quarter of next year. Construction is expected to start this month, with revenue recognition in line with ASL Marine's policy. The contracts are expected to have a positive but not material impact on the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the financial year ending June 30, 2021.

site_title: Zara founder had 15b euros in real estate assets globally in 2019
summary: Amancio Ortega, founder of Inditex and Europe's richest man, had €15.16 billion (S$23.9 billion) in real estate assets globally as of 2019, according to his investment vehicle Pontegadea. This includes properties like London's Oxford Street, New York's EV Haughwout Building, and office blocks leased to Amazon in Seattle. Pontegadea booked €1.63 billion in Inditex dividends in 2019, with income from real estate rising 19% to €621 million. The company expects dividend payments to be reduced in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on retail and office real estate.

site_title: End to Australia's apartment binge clouds outlook
summary: Australia's apartment building boom is ending due to a surge in housing supply from the country's closed international borders. The construction sector, accounting for 10% of jobs and economic activity, is experiencing a glut. Since 2000, Australia's population has grown by 6 million, largely from immigration. The halt in international arrivals has led to an oversupply of apartments, threatening jobs and economic growth. This shift reverses the country's recent prosperity, which was driven by the apartment building boom. The country's housing market is now facing a correction.

images.alt_text: Although the hit to construction has so far been mild, policymakers are deeply worried about that changing as builders approach a plunge in the project pipeline over the next 12 months.

site_title: ChildAid raises funds for over 10,000 kids a year
summary: ChildAid, an annual charity event in Singapore, raises funds for two charities that support over 170,000 children annually. The first charity, The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, helps artistically-gifted children from low-income families pursue the arts, while the second, The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, assists underprivileged children with meal and transport costs. Since the pandemic, the need for support has increased, with single mothers and families struggling to make ends meet. ChildAid 2020: Virtually Yours premieres on July 15, with all proceeds going towards the two charities.

images.alt_text: Xu Jing Feng received funds raised by ChildAid when he was in secondary school. Last year, he picked up a gold medal at the 2019 SEA Games.
Sisters Durgashini d/o Gunasegaran (left), and Shrinithi d/o Gunasegaran, are recipients of ST School Pocket Money Fund.
Beneficiaries of the BT Budding Artists Fund develop their self-confidence through the arts.

site_title: Despite downturn, Saudi Arabia pursues goal of doubling size of capital city
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to double the size and population of its capital city, Riyadh, to 15 million people by 2030, despite an economic downturn due to the coronavirus crisis and low oil prices. The government has committed $266.6 billion to ongoing and new projects, part of a $800 billion investment over the next decade. The goal is to transform Riyadh into a mega-metropolis and create jobs, with most projects set for completion between 2023 and 2025. The ambitious plan is part of Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's Vision 2030 to diversify the economy and reduce reliance on oil.

site_title: Chinese trading apps struggle as millions of investors pile in during rally
summary: Chinese trading apps are struggling to keep up with a surge in trading activity, as millions of investors rush to capitalize on the market's rally. Trading volume hit a five-year high, with 3.2 trillion yuan (S$645.6 billion) in the first two days of the week. Glitches were reported on several trading apps, including Huatai Securities and Guotai Junan Securities. The brokerage industry is surging, with a 17% gain this year, as Chinese investors load up on leverage to speculate in the stock market.

site_title: Corelogic rejects US$7b takeover bid from investment firms
summary: Corelogic, a real estate data analytics firm, has rejected a US$7 billion takeover bid from investment firms Cannae Holdings and Senator Investment Group, citing that the proposal undervalues the company and raises regulatory concerns. The company's board unanimously rejected the offer, which was made at US$65 per share. Corelogic also raised its full-year revenue forecast to between US$1.84 billion and US$1.88 billion, beating analyst expectations. The company has implemented a short-term shareholder rights plan to prevent investors from acquiring 10% or more of the company's common stock.

site_title: 384 dormitories declared cleared of Covid-19 virus: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) announced that 384 more dormitories have been cleared of the Covid-19 virus, bringing the total to 625 dormitories and 44 blocks for recovered workers in 17 purpose-built dormitories. Approximately 180,000 workers have either recovered or tested negative for the virus. Employers can now use the Safe@Work Service to check AccessCode details on the SGWorkPass mobile app, streamlining the process for workers to return to work.

site_title: GE quick takes: WP will look into Raeesah Khan's comments; Peoples Voice unveils manifesto
summary: Singapore is set to hold its General Election on Friday, with 93 seats in 31 constituencies up for contest. The People's Action Party (PAP) has emphasized inclusivity in its strategies, while the Workers' Party (WP) has proposed seven Covid-19 measures, including independent inquiries and vaccinations for all residents. The WP will review Raeesah Khan's Facebook comments, but will not prejudice ongoing police investigations. The Peoples Voice party has released a manifesto focusing on prioritizing Singaporeans for jobs and improving accountability in the government.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust urges unitholders to make informed vote on divestment
summary: Accordia Golf Trust is urging unitholders to carefully review its proposed divestment of 88 golf courses in Japan, which was proposed for 61.8 billion Japanese yen (S$804.1 million) per unit. The largest minority unitholder, Hibiki Path Advisors, has expressed concerns over the low price, stating that the assets generate "significantly attractive cash flow." Unitholders are advised to review the circular, which will be released soon, and refrain from taking any actions that may be prejudicial to their interests.

site_title: Wirecard administrator sees strong interest from potential buyers
summary: The administrator of Wirecard, a German payments firm, reported over 100 investors interested in buying the company's core business and assets. The sale of Wirecard North America's assets is most advanced, with investment bank Moelis & Company already mandated to support the sale. This comes after Wirecard filed for insolvency last month due to a 1.9 billion euro fraud hole in its accounts, leaving creditors 4 billion euros in debt. The goal is to find timely investor solutions in the interest of creditors, employees, and customers.

site_title: WHO doesn't see bubonic plague in China as high risk
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has deemed an apparent bubonic plague outbreak in China as "well managed" and not considered a high-risk event. The outbreak, reported in the city of Bayan Nur in Inner Mongolia, follows four cases in November, including two cases of pneumonic plague. WHO officials are monitoring the situation closely, but at present, they are not considering it a high-risk event. Cases of bubonic plague are common in China, but are becoming increasingly rare.

site_title: UK house prices fall for longest period since 2010: Halifax
summary: UK house prices fell for a fourth consecutive month in June, the longest decline since 2010, according to Halifax. Prices dropped 0.1% in June, 0.2% in May, and 0.9% compared to the first quarter of 2020. Despite a 2.5% year-over-year increase, this was the slowest rate of growth since November 2019. The near-term outlook suggests a continued downward trend in prices through the third quarter, according to Halifax managing director Russell Galley.

site_title: ASL Marine unit to build floating fish farms off Pulau Ubin
summary: ASL Marine has secured contracts to build two floating fish farms, Eco-Ark, off Pulau Ubin in Singapore. The farms, designed for sustainability and higher fish yields, are expected to start construction this month and be completed by the first quarter of 2021. The revenue from the contracts is expected to have a positive but not material impact on ASL Marine's net tangible assets and earnings per share by 2021. The companies' shares are now on the SGX watchlist, with ASL Marine closing at S$0.038 on Tuesday, down 2.6%.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific, Teo Tong Lim's family office to buy Melbourne tower for A$145m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings, a Singapore-based property developer, has partnered with Teo Tong Lim's family office to acquire a 21-storey Melbourne office building for A$145 million. The deal, valued at S$140.5 million, is part of a joint venture between the two parties through a master trust. The acquisition is subject to conditions, including Foreign Investment Review Board approval. Roxy-Pacific plans to pursue a 12-month refurbishment program for the building, which has a freehold tenure and a total site area of 1,787 square meters.

site_title: US government awards Novavax US$1.6b for coronavirus vaccine
summary: The US government has awarded Novavax $1.6 billion to develop and manufacture a potential COVID-19 vaccine, with the aim of delivering 100 million doses by January. This is the largest award from the "Operation Warp Speed" initiative, which aims to accelerate vaccine development and distribution. Novavax expects to start producing doses in the fourth quarter of this year and will cover the cost of a large Phase III trial. The company's CEO, Stanley Erck, said the award places Novavax in a "very enviable position" if its data is compelling later in the year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower after rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day with a 1.38% decline, shedding 363.50 points, after a four-day rally. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.37% and the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 1.71%. The decline follows a strong rally in Hong Kong, while mainland Chinese shares continued their gains.

site_title: SGX rejects Tee International's request for more time to unveil FY2020, Q1 FY2021 results
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Tee International's request for a two-month extension to unveil its FY2020 and Q1 FY2021 results, with the deadline now set for July 30 and October 15 respectively. The company had also asked for an extension to hold its annual general meeting (AGM), which will now take place by October 31, following a one-month extension granted by the SGX. Tee International had previously requested a two-month extension for its AGM, with the outcome of its application to the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority of Singapore (ACRA) to be announced later.

site_title: More Covid-19 cases linked to workplace transmissions in Phase 2
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry taskforce on Covid-19 reported a rise in workplace transmissions linked to community cases, increasing from 22% in Phase 1 to 36% in Phase 2. New community cases have also risen to an average of 12 per day, with most linked to confirmed cases or households. The taskforce advises employers to keep staff at home unless necessary, and warned of potential clusters, with Health Minister Gan Kim Yong stating that the number of community cases may increase over the next few weeks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government has stepped up inclusivity strategies, emphasizing social mobility from early childhood stages. Fitch Ratings has placed Singapore banks under pressure, reviewing their ratings. Roxy-Pacific has invested in a Melbourne tower, while AGV Group has successfully completed a rights issue. AIA Singapore has announced leadership changes, and Singapore shares closed 1% lower on Tuesday. The country has also seen progress in clearing Covid-19 virus from dormitories, with 384 now declared cleared.

site_title: JD Sports says mall footfall still weak, cancels final dividend
summary: JD Sports, Britain's largest sportswear chain, cancelled its final dividend payment due to weak mall footfall in Europe amid COVID-19 concerns. The company reported a 24% jump in profit to £438.8 million for the year ended Feb 1, but warned of a "material" hit from the crisis this year. Chairman Peter Cowgill attributed uncertainty to consumer behavior and footfall due to the pandemic, affecting future store investments.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1% lower
summary: Singapore shares closed 1.05% lower on Tuesday, snapping a five-day winning streak, with the Straits Times Index losing 28.19 points to 2,661.42. Most regional bourses also took a breather, while China's Shanghai Composite extended gains. The decline came despite improved trading sentiments due to easing lockdown restrictions in countries.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets retreat at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Tuesday, following losses in Tokyo, as investors weighed the risks of a second wave of the virus against a rebounding economy. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.8% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also fell 0.9%. Despite a strong previous session, investors were cautious, with analysts citing a need to pause after recent gains.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia sees 2020 capacity at 45-60% of 2019 levels on virus hit
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia Group expects 2020 capacity to be 45-60% of 2019 levels due to the coronavirus outbreak. The airline forecasts travel demand will rebound in 2021, with capacity reaching 85% of 2019 levels and load factor returning to 85%. AirAsia aims to fill 70-75% of seats in 2020, down from 85% in previous years. The airline reported its biggest first-quarter loss since its listing in 2004.

site_title: Euro zone set for deeper recession, less steep rebound
summary: The European Commission has revised its forecast for the euro zone economy, predicting a deeper recession this year and a less steep rebound in 2021. The euro zone is expected to contract by 8.7% in 2020 and 6.1% in 2021, with France, Italy, and Spain expected to experience downturns of over 10% due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Germany's 2020 downturn is forecast at 6.3%, with a less pronounced rebound in 2021. The revised forecasts assume no second wave of infections and the continued use of monetary and fiscal policy measures to support the recovery.

site_title: PM would know about SDP's Covid-19 comments if he was not so disconnected: Paul Tambyah
summary: Singapore's opposition parties, including the Singapore Democratic Party and Workers' Party, have rebutted Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's comments that they have ignored the COVID-19 crisis. Opposition leaders, including Paul Tambyah and Pritam Singh, have proposed live televised debates with the government on the pandemic response and emphasized their experience and expertise in tackling the crisis. They argue that holding an election during a pandemic is reckless and that the government's handling of the crisis is not effective.

site_title: Premier Inn owner Whitbread cautious on outlook as hotels reopen
summary: Whitbread, the owner of Premier Inn, reported an 80% fall in first-quarter like-for-like UK sales due to lockdowns. However, demand for hotel rooms in tourist spots is improving, and over 270 hotels and 24 restaurants have reopened. All German hotels have also reopened. Whitbread plans to reopen the remaining hotels by the end of the month, despite cautioning on its outlook.

site_title: Zara founder books 15b euros real estate assets in 2019
summary: Amancio Ortega, founder of Inditex, booked 15.16 billion euros in real estate assets in 2019 through his investment vehicle Pontegadea. The assets include prime commercial properties in London and New York, as well as stakes in Spanish telecom towers and gas grid operator. Pontegadea also made over 2 billion euros in real estate purchases in 2019. However, the company's income from real estate decreased 19% in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with dividend payments cut to 646 million euros.

site_title: Deutsche Bank and Google agree multi-year, strategic partnership
summary: Deutsche Bank and Google have agreed on a strategic, multi-year partnership to provide cloud services and drive innovation in technology-based financial products for clients. The partnership is expected to generate over €1 billion in earnings over the next decade. Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing described the partnership as a key driver of the bank's transformation, linking its future to successful digitization. A multi-year contract is expected to be signed within the next few months.

site_title: US solar giant Sunrun is about to become a rooftop juggernaut
summary: US solar giant Sunrun is set to acquire Vivint Solar Inc for $1.46 billion, becoming the industry's largest rooftop-solar company. The deal, subject to approvals, threatens to further weaken Tesla's grip on the rooftop-solar market and could inspire more sector consolidation. The combined Sunrun and Vivint provide about 75% of new residential solar leases each quarter. This acquisition is the second major US energy deal in as many days, following Berkshire Hathaway's $4 billion purchase of Dominion Energy assets.

site_title: UK newspaper publisher to cut 550 jobs on virus fallout
summary: Reach, a UK newspaper publisher, plans to cut 550 jobs, or 12% of its workforce, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on advertising revenues and circulation. The restructuring aims to achieve annual cost savings of £35 million and will result in £20 million in costs. The company's revenue declined 27.5% in the second quarter, with editorial and management structures to be centralized for increased efficiency.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 10.18 points to 1,566.72. The index saw a volume of 7.781 billion lots worth RM4.931 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 648 to 428, indicating a negative market trend.

site_title: US 'looking at' banning TikTok and other Chinese apps: Pompeo
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced the country is "looking at" banning Chinese social media apps, including TikTok, due to allegations of spying. This follows India's ban on TikTok over national security and privacy concerns. Pompeo stated the Trump administration is taking the issue seriously and is considering blocking the apps. Other countries may also take similar measures, citing concerns over user data and potential espionage.

site_title: Finns turn to berry-picking as coronavirus job losses bite
summary: Finland is experiencing a labor shortage in its strawberry harvest due to coronavirus travel restrictions, prompting farmers to turn to domestic workers. Thousands of Finns, including students and those made jobless by the pandemic, have answered the call to fill the gap, with many receiving a 10% bonus to compensate for the slower picking pace. However, the demand for domestic workers may not be enough to save the country's bilberry harvest, which relies on Thai workers and may be replaced by imports from Poland or Russia.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down after 3-day winning streak
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, ending a three-day winning streak, as investors locked in profits. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.44% to 22,614.69 and the Topix index dropped 0.34% to 1,571.71. The decline comes as investors cautiously assess the impact of deadly floods and landslides on local economies.

site_title: AIA Singapore announces leadership changes
summary: AIA Singapore has announced leadership changes, effective immediately. Ho Lee Yen has been appointed as Chief Distribution Officer, replacing herself, and will lead the transformation of the next generation distribution force. Melita Teo has taken on the role of Chief Customer and Digital Officer, focusing on strengthening customer propositions and accelerating digital experiences. Tan Kian Loy, who previously led core operation systems transformation initiatives, has been appointed as Chief Operations Officer, driving the use of digital tools and expanding customer-centric service propositions. These changes follow the appointment of Wong Sze Keed as CEO in July.

site_title: Coronavirus: Four students and school teacher among new cases in the community
summary: Singapore reported 20 new community cases of COVID-19 on Tuesday, including four students and a school teacher from various schools. The cases are linked to household infections, previous clusters, or asymptomatic individuals. The affected schools have implemented additional precautions, and about 60 students and 10 staff have been issued 14-day leave or home quarantine orders. The average number of new community cases has increased to 14 per day, with 285 cases discharged and 40,990 patients fully recovered.

site_title: Rivals Royal Caribbean, Norwegian Cruise Line team up to plan restart
summary: Royal Caribbean Group and Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd have formed a joint task force, the "Healthy Sail Panel," to develop safety standards for restarting their businesses during the coronavirus pandemic. The panel, co-chaired by former Utah Governor Mike Leavitt and former US FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb, will advise the companies on their restart plans to be submitted to the US CDC and other regulators by the end of August. The move aims to help the cruise industry navigate the pandemic and return to operations, following a pause in operations from US ports until September.

site_title: China should delay asset management rules to end-2022: report
summary: China's asset management rules, aimed at cracking down on shadow banking, may be delayed by two years to end-2022, according to a report by China Wealth Management 50 Forum and the National Institute of Financial Research of Tsinghua University. The report recommends a phased reduction of off-balance-sheet wealth management products (WMPs) by at least 30% each year to zero by end-2022. Regulators are also advised to relax rules on granting securities business licenses and unify the regulation of the $15 trillion asset management industry.

site_title: Spackman says potential buyer eyeing production house Zip Cinema
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group has entered a non-binding letter of intent (LOI) with a potential buyer to acquire its Zip Cinema subsidiary, a major South Korean production house. The buyer, an unnamed content production company, is seeking to acquire 100% of Zip Cinema's shares for an undisclosed price. Spackman's board aims to explore strategic alternatives to unlock shareholder value, and negotiations are set to begin in good faith by Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Seoul: Shares drop 1% as virus fears threaten economic revival
summary: South Korean shares dropped 1% on Tuesday as concerns over a second COVID-19 wave globally overshadowed hopes for a swift economic recovery. The Kospi index closed at 2,164.17, down 23.76 points. US health official Anthony Fauci described the US outbreak as a "serious situation," while South Korea reported 44 new cases, bringing the national tally to 13,181. Despite early gains, foreign investors sold US$327.34 million worth of shares, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Australian dollar holds gains after RBA, coronavirus lockdowns a concern
summary: The Australian dollar maintained its gains on Tuesday, steady at US$0.6970, after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates at record lows. The decision came amid concerns over a renewed coronavirus outbreak in Victoria, which has led to lockdowns and border closures. The RBA reiterated its readiness to ease rates further if needed, while the economic downturn is expected to be less severe than initially feared.

site_title: Japan government says coincident indicator index suggests economy is worsening
summary: Japan's coincident indicator index fell 5.5 points to 74.6 in May, signaling a worsening economy due to the coronavirus outbreak. The index, which includes factory output, employment, and retail sales data, was lower than the previous month. In contrast, the leading economic indicators index rose 1.6 points to 79.3, suggesting the economy may be improving. The government's view on the index remains unchanged, indicating a continued economic impact from the pandemic.

site_title: Australia's second-biggest city under new virus lockdown
summary: Melbourne, Australia's second-largest city, is under a six-week lockdown due to a surge in coronavirus cases. The lockdown, starting at midnight on Wednesday, affects over 5 million residents and will limit restaurants and cafes to takeaway food. Schools will return to remote learning. The lockdown is the latest measure to curb the spread of the virus, which has been largely contained in other parts of the country. Australia has reported almost 9,000 cases and 106 deaths from the virus.

site_title: Singapore banks' weakening operating environment pressures ratings: Fitch Ratings
summary: Fitch Ratings plans to review and resolve its rating watch negative on Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and United Overseas Bank within the next three months. The review follows the impact of the coronavirus pandemic and the banks' limited headroom in their AA- viability ratings. Potential outcomes include a downgrade to A+ and viability ratings to a+, or an affirmation at AA- with a negative or stable outlook.

site_title: Brazil exporters propose tests to show China their meat is safe
summary: Brazil's meat exporters propose testing all meat shipments to China to prove safety and avoid further bans. The proposal, made to Brazil's Agriculture Ministry, would be carried out by export companies. This comes after China suspended imports from two pork plants and halted exports from three plants last week. The move aims to restore confidence in Brazilian meat exports to China, the largest consumer of Brazilian meat.

site_title: PAP has significantly stepped up strategies for inclusivity: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam outlined the People's Action Party's (PAP) strategies for building a more inclusive society in Singapore, highlighting the importance of inclusivity in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic. The PAP aims to create a more inclusive society for children, working adults, and seniors through investments in education, skills training, and social welfare programs. The government plans to double its expenditure on the preschool sector, upgrade the teaching profession, and provide support for those falling behind in education. Tharman also emphasized the need to sustain upward income growth for the majority of Singaporeans and ensure that seniors have a sense of security and ability to live life to the fullest.

images.alt_text: In his speech, Mr Tharman outlined the PAP's strategies for creating a more inclusive society for children, working adults and seniors.

site_title: SOLshare bags US$1.1m funding with support from IIX Impact Partners
summary: BANGLADESH-BASED clean energy firm SOLshare secured US$1.1 million in funding from IIX Impact Partners, along with innogy New Ventures and EDP Ventures. The funding will be used to bring smart solar microgrids to off-grid communities in Bangladesh, particularly in Rohingya refugee camps. SOLshare is in discussions with the UNHCR to supply the technology. This investment supports SOLshare's growth and expansion, following a 2018 investment through IIX's Growth Fund.

site_title: North Korea says it won't sit down with US
summary: North Korea has stated it has no intention to meet with the US, urging South Korea to stop meddling in its affairs. This comes as a US envoy, Stephen Biegun, was set to visit Seoul to discuss renewing stalled nuclear talks with Pyongyang. North Korean diplomat Kwon Jong Gun accused South Korea of misinterpreting an earlier statement dismissing a potential summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The US and North Korea had previously met in 2018 and 2019, but working-level negotiations fell apart.

site_title: 'He's buying up Brixton': Beloved grocer's eviction sparks gentrification fight
summary: Saja Shaheen's family-owned grocery store, Nour Cash & Carry, in London's Brixton Market, is at risk of eviction due to a new power substation being built on the premises. The store, a staple in the diverse community, has been a symbol of gentrification, with new immigrant communities arriving and changing the area's character. The eviction sparked a campaign to save the store, with locals and activists arguing that it is a referendum on broader changes in Brixton, disproportionately affecting lower-income and minority communities.

site_title: Australia's central bank holds rate at record low, keeps wary eye on recovery
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held its cash rate at a record low of 0.25% amid a cautious outlook for the country's economy. Despite a significant drop in new infections and easing of restrictions, the RBA sounded wary about the recovery due to a recent spike in cases in Melbourne and the closure of the state border. The central bank emphasized that fiscal and monetary support will likely be needed for some time to meet its employment and inflation objectives. The accommodative approach will be maintained as long as required, with no plans to increase the cash rate target.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank left its cash rate at a record low of 0.25 per cent on Tuesday in a widely expected decision and reiterated it stood ready to ease policy further if necessary.

site_title: Hong Kong security law is not 'doom and gloom', Lam says
summary: Hong Kong's national security law, imposed by Beijing, was not "doom and gloom" for the city, according to Carrie Lam. The law, which punishes up to life in prison for "secession, subversion, terrorism, and collusion with foreign forces," was announced and came into force simultaneously. Lam said the law was "mild" and would restore Hong Kong's safety, but critics have criticized it for undermining freedoms and giving mainland security agencies an enforcement presence in Hong Kong.

site_title: Thousands of copper workers have fallen ill in Chile
summary: Thousands of copper workers in Chile have fallen ill amid a nationwide surge of COVID-19 infections, threatening the country's copper output. Chile accounts for over a quarter of global supply, and mines have postponed non-essential activities to minimize risk. With fewer workers on site, output levels are being maintained, but the situation raises concerns about the long-term impact on the country's copper industry. The rise in copper prices is partly attributed to the surge in Chilean COVID-19 cases.

site_title: Broker's take: AmBank 'overweight' on Malaysia glove sector; ups Top Glove's FV
summary: AmBank has maintained its "overweight" call on Malaysia's glove sector, citing exponential growth in sales volume and average selling price in the second half of this year. Analyst Nafisah Azmi expects soaring selling prices, low raw material costs, and a strengthened US dollar to boost earnings. The bank raised its fair value of Top Glove, the world's largest rubber glove maker, amid these positive forecasts.

site_title: Fewer medical graduates from Muslim countries entering US in Trump-era
summary: The number of foreign medical graduates from Muslim-majority countries entering the US to become doctors has declined by 15% under the Trump administration, exacerbating physician workforce shortages. These international medical graduates, who represent about a quarter of practicing US doctors, are required to take licensing exams and complete training to practice medicine in the US. The decline in their numbers could worsen the US physician shortage, which is already a pressing concern.

site_title: Car-sharing startups take US loans after covid-19 disruptions
summary: Car-sharing startups Getaround and Turo, valued at over $1 billion, have taken US$5-10 million loans through the Paycheck Protection Program, a government aid program for small businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic. The companies cited the program as a "lifeline" to continue providing essential services despite the pandemic's severe impact on the transportation industry.

site_title: Asia: Investors take breather after latest stocks surge
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day on Tuesday after their latest surge, with investors taking a breather amid concerns about a potential virus second wave. Despite ongoing lockdown easing and economic data, several countries are reporting fresh surges in infections, particularly the US. Markets are expected to remain optimistic, driven by government and central bank support, with Shanghai hitting a two-year high and the Nasdaq reaching a record. Analysts expect more gains, particularly with Samsung Electronics' expected 23% operating profit jump in the second quarter.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Bostic says US recovery may be 'levelling off': FT
summary: Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Raphael Bostic stated that the US economic recovery may be "levelling off" due to a recent spike in coronavirus cases across the US. High-frequency data indicates a slowdown in business openings and mobility, raising concerns about the recovery's trajectory. Bostic warned that the recovery might be "bumpier" than expected, citing troubling signs.

site_title: Parents are paying US$50,000 for prep schools their kids might not attend
summary: Wealthy US families are paying $50,000 in full tuition to Manhattan private schools, even if their children won't attend. Some parents have enrolled their kids in public schools in other states, where they're currently staying. The goal is for the children to attend in-person classes at the public school or virtually join friends in New York for homeroom once a week, pending their return to Manhattan. This practice raises questions about the value of these prep school spots and the true cost of elite education.

site_title: 'Do your part': WWII film 'Greyhound' teaches virus lesson, says Hanks
summary: Tom Hanks' WWII film "Greyhound" is now available on Apple TV+, teaching audiences about acting decently in a global crisis like the COVID-19 pandemic. The movie follows a rookie captain escorting a convoy of Allied ships across the North Atlantic, hounded by Nazi U-boats. Hanks, who contracted the virus, hopes the film will encourage viewers to practice basic safety measures such as social distancing, handwashing, and wearing masks, saying "Don't be a pussy. Get on with it, do your part. It's very, very basic."

site_title: Blogging and playing e-sports now count as jobs in China
summary: China has broadened its definition of a job to include blogging, freelance work, and e-sports playing for fresh graduates, aiming to address high unemployment due to the coronavirus downturn. The new rules classify individuals who work at least one paid hour a week as employed, regardless of whether they are part of a traditional work unit. This move follows comments by a senior government adviser, who emphasized the need for a more tolerant stance towards flexible forms of work. The move aims to address the country's record 8.74 million fresh graduates entering the job market this summer.

site_title: SoftBank-backed startups among those approved for US paycheck loan programme
summary: Four SoftBank-backed startups, including Getaround, Nauto, Energy Vault, and CloudMinds Technology, were approved for US paycheck loan program aid under the US$500 billion Paycheck Protection Program. The companies received loans ranging from $150,000 to $10 million, with Getaround receiving a $5-10 million loan and Energy Vault receiving a $150,000 to $300,000 loan. The Treasury Department did not disclose the loan amounts for companies with less than $150,000 in loans.

site_title: Singapore oil trader ZenRock said to be winding down by August
summary: Singapore-based oil trader ZenRock is planning to wind down its business by August, with employees departing from its offices in Singapore and China. The company faces allegations of dishonest deals and has been raided by police. ZenRock has handed over responsibilities to KPMG's interim judicial manager. The move comes after oil's historic plunge earlier this year, which has sparked feuds with international lenders. The company's struggles highlight the challenges faced by trading houses in Asia's commodities hub.

site_title: China approves more scrap metal import quotas as new system slips
summary: China has approved new scrap metal import quotas, exceeding previous concerns of a shortage. The country has awarded 176,746 tonnes of high-grade copper scrap, 209,660 tonnes of aluminium scrap, and 4,990 tonnes of steel scrap imports in 2020. The move comes after the implementation of a new system for importing high-quality scrap material was delayed. This decision brings total approved import quotas for the year to 718,500 tonnes of copper scrap, 693,659 tonnes of aluminium scrap, and 16,530 tonnes of steel scrap.

site_title: China censors Hong Kong Internet, US tech giants resist
summary: China has rapidly censored Hong Kong's internet and accessed users' data under its new national security law, prompting resistance from US tech giants. The law, imposed last week, allows police to conduct warrantless raids and surveillance, and grants them expanded powers to control online information. Facebook, Google, and Twitter have put a hold on requests for user information, citing human rights concerns. The move is seen as a significant erosion of Hong Kong's freedoms and rights, with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo labeling it "Orwellian" and a threat to the city's "free thinking and free speech".

site_title: AGV Group rights issue 53.4% subscribed, raises net proceeds of S$5.1m
summary: AGV Group, a Catalist-listed company, successfully raised net proceeds of S$5.1 million from its rights issue, with 53.4% of the total 929.7 million rights shares subscribed. The company plans to use 41.9% of the net proceeds for general working capital and 58.1% for working capital and capital expenditure in Malaysia. Executive chairman Chua Wei Kee, who holds 29.95% of the enlarged issue share capital, will have 184.8 million rights shares after scaling down his application.

site_title: 6.6-magnitude quake strikes off Indonesia: USGS
summary: A 6.6-magnitude earthquake struck off Indonesia's Java island, with a low likelihood of casualties and damage. The quake, at a depth of over 500km, occurred 100km off the city of Batang. Indonesia is prone to seismic activity due to its location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire". This is the latest in a series of significant quakes in the region, following a 7.5-magnitude quake and tsunami in 2018 that killed over 4,300 people.

site_title: Global LNG projects jeopardised by climate concerns, pandemic delays: report
summary: LNG projects worldwide are facing significant delays and investment risks due to climate concerns, public protests, and pandemic-related disruptions. At least 20 of 45 major LNG export projects are now at risk of being delayed, with a potential capital outlay reduction of $292 billion. This shift marks a stark change from investors' previously optimistic outlook, with the European Investment Bank's vice president stating that investing in LNG assets is economically unsound. The pace of LNG terminal development has been pushed back by at least 18 months, raising concerns about the industry's impact on climate goals.

site_title: Chinese students take college exam after virus delay
summary: Nearly 11 million Chinese students took the country's annual college entrance exam, known as the "gaokao," on Tuesday, after a month-long delay due to the coronavirus. The two-day test, which is a source of great anxiety for students and parents, features inspectors checking for cheaters and students with fevers or coughs. To mitigate the risk of COVID-19 transmission, students and invigilators tracked their health for 14 days prior to the exam, and students from high-risk areas wore masks during the tests.

site_title: 'Race against time' in Japan floods, 50 feared dead
summary: Devastating floods and landslides in western Japan have killed at least 50 people, with 49 confirmed dead and one feared dead, as emergency services scramble to rescue those stranded. The floods, which began on Saturday, have destroyed homes and infrastructure, with rivers overflowing and roads turning into lakes, making rescue efforts challenging. The death toll is expected to rise, and rescue workers are racing against time to save those trapped, while also navigating the risk of spreading the coronavirus.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after 3-day winning streak
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, marking a three-day losing streak, as investors cashed in on recent gains. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.32% to 22,641.22, while the Topix index dropped 0.31% to 1,572.25. The decline follows a three-day winning streak, with investors lacking fresh buying incentives.

site_title: Nissan secures 832.6b yen from creditors since April: filing
summary: Nissan Motor secured 832.6 billion yen (S$10.78 billion) in financing from creditors since April to shore up its cash position amid falling sales due to the coronavirus pandemic. The company, Japan's No. 2 automaker, posted its first annual loss in 11 years, citing a tarnished image and deteriorating cash position. Under new CEO Makoto Uchida, Nissan aims to cut 300 billion yen from fixed costs over four years. The company has 1.10 trillion yen in net cash and credit lines of up to 1.30 trillion yen.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 9.41 points to 1,586.31. The gain was driven by a 0.60% increase in trading volume, with 338.69 million lots traded worth RM122.99 million. Gainers outpaced losers 322 to 61.

site_title: TikTok says it will exit Hong Kong market within days
summary: TikTok announced it will exit the Hong Kong market within days due to China's establishment of a new national security law. The decision follows other tech companies, including Facebook, suspending data requests in the region. TikTok's decision comes amid a decline in the app's popularity in the semi-autonomous city. The company has stated its user data is not stored in China, and the move is seen as a response to the new security law.

site_title: Japan's household spending slumps by record as curbs hit travel, dining out
summary: Japan's household spending plummeted 16.2% in May, the largest decline on record, due to government-imposed curbs on travel and dining out to combat the coronavirus pandemic. This sharp drop adds to economic pressure on policymakers to boost confidence among businesses and consumers. The decline marks the fastest pace since comparable data began in 2001, further deepening Japan's economic decline.

site_title: SoftBank's shares return to dot-com bubble era highs
summary: SoftBank Group Corp shares rose 3% to reach 6,100 yen, a level last seen in 2000 during the dot-com bubble, after massive buybacks helped narrow the group's discount. The rebound comes after CEO Masayoshi Son pledged to spend up to 2.5 trillion yen on buybacks. SoftBank's Vision Fund reported a 1.9 trillion yen operating shortfall, but analysts expect a rebound in valuation gains in the April-June quarter. The fund's portfolio has been impacted by the coronavirus outbreak, but progress in monetizing core assets like Alibaba Group Holding may help stabilize its balance sheet.

site_title: No doorman? No problem. Covid-19 changes NYC's real estate rules
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has altered NYC's real estate rules, with potential homebuyers increasingly viewing doormen as a liability due to social distancing concerns. Ground-floor apartments, previously shunned for street noise, are gaining favor for their escape from elevators and lobbies. Outdoor space, laundry, and proximity to affordable neighborhoods are also top priorities. Sellers are capitalizing on the shift, with some securing offers for properties with outdoor spaces despite not being seen in person.

site_title: An end to Australia's apartment binge looms over jobs, growth
summary: Australia's apartment building boom, which fueled the country's population growth and economic prosperity, is expected to end due to the closure of international borders. The decline in construction, which accounts for 10% of jobs and economic activity, is set to push unemployment higher and hurt businesses. With vacancy rates rising, especially in Sydney, economists predict a significant drop in construction starts, including high-rise apartments, and a potential contraction in the construction industry.

images.alt_text: A heavy decline in construction, which accounts for roughly 10 per cent of all jobs and economic activity, is set to push unemployment higher and hurt businesses both up and downstream.

site_title: Google couldn't help this Chinese games startup beat Tencent
summary: Chinese game-streaming platform Chushou TV has shut down after receiving $120 million in investment from Google in 2018. The company, which had 8 million unique streamers and 90 million registered users, was struggling to compete with Tencent Holdings Ltd, which dominates the market. Chushou's demise highlights Tencent's supremacy in China's game-streaming market, which is expected to generate $4.74 billion in revenue by the end of this year. The company had asked streamers to switch to Tencent-backed Kuaishou, but failed to pay virtual-gifting revenue to streamers, leading to a lawsuit and court-ordered asset freeze.

site_title: China's Sinovac starts late stage trials for its Covid-19 vaccine
summary: China's Sinovac Biotech has started Phase III trials of its potential Covid-19 vaccine in Brazil, joining AstraZeneca and Sinopharm in late-stage trials. The study, in partnership with the Instituto Butantan, will recruit nearly 9,000 healthcare professionals and begin this month. Sinovac's vaccine candidate is one of 19 in clinical evaluation, according to the World Health Organization, with no vaccine yet approved for commercial use.

site_title: Singapore stocks advance at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.5% to 2,703.13 points, driven by gains in 107 stocks to 28 losers. A total of 191.5 million securities worth S$100.2 million changed hands. The rally follows a 5-day advance ahead of GDP data and despite US tariff uncertainty.

site_title: New York luxury condo developer tries hand at Reit investing
summary: A New York luxury condo developer, Ziel Feldman's HFZ Capital Group, has launched a real estate investment trust (REIT) fund to invest in undervalued companies. The $50 million fund, aiming to raise $500 million, has already bought stakes in Vornado Realty Trust and Ventas Inc. These companies' shares have declined since March due to the pandemic. HFZ's venture seeks to capitalize on the market's recovery and provide institutional investors with a more stable alternative to direct property investments.

images.alt_text: A developer of some of Manhattan's newest ultra-luxury condos has started a more down-to-earth project: a fund investing in real estate companies that appear undervalued.

site_title: Philippine inflation quickens in June as coronavirus lockdown eased
summary: Philippine inflation increased 2.5% in June, surpassing the central bank's forecast range of 1.9-2.7% and the median estimate of 2.2%. This rate is near the upper end of the 2-4% target. Core inflation, excluding food and fuel prices, rose to 3%. Despite easing lockdown restrictions, economists expect sluggish domestic consumption in the second half, keeping price pressures in check. The central bank expects inflation to average 2.3% this year and 2.6% in 2021.

site_title: Facebook, Google, Twitter pause user info requests from HK government
summary: Facebook, Google, and Twitter have paused requests from Hong Kong's government and police for user information, following China's imposition of a new national security law. The pause will remain in place pending further assessment and includes human rights due diligence and consultations with experts. The companies believe freedom of expression is a fundamental human right and will protect users' safety. Twitter and Google have also expressed grave concerns about the law and its full intention.

images.alt_text: Facebook, Google and Twitter said Monday they have put a hold on requests by Hong Kong's government or police force for information on users, following China's imposition of a sweeping new security law.

site_title: GS Holdings proposes to dispose of cleaning and dishwashing business
summary: GS Holdings has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to dispose of its cleaning and dishwashing business through its wholly-owned subsidiary GreatSolutions. The disposal, valued at S$2, is in line with the group's plan to divest non-profitable businesses. GS Cleaning Services and GS Equipment Supply, which have been non-profitable since 2016, will be sold, allowing the group to focus on its food and beverage business and branding operations. The proposed disposal is expected to have minimal financial impact on GS Holdings.

site_title: US charges sons of ex-Panama president with bribery, money laundering
summary: US prosecutors have charged two sons of former Panamanian President Ricardo Martinelli with bribery and money laundering in connection with Odebrecht, a Brazilian construction firm. Luis Enrique Martinelli and Ricardo Alberto Martinelli were arrested in Guatemala City. The charges are tied to alleged corruption and money laundering schemes. The sons were accused of receiving bribes and laundering funds from Odebrecht, a company at the center of a major corruption scandal in Latin America.

site_title: Wall Street investors scored emergency government loans amid pandemic
summary: US government loans totaling $12.2 billion were approved to small companies and non-profits during the pandemic, with finance and insurance firms receiving 2.3% of the total lending. Investment firms such as Semper Capital Management, Domini Impact Investments, and Truvvo Wealth Management were among those approved for emergency loans. These firms typically earn fees based on assets under management and profits. The loans were part of the Paycheck Protection Program, which helped businesses classified as investment advisors and portfolio management companies stay afloat during the lockdowns.

site_title: Singapore's Indies Capital raises US$100m for third Asian fund
summary: Indies Capital Partners, a Singapore-based alternative asset manager, has raised over US$100 million for its third flagship fund, Indies Special Opportunities III, focused on structured credit and private equity deals in South-east Asia, particularly Indonesia. Pavilion Capital, a unit of Temasek Holdings, is an anchor investor. The fund aims to capitalize on emerging opportunities post-COVID-19, with co-managing partner Pandu Sjahrir noting the diverse set of opportunities across different sectors. This is part of Indies Capital's efforts to finance promising deals in the region.

site_title: Australia rushing to implement permit system before coronavirus-sparked border closure
summary: Australia is rushing to implement a travel permit system for its heavily trafficked border between New South Wales and Victoria before closing the border due to a coronavirus outbreak in Melbourne. The border, which has not been closed in 100 years, is set to close at 11:59pm on Tuesday. New South Wales is issuing daily permits for residents, but Premier Gladys Berejiklian warned of potential delays and frustration. The closure aims to contain the outbreak, which has led to a surge in cases nationally, with Australia reporting almost 9,000 cases and 106 deaths.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q2 profit likely jumped 23% on solid chip demand, one-off gains
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 23% increase in second-quarter operating profit, beating analyst estimates, driven by solid chip sales to data centers amid the work-from-home economy. Revenue likely fell 7% to 52 trillion won. One-off gains from its display business also contributed to the boost. Analysts warn that increases in memory chip prices may not continue in the second half due to conservative data center customers.

site_title: Kanye West's clothing brand, Hollywood production firms on pandemic loan list
summary: Kanye West's clothing brand Yeezy and several Hollywood production firms, including The Jim Henson Company and Apatow Company, received loans under the US government's Paycheck Protection Programme (PPP) to aid businesses affected by the coronavirus pandemic. Yeezy received a loan of $2-5 million, which will save 160 jobs. Other approved applicants include Francis Ford Coppola's production firm and e-sports company FaZe Clan. Cinema operators like Laemmle Theatres and Regency Theatres also received loans to help them recover from pandemic-related closures.

site_title: Israeli carrier agrees to bailout terms after virus losses
summary: Israeli airline El Al has agreed to a government bailout worth $250 million, which could pave the way for the carrier's renationalisation. The airline, which has been struggling due to losses caused by the novel coronavirus pandemic, had previously laid off 1,000 staff and canceled flights. The government has agreed to absorb any unsold stocks from a planned stock offering. The plan must still be approved by the government and parliament.

site_title: Singapore finds staycations can't fill US$20b tourism hole
summary: Singapore's tourism industry, which generated nearly $20 billion in revenue last year, is struggling due to the border closure and limited domestic options. Hotels and tourist attractions are relying on "staycations" to fill the gap, but experts say it may not be a sustainable solution. Occupancy rates remain low, with some hotels offering discounts and promotions to attract locals. The industry is expected to take time to recover, with a full recovery likely before 2022, depending on the development of a vaccine and countries avoiding additional waves of the virus.

site_title: ARA Logos Logistics Trust's manager names new CEO; Daniel Cerf retiring on Aug 14
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust's manager has announced the retirement of CEO Daniel Cerf on August 14, after nearly 11 years. Karen Lee Kiah Ling will assume the role of CEO from August 15, subject to approval from relevant authorities. Lee has over 20 years of experience in the real estate industry, including her previous role as head of asset and investment for Logos SE Asia. ARA group CEO John Lim praised Cerf's contributions to ALog's growth and expressed confidence in Lee's ability to lead the trust into its next phase of growth.

site_title: Commonwealth should 'acknowledge' past wrongs, says Prince Harry
summary: Prince Harry has urged the Commonwealth to acknowledge its colonial past, following the Black Lives Matter movement. In a video conference call with leaders, Harry emphasized the need for the organization to confront its uncomfortable history. The call was organized by the Queen's Commonwealth Trust in response to the movement. This move comes as the Commonwealth, led by Queen Elizabeth II, faces growing calls to address its legacy of colonialism.

site_title: Good government needed to fight Covid-19, support economy: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for a strong government to navigate the country through the COVID-19 crisis and economic downturn. In a digital rally, he highlighted the PAP's efforts in managing the pandemic and supporting the economy, and urged voters to give the party a strong mandate to ensure continuity and stability. Lee pledged that he and his team will see the crisis through, and that investors will scrutinize the election results, which will determine the country's future direction.

site_title: SIA's Vistara in talks with planemakers, lessors to delay delivery of some aircraft
summary: Indian airline Vistara, owned by Tata Sons and Singapore Airlines, is in talks with planemakers and leasing companies to delay delivery of some aircraft due to low air travel demand caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Vistara had ordered 50 planes, with deliveries set for 2019-2023, but is now pushing back some deliveries due to production delays and commercial concerns. The airline expects to take delivery of at least one Boeing 787 and two other planes this year, with a final decision on deferrals yet to be reached.

site_title: Fuxing China proposes 430.3m yuan sale of Xiamen headquarters
summary: Fuxing China Group, a mainboard-listed company, is proposing the sale of its Xiamen headquarters for approximately 430.3 million yuan (S$84.9 million) in cash. The sale will result in a net loss of about 76.4 million yuan for the group. The company plans to dispose of most of the office space in the building due to weak leasing demand amid the coronavirus pandemic. The sale will allow Fuxing China to realize its current investment value, bolster its working capital, and reduce its gearing ratio, positioning the group for future economic challenges.

site_title: Taking the leap of faith
summary: Robert Yap, a former corporate insider, transitioned to a personal investor with a family office vehicle in 2012. He has since invested in IT and sustainable ventures, reflecting his strengths and convictions. As chairman of Sunseap Group, Yap's investment choices prioritize sustainability, showcasing his unique blend of technical expertise and values-driven approach to finance.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence remains low in Q2: NZIER survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence improved slightly in the June quarter, with 63% of firms expecting general business conditions to deteriorate, down from 70% in the previous quarter. Seasonally adjusted data showed business confidence at 59%, down from 68% in the previous quarter. Capacity utilisation remained at 92.8%, a slight increase from the previous quarter. Despite the slight improvement, businesses remain pessimistic about the coming months, reflecting the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and economic uncertainty.

site_title: New security law starts to break down Hong Kong's pro-democracy economy
summary: A new national security law in Hong Kong has led to a decline in pro-democracy businesses, with many removing protest-themed products and decorations from their shops. Ivan Ng, owner of Onestep Printing, said his sales are down 80% after removing protest-related items. Other businesses, such as Hair Guys Salon and Talk 2 DeCream, have also taken down pro-democracy decorations to avoid potential penalties. The law, which prohibits secession, subversion, and collusion with foreign forces, has been criticized for eroding Hong Kong's autonomy and freedom.

site_title: Down to handful of active rigs, Canada's oil and gas drillers face permanent contraction
summary: Canada's oil and gas drilling rig count has plummeted to 18 active rigs, a fraction of previous records, due to declining demand and costly equipment recertifications. The industry's fleet is expected to shrink 25% in the next year, with companies opting against recertifications. This permanent contraction raises concerns about equipment falling out of service, impacting Canada's oil production.

site_title: US says foreign students whose classes move online cannot stay
summary: The US has announced that foreign students whose classes move online due to the coronavirus crisis cannot stay in the country. According to US Immigration and Custom Enforcement, nonimmigrant F-1 and M-1 students attending schools with entirely online instruction must either depart the US or transfer to a school with in-person instruction to remain in lawful status. This policy change applies to the fall semester.

images.alt_text: The United States said Monday it would not allow foreign students to remain in the country if all of their classes are moved online in the fall because of the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yanlord Land, Hi-P, ARA Logos Logistics Trust, United Hampshire US Reit
summary: Stocks to watch include Yanlord Land, which saw a 65% increase in contracted pre-sales in the first half of the year, and Hi-P International, whose shares surged 15.9% on Monday. Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust announced a new board member, while ARA Logos Logistics Trust's CEO is retiring on August 14. United Hampshire US Reit collected 80% of base rents in June. Other stocks to watch include SIA, which is participating in UK-Singapore travel trials, and Boustead Projects, whose net profit remained steady in the half-year ended March 31.

site_title: Fewer medical graduates from Muslim countries entering US in Trump-era
summary: US sees a 15% decline in foreign medical graduates from Muslim-majority countries entering the country to become doctors, exacerbating physician workforce shortages. These graduates, who represent about a quarter of practicing US doctors, declined from 4,244 in 2009-2015 to 3,604 in 2018. Recent US policies, including a travel ban, may be contributing to this decline, potentially affecting certification and residency programs. The US faces a shortage of up to 122,000 doctors by 2032, with gaps in the workforce widening if these graduates choose alternative destinations.

images.alt_text: The number of foreign medical graduates from Muslim-majority countries coming to the US to become doctors has declined by 15 per cent under the Trump administration, exacerbating shortages in America's physician workforce, a study said on Monday.

site_title: Oil steady as hopeful economic data face spike in virus cases
summary: Oil prices ended steady on Monday, with Brent crude settling at $43.10 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $40.63 a barrel. Positive economic data supported prices, but a spike in US coronavirus cases could curb fuel demand. Analysts say the market is balancing reopening economies with concerns over virus cases.

site_title: Investment banks got aid intended for US small businesses
summary: Tens of millions of dollars in US aid for small businesses during the coronavirus pandemic went to investment banks instead, according to official data. Investment banks such as Broadhaven Capital Partners, Union Square Advisors, and North Point Advisors received loans between $350,000 and $5 million, with some retaining jobs. The loans were part of the Paycheck Protection Programme, which is forgivable if companies restore pre-pandemic employment levels. The move has raised questions about the effectiveness of the program and how it was administered.

site_title: UK to ease property tax liabilities, cut VAT in hospitality sector temporarily
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak plans to raise the property tax threshold to £500,000 and temporarily cut VAT in the hospitality sector to kickstart the economy. This includes exempting most homebuyers from paying stamp duty for a temporary period, potentially up to a year. The measures aim to protect 2.4 million jobs in the hospitality sector and support Britain's economy, which contracted by 20% in April due to the Covid-19 lockdown.

site_title: Singapore's startup ecosystem is braving its first crisis
summary: Singapore's startup ecosystem is facing its first crisis, with the COVID-19 pandemic forcing many young companies to struggle with cash flow and business disruptions. However, the community has responded agilely, with many startups adapting their business models to stay afloat, exploring new opportunities, and prioritizing social responsibility. Examples include Chope Group's food delivery service and fintech firm MatchMove's migrant worker remittance solution. Community initiatives, such as Mentor for Hope and Action Community for Entrepreneurship, have also emerged to provide support and resources to affected startups. Despite the challenges, Singapore's startup ecosystem has demonstrated resilience and a strong collaborative spirit.

images.alt_text: Anu Gupta, director of startups and global markets at Asia PR Werkz.

site_title: Covid-19 proposals include independent inquiry and medical board: WP
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has proposed seven measures to address the Covid-19 pandemic, including an independent commission of inquiry, medical board, and vaccination for all residents. The proposals are also outlined in the party's GE2020 manifesto. In response to PM Lee's criticism, the Progress Singapore Party (PSP) chief Tan Cheng Bock disagrees, saying the PAP has been treating symptoms instead of managing the disease.

site_title: Europe: China recovery hopes, upbeat data lift shares; HSBC leads
summary: European shares rose 1.6% on Monday, their highest in nearly a month, driven by upbeat economic data and a rally in China's markets, boosting hopes for recovery. HSBC led gains, with Asia-focused lenders and stocks exposed to China also rising. The Stoxx 600 index, a pan-European benchmark, surged 4% higher, as investors welcomed positive economic indicators and a potential end to coronavirus-induced slumps.

site_title: Springleaf Tower's level 22 office floor up for sale with guide price of over S$26m
summary: A level 22 office floor in Springleaf Tower, a Grade A strata office development in Singapore's central business district, is up for sale via expression of interest with a guide price of over S$26 million. The 10,527 square foot office floor offers exclusive use of the lift lobby, pantry, and restrooms and is one of the few strata office developments with Grade A specifications. The sale comes at a time of high demand for premium-grade office space in the CBD, particularly with the planned Greater Southern Waterfront development nearby.

site_title: Britain headed for double whammy of spike in virus cases and no-deal Brexit
summary: Britain is at risk of experiencing a "perfect storm" this Autumn, with a potential spike in coronavirus cases and a no-deal Brexit. Despite the UK's latest lockdown lifting, the economy is in its worst downturn in 300 years, and Prime Minister Boris Johnson is under pressure to secure a Brexit deal. EU-UK negotiations have broken up, with significant differences remaining, and Johnson is scaling down expectations of a breakthrough, aiming for a "bare-bones" trade deal that strips out fundamental areas.

site_title: Maybank KE positive on Malaysia's 4D operators
summary: Maybank KE maintains "buy" calls on Malaysia's 4D operators Magnum and Berjaya Sports Toto, citing positive outlook. Magnum's target price is set at RM2.51, up from RM2.25. The analysts expect the companies to perform well in the market, driven by their strong track record and growth potential.

site_title: With US department stores vanishing, malls could be next
summary: US department stores are disappearing, leaving malls vulnerable to redevelopment. JC Penney's bankruptcy and Sears' previous filing for bankruptcy have contributed to the decline. Analysts predict 25% of the country's nearly 1,200 malls will close in the next five years, reshaping suburban communities. Malls may be repurposed as local markets, office space, or affordable housing. Department stores account for 30% of mall square footage, with 10% coming from Sears and JC Penney. Many malls face financial struggles, with some skipping interest payments and exploring alternative strategies.

site_title: India caseload surges as experts warn of virus going airborne
summary: India has become the country with the third-highest coronavirus caseload, surpassing Russia, with nearly 700,000 cases reported. Experts warn that the virus can spread through the air, not just through close contact, and recommend measures such as installing air filters and preventing overcrowding. The US is struggling to cope with a surge in infections, with hospitals in Texas and other states nearing capacity. Global infections have surged past 11.5 million, with over 535,000 deaths, and many countries are balancing the need to reopen economies with the risk of new infections.

images.alt_text: India on Monday became the country with the third-highest coronavirus caseload in the world, as a group of scientists said there was now overwhelming evidence that the disease can be airborne - and for far longer than originally thought.

site_title: Political broadcasts move few but are not without benefits
summary: Singapore's constituency political broadcasts, which aired daily on TV, radio, and online from July 3 to July 8, proved to be a distant substitute for physical rallies, lacking key traits. Introduced as a special provision for the General Election during the Covid-19 pandemic, the broadcasts gave national airtime to candidates for each of the 31 constituencies. While they may have some benefits, they appear to do little to engage the public or promote meaningful interaction between candidates and voters. The broadcasts were seen as a substitute, but not a replacement, for the real experience of physical rallies.

site_title: Carro driving digital push for automobile sector
summary: Singapore's automobile industry is adapting to the digital age, with companies like Carro and Carousell launching contactless car purchase services to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Carro's service allows buyers to purchase pre-owned vehicles without face-to-face interaction, while Carousell has introduced a digital showroom experience to simulate in-person viewings. However, some industry experts, such as Motorist's CEO Damian Sia, believe that traditional dealership models are still necessary for building trust and ensuring customer satisfaction. As the industry continues to evolve, it remains to be seen whether digitalization will become the norm for car sales in Singapore.

site_title: Buy-now-pay-later firms benefit as lockdowns lift online shopping
summary: Buy-now-pay-later firms have benefited from the shift to online shopping during the coronavirus crisis, with swelling subscriber numbers and retailers partnering with the companies. However, as lockdowns lift and government aid ebbs, the business model will face its first real test in a recession. The firms charge merchants a 4-6% commission and make their money by charging interest-free instalments, but rising costs and credit losses may make them unprofitable for some time. Young people with stimulus money in their wallets are driving sales, with most BNPL shoppers under 35.

site_title: Australia's extra spending on security could come with unintended costs
summary: Australia's 2020 Defence Strategy Update plans to spend A$270 billion over 10 years on anti-ship missiles, cyber capabilities, and high-tech surveillance systems, amid an "existential threat" from China and other regional powers. The strategy aims to counter China's military modernisation and territorial claims in the South China Sea. However, experts warn that acquiring anti-ship missiles may not provide a significant deterrent, as other regional powers possess nuclear or conventional capabilities to strike major Australian cities. The plan also raises concerns about regional stability and the potential impact on Indonesia and other countries in the region.

site_title: Playing Beethoven's piano sonatas changed how I hear them
summary: A young pianist's senior recital featured a challenging Beethoven Opus 110, which the author now relishes for its complexity and mystique. The sonata's multi-movement, episodic structure and challenges were unprecedented for its time, and Beethoven believed that difficulties were also beautiful and good. Recent recordings, including a nine-disc survey by Igor Levit, showcase younger pianists cutting through the "masterpiece" trappings and making personal statements. Levit's approach brings out the wildness and intensity of the sonatas, with a visceral feeling for drama and clarity. His tempos are sometimes fast, but his playing is uncannily clear and alive.

site_title: Oil edges higher as traders weigh supply against virus impact
summary: Oil prices rose 1.1% to trade above $43 a barrel, driven by tightening crude supplies and robust US economic data, but concerns over surging coronavirus infections and potential lockdowns kept gains in check. Libya's oil exports are expected to fall this month due to blockages, while the US labor market rebounded in June. Opec+ is yet to decide on extending production cutbacks, with some analysts predicting that oil prices may have peaked for now.

site_title: Fujitsu to cut its office space in Japan by 50 per cent
summary: Fujitsu, Japan's 17th largest publicly traded employer, will cut its office space by 50% over three years, shifting 80,000 office workers to primarily work from home. The plan includes a 5,000 yen monthly stipend for home office setup and "hot-desking" in existing offices. This move is seen as a sign for Japan's office sector, with Tokyo office vacancies rising to 1.64% in May and a falling job-to-applicant ratio.

site_title: Hi-P climbs 16.8%, receives SGX query
summary: Shares of Hi-P International rose 16.8% on Monday, reaching S$1.25, after the Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried the "unusual price movements" of the mainboard-listed stock. The stock traded heavily with 12.2 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Singapore's global schoolhouse upbeat beyond short term
summary: Singapore's global schoolhouse, which had been gaining momentum, is expected to take a hit from the coronavirus pandemic's travel restrictions. Private-sector schools, particularly in the higher education sector, are likely to experience a decline in enrolments. This setback is attributed to the widespread travel curbs in place, hindering international student recruitment.

site_title: Hyflux's potential investors must disclose more
summary: Hyflux, a Singaporean water treatment company, is struggling to avoid liquidation after rescue talks with an Indonesian consortium broke down in April last year. The company owes S$900 million to 34,000 retail investors, and its restructuring process is entering a tense final leg. A debt moratorium has been granted, but the company's progress will depend on its ability to show concrete progress at its next court date. A special purpose vehicle, Aqua Munda, has offered to pay cash for Hyflux's senior debt at a minimum discount of 85%, but no offer has been made to junior creditors.

site_title: Staycation reopening a plus for hospitality S-Reits: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded its stance on hospitality S-Reits, including Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) and CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT), citing the reopening of hotels for staycations in Singapore as a positive factor. The research team believes FEHT and CDLHT, with significant exposure in Singapore, will benefit from the trend, particularly Sentosa hotels. DBS has a "buy" call on CDLHT and FEHT, with target prices of S$1.30 and S$0.60 respectively.

site_title: CapitaLand expects H1 operating patmi to fall 25-35 per cent
summary: CapitaLand expects its 1H net profit to be "materially and adversely" affected, with operating profit declining 25-35% and cash profit falling 40-50% from the previous year. The company will value properties annually in December, excluding revaluation gains or losses, but will still recognize share of revaluation gains or losses from listed investments. This guidance follows the announcement of further rent waivers for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Fighting Covid-19 with local innovations
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are developing innovative solutions to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. Gill Lab has created a reusable respirator that can extend the use of surgical masks by up to six times, while Star Array has developed a superfast genetic analyser that can complete Covid-19 tests in as little as eight minutes. Lion TCR is working on a potential treatment involving T-cell receptors that can confer longer-term immunity.
