These companies are leveraging the country's medical technology sector, which is supported by the JTC MedTech Hub, to bring their innovations to market and aid in the fight against Covid-19.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit collected 80% of base rents from retail tenants in June
summary: United Hampshire US Reit reported collecting around 80% of base rents from retail tenants in June, with 91% of its total base rental income coming from open tenants. This follows 77% in May and 82% in April. The Reit's properties in New York and surrounding areas are seeing a decline in Covid-19 cases, and 70% of tenants closed in April have reopened. The company is also exploring potential lease extensions and is assessing the financial impact of rental relief.

site_title: China accuses Britain of 'gross interference' over Hong Kong
summary: China's ambassador to London accused Britain of "gross interference" over the imposition of new security legislation in Hong Kong, which he claimed could damage future Chinese investment. Britain described the law as a "clear and serious" violation of the 1984 Joint Declaration, which led to Hong Kong's handover to China. The ambassador warned of "consequences" for treating Beijing and Huawei with suspicion, amid rising tensions between the two nations.

site_title: UK set to phase out Huawei from its 5G network, says FT report
summary: The UK is set to phase out Huawei's equipment from its 5G network, citing "very, very serious" spying concerns, according to a Financial Times report. The decision is expected this month and comes amid pressure from the US to cut ties with the Chinese technology giant. The UK government is also considering alternative vendors, including Samsung and NEC, following US sanctions that could cripple Huawei's production of 5G chips. The move would mark a U-turn from January's decision to allow Huawei to participate in the UK's 5G build-out subject to strict conditions.

images.alt_text: The FT says Mr Johnson is drawing up plans to remove the Huawei technology from Britain's 5G network after warnings that the US sanctions could curtail the company's access to American semiconductors and force it to use riskier supplies.

site_title: STI posts 5-day winning streak on string of upbeat macro data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) posted a 5-day winning streak, rising 36.7 points or 1.4% to 2,689.61, driven by upbeat macro data and a renewed feel-good factor. Analysts warn that the rally is driven by liquidity and risk aversion, which could lead to a sharp correction if fundamentals fail to catch up. Hospitality Reits and electronics contract manufacturer Hi-P International led the gains, with hotel reopenings and significant share price movements contributing to the rally.

site_title: Clock ticks on greener homes as UK seeks jobs, emissions cuts
summary: The UK needs to retrofit 29 million homes to use less fossil-fuel energy by 2050 to meet its net-zero climate-changing emissions goal. Britain must upgrade almost two homes a minute, a challenge from persuading landlords and altering historic homes. Retrofitting homes could bring new jobs and progress towards climate goals, with potential payoffs including reduced emissions, fuel poverty, and inequality. A government-backed green programme was shut down in 2013 due to lack of energy savings, and experts recommend reviving interest and training more people to do the work.

site_title: Turkey bans six global banks from bets against nation's stocks
summary: Turkey has banned six global banks, including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, from betting against the nation's stocks for up to three months. The ban, announced by Borsa Istanbul, aims to protect the country's stock market from short-selling. The move appears to contradict recent efforts to ease restrictions on such activities. The affected banks will be barred from short-selling stocks from July 13, 2020, until October 13, 2020.

site_title: Yanlord records 29.8b yuan in property pre-sales
summary: Chinese property developer Yanlord Land Group reported 29.8 billion yuan (S$6 billion) in total contracted pre-sales in the first half of the year, a 65% increase from the previous year. This translates to a 30.7% increase in contracted gross floor area to 831,457 square meters. The majority of pre-sales came from five Chinese cities, accounting for nearly 84% of the total. As of June 30, Yanlord had 4.0 billion yuan of subscription sales, expected to be converted into contracted pre-sales in subsequent months.

site_title: Why super rich fashionistas are not crying for Paris shows
summary: The Paris fashion shows were cancelled due to the coronavirus, but a select group of super-rich women, who buy handmade, expensive haute couture creations, are not upset. Instead, they expect personalized presentations in their palaces and penthouses. Designers like Julien Fournie are now focusing on pampering clients with exclusive, one-off pieces made to measure. These clients prioritize exclusivity and uniqueness, and designers cater to their needs, creating custom looks that are tailored to their individual style and preferences.

site_title: Indonesia unveils 574.59t rupiah bond scheme to fund recovery
summary: Indonesia's central bank agreed to buy 574.59 trillion rupiah (S$55 billion) of low-yielding government bonds to fund the economic recovery program. The bond-buying program will help finance the 2020 fiscal deficit, which is forecast to reach 6.34% of GDP, and will be used to support recovery schemes for businesses. The policy aims to invoke confidence in the economic recovery and healthcare response. The bond scheme is a one-off policy and will be fully borne by the central bank, with minimal impact on inflation.

site_title: AMTD Digital eyes controlling stake in Singapore fintech FOMO Pay
summary: AMTD Digital is set to acquire a controlling stake in Singapore-based fintech FOMO Pay, its third acquisition in the country's fintech industry, following PolicyPal and CapBridge in June. The deal will allow FOMO Pay to become a key member of AMTD Digital's SpiderNet ecosystem, enhancing the latter's fintech platform across South-east Asia. FOMO Pay's payment function will add to AMTD Digital's digital financial services, promoting cashless payments and financial inclusion in the region.

site_title: Credibility of US' global power being challenged
summary: The US' credibility as a global power is being challenged due to a public-health disaster, economic crisis, and growing political unrest. The nation's ability to fulfill its military and diplomatic commitments, once seen as reliable, is now in question. The collapse of the Soviet Union led to a perceived status of a global strategic hegemon, but subsequent events, including the 9/11 attacks, the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and the global financial crisis, have tarnished the image of America. The election of President Donald Trump has further eroded trust, with his withdrawal from international treaties and multilateral organisations, and his handling of the pandemic, raising concerns among US allies about their ability to rely on the US for defense.

site_title: Channelling capital towards sustainable investments
summary: Wealth managers are channeling capital towards sustainable investments to address environmental and social issues, as investors seek to minimize risks and meet consumer demand for sustainable solutions. UBS has committed $5 billion to impact investments and manages $488 billion in core sustainable investments, with a 20% share of all Asia-Pacific mandates. Sustainability is a growing focus among Asian clients, who are seeking investments that generate returns comparable to traditional investments while also promoting social and environmental impact.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Oyo Hotels slashing footprint, headcount in virus-hit Japan
summary: OYO Hotels, a SoftBank-backed startup, is significantly reducing its presence in Japan due to the novel coronavirus. The company closed offices in Sapporo, Sendai, Nagano, Hiroshima, and Omiya, slashing its regional footprint and headcount. This move comes as bookings in Japan plummet due to travel restrictions. OYO Hotels will also downsize its Tokyo offices. The decision reflects the challenges faced by the hospitality industry in Japan during the pandemic.

site_title: China waves the green flag for yuan bulls
summary: China's yuan surged against the dollar, reaching its highest levels since March 18, as investors bet on a strong economic rebound. The yuan's rise supported other commodity currencies, including the euro and Australian dollar, while the dollar fell to its lowest level since July 2 against a basket of currencies. The US economy's growth prospects were downgraded, with Goldman Sachs revising its projections to a 4.6% contraction in 2020. The strong Chinese economic outlook also boosted risk appetite, leading to a "Risk On, Dollar Off" trend.

site_title: WHO reviewing NYT article on concerns over airborne spread of Covid-19
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is reviewing a report suggesting its advice on the novel coronavirus needs updating, citing evidence that the virus could be spread by airborne particles. 239 scientists from 32 countries wrote an open letter to the WHO, urging an update to its guidance due to the lingering nature of smaller exhaled particles in the air. The WHO initially stated that Covid-19 spreads primarily through small droplets, but the scientists argue that airborne transmission is possible.

site_title: US Big Tech builds appetite for startup pie in South-east Asia
summary: US tech giants, including Google, Facebook, and Visa, are investing heavily in South-east Asian startups, with a focus on e-commerce and fintech opportunities. The investments aim to tap into the region's growing internet economy and favourable demographics. Unlike Chinese tech firms, which have historically taken a more aggressive buy-and-build strategy, US firms prefer to partner or build in the region. This shift may lead to a "proxy war" between the two tech giants, with US firms seeking to gain exposure to emerging markets and Chinese firms looking to expand their presence.

site_title: Planting the seeds of 'Smart Farming'
summary: Agrimax Ventures, a company founded by Ankesh Shahra, aims to address inefficiencies in global agriculture through technology, promoting "smart farming." The global agriculture sector faces significant challenges, including a 50% increase in demand by 2050, while natural resources are becoming increasingly stressed due to climate change. Shahra's company seeks to overcome these hurdles by leveraging technology to increase food production while preserving small-scale and family farmers' livelihoods. Agrimax Ventures' ambitious vision is to catalyze the next green revolution.

site_title: HK schools should not provide material against new law: govt
summary: The Hong Kong Education Bureau advises schools not to provide reading material that violates the new national security law, unless it's used to "positively teach" students about the issue. The law, imposed by Beijing, carries penalties of up to life in prison for crimes defined as secession, subversion, terrorism, and collusion with foreign forces.

site_title: Singapore universities make 2,000 extra undergrad offers amid pandemic
summary: Singapore's Education Ministry has announced that 2,000 extra undergraduate offers will be made to local students whose overseas study plans were disrupted by the pandemic. This move is expected to boost the autonomous university cohort participation rate from 40% to 42%. The ministry also plans to review bids from Singaporeans who had studied abroad but want to transfer to local universities. Meanwhile, students who plan to resume overseas studies can still apply for short modular courses or semester programs at local universities.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Vallianz Holdings will defer a distribution to perpetual securities holders due to a US$22.5 million debt-issuance programme. Ascendas Reit's BEH Swan Gin joined the board as chairman, replacing Lim Hock San. Boustead Projects maintained steady net profit of S$12.6 million, with revenue jumping 93% to S$269.5 million. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Profit figures in income statements don't tell the whole story
summary: A study found that companies' reported profit figures may not accurately reflect wealth creation for shareholders due to the omission of "cost of equity financing" in accounting standards. By deducting this cost from reported profits, "profit after cost of equity financing" provides a more accurate measure of wealth creation. The study applied this concept to Straits Times Index companies and found that many reported profits but did not create wealth for shareholders, with wealth creation amounts significantly lower than reported profits.

site_title: Create better tax policies to cut cost of rescue packages
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has left the world economy severely strained, with governments launching large-scale stimulus measures, but tax revenues plummeting and unemployment skyrocketing. To revive demand and stimulate growth, governments should focus on boosting corporate tax revenues by introducing progressive tax systems and floors under tax rates. Introducing a 25% effective minimum tax rate on multinationals' global profits and progressive digital-service taxes can help curb tax avoidance and ensure those who have avoided paying their fair share contribute more.

site_title: Sustainability in the spotlight
summary: Sustainability is becoming a top priority among governments, industry groups, and investors, particularly in Asia-Pacific. A survey by the CFA Institute found 39% of retail investors in Singapore are "very interested" in ESG investing, with two-thirds willing to sacrifice returns. Evidence suggests that sustainable investments can maintain returns, even during the Covid-19 crisis. Several profiles highlight individuals and institutions incorporating sustainability into their portfolios, emphasizing the need for private capital support and awareness of ESG efforts.

site_title: China stokes stock-market mania, risking repeat of 2015 bubble
summary: China's stock market has surged 14% in five days, mirroring the 2014 bubble that burst, due to low interest rates, state media promotion, and increasing participation from retail investors. Daily turnover has exceeded 1 trillion yuan, with the CSI 300 Index reaching a five-year high. Regulators have unveiled measures to boost trading, but caution against another boom-bust, citing the harm to confidence from previous market crashes.

images.alt_text: The CSI 300 is up 14 per cent this year, one of the biggest gains among major global benchmarks, to trade at a five-year high, while the Shanghai Composite Index closed 5.7 per cent higher Monday, with 17 stocks gaining for every one that declined.

site_title: Disney+ downloads climb following debut of 'Hamilton' online
summary: Disney+ downloads surged after the July 3 premiere of 'Hamilton', with 513,323 new mobile downloads worldwide, including 266,084 in the US, over the weekend. This represents a 47% increase from the average weekend in June and a 72% increase in the US. The service's success highlights the demand for exclusive content, with the filmed musical paying $75 million for the production.

site_title: Starburst bags S$13.1m contract to upgrade tactical training facility
summary: Starburst Holdings, a CATALIST-listed company specializing in firearms training facilities, has been awarded a S$13.1 million contract to upgrade a tactical training mock-up facility in South-east Asia. The contract, expected to be completed by July 2021, is part of a larger trend of rising demand for military equipment and facilities globally, driven by increased security concerns. This contract is also expected to positively impact Starburst's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the 2020 financial year.

site_title: Entrenching sustainability trends
summary: Experts discuss the long-term prospects of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) investments. Garth Bregman, Head of Investment Services at BNP Paribas Wealth Management, notes that sustainability trends are here to stay, driven by growing consumer awareness and regulatory pressures. He believes investors will continue to prioritize ESG factors, potentially leading to increased investment in sustainable assets. The consensus is that ESG is no longer a niche area but a mainstream consideration for investors, shaping the future of the financial industry. This shift is expected to persist even as markets evolve.

site_title: Weibo-owner Sina gets buyout bid at 12% premium from CEO-led company
summary: Sina Corp, the owner of Weibo, received a go-private offer of US$41 per share in cash from a holding company led by CEO Charles Chao, valuing the company at about US$2.7 billion. The offer represents a 12% premium over the stock's closing price. New Wave, controlled by Chao, already owns 12.15% of Sina's shares.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore Stocks: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for H2. The US stock market opened lower after the US imposed fresh tariffs on Canada. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation on green and transition finance.

site_title: Indonesia's Lion Air slashes 2,600 jobs as virus bites
summary: Indonesia's Lion Air Group is slashing 2,600 jobs, about 9% of its 29,000 employees, due to the coronavirus pandemic. The layoffs mainly affect contract workers, following earlier salary reductions for management and staff.

site_title: US services sector rebounds strongly in June
summary: The US services sector experienced a strong rebound in June, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing activity index jumping to 57.1, the highest since February. This marks a significant improvement from the 41.8 reading in April and surpasses economists' forecasts of a 48.9 reading. However, a resurgence in COVID-19 cases threatens the emerging recovery, with several states scaling back reopenings and impacting restaurants and bars. The services sector now accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity.

site_title: Navigating supply chain disruptions for banks
summary: Banks must enhance digital capabilities to support trade financing amid supply chain disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The World Trade Organization predicts a 13-32% decline in international trade in 2020, with complex supply chains facing significant challenges. To adapt, businesses must understand the intricacies of their supply chains and implement digital transformation strategies, including data analytics and real-time trade financing. Banks must also prioritize digital capabilities to provide prompt relief to businesses, mitigate cyber risks, and enable the growth of global economies.

site_title: US: Wall St gains on hopes of China-led recovery
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, driven by hopes of a China-led recovery from the coronavirus outbreak. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all opened higher, with record highs reached on the Nasdaq. Investors dismissed concerns over a surge in domestic COVID-19 cases. The market's optimism is attributed to China's economic recovery, which is seen as a positive indicator for the global economy.

site_title: Two freehold industrial properties for sale
summary: Two industrial properties in Singapore are up for sale, including a warehouse at 12 Tagore Drive with an indicative price tag of S$55 million and two strata units at 205 Henderson Road with indicative prices of about S$8 million. The sale will be conducted via an expression of interest (EOI) exercise, which opens on Tuesday and closes on August 4.

site_title: Election digest
summary: Singapore's Elections Department has warned against shouting or chanting party slogans during campaigning to prevent COVID-19 spread. The PAP has called on the WP to clarify its stance on Raeesah Khan's derogatory Facebook posts. Assistance will be provided to people with disabilities to vote independently, including a portable booth for wheelchair users and stencils for visually impaired voters. Meanwhile, international news includes Vietnam's surprise at Trump's tariff announcement, the Asian garment industry's concerns about higher US tariffs, and China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: Family offices could bridge ESG and asset management
summary: Family offices, which are private wealth management firms, have the potential to drive positive change through their investments and business operations. According to the Monetary Authority of Singapore, foundations, trusts, and family offices are well-positioned to bridge the gap between philanthropy and asset management. Over 25% of family foundations are actively engaged in sustainable investing, with climate change being a predominant concern. To effectively implement impact investing, family offices should establish clear vision, guidelines, and resources, and focus on material ESG factors that impact financial performance.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 24.25 points to 1,576.90. The index saw 744 gains and 332 losses, with a total trading volume of 8.731 billion lots worth RM5.074 billion.

site_title: For some, a general election without real rallies is missing something
summary: Singapore's parliamentary elections lack the traditional "electrifying atmosphere" of physical rallies due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to pre-recorded broadcasts and online rallies. Some candidates lament the absence of in-person interactions and the need for social media outreach to reach a broader audience. While some appreciate the virtual forms of outreach, many feel it's not the same as a live rally, which brings Singaporeans together. This shift highlights the challenges of campaigning in a post-pandemic era.

site_title: GovTech, Tableau renew partnership to deepen public officers' data skills
summary: GovTech and analytics platform Tableau have renewed their partnership to train public officers in data analytics and visualization. The collaboration aims to deepen public officers' data skills, support the digitalization of the public sector, and align with Singapore's Smart Nation initiative. Thousands of public officers have already been trained with visual analytics skills since 2017. The partnership will provide access to Tableau's content, learning resources, and subject matter experts to empower more public officers to make data-driven decisions. This will support GovTech in building a digitally ready and data-literate workforce.

site_title: Regeneron Covid-19 treatment enters final stage trials
summary: Regeneron announced it's entering the final stage of human clinical trials for its Covid-19 treatment, REGN-COV2, a combination of two antibodies blocking the virus's spike protein. The Phase 3 trial aims to prevent infection among people recently exposed to the virus, with 2,000 US patients expected to enroll. The company also plans a separate trial to treat both hospitalized and non-hospitalized Covid-19 patients, involving 1,850 hospital and 1,050 non-hospital patients in the US, Brazil, Mexico, and Chile. Preliminary data is expected later this summer.

site_title: Britain set to axe Huawei 5G involvement
summary: Britain is set to phase out Huawei's equipment from its 5G network amid persistent spying concerns. A UK security investigation has raised "very, very serious" questions over Huawei's limited 5G role. The decision comes under pressure from the US, which argues that Huawei could spy on Western communications or shut down the UK network under orders from Beijing. The UK government is drawing up plans to remove Huawei technology from the 5G network due to US sanctions that could curtail the company's access to American semiconductors.

site_title: With miniature mannequins, Dior unveils post-lockdown collection
summary: Christian Dior unveiled its post-lockdown collection during Haute Couture week in Paris, presenting intricate designs on miniature mannequins instead of a traditional catwalk show. The collection, inspired by female surrealist artists, featured intricate embroideries and feathers. Designer Maria Grazia Chiuri coordinated remotely from Rome, using a format last used during World War Two to showcase the collection to top clients. The miniatures were presented through a whimsical film shot by Matteo Garrone, highlighting the label's efforts to keep traditions alive despite the pandemic.

site_title: China accuses UK of 'gross interference' over Hong Kong
summary: China has accused the UK of "gross interference" in its internal affairs over its response to a controversial national security law in Hong Kong. The UK has offered Hong Kong residents a broader path to citizenship, which China sees as a breach of the 1984 Sino-British joint declaration. China has expressed "grave concern and strong opposition" to the proposals, which could allow over 3 million Hong Kongers to move to Britain. The move is seen as a response to the sweeping security law, which has criminalised dissenting opinions and sent fear through the territory.

site_title: Money Hacks: Insurance - term vs whole life, what makes sense amid Covid-19? (Ep 75)
summary: Host Chris Lim discusses insurance options with MoneyOwl's CEO Chuin Ting Weber amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Key points include: insurance as protection, comprehensively insured status, and term insurance being more affordable until retirement age with dependents. Term insurance is preferable until dependents are no longer reliant on the policyholder's income. Financial experts emphasize the importance of income over assets during this period. The discussion highlights the need for tailored insurance strategies to manage risk and protect one's financial well-being.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit collects 80% of base rents from retail tenants in June
summary: United Hampshire US Reit collected approximately 80% of base rents from retail tenants in June, with 91% of tenants open for business. This represents a slight increase from May's 77% and April's 82%. The Reit's self-storage properties experienced a steady upward trend in leasing activity, and its manager is in talks with tenants on potential lease extensions. Despite ongoing Covid-19 transmission cases, the Reit remains resilient due to its suburban locations and essential business tenants.

site_title: Indonesia unveils 574.59t rupiah bond scheme to fund recovery from pandemic
summary: Indonesia's central bank has agreed to buy 574.59 trillion rupiah (S$55.3 billion) of low-yielding government bonds this year to fund the economic recovery programme, aiming to finance the 2020 fiscal deficit of 6.34% of GDP. The bond-buying programme will support recovery schemes for businesses and public interest programmes, with no impact on inflation or monetary policy, according to Bank Indonesia Governor Perry Warjiyo. The programme is a one-off policy and debt-tradable, allowing for monetary operation flexibility.

site_title: Hong Kong details new powers under controversial China law
summary: Hong Kong released additional details of China's national security law, granting security forces authority to enter and search properties, and stop people from leaving the city. The law, which came into effect on July 1, 1997, under the "one country, two systems" formula, now punishes crimes of secession and sedition with up to life in prison. This move has stoked concerns of a more authoritarian era in Hong Kong, where anti-China protests have been ongoing for a year. The law's implementation has raised fears of a loss of autonomy and freedoms in the city.

site_title: Trials to test public-health safety measures during flights underway
summary: Singapore Airlines and the UK have launched trials to test public-health safety measures during flights, following guidelines from the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO). The trials, which involve cabin crew and multiple airlines, aim to reduce the risk of COVID-19 transmission on flights. Measures tested include safe distancing, customs and immigration requirements, hand hygiene, and reduced passenger interactions. Data collected will be analyzed to strengthen guidelines and improve safety processes, with the goal of keeping aviation safe for passengers and crew.

site_title: India overtakes Russia to become world's third highest for virus cases
summary: India has surpassed Russia to become the world's third-highest country in terms of coronavirus cases, with 697,358 recorded cases and 19,693 deaths. The US and Brazil remain the top two countries. India's lower death toll compared to other badly hit countries is a notable difference.

images.alt_text: India announced Monday that it had logged nearly 700,000 coronavirus cases.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong criticized opposition parties for their silence on addressing the Covid-19 pandemic and economic crisis, a key issue in the upcoming General Election. Meanwhile, local universities are making more room for Singaporean undergrads who had planned to study abroad, and funds raised from Singapore IPOs halved to S$725 million in the first half of 2020. Singapore shares closed 1.4% higher, marking the fifth straight win. Property group CapitaLand expects a 25-35% reduction in H1 net profit due to the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Hong Kong government tells schools to remove books breaching security law
summary: Hong Kong's government has ordered schools to review and remove books that may breach the new national security law, which was imposed by Beijing last week. The law outlaws subversion, secession, terrorism, and colluding with foreign forces, and authorities have declared political views espousing independence or self-autonomy as illegal. The move comes as rights groups warn of a chilling effect on political freedoms, following the withdrawal of books by prominent activists and scholars, including Joshua Wong and Chin Wan, from libraries and school shelves.

site_title: It starts from the top
summary: Wealth managers are increasingly adopting sustainable strategies, driven by institutional commitments to the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDG). This trend is trickling down to clients, with 39% of retail investors expressing interest in ESG investing. Despite initial concerns, sustainable funds have outperformed conventional funds, with 70% of sustainable funds in the US ranking in the top halves of their categories. Institutions such as Credit Suisse, UBS, BNP Paribas Wealth Management, and DBS Wealth are also making significant commitments to sustainability, with plans to achieve high ESG ratings and mobilize billions of dollars into impact investments.

site_title: Uber buys delivery startup Postmates for US$2.65b
summary: Uber is acquiring delivery startup Postmates for US$2.65 billion in stock, expanding its food delivery business. The acquisition, announced on July 6, 2020, aims to diversify Uber's business and capitalize on the surge in delivery demands during the coronavirus pandemic. Postmates will be integrated into Uber Eats, which has seen its business double during the crisis. The deal is seen as both defensive and offensive for Uber, as it seeks to counter growing competition in the food delivery space.

site_title: Singapore's Concord Energy hires crude oil trader from ZenRock
summary: Concord Energy has hired Jason Lai as its new crude oil trader, effective Monday. Lai, formerly a senior trader at ZenRock Commodities Trading, which is now under judicial management, will report to Li Bo, head of trading at Concord Energy. This move comes as the Singapore-based company looks to expand its crude oil trading business.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia logs record loss in Q1 results
summary: Malaysia's budget carrier AirAsia reported its largest quarterly loss, logging a net loss of 803.3 million ringgit (S$261.7 million) in Q1 due to the coronavirus pandemic and losses on fuel hedges. Revenue fell 15% to 2.31 billion ringgit, with passengers carrying 22% fewer than the year-ago period and load factor dropping 11 basis points to 77%. The airline's cost per unit rose 36%. This marks the largest quarterly loss in AirAsia's history.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.4% up
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.4% to close at 2,689.61, marking their fifth consecutive gain, driven by regional bourses' gains and a renewed feel-good factor despite the still-cloudy economic picture. Analysts warn that the rally may be driven by liquidity rather than fundamentals, with risk aversion potentially leading to a sharp correction. Key gauges in Japan, Taiwan, and Malaysia also rose, while Australia declined 0.7%.

site_title: Cardless cash withdrawal app SoCash adds Prime supermarkets to network
summary: SoCash, a cash-withdrawal app, is expanding its network to include Prime supermarkets in Singapore. The company already has 62 Sheng Siong supermarket outlets and plans to add 1,500 Prime supermarket branches, increasing the total number of touchpoints to over 1,500. Users can withdraw cash without human interaction, reducing the need for cash handling and freeing employees to focus on customer service. SoCash aims to promote contactless methods for safety and wellbeing in a post-pandemic world.

site_title: Yanlord records 29.8b yuan in property pre-sales for first six months of 2020
summary: Chinese property developer Yanlord Land Group recorded 29.8 billion yuan in property pre-sales for the first six months of 2020, a 65% increase from the previous year. The pre-sales were for 831,457 square meters of contracted gross floor area, a 30.7% increase. The majority of the sales came from five cities in China, accounting for nearly 84% of the total pre-sales. As of June 30, the company had 4 billion yuan of subscription sales, expected to be converted into contracted pre-sales in the following months.

site_title: Bali set to welcome back tourists even as virus cases surge
summary: Bali, Indonesia, will welcome back tourists starting July 31 for local visitors and September 11 for foreign visitors, despite a four-fold increase in virus cases in June. The reopening is part of a plan to restart the economy in a phased manner. Bali's tourism-dependent economy was severely impacted by the nearly four-month shutdown of resorts and hotels, with hotel occupancy dropping to 2.1% in May. Authorities are urging citizens to wear masks, avoid large gatherings, and practice social distancing to stem the spread of the virus.

site_title: Oscar-winning composer Ennio Morricone dead at 91
summary: Ennio Morricone, a renowned film composer, died at 91 in a hospital in Rome where he was being treated for a fractured femur following a fall. He composed music for over 500 films, including "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" and "The Hateful Eight." Morricone won an Oscar in 2016 for his work on "The Hateful Eight."

images.alt_text: Ennio Morricone, one of the world's best-known and most prolific film composers, died in Rome on July 6, 2020.

site_title: Chinese troops seen withdrawing from flashpoint Himalayan valley: Indian army
summary: Chinese troops have started removing tents and structures from the Galwan Valley in Ladakh, India, following a deadly battle with Indian soldiers on June 15. The Indian army reported 20 killed and acknowledged China suffered casualties. The two sides have held talks and agreed on a negotiated settlement. Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian said both sides made "positive progress" in disengaging frontline troops. The withdrawal marks a significant development in easing tensions between nuclear-armed neighbours India and China.

site_title: Springleaf Tower office floor up for sale with guide price of more than S$26m
summary: A floor in Springleaf Tower, a 2002 Singapore office building in the central business district, is up for sale with a guide price of over S$26 million. The 10,527 sq ft strata area comes with exclusive use of lift lobby, pantry, and restrooms, and has a high occupancy rate. Located near Tanjong Pagar MRT station and the planned Greater Southern Waterfront, the property offers Grade A specifications and direct underground access. The expression of interest closes on August 13.

site_title: Starburst bags S$13.1m contract to upgrade tactical training facility in South-east Asia
summary: Starburst Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, has been awarded a S$13.1 million contract to upgrade a tactical-training mock-up facility in South-east Asia. The project, set to begin this month and be completed by July 2021, will involve designing, supplying, and installing ballistic protection works. This contract is expected to positively impact the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the 2020 financial year. This follows a previous contract worth S$40.9 million to build a firearms-training facility in the region, scheduled for completion by February 2022.

site_title: Indonesian consumers bursting with pent-up demand: Poll
summary: Indonesian consumers are expected to experience "revenge spending" as they emerge from pandemic lockdowns, with a survey indicating a surge in demand for lower-ticket items such as clothes and skincare products. Retailers are advised to focus on personalization and value for each market segment to capitalize on this trend, while also addressing overstocked inventory.

site_title: Britain's Boohoo to ditch suppliers that don't meet standards
summary: Boohoo, a British online fashion retailer, will end relationships with suppliers that breach its code of conduct after a media report exposed poor working conditions at a factory in Leicester, England. The factory, Jaswal Fashions, was found to be paying workers as little as £3.50 an hour and operating during a local coronavirus lockdown without proper hygiene measures. Boohoo is investigating the incident and will review its relationships with any suppliers who subcontracted work to the manufacturer.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with more big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged, following a rally in mainland Chinese markets, for a fourth consecutive day. The Hang Seng Index rose 3.81% to 26,339.16, driven by hopes for economic recovery from the coronavirus. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also gained, with the Shanghai Composite Index reaching its best close since March 2018. The gains were fueled by expectations of economic growth and recovery, despite ongoing uncertainty from US trade policies.

site_title: Hot stock: Hi-P climbs 16.8%, receives SGX query
summary: Hi-P International's shares rose 16.8% on Monday, reaching S$1.25, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) about "unusual price movements". The company responded, stating it was unaware of any information not previously announced that might explain the trading. Hi-P confirmed compliance with listing rules, following recent changes to its executive leadership and employee share option scheme.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound strongly at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded strongly at the start of trading on Monday, driven by hopes of a swift and solid economic recovery. London's FTSE 100 index surged 1.8%, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indexes jumped 1.9% and 2.0%, respectively. The gains followed a rally in Asia, with investors optimistic about the economic outlook.

site_title: Aviva chief steps down, citing family health reasons
summary: Aviva's CEO Maurice Tulloch is stepping down with immediate effect due to family health reasons. He will be replaced by Amanda Blanc, an independent director and former Zurich Insurance executive. Tulloch took over as CEO in March 2019.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as virus spike forces stringent curbs
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Monday, closing 0.7% down at 6,014.6, as a spike in domestic Covid-19 cases forced fresh restrictions. The border between Victoria and New South Wales was closed for the first time in 100 years to contain an outbreak in Melbourne, with 127 new infections reported. This marks the biggest one-day spike since the pandemic began. The S&P/ASX 200 index has shed 9.37% for the year so far.

site_title: Vallianz Holdings defers distribution for US$22.5m perpetual securities
summary: Vallianz Holdings, an offshore support-vessel owner and operator, has deferred the distribution of US$22.5 million to perpetual securities holders. This decision was made as the company had not paid any dividend or made other payments in the preceding 12 months, and its junior obligations had not been redeemed, reduced, or acquired. This is not the first time Vallianz has exercised its rights to defer a distribution, as it did the same in 2018. The company's shares closed flat on the day of the announcement.

site_title: GE quick takes: Candidates shouldn't chant party slogans; WP highlights gender wage gap
summary: Singapore will hold its General Election (GE2020) on July 10, with all 93 seats in 31 constituencies up for grabs. The election comes amidst the COVID-19 pandemic and economic crisis, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong criticizing opposition parties for their silence on these issues. The Elections Department has also warned candidates against shouting or chanting party slogans to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Meanwhile, the Workers' Party (WP) has highlighted the gender wage gap and the challenges faced by older women in retirement, with candidates promising to address these issues if elected.

site_title: Local universities make more room for Singaporean undergrads who had planned to study abroad
summary: Singaporean undergraduates whose overseas study plans were disrupted by the pandemic will be accepted into local universities, with 2,000 offers made for fresh school-leavers, expected to boost the autonomous university cohort participation rate to 42% from 40%. Public universities are also reviewing bids from Singaporeans who want to transfer schools. The move aims to provide options for students reassessing their plans to study overseas due to COVID-19, with the possibility of short modular courses or one-semester enrollment at autonomous universities.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gain most in 3 weeks on recovery hopes, fresh stimulus support
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.7% on Monday, the largest daily gain in three weeks, driven by economic recovery hopes and fresh stimulus measures. The Kospi index closed at 2,187.93, surpassing the previous record since June 16. Risk appetite remained firm following US job data and China's fastest-growing services sector.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares jumped nearly 1.7 per cent on Monday, rising for a third straight session with the sharpest daily gain in three weeks, as sentiment boosted on economic recovery hopes and the country's fresh stimulus measures.

site_title: Geberit's quarterly sales drop as pandemic hammers construction sector
summary: Swiss plumbing supplies company Geberit reported a 15.9% drop in second-quarter sales to 671 million Swiss francs, citing a 10.7% decline when adjusted for currency swings. The company attributed the decline to the coronavirus pandemic, which has dented the construction sector, and did not provide an annual outlook due to market uncertainty. Despite this, Geberit's supply chains remained intact, and sales in Germany, its largest market, were up 2.9% in the first half.

site_title: Gold slips as risk appetite improves, virus surge caps losses
summary: Gold prices eased 0.1% to $1,772.73 per ounce, despite improving risk sentiment, as investors awaited US services sector data. The surge in coronavirus cases in US states, however, capped losses and supported gold prices. Central bank stimulus and lower interest rates continue to support gold markets, with some analysts predicting a potential rise to $1,788-$1,795 per ounce.

site_title: Lloyds Bank CEO Antonio Horta-Osorio to step down in 2021
summary: Lloyds Banking Group CEO Antonio Horta-Osorio will step down in 2021 after a decade at the helm. He will be succeeded by Robin Budenberg, who was appointed as the new chairman. Horta-Osorio expressed "mixed emotions" about leaving the position, but no reason was given for his departure.

site_title: US$125b pension fund buys stocks as it bets on recovery
summary: Australia's largest pension fund, AustralianSuper, plans to boost its equity exposure to 58% of its $125 billion portfolio over the next year, betting on economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. Chief Investment Officer Mark Delaney is optimistic about the outlook, citing low interest rates and undemanding valuations. The fund's default investment option achieved a 0.52% return in the last 12 months, marking its 11th consecutive year of positive returns. Delaney believes the medium-term outlook is clearer, favoring a pro-growth bias portfolio.

site_title: Tesla mocks shortsellers with sale of red satin shorts
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has mocked short-sellers with the sale of red satin shorts, priced at $69.420, on the company's website. The move comes after Tesla surpassed Toyota as the world's most valuable automaker and beat forecast with forecast-beating deliveries. Musk has previously targeted short-sellers, including hedge fund owner David Einhorn, with a box of shorts in 2018. The sales of the "Short Shorts" are seen as a response to Tesla's strong Q2 deliveries and heightened expectations for the company's earnings results.

site_title: Two industrial properties for sale with S$55m, S$8m indicative prices
summary: Two industrial properties in Singapore are up for sale via an expression of interest exercise, with indicative prices of S$55 million and S$8 million. The properties, located at 12 Tagore Drive and two strata units at 205 Henderson Road, offer flexible redevelopment options and strong connectivity to major arterial roads and expressways. Colliers International expects the properties to attract developers looking for freehold industrial redevelopment sites, citing a forecasted decline in industrial property supply over the next five years.

site_title: Orchard Road malls, Jewel among places visited by Covid-19 patients while they were infectious
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has released a list of locations visited by Covid-19 patients while they were infectious, including Orchard Road malls and Jewel Changi Airport. Over 20 new locations and time slots have been added to the list. MOH advises those who visited these places to monitor their health closely for two weeks. The country reported 23 new community cases, with 18 linked to previous cases or clusters, and 6 unlinked cases. The total number of cases has reached 44,983, with 40,705 patients fully recovered and 208 patients in hospital.

site_title: India growth forecast cut again at Citi as virus cases surge
summary: Citi sharply lowered its forecast for India's economy, predicting a 6% contraction in the fiscal year to March 2021, compared to a 3.5% decline previously estimated. The revision is largely due to a cut in the first-quarter forecast, with the economy expected to slump 21% during the period. The COVID-19 pandemic's rapid spread and delayed flattening of the curve led to the forecast revision, surpassing the IMF's 4.5% decline and Goldman Sachs' 5% contraction. Consumer and business sentiment is expected to remain low in the second quarter.

site_title: Big Four told to ring fence auditing in Britain by June 2024
summary: The UK's Financial Reporting Council has told the "Big Four" auditing firms (PwC, Deloitte, KPMG, and EY) to separate auditing into a distinct business by June 2024. This move aims to improve audit quality following corporate failures such as Carillion and BHS. The firms must submit an implementation plan by October 23, with the goal of separating auditing operations by June 30, 2024. This change is a response to previous reviews and follows the regulator's efforts to speed up reform, despite Brexit and the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Fujitsu to halve office space in 3 years citing 'new normal'
summary: Fujitsu plans to halve its office space in three years due to the "new normal" of remote working amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company, with approximately 80,000 employees in Japan, will adopt flexible hours and work-from-home arrangements. Fujitsu aims to overhaul its work framework, focusing on software services that can be easily conducted remotely. The company will also launch satellite offices in employees' residential areas and partner with shared workspace providers.

site_title: UK new car sales post smaller slump in June on annual basis
summary: UK new car sales declined by a third in June compared to the same period last year, with 145,000 units registered. This is a smaller drop than in March, April, and May, when demand fell by 44%, 97%, and 89% respectively. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders attributed the decline to the reopening of dealerships after the Covid-19 lockdown.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 2,661.07 on Monday, driven by gains from local banks. The STI opened higher, with 100 gainers outnumbering losers 100 to 36. Banking stocks such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC rose 0.3-0.5%. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China lays groundwork to crackdown further on political threats
summary: China has established a special working group to boost political policing amid rising international tensions, including criticism over its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. The group, led by Vice Secretary-General Lei Dongsheng, aims to protect the Communist Party's safety and safeguard the regime's security. Officials vowed to crack down on infiltration, subversion, and other activities deemed threats to the system. This move comes as China faces criticism from nations like the US and Australia, and amid a growing list of international disputes.

images.alt_text: The Chinese government took steps to boost political policing as a slew of international spats risk sowing domestic unrest, potentially undermining support for the Communist Party.

site_title: Rothschild & Co to transfer its hedge fund business to Candriam
summary: Rothschild & Co plans to transfer its 350 million euro hedge fund business to Candriam, a global asset manager, in a deal worth 600 million euros. The move will help Candriam enter a new phase in the alternative investment space and appeal to investors in the current environment. Rothschild's assets under management will be significantly reduced, while Candriam's assets will increase to 600 million euros, putting it among the world's largest asset managers.

site_title: India's growing appetite for takeaway looks set to outlast lockdown
summary: India's takeaway market is expected to outlast the coronavirus lockdown, with cloud kitchens projected to reach a $2 billion industry by 2024. According to a survey, 21% of respondents plan to increase online ordering, while only 9% intend to dine out more often. Cloud kitchens offer convenience, minimize costs, and cater to socially distanced customers, making them a viable option for restaurants. While takeaway won't replace restaurants entirely, it's expected to become a permanent shift post-crisis, with demand driven by convenience and variety.

site_title: PM Lee: Opposition parties silent on tackling Covid-19, economic crisis
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong criticized opposition parties for their silence on tackling the Covid-19 pandemic and economic crisis, a key issue in the upcoming General Election. Lee emphasized the need for a good government to fight the pandemic, support the economy, and navigate the crisis. He urged voters to trust his government to get through the difficult times ahead.

site_title: Temasek-backed Indonesian beauty startup Social Bella raises US$58m funding round
summary: Indonesian beauty startup Social Bella, backed by Temasek, has raised US$58 million in funding. The company operates the e-commerce platform Sociolla and has 30 million users in Indonesia, with six physical stores in the country. This funding round is part of Social Bella's existing investors, demonstrating the startup's growth and potential in the Indonesian beauty market.

site_title: Luckin Coffee shareholders vote to remove chairman, report says
summary: Luckin Coffee's chairman, Charles Zhengyao Lu, was removed by shareholders in an extraordinary meeting in Beijing, just days after surviving an attempt to strip him of control. Three other board directors, including Sean Shao, were also ousted, while Ying Zeng and Jie Yang were added as independent board directors. The move follows the company's ongoing scandal-plagued issues.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei hits near 1-month high after hopes of a China rebound
summary: Japanese shares rose on Monday, with the Nikkei hitting a near one-month high, driven by hopes of a Chinese economic rebound. Cyclical stocks led the gains as Chinese shares jumped over 5% to a five-year high. The Nikkei rose 1.83% to 22,714.44, its highest close since June 10, while the Topix gained 1.60% to 1,577.15. The rebound in China's economy boosted shippers and steelmakers, offsetting concerns over COVID-19 cases in US states and the impact of US trade policies.

site_title: China imposes checks on large transactions after bank runs
summary: China has introduced a program to monitor large transactions, requiring businesses and individuals to pre-report withdrawals or deposits exceeding 500,000 yuan (S$98,900) and 100,000-300,000 yuan, respectively. The two-year pilot program aims to prevent bank runs and tighten monitoring of "unreasonable demands of large amounts of cash" amid a surge in bad debt and a slow-growing economy. The program will be expanded to more provinces and is part of efforts to shore up the country's US$41 trillion banking system, which could face an 8 trillion yuan increase in bad debt this year.

site_title: Banks are ditching London offices and not just because of Covid-19
summary: Banks are downsizing their London offices, a trend that predates the COVID-19 pandemic. Barclays, Credit Suisse, and Morgan Stanley plan to vacate or sublease office space, with Barclays likely to step up plans to leave its investment bank headquarters. The pandemic has accelerated job cuts, with headcount at the 12 biggest investment banks dropping 5% in the first quarter. Experts predict 20% fewer staff at European banks by the end of the year. The shift away from traditional office spaces may be permanent, with some banks considering remote work options, and serviced office providers like WeWork gaining popularity.

site_title: Why super rich fashionistas are not crying for Paris shows
summary: The Paris fashion shows were cancelled due to the coronavirus, but the super rich fashionistas who buy handmade haute couture creations were not upset. Instead, they expect personalized presentations in their palaces and penthouses. Designers like Julien Fournie and Jean-Paul Cauvin are now offering virtual fashion weeks, focusing on bespoke designs for individual clients. Fournie emphasizes the exclusivity and uniqueness of haute couture, which is made to fit each client's body, rather than mass-produced ready-to-wear clothes.

site_title: Samsung's Q2 chip sales unlikely made up for smartphone weakness
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is unlikely to offset smartphone weakness with strong chip sales in the second quarter, analysts say. The company's chip sales, driven by data centres and work-from-home traffic, are expected to show a decline in revenue and operating profit, with a 4.5% to 6.3 trillion won (S$7.31 billion) drop. Smartphone shipments have fallen along with discretionary spending during the pandemic, and the display business is likely to post a second consecutive quarter of loss. Samsung will release detailed earnings figures later this month.

site_title: UK's Royal Mint celebrates singer Elton John with commemorative coin
summary: Elton John has become the second artist to be honored by Britain's Royal Mint with a commemorative coin, paying tribute to the decorated British singer-songwriter. The coin, designed by Bradley Morgan Johnson, features John's straw boater's hat and fashions his trademark glasses out of musical notes. John, 73, described the honor as "fabulous" in a statement.

site_title: Louvre museum reopens after 16-week virus shutdown
summary: The Louvre museum in Paris reopened after a 16-week coronavirus closure, but with nearly a third of its galleries still shut. The museum lost over 40 million euros in ticket sales during the lockdown and may face lean years ahead. Most popular draws like the "Mona Lisa" will be accessible, but social distancing measures will limit visitor numbers to around 20-30% of last summer's 4,000-10,000 visitors per day. The museum aims to attract more French visitors and shake off its elitist image before the 2024 Paris Olympics.

site_title: To buy a drink in this border town, make sure you're in England
summary: A border town in England, Llanymynech, has become a contested area due to a disputed border between England and Wales. The border, largely invisible, has sparked a debate over who has the authority to serve drinks. Following England's decision to reopen restaurants, cafes, and bars, two pubs in Llanymynech can now serve customers, while pubs in Wales remain closed, citing a lack of clear authority over the border. The dispute highlights the complexities of the Anglo-Welsh frontier and the challenges of enforcing public health measures across the border.

site_title: Uber, Postmates agree on US$2.65b all-stock deal
summary: Uber Technologies has agreed to acquire Postmates in a US$2.65 billion all-stock takeover, expanding its delivery business. The deal is expected to be announced Monday and will help Uber gain ground against privately-held DoorDash. Postmates maintains a strong position in Los Angeles and the American Southwest, which could be valuable to Uber Eats. Uber's board of directors has approved the deal, and Postmates' CEO Bastian Lehmann's role after the acquisition is unclear. This move comes after Uber's failed bid to acquire GrubHub, which was acquired by Just Eat Takeaway.com for US$7.30 billion.

site_title: Oyo is slashing footprint and headcount in virus-hit Japan
summary: Oyo Hotels, a major startup in SoftBank Group's portfolio, is significantly downsizing its presence in Japan due to the coronavirus outbreak. The company has closed offices in five provincial centers and is considering reducing its Tokyo headquarters, with some employees encouraged to quit and receive up to a four-month severance. This move follows a broader global retrenchment, with Oyo having previously reduced its workforce by 5,000 people and furloughed thousands more. Japan's travel restrictions have led to a 99.9% decline in overseas visitors and a standstill in domestic tourism.

site_title: Dominion, Duke exit pipeline project after years of delays
summary: Dominion Energy Inc and Duke Energy Corp have abandoned the US$8 billion Atlantic Coast Pipeline project due to increased legal uncertainty and anticipated delays, despite a favorable US Supreme Court ruling in June. The project's estimated cost more than doubled from US$4.5-5.0 billion to US$8 billion. Environmental groups, including the Sierra Club and Southern Environmental Law Center, had sued to stop the pipeline, citing inadequate studies and protection of endangered species. The decision reflects the increasing legal uncertainty in large-scale energy and industrial infrastructure development in the US.

site_title: Brexit talks move to London after tough week in Brussels
summary: Britain's Brexit talks resume in London after a tough week in Brussels, with few signs of compromise on a new trade agreement. EU negotiator Michel Barnier and UK counterpart David Frost have expressed deep divides in their approaches, with Barnier stating "serious divergences remain" and Frost saying "significant differences" exist. German Chancellor Angela Merkel has warned that an agreement may not be reached, and a standstill transition period ends on December 31. EU officials suggest a deal could still be reached by late October, but British businesses are pressing for guidance on the feasibility of a trade deal.

site_title: US adds 40,000 new virus cases in 24 hours: tracker
summary: The US recorded 39,379 new coronavirus cases in 24 hours, bringing the total to 2,876,143 cases. The country's death toll rose to 129,891, with 234 fatalities reported. The lower number of cases on Sunday may be attributed to reduced reporting due to the July 4th national holiday weekend. The US remains the hardest-hit country in the pandemic, with concerns about overwhelmed healthcare systems and early reopening of cities.

site_title: AMTD Digital to buy controlling stake in Singapore fintech FOMO Pay
summary: AMTD Digital is set to acquire a controlling stake in Singapore-based fintech FOMO Pay, its third acquisition in Singapore's fintech industry, following PolicyPal and CapBridge. The deal, subject to approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore, aims to reinforce AMTD Digital's expansion in South-east Asia. FOMO Pay will become a key member of AMTD Digital's ecosystem, offering a suite of digital payment methods in Singapore and Malaysia. The acquisition is expected to enhance AMTD Digital's fintech platform and promote cashless payments and financial inclusion in the region.

site_title: Digital to drive healthcare delivery in post-Covid Asia
summary: Asia's healthcare sector has rapidly shifted towards digital infrastructure to maintain and improve patient services amid the COVID-19 pandemic. With markets reopening, healthcare providers will need to navigate several phases, including a bounce-back period, where surgical and elective procedures will increase, and a living with COVID-19 stage, where containment and new care models will be introduced. The "New Normal" will see patients consulting remotely, medical professionals adopting new ways of working, and healthcare spending expected to increase to $740 billion by 2025. Digital solutions, including AI, data analytics, and telemedicine, will be essential to manage patient volumes and staffing pressures.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE remains positive on Malaysia's 4D operators
summary: Maybank Kim Eng maintains a "buy" call on Malaysia's number forecast operators (NFOs), specifically Magnum and Berjaya Sports Toto. Analysts attribute the rapid recovery of NFO jackpot sales to small sales per person and less aversion to visiting outlets due to their non-enclosed nature. The brokerage also expects a similar recovery trend in Classic 4D sales and notes the possibility of special draws to "claw back" foregone taxes. Target prices are set at RM2.51 for Magnum and RM2.88 for Berjaya Sports Toto.

site_title: Australia closes state border for first time in 100 years to halt coronavirus
summary: Australia closed its border with New South Wales, its most populous state, for the first time in 100 years due to a surge in COVID-19 cases in Victoria. The decision, announced by Premier Daniel Andrews, aims to contain the outbreak, which has led to a spike in cases and one death. The closure will likely impact the country's economic recovery, which is heading into its first recession in nearly three decades. The border closure, effective immediately, was made jointly with the New South Wales and federal governments.

site_title: German restaurants still hungry for customers post-lockdown
summary: Germany's hospitality sector continues to struggle two months after lifting lockdowns, with restaurants like Zen Kitchen seeing only 20-30% of pre-lockdown clientele. Despite efforts to adapt to the new normal, the sector faces difficulties as Europe's top economy confronts the steepest recession since World War II. The government has pledged over a trillion euros in stimulus spending, and Economy Minister Peter Altmaier expects the economy to rebound by October. However, many businesses, including restaurants, fear a record wave of bankruptcies without more state support.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Japfa, Accordia Golf Trust, Q&M Dental, UnUsUaL
summary: Singapore stocks experienced various developments on Monday, with CapitaLand expecting its six-month profit to be "materially and adversely" affected, Japfa selling a 25% stake in its dairy farming business, and Accordia Golf Trust's sponsor offering too low for the trust's golf courses. Q&M Dental Group acquired Covid-19 test kits and UnUsUaL's costs are down despite revenue faltering. Trading halted for Tee International pending announcements.

site_title: Australian job advertisements jump record 42% in June: ANZ
summary: Australian job advertisements jumped 42% in June, reaching a record 89,252, as the economy partially reopened from coronavirus lockdowns. Despite the increase, ads were still down 44.6% from June last year. Economists predict unemployment could spike to 10% in coming months due to ongoing lockdowns and large-scale layoffs. The Reserve Bank of Australia has taken measures to cushion the economy, including slashing interest rates to a record low and launching a bond buying program.

site_title: Sembmarine CEO named co-chair of maritime decarbonisation panel
summary: Sembmarine CEO Wong Weng Sun has been appointed co-chair of the International Advisory Panel on Maritime Decarbonisation, alongside Maritime Singapore Foundation's chairman Andreas Sohmen-Pao. The panel aims to explore decarbonisation strategies for the maritime industry, aligning with the International Maritime Organization's 2050 target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 50%. As co-chair, Wong will contribute Sembmarine's expertise in developing low-carbon engineering products and solutions.

site_title: Argentina sweetens debt revamp offer to creditors; sets Aug 4 deadline
summary: Argentina's government has unveiled an amended debt restructuring proposal, offering sweeteners such as reduced principal haircuts, increased coupons, and a bond to account for accrued interest. The proposal sets an August 4 deadline for creditors to accept it, aiming to defuse recent tensions and strike a deal to avoid a messy legal standoff. The move comes after talks stalled last month and follows the country's ninth sovereign default in May, amid a deep economic recession.

site_title: AnAn unit proposes acquisition of French petrol products distributor for 4m euros
summary: A UNIT of AnAn International, Dyneff, proposed acquiring French petrol products distributor Orceyre for approximately 4 million euros (S$6.3 million). The acquisition will be financed through internal resources of Rompetrol France, which is 51% owned by AnAn International. The seller is not affiliated with AnAn International, and none of its directors or substantial shareholders have interests in the transaction.

site_title: Desperate searches as dozens feared dead in Japan floods
summary: Rescue workers in western Japan continue searching for survivors after record rains caused deadly floods and landslides, killing at least 36 people and leaving 11 unaccounted for. The death toll is expected to rise as torrential rain continues, with hundreds of thousands of residents evacuated and thousands of homes without power. Emergency services are hampered by concerns about the spread of COVID-19, with evacuation centers set up to maintain social distancing. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has deployed over 40,000 personnel for search and rescue operations.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS positive on hospitality S-Reits as hotels to reopen for staycations
summary: DBS Group Research predicts a positive impact on hospitality S-Reits in Singapore, particularly Ascott Residence Trust and Frasers Hospitality Trust, due to the reopening of hotels for staycations. The Sentosa hotels are expected to benefit first, and DBS has a "buy" call on CDL Hospitality Trust and Far East Hospitality Trust with target prices of S$1.30 and S$0.60, respectively. The reopening of hotels is seen as a step towards a gradual recovery for the sector, which has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Australia to set up A$190m fund to boost recycling following export curbs
summary: Australia plans to establish a A$190 million fund to support companies converting waste into manufactured products, aiming to reduce landfill waste. The Recycling Modernisation Fund will be co-invested by state and territory governments, as well as the private sector, with a target of A$600 million in private investment. This initiative follows China's export curbs on waste, with the goal of stopping millions of tonnes of waste from being sent to landfills.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open the week on positive note
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 25.74 points or 0.12% to 22,332.22, while the Topix index added 2.94 points or 0.19% to 1,555.27. Investors monitored the continued rebound of global coronavirus infections.

site_title: Gen Z bearing economic brunt of coronavirus
summary: A generation of younger people, known as Gen Z, is bearing the economic brunt of the coronavirus pandemic, with many struggling to find employment due to the casualization of jobs and lack of fiscal support. In Australia, unemployment among 15-24-year-olds has surged to 16.1%, while those over 25 have a lower rate of 5.5%. This issue is not unique to Australia, with similar trends observed in the UK, where one-third of 18-24-year-old employees have lost jobs or been furloughed. Experts warn that generational scarring and widening wealth gaps are at risk, with many young people struggling to access support and secure stable employment.

site_title: Britain's finance ministry pledges funding to triple number of UK traineeships
summary: Britain's finance ministry has pledged £111 million to triple the number of traineeships, aiming to support the country's post-pandemic economic recovery. The move, part of a larger £133 billion funding package, will provide businesses with a £1,000 bonus for each work experience placement. This expansion is expected to help address the economic challenges posed by the COVID-19 lockdown, which saw the economy shrink 25% in March and April.

site_title: Funds raised from Singapore IPOs halve in H1 2020: Deloitte
summary: Funds raised from Singapore IPOs in the first half of 2020 fell 53.2% to S$725 million, down from S$1.55 billion in the same period last year. This decline was largely due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the global market. Despite this, there is still an appetite for fundraising in the market, with Deloitte receiving enquiries for potential Reit listings. The report suggests that companies may turn to IPOs with essential services, potentially giving the market a "shot in the arm".

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose at the open on Monday, building on last week's rally, as investors look to economies reopening globally. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.68% to 25,545.54, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.11% to 3,187.84. These gains follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the US S&P 500.

site_title: China's era of mega-dams is ending as solar and wind power rise
summary: China is ending its era of mega-dam construction as solar and wind power rise, marking a shift towards smaller, pumped storage projects. The country's hydro industry is down-shifting due to the falling cost of renewable energy and the lack of suitable locations for massive dams. China has completed five of the world's 10-largest hydropower plants in just 10 years, but there are no dams bigger than 10 gigawatts under construction or in planning stages. Instead, China is expanding its overseas hydropower projects, with its development banks financing nearly $44 billion worth of projects globally since 2000.

site_title: China reports 4 new coronavirus cases in mainland for July 5
summary: China reported 4 new coronavirus cases in mainland on July 5, down from 8 the previous day, with 3 being imported cases and 1 in Beijing. The death toll remained at 4,634, and 11 new asymptomatic cases were reported. As of July 5, China had 83,557 confirmed cases.

images.alt_text: China on Monday reported 4 new coronavirus cases in the mainland for July 5, down from 8 cases a day earlier, the health authority said.

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire to buy Dominion Energy gas assets for US$4b
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc agreed to buy Dominion Energy Inc's natural gas transmission and storage business for US$4 billion in cash. The deal includes 12,390km of pipelines, 900 billion cubic feet of gas storage, and a 25% stake in the Cove Point liquefied natural gas facility. This expansion allows Berkshire to focus on its energy operations while Dominion focuses on utilities. The transaction is expected to enhance Berkshire's energy presence and provide Dominion with flexibility to allocate resources.

site_title: Indonesia debt plan set for scrutiny as S&P sees no rating risk
summary: Indonesia is set to scrutinize its plan to sell billions of dollars of bonds to the central bank to finance a widening fiscal deficit. Despite concerns from lawmakers and economists, credit rating companies S&P Global Ratings and Moody's Investor Service say the plan poses no immediate threat to Indonesia's sovereign rating, citing the plan's small size and the nation's well-anchored inflation. The government is seeking to borrow 1.65 quadrillion rupiah this year to fund a budget deficit of 6.34% of gross domestic product and repay its debts.

site_title: Virgin Australia bondholders seek permission to put forward sale alternative
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings bondholders are seeking permission to present an alternative sale proposal to creditors for the airline's sale to private equity group Bain Capital. The proposal was rejected by Virgin's administrator Deloitte, who selected Bain over a debt-to-equity swap proposed by the bondholders. The bondholders claim certain circumstances regarding the sales process are unacceptable, and the vote by creditors on the Bain deal will take place in August. The bondholders have applied to the Takeovers Panel for approval to access information on the Bain transaction.

images.alt_text: Virgin Australia Holdings bondholders have applied to the Takeovers Panel for approval to allow them to make an alternative proposal to creditors for the sale of the airline to private equity group Bain Capital, the panel said on Monday.

site_title: Q&M buys Covid-19 test kits, related business
summary: Q&M Dental Group has completed its acquisition of Covid-19 test kits and related business from Acumen Research Laboratories (ARL) through its subsidiary Acumen Diagnostics. Q&M initially invested S$3 million in April and agreed to pay an additional S$250,000 upon meeting certain performance conditions. Following the completion of the share subscriptions, Q&M's shareholding in Acumen Diagnostics is now 51%. The acquisition aims to develop Acumen Diagnostics' business further with Q&M's support.

site_title: Qantas signs deal, frequent flyers to benefit on Afterpay's platform
summary: Qantas Airways and Afterpay have partnered to allow Qantas frequent flyers to earn up to 5,000 points by linking their membership number to Afterpay's payment platform. This deal is a boost for Afterpay, which has benefited from the shift to online shopping during the coronavirus crisis. The partnership aims to expand Qantas' rewards offerings and increase customer engagement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 3.42 points or 0.22% to 1,556.07. The index saw 308.74 million lots traded worth RM103.92 million, with gainers beating losers 272 to 74.

site_title: Golden Energy sells 0.95% stake in Australian gold miner for A$9m
summary: Golden Energy and Resources has sold a 0.95% stake in Westgold Resources for A$9 million, reducing its stake to 1.59%. The sale will result in a gain of about A$1.5 million, partly offset by a foreign exchange loss. Gear plans to use the proceeds for future investments and general working capital. The disposal is part of Gear's efforts to monetize its investment in Westgold, with the company reducing its shareholding through on-market sales since February.

site_title: SoftBank governance reforms stop short of Vision Fund: sources
summary: SoftBank Group has no plans to increase board oversight of its $100 billion Vision Fund, despite calls from activist investor Elliott Management, according to sources. Governance reforms, initiated by CEO Masayoshi Son, have only partially addressed concerns, with the board remaining largely intact. This decision comes after SoftBank's disastrous run in startups, including WeWork, which led to its biggest-ever annual loss. The lack of significant reforms has been met with disappointment from Elliott Management, which had previously made several demands.

site_title: Cathay Pacific considers drier storage options for unused planes
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways is evaluating options for storing over 50 of its 236 aircraft in less humid locations, such as Dubai and the Australian desert, due to reduced demand caused by the pandemic. The airline is considering sending planes to these locations for long-term storage and possible early retirement. This move follows similar strategies employed by rivals Singapore Airlines, Qantas Airways, and Air New Zealand, which have sent long-haul planes to desert locations for storage. The decision aims to optimize the airline's fleet size in light of the ongoing pandemic-driven slump in air travel demand.

site_title: UK's Sunak plans to raise property tax threshold, cut VAT for hospitality sector: The Times
summary: British Finance Minister Rishi Sunak plans to raise the property tax threshold to £500,000 and temporarily cut VAT for the hospitality sector to boost Britain's economy. The move aims to exempt most homebuyers from paying stamp duty and protect 2.4 million jobs in the hospitality sector. The exemption will be for a temporary period, potentially up to a year, and will be accompanied by an announcement on job support schemes. The measures are part of efforts to steer the UK's economy away from its coronavirus lockdown slump.

site_title: WP candidate apologises for posts allegedly promoting enmity between different groups
