site_title: Acra rejects BDO's application to resign as Mirach Energy's auditor
summary: Acra has rejected BDO's application to resign as auditor of Mirach Energy and its wholly-owned subsidiary Mirach HP Management, citing concerns over the premature resignation's public interest implications. BDO submitted a resignation due to disagreements with Mirach Energy's management over accounting treatment for key audit matters, including revenue recognition and trade receivables. The decision will keep BDO's duties as auditor until the end of its appointed term. Mirach Energy's board is assessing the impact and will discuss further with BDO and other professionals.

site_title: Flexibility needed to counter Covid-19 impact
summary: Investors need to be dynamic and flexible to navigate market volatility caused by the Covid-19 pandemic and geopolitical tensions. Three key strategies are diversifying into non-traditional investments, capitalizing on market dislocations, and maintaining flexibility to shift between defensive and growth-oriented assets. This approach can help protect portfolios from large drawdowns and capture upside potential.

site_title: A gentle path towards greater resistance
summary: A barre class workout is often perceived as easy, but it can be humbling and exhausting, requiring participants to contract and relax muscles repeatedly. The science behind barre workouts is to exhaust parts of the body through isometric exercises, promoting grit and resilience. By focusing on small, manageable movements and taking breaks to recover, individuals can build a "toughened muscle" of strength and perseverance, rather than simply enduring through challenges. This approach challenges the conventional notion of resilience, which often emphasizes pushing through difficulties without rest.

site_title: More than 12,000 people placed in new jobs under SGUnited Jobs initiative: Josephine Teo
summary: More than 12,000 people have been placed in new jobs since March under the SGUnited Jobs initiative, which aims to support job seekers amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The majority of placements, around 70%, were in the public sector, including Covid-19-related positions. The initiative, launched in March, also offers over 16,000 opportunities, including 5,000 job vacancies and 3,000 traineeships. A new scheme, the SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways Programme, will provide 14,500 traineeships and training programs for mid-career workers.

site_title: US: Stock markets closed for holiday on Friday
summary: US stocks closed on Friday for Independence Day, marking the first of a four-day holiday weekend. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US tariff uncertainty. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, with investors remaining positive despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's future actions.

site_title: May retail sales hit all-time low; industry hoping for rebound
summary: Singapore's retail sales plummeted 52.1% in May, the worst decline since records began in 1986, according to the Department of Statistics. Despite some segments, such as supermarkets and convenience stores, showing revenue growth, the overall retail industry is struggling. The decline is attributed to circuit-breaker measures during the pandemic, which reduced sales conversion and led to a year-on-year slump in full-year retail sales. Experts predict a bleak outlook for recovery, with discretionary retail purchases expected to drop by over 50% in the next six months.

site_title: EU opens bidding for 1b euros from clean technology fund
summary: The European Union has launched a 1 billion-euro clean technology fund to support breakthrough low-carbon technologies, including floating wind farms and carbon capture technology. The EU Innovation Fund aims to encourage companies to invest in green technologies by sharing the risk of large first-of-a-kind projects. The fund is expected to restart the EU economy and create a green recovery, leading to climate neutrality by 2050. Funding calls will follow over the next decade, with a total size of approximately 12 billion euros, depending on the development of the EU carbon price.

site_title: US jobs data underpins Singapore stocks
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.62% on July 3, 2020, driven by better-than-expected US jobs data, with payrolls increasing by 4.8 million in June. The Straits Times Index (STI) opened at 2,648.64 and closed at 2,652.94, up 16.25 points. Despite elevated jobless claims, investors cheered the positive economic news.

site_title: Airlines to end legal challenge to UK quarantine policy
summary: Three major European airlines, British Airways, easyJet, and Ryanair, have ended their legal challenge against the UK's quarantine policy for travelers from popular tourist destinations. The policy, which was scrapped for countries like France, Spain, and Italy, but remains in place for the US, was initially criticized by the airlines for its impact on the industry's recovery. The airlines agreed to withdraw the challenge after the government confirmed the list of affected countries would be published, following a meeting with government lawyers who argued the measures were justified and proportionate.

site_title: SDP candidates vow to be full-time MPs and personally see to running of wards
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) has pledged to run town councils and constituency matters personally if voted into Parliament. SDP chairman Paul Tambyah and chief Chee Soon Juan vowed to serve residents full-time and oversee town council finances transparently. They criticized PAP MPs for doing part-time jobs, citing the need for full-time MPs to address residents' concerns and conduct parliamentary work. The opposition party also promised to publish financial reports and produce work plans to ensure transparency and accountability.

site_title: Citigroup expects to cap office occupancy at 40% without a vaccine
summary: Citigroup expects to limit office occupancy to 40% globally until a coronavirus vaccine is available. The bank has begun returning a small percentage of workers to offices, but public transportation issues and employee hesitation are major concerns. Citigroup's CEO, Mike Corbat, emphasizes the importance of maintaining relationships and talent, as remote work may lead to "relationship equity" diminishing over time. The bank has seen record trading and underwriting activity, but expects this to slow down in the coming quarters.

site_title: Miyoshi expects a Q3 loss triggered by pandemic
summary: Miyoshi Limited expects to report a Q3 loss for FY2020 due to lower revenue from the novel coronavirus pandemic and impairment losses from a fire at a production plant in the Philippines.

site_title: Biolidics elaborates on scrapped deal with virus test kit distributor in the US
summary: Biolidics scrapped a deal with Aytu Bioscience to distribute its COVID-19 antibody test kits in the US, citing increased competition. Aytu had paid deposits for 500,100 kits but received only 13,000 delivered by June 28. Biolidics has refunded Aytu's deposits and will return the kits to the distributor. The companies have mutually agreed to terminate the distribution agreement, with no compensation required for Biolidics.

site_title: Canada says it will suspend its extradition treaty with Hong Kong
summary: Canada has suspended its extradition treaty with Hong Kong in response to China's imposition of national security legislation on the former British colony. Foreign Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne condemned the "secretive" process and said Canada will not permit the export of sensitive military items to Hong Kong. The move follows a diplomatic and trade dispute between Canada and China, sparked by the detention of Huawei's CFO in 2018. Canada Prime Minister Justin Trudeau hinted at further measures, including those related to immigration, but did not provide details.

site_title: WP: Public housing prices should be pegged to 'objective criteria' like household income
summary: Singaporean Workers' Party (WP) candidates propose pegging public housing prices to "objective criteria" such as household income to increase affordability and encourage early marriage and childbearing. The party suggests lowering the age limit for buying a two-room Build-to-Order (BTO) flat from 35 to 28. WP also emphasizes the importance of giving young adults access to public housing for personal development and to "sink roots" in the country. The party aims to make public housing more sustainable and equitable for Singaporeans.

site_title: France's Macron picks new prime minister to reinvent presidency
summary: France's President Emmanuel Macron appointed Jean Castex, a 55-year-old civil servant and local mayor, as his new prime minister to reinvent his administration. Castex, a social Gaullist, will help Macron connect with provincial France and is seen as a key figure in the government's overhaul amid France's economic depression. The move comes after Edouard Philippe's resignation, and investors will watch to see if Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire keeps his job. Macron aims to start anew after a poor showing in municipal elections and a surge in support for the Green party.

site_title: Ang Mo Kio's PAP incumbents plug estate plans, RP pledges more attention if elected
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) candidates for Ang Mo Kio GRC presented their estate plans, focusing on resident-centered initiatives, including care for the aged and economic support. The plans were showcased in a constituency political broadcast, where PAP leaders emphasized the need to protect elderly residents and provide economic support. In contrast, the Reform Party (RP) opponents aired residents' grievances and promised to give more dedicated attention if elected, with promises of full-time MPs and more frequent Meet-the-People sessions.

images.alt_text: Ng Ling Ling, who is on the PAP ticket, says she hopes to develop more social and healthcare programmes for residents.
Reform Party's Noraini Yunus says she will work with the party's lawyers and economists to care for residents.

site_title: Convertible bond issues surge in coronavirus-hit market
summary: Convertible bond sales have surged to a 13-year high of $89 billion in 2020, driven by companies seeking to raise cash amidst the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. European issuance is growing as lockdowns end, and investors are attracted to convertible bonds as an alternative to equity placements and bonds, offering equity gains while paying a coupon and repaying principal at maturity. The market has recovered from the 2008 financial crisis, with hedge funds now holding only 20-25% of the market, down from 2/3 in 2008.

site_title: South Korean AR mirror allows touchless cosmetics shopping
summary: A South Korean cosmetics boutique has introduced an augmented reality (AR) mirror that allows customers to try on products without touching their faces, adhering to social distancing guidelines. The mirror takes a photo of the customer's face and recommends products based on skin texture and features. This innovative technology enables customers to see how products would look on their face without direct contact, making it a convenient and hygienic shopping experience. The move is part of South Korea's efforts to minimize human contact and limit the spread of the coronavirus.

site_title: Hong Kong man accused of terrorism in first use of new China security law
summary: A 23-year-old Hong Kong man, Tong Ying-kit, has become the first person charged with terrorism and inciting separatism under China's new security law. He was accused of ramming his motorcycle into police at a protest, injuring some officers. The law, which punishes crimes of secession, subversion, and terrorism with up to life in prison, has sparked international anxiety and criticism that it aims to crush dissent and democracy in Hong Kong. The European Union has put Hong Kong on its agenda, and the UN has expressed alarm over arrests under the new law.

site_title: Gilead's Covid-19 antiviral remdesivir gets conditional EU clearance
summary: The European Commission has given conditional approval for the use of Gilead's antiviral remdesivir in severe Covid-19 patients, making it the region's first therapy to treat the virus. The approval comes after an accelerated review process and follows a similar decision by the European Medicines Agency. The move aims to address the unmet medical need for Covid-19 treatments, and the EU is negotiating with Gilead to secure doses for the 27 EU countries.

site_title: Liverpool reiterate need for safe celebrations ahead of Villa clash
summary: Liverpool's chief executive, Peter Moore, urged fans to celebrate their Premier League triumph safely at home due to coronavirus concerns. Following their 30-year wait for the title, thousands gathered at Anfield stadium, but some fans launched fireworks in the city, causing a fire at the Royal Liver Building, owned by Everton's majority shareholder. Moore emphasized the need for safe celebrations to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 16.37 points to 1,552.65. The index saw a gain-to-loss ratio of 667-355. Volume reached 6.723 billion lots worth RM3.813 billion.

site_title: Darco Water Tech's audit panel calls for deputy chairman to recuse himself from project
summary: Darco Water Technologies' audit committee has recommended that Deputy Chairman Robert Wang Zhi recuse himself from discussions and decisions on the Nambo project, a waste-management project in Indonesia that he has reportedly been pushing for. The recommendation comes in response to queries from the Singapore Exchange. The company is awaiting Wang's response. This move is related to the company's response to queries from the SGX regarding its involvement in the project.

site_title: Ang Mo Kio incumbents plug estate plans, Reform Party team pledges greater attention
summary: In Singapore's Ang Mo Kio GRC, the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) team presented past and future plans, while the Reform Party (RP) team highlighted residents' grievances and promised dedicated attention. PAP candidates discussed various issues, including healthcare, infrastructure, and education, while RP candidates criticized the PAP's accessibility and vowed to provide better support. The constituency political broadcasts, introduced for this GE, will run nightly until Wednesday, with each team receiving varying amounts of airtime.

site_title: Britain and India's Bharti Global win auction for OneWeb satellite company
summary: Britain and India's Bharti Global have won the auction for OneWeb, a collapsed satellite operator, investing $1 billion in total. Britain will invest $500 million and take a significant equity share, while Bharti will provide commercial and operational leadership. The deal puts the two companies in competition with SpaceX, aiming to develop a low Earth orbit satellite constellation for high-bandwidth and low-latency communications services.

images.alt_text: Britain has joined forces with India's Bharti Global to buy the collapsed satellite operator OneWeb, with the two sides pledging US$1 billion between them to develop a constellation that could boost broadband and other services.

site_title: Singapore factory sentiment negative for fifth month as PMI inches up to 48.0 in June
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sentiment remains negative for the fifth consecutive month, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reading of 48.0 points in June, up 1.2 points from May. The improvement is attributed to the easing of "circuit breaker" measures but weak global demand due to the novel coronavirus pandemic. Key sectors, such as electronics, showed slower growth, and economists predict further headwinds for the manufacturing and trade environment, with some expecting a modest expansion for the full year.

site_title: Tokyo scare squad offers drive-in horror shows amid coronavirus fears
summary: A Japanese performance group, Kowagarasetai, is hosting drive-in horror shows in Tokyo to cater to those afraid of catching the coronavirus. For up to 9,000 yen ($117), audience members drive into a garage, listening to a murder story and sound effects while actors dressed as monsters create a frightful experience. The shows, lasting 15 minutes, will run at weekends in July and August, with up to 11 carloads of people expected per day. This is a response to the group's previous walk-in shows being cancelled due to the pandemic.

site_title: Eurozone business slump eased in June as lockdowns relaxed
summary: The eurozone business slump eased in June as lockdowns relaxed, with the Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 48.5, indicating economic activity is bouncing back quickly but remains lower than before the crisis. Despite this, demand still fell, and firms reduced headcount for a fourth straight month, with unemployment in the bloc edging up in May. Governments and the European Central Bank have implemented unprecedented fiscal and monetary stimulus, which may be paying dividends in supporting ravaged economies.

site_title: Uber is coming to Tokyo after six years in Japan
summary: Uber is expanding to Tokyo after six years in Japan, partnering with three local taxi operators to offer 600 cars in central business districts and popular areas. The company will initially focus on black-car hires, with plans to expand to ride-sharing in the future. This marks a significant step for Uber in Japan, where strict regulations have limited its ride-sharing services. The move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for ride-hailing services in Tokyo.

images.alt_text: After six years in Japan, Uber Technologies is finally coming to Tokyo.

site_title: Philippine broadband firm Converge ICT files for up to US$725m IPO
summary: Converge ICT Solutions, a Philippine fibre broadband services provider, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) of up to 35.92 billion pesos (S$1.01 billion). The company plans to raise funds to build a US$1.80 billion internet backbone for a nationwide fibre internet roll-out. The IPO, if successful, could be the country's biggest on record, but faces regulatory hurdles and volatile markets. Converge ICT has 750,000 residential customers and is banking on increased demand for broadband amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Suspects in Ghosn's Japanese escape stand trial in Turkey
summary: Seven suspects in Carlos Ghosn's escape from Japan to Lebanon via Istanbul are standing trial in Turkey. Ghosn, former Nissan boss, was charged with underreporting his salary and using company funds for personal purposes. He escaped from house arrest in Japan in December 2019. The trial in Turkey focuses on the suspects' alleged involvement in Ghosn's escape. Ghosn denies the charges and remains in Lebanon. The trial is ongoing in Turkey, with the suspects facing potential charges related to the escape.

site_title: Indonesia's anti-trust watchdog levies US$3m in fines on Grab and partner
summary: Indonesia's anti-trust watchdog has fined Grab and its partner, PT Teknologi Pengangkutan Indonesia (TPI), a total of $3.9 million for discriminating against drivers and breaking anti-monopoly laws. Grab has vowed to appeal the verdict, claiming the findings are "unsubstantiated allegations." The Business Competition Supervisory Commission found Grab prioritized drivers from TPI, a Softbank-backed firm, over others. The watchdog imposed a fine of $2.9 million on Grab and $1.9 million on TPI.

site_title: Aramco Trading sells crude from Malaysia as refinery remains shut: sources
summary: Aramco Trading Co, the trading arm of Saudi Aramco, has sold approximately 10 million barrels of crude oil stored in Malaysia since its joint venture refinery with Petronas was shut down in March following a fire. The crude sales occurred amid improved spot demand and prices due to reduced global oil output. The refinery's closure has resulted in the storage of supplies, which were later sold through ship-to-ship transfers at Malaysia's Linggi port to buyers including north Asian refiners and European trading companies.

site_title: Budweiser brewer turns off taps at post-lockdown London office
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world's largest brewer, has reopened its London office, two days after British pubs, with enhanced safety measures in place due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The brewer, known for its frugal culture, implemented social distancing measures, including temperature checks, hand sanitizer stations, and limited desk usage. The move marks a return to normalcy for the company, which had previously maintained a fully remote work setup.

site_title: Germany fears erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy, Merkel says
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed concerns about the erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy, stating that the EU will raise issues such as human rights and the rule of law with China during its presidency. Merkel cited the erosion of Hong Kong's 'one country, two systems' principle as a concern, amid pressure from rights groups and activists over China's national security law. The EU aims to make a trade deal with China a priority, but faces skepticism about achieving ambitious deals due to China's drifting toward isolation.

site_title: Britain to extend pandemic relief in auto finance, high-cost credit
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) proposed extending pandemic relief measures for consumers with car financing contracts or high-cost credit until October 31. The measures include payment deferrals or reduced payments for three months. The ban on repossessions should continue during this period. The proposals are subject to a public consultation, with the FCA finalizing the guidance shortly after.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's retail sales plummeted by a record 52.1% in May, mainly due to the 'circuit breaker' measures. The country had just 880 visitor arrivals in May 2020, down from 1.49m in May 2019. DBS and Schroders launched a multi-asset fund for retirement income planning, while the chief investment officer of EC World Reit was questioned by the Commercial Affairs Department. Singapore shares traded higher on US jobs data, with analysts noting elevated jobless claims. A nationwide parcel locker network is set to be fully rolled out by end-2021, a year ahead of schedule.

site_title: In Aljunied, PAP homes in on residents' welfare; WP focuses on its constructive role in Parliament
summary: In Aljunied GRC, the People's Action Party (PAP) focused on the constructive role they could play in Parliament, while the Workers' Party (WP) emphasized holding the government accountable for various issues. WP's Leon Perera highlighted the party's efforts to scrutinize government spending and corruption. The contrast in approach between the two parties was stark, with the PAP prioritizing welfare and the WP focusing on their role in Parliament.

site_title: US jobs data underpins Singapore stocks
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.62% on July 3, 2020, driven by better-than-expected US jobs data, with payrolls increasing by 4.8 million in June. The Straits Times Index (STI) opened at 2,648.64 and closed at 2,652.94. News of China's services sector expanding at the fastest pace in over a decade also supported the market. However, retail sales in Singapore fell 52.1% in May, the lowest recorded decline since 1986.

site_title: Fiat sticks by terms of PSA deal after dividend cut report
summary: Fiat Chrysler (FCA) has reaffirmed the terms of its merger with France's PSA, despite reports suggesting the Italian-American automaker might spin off assets to reduce a planned €5.50 billion cash payout to shareholders. FCA is sticking to the deal agreed in December, with the merger to be finalized by the first quarter of next year. Options being considered include spinning off the Sevel van business or FCA's Alfa Romeo and Maserati brands to address European Union concerns about the merger's consequences on competition.

site_title: PAP focuses on plans; SPP presses need to ask tough questions in Parliament
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has outlined its plans and achievements in Bishan-Toa Payoh, led by Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen, during a constituency political broadcast. The party stressed its commitment to improving the town and supporting residents through various schemes, including wage support and community scholarships. However, the Singapore People's Party (SPP) pressed for tougher questions in Parliament, calling for greater transparency, accountability, and representation. The SPP also pledged to raise issues such as stagnating wages, higher cost of living, and income inequality.

site_title: South Korea's Moon shuffles top aides in bid to revive North Korea talks
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae-in has shuffled top aides in a bid to revive North Korea talks. He appointed officials known for advocating inter-Korean engagement, including Suh Hoon as national security adviser and Lee In-young as unification minister. The moves aim to restart diplomatic exchanges and economic initiatives stalled due to international sanctions. The nominees will face parliamentary questioning and approval, as Moon seeks to cement progress in inter-Korean relations as his legacy in his final two years in office.

site_title: China beverage giant Wahaha said to weigh IPO above US$1b
summary: China's beverage giant Wahaha is considering an initial public offering (IPO) valued at over $1 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter. The company, founded in 1987, is working on preparations for the share sale and has considered Hong Kong as a potential listing venue. Wahaha joins fellow Hangzhou-based beverage firm Nongfu Spring in seeking a first-time share offering, with Nongfu planning to raise about $1 billion. The IPO could come as soon as next year, providing Wahaha with more resources to compete in China's increasingly competitive food and beverage market.

site_title: Citadelle Corporate Services and Senjo Group under probe following Wirecard review
summary: Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department and Monetary Authority of Singapore are investigating Citadelle Corporate Services and Senjo Group over suspected falsification of accounts and unlicensed trust business. The probe follows a Wirecard review, where US$2.1 billion of the German payment processing company's cash was found to not exist. Documents and records have been obtained, and interviews have been conducted with individuals involved. Citadelle is not licensed to provide trust services in Singapore and has been listed on the Investor Alert List. The investigation is a joint effort between CAD and MAS.

site_title: Japan picks four more 'promising areas' for offshore wind power
summary: Japan's industry ministry has identified 10 areas as potentially suitable for offshore wind farms, with four designated as "promising areas". The new areas include two in the Sea of Japan off Aomori and Akita, and one in the Sea of Japan off Nagasaki. This move follows the government's enforcement of a law last year to enhance wind farm development. The ministry will start a second round of the process to select operators for the promising areas, aiming to boost Japan's offshore wind power market.

site_title: Singapore had 880 visitor arrivals in May 2020, down from 1.49m in May 2019: STB
summary: Singapore recorded 880 visitor arrivals in May 2020, down from 1.49 million in May 2019, as the country remained closed to short-term visitors to combat Covid-19. The average length of stay for each visitor increased to 51.7 days, while year-to-date visitor arrivals were 2.7 million, a 65.7% decline. The government's "circuit breaker" period, which included a 14-day Stay Home Notice for returnees, led to a significant decrease in visitor arrivals and occupancy rates in hotels.

site_title: Hibiki fund says will vote against Accordia Golf Trust divestment unless price is raised
summary: Hibiki Path Advisors, the largest minority unitholder of Accordia Golf Trust, will vote against the proposed divestment of the trust's golf courses unless the price is revised upwards. The current price offered by the sponsor is too low, with Hibiki estimating the trust's value at around S$0.821 per unit. The unitholder argues that the trust's assets generate "significantly attractive cashflow" and that the proposed divestment is not in the best interest of unitholders, citing factors such as suppressed annual dividends and questionable impairment values. Hibiki is seeking a "control premium" to be paid to unitholders to reflect the fees saved by consolidating assets and delisting the trust.

site_title: 169 new Covid-19 patients in Singapore, including 11 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 169 new Covid-19 patients, bringing the total to 44,479. The cases include 11 community cases, with three Singaporeans and eight work pass holders, as well as 177 migrant workers in dormitories. The number of community cases has increased to an average of nine per day, with unlinked cases averaging four per day. The ministry has advised those who visited affected locations to monitor their health closely.

site_title: There will always be crises, so let's boost resilience
summary: The COVID-19 crisis has hit small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, exacerbating their vulnerabilities due to lack of financial buffers and diversification. To boost resilience, SMEs should focus on five key areas: building strong balance sheets through prudent debt management and savings, adopting a lean cost structure, embracing new business models through partnerships and technology, investing in durable assets such as branding and human capital development, and diversifying customers, geographies, and industries. By implementing these strategies, SMEs can improve their chances of surviving and thriving in future crises.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.72% to 22,306.48, following a solid US employment rebound, but investors remained cautious due to a surge in coronavirus cases in Japan. The Nikkei 225 index extended gains on Wall Street, with the broader Topix index also up 0.62%. The rally came despite uncertainty surrounding the US-China trade talks and tariff fog.

site_title: Greece starts clearing ground for Athens property plan after long delay
summary: Greece has begun clearing land for a massive real estate project in Athens, a 1,500-acre site that will transform a disused airport into a luxury tourist resort. The project, led by Lamda Development, aims to create 10,000 jobs and attract thousands of tourists, with a total cost of €8 billion. After years of delays, the demolition of hundreds of buildings has started, paving the way for a complex of luxury homes, hotels, offices, and amenities. The project is a requirement for Greece's international bailouts and is seen as a symbol of the country's new economic era.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, building on gains from the previous session, driven by solid US jobs data. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.4% to 6,262.19 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices advanced 0.3% and 0.2% respectively.

images.alt_text: European stock markets rose modestly at the start of trading on Friday, building on strong gains won the previous session thanks to solid US jobs data.

site_title: Temasek-backed Pine Labs said to weigh bid for part of Wirecard's Asia business
summary: Pine Labs, a Singapore-based payments company backed by Sequoia Capital and Mastercard, is considering a bid for part of Wirecard's Asia business, including its regional point-of-sale business. The potential bid is still exploratory, and no information is available on valuation and finances. Wirecard's Asian operations are clouded by ongoing probes into its operations following an accounting scandal. If successful, the acquisition would allow Pine Labs to expand its operations further in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Gojek names new Vietnam GM; unifies regional branding
summary: Gojek has appointed Duc Phung, current chief operating officer of its Vietnamese business, as the new general manager for Vietnam, replacing Andrew Lee. The company is also streamlining its brands in Vietnam and Thailand into the single "Gojek" branding, previously used in Singapore and Indonesia, to accelerate growth in South-east Asia. The move comes as Gojek continues to expand outside of Indonesia, despite challenging conditions. The rebranding aims to deliver a better experience for users across the region.

site_title: IMDA to roll out full parcel locker network by end-2021
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) announced that a nationwide parcel locker network will be fully rolled out by end-2021, one year ahead of schedule. The first 200 stations will be deployed in Q1 2021 at high footfall areas. The initiative comes in response to the rise in e-commerce shopping and delivery solutions during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week on strong note
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the week on a strong note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.99% to 25,373.12. The gains were driven by a better-than-expected US jobs reading and were boosted by global markets. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw significant gains, rising 2.01% and 1.28% respectively. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and US-EU trade talks, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Acra rejects BDO's application to resign as Mirach Energy auditor
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) has rejected BDO's application to resign as auditor of Mirach Energy and its subsidiary Mirach HP Management, citing the public interest implications involved. BDO's resignation was due to a disagreement with Mirach Energy's management over accounting treatment for an agricultural project in Malaysia. The decision will allow BDO's duties as an auditor to continue until the end of its appointed term. Mirach Energy's board is assessing the impact and will discuss further with BDO and other professionals.

site_title: HSBC pledges more investments in China as tension escalates
summary: HSBC Holdings has pledged to increase investments in China despite escalating tensions, with a new service to provide digital wealth and insurance planning services for mainland Chinese customers. The move comes as the bank faces criticism for its support of China's new security law. HSBC aims to tap into China's vast wealth pool, with households holding approximately $17.71 trillion in investable assets. The bank's efforts are part of its broader strategy to expand its presence in Asia, particularly in mainland China.

site_title: Taiwan expels two Chinese journalists over political shows
summary: Taiwan has expelled two mainland Chinese journalists from the country after a talk show on their channel promoted Beijing's "unifying" with the self-ruled island, further deteriorating ties between the two rivals. The move comes amid a spate of tit-for-tat expulsions of reporters between China and the US. The journalists were ordered to leave due to violating regulations covering mainland journalists, with one of them expressing puzzlement over the order. The expulsions mark a significant escalation in tensions between Taiwan and China, with Beijing viewing Taiwan as its own territory and vowing to one day seize it by force.

site_title: DBS, Schroders launch multi-asset fund for retirement income planning
summary: DBS and Schroders Singapore launched the Schroder Asia More+, a multi-asset fund for retirement income planning. The fund, managed by Schroders Singapore, offers exposure to Asian investment growth themes and is tilted towards Singapore-based assets. It aims to tap into Singapore's long-term growth potential, providing investors with a diversified portfolio.

site_title: Corporate debt defaults spike in Jan-May this year, exceeding 2019 total: Fitch Ratings
summary: Global corporate debt defaults surged in the first five months of 2020, exceeding the total for 2019, according to Fitch Ratings. There were 28 non-financial corporate defaults recorded from January to May, compared to 25 in 2019. The pandemic has put pressure on the corporate sector, with Fitch expecting more defaults in the South American region and erasing over $5 trillion in revenue from its global portfolio this year. The agency notes that the defaults will remain high throughout 2020, with most defaults concentrated in the CCC to C range.

site_title: Australia: Shares mark best week in a month as data drives rebound hopes
summary: Australian shares closed 0.4% higher on Friday, marking their best weekly gain in nearly a month, driven by strong US jobs data and a record surge in domestic retail sales. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.1% before paring gains, with healthcare stocks jumping 2.3% to an over five-week high. The data raised hopes for a recovery in the economic environment, with analyst James Tao citing "green shoots" for the economy.

site_title: Tencent launches new US game studio for global appeal
summary: Tencent Holdings, China's largest social media and video game company, launched a new US-based studio, LightSpeed LA, in California, aimed at expanding its global presence and deriving half its games revenue from overseas. The studio, led by former Rockstar Games veteran Steve Martin, will focus on AAA titles with global appeal. This move is part of Tencent's strategy to create original intellectual property and follows the launch of another studio in the US, TiMi Studios, which hired Halo 4 lead designer Scott Warner.

site_title: Luckin Coffee sticks by chairman despite scandal over fake sales
summary: Luckin Coffee's chairman, Charles Zhengyao Lu, will remain as chairman despite an internal investigation finding the company's 2019 revenue was inflated by 2.12 billion yuan (S$433.9 million). The scandal led to the ousting of two top executives and a 70% decline in shares. Lu's position was put to a vote, but failed to garner enough support. The company will also delist from the Nasdaq and fire 12 more employees involved in the fake transactions.

site_title: Former Panama presidents charged with money laundering
summary: Panama's former presidents, Ricardo Martinelli and Juan Carlos Varela, have been charged with money laundering. Martinelli faces charges related to the "New Business" case, in which government funds allegedly purchased a publishing group during his 2009-14 term. Varela is being investigated for allegedly accepting illegal donations from Brazilian construction giant Odebrecht. The charges mark a significant move against the former allies, who have become enemies since their alliance broke down in 2011. The cases could potentially bring a measure of justice to the public, but the country's history of impunity raises concerns about the outcome.

site_title: Man fined S$100,000 for promoting MLM scheme linked to purported cryptocurrency
summary: A 52-year-old man, Fok Fook Seng, was fined S$100,000 for promoting a multi-level marketing scheme linked to the purported cryptocurrency OneCoin in Singapore. The offence occurred between January 2016 and June 2017. This case is considered the first of its kind under the Multi-Level Marketing and Pyramid Selling (Prohibition) Act.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise on US payrolls jump, log best weekly gain in a month
summary: South Korea's main Kospi index rose 0.8% on Friday, logging its best weekly gain in four weeks, following a record surge in US payrolls in June. The US economy created jobs at a record clip as more restaurants and bars reopened, boosting market sentiment. However, concerns over a global spike in Covid-19 infections capped further gains. South Korea reported 63 new coronavirus cases, triggering tighter social distancing curbs. Foreigners were net buyers of 12 billion won worth of shares, and the Korean won strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: GE quick takes: SDA calls for stricter hiring of foreigners; PSP seeks full disclosure on reserves
summary: Singapore is set to go to the polls on July 10, with 93 seats in 31 constituencies up for contest. The People's Action Party (PAP) has responded to the Singapore Democratic Party's (SDP) "No to 10 million population" claim by stating it is pointless. The SDP has launched its manifesto, calling for a lower 3% GST, stricter hiring of foreigners, and tweaks to the Central Provident Fund scheme. The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) will seek full disclosure on the use of reserves if given seats, while the Workers' Party (WP) will aim to safeguard Singapore and protect it against a single-party dominance.

site_title: Australia retail sales see record surge in May as economy reopens
summary: Australian retail sales surged 16.9% in May, a record high, as lockdowns eased and the economy reopened. This rebound suggests consumer spending won't be weak in the June quarter, giving hope for a quick recovery from its first recession in three decades. Sales in clothing, footwear, and personal accessories increased 129.2% and cafes and restaurants saw a 30.3% surge. The country's strong economic recovery is also reflected in credit card spending and new vehicle sales, with economists monitoring the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting for potential upgrades in forecasts.

site_title: Canada, Sweden pave way for compensation talks with Iran on downed plane
summary: Canada and Sweden have agreed to negotiate compensation with Iran for the families of foreign victims of a Ukrainian passenger plane shot down in January. A memorandum of understanding was signed by Canada, Britain, Ukraine, Sweden, and Afghanistan, paving the way for talks with Tehran. Sweden's Foreign Minister Ann Linde expressed confidence that Iran would pay compensation, while Canada's Foreign Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne warned that Iran's actions, not words, would determine the outcome. Negotiations are expected to take several months or even years.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as strong US jobs data rekindles recovery hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 1.05% to 6,096 points, on track for a fourth straight session of gains, following a record surge in US payrolls for June. The strong jobs data raised hopes for a recovery from the economic downturn. The S&P/ASX 200 index is set to rise nearly 3% for the week, benefiting from stimulus hopes, optimistic factory data, and a successful Covid-19 vaccine trial.

site_title: Ambani's Jio adds Intel backing with 18.95b rupee deal
summary: Intel's investment arm has agreed to pay 18.95 billion rupees (SUS$354.1 million) for a 0.39% stake in Jio Platforms, a digital services business of Reliance Industries. The deal values Jio Platforms at a US$65 billion equity. Intel joins other investors, including Facebook, KKR & Co, and Silver Lake Partners, in backing billionaire Mukesh Ambani's bid to transform Reliance into a digital services giant. The investment aims to fuel digital transformation in India, where Intel has a significant presence.

site_title: Australia's new virus cases fall, but testing blitz runs into resistance
summary: Australia reported 66 new COVID-19 cases in Victoria, a decrease from over 70 cases in the previous four days, as the state's lockdowns in hotspot suburbs appear to be easing. Despite a surge in testing, over 10,000 people have refused to be tested, citing conspiracy theories. The rest of the country has seen a decline in cases, with New South Wales reporting zero new cases. Australia has weathered the pandemic relatively well, with just over 8,000 cases and 104 deaths.

site_title: Malaysia suspends Pakistan pilots after licence fraud revelation
summary: Malaysia's Civil Aviation Authority (CAAM) has temporarily suspended pilots employed by domestic airlines holding Pakistani licenses, following a revelation of dubious qualifications. The regulator evaluated foreign pilots in Malaysia, finding less than 20 Pakistani pilots. The decision comes after Pakistan grounded almost a third of its pilots, with global concern mounting. CAAM is working with the Pakistani Civil Aviation Authority to verify the authenticity of license holders, with those verified to be valid to be reinstated immediately.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank seen cutting key rate again as pandemic persists: poll
summary: Malaysia's central bank is expected to cut its overnight policy rate by at least 25 basis points to 1.75% in its upcoming meeting, according to a Reuters poll. The move is seen as a response to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the country's economy, with the bank citing a "poor outlook for growth and deeply negative inflation." The rate cut would be the third consecutive reduction this year, and is expected to be followed by further easing of monetary policy.

site_title: China inches closer to merging top two brokers in shakeup
summary: China is moving forward with a potential merger of its two largest investment banks, Citic Securities Co and CSC Financial, which would create a US$82 billion powerhouse. Citic Group, the parent of Citic Securities, is set to buy a stake in CSC Financial from state-controlled shareholder Central Huijin Investment, paving the way for consolidation of resources and operations. The proposal has been approved by Communist Party committees and Citic Group is now lobbying the State Council for support before finalizing the details. The merger is expected to be completed in the near future, sparking a wave of consolidation among China's more than 130 brokers.

site_title: Chaos in gold markets ripples to other precious metals
summary: Chaos in gold markets, caused by the global pandemic, is affecting other precious metals, resulting in price dislocations and increased exchange inventories for silver and platinum. Silver and platinum futures have traded at elevated levels relative to spot metals since April, leading to record deliveries and a surge in on-exchange inventories. This is causing banks to shift positions out of New York futures and limiting their exposure to price dislocations. Deliveries for platinum have been particularly high, with the largest single day of deliveries in nearly 25 years.

site_title: Ascendas Reit 'not presently proceeding' with Hyflux moratorium carve-out request
summary: Ascendas Reit is not proceeding with its application to be carved out of Hyflux's debt moratorium, the Singapore water treatment firm said in a court update. The High Court had set revised dates for parties to file affidavits ahead of a July 27 hearing. The court has directed Hyflux to file reply affidavits by July 11, while the unsecured working group of banks will file response affidavits by July 21. If approved, the group plans to appoint judicial managers to oversee Hyflux. The debt moratorium has been extended to July 30.

site_title: Asia: Stocks extend gains as US jobs trump virus worries
summary: Asian stocks rose on Friday as a strong US jobs report beat expectations, despite concerns about the COVID-19 pandemic. The US added nearly 5 million jobs in June, with employment in sectors like leisure and hospitality increasing. The report also sparked optimism about vaccine tests and economic recovery. Asian markets followed, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Shanghai seeing significant gains. However, analysts warned that the recovery may slow due to rising virus cases and potential export restrictions.

site_title: Wireless laser communications startup Transcelestial snags US$9.6m from EDBI, Wavemaker
summary: Singapore-based wireless laser communications startup Transcelestial has secured US$9.6 million in Series A funding from EDBI, Wavemaker, and other investors. The round aims to scale up production of its CENTAURI device, which uses wireless laser communication technology to deliver high-speed Internet connectivity. The startup's goal is to eventually deliver Internet connectivity at up to 100 gigabits per second, aiming to address the growing demand for 5G adoption and support the next wave of growth in the digital economy.

site_title: Google, Temasek said to be in talks to invest in Indonesian e-commerce giant Tokopedia
summary: Google and Temasek Holdings are in talks to invest US$500 million to US$1 billion in Indonesian e-commerce giant Tokopedia, according to people familiar with the matter. The talks may conclude in coming weeks, marking a major boost for one of South-east Asia's biggest e-commerce operators. The investment comes as America's largest internet corporations seek to tap Asia's rapidly growing smartphone-savvy population, with Tokopedia co-founder William Tanuwijaya's company planning to list shares at home and abroad.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.33 points, or 0.48%, to 1,543.61. The index saw 265.84 million lots traded worth RM89.95 million, with 254 gainers outpacing 54 losers.

site_title: ARA Venn's European real estate debt fund bags 200m euros for first close
summary: ARA Venn's European real estate debt fund, Venn Commercial Real Estate Fund II (VeCREF II), has secured 200 million euros (S$313.8 million) from institutional investors for its first close. The fund targets whole loans secured by commercial real estate assets across Western Europe, with a focus on value-add opportunities and a net internal rate of return of "mid to high single digits". The fund aims to provide regular quarterly income distributions to investors. site_title: Retail apocalypse getting darker for UK landlords
summary: The UK retail sector is facing a severe crisis, with the collapse of mall landlord Intu Properties sending shockwaves through the industry. Nine major shopping centers are at risk of being sold at knock-down prices, threatening the values of malls nationwide. Retailers are paying only 36% of third-quarter rent, down from 41% three months earlier, with some stores withholding payments. Landlords are struggling to maximize rent collection, and the government has relaxed planning laws to facilitate store conversions into apartments or warehouses. Cashed-up real estate companies and private equity firms are expected to take advantage of the situation.

site_title: Singapore H1 property investment sales down 45%: C&W
summary: Singapore's property investment volume fell 45% to S$6.13 billion in the first half of 2020, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Commercial sector deals accounted for 66% of Q2's investment volume, with the largest deal being Alibaba Group's purchase of AXA Tower for S$1.68 billion. The hospitality sector remained quiet due to uncertainty over the Covid-19 crisis, while industrial sector volume remained stable. Residential sector investment volume was down 84.9% in Q2, but is expected to continue sluggish in the second half of the year, with full-year volume forecast to be between S$12 billion and S$15 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong businesses welcome new security law despite residents' fear
summary: Hong Kong businesses have welcomed China's new security law, seeing it as a way to restore stability and certainty in the city, despite residents' fears. The law grants mainland Chinese authorities control over Hong Kong, which has been impacted by pro-democracy protests. Many firms, including HSBC and Standard Chartered, have publicly backed the law, and Hong Kong stocks rallied 3% on the news. Analysts say the law may add complexity to doing business in Hong Kong, but the city's status as a gateway to mainland China's vast market remains a major consideration.

site_title: Fitch revises Geo Energy's rating back to 'CC' after failed bond tender offer
summary: Fitch Ratings has revised Geo Energy Resources' long-term issuer default rating to 'CC' from 'C' due to the company's failed bond tender offer and consent solicitation. The rating reflects Fitch's view that a default appears probable within the next 12 months, with Geo Energy facing heightened default risk due to its weak liquidity and inability to meet the condition of 80 million tonnes of coal reserves. The company's liquidity is expected to fall short of its principal payments, including a $132.7 million payment in May 2021.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary:
Here's a summary of the article content in 100 words or less:

Re:Well Rebels offers a silent home wellness retreat, 'A Day With Me', priced from S$100 to S$500. One Orchard Store launched, featuring over 28 Singapore-based designers. Epigram Books released new titles, including Joshua Kam's 'How the Man In Green Saved Pahang, And Possibly the World'. Local stationer PapyPress curated gift packages for wedding guests. WhatIF Foods introduced eco-friendly instant meals. The Old Vic's YouTube channel will show the hit play 'Mood Music'. This Humid House launched online floral products featuring ingredients grown in its own garden. Alternative radio station Singapore Community Radio went online.

site_title: Skyrise Oasis
summary: A Singaporean polytechnic lecturer, Tay Suan Chiang, has collaborated with architect Goy Zhenru to design a two-bedroom apartment at Telok Blangah with stunning views of the Labrador Nature Reserve. The apartment features an L-shaped island counter that serves multiple functions, a custom-made timber bookshelf for a cozy living space, and a daybed with unobstructed views of the reserve. The design incorporates a largely green palette, natural textures, and handmade tiles to bring nature indoors. The result is a unique and functional space that seamlessly integrates work, relaxation, and entertainment.

site_title: Daimler CEO sees drastic pay cuts, deeper restructuring
summary: Daimler CEO Ola Kallenius announced drastic pay cuts and deeper restructuring to overcome the economic fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic. The company faces a "significantly harsher reality" and will need to protect its financial condition and invest in future technologies. Daimler executives will face bigger reductions than rank-and-file workers, with the company aiming to cut 10,000 jobs by 2025. The German auto industry's prospects are slowly improving, but the current situation is "very pessimistic", with companies expecting second-quarter losses. Kallenius will face critical questions from investors at the annual general meeting.

site_title: Fresh Faced
summary: Aesthetic clinics in Singapore are seeing a surge in demand for skin rejuvenation treatments following the reopening of services after the COVID-19 circuit breaker. Doctors Angela Hwee and Gabriel Wong recommend treatments such as the DRx Essential Facial Re/juvenation and Fotona4D, which use advanced technology to brighten, tighten, and hydrate the skin. To ensure safety, clinics are implementing strict sanitation measures and wearing protective gear during treatments. Clients can also opt for at-home kits and customized treatments to address specific skin concerns.

site_title: China's central bank slows monetary easing as economy recovers
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has slowed down monetary easing as the economy recovers, disappointing investors who had anticipated tighter liquidity. Despite a manufacturing survey showing continued improvement in demand and supply, PBOC Governor Yi Gang is taking an unusually long time to deliver a fresh liquidity injection. The central bank is instead signaling an "exit" from looser financial policies, with a focus on targeted stimulus and credit growth. This approach is part of a more restrained strategy than global peers, with the goal of avoiding prolonged monetary easing and its potential risks.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tung Lok Restaurants, a Singapore-based restaurant chain operator, reported a net loss of S$1.2 million in the second half of FY2020, reversing from earnings of S$405,000 a year ago. Revenue dropped 5.9% to S$39.9 million, and losses widened to S$2.6 million for the full year. Chuan Hup Holdings received approval for a 32-level tower development in Perth, while Chasen Holdings agreed to buy industrial land in Penang, Malaysia.

site_title: The Soul of Heritage Food
summary: Home cooks and private chefs in Singapore are sharing their heritage food traditions with others, promoting authentic Asian cuisine and cultural exchange. These cooks, often schooled in traditional recipes from their families or communities, are letting others in on the joys of small-batch cooking and attention to detail. From Indonesian pempek to Sri Lankan sambals, and from Kristang devil curry to Malay curries, these chefs are preserving and honoring their cultural heritage through food. Their passion is not just about cooking, but about sharing their stories and traditions with others, and fostering a sense of community and appreciation for diverse culinary influences.

site_title: Style - Best of Both Worlds
summary: This article features a style segment from the Pre-Fall 2020 collections, showcasing essential gender-neutral basics, including a navy blue suit that can fit all occasions, and a versatile white shirt. No specific key facts, events, or conclusions are mentioned in the provided text, as it appears to be an unrelated list of article titles.

site_title: A slice of Americana
summary: A Singapore-based American hospitality entrepreneur, Gibran Baydoun, has opened a new restaurant, Lucali BYGB, in Brooklyn, New York, offering a unique take on classic American dishes. Meatloaf, a staple of American cuisine, is one of the featured dishes, paired with salads and pasta options. The restaurant's menu also includes Norma's Rigatoni, a tomato-based eggplant sauce pasta dish, and Wildfire Chicken & Burgers, which serves up well-executed burgers and fried chicken. The restaurants aim to bring a taste of American classics to a global audience.

site_title: Boris Johnson's 'New Deal' really depends on Brexit deal
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has outlined a £5 billion post-pandemic economic recovery package, dubbed a "New Deal", but critics argue it is insufficient compared to the scope of the US New Deal. The package risks raising public expectations and failing to address the UK's high unemployment rate, with the Bank of England's chief economist estimating up to half of the workforce is currently unemployed or underemployed. Johnson's decision to push for Brexit, regardless of a trade deal, may undermine his efforts to boost prosperity in disadvantaged areas, potentially leading to increased inequality and damaging his chances of a second term.

site_title: Here's how to pave the road ahead in the 'new normal' of travel
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted the travel industry, with unprecedented lockdowns and travel restrictions. As markets begin to recover, businesses must be opportunistic, agile, and innovative to capture growth opportunities. Domestic travel is expected to be the first step forward, with 60% of searches in the Asia-Pacific and Europe related to domestic experiences. Businesses must navigate uncertainties, remain adaptable, and prioritize partnerships to thrive in the new normal of travel. Those that accelerate quickest will be in a better position to survive, and fostering trust with partners is crucial in this challenging period.

site_title: PSP will fight for full disclosure on use of reserves: Tan Cheng Bock
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) will contest the upcoming Singapore polls and fight for full disclosure on the government's use of reserves. PSP chief Tan Cheng Bock vowed to challenge the ruling People's Action Party's (PAP) parliamentary supermajority and scrutinize the government's stewardship of the country's reserves. If elected, PSP members will push for transparency and accountability, citing concerns over the PAP's handling of key issues such as unemployment and foreign workers.

site_title: Gillman Reopens
summary: Singapore's Gillman Barracks, a premier visual arts cluster, has reopened to visitors after a 10-week closure. Galleries welcomed a large number of art enthusiasts, with many observing artworks more intently than usual. Exhibitions featured works by Singaporean artists Ang Song Nian, Robert Zhao Renhui, Zen Teh, and Marvin Tang, exploring themes of nature and human relationships. Other notable exhibitions include solo shows by Japanese artist Tomoko Kashiki and a group show at Sundaram Tagore Gallery. The NTU Centre For Contemporary Art showcased three film works by acclaimed artists exploring post-colonial struggles.

images.alt_text: Chun Kwang Young at Sundaram Tagore Gallery.
Wah Nu at Richard Koh Fine Art.

site_title: Rise in community cases 'not unexpected' with reopening, testing
summary: Singapore's Multi-Ministry Taskforce on Covid-19 stated that the recent rise in community cases is "not unexpected" due to the country's progression in Phase Two of reopening and expanded testing. The number of community cases, including unlinked ones, has increased since the start of Phase Two, which began two weeks ago. The taskforce emphasized that the current case numbers may not fully reflect the actual effect of Phase Two and the expanded testing.

site_title: US 'troubled' by conduct of Russia constitutional vote
summary: The US expresses concern over Russia's constitutional referendum, citing reports of voter coercion and pressure on opponents. 77.92% of voters backed reforms allowing President Vladimir Putin to run for additional terms until 2036, potentially extending his rule. The US opposes amendments favoring incumbents and extending terms in office where democratic processes are lacking. The European Union also calls for Russia to investigate reported vote irregularities.

site_title: Soulful Septuagenarians
summary: Rock music legends Bob Dylan and Neil Young have released their best albums in years, defying age stereotypes. Dylan's 39th studio album, "Rough And Rowdy Days," is a rich and kaleidoscopic masterpiece that spans history, politics, and pop culture. Young's 40th studio album, "Homegrown," is a lost record from 1974 that he shelved due to heartache, but has now been released. Both albums showcase the artists' continued passion and creativity, inspiring listeners with their stories of love, loss, and human resilience.

site_title: Economy adds jobs at record pace in June, bolstering hopes of rebound
summary: The US economy added 4.8 million jobs in June, a record pace, bolstering hopes for a post-pandemic economic rebound. The unemployment rate fell to 11.1% despite elevated filings for unemployment benefits. The jobs report also showed the economy reopening more broadly, with gains in leisure and hospitality, retail, and most sectors, except mining and logging. However, a resurgence in virus cases and the upcoming expiration of federal unemployment benefits may complicate the recovery, particularly for minority and women workers.

images.alt_text: A resurgence in virus cases has already led to some workers who were rehired following the start of reopening efforts getting laid off once more.

site_title: Hatten Land subsidiaries plan debt restructuring
summary: Hatten Land subsidiaries MDSA Resources and MDSA Ventures have applied to the High Court of Malaya for court leave to call for creditors' meetings to consider a proposed scheme of arrangement and compromise. The move aims to restructure legacy contractual obligations and strengthen the balance sheets of the developers. This comes as the group seeks to make its property development business more resilient in the face of ongoing pressures from the Covid-19 pandemic, which has affected consumer expenditure and property purchases in Malacca.

site_title: Trump cheers US economy after June jobs surge despite virus
summary: President Donald Trump praised the US economy after June's jobs surge, with 4.8 million people returning to work, including 2 million in the leisure and hospitality sector, reducing the jobless rate to 11.1%. This marks the economy's recovery of 7.5 million jobs lost since mid-March due to the pandemic. Trump downplayed the impact of surging Covid-19 cases, which could reverse the recovery.

site_title: Singapore property, bank stocks ride on Hong Kong tailwind
summary: Singapore property and banking stocks with exposure to China rallied alongside Hong Kong-listed mainland developers on Thursday, driven by speculation that China's security legislation could lend stability and attract funds back to Hong Kong. China developers led gains, with local brokers predicting a shift in fund interest towards Hong Kong as US-listed Chinese firms move to list there. This sentiment lifted stocks such as NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer, which was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: A true safeguard is having institutions that do not favour any political party: WP
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh warns that a single-party dominance in Parliament could lead to a small group controlling the country. Singh emphasizes the need for a healthy democracy with multiple parties to prevent power from falling into the wrong hands. He believes having WP MPs in Parliament will safeguard Singapore and protect it from such a scenario, aligning with his party's long-term goal of promoting a competent and honest government.

site_title: US dollar set for biggest weekly drop in a month
summary: The US dollar is set for its biggest weekly drop in a month, with a 0.5% decline against a basket of currencies. The drop comes as upbeat US and European economic data, as well as hopes for a Covid-19 vaccine breakthrough, boost risk appetite. Despite a strong June manufacturing report, the US dollar remains down 2.5% from its 2020 low due to weak global demand.

site_title: BBC cuts 450 regional jobs
summary: The BBC announced plans to cut 450 regional jobs in England, on top of 150 jobs lost in Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. This move is part of a "significant reinvention" of BBC England, which employs over 3,000 people. The cuts are aimed at reducing costs and modernizing local radio stations and TV news.

site_title: Sustainable healthcare needs change in focus
summary: A growing reliance on diagnostics can help prevent diseases and reduce their economic impact. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the importance of proactive interventions and early diagnosis, which can lead to better patient outcomes and efficient resource use. To create a sustainable healthcare ecosystem, there is a need for a fundamental shift in approach, focusing on patient-centered care and changing traditional healthcare structures. Countries that have successfully managed the pandemic through mass testing and quarantine measures, such as South Korea and Singapore, demonstrate the potential of diagnostics in preventing and controlling infectious diseases.

site_title: PAP parliamentary majority is no 'formula for success', says Tan Cheng Bock
summary: Progress Singapore Party (PSP) chief Tan Cheng Bock stated that having a parliamentary majority is not a "formula for success" and that his party will challenge the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) to ensure transparency and accountability. PSP will field the most candidates among opposition parties and ask tough questions on the government's use of reserves if elected. Tan emphasized the need for independence and transparency, saying voters can achieve this through their choice.

site_title: Tesla deliveries slipped in Q2 even as pandemic hit
summary: Tesla reported 90,650 car deliveries in Q2, down 5% from 2019, despite the pandemic's impact on US sales. Sales in China, where Tesla began producing Model 3 sedans in Shanghai, helped the company weather the virus. Analysts attributed the better-than-expected delivery numbers to Tesla's expansion in China, where it avoided import duties. The company's stock price rose 8% on the news, valuing it at nearly $210 billion.

site_title: DBS downgrades Shopee, Garena owner Sea to 'sell'
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Sea Ltd, owner of Shopee and Garena, to "sell" from "fully valued" due to slower-than-expected e-commerce sales, higher losses in its e-wallet business, and rich valuations. Despite this, DBS maintains its target price of US$72.50. Sea shares closed at US$114.46 on Wednesday, up 6.6% from the previous day. The downgrade comes after the company reported disappointing earnings.

site_title: US factory orders rebound in May
summary: US factory orders rebounded 8.0% in May, reversing a 13.5% decline in April, suggesting a turnaround in manufacturing. However, business spending is expected to contract again in the second quarter due to cheaper crude oil. The Institute for Supply Management reported a 14-month high in national factory activity in June. Transportation equipment orders surged 82.0% in May, while inventories and shipments of manufactured goods increased. Despite a rebound in factory orders, the economy is expected to contract at a record 36.8% annualized rate in the April-June quarter.

site_title: UniCredit close to selling US$1.7b bad debt to Italy banks
summary: UniCredit is close to selling €1.5 billion (US$2.35 billion) in bad corporate loans to Italian banks Illimity Bank and Guber Banca, signaling a thriving market for Italian credit despite the pandemic. The lender is also set to finalize the sale of an €800 million package of soured debt to Guber and Banca Ifis. This sale marks a significant development in the Italian banking sector, demonstrating resilience in the market for non-performing loans.

site_title: EU banks to take on Visa, Mastercard with new payments system
summary: Sixteen European banks, including those from Germany, France, and three other euro zone countries, have agreed to launch a unified European payment system by 2022, aiming to compete with Visa and Mastercard. The system will be digital, covering various transactions, and will be a "truly European" alternative. The European Central Bank has welcomed the move, citing the need for a more independent and robust payments market. The initiative is expected to become operational in 2022, with an interim company set up in Brussels.

site_title: US: Wall St jumps at open as US job growth accelerates
summary: US stocks jumped at the open on Thursday as the US economy added jobs at a record pace in June, bolstering post-pandemic economic rebound hopes. The Nasdaq hit a record high, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rising. The Nasdaq Composite gained 1.12% to 10,268.67, while the S&P 500 opened higher by 0.89% at 3,143.64.

site_title: US trade deficit widens as exports fall to lowest level since 2009
summary: The US trade deficit widened 9.7% to $54.6 billion in May, with exports falling to their lowest level since 2009, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Exports plummeted 4.4% to $144.5 billion, and services exports dropped 5.8% to $90.0 billion. Imports slipped 0.9% to $199.1 billion, the lowest since July 2010. This decline in imports is expected to contribute to a sinking gross domestic product in the second quarter, with the Atlanta Federal Reserve forecasting a 36.8% annualized GDP contraction.

site_title: Chuan Hup's associated firm gets nod to develop residential tower in Perth
summary: Chuan Hup's associated company, 240 Adelaide Terrace Pty Ltd, has received approval from Perth's development assessment panel to develop a 32-level residential tower in a prime area of Perth. The project, located at 240 Adelaide Terrace, will feature 119 apartments with resort-style facilities, including a rooftop viewing deck with outdoor cabana and barbecue area. Construction is expected to begin in January 2021, marking a significant development in the Perth property market.

site_title: Hundreds arrested after European police hack crime chat network
summary: European police have arrested over 800 people after hacking into the EncroChat network, a encrypted phone system used by organised crime groups. The operation, led by French and Dutch police, allowed authorities to read millions of messages "over the shoulders" of suspects. Arrests were made in countries including Britain, Norway, Spain, and Sweden, with 746 people arrested in Britain alone. The operation is seen as a "massive breakthrough" against organised crime.

site_title: Singapore properties, banks ride HK tailwind
summary: Singapore property and banking stocks, exposed to China, rallied alongside Hong Kong-listed Mainland developers, driven by speculation on stability and investor interest. Shares of China Evergrande soared 5% in Hong Kong, while Singapore stocks like City Developments and CapitaLand also rose. The Straits Times Index ended 0.87% higher, with healthcare and PPE stocks also seeing gains.

site_title: WP supports broad-based, inclusive economic growth: Sylvia Lim
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party (WP) supports broad-based and inclusive economic growth, chairperson Sylvia Lim stated in a recent episode of Hammer Show. The party emphasizes the need to boost productivity, help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) compete, and implement a redundancy insurance scheme to ensure good jobs for the long-term. WP candidates proposed loaning productivity-enhancing equipment to construction companies and providing support for local start-ups in green technology. They also reiterated their proposal for a national redundancy insurance scheme, which would provide a social safety net for workers affected by job losses.

site_title: UOB to make second cut on rates on flagship savings account this year
summary: Singapore's third-largest retail bank, UOB, will lower interest rates on its flagship savings account, UOB One, from August 1. The rate cuts will apply to account balances up to S$75,000, with customers meeting minimum card spend requirements seeing interest payouts reduced to 0.25% per annum. This is the second rate revision this year, following an earlier cut in May. The move reflects the prolonged low-interest rate environment, as central banks provide economic support amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hoe Leong re-appoints executive director 2 days after his failed re-election
summary: Hoe Leong Corp re-appointed Joseph Liew Yoke Pheng as an executive director just two days after his failed re-election at the company's annual general meeting. The re-election was voted down due to late submission of proxy forms from substantial shareholders United Overseas Bank and DBS. Liew was initially re-appointed as executive director, board chairman, and member of the nominating committee on June 26, but this appointment will be subject to a shareholder vote at the next general meeting.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 21.85 points to 1,536.28 on Thursday, with a trading volume of 5.905 billion lots worth RM4.027 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 701 to 334, driven by a positive sentiment despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: WP apologises for not taking part in televised debate in Mandarin
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh has apologized for not participating in a live, televised debate in Mandarin on Wednesday. However, he claimed it didn't reflect the party's difficulty in reaching out to the Mandarin-speaking population. The party will instead field a representative for a live discussion organized by Chinese daily Lianhe Zaobao on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore watchdog raises concerns about LSE's proposed Refinitiv acquisition
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) has raised concerns about the London Stock Exchange's (LSE) proposed $27 billion acquisition of Refinitiv, citing potential issues with the provision of foreign exchange benchmarks to rival providers. The CCCS will conduct a second phase review to assess the matter further. This comes after European Union antitrust regulators warned about the possible anti-competitive effects of the deal. The CCCS is uncertain whether competitors can mitigate the risk of foreclosure and whether existing regulations overseas can address competition concerns.

site_title: Vote PAP for a harder push for economic transformation, Heng Swee Keat urges
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) plans to step up efforts for economic transformation, aiming to make the economy more innovative and resilient. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for a stronger push for economic growth, improved education, and better support for seniors and SMEs. He also highlighted the need for partnerships to protect Singapore from climate change and the rising seas, and to emerge stronger after the COVID-19 pandemic. The PAP is seeking to secure votes by promising a better future for all Singaporeans, with a focus on providing more good jobs and a better life.

site_title: Companies tap Covid-19 skills upgrading scheme more than 60,000 times
summary: Singapore's Enhanced Training Support Package (ETSP) has been taken up over 60,000 times since its launch in February, with nearly 800 companies participating. The scheme provides 90% absentee payroll support for employees undergoing training, capped at $10 an hour. Senior Minister of State Chee Hong Tat emphasized the importance of workforce development in competing for new investments and jobs amidst global shifts. The support package has been extended to cover courses until January 2021.

site_title: GE2020: PAP has not delivered on promise to ease cost of living burden, says SDP's Chee Soon Juan
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) has failed to deliver on its promise to ease the cost of living burden, according to opposition party chief Chee Soon Juan. Chee criticized the government's hikes in water prices, town council fees, healthcare costs, and electricity rates, among others. The SDP's "4Yes1No" campaign proposes suspending the GST, introducing retrenchment benefits, and providing a monthly income for retirees. The opposition parties, including the SDP, Peoples Voice, and National Solidarity Party, are campaigning on issues such as income disparity and affordable housing.

site_title: World food price index rises in June, first increase in 2020: UN
summary: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization reported that the world food price index rose 2.4% in June, marking its first increase in 2020, as prices rebounded from sharp declines triggered by the coronavirus pandemic. The vegetable oil, sugar, and dairy product prices surged to multi-month highs, while cereal and meat prices remained under downward pressure. The FAO revised its forecast for the 2020 cereal season, predicting a 3% increase in global output and a record high in world cereal trade.

site_title: PE and VC fund-raising hit a snag in Q1: Preqin
summary: Private equity and venture capital firms faced headwinds in fund-raising during Q1 2020, with no funds closed in South-east Asia.
