Funds in other parts of Asia raised 48% less capital than in Q1 2019. Preqin attributes this to the composition of investors, with 79% based offshore. Despite this, the outlook for medium to long term is positive.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees oil demand returning to pre-coronavirus levels by 2022
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts global oil demand will return to pre-coronavirus levels by 2022, driven by a rebound in commuting and private transportation, as well as government infrastructure spending. Demand is expected to fall 8% in 2020, recover 6% in 2021, and fully recover to pre-pandemic levels by 2022, with June demand still 12% below last year's levels.

site_title: US job growth accelerates in June; unemployment rate falls
summary: The US economy added 4.8 million jobs in June, the largest increase since 1939, as the COVID-19 recession appears to be over. The unemployment rate fell to 11.1% from 13.3% in May. The job gains are attributed to the reopening of businesses and the government's Paycheck Protection Programme. However, a surge in coronavirus cases threatens the recovery, with several states scaling back reopenings and sending workers home. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell cautioned that the outlook is uncertain and dependent on containing the virus.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Banks in Singapore have agreed to develop "best practices" for commodity financing, with the support of government agencies. Temasek has delayed its annual reporting to September due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Singapore has added China to its 12-country pledge to keep trade open amid the virus crisis. Property investment sales in Singapore fell 45% in the first half of the year, while private equity and venture capital fund-raising hit a snag in Q1. Over 60,000 employees from nearly 800 companies have taken up training places under the Enhanced Training Support Package.

site_title: 1.2m Singaporean households to get S$340m in utilities support
summary: The Singaporean government will provide a one-off S$100 subsidy to 1.2 million households, amounting to S$340 million, to support utility bills during the pandemic. The Solidarity Utilities Credit will be credited to households' July or August bills, on top of existing U-Save GST Vouchers and Special Payments for HDB flat residents. Eligible households will also receive additional U-Save rebates and rebates equivalent to at least 2-8 months of utility bills.

site_title: Banks in Singapore band together to lift standards for commodity financing
summary: Banks in Singapore have formed a working group to develop industry standards for commodity financing, a move aimed at raising standards and improving practices. The initiative, supported by government agencies, involves 20 banks, including major lenders such as HSBC, DBS, and OCBC. The working group will propose new guidelines to enhance transparency and risk management in commodity financing, which is a critical sector in Singapore's economy. This collaborative effort is expected to improve the overall quality of commodity financing in Singapore.

site_title: Novartis agrees to US$642m settlement over kickbacks
summary: Novartis, a Swiss pharmaceutical giant, has agreed to pay over US$642 million to settle a US Department of Justice lawsuit alleging kickbacks to doctors and misuse of foundations to funnel payments for its medications, including Gilenya and Afinitor. The settlement also covers allegations of bribing doctors to prescribe the company's medication. The company will pay the settlement to resolve these claims and avoid further litigation.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn, others hit as India holds up imports from China: sources
summary: India's customs officers have disrupted operations at Apple supplier Foxconn's plants in southern India, holding back shipments from China and imposing additional clearances without formal orders. Over 150 Foxconn shipments, containing smartphone and electronic parts, are stuck at the port of Chennai, with some being cleared slowly. The delays also affect other foreign firms, including Dell and MG Motor, which have committed significant investments in India. The Indian government has said the inspection measures are temporary and will ease soon, but tensions between the two countries build amid border clashes.

site_title: Exxon signals Q2 loss in a row on production, refining hit
summary: ExxonMobil Corp. reported that its oil and gas producing and refining businesses will report operating losses in the second quarter due to lower oil prices, which have dropped 35% since January. The company estimates a loss of $2.3 billion, or 52 cents per share, marking the second quarterly loss this year. Its refining unit is expected to suffer losses between $800 million and $1.1 billion, larger than its first quarter loss. The losses are attributed to a low point for oil and gas prices, refining margins, and production.

images.alt_text: Exxon Mobil Corp's oil and gas producing and refining businesses will report operating losses in the second quarter, it said in a regulatory filing on Thursday, setting the stage for the company to post another quarterly loss this year.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries' urban business forms JV to expand warehousing properties in Vietnam
summary: Sembcorp Industries' urban business has formed a joint-venture company, Sembcorp Infra Holdings, with CRE Asia to expand warehousing properties in Vietnam. The joint-venture company, with Sembcorp Development holding 70% ownership, aims to facilitate the expansion of its Vietnam Singapore Industrial Park. The move is expected to have minimal impact on Sembcorp Industries' earnings per share and net asset value per share for the financial year ending December 31, 2020.

site_title: End of lockdown fails to boost jobs market in Spain
summary: Spain's end of coronavirus lockdown failed to boost its jobs market, with the number of jobless people rising to 3.86 million, a 0.13% increase in June. The 900,000 jobs lost at the pandemic's peak have not been regained, and the tourism sector remains inactive. The Labour Ministry reported 847,197 more jobless people in June compared to the same month last year.

site_title: Vaniday relaunches as one-stop beauty, wellness platform with marketplace
summary: Vaniday, a Singapore-based beauty and wellness platform, has relaunched as an all-in-one platform featuring a marketplace, digital magazine, and improved loyalty program. The company, led by CEO Ruth Teo, has expanded its services to include a new online marketplace, VaniMall, and a digital magazine, VaniZine. The platform now allows users to discover and book beauty deals and services, as well as buy and sell curated beauty products. Vaniday aims to triple its merchant pool within the next 12 months and has already onboarded 10% more merchants since its soft launch in February.

site_title: Halcyon Agri obtains up to US$75m sustainability-linked loan from Deutsche Bank
summary: Deutsche Bank has extended a sustainability-linked loan of up to $75 million to Halcyon Agri Corp, a natural rubber supplier, to support the company's rubber plantations in Cameroon and Malaysia. The loan, which includes an accordion feature to upsize to $75 million, will be used to maintain plantations and promote the Cameroon Outgrower Programme, which aims to provide food security and boost local farmers' income. The loan complements Halcyon's existing sustainability strategy and sets a new standard for the rubber industry with its comprehensive key performance indicators.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets recover at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index climbing 0.7% to 6,202.03 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices rising 1.0% and 0.8% respectively. This rebound follows a decline on Wednesday, with the three indices closing between 0.2 and 0.4% lower. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, as investors remained positive despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Australian scientists discover ancient underwater Aboriginal sites
summary: Australian scientists have discovered two ancient underwater archaeological sites off Western Australia's west coast, dating back over 7,000 years. The submerged sites, located in the Dampier Archipelago, contain hundreds of stone tools made by Aboriginal people. The findings are significant, providing insights into the cultural and technological development of Australia's first peoples. The artefacts, including cutting and grinding tools, were retrieved by divers and are being analysed for precise dating, with radiocarbon dating and sea-level changes analysis confirming the site's age.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks post strong gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 2.85% on Thursday, following a global advance on hopes for a virus vaccine. The Hang Seng Index reached 25,124.19, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 2.13% and 1.25%, respectively. The gains came despite concerns over a draconian security law imposed by Beijing, which raised questions about Hong Kong's future as a business hub.

site_title: Too early to discuss Phase 3 or easing of rules: multi-ministry taskforce
summary: Singapore's Multi-Ministry Taskforce on Covid-19 says it's too early to discuss Phase 3 of reopening or easing safe distancing rules, despite rising community cases. The taskforce emphasizes the need to monitor the current situation before considering further relaxation. As of Thursday, 188 new cases were confirmed, including 10 community cases, with migrant workers making up the majority of cases. Authorities urge the public to stay vigilant and uphold safe-distancing measures. The taskforce had previously stated it would take "months" to reach Phase 3, operating in a "steady state" before a vaccine is available.

site_title: GE quick takes: MOM, Heng Swee Keat refute opposition claims
summary: Singapore will hold its General Election on July 10, with all 93 seats in 31 constituencies up for contest. The Workers' Party (WP) chairman Sylvia Lim stated the party will not be affected by the retirement of a leader. Progress Singapore Party (PSP) chief Tan Cheng Bock criticized the expanded Non-Constituency MP (NCMP) scheme, stating it's a ploy to discourage opposition voting. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat clarified he did not suggest increasing Singapore's population to 10 million, contrary to Chee Soon Juan's claims. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) also refuted PSP's figure of 100,000 unemployed local PMETs.

site_title: What Phase 2 might mean for selected entertainment, F&B and retail segments
summary: Singapore has entered Phase 2 of reopening, with key segments of the economy, including retail, entertainment, and F&B, set to re-open under safe management measures. Video technology will play a crucial role in ensuring the safe recommencement of activities and reopening of these sectors. Businesses can use video management solutions to regulate access, manage crowds, and provide data on consumer preferences. However, concerns about data privacy remain, and businesses must prioritize data protection and comply with regulations. The Singapore government has allocated S$500 million for digital transformation, encouraging businesses to adopt video technologies to mitigate risks and maximize profits.

site_title: West Mall, Paya Lebar Square and IMM among places Covid-19 patients visited
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has added West Mall, Paya Lebar Square, and IMM to the list of places visited by Covid-19 patients. Patients who visited these places are advised to monitor their health closely for two weeks. The MOH also reported 188 new coronavirus cases, including a Filipino national who tested positive after returning from the UK. The 10 community cases include seven Singaporeans, one permanent resident, and two work permit holders. With 418 cases discharged, 39,417 patients have recovered, and 201 remain in hospital.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Bullard warns of a financial crisis amid pandemic: FT
summary: Federal Reserve President James Bullard warns of a potential financial crisis due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing a wave of "substantial bankruptcies" that could lead to a crisis. Bullard suggests keeping lending facilities in place to mitigate the impact.

images.alt_text: St Louis Federal Reserve president James Bullard told the Financial Times that a wave of "substantial bankruptcies" triggered by the coronavirus pandemic could lead to a financial crisis.

site_title: CH Offshore loses appeal against arbitration award
summary: CH Offshore has lost an appeal against a final arbitration award granted to three shipbrokers, Internaves Consorcio Naviero, Martima Altair Petromar, and Lamat Offshore Marine, in favor of $3.7 million unpaid brokers' commissions and damages. The arbitration tribunal had previously ruled in favor of the shipbrokers in 2019, and the court upheld this decision on July 1, dismissing CH Offshore's appeal. The company may still attempt to further appeal, but there is no guarantee of success.

site_title: Singapore property investment sales down 45% in H1: Cushman & Wakefield
summary: Singapore's property investment sales plummeted 45% in the first half of the year to S$6.13 billion, with commercial sector deals accounting for 66% of the total. The hospitality sector remained quiet due to uncertainty over the Covid-19 crisis, while industrial and residential sectors saw stable and muted volumes respectively. Experts predict a sluggish market sentiment in the second half, with full-year property investment volume expected to be between S$12 billion and S$15 billion.

images.alt_text: Deals in the commercial sector accounted for 66 per cent of Q2's investment volume as big-ticket commercial deals make their return.

site_title: Shampoo is big business in Indonesian haircare market
summary: Indonesia's haircare market is a significant industry, with shampoo sales accounting for half of the country's $1.2 billion market in 2019. The market is expected to reach $25 trillion by 2024. GlobalData reports that consumer multinationals dominate the market, with 86.1% of shampoo sales by value. Demand for halal-certified products and natural ingredients is rising, while convenience stores account for 44% of haircare product sales. The ongoing pandemic's impact on the market is not accounted for in the projections.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 3-week high on hopes of virus vaccine, fresh stimulus
summary: Australian shares rose 1.7% to a three-week high, led by financials and technology stocks, as a promising COVID-19 vaccine trial and fresh stimulus boosted economic recovery hopes. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,032.7, its highest level since June 11. Technology stocks jumped 3.7%, with Afterpay and Citi more than doubling their price targets, while heavyweight financials gained 1.9%. The optimism outweighed concerns over rising cases in the US, with analysts citing a V-shaped recovery story.

site_title: Vanguard and State Street are resisting the new ETF craze
summary: Vanguard Group and State Street Corp are hesitant to adopt active, non-transparent (ANT) exchange-traded funds (ETFs), despite their potential to attract trillions of dollars to the US$4.3 trillion ETF market. These ANTs offer benefits of traditional ETFs with reduced disclosure requirements, making them a conduit for stock-picking strategies. The two industry giants are in a wait-and-see mode, preferring to observe the market's development before deciding on their involvement.

site_title: UK will ditch travel quarantine for 75 countries: Daily Telegraph
summary: The UK will lift its 14-day quarantine period for arrivals from 75 countries, including most European destinations, Turkey, and certain territories, allowing people to travel for holidays. The decision aims to boost the tourism industry, which has been severely impacted by the quarantine rules. The move is part of a broader effort by the government to ease travel restrictions and encourage international travel.

site_title: Seoul: Shares surge on upbeat US data, virus vaccine hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.36% to close at 2,135.37, driven by upbeat US factory data and positive developments in a COVID-19 vaccine trial. The rebound in US economic indicators suggests the worst of the coronavirus crisis has passed, according to analyst Shin Joong-ho. Despite foreign net selling of $10.41 million, the Kospi index still ended higher.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades Sea to 'sell' on e-wallet drag, rich valuations
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Sea Ltd to "sell" from "fully valued" due to slower-than-expected e-commerce sales, higher losses in the e-wallet business, and rich valuations. The analyst, Sachin Mittal, maintained a target price of US$72.50 but expects the gaming arm to need a 50% growth in adjusted operating profit and e-commerce revenue to reach the bull-case fair value of US$90. The company faces risks from revised tax regulations and increasing customer acquisition costs for its e-wallet platform.

site_title: Fitch revises Geo Energy's rating back to CC after failed bond tender offer
summary: Fitch Ratings has revised Geo Energy's long-term issuer default rating to CC from C due to the company's failed bond tender offer and consent solicitation. The rating change reflects Fitch's view that a default appears probable within the next 12 months, primarily due to Geo Energy's limited liquidity and inability to meet the condition of 80 million tonnes of coal reserves. The company's liquidity is expected to fall short of its principal obligations, including a $132.7 million payment in May 2021.

site_title: Australia weighs 'opportunities' for Hong Kong people after security law
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison hinted at offering visas to Hong Kong citizens following China's imposition of a new security law, similar to Britain's plan to grant leave to Hong Kong citizens with British National Overseas passports. The move comes amid strained Australia-China relations and concerns over Hong Kong's freedoms. Morrison stated that the Australian government is "prepared to step up and provide support" and is considering proposals to provide similar opportunities, although no details were provided.

site_title: Singapore adds China to 12-country pledge to keep trade open amid virus crisis
summary: Singapore has added China to a 12-country pledge to maintain open trade amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The joint ministerial statement aims to ensure supply chains remain open, avoiding export controls, tariffs, and non-tariff barriers. The countries involved, including Singapore, New Zealand, and 10 others, affirm their commitment to keeping trade lines open and removing restrictions on essential goods, particularly medical supplies. The move is seen as a strong signal of collective commitment to maintaining supply chain continuity during the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge up in cautious trading
summary: Tokyo stocks edged up 0.11% on Thursday, following a rally on the Nasdaq, but traders remained cautious due to growing coronavirus infections worldwide. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 22,145.96, while the Topix index increased to 1,542.76.

site_title: Broker's take: Koufu's Deli Asia deal will 'bring in the dough', CGS-CIMB says
summary: Koufu Group's proposed S$22 million acquisition of Deli Asia, a fried food and dough products supplier, is deemed an "attractive" deal by CGS-CIMB, boosting earnings per share. The research firm maintains its "add" call on Koufu and targets 86 Singapore cents. The acquisition is expected to bring in revenue and increase the company's earnings.

site_title: Judge lifts ban on 'tell-all' book by Trump's niece
summary: A New York appeals court judge has lifted a temporary ban on the publication of Mary Trump's "tell-all" book, titled "Too Much and Never Enough: How My Family Created the World's Most Dangerous Man". The book, which criticizes President Donald Trump, had been blocked by his brother Robert Trump over a non-disclosure agreement. The judge's ruling allows publisher Simon & Schuster to print and distribute the book, which Mary Trump's attorney says is "very good news". The book is set to reveal family secrets and Mary Trump's role in the New York Times reporting on Trump's finances.

site_title: Singapore to tackle climate change by developing carbon capture tech
summary: Singapore has signed a deal with four local companies to develop a carbon capture, utilisation and sequestration (CCUS) system, a technology that captures and stores carbon dioxide to mitigate emissions. The joint venture aims to create a low-carbon economy and achieve Singapore's climate goal of halving emissions by 2050. The CCUS system will utilize cryogens, membranes, and hydrogen to convert carbon dioxide into novel chemicals, materials, and fuels, offering potential for growing new industries. The project is expected to help Singapore reduce its greenhouse gas emissions and become a global hub for low-carbon technologies.

site_title: India's Prime Minister Modi shuts Weibo account after app ban
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi had his Sina Weibo account deleted at the request of the Indian embassy, following India's ban on dozens of Chinese apps, including Sina Weibo and TikTok. The move comes amid heightened tensions between the two countries after a border skirmish. Modi, who had over 200,000 followers, was an infrequent user of the platform. The account closure is seen as a rare instance of a foreign leader sharing private information on Chinese social media, and follows India's decision to ban Chinese apps.

site_title: Life science investor Novo Holdings to open Asia office in Singapore
summary: Novo Holdings, a life science investor, plans to open an office in Singapore in August, marking its entry into the Asian market. The office will be led by Amit Kakar, who will focus on investments and partnerships in Singapore, China, Japan, and Southeast Asia. Novo Holdings aims to explore investment opportunities in three areas: Novo Growth, Principal Investments, and Novo Ventures. The company's CEO, Kasim Kutay, sees the region as a "compelling area" due to its growth, demographics, and innovation focus.

site_title: China tech giant Tencent duped by saucy scammers
summary: Chinese tech giant Tencent was duped by impostors posing as Lao Gan Ma representatives, a famous chilli sauce brand, in a case that nearly landed the two companies in court. Tencent sued Lao Gan Ma for unpaid advertising fees under a 2019 contract, but the chilli maker claimed it never entered the agreement. Police detained three suspects aged 36-40 who faked a Lao Gan Ma company seal to obtain online game package codes from Tencent, which they then resold for financial gain, sparking widespread ridicule on social media.

site_title: Russians grant Putin right to extend his rule until 2036 in landslide vote
summary: Russia's Constitutional Commission announced that Vladimir Putin has been granted the right to extend his rule until 2036 in a landslide vote, with 77.9% of votes supporting the changes. Critics, including opposition politician Alexei Navalny, claim the vote was falsified on an industrial scale and that Putin will rule until the age of 83. The changes allow Putin to run for two more six-year terms, cementing his position as Russia's longest-serving leader.

site_title: UIC chief Lim Hock San to retire on Sept 30
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) CEO and President Lim Hock San will retire on September 30, 2020, after 28 years in both roles. He has contributed significantly to the company's growth, increasing its total assets from S$3.8 billion in 1991 to S$9 billion in 2019. UIC's board is reviewing internal and external candidates to replace Lim.

site_title: Singtel Optus to launch new satellite in 2023 for Australia, New Zealand
summary: Singtel's Optus subsidiary has secured a contract with Airbus Defence and Space to launch a new software-defined satellite, Optus 11, for Australia and New Zealand in 2023. The satellite will be deployed at an existing orbital location 36,000 kilometers above Earth and will serve as a cornerstone for pay-television broadcaster Sky New Zealand, under a revised agreement with Optus.

site_title: Japan to shut or mothball 100 ageing coal-fired power plants
summary: Japan plans to shut or mothball 100 of its 114 older, inefficient coal-fired power plants by 2030, according to the Yomiuri newspaper. This marks a significant shift in the country's reliance on coal, with the goal of reducing its energy supply mix to 26% from 32% by 2030. The move comes after criticism from NGOs and companies over Japan's high fossil fuel use, and follows the Fukushima nuclear disaster in 2011. The government views the closures as a necessary step to meet its climate change targets.

site_title: Luckin probe ends ahead of meeting seeking chairman's ouster
summary: Luckin Coffee's internal investigation into fabricated transactions has concluded ahead of a special meeting where the company's chairman, Charles Lu Zhengyao, is expected to be removed. The investigation found that transactions dating back to April 2019 inflated net revenue by 2.12 billion yuan and costs by 1.34 billion yuan in 2019. The company has already fired several executives and employees, and will consider removing Lu as a director and chairman, as well as taking disciplinary actions against 15 others. Luckin's board will meet on Thursday to make these decisions.

site_title: Rebekah Neumann buys back assets of school inside WeWork
summary: Rebekah Neumann, co-founder of WeWork, has purchased the assets of WeGrow, the private elementary school she founded within WeWork, for an undisclosed price. The school, which cost over $40,000 per year, will now operate as "Students of Life For Life" (SOLFL), a new school combining remote and physical learning. This move comes after WeWork's collapse and Neumann's legal battle with SoftBank Group. Neumann aims to salvage her passion project and provide a worthy education for her children.

images.alt_text: Rebekah Neumann has purchased the assets of WeGrow, the private elementary school she founded within WeWork, back from the company, suggesting she could salvage her passion project after the co-working startup co-founded by her husband imploded.

site_title: Twitter removes image tweet by Trump over NYT copyright complaint
summary: Twitter has removed an image tweet by US President Donald Trump after receiving a copyright complaint from the New York Times. The image, taken by a NYT photographer in 2015, was used in a meme by Trump in June 2020. The tweet has been replaced with a message stating that the image has been removed due to a copyright complaint. This is the latest instance of Trump's content being flagged or removed by Twitter, which has previously challenged his tweets over copyright and policy violations.

site_title: US sees record 52,000 new virus cases in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US reported a record 52,898 new Covid-19 cases in 24 hours, according to Johns Hopkins University, bringing the total number of cases to 2,682,270. The death toll also increased to 128,028 with 706 new fatalities. This marks a new one-day record for infections in the country, which have been hovering around 40,000 in recent days.

site_title: British musicians warn of crisis in live music industry
summary: British musicians, including Paul McCartney and Ed Sheeran, have written an open letter to the British government warning of a crisis in the live music industry due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. They called for government support to help businesses and jobs survive until 2021, when they hope to reopen. The industry, which added £4.50 billion to the British economy and supported 210,000 jobs in 2019, is at risk of mass insolvencies and the end of the world-leading industry. The government has promised to provide a clear roadmap back to normal operations.

site_title: Hatten Land subsidiaries plan debt restructuring
summary: Hatten Land's subsidiaries, MDSA Resources and MDSA Ventures, are planning debt restructuring as the company seeks to strengthen its balance sheets amid the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the property market. The subsidiaries have applied to the High Court of Malaya for a court-ordered meeting to consider a proposed scheme of arrangement and compromise with creditors. This move comes as Hatten Land adjusts salaries and reduces expenses to conserve financial resources and achieve a more sustainable capital structure.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as recovery signs offset new lockdowns
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, driven by hopes for a vaccine and economic recovery, despite new lockdowns and concerns over a second wave of COVID-19. Hong Kong led the gains, followed by Tokyo, Sydney, and Shanghai, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.6%. The US stock market also reached new highs, with investors awaiting June jobs data. However, the World Health Organization warned that the pandemic is not over, and the US experienced a spike in new cases, prompting some states to reimpose containment measures.

images.alt_text: Asian markets rose on Thursday following a record lead from Wall Street, with investors cheered by hopes for a vaccine, more positive economic data and further lockdown easing in Europe.

site_title: US delays diplomats' return to China amid concerns over Covid-19 testing, quarantine
summary: The US has postponed flights for dozens of American diplomats returning to China due to disagreements over Covid-19 testing and quarantine procedures. The delay comes as tensions between the US and China remain high, with the global pandemic intensifying worldwide. Diplomats are concerned about being separated from their families if they test positive, and Washington is seeking assurances from Beijing. The US has not reached an agreement on Chinese testing and quarantine procedures, citing concerns about diplomatic inviolability. Diplomats had planned to return to China in July, but the flights have been rescheduled, with no new date announced.

site_title: Japan's NTT Data to set up research centre in Singapore
summary: NTT Data, a Japanese data solutions firm, plans to establish a research centre in Singapore to boost the construction sector's productivity and resilience. The centre, in partnership with LeapThought, will hire up to 40 engineers and focus on research and development, advisory services, and business development. The goal is to accelerate digital transformation in the architecture, engineering, and construction (AEC) sector, leveraging technologies such as building information modelling and virtual design and construction. This is part of NTT Data's plans to build social infrastructure across South-east Asia, utilizing Singapore as a springboard.

site_title: Qashier bags S$1.2m in seed funding round led by Cocoon Capital, Hardware Club
summary: Qashier, a smart point-of-sale terminal provider, has secured S$1.2 million in seed funding led by Cocoon Capital and Hardware Club. The startup, founded by CEO Christopher Choo and CTO Frank Zhao Liang, plans to expand into South-east Asia, grow its team, and invest in product development. Qashier's POS terminal, starting at S$1 a day, offers a low-cost alternative to traditional systems, and the company has already deployed its system in hundreds of businesses across Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.56% to 24,563.57, following a global market trend. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.07% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.08%. Despite concerns over China's new law, investors remained optimistic, driven by a global rally.

site_title: Elon Musk selling California properties listed for US$62.5m
summary: Elon Musk has signed a letter of intent to sell four properties in Bel-Air, California, listed for US$62.5 million, to developer Ardie Tavangarian. The properties will be combined into a single project. Musk's fortune has increased by US$24.40 billion this year, making him the world's 17th-richest person. Demand for Los Angeles luxury housing has recovered, with the average time on the market for homes over US$1.5 million falling to 138 days in June.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascendas Reit, SIA, Suntec Reit, UIC, Frasers Centrepoint Trust
summary: Ascendas Reit announced the purchase of a new logistics property in Sydney for S$21.1 million. Singapore Airlines stored four more aircraft in Australia, increasing the total to 22, amid international travel restrictions. The STI rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investors' positive sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday's open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.3% to 2,601.85, led by losses in Singtel and the Singapore Exchange, amidst weaker opening among index counters. Gainers outnumbered losers 63 to 43, with BlackGold Natural Resources rising 66.7%. US stocks surged, with the Nasdaq reaching a fresh record close, while the Dow retreated. Asia's Tokyo stocks opened higher, and the S&P 500 gained 0.5%.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars tense for make or break US jobs report
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are experiencing volatility ahead of the US payrolls report, which could impact the global economy. The Aussie is trading at US$0.6916, while the kiwi dollar holds at US$0.6489, with resistance levels around US$0.6945 and US$0.6532, respectively. A strong jobs report could boost stocks and the Aussie, but a weak one could challenge the market's optimism and send the currency lower, given its correlation to global growth and US equities.

site_title: German MPs bid to close case on ECB bond-buying row
summary: Germany's parliament is set to pass a resolution on Thursday, confirming the European Central Bank's bond-buying scheme is proportionate to its goal of maintaining price stability in the eurozone. The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, had faced a court-ordered review after the Federal Constitutional Court raised concerns that the ECB's 2.7-trillion-euro program was "disproportionate". However, the ECB has provided documentation to Berlin, which politicians believe meets the court's criteria, and the Bundestag is expected to approve the resolution.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by gains in high-tech shares following a rally on the Nasdaq. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.43% to 22,217.03, while the Topix index edged up 0.47%. Traders are awaiting US jobs data, but investors remain optimistic despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Hot stock: BlackGold racks up heavy volume on potential acquisition by Indian firm
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources, an Indonesia-focused coal miner, saw its shares rise 66.7% on Thursday after Indian firm S Lad Group sent a non-binding letter of intent (LOI) for a proposed acquisition and tie-up. The LOI proposes a strategic collaboration and potential acquisition of BlackGold's mining assets. The collaboration is expected to achieve synergies and tap into India's extensive mining expertise, while also creating new market opportunities. The board of BlackGold is considering the proposal and will formulate a response with respect to the possible transaction.

site_title: American Airlines warns it's overstaffed by about 8,000 flight attendants
summary: American Airlines warned it is overstaffed by about 8,000 flight attendants due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline plans to reduce its workforce by early retirements and voluntary leaves, starting from October 1, 2020, to meet minimum Federal Aviation Administration requirements. US carriers are at risk of furloughs when government payroll aid expires in October, but the company aims to avoid them. The airline expects a 25% decline in summer 2021 long-haul international capacity compared to 2019.

site_title: Jeff Bezos's wealth soars to US$171.6b to top pre-divorce record
summary: Jeff Bezos's net worth has surged to a record $171.6 billion, surpassing his previous peak of $167.7 billion in 2018, despite relinquishing a quarter of his Amazon stake in a divorce settlement. The billionaire's gains of $56.7 billion this year reflect the widening wealth gap in the US during the pandemic, with many tech sector billionaires also experiencing significant wealth increases.

site_title: France recovered record 12b euros in taxes last year
summary: France recovered a record 12 billion euros in taxes in 2019, according to Budget Minister Gerald Darmanin. This includes 11 billion euros from tax audits, 358 million euros from rectified declarations, and 530 million euros from judicial arrangements involving Google and Carmignac. The figure represents a 50% increase over the previous year and a 2 billion euro increase over the previous record year in 2015.

site_title: US House approves US$1.5t infrastructure bill but outlook uncertain
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a $1.5 trillion infrastructure package with a 233-188 vote, but its fate is uncertain due to opposition from the White House and Senate Republicans. The bill allocates nearly $500 billion for surface transportation and $100 billion for broadband internet, among other spending areas. Congress faces a September 30 deadline to reauthorize surface transportation spending, and a compromise deal is increasingly unlikely before the November presidential election. The Senate has yet to act on the bill, and the Trump administration is reportedly preparing a separate $1 trillion infrastructure package.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 3.17 points or 0.21% to 1,517.60. The index saw 186.15 million lots traded, with gains beating losses 229 to 72. The market's positive sentiment was attributed to the ongoing rally in Singapore stocks and the recent positive trading in the US market, despite uncertainty surrounding US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: In Brazil, delivery drivers for Uber, Rappi and others protest amid pandemic
summary: Brazil's food delivery drivers protested in São Paulo and other cities, demanding better pay and improved health measures due to the coronavirus pandemic. Over 1,000 drivers, who work for companies like Uber, Rappi, and iFood, blocked traffic and paraded through the city, citing low pay and long working hours. The drivers face exposure to the virus and risk suspension if they don't comply with app rules. The protests have drawn attention from customers, restaurants, and prosecutors, who are investigating the companies' treatment of workers.

site_title: Jefferies sees jump in mergers of equals as coronavirus hammers economy
summary: Jefferies predicts a surge in mergers of equals as companies seek to cut costs and boost earnings amid the coronavirus crisis. The trend allows companies to increase scale without incurring the stigma of lower transaction values. The economic downturn has reduced demand across industries, making it difficult for firms to raise new capital, and mergers of equals can help alleviate this challenge.

site_title: US House moves to toughen sanctions over Hong Kong law
summary: The US House of Representatives unanimously passed a bill to impose tough sanctions on Chinese officials and Hong Kong police in response to Beijing's imposition of a security law in Hong Kong. The bill, which had already passed the Senate, makes sanctions mandatory, limiting President Trump's ability to waive them. The move comes after Hong Kong police arrested hundreds of protesters, and President Trump has not said if he will sign the bill. The bill's passage is seen as a strong stance against China's human rights record, with critics accusing President Trump of being too soft on Beijing.

images.alt_text: The US House of Representatives agreed unanimously on Wednesday to seek tough sanctions on Chinese officials and Hong Kong police after Beijing imposed a security law that clamps down on the city.

site_title: California rolls back reopening, steps up enforcement as coronavirus surges
summary: California has rolled back its reopening efforts due to a surge in coronavirus cases, banning indoor restaurant dining and closing bars in 19 counties. Governor Gavin Newsom has also stepped up enforcement, setting up strike forces to monitor businesses and issuing citations to those that flout orders. Hospitalizations and deaths from Covid-19 have soared, with nearly half of California's intensive care beds being used, prompting Newsom to re-activate four non-hospital sites. The move comes as the US death toll nears 128,000 and concern about the pandemic reaches its highest level in over a month.

site_title: Suntec Reit pumps S$40m into convention centre to weather Covid-19 storm
summary: Suntec Reit has invested S$40 million into Harmony Investors Group (HIG), which indirectly holds the Suntec International Convention and Exhibition Centre, to support the MICE industry in Singapore during the Covid-19 pandemic. The trust's stake in HIG has increased to about 66.3%, with the centre temporarily closed until August 2, 2020, to reduce operating costs. The recovery in the industry is expected to be slow in 2020, with smaller-scale events and meetings leading the way.

site_title: Britain's annual house prices fall for first time since 2012
summary: Britain's annual house prices fell by 0.1% in June, marking the first annual decline since 2012, according to Nationwide. This drop was driven by the coronavirus shock to the economy, with mortgage approvals at a record low in May. Despite a possible slight pick-up in activity in the coming weeks, the medium-term outlook remains uncertain. London house prices rose by 2.1% over the second quarter, but average prices in the capital remain 3% below all-time highs struck in 2017.

site_title: New Zealand's health minister resigns after coronavirus criticism
summary: New Zealand's Health Minister David Clark resigned after criticism over security breaches at quarantine facilities where coronavirus was detected despite the country's elimination. He also faced backlash for breaching lockdown rules twice. Clark cited his role's distraction from the government's response to Covid-19. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern agreed with his decision, amid a decline in public confidence in her government. Ardern had previously lifted social distancing restrictions despite warnings of new cases. Chris Hipkins is now interim health minister until the September election.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's embattled Health Minister resigned on Thursday after security slip-ups at quarantine facilities where the coronavirus was detected just days after officials declared it had been eliminated from the country.

site_title: Geo Energy engages legal advisers on potential dispute over proposed acquisition
summary: Geo Energy Resources has engaged legal advisers in response to a potential dispute over its proposed US$25 million acquisition of Titan Global Energy. The dispute, filed by current or former TIE shareholders, claims that Geo Energy subsidiaries acted against TIE shareholders' interests, including coal purchase agreements. Geo Energy has stated it will defend any claims against its subsidiaries if notified of the legal claim. The group's shares rose 3.5% on Wednesday.

site_title: Evergrande's 101% rally seen slowing after HK$3.2b buyback
summary: Evergrande Group, China's third-largest property developer, has seen its stock price surge 101% since late March, driven by massive buybacks worth HK$3.2 billion (US$575.3 million). However, the company is now running low on fuel to sustain the rally, as it approaches its liquidity limit set by the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Analysts warn that Evergrande's valuation boost could be fleeting, and the company's debt load may eventually lead to a share decline. Moody's has downgraded the company's credit outlook to negative, and a trading halt or delisting is possible if the company fails to maintain the minimum free float.

site_title: US buys up Covid-19 drug, as some countries say well-stocked
summary: The US has purchased nearly all remdesivir production by the Gilead laboratory until the end of September, securing 92% of the world's supply. This has raised concerns about a global shortage, but Britain and Germany say they have sufficient stocks. The US paid $390 per vial for developed countries, while private insurers will pay $520 per vial. Gilead has granted royalty-free licenses to manufacturers in India, Pakistan, and Egypt to produce generic versions of remdesivir for 127 developing countries.

site_title: Singtel lays out 5G strategy in annual report; Bharti Airtel plans sale of 25% stake in data centres
summary: Singtel, a Singapore-based telco, has outlined its 5G strategy, aiming to create new solutions and services beyond connectivity. The company plans to integrate 5G with AI, cloud, and data technology to deliver next-generation services. Singtel prioritizes getting 5G coverage off the ground and expanding its capabilities across its subsidiaries. Meanwhile, its Indian associate Bharti Airtel plans to sell a 25% stake in data center subsidiary Nxtra Data for $235 million.

site_title: Hotels offer rooms as offices to boost business
summary: New York City hotels, struggling with low occupancy rates, are offering rooms as temporary offices to boost business. The NoMo Soho hotel is charging $89 for a 4-hour office session, which includes desks, snacks, and WiFi. This move aims to cater to workers stuck at home and capitalize on the growing demand for virtual meeting spaces. With corporate travel and international visits expected to take time to recover, hotel owners are exploring new uses to stay afloat, such as converting rooms into offices.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Amazon summit helps local companies embrace online growth opportunities
summary: Amazon's country leader Bernard Tay discussed the findings of the recent Amazon Singapore Online Seller Summit 2020, highlighting opportunities for local companies to grow in the online business. Tay emphasized the importance of adapting to changing consumer behaviors and leveraging digital tools to succeed. He also encouraged local businesses to explore Amazon's global selling platform to expand their reach.

site_title: Japan begins charging for plastic bags
summary: Japan has begun charging for plastic bags in an effort to curb excessive packaging and reduce plastic waste. Retailers can set prices, with a common charge being 3 yen (S$0.04). The move aims to increase awareness of environmental issues and encourage consumers to use reusable bags. Japan produces more plastic packaging waste per capita than the US and has set a goal to reduce its waste by a quarter by 2030. While the country has a robust waste management system, much of its recycling involves incinerating plastic, contributing to climate change.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end choppy session higher on vaccine hopes
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% at the end of a choppy session on Wednesday, driven by hopes of a Covid-19 vaccine and improving economic data. The Stoxx 600 index rebounded despite concerns over a possible no-deal Brexit and the European Union's recovery fund. The pan-European index rose despite a warning from German Chancellor Angela Merkel about limited progress in Brexit negotiations, and a technical issue with the Frankfurt-based cash market system Xetra affecting morning trading in some European markets.

site_title: Tesla becomes richest auto group as Detroit giants see sales drop
summary: Tesla has become the world's richest car company, surpassing Toyota, as the US auto industry struggles with declining sales amid the coronavirus pandemic. General Motors and Fiat Chrysler reported significant sales drops, with GM's sales plummeting 34% and FCA's declining 39%. Tesla's shares rose 3.7% to $1,119.63, while GM shed 1.3% and FCA fell 3.3%. Analysts warn of a "cruel summer" for auto sales, citing waning consumer sentiment and inventory challenges.

site_title: American Airlines resumes trying to pack planes as virus cases surge
summary: American Airlines resumed filling its planes to full capacity on July 1, despite a surge in COVID-19 cases and criticism from public health officials. The decision, which was met with "substantial disappointment" from CDC Director Robert Redfield and Dr. Anthony Fauci, comes as the US economy reopens. American Airlines claims to have multiple layers of protection, including required face coverings, enhanced cleaning procedures, and a pre-flight symptom checklist. However, critics argue that the lack of social distancing measures makes the airline's decision problematic.

site_title: Oil rises over 1% on US crude stockpile draw, manufacturing activity
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Wednesday due to a drawdown in US crude inventories and positive manufacturing data. US crude inventories fell 7.2 million barrels, while refinery utilisation rates rose to 75.5%. Global economic activity also supported prices, with US manufacturing activity rebounding in June. However, a surge in US infections tempered gains, and investors remain cautious. Brent crude rose 76 cents to $42.03 a barrel, while US crude rose 55 cents to $39.82 a barrel.

site_title: Election digest
summary: Singapore's IMDA announces time allocations for broadcasts during the upcoming general election, allowing candidates to speak during prime time on TV from July 3-7. Two party political broadcasts will also be aired on July 2 and July 9.

site_title: Fuel demand shock threatens future of Australia's oil refineries
summary: Australia's oil refining industry is threatened by a coronavirus-driven collapse in fuel demand, with at least one refinery at risk of closure. The industry, already reliant on imports for over half its fuel needs, has seen demand for gasoline, jet fuel, diesel, and shipping fuel plummet due to pandemic lockdowns. The government is under pressure to shore up fuel security, and the potential closure of a refinery could have significant economic implications for the country. Industry analysts warn that the government must act quickly to prevent further losses.

site_title: Australia home prices slip in June, but sharp rebound in sales a boost for economy
summary: Australian home prices declined 0.7% in June, marking a second consecutive month of drops, due to coronavirus lockdowns and rising unemployment. However, sales rebounded sharply, providing a positive boost for the economy. This reversal suggests a potential shift towards a more balanced market.

site_title: Automatic recount if difference in votes is 2% or less; special voting hour for those serving stay-home notice
summary: Singapore will hold a general election on July 10, with an automatic recount if the difference in votes between the top candidate and any other candidate is 2% or less. This eliminates the need for candidates to apply for recounts. Meanwhile, individuals under quarantine or with Covid-19 are barred from voting.

site_title: SIA group mothballs four more planes in Australia, taking total tally to 22
summary: Singapore Airlines has stored four more aircraft in Australia, bringing the total to 22, as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to impact the aviation industry. The planes, including two double-decker Airbus A380s and two Boeing 787-8 planes, were sent to the Asia Pacific Aircraft Storage facility in Alice Springs. The airline has raised S$10 billion in liquidity and plans to continue monitoring the situation before returning the aircraft to Singapore.

site_title: Explore food culture with family recipes
summary: A younger generation of home cooks is sharing traditional Asian family recipes, previously reserved for immediate family and close friends, with others. The recipes, such as Indonesian pempek fish cakes and Sri Lankan curries, offer a glimpse into authentic culinary history. Private chefs are also sharing their expertise, allowing others to experience the rich flavors of their cultures. This trend is part of a broader effort to preserve and celebrate cultural heritage through food.

site_title: US: Nasdaq gains 1.0% to end at record as tech giants surge
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index reached a fresh record close on July 1, 2020, rising 1.0% to 10,154.63, driven by gains from tech giants such as Amazon and Netflix. In contrast, the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.3%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.5%. The recent surge in the Nasdaq is attributed to the ongoing US struggle with a resurgent coronavirus crisis.

site_title: It is not that easy to start a crypto currency exchange
summary: Starting a cryptocurrency exchange in Singapore is not as straightforward as implied, according to a recent article. The Payment Services Act 2019 requires a licence or exemption to operate a digital payment token service, including cryptocurrency exchanges. This licence is not easily obtainable, and attempting to start an unlicensed exchange can result in severe penalties. The article serves as a warning to the public and businesses considering entering the cryptocurrency exchange market, highlighting the complexities and risks involved.

site_title: Federal Reserve deluged by letters from needy over US loan programme
summary: The US Federal Reserve received thousands of letters and emails from individuals, businesses, and non-profit groups seeking wider access to its Main Street Lending Program during the pandemic. The program, launched in mid-June, offered loans to medium-sized businesses with up to 15,000 employees or revenues up to $5 billion. In response to public feedback, the Fed lowered the minimum loan threshold to $250,000 and allowed non-profits to borrow alongside private companies. As of last week, 300 lenders had signed up to participate, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell indicating the Fed is open to further adjustments.

site_title: After #OscarsSoWhite, Academy meets goal to diversify membership
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has met its 2016 goal to double the number of women and voters of color in its membership, with 45% of new members being women and 36% being racial minorities. The 819 new members include notable actors, directors, and executives, with 49% hailing from international countries. Despite progress, only 19% of current members are people of color and 33% are female. The academy has announced a new program, Academy Aperture 2025, to implement representation and inclusion standards for Oscars eligibility.

site_title: Trump says he'd have 'no problem' using mask in 'tight' quarters
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he would wear a face mask in 'tight' quarters during an interview with Fox Business. Trump expressed his belief the coronavirus contagion will 'disappear' and added he's not usually in such situations. However, he acknowledged wearing a mask would be 'no problem' if necessary. This comes as many US states are experiencing a surge in coronavirus cases.

site_title: Blue-chip gains push Singapore market cap higher in June
summary: Singapore's stock market value surged 2.1% in June, driven by blue-chip stocks, with the Straits Times Index rebounding 16% to S$752.1 billion. Mainboard-listed counters gained 2%, while Catalist stocks rose 8.7%. DBS, OCBC, and UOB led the gains, with DBS' market value increasing by S$3.4 billion. Other sectors, including consumer staples and supermarkets, also saw gains, while companies severely impacted by the pandemic continued to suffer losses.

site_title: Can the India-China border skirmishes spur Indian economic growth?
summary: India's border skirmishes with China may not impact the country's economy due to existing Chinese investments. Chinese companies have invested over $26 billion in India, with major investors like Alibaba and Tencent holding stakes in numerous Indian startups. The "no war and no peace" situation may actually spur economic growth, as seen in historical examples of wartime technological advancements. Indian defense spending and emergency orders for weapons are expected to contribute to higher economic growth, potentially offsetting the impact of the border tensions on the economy.

site_title: 1.1% drop in URA's Q2 private home price index 'mild', say analysts
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) Q2 2020 private home price index fell 1.1% quarter-over-quarter, marking the second consecutive quarter of decline. Suburban non-landed private home prices remained unchanged. Analysts attribute the drop to agents propping up headline prices with commissions, rather than actual market trends. Overall, the decline suggests a mild market, but experts warn that a Q3 wave of condo launches may test demand for prime projects above $3,000 per square foot benchmark.

site_title: Biden blames 'weak' Trump for Hong Kong clampdown
summary: US presidential contender Joe Biden blamed a "weak" Donald Trump for China's clampdown in Hong Kong, vowing a tougher stance on human rights if he wins the White House. China imposed a security law in Hong Kong, arresting 370 protesters, including 10 under the new law. The Trump administration has been criticized for its response, with Biden saying Trump has surrendered US values and allowed China's autocrats to act with impunity. Biden promised to "fully enforce" laws on Hong Kong's rights and impose swift economic sanctions if China tries to silence US citizens and institutions.

images.alt_text: Presidential contender Joe Biden on Wednesday blamed a "weak" Donald Trump for China's clampdown in Hong Kong, vowing a tougher stance on human rights if he wins the White House.

site_title: As lockdown eases, UK mall landlords collect even less rent
summary: UK mall landlords collected significantly less rent in the third quarter, with Hammerson receiving 16% and British Land collecting 36% of due rent. This is lower than the 43% collected in March and compared to 73% in the first half of the year. The government's temporary eviction ban and lockdown have led to retailers withholding rent despite remaining well-capitalized. However, more retailers are now paying rents monthly, which should increase throughout the quarter.

site_title: US dollar edges up, euro slips amid wait for US data
summary: The US dollar edged up against the euro amid expectations of improved European economic data and a potential global economic recovery. The euro slipped 0.2% to US$1.12105, while the US dollar index rose slightly. Markets are balancing hopes for a quick recovery with surging Covid-19 infections in the US. US manufacturing data for June is expected to show a rebound, and investors are betting that the surge in new infections won't derail a broader global economic recovery.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is introducing a futures contract on the FTSE Taiwan RIC Capped Index, allowing investors to gain exposure to Taiwan stocks. The contract will launch on July 20 and is expected to receive certification from the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Meanwhile, DBS Bank has extended KrisEnergy's revolving credit facility by six months to December 31, 2020, and Olam International has refinanced its revolving credit facility aggregating US$375 million. SPH Reit has proposed a distribution of 0.5 cents per unit for Q3FY2020.

site_title: Weathering Covid-19 storm through trust and technology
summary: Organisations are navigating the post-Covid-19 economy by leveraging trust and technology to drive growth. Trust, encompassing physical, emotional, digital, and financial aspects, has become a crucial determinant of survival in times of crisis. Five growth pivot areas have been identified: scaling up healthcare, securing vulnerable populations, improving connection and communication, entertainment, and education. These areas aim to address the needs of individuals, businesses, and communities during the pandemic. By repurposing capabilities and management systems, organisations can weather the storm and thrive in the crisis, with trust and technology playing key roles in their success.

site_title: Undergoing successful digital transformations
summary: A global study found that only 25% of organizations have undergone successful digital transformations, while 41% are on transformative journeys. The COVID-19 pandemic is expected to accelerate the shift towards a more technologically reliant world, with experts predicting a gig economy and decreased value of physical spaces. Governments are prioritizing digital transformation, with Singapore allocating over $500 million to support businesses. Understanding the differences between digitization, digitalization, and digital transformation is crucial for navigating the present economic transformation.

site_title: Two ex-UOBKH staff charged with lying to MAS over due diligence reports on a Catalist aspirant
summary: Two former UOB Kay Hian Private Limited (UOBKH) employees, Lan Kang Ming and Wee Toon Lee, have been charged with lying to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) over due diligence reports on a Catalist aspirant. They allegedly provided false information in October 2018 and face charges under the Securities and Futures Act, which carry penalties of up to S$50,000 and two years in jail. The incident occurred during an onsite inspection of UOBKH between June and August 2018 to assess its controls and procedures for IPOs.

site_title: Cortina reports uptick in H2 earnings on better sales margin
summary: Cortina Holdings, a luxury watch retailer, reported a 19% increase in second-half earnings to S$20.4 million, driven by a 1.6% improvement in sales margin. Revenue edged up 5% to S$256.8 million, while earnings per share rose 36% to 23.7 cents. The company's balance sheet remains healthy, with cash and bank balances at S$114.4 million. Cortina has proposed an interim dividend of 4 cents per share, its first in two years.

site_title: HSBC continues string of senior hires with another two from Deutsche Bank
summary: HSBC has made two senior appointments in Singapore to strengthen its South-east Asia equities capabilities. Edward Lee, a former Deutsche Bank executive with over 20 years of experience, has been appointed as regional head of equity capital markets, South-east Asia. Joy Wang, also from Deutsche Bank, has been named as head of South-east Asia equity research. The appointments are part of HSBC's efforts to build out its regional coverage and capture growth opportunities in the region.

site_title: US regulators complete test flights on Boeing 737 MAX
summary: US regulators completed three days of flight tests on the Boeing 737 MAX, a crucial step in recertifying the plane. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) will evaluate data from the tests and develop pilot training protocols before lifting the grounding order. The MAX has been grounded since March 2019 following two fatal crashes that killed 346 people. Additional inspections and a final review by a technical advisory board are also required. The FAA will only recertify the plane after it meets certification standards.

images.alt_text: Air safety regulators successfully completed three days of flight tests on the Boeing 737 MAX, a key step in recertifying the plane, US officials said on Wednesday.

site_title: A-Reit to add Sydney logistics property to its portfolio
summary: Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (A-Reit) has agreed to buy a 26,632 sq m logistics property in Sydney, Australia for A$23.5 million. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to the trust's distribution per unit and is valued 19.8% below the cost of buying a similar completed property. The property is expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2021 and will have a net property income yield of 5.8% after accounting for transaction costs. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to tap into Sydney's strong industrial market.

site_title: RHB upgrades Genting Singapore to 'neutral' as RWS reopens attractions
summary: RHB has upgraded Genting Singapore's stock rating to "neutral" with a new target price of S$0.73, following the integrated resort operator's reopening of its attractions at Resorts World Sentosa with limited capacities and safe distancing measures.

site_title: Magnus corrects statements, says CEO has interest in Blue Water Malaysia
summary: Magnus Energy, a Singapore-based company, has corrected its earlier statements regarding its CEO Charles Madhavan's interest in Blue Water Engineering (M) Sdn Bhd (BWEM). Madhavan owns a 50% stake in Blue Water Asia Pacific Group (Blue Water BVI), the parent company of BWEM, which provides administrative services to Magnus. The CEO's indirect interest in BWEM has led to a reclassification of transactions between the two companies as interested person transactions (IPTs) under Catalist rules. As a result, Magnus will terminate its payments to BWEM and its subsidiary MEG Management Sdn Bhd, effective July 1.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.2% in Q2 amid Covid-19 outbreak: flash estimates
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 0.2% in Q2 2020, according to flash estimates, amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Resale volume plummeted to 789 transactions in April and May, down from 3,985 in the same period in 2019. Experts attribute the low sales volume to the circuit breaker period and the importance of physical house viewings. Despite this, prices remained relatively firm, indicating little panic selling. The HDB expects to release final figures on July 24, with new BTO flats to be launched in August and November.

site_title: ESR-Reit secures two new tenants at 8 Tuas South Lane
summary: ESR-Reit has secured two new tenants at 8 Tuas South Lane, leasing 284,700 square feet. The tenants are Pacific Integrated Logistics, a global logistics provider, and Royal's Engineering & Trading (S), a local construction company. The deal marks a significant addition to the industrial Reit's portfolio.

site_title: Telcos need to step up to keep up
summary: Telcos face significant challenges due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with mobile subscribers staying home and reducing spending power. However, the rollout of 5G technology presents an opportunity for telcos to rebuild revenues. Despite a crowded market and intense competition, telcos such as Singtel and StarHub are investing in new segments, including cyber security. The 5G rollout is expected to boost the mobile business, with Singtel's chief executive calling it a "timely licence" in light of the pandemic. Investors are likely to focus on telcos with stable connectivity and proactive customer outreach strategies.

site_title: Art helps kids cope with pandemic
summary: The Rice Company, a charity, provided virtual art and music classes to over 300 children from 33 schools in Singapore during the pandemic. When schools shifted to home-based learning, the organization expanded its services to support students who still attended classes. By offering free online classes, The Rice Company aimed to ensure no child was denied the opportunity to learn the arts due to financial constraints.

site_title: Fans over the moon as Tokyo Disney reopens
summary: Tokyo Disney Resort reopened on July 1, 2020, after a four-month closure due to the coronavirus pandemic. The resort welcomed visitors with limited capacity and enhanced safety measures, including social distancing, temperature screening, and mandatory face masks. Parades and shows remain suspended. Fans expressed enthusiasm, with many praising the decision to limit guest numbers to prevent the spread of the disease. The resort will operate at 50% capacity for the foreseeable future.

images.alt_text: Tokyo Disney Resort, consisting of both Tokyo Disneyland and Tokyo Disney Sea, is the third Disney-themed park globally to reopen following the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Covid-19 to dampen global insurance market in 2020, but Asia to pick up steam more quickly: Allianz
summary: The global insurance market is expected to be negatively impacted by Covid-19, with premium income shrinking by 3.8% globally in 2020 and 0.7% in Asia ex-Japan. This is worse than the 2008 global financial crisis. Asia, however, is expected to recover more quickly, driven by dollar asset diversification.

site_title: Amid pandemic crisis, disclosure of material changes even more crucial
summary: During the pandemic, companies must disclose material changes to their business models, even if it means closing existing businesses. The Singapore Exchange emphasizes the importance of specific, quantifiable explanations of financial impacts, rather than vague references to recessionary conditions. Companies must balance disclosure with confidentiality and timeliness to ensure a level playing field. The Chartered Financial Institute advises companies to disclose or not disclose based on materiality, and to provide sufficient information for investors to assess financial impact independently. Transparency is crucial in navigating the crisis, and companies should adopt the principle of "when in doubt, disclose."

site_title: China orders four US media outlets to disclose finances, staff
summary: China has ordered four US media outlets, The Associated Press, United Press International, CBS, and NPR, to disclose details of their staff and financial operations in China within seven days. This move comes in retaliation for the US reclassification of four Chinese state media outlets as foreign missions in the US. The US State Department has stated that all nine outlets are effectively controlled by the Chinese government. The action escalates tensions between Washington and Beijing, which have been trading barbs over the COVID-19 pandemic and human rights violations.

site_title: First arrests in HK under just-passed national security law
summary: Hong Kong police fired water cannon and tear gas, arresting over 300 people, including nine suspected of violating the national security law, as protesters defied the new legislation. The law, introduced by China, punishes crimes of secession, subversion, and terrorism with up to life in prison and allows for mainland extradition. Critics fear it aims to crush pro-democracy opposition and end Hong Kong's freedoms, sparking concerns among diplomats and investors. The arrests marked the first time the law was enforced, amid warnings of a "stark new era" of mainland justice.

site_title: Big-serving Murray upbeat as he prepares for post-injury return
summary: Andy Murray, a three-time Grand Slam champion, is preparing for his post-injury return to tennis. He played his first tournament since November at the Battle of the Brits event and is set to return to action at the Washington Open in mid-August. Murray is planning to play both the US Open and the French Open, which will begin a week later than its traditional May-June slot due to the Covid-19 pandemic. He expressed positivity about his fitness, stating he can serve at full throttle again, which he believes will be beneficial for his injured hip.

site_title: Jobs, social mobility at forefront of live debate
summary: Singapore's live debate on jobs and social mobility saw disagreements between the ruling PAP and opposition parties over tax plans and business support. The opposition camp criticized the PAP's plans, citing inadequate support for small businesses and insufficient support for social mobility. The debate highlighted differing views on the trade-offs between economic growth and social welfare.

site_title: DBS to make second cut on Multiplier account rates this year
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, will cut interest rates on its flagship deposit account, the Multiplier account, from August 1. The rate reductions aim to address weaker interest rates and increased resident deposits due to macro uncertainties. The changes affect interest rates for account balances up to S$50,000, with some tiered rates being halved or reduced. This move follows similar rate cuts by banking peers OCBC and Standard Chartered.

site_title: WP won't be affected by retirement of a leader: Sylvia Lim
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party (WP) chairman Sylvia Lim stated that the party will not be affected by the retirement of a leader, despite facing challenges in its six-decade history. In the first episode of WP's Hammer Show, Lim praised former chief Low Thia Khiang and emphasized that the party's unity is rooted in its mission and sense of duty. Party members discussed election issues, including pluralism, inclusivity, and scrutinizing government bills, with candidates urging voters to choose a government that listens to its people.

images.alt_text: The Workers' Party (WP) will never be affected by the retirement of a leader despite the many challenges it has faced in its six-decade history, the party's chairman said.

site_title: Koufu to acquire fried food and dough product supplier for S$22m
summary: Koufu Group has proposed to acquire Deli Asia, Delisnacks, Dough Culture, and Dough Heritage for S$22 million, expanding its supplier base for fried food and dough products. The Deli Asia group is one of Koufu's largest suppliers, operating four companies that cater to the food court and coffee shop businesses. The acquisition is part of Koufu's efforts to diversify its supply chain and enhance its offerings. The deal is subject to regulatory approval and other conditions.

site_title: Foreign investors trust Singapore's government and its support: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the country's strong government and investor trust as key factors in its economic success during a crisis. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the Singapore Economic Development Board secured $13 billion in investment commitments. Lee urged voters to grant the ruling People's Action Party a strong mandate to navigate the economic downturn and create jobs. The government is providing 100,000 jobs and training opportunities, with investments expected to create thousands of jobs in the coming years.

site_title: China's manufacturing sector beats expectations in June
summary: China's manufacturing sector experienced a stronger-than-expected recovery in June, with the Caixin/Markit PMI rising to 51.2 and the official PMI at 50.9. This growth was driven by increased factory production, demand for advanced technology, and infrastructure projects. However, challenges persist, including ongoing COVID-19 pandemic impacts on export-dependent industries and concerns over the labor market. A full economic recovery is deemed distant, with analysts warning that consumer demand will take months to return to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Japan retailers start charging for plastic bags
summary: Japan retailers began charging for plastic bags on July 1, 2020, as part of a move to reduce the country's reliance on single-use packaging. The charge, typically three yen (around four Singapore cents), will be set by individual shops. This initiative aims to curb Japan's "packaging culture" and align the country with other major economies.

site_title: John Paulson to turn hedge fund firm into family office
summary: Billionaire hedge fund manager John Paulson is converting his firm, Paulson & Co., into a family office after managing US$38 billion at its peak. With roughly US$10.7 billion in assets under management, Paulson will now focus on investing his family's fortune, joining other prominent fund managers like Carl Icahn and George Soros who have shifted their focus to managing family wealth. Paulson announced the move in a regulatory filing and a letter to investors, stating that he will return external investor capital and operate the firm as a private investment office.

site_title: Gold hurtling towards all-time high amid perfect storm
summary: Gold prices surged to a seven-year high, reaching US$1,789.28/oz, amid a "perfect storm" of renewed pandemic fears, hopes of more stimulus, and rising geopolitical tensions. The US$1,800 psychological mark is now within striking distance. The surge in gold prices follows a series of events, including Trump's fresh tariffs on Canada and tariff threats to others, and China's national security law in Hong Kong. The safe-haven hedge is drawing demand from uncertain times.

site_title: Biotech firm Carmine Therapeutics inks US$900m deal with Takeda Pharmaceutical
summary: Carmine Therapeutics, a biotech firm, has signed a $900 million research agreement with Takeda Pharmaceutical to discover, develop, and commercialize two rare-disease drugs using the Regent gene therapy platform. The deal includes an upfront payment and tiered royalties. Carmine Therapeutics, founded in 2019, aims to develop novel gene therapies based on red blood cell extracellular vesicles, which are safer and cheaper than current methods. The company has raised $9.4 million in seed equity financing and will receive $5 million in convertible notes from Takeda to support its technology development.

site_title: Japan land prices rise in 2019 for 5th straight year
summary: Japan's land prices rose 1.6% in 2019, marking the fifth consecutive year of growth, driven by the tourism industry and urban re-development ahead of the 2020 Olympics. However, the National Tax Agency warns that this trend may not continue due to the economic strain caused by the coronavirus pandemic. If land prices drop, it could add to evidence of the pandemic's economic damage, which Japan is bracing for its worst post-World War II recession.

site_title: Singapore firms see more payment delays in Q2; retail and services post highest jumps
summary: Singapore firms experienced a rise in payment delays in Q2, with retail and services sectors posting the highest jumps. Slow payments increased to 45.78% in Q2, up 3.20 percentage points from Q1, and 8.68 percentage points year-over-year. The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau attributed the deterioration to the economy's coronavirus-induced lockdown. Retail and services industries saw the largest quarterly and year-on-year increases in payment delays, with cash flow for most firms likely to remain tight. Firms are advised to exercise vigilance and prudence in their credit policies.

site_title: Analysts bullish on FCT as it ups stake in PGIM Real Estate AsiaRetail Fund
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has acquired an additional 12.07% stake in PGIM Real Estate AsiaRetail Fund (ARF), increasing its interest to 36.89%. The acquisition is expected to raise FCT's pro forma gearing to 36.2% and is fully funded by debt. Analysts are optimistic on FCT, with some predicting a 5% distribution per unit (DPU) accretion. The acquisition of ARF's assets, including several malls in Singapore and Malaysia, fits FCT's suburban mall landlord positioning. Analysts maintain their "add" ratings on FCT, with target prices ranging from S$2.23 to S$2.58.

site_title: American Air to cut overseas flights 25% in slow recovery
summary: American Airlines will reduce its international summer 2021 schedule by 25% due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.
