The airline will drop 15 routes, shifting focus to Asian service from Los Angeles to Dallas-Fort Worth. International business travel is expected to be slow to recover, with demand not returning to 2019 levels until 2022 at the earliest. American will operate just 20% of its pre-pandemic international service in July, and will retire several aircraft types to reduce capacity.

site_title: Singapore shares up as election campaigning gets underway
summary: Singapore shares rose 20.26 points to 2,610.17, boosted by signs of China's factories recovering and market sentiment. The Straits Times Index (STI) opened at 2,604.08, hit an intraday high of 2,619.35, and ended at 2,610.17. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC underpinned the STI. Luzhou Bio-chem technology led advancers, soaring 90% to close at S$0.029, while the Singapore Exchange (SGX) ended 15 cents lower at S$8.19.

site_title: AGV Group to assist MAS and CAD with probe into possible SFA offence
summary: The AGV Group, a provider of hot-dip galvanising services, has received notices from the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) regarding an alleged offence under the Securities and Futures Act (SFA) between July 2017 and March 2018. The company has assured that its business and operations remain unaffected and will continue as usual. One of its directors has given a statement to the CAD, but the director's name has not been disclosed. The investigation will not affect key executive management roles.

site_title: Big Four hobbled by conflict-of-interest issues
summary: The Big Four accounting firms, EY, KPMG, Deloitte, and PwC, face a major cultural problem due to their lucrative advisory arms, which create conflicts of interest and restrain auditors from being thorough in their audits to protect consulting opportunities. Former accountants have joined regulatory bodies, further exacerbating the issue. Regulators, including German BaFin, have come under fire for oversight failures, and lawmakers are calling for a comprehensive reassessment of BaFin's role and a breakup of the Big Four. Despite the firms' efforts to address the issue, experts say the influence of industry members on regulators remains a significant obstacle to reform.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse reports second major trading outage of 2020
summary: Deutsche Boerse's electronic trading system was unavailable due to a technical glitch, its second major outage this year, disrupting markets in central and eastern Europe. The outage, caused by faulty third-party software, was resolved after a 30-minute halt on derivatives trading and a 5-hour halt on cash equities. Trading resumed gradually, with some exchanges resuming normal operations in the afternoon. The exchange has repaired the issue and expects the system to remain stable. The previous outage in April had similar causes and was resolved after a 5-hour halt.

site_title: Airbus plans to cut 11% of workforce to face aviation's gravest crisis
summary: Airbus plans to cut 15,000 jobs, 11% of its workforce, due to the coronavirus crisis, which it describes as the "gravest crisis" the industry has seen. The cuts will be implemented by summer 2021, affecting 5,000 positions in France, 5,100 in Germany, 900 in Spain, 1,700 in Britain, and 1,300 at other worldwide sites. The company warns that "compulsory actions" cannot be ruled out, and management is committed to limiting the social impact of the adaptation. Airbus had previously cut production of its planes by around a third.

site_title: US manufacturing continues recovery in June: survey
summary: US manufacturing continued its recovery in June, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index rising to 52.6% from 43.1% in May. The increase, beating consensus expectations, suggests the easing of lockdowns is boosting the economy. This marks the sector's entry into an expected expansion cycle after the coronavirus pandemic disruption.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on hopes of Covid-19 vaccine
summary: US stocks opened higher on July 1, 2020, driven by rising hopes of a Covid-19 vaccine. Pfizer and BioNTech announced a vaccine showed potential and was well-tolerated in early-stage human trials. The Dow Jones rose 66.50 points, the S&P 500 gained 5.63 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 4.91 points. This optimism overshadowed concerns of another round of lockdowns amid record coronavirus cases in the US.

site_title: A Waze to show where viruses are, and where they're heading
summary: The US is experiencing rising COVID-19 infection rates, particularly in the South and Southwest. To combat this, experts propose a "Waze-like" system providing real-time information on virus locations and spread. High-frequency testing, potentially through self-sampling, could help keep infection rates low and boost efficiency. Serology testing could also aid in outbreak detection. A data-sharing system, with differential privacy to protect individual identities, could help alert people to areas with high virus presence, enabling them to take precautions and protect themselves and others.

site_title: UK retailer John Lewis says unlikely all its stores will re-open
summary: UK retailer John Lewis says it's "highly unlikely" all its 50 stores will re-open after the coronavirus lockdown. The company plans to re-open 9 stores on July 13 and its flagship store on July 16, taking the total re-opened stores to 32. John Lewis Chairman Sharon White warned of job losses due to store closures and one office closure. The retailer cited "too much store space" and a shift in consumer shopping habits as reasons for the re-opening limitations.

site_title: Wirecard administrator eyes piece-by-piece sell-off
summary: Wirecard, a German payments processor, is considering a piecemeal sale after its insolvency administrator said investors are interested in buying profitable business units. The provisional committee of creditors signed off on an international search for buyers and confirmed Michael Jaffe as administrator. The company's shares have rebounded after tumbling 99% last week, and former executives Markus Braun and Jan Marsalek are facing charges and are being pursued by authorities. The sale could lead to the break-up of the group, which filed for insolvency on Thursday despite continuing to trade.

site_title: GE2020: Jobs, local businesses and social mobility at forefront of live political debate
summary: Singapore's ruling party, the People's Action Party (PAP), emphasized job security, supporting local businesses, and improving social mobility in their campaign for the 2020 general election. The opposition parties, including the Workers' Party, Progress Singapore Party, and Singapore Democratic Party, argued that the government needs to provide more resources for education and healthcare, and address the issue of stagnant productivity and rising unemployment. The debate highlighted the differences between the two camps on how to support local businesses and promote social mobility, with the opposition parties calling for greater support for small and medium-sized enterprises and a more equitable education system.

site_title: Parties work the ground as hustings gather speed
summary: Singapore's GE2020 campaigning kicked off on its first full day, with 192 candidates from 11 parties canvassing support on the ground and online. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong reiterated the need for "best possible leadership" to combat the Covid-19 crisis, while Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of skills mastery and job security. The Workers' Party (WP) and the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) are set to contest several constituencies, including East Coast and Aljunied GRC. A live televised debate took place, featuring candidates from four parties, and the first party political broadcasts will air on TV and radio on Thursday night.

site_title: WP will never be affected by retirement of a leader: chairman Sylvia Lim
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party (WP) chairman Sylvia Lim stated that the party will not be affected by the retirement of a leader, citing its united members and sense of duty. She paid tribute to former party chief Low Thia Khiang, who decided not to contest in the General Election after 29 years. This marks a significant milestone in the party's six-decade history. Lim emphasized the party's resilience and unity, indicating that its mission and values will continue to drive its actions.

site_title: Tech tycoons flood Hong Kong with US$20b of stock listings
summary: Chinese tech tycoons are flooding Hong Kong's stock exchange with $20 billion worth of new listings, despite a national-security law threatening the city's judicial independence. Billionaires like William Ding of NetEase and JD.com's Richard Liu have raised billions from share sales, making Hong Kong an increasingly appealing destination for mainland companies seeking to avoid US scrutiny. The influx of new listings may help secure Hong Kong's status as Asia's financial hub and increase representation of new-economy companies on the benchmark Hang Seng Index.

site_title: Lego pauses social media ad spending
summary: Lego, a Danish toy maker, has paused its paid social media advertising for a month in response to the handling of hateful and toxic content on platforms like Facebook and Instagram. The move joins over 400 companies, including Adidas and Coca-Cola, in boycotting the social networking giants as part of the #stophateforprofit campaign. The campaign aims to encourage Facebook and Instagram to review their policies on hateful rhetoric, harassment, and misinformation. Lego's Chief Marketing Officer, Julia Goldin, stated that the company is committed to a positive digital environment.

site_title: Macy's posts nearly US$4b in losses, doesn't expect another shutdown
summary: Macy's reported a US$3.58 billion loss for its first quarter due to coronavirus-related store shutdowns, resulting in a US$3 billion impairment charge. The company expects the pandemic to continue impacting the US for the remainder of the year, but does not anticipate another total store shutdown. Macy's tapped credit lines, laid off employees, and suspended dividends and buybacks to stay afloat amid the crisis.

site_title: US private hiring rebounds, adding 2.4m jobs in June: ADP
summary: US private hiring rebounded in June, adding 2.4 million jobs, according to ADP. This marks a significant rebound from May's three million hires, with over five million people returning to work after losing their jobs in March and April. While the hiring gain fell short of economists' expectations, it shows signs of life in industries hit hard by the pandemic. Many businesses have rehired workers with aid from the Paycheck Protection Program, with 70% of added jobs in leisure, hospitality, and construction industries.

site_title: 1.4m Singaporeans to get S$570m in GST vouchers in August
summary: About 1.4 million Singaporeans will receive S$570 million in GST vouchers, consisting of cash payouts of up to S$300 and Medisave top-ups, starting from August 1. Eligible individuals will receive notification by July 3. The vouchers aim to support low- and middle-income households affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: E-commerce in a post-Covid-19 economy - what's next?
summary: Consumers in Singapore have shifted their shopping patterns due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with increased spending on groceries and household supplies. A Nielsen study found that 37% of consumers in Singapore have increased online shopping, and 76% expect to maintain this level. The pandemic led to the closure of physical stores, forcing retailers to turn to e-commerce to supplement lost revenue. As a result, e-commerce has become a significant channel for shopping in Singapore, with many consumers expected to continue this trend.

site_title: Fox News fires anchor for sexual misconduct
summary: Fox News has fired Ed Henry, co-anchor of America's Newsroom, following allegations of "willful sexual misconduct" involving a co-worker from years ago. The network received a complaint on June 25, prompting an outside investigation that led to Henry's suspension and eventual termination, according to an internal memo. This comes after the departure of former Fox News chairman Roger Ailes in 2016 due to sexual harassment allegations, which inspired the 2019 film Bombshell.

site_title: Global tourism stands to lose up to US$3.3t from Covid-19
summary: Global tourism revenues are expected to fall by up to US$3.3 trillion due to Covid-19 restrictions, according to a UN study. The US is expected to lose the most, followed by China, with Thailand and France also facing significant losses. Small island states, such as Jamaica, are likely to suffer big losses in proportion to their economies. The report calls for governments to boost social protection for affected workers in badly-hit nations, with estimated losses comparable to a 60-80% decline in tourism numbers.

site_title: Harrods to cut nearly 700 jobs
summary: Luxury British department store Harrods plans to cut up to 672 jobs, approximately 14% of its workforce, due to the coronavirus crisis that kept its flagship branch closed for nearly three months. Employees in parts of the business worst hit by the lockdown will be primarily affected. The move is part of Harrods' efforts to adapt to the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: HSBC boosts regional equities teams with senior hires from Deutsche Bank
summary: HSBC has appointed two senior executives, Edward Lee and Joy Wang, from Deutsche Bank Singapore to strengthen its South-east Asia equities capabilities. Lee, with over 20 years of experience, will lead equity capital markets, while Wang, with over a decade of experience, will lead equity research. The appointments reflect HSBC's growth ambition in the region, which has been building out its regional coverage since 2018.

site_title: Singapore Airport adopts contactless toilets and robot cleaners for Covid-19 travel
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport is introducing various anti-virus measures to increase hygiene levels and reduce virus transmission ahead of its gradual reopening. New measures include proximity touch check-in kiosks, acrylic screens for counter staff, autonomous cleaning robots, and contactless toilets coated with anti-microbial disinfectant. The airport has also signed agreements with Chinese cities for business travelers and is in talks to establish "travel bubbles" with several countries, including Malaysia, New Zealand, and South Korea. These measures aim to support the tourism industry's recovery in the post-Covid-19 world.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Changi Airport is implementing a range of new anti-virus measures as it prepares for a gradual resumption of flights in the post Covid-19 outbreak world.

site_title: Nearly 300 arrested in first protest under new Hong Kong security law
summary: Nearly 300 people were arrested in Hong Kong on July 1 as protesters defied the new security law introduced by China, which critics say aims to snuff out dissent. Police fired water cannon and tear gas, and 9 protesters were charged under the law for breaching it. The law, which can punish crimes with up to life in prison, has been criticized by the US and its allies, and has sparked widespread protests in the city.

site_title: Cortina Holdings delivers 19% increase in H2 earnings on bigger sales margin
summary: Cortina Holdings delivered a 19% increase in second-half earnings to S$20.4 million, driven by a 1.6% increase in sales margin to 27.6%. Revenue rose 5% year-over-year to S$256.8 million. For the full year, earnings increased 36% to S$39.3 million and revenue rose 11% to S$513.8 million. The company's balance sheet remains healthy, with cash and bank balances at S$114.4 million and inventories down S$19.4 million.

site_title: Indonesia province declares state of emergency over forest fire risk
summary: Indonesia's Central Kalimantan province has declared a state of emergency due to a high risk of forest fires on Borneo island. Over 700 hotspots have been detected, with 70 already extinguished, amid concerns about the impact on the environment and global warming. Last year's fires, which burned 1.6 million hectares of land, were the worst since 2015. The province has deployed personnel and water-bombing aircraft to tackle the fires, with cloud seeding operations also underway to induce rain. The emergency declaration comes as Indonesia struggles to tackle the crisis amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia to file WTO legal action against EU over palm oil
summary: Malaysia plans to file World Trade Organization (WTO) legal action against the European Union for restricting free trade practices, particularly in the palm oil industry. The EU's Delegation Regulation has been cited as the reason for the action. Malaysia, the world's second-largest palm oil producer, will also act as a third-party representative in Indonesia's WTO case against the EU. The two countries, along with Indonesia, produce 85% of the world's palm oil.

site_title: UK offers Hong Kong residents citizenship in response to China
summary: The UK has extended citizenship to Hong Kong residents with British National Overseas (BNO) passports in response to China's new security law. About 300,000 Hong Kongers have BNO passports, and another 2.6 million are eligible to apply. The offer includes dependents of those with BNO status. Prime Minister Boris Johnson criticized China's law as "Orwellian" and said it tests the limits of the "One Country, Two Systems" principle. The move is seen as a direct response to China's actions and represents a significant shift in the UK's relations with Beijing.

site_title: Don't sacrifice Hong Kong for a banker's bonus, UK tells HSBC
summary: British Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab criticized HSBC and other banks for supporting China's new security law in Hong Kong, stating that the rights of Hong Kong citizens should not be sacrificed for bankers' bonuses. Senior British and US politicians also expressed concerns over the banks' backing of the law. Raab emphasized the UK's commitment to protecting Hong Kong's freedoms and responsibilities.

site_title: HR tech startup Qualee raises US$1m in seed funding
summary: HR tech startup Qualee has raised US$1 million in seed funding from Tandem Technology Partners. The Singapore-based company's app-based platform enables customized on-boarding, off-boarding, and micro-learning journeys for remote and contingent staff. Qualee's platform is now available in 16 languages and will be used to extend features and expand its team. The funding aims to help employers remain connected with displaced staff and quickly reinitiate as conditions improve, given the current limitations of physical presence in workplaces.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.46 points to 1,514.43 on Wednesday, driven by a gain of 660 to 313 stocks. The index closed at RM3.601 billion in volume. This marks a positive trend in the market, following a 5-day rally in Singapore and other Asian markets.

site_title: Political debate less about direction, more on costs, trade-offs, value of elected opposition
summary: In a televised debate for Singapore's General Election 2020, representatives from the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and three opposition parties focused on costs, trade-offs, and the value of elected opposition members rather than policy directions. The PAP's Vivian Balakrishnan criticized the Workers' Party (WP) for being "PAP-lite," while the WP's Jamus Lim argued that his party's manifesto is budget-neutral. The debate highlighted the importance of a free contest of ideas and constructive voices in Parliament, with all parties agreeing to engage in open discussions.

site_title: A-Reit to add Sydney logistics property to its portfolio
summary: Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (A-Reit) agreed to buy a 26,632 sq m logistics property in Sydney's Yennora suburb for A$23.5 million. The acquisition, expected to be completed in 2021, will be accretive to A-Reit's distribution per unit. The property, with 13,100 sq m of lettable floor area, has a net property income yield estimated at 5.8% for the first year, driven by a 9.5-month rental guarantee. The deal is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on Sydney's strong industrial market with robust tenant demand.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of investor confidence in Singapore's government, citing its ability to command popular support as a key factor in the country's economic success. Automatic recount procedures have been established for elections, and a special voting hour has been allocated for those under the Covid-19 stay-home notice. Meanwhile, DBS is set to cut interest rates on its flagship deposit account, and Singapore firms reported higher payment delays in Q2. Private home prices also decreased by 1.1% in Q2, according to the URA flash estimate.

site_title: SPH Reit proposes DPU of 0.5 cents for Q3FY20
summary: SPH Reit proposes a distribution of 0.5 cents per unit for Q3FY20, with a record date of July 9 and payment date of August 18. The Reit reported a 98.8% portfolio occupancy and a 4.1-year weighted average lease to expiry. Footfall declined during the "circuit-breaker" period but has shown a gradual recovery since Singapore's reopening. In Australia, there has been an encouraging recovery of footfall and sales since movement restrictions were relaxed. The proposed distribution is below the Reit's average distribution per unit of 1.46 cents for Q3FY20.

site_title: Americans' concerns about coronavirus jump as cases surge: poll
summary: Americans' concerns about the coronavirus have reached their highest level in over a month, with 81% of adults saying they are "very" or "somewhat" concerned. Concerns are rising among Republicans, who are increasingly worried about the virus, while Democrats remain similarly concerned. The pandemic is taking over the 2020 presidential campaign, with 27% of respondents citing the candidate's coronavirus plan as the most important factor. Joe Biden appears to have a slight advantage over President Trump in handling the pandemic, with 41% of adults thinking he would be better at directing the country's response.

site_title: Stamford Land refutes report that its Melbourne hotel was behind 29 Covid-19 cases
summary: Stamford Land has denied a report that its Melbourne hotel, Stamford Plaza Melbourne, was responsible for 29 Covid-19 cases. The hotel allegedly breached infection-control protocols after staff shared a cigarette lighter and car-pooled to work. However, Stamford Land stated that the 29 cases did not originate from the hotel's staff or the purported breach of protocols. The company is investigating the source of the cases and has not confirmed any link to the hotel.

site_title: Indonesia watchdog cautions on excess bank withdrawals, to investigate social media
summary: Indonesia's Financial Services Authority (OJK) warned customers not to withdraw excess cash from banks amid "irresponsible" social media posts about mid-sized Bank Bukopin. The OJK urged customers to remain calm and limit withdrawals to avoid affecting the bank's condition. The agency plans to investigate the social media posts and has asked customers to avoid excess withdrawals from all banks. The move comes as Bank Bukopin faces a liquidity crisis due to the viral posts.

site_title: Singapore shares drift up, with eyes on GE2020 campaign
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.78% on Wednesday, driven by a six-month high in China's manufacturing PMI and a boost from local banks. The Straits Times Index (STI) opened at 2,604.08 and hit an intraday high of 2,619.35, before settling at 2,610.17. Luzhou Biochem technology led the advancers, soaring 90% to close at S$0.029. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) ended 15 cents lower despite launching a new FTSE Taiwan Index.

site_title: Wirecard raided by prosecutors over missing 1.9b euros
summary: Munich prosecutors raided Wirecard's offices in Germany and Austria, investigating 1.9 billion euros missing from the fintech company's accounts. Former CEO Markus Braun was arrested and granted bail after being accused of forging accounts and market manipulation. Wirecard filed for protection from creditors, and a preliminary insolvency administrator was appointed. The probe follows Wirecard's revelation that previously reported cash never existed, leading to the company's collapse.

site_title: US: Strong tech earnings lift stocks, Nasdaq +1.5%
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, driven by strong earnings from tech companies, lifting the Nasdaq Composite Index 1.5% to 10,745.27. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained 0.4% and 0.8% respectively. The strong tech earnings helped offset uncertainty from ongoing fiscal support discussions in Washington.

site_title: Pandemic must not stop move to scrap Libor, say regulators
summary: Regulators say the COVID-19 pandemic disruption to markets shouldn't stop banks from ending their use of the Libor interest rate benchmark by the end of 2021. The Financial Stability Board (FSB) stated this, as regulators want banks to use rates compiled by central banks after lenders were fined billions for trying to rig Libor. The global Libor is used to price around $400 trillion worth of contracts, including mortgages and credit cards.

images.alt_text: Disruption to markets caused by the Covid-19 pandemic must not stop banks from ending their use of the Libor interest rate benchmark by the end of 2021.

site_title: Unlocking growth opportunities online for retail's sustained success
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, retail businesses in Singapore have had to adapt to new demand patterns, increased regulations, and disrupted supply chains. To navigate the challenges, businesses can leverage globalization, online shopping, and digitalization to meet evolving market demands. Selling online can help retailers expand their footprint and recover quickly, with support from e-commerce providers and government initiatives like the E-Commerce Booster Package. By adopting personalized customer experiences and investing in virtual tools, retailers can stand out in a crowded market and build a differentiated offering.

site_title: Euro zone sees biggest contraction in Q2 GDP
summary: The euro zone economy recorded its largest contraction on record in Q2, with a 12.1% decline in GDP from the previous quarter, according to Eurostat. This followed a 3.6% drop in the first quarter, and was driven by coronavirus lockdowns that eased only from May. Spain's economy shrank 18.5% quarter-on-quarter, while Italy and France saw falls of 12.4% and 13.8%, respectively. Despite these declines, inflation in the euro zone ticked up in July, defying expectations of a slowdown.

site_title: SocGen shuts Singapore trade commodity desk after Hin Leong hit
summary: Societe Generale is closing its trade commodity finance unit in Singapore after the collapse of Hin Leong Trading, prompting the bank to halt fresh funding to such firms in the region. The bank will dismiss all front office staff, while keeping administrative workers, and will now handle large Asian commodities trading clients from Hong Kong. This move comes after SocGen was owed $240 million by Hin Leong, which filed for creditor protection earlier this year, and amid a broader review of trade commodities financing activities by French lenders due to plummeting oil prices and rising bankruptcies.

site_title: ECB lowers bar for bank mergers in hope of spurring consolidation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has lowered the bar for bank mergers in the euro zone, aiming to encourage consolidation in the sector. The new guide clarifies that merged entities won't need extra capital and can use their own accounting models, as well as "badwill" from asset purchases. This move addresses concerns from bankers about mergers and acquisitions in the eurozone, which have been plagued by low profits and unresolved issues from the last financial crisis. The ECB hopes this change will stimulate an elusive wave of consolidation.

site_title: Facebook challenges YouTube with licensed music videos
summary: Facebook has launched licensed music videos on its platform in the US, challenging YouTube for online music audiences. The move follows successful launches in India and Thailand, with partnerships from major music groups like Sony, Universal, Warner, and BMG. The service promises new social experiences for users to connect and share music, with premier content from artists like J. Balvin and Karol G. This expansion aims to capitalize on the surge in interest in streamed entertainment during the pandemic, with YouTube boasting over 2 billion monthly users.

site_title: Najib's 1MDB trial on hold for by-election
summary: Malaysia's former leader Najib Razak's 1MDB trial has been put on hold due to his involvement in the upcoming Chini by-election campaign. The trial, which revolves around corruption and money-laundering charges linked to US$681 million in his personal bank accounts, will resume on July 17. This allows Najib to join the campaign and attend a parliament session set to begin on July 13. The trial's delay comes as global investigations into 1MDB continue.

site_title: Japan extends US$464m loan for Philippines Covid-19 response
summary: Japan is extending a 50 billion yen (approximately $646.9 million) loan to the Philippine government to aid its COVID-19 response. The loan, part of a highly concessional emergency support program, aims to help the Philippines combat its fourth-highest COVID-19 infection numbers in East Asia, with 37,514 cases and 1,266 deaths reported. This is the first loan of its kind for Japan, designed to ease the global health crisis.

site_title: South Korea to start talks on Covid-19 drug remdesivir purchases in August
summary: South Korea plans to start talks with Gilead Sciences in August to purchase more of the Covid-19 treatment remdesivir, which has been donated and is priced at $390 per vial in developed countries. Remdesivir has shown to alter the course of Covid-19 and has won emergency-use authorization in several countries, including Japan. The drug is in high demand, and South Korea's move comes after being the first country to disclose a timeline for talks with Gilead.

site_title: South Korea to probe its private funds after hedge fund scandal
summary: South Korea's Financial Services Commission plans to investigate all 11,734 private and hedge funds over the next three years due to misleading selling practices and riskier investments. The regulator, seeking assistance if needed, aims to raise the minimum investment amount for private funds to 300 million won from 100 million won. The probe follows a series of scandals, including Lime Asset Management's freeze on withdrawals and Optimus Asset Management's suspension of operations. The move aims to restore trust in the domestic financial industry, which has grown to $346 billion in assets under management.

site_title: Pizza Hut and Wendy's US operator NPC files for bankruptcy
summary: NPC International, the largest Pizza Hut US franchisee, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Texas court on Wednesday, citing coronavirus-related shutdowns and competitive pressures. The company operates over 1,225 Pizza Hut and 385 Wendy's stores across the US. Rising labor and food costs, as well as competition from Domino's and Papa John's, have contributed to the financial struggles. The bankruptcy filing aims to restructure debt and navigate the challenging restaurant industry landscape.

site_title: Geely's Volvo announces its biggest ever recall over seat belt cable
summary: Volvo Cars, owned by Geely, is issuing its largest-ever recall of nearly 2.2 million cars from 2006 to 2019 due to a potential issue with cables attached to front seat belts. The issue, which may cause fatigue and damage to the cable over time, has not been linked to any reported accidents or injuries. Owners of affected models, such as the V60, V70, and XC60, will be contacted to arrange free repairs through their Volvo retailer. The recall is preventative to avoid potential issues in the future.

site_title: South Korea's July exports record slowest decline in 4 months
summary: South Korea's exports fell 7.0% in July from a year earlier, the slowest decline in four months, beating market expectations. The trade-reliant economy has slipped into recession, but recent data suggest a recovery is gaining traction, with factory output jumping at the fastest rate since 2009. Exports to China and the US rose, while those to the EU continued to fall. The trade surplus expanded to $4.27 billion, with imports dropping 11.9%. Global coronavirus spread and US-China tensions are seen as key variables affecting South Korean trade.

site_title: Seoul: Shares shed early gains amid mixed cues
summary: South Korean shares declined on Wednesday, shedding early gains amid mixed cues. The Kospi index closed 1.63 points lower, or 0.08%, at 2,106.70, following reports of a Hong Kong police arrest under a national security law and the US recording its biggest single-day spike in Covid-19 cases. South Korean exports slumped in June, and a private survey showed manufacturing activity declining. Foreigners were net sellers of $139.12 million worth of shares, further weighing on the market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower as virus spike hits capital
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday due to a spike in coronavirus cases in the capital, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.26% to 22,339.23. Investors were concerned about fresh business restrictions, including shortened opening hours for restaurants and bars, amid record infection numbers. Trading was also affected by thin volumes ahead of US tech earnings reports. The Tokyo governor is expected to announce plans to restrict businesses, following a central government decision two months ago to lift a state of emergency.

site_title: GE quick takes: NSP campaigns to stop GST hike; Potong Pasir candidates unveil plans
summary: Singapore is set to go to the polls on July 10 for the General Election, with all 93 seats in 31 constituencies contested. The National Solidarity Party (NSP) has announced its manifesto, calling for the GST hike to be scrapped. Candidates for the Potong Pasir SMC have unveiled their five-year plans, including proposals for a polyclinic and community geriatric programme. The Elections Department has also announced special voting arrangements, including an automatic recount if the difference in votes is 2% or less.

images.alt_text: The NSP manifesto said the government should look for alternative sources of revenue instead of raising the GST, which is slated to rise from 7 per cent to 9 per cent between 2022 and 2025.

site_title: Jardine C&C's underlying profit falls 66% in H1; interim dividend halved
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) reported a 66% drop in its underlying profit to US$138 million for the first half of FY2020 due to a slump in car sales amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue fell 28% to US$6.59 billion, with Astra's automotive business experiencing a 79% decline in net income. The company declared an interim dividend of 9 US cents per share, half that of last year, and its consolidated net debt was lower at US$1.3 billion as of end-June. Despite the challenges, Jardine C&C remains confident in its long-term growth prospects.

site_title: Chinese tech's next battleground
summary: Chinese tech giants are shifting their focus to South-east Asia amid global trade tensions and the push for digitalization in the region. Following India's ban on 59 Chinese apps, including TikTok and WeChat, market watchers expect the likes of Baidu, Alibaba, and Tencent to intensify their expansion and investments in South-east Asia. The region offers a fragmented market with lower digital maturity, making it easier for Chinese companies to replicate their business model. Key battlegrounds include OTT streaming, fintech, and e-commerce, with players like Tencent, Alibaba, and ByteDance vying for dominance. The e-wallet market is also becoming increasingly competitive, with Tencent and Alibaba backing rival operators. As the Chinese companies continue to expand in the region, they will face a cut-throat competition for the South-east Asian market, with potential implications for the global consumer, businesses, and jobs.

site_title: Singapore banks' dividend cap to bring short-term pain, but higher payouts in end
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has asked local banks to cap dividend payouts for FY20 at 60% of FY19's total dividends, with the option of receiving dividends in scrip instead of cash. This move aims to ensure the banks have adequate capital buffers to absorb economic shocks. The move is expected to bring short-term pain to the banks, with shares of DBS, OCBC, and UOB falling 3-3.8% on Thursday. Analysts predict lower dividend yields and a potential increase in payouts in the future.

site_title: Time to bring JB-Singapore RTS Link project to quicker realisation
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin met to restart the stalled Johor Bahru-Singapore Rapid Transit System (RTS) Link project. The two countries signed three agreements to move the project forward, including amendments to the bilateral agreement, setting up an operating company, and appointing it as the RTS Link operator. The project, which was stalled since 2018, aims to connect Singapore and Malaysia with a rapid transit system. The signing of the agreements is seen as a positive step towards realizing the project.

site_title: Recovered from virus, Bolsonaro says nothing to fear
summary: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro has downplayed the severity of COVID-19 after recovering from a bout of the virus, stating that nearly everyone will catch it and urging Brazilians to "face up to it." Bolsonaro, who is in the high-risk group, has faced criticism for his handling of the pandemic, which has surged in Brazil with over 2.6 million cases and 92,000 deaths. He has also promoted hydroxychloroquine as a treatment for the virus, despite studies showing it has no benefit.

images.alt_text: Fresh off a bout of Covid-19, President Jair Bolsonaro said on Friday nearly everyone will probably end up catching the new coronavirus, urging Brazilians to "face up to it" and saying there was nothing to fear.

site_title: HK's dollar peg is 'unassailable,' says StanChart CEO
summary: Hong Kong's dollar peg to the US dollar is deemed "unassailable" by Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters, citing the city's extensive foreign reserves. The peg is supported by over $440 billion in reserves, and US President Donald Trump decided against undermining it due to concerns about its potential impact on the financial system. Executives at HSBC and Kyle Bass's Hayman Capital Management are, however, exploring potential disruptions to the peg amid worsening political tensions.

site_title: 3 out of 4 imported Covid-19 cases were Singaporeans and PR returning from Pakistan
summary: Singapore reported four imported COVID-19 cases on July 1, with three being Singaporeans and a permanent resident who returned from Pakistan. The individuals, who are asymptomatic, were placed on stay-home notice and tested while serving their 14-day isolation. The first case, a 39-year-old female Singaporean, tested positive on Tuesday. The Ministry of Health is monitoring the situation and ensuring the individuals comply with their quarantine requirements.

site_title: Chinese airlines offer unlimited flights to revive industry
summary: Chinese airlines offer ultra-cheap, all-you-can-fly deals to revive the domestic aviation sector. At least eight carriers have launched similar schemes, with China Southern being the latest. These offers, which began in July, aim to boost air travel following coronavirus lockdowns. The ultra-cheap deals have already led to high demand, with Lucky Air hitting capacity for monthly and seasonal passes just two days after announcing the offers. The moves are part of China's efforts to stimulate its ailing aviation industry.

site_title: Wirecard debt hedges set to pay out US$212m to funds
summary: Hedge funds that purchased credit insurance on Wirecard debt are set to receive payouts of up to $212 million after the German payments company filed for insolvency. Wirecard's bankruptcy credit event triggered payouts to holders of credit-default swaps, which were used to bet on the company's financial struggles. The decision is binding on swaps governed by 2014 definitions and a panel will meet again to decide on a settlement. The scandal led to the arrest of former CEO Markus Braun and severe damage to Germany's financial sector, prompting a pledge for a quick overhaul of regulatory oversight.

images.alt_text: Hedge funds that bought credit insurance on Wirecard debt are among those in line for a windfall of as much as US$212 million after the disgraced German payments company filed for insolvency last week.

site_title: DHL temporarily suspends Chinese import shipments to India
summary: DHL has temporarily suspended picking up import shipments from China to India due to clearance delays caused by border tensions. Another freight transporter, FedEx, has also suspended shipments, citing backlogs beyond its control. The move follows the imposition of tariffs and clearance issues, affecting global supply chains.

site_title: Flash forward
summary: Pure Storage CEO Charles Giancarlo notes that despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, 2020 has started positively for the company, with revenue growing 12% and bookings increasing 24%. Giancarlo, who contracted the virus and recovered, attributes the company's success to its remote work capabilities and strong supply chain. He predicts that remote working and social distancing will be more prevalent after the pandemic, citing the Roaring 20s decade of growth and social change as a similar phenomenon. Giancarlo also emphasizes the need for a kinder and gentler world, calling for calm and determination over anger and violence.

site_title: China launches its first unmanned mission to Mars
summary: China successfully launched its first unmanned mission to Mars, the Tianwen-1 probe, on July 23, 2020, from Wenchang Space Launch Centre. The probe is expected to reach Mars in February and land in Utopia Planitia, where it will deploy a rover to explore for 90 days. If successful, it will make China the first country to orbit, land, and deploy a rover in its inaugural mission. The mission aims to study the planet's atmosphere and surface, searching for signs of water and ice, and will carry 13 scientific instruments.

site_title: Reits (July 25-26, 2020)
summary: Reits reported mixed results from July 25-26, 2020. US mortgage rates rose for the first time in five weeks, while Singapore prime condo projects above S$3,000 psf faced demand testing. Manhattan rents hit another record, and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. Meanwhile, New World sold China property assets and WeWork secured new tenants at its Singapore location. Goldman Sachs acquired a hotel and retail assets in Seoul, and Goldman's move in the US was not mentioned.

site_title: Asian airlines suffer 98% slump in June passenger traffic
summary: Asian airlines saw a 98% slump in June passenger traffic, carrying 724,000 international passengers, a 98% drop from the previous year. The Association of Asia Pacific Airlines (AAPA) attributed this decline to restrictions on movement and a resurgence of infections. The industry's cash reserves are rapidly depleting, and airlines are incurring massive losses. The prospect of a recovery in the second half of the year is uncertain, with the AAPA director general stating the industry is in a "perilous condition."

site_title: Covid-19 a catalyst for Vietnam manufacturing
summary: Vietnam's manufacturing sector continues to thrive, ranking second most cost-competitive globally, according to Cushman & Wakefield. The country's stable geopolitical situation, wide-reaching market integration, and efforts to move up the value chain to Industry 4.0 are key factors. Vietnam's manufacturing sector is expected to continue growing, driven by its biomedical, food manufacturing, and pharmaceutical industries. The country is poised to benefit from the US-China trade war, with foreign direct investments reaching $6 billion in the first half of 2020. Vietnam's government is expected to focus on infrastructure development, land compensation, and new legislation to support the sector's growth.

site_title: Beijing needs to hold urgent talks with key partners in global economy
summary: China's government has threatened retaliation against its main trading partners, the US and UK, amid rising tensions over spying claims, Hong Kong's security legislation, and human rights issues. China's economy, worth $14 trillion, is recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic, but its staggering debt levels pose a weakness. China needs urgent talks with its key partners to resolve issues and improve trade and investment. The UK's decision to cancel Huawei's 5G contract and the US's closure of the Chinese consulate in Houston have fueled tensions, while China's ambassador to the UK accuses the British government of interfering in Chinese internal affairs.

site_title: Retro Revival
summary: Singapore's vintage fashion scene is experiencing a resurgence, driven by growing interest in sustainability and nostalgia. Boutiques like Baju Mama Vintage, The Vintage Tale, and Déjà Vu Vintage are capitalizing on the trend, offering unique and affordable vintage clothing options. The rise of social media has made it easier for fashion inspiration to be shared, especially among younger generations. As a result, consumers are increasingly seeking out sustainable and individualized fashion choices, with vintage clothing representing a valuable alternative to fast fashion. With the industry expected to continue growing, vintage players are confident that its appeal is here to stay.

site_title: Deutsche Bank tightens fossil fuel lending policies
summary: Deutsche Bank has announced plans to end business worldwide with companies most exposed to coal mining by 2025, as part of a revamp of its fossil fuel lending policies. The bank will cease financing new projects in the Arctic and oil sand projects, but will still lend to some of the world's biggest coal miners. The policy change follows the bank's new sustainability targets and the issuance of its first green bond, but critics say it is "still too little, too late" and lags behind rival banks in terms of ambition.

site_title: STI down 0.37% on muted trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 9.52 points or 0.37% to 2,573.45, with losers outnumbering gainers 215 to 185. CapitaLand Mall Trust and CapitaLand Commercial Trust were the biggest losers, while Venture Corporation rose 3.58% to S$17.94. The STI was boosted by consistent institutional buying and positive momentum in Venture's share price. Regional markets were mixed, with China's Shanghai Composite Index adding 2.06% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising 0.45%.

site_title: Sterling slips despite retail recovery; focus on Brexit talks
summary: The pound slipped in London trading despite a recovery in British retail sales, with sales volumes exceeding forecasts in June. The pound remained subdued, slipping 0.1% against the euro and 1.2731 against the US dollar. Investors focused on the lack of progress in Brexit talks with the EU, with EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier saying a new trade deal was "unlikely". Implied volatility gauges rose, suggesting investors are wary of volatile price action from Brexit-related headlines.

site_title: Prolonged ultra-low interest rate environment may hurt growth: Tharman
summary: Singaporean Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam warned at the DBS Asian Insights Conference 2020 that a prolonged ultra-low interest rate environment may hurt growth. He emphasized the need for international cooperation to address the global economic crisis, particularly in preventing the "submerging world" in emerging markets. Tharman suggested that governments should focus on enabling future growth, rather than just preventing collapse, and highlighted the importance of preserving capabilities, diversifying supply chains, and supporting the financial sector.

site_title: Malaysia's Top Glove factory raided, no evidence of forced labour found
summary: Malaysian authorities conducted a raid on Top Glove Corporation, the world's largest glove maker, and found no evidence of forced labor. The raid was carried out two days before the US Customs barred two Top Glove units due to forced labor allegations. The company claims to have upheld good labor practices and received an "A" rating in a social audit conducted by a global business association. The human resources ministry warned employers to abide by labor laws and urged transparency to maintain international credibility and investor confidence.

site_title: Classic French fare at home with Odette
summary: Odette, a three-Michelin-starred restaurant, has launched a home delivery service, Odette At Home, catering to those who don't want the fuss of a fine dining experience. The service, introduced during the Covid-19 pandemic, allows customers to enjoy the restaurant's luxurious ingredients and cooking without the need for a reservation. The Decouverte menu, priced at S$188, offers a selection of dishes, including Pate en croute de Tradition Bourgeoise, Poularde de Bresse au Vin Jaune, and Niigata rice, all perfectly presented and easy to reheat. The service is available from Wed to Sun and can be ordered through the restaurant's website or Oddle app.

site_title: No mass market travel for now, Chan tells tourism firms
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing announced that the country will not see mass market travel for now, focusing instead on domestic spending on local tourism and lifestyle activities. The government has launched a S$45m marketing blitz to boost these sectors. Chan emphasized the need for businesses to redesign their products to cater to a demand for quality, niche-market services, appealing to both locals and new segments.

site_title: Euro, gold on a high as the US dollar breaks down
summary: The euro reached a 21-month peak against the US dollar, rising to $1.1616, amid a deal on a European Union recovery plan. The US dollar fell 1.4% against a basket of currencies, marking its fifth consecutive weekly loss. Asian equities paused short of a six-month high, while gold neared its record high at $1,886 an ounce, driven by low interest rates and uncertainty. The Dow and S&P 500 ended Thursday down 1.31% and 1.23% respectively, amid concerns over US stimulus measures and tech antitrust investigations.

site_title: A mega-good match
summary: IBM's acquisition of Red Hat for $34 billion marks a significant milestone, as the tech giant combines its proprietary software with the open-source software model, championed by Red Hat. CEO Paul Cormier credits the deal to the success of the Red Hat model, stating that open-source has "arrived as the mainstream." Cormier explains that Red Hat's software developers work in an open-source environment, where the best idea wins, and commercial engineers solve customer problems. The acquisition aims to bring together the commercial and open-source sides, allowing IBM to tap into Red Hat's expertise and customer base. Cormier believes the deal will continue to evolve, but for now, it's a "marriage in heaven" that combines the strengths of both companies.

site_title: China raises equity investment cap for insurers to 45%
summary: China's banking and insurance regulator, CBIRC, has raised the cap on equity investments for insurers to 45% of total assets, up from 30%. This move aims to bring more long-term funds into the capital market. The new cap allows insurers to invest up to 10% of a single listed company's share capital. The move is expected to introduce hundreds of billions of yuan to China's A-share market, boosting the market.

site_title: Top Glove proposes 2-for-1 bonus issue
summary: Top Glove Corp, the world's largest glove manufacturer, is proposing a 2-for-1 bonus issue to reward shareholders, issuing up to 5.48 billion bonus shares. The move aims to increase liquidity and marketability for the company's shares, while retaining shareholders' equity interest. The proposed bonus issue is subject to shareholder approval and follows a previous bonus issue in 2018.

site_title: EU's 'moment of truth' as leaders debate virus rescue
summary: European Union leaders gathered for their first face-to-face summit in five months, but a post-virus economic rescue plan remains uncertain. Chancellor Angela Merkel and President Emmanuel Macron back a 750-billion-euro recovery package, while the Netherlands, backed by other "Frugal Four" countries, insists on strict conditions attached to loans and grants. The summit, which began on Friday and is expected to run into Saturday, faces a tough timetable and few are confident of a breakthrough, with the chance of success seen as less than 50%.

site_title: In the shadow of Covid
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has overshadowed the climate change agenda, with many countries scrambling to respond to the crisis. Climate change experts warn that the pandemic's impact on low-income communities and the environment has been disproportionate, with the poor and disenfranchised dying from climate-related illnesses. The pandemic has also highlighted the need for social and financial implications of climate change, which must be acknowledged and addressed. Despite the temporary drop in carbon emissions during lockdowns, experts fear that countries will struggle to sustain this lower economic activity without being forced to do so by future pandemics. The issue of climate change is now being pushed to the backburner, with the UN Climate Change Conference postponed due to the pandemic. However, experts believe that the pandemic offers a unique opportunity for countries to transition to renewable energy and adopt sustainable development policies.

site_title: Hafary, AF Global and Sino Grandness issue profit warnings
summary: Three Singapore-listed companies, Hafary Holdings, AF Global, and Sino Grandness Food Industry Group, have issued profit warnings due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Hafary and AF Global expect H1 losses, while Sino Grandness expects Q1 losses. The companies attribute their losses to a slowdown in business volumes, disruptions to operations, and travel restrictions. Despite the challenges, Sino Grandness' management believes the company's working capital remains healthy.

site_title: Hong Kong virus outbreak set to top earlier waves
summary: Hong Kong is experiencing a new coronavirus outbreak, with cases surpassing its previous wave in March and April, exceeding 300 in under two weeks. Over a third of infections are of unknown origins, indicating widespread hidden transmission. The current outbreak is on track to eclipse its previous wave, mirroring similar scenarios in Japan and Australia. While healthcare systems are not being overwhelmed, an effective vaccine remains crucial to mitigate economic and social suffering, as the virus continues to spread silently and potentially linger in the air for hours.

site_title: Cybersecurity unicorn Acronis acquires DeviceLock
summary: Cybersecurity firm Acronis has acquired DeviceLock, a US-based device control and endpoint data leak prevention software provider, for an undisclosed sum. DeviceLock will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Acronis, with its technology integrated into the Acronis cyber platform. The acquisition aims to accelerate product innovation, expand distribution channels, and leverage existing technology to meet customer requirements. DeviceLock's DLP solution protects over 4 million computers in 5,000 organizations worldwide, with a focus on preventing data leaks caused by employees or malicious intent.

site_title: Banker on a mission
summary: DBS Singapore's country head Shee Tse Koon reflects on the bank's role in the economy during the novel coronavirus pandemic. He emphasizes the importance of maintaining livelihoods and notes that DBS has led the industry in offering debt moratoriums and relief measures for customers. The bank has also committed to hiring more staff and providing meals and care packs for vulnerable individuals. Shee considers the pandemic a crisis like no other, requiring more than just financial instruments to address. He stresses the need for authenticity, integrity, and a commitment to "doing the right thing" in leadership.

site_title: Disney holder warns streaming gains too meager to offset parks
summary: Disney's streaming service is not generating sufficient revenue to offset the losses in its theme park division due to the COVID-19 crisis. Investment adviser Nick Licouris warns that Disney is "in a tough situation" with a significant portion of its revenue locked down in hotels, cruises, and theme parks. Despite the launch of Disney+, the company's stock has dropped 18% year-to-date, and Cowen has cut its investment rating to "market perform" due to the prolonged impact of the pandemic on its park and film businesses.

site_title: Where are the jobs?
summary: Singapore is experiencing a recession, with the GDP falling 12.6% year-on-year in the second quarter. The labour market has also been severely impacted, with over 187,000 workers on no-pay leave or reduced hours, and thousands of retrenchments announced by companies such as Rolls-Royce and Resorts World Singapore. However, the government has launched initiatives to support job seekers, including wage subsidies and job fairs. Despite the challenges, some employers, such as DBS and OCBC, have pledged to hire over 2,000 and 3,000 people respectively, with a focus on tech roles. Hiring activity is expected to recover gradually, with 66% of employers anticipating a return to pre-pandemic levels within the next 12 months.

site_title: Dos and don'ts on social media
summary: Social media users are advised to exercise prudence when airing their views online, as it can lead to unintended consequences such as loss of job or identity theft. Experts recommend following community guidelines and rules, avoiding falsehoods, doxxing, and attacks, and disengaging immediately if discussions escalate. Anonymity online can lead to uninhibited expression, but also increases the risk of backlash. It's essential to consider the potential impact of online posts and to prioritize digital etiquette to avoid damaging one's reputation and digital identity.

images.alt_text: Lashing out online can sometimes lead to backlash and cause unintended consequences, such as loss of a job, or identity theft.

site_title: Raffles Education to raise stake in Chinese property firm for 254m yuan
summary: Raffles Education Corporation is set to acquire a 35.9% stake in Langfang Hezhong Real Estate Development Co for 254 million yuan (S$49.2 million) in cash. The acquisition aims to rationalize land use rights for education facilities, with the company expecting a shorter development time frame compared to mixed residential and commercial usage. The deal, valued at 290.2 million yuan, is conditional on shareholders' approval and completion within 14 days from July 16.

site_title: Indians pawning gold lifts lender's stock in reeling economy
summary: Muthoot Finance, India's largest cash-for-gold lender, has seen its shares surge 46% this year, outperforming peers. The lender's success is due to a surge in gold pawning by Indian households, who are using gold as collateral to tide over a cash crunch amid the pandemic. Analysts recommend buying or holding the stock, citing its credit quality, low leverage ratio, and unique business model. The market for gold loans is expected to expand by 33% to $85.16 billion by 2022, with Muthoot forecasting 15% growth in lending against gold.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng warns of H1 2020 net loss due to Covid-19 and lower consumer spending
summary: Beverage company Yeo Hiap Seng expects to report a net loss in the first half of 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic and lower consumer spending. The company attributes the decline to softness in consumer spending, disruptions to operations and sales channels, and higher operating costs. Yeo Hiap Seng is in a "robust financial position" to navigate the crisis, but the pandemic will likely cause significant market and business uncertainty in the near term. The company will announce its H1 2020 unaudited financial results by August 15, 2020.

site_title: Redevelopment of Marina Bay floating platform to start in 2022
summary: Singapore's redevelopment of The Float @ Marina Bay floating platform is set to begin in March 2022 and be completed by end-2025. The project, led by Woha Architects, will transform the platform into a permanent space for large-scale national and community events, community sports facilities, and a National Service themed gallery. The redevelopment aims to enhance the site's features and create public spaces for community activities, aligning with Singapore's long-term urban-development plans.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 7.68 points lower to 1,598.75 on Tuesday, with 770 losers outnumbering 304 gainers. Volume reached 8.761 billion lots worth RM8.219 billion.

site_title: Facebook helps Asia's richest man shed dependence on oil
summary: Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries has reduced its dependence on oil, with the company's stock more than doubling since March 2020 due to its expansion into e-commerce and technology. Reliance's digital services business unit, Jio Platforms, has netted almost $16 billion in a fundraising blitz. The company's shares now have a beta of 0.14, meaning a 1% drop in oil prices has a minimal impact on its stock price. Ambani's ambition to create a homegrown version of Alibaba Group has been backed by deals with Facebook and other Silicon Valley players, luring a dozen investors.

site_title: DBS, Contour complete secured LC transaction on blockchain network
summary: DBS Bank and blockchain trade-finance network Contour have completed the first digital end-to-end secured letter of credit (LC) transaction on the network, facilitated by essDOCS. The transaction, between Nanjing Iron & Steel, Singapore Jinteng International, and Hope Downs Marketing Company, demonstrates the network's ability to increase accuracy and transparency in LC issuance. Contour aims to digitalize global trade processes and provide a neutral and open network for financial institutions and corporates to integrate. The transaction is seen as a positive sign for the industry's shift towards digital trade finance.

site_title: Another European capital is joining the anti-Airbnb drive
summary: Budapest, Hungary, is preparing to join other European cities in regulating short-term apartment rentals, such as those on Airbnb, to curb over-tourism and alleviate a housing squeeze. The city's lawmakers have approved legislation allowing municipalities to cap the number of days annually that proprietors can rent out these apartments. The move aims to reduce the proliferation of low-cost airlines and the resulting influx of tourists, which has led to rising property prices and noise, crime, and trash in the city's party district.

site_title: Brave new arrivals see opportunity in New York
summary: Tens of thousands of New Yorkers have left the city since the pandemic, but some have moved in, drawn by the city's resilience. Despite apocalyptic headlines, buyers and renters have snapped up apartments, convinced that New York's problems are temporary. This contrasts with those who fled, and the city's real estate market continues to see increased activity, with Manhattan rents hitting a record high. The influx of new residents suggests a shift in the city's dynamics, as it adapts to the changing landscape of the pandemic era.

site_title: More digital trade, financial options for SMEs as financial players join hands
summary: Financial players AMTD Group and CIMB Bank in Singapore have agreed to collaborate on digital trade and financial options for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The partnership aims to aid SMEs' long-term development and competitiveness through access to a global ecosystem of buyers, sellers, logistics service providers, financing, and digital solution providers. AMTD will join GlobalLinker's SME network, while CIMB will become the preferred financial services partner. Funding Societies has also partnered AMTD to explore digital financial solutions for SMEs in Singapore and South-east Asia.

site_title: Nissan unveils new electric SUV and corporate logo redesign
summary: Nissan Motor Co unveiled its new electric SUV, the Ariya, with a range of up to 610 km, as part of its efforts to revamp its lineup after management turmoil and declining profitability. The Ariya, priced around $64,948, is the first new product under new management since December and features advanced autonomous driving technology. Analysts expect the Ariya to generate buzz, but its sales potential remains uncertain, with Nissan projecting a 17% decline in sales for the coming fiscal year.

images.alt_text: Nissan's Ariya is an electric SUV which comes with ProPilot 2.0, the latest version of Nissan's autonomous driving technology.

site_title: PSP NCMPs to work with WP as 'alternative front'
summary: Two Progress Singapore Party (PSP) candidates, Hazel Poa and Leong Mun Wai, will take up Non-Constituency Member of Parliament (NCMP) seats in Singapore's 14th Parliament. The pair, who came close to winning the West Coast GRC, will work together with the Workers' Party (WP) as a "constructive alternative front" led by WP secretary-general Pritam Singh. PSP chief Tan Cheng Bock expressed optimism for "constructive change" in Singapore, citing reduced fear among voters and a narrower PAP victory.

site_title: HSBC, StanChart urge Hong Kong staff to work at home as virus spikes
summary: HSBC, StanChart, and other banks in Hong Kong are urging staff to work from home due to a spike in coronavirus cases. The city has seen 40 new local cases, bringing the total to 224 over the past week. Staff are encouraged to work remotely if possible, with some banks pausing plans to bring more people back to their offices. The measures come as the city imposes stricter measures to slow the spread, including closing bars, gyms, and beaches, limiting public gatherings, and imposing fines for mask-wearing violations.

site_title: GE2020: PAP's Henry Kwek wins Kebun Baru SMC with 63% of votes
summary: The People's Action Party's Henry Kwek won the Kebun Baru Single Member Constituency (SMC) in Singapore's 2020 General Election with 62.97% of the vote, defeating the Progress Singapore Party's Kumaran Pillai by 35.18% votes. This marks a stronghold for the PAP in the traditionally PAP-held constituency, which was carved out as an SMC for the first time in nearly 30 years.

site_title: Steeper falls likely for Singapore retail rents in H2, dragged by more vacancies: C&W
summary: Singapore retail rents are expected to decline further in the second half of 2020 due to higher vacancies and safe-distancing measures, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Activity-based tenants, such as those in food and beverage, will continue to face challenges with reduced footfalls, leading to a rise in vacancies. Prime retail rents are expected to fall by 10% in Orchard and city areas, while suburban prime rents are forecasted to decrease by 5%.

images.alt_text: Vacancies in the second quarter of 2020 are expected to put pressure on retail rents in Singapore, as more businesses shutter for good in the period, said Cushman & Wakefield in a report on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia sought Hong Kong's help in hunt for 1MDB fugitives
summary: Malaysia's police sought assistance from Hong Kong authorities in their 1MDB probe, including the hunt for Jho Low, the alleged mastermind behind the billion-dollar scandal. Inspector-general of police Abdul Hamid Bador sent letters and information to Hong Kong, but received "negative" responses, stating the information was incorrect. Malaysia has also sought help from Interpol to find Low and bring him to face charges. The people sought by Malaysia are traveling freely, with trips to Cambodia, Thailand, and Hong Kong, and the police suspect a party of protecting Low.

site_title: COE prices end higher as bidding resumes
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices ended higher across the board at the July 8 tender, with premiums increasing modestly. The COE premium for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp rose to S$33,520, while those above 1,600cc or 130bhp ended at S$35,889. The Open COE price also increased to S$34,989. These increases come after a three-month suspension due to circuit breaker measures.

site_title: Local Pride
summary: Local fashion labels recommend comfortable and stylish clothing for voting. Biro Company suggests vintage-inspired T-shirts ($140), Another Sole offers leather sneakers ($125), and Hher Studio recommends a red tent dress ($129). The Prefecture suggests a tailored linen shirt and shorts ($275, $245), and In Good Company offers high-waisted cotton trousers ($189). These picks prioritize comfort and quality for a fuss-free Election Day.

site_title: Britain wants to juice the housing market again
summary: Britain's finance minister, Rishi Sunak, plans to temporarily scrap transaction taxes on homes under £500,000 to boost the housing market. The move aims to stimulate spending and address the UK's housing shortage. However, experts warn that this could create a market distortion and lead to a "hangover" later on. With the UK facing a recession and uncertain economic conditions, some question the timing and responsibility of prodding people to commit to a major financial commitment.

site_title: GE2020: PAP defeats SPP in Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC with 67.26% of votes
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) won the Bishan-Toa Payoh Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's 2020 general election with 67.26% of the vote, securing 62,853 votes. The SPP came in second with 32.74% of the vote, receiving 30,594 votes. This marks the PAP's second consecutive win in the constituency, following their 73.59% victory in 2015.

site_title: New South-east Asian HR tech accelerator eyes post-Covid-19 future of work
summary: A new accelerator, The Workplace Accelerator, has launched in Singapore to support human resources (HR) tech startups in South-east Asia. The 12-week virtual program focuses on talent acquisition, management, productivity, and collaboration. The accelerator provides access to a network of 50 HR leaders and offers cash investment to help startups grow towards their Series A round. Partners include Malaysian Digital Economy Corporation, Vantage Capital Partners, and HR-focused investor Chapman V, aiming to shape the future of work in the region, particularly for the growing millennial and younger population.

site_title: WHO says airborne transmission of coronavirus can occur during medical procedures
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) acknowledged that airborne transmission of the novel coronavirus can occur during medical procedures generating aerosols, such as choir practice or fitness classes. This is based on emerging evidence and reports of outbreaks in crowded indoor spaces. The WHO previously only recognized droplet transmission as a primary method of spread, but the new guidance reflects the possibility of aerosol transmission. This update aims to provide more comprehensive guidance on the virus's spread.

site_title: GE quick takes: Final day of campaigning; Ng Chee Meng says community job fairs rolled out
summary: Singapore will hold its General Election (GE2020) on Friday, with all 93 seats in 31 constituencies up for grabs. The ruling PAP's inability to engage on issues is a major concern for opposition candidate Paul Tambyah. The PAP has rolled out community job fairs to help workers find jobs near them, while the government's productivity and median wage have grown by a third over the last decade. The Workers' Party (WP) chairman, Sylvia Lim, accuses the PAP of presenting voters with a false choice, while the Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam counters that the government will be effective in tackling Covid-19 regardless of the outcome.

site_title: Big Tech's China face-off presages an exodus from Hong Kong
summary: Big Tech companies, including Facebook, Google, and Twitter, are taking a stand against China's new internet policing law in Hong Kong by suspending data requests and considering departure. The move could lead to a loss of financial hub status, sparking an exodus of professionals and businesses. Companies must weigh the value of China and Hong Kong markets against potential reputational damage. The decision has a chilling effect on pro-democracy protesters and raises questions for businesses, with some warning of uncertainty and potential sanctions from the US.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.59 points to 1,591.84. The market saw 657 losers compared to 425 gainers. The rally comes as investors remain optimistic despite US trade uncertainty, while the US stock market edges to fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (July 13)
summary: A podcast discussing the minimum wage policy in Singapore, featuring Vikram Khanna, was released. Additionally, Ken Foong, an equity analyst, shared insights on the Reit space. Market news includes updates on Asia's markets, structured notes, and private equity for regular investors. CEO salaries in Singapore were also discussed, with Tan Teck Long being named OCBC's new CEO.

site_title: Boustead Singapore's H2 net profit rises 11% to S$18.5m
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a 61% year-on-year increase in second-half revenue to S$434.5 million, driven by a 54% rise in full-year revenue to S$726.6 million. However, net profit rose only 11% to S$18.5 million due to gross margin pressure, fair-value losses, and higher expenses. The group's earnings per share increased to 3.8 cents from 3.4 cents in the previous year. Net asset value per share strengthened to 70.3 cents, and a final cash dividend of two cents per share was proposed.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gain as recovery hopes offset Covid-19 worries
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.42% to 2,167.90 on Thursday, driven by economic recovery hopes despite COVID-19 concerns. The US reported a record 60,000 new cases, while global cases exceeded 12 million. South Korea reported 50 new cases, bringing the national tally to 13,293. Foreigners were net sellers, but shares of companies with solid growth expectations rose sharply, contributing to the index's gain. The won held steady against the US dollar.

site_title: Singapore stocks inch up after losing steam; STI rises 0.3% at open
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at the open on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 6.92 points to 2,668.34. DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank all started in the green. Tee International led the gains, up 10% to 3.3 cents, after Tramore Global announced a conditional cash offer. European shares fell on Tuesday, with Tokyo stocks opening lower on Wednesday, while US stocks tumbled on Tuesday.

site_title: Palantir moves toward stock listing with confidential filing
summary: Palantir Technologies Inc has filed confidentially with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for a public stock listing, marking a major step towards a market debut. The company is seeking to go public by autumn, with the possibility of pursuing a traditional initial public offering (IPO) to raise capital. Palantir has already secured $550 million of its $961 million fundraising goal, and a direct listing could allow it to bypass formalities and let current stockholders sell their shares at the opening bell. The company, founded by billionaire Peter Thiel in 2003, has been weighing a direct listing against an IPO amid controversy over its use of data analysis software.

site_title: Oil prices mixed as coronavirus spike casts shadow over US demand
summary: Oil prices are mixed, with Brent crude up 11 cents to $42.91 a barrel and US WTI futures down 30 cents to $40.35 a barrel. The increase in Brent crude is due to tighter supplies, while US WTI futures drop due to concerns about a surge in coronavirus cases potentially curbing oil demand in the US. Opec and allies have pledged to cut production by 9.7 million barrels per day for a third month in July, with US production also falling to an all-time low.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on recovery hopes, despite virus surge
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday, driven by hopes of economic recovery and positive data on US jobs creation and factory activity. The easing of lockdowns and potential COVID-19 vaccine also boosted investor confidence. Shanghai led gains, jumping 3% in the morning, while Hong Kong and Tokyo also rose. However, new infections in the US and other countries raised concerns, with some states considering lockdown measures and Australia sealing off a state from the rest of the country.

site_title: Samsung's earnings surprise shows confusion in tech sector
summary: Samsung Electronics reported second-quarter earnings that beat estimates, but the results are mixed due to a one-time gain related to its display business. Revenue was 7.4% lower than a year earlier, and the company's shares initially rose but later fell as the market digested the news. The earnings highlight the confusion in the tech sector, where bad news is often taken as optimistic due to beating estimates, while seemingly good news may be a sign of weakness.

site_title: Check in but never leave: Taiwan offers fake flights for travel-starved tourists
summary: Taiwan's Songshan Airport began offering "fake flights" to travelers eager to experience air travel despite the coronavirus lockdown. Around 60 people checked in, went through security and immigration, and boarded a flight with no actual destination, to show off airport renovations and coronavirus-prevention measures. The initiative aims to boost passenger numbers, which have plummeted 64% since the pandemic began, while Taiwan has largely closed its borders and advises citizens against overseas travel unless necessary.

site_title: 'The Commitments' and 'Evita' director Parker dies aged 76
summary: Alan Parker, director of films such as 'Bugsy Malone', 'The Commitments', and 'Evita', died at 76. A 10-time Oscar and 10-time Golden Globe winner, Parker explored music, US race relations, and film noir. He began with commercials and BBC films before achieving success with 'Bugsy Malone' and 'Midnight Express'.
