Parker's career included 'Fame', 'Pink Floyd - The Wall', and 'Mississippi Burning', which won one Oscar despite controversy. His final major success was 'Evita', starring Madonna, and he collaborated with Oliver Stone on many works.

site_title: China opens new Hong Kong security agency headquarters
summary: China has opened a new security agency headquarters in Hong Kong, marking the force's first open operation under a new security law. The Metropark Hotel, which overlooks Victoria Park, has been transformed into the agency's headquarters. The law, imposed last week, gives China jurisdiction over serious national security cases and allows its security apparatus to work openly in Hong Kong. The move marks a significant shift in Hong Kong's freedoms and autonomy since its handover from Britain in 1997. The agency's presence is seen as a major development in the city's changing security landscape.

images.alt_text: China on Wednesday opened a new office for its security agents to operate openly in Hong Kong for the first time under a tough new law, transforming a hotel into the force's headquarters.

site_title: Banks in Singapore band together to lift standards for commodity financing
summary: Singaporean banks have formed a working group to develop industry standards for commodity financing, with the support of government agencies. The group, comprising 20 banks including HSBC, DBS, and OCBC, aims to improve transparency and lending standards in the sector. The move follows a series of defaults by trading firms amid the historic plunge in oil prices, including the collapse of Singapore's oil trading giant Hin Leong Trading. The collaboration is seen as a step forward to boost corporate transparency and governance in the commodities sector.

site_title: Sickly sweet: Drinks makers turn the anti-sugar tide in their favour
summary: Singapore's market for lower-sugar drinks is set to boom, driven by the war on sugar and increasing consumer demand for healthier products. Despite a 12% growth in reduced-sugar products, the average Singaporean still consumes four teaspoons of sugar per day. To comply with stricter rules, manufacturers are reformulating their products, with some seeing sales of healthier drinks increase by over 20% year-on-year. The Ministry of Health has banned advertising beyond the point of sale for pre-packaged drinks containing more than 10g of sugar per 100g, and companies are expected to adjust before the measures come into effect in 2021.

site_title: Oil edges up after sharp US crude inventory drop
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday after a 10.6 million barrel drop in US crude inventories, the largest since December. Brent crude futures settled at $43.75 a barrel, up 1.2%, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled at $41.27 a barrel, up 0.6%. The decline in US crude stocks is attributed to supply cuts agreed by OPEC and its allies in April. However, gains were limited by a record day for coronavirus cases worldwide, with nearly 150,000 US deaths and a surge in cases in the Americas.

site_title: Amcorp Global gets SGX nod for extension to restore free float
summary: Amcorp Global, formerly known as Tee Land, has received a Singapore Exchange (SGX) extension to restore its free float until October 20. The company is working on a private placement, but the COVID-19 pandemic and border restrictions have limited its efforts. Amcorp aims to maintain its listing status after completing the offer and restore the free-float status, which will allow it to lift the trading suspension and keep the counter listed. The company needs at least 10% of shares to be held by 500 public shareholders.

site_title: Indians switch to 'local TikToks' after ban on Chinese apps
summary: Millions of Indians have joined domestic social media platforms since the government banned Chinese apps, including TikTok, amid growing tensions between the two nations. Sharechat and Roposo, homegrown platforms, saw a surge in new users, with Sharechat clocking 15 million new downloads and Roposo gaining 10 million new subscribers. The ban aims to address concerns over data security, privacy, and national security risks posed by Chinese apps. However, retaining new followers will be a challenge for local platforms, which must now invest in staff and content to keep audiences.

site_title: Thailand's main airport offers rapid coronavirus test for international arrivals
summary: Thailand's Suvarnabhumi Airport has introduced rapid coronavirus tests for international arrivals, particularly for business travelers, diplomats, and government guests who are allowed to enter the country for less than 14 days. The tests, costing 3,000 baht, take around one and a half hours and are a requirement for "fast track" entry without quarantine. This comes as Thailand partially lifts its three-month ban on foreign visitors after no recorded community transmission of the virus. The move aims to boost tourism, which is expected to draw around 8 million foreign tourists this year, down 80% from last year.

site_title: IMDA to roll out parcel locker network by end-2021
summary: IMDA plans to roll out a nationwide parcel locker network by end-2022, one year ahead of schedule, to support e-commerce activity during the pandemic. The 1,000 lockers will be located near residential areas, MRT stations, and community centers, aiming to have a Pick station within five minutes' walk for every household. The first 200 stations will be rolled out in Q1 2021, and logistics service providers will have fair and open access to the network, with industry stakeholders to raise awareness and use of the system.

site_title: Temasek to delay annual reporting to September amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state investor, will delay its annual reporting to September due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Executive director and CEO Ho Ching cited the global financial impact of the pandemic as the reason for the delay. Despite the delay, Temasek has been in net cash since 2007/2008 and has worked to build a "resilient portfolio for the long term". The delay will not affect Temasek's financial performance or its commitment to contributing to the Singapore budget through the net investment income framework.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia reports record RM803m loss in Q1
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia Group reported a record Q1 loss of RM803.3 million due to the novel coronavirus pandemic, a collapse in air travel demand, and fuel hedge losses. Revenue fell 15% to RM2.31 billion, with passengers carried dropping 22% to 9.85 million. The carrier aims to increase flight frequencies to 50% of pre-Covid operations and has restructured fuel hedges to reduce costs by at least 30% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: Load factor - a measure of how full planes are - dropped 11 basis points to 77 per cent.

site_title: Cinematic chronicler
summary: Chinese filmmaker Jia Zhangke, known for his arthouse films capturing China's social changes, has been appointed as a delegate to China's top-level national advisory body, the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC). Jia, who has produced and acted in numerous films, including "Still Life" and "Platform," has also conducted field research and presented a proposal to assist the elderly in adapting to digital technology. This marks a new venture for Jia, who has previously focused on film production and advocacy for young directors. His goal is to expand film offerings to match online platforms and promote cultural diversification.

site_title: US: Pandemic can't stop Wall Street rally, shares close higher
summary: US stocks continued their rally on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.8%, the S&P 500 gaining 1.6%, and the Nasdaq reaching a fresh record close of 10,433.65. Despite concerns over the coronavirus pandemic, Wall Street shows resilience, with tech stocks leading the gain. Amazon, Netflix, and Apple all rose, while Uber announced a $2.65 billion acquisition deal, shaking up the sector. The market remains optimistic despite mounting fears of a resurgence in cases.

images.alt_text: Wall Street continued to rally on Monday, with main indices ending higher and the Nasdaq again notching a fresh record even as the coronavirus continues to bedevil the United States.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.88% at the open on Tuesday, following a 6% gain over the previous four sessions. The Hang Seng Index reached 26,571.08, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.44% to 3,380.95. The rally comes as Wall Street surged and traders brush off new US threats, with investors focusing on positive economic data and new funding rounds.

site_title: Auditors should avoid ditching companies midway on audit work
summary: Auditors should not abruptly quit a company midway through an audit, leaving investors in the lurch. A recent example is Mirach Energy, which faced disagreements with its auditors BDO over accounting treatment. The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) rejected BDO's bid to resign, stating it was "premature" and had serious public interest implications. As a result, BDO's duties as auditor will continue until the term ends, allowing Mirach to provide its FY2019 audit conclusion, which is crucial for investors.

images.alt_text: In announcing the proposed amendments, MOF and Acra said the suggested changes to the current legislation "seek to promote audit quality, in order to enhance Singapore's standing as a trusted business location through better assurance of information available to investors and the public".

site_title: Huawei not totally banned from France, says watchdog: report
summary: France's national cybersecurity agency head, Guillaume Poupard, stated that Huawei is not completely banned from France's 5G market but will face limited licenses. French operators using Huawei will only be granted permits lasting 3-8 years. This decision restricts Huawei's access to France's 5G network, despite the company's significant investment in the technology. The US, Britain, and other countries have raised security concerns over Huawei's involvement, citing its founder's background in the Chinese military.

images.alt_text: China's Huawei is not totally banned from France's next-generation 5G wireless market, but French operators using them will only get limited licences, the head of the national cybersecurity agency told Les Echos newspaper on Sunday.

site_title: Gold flat as virus fears offset gains in equities
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Friday, influenced by concerns over the accelerating coronavirus cases and the US economy's positive job report. Despite a positive Chinese services data, physical demand in top consumers China and India continued to wane due to the pandemic. Gold prices are expected to trade in a tight range, supported above $1,750 an ounce, as central banks ease policies and uncertainty surrounding the second wave persists.

images.alt_text: Gold showrooms in India have opened after the government eased a nationwide lockdown, but customers have been put off by higher prices.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI 'neutral' on Singapore O&G, cites risks from skin clinic, falling birth rates
summary: KGI Securities has initiated coverage on Singapore O&G (SOG) with a "neutral" rating and a 12-month target price of 32 cents. The Catalist-listed company's shares fell 1.9% to 25.5 cents due to risks including declining birth rates and a possible impairment from a skin clinic. The research team will reassess its forecasts after SOG releases its financial results for the first half of the year.
